column2: CHICAGO, Nov. 8 (AP) -- The Chicago Bears converted two Green Bay fumbles into touchdowns in the first quarter today and held the Packers on the 1-yard line twice in the last half to score a 28-17 victory.

HERSHEY, Pa., Nov. 8 -- Philip Morini of New York and Robert Johnson of Hasbrouck Heights, N. J., captured the three-day Appalachian National Sports Car Rally today. They drove their 3.4 Jaguar through twenty-eight controls with a total error of only 114 seconds.

MANILA, Monday, Nov. 9 (AP) -- The Government banned Nationalist Chinese today from entering the Philippines. The action came after thirty-one Chinese ordered deported to Nationalist China had failed to leave.

ALBANY, Nov. 2 (UPI) -- A biochemical test for fat tolerance may prove useful in early diagnosis of coronary heart disease, Dr. David F. Brown, associate director of the Cardio-vascular Health Center at Albany Medical College, said today.
Sixty years ago today, a raw northeaster was sweeping the city, but there nevertheless was warm excitement in the air.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 8 -- Today's children in grades four, five and six are not only taller and heavier than those of years gone by but also more sophisticated. "Going steady" and use of lipstick are becoming commonplace in the age group of 9 through 11.

In a letter to the Brooklyn Hebrew Home and Hospital for the Aged, Governor Rockefeller called for more research into the medical problems of the aged. His message was read last night at the annual dinner of the home in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

Because Bach did not specify on which instruments his "Art of the Fugue" should be played, all performances of this, his final work, are of necessity arrangements. Sometimes it is performed by a string quartet and sometimes by a small instrumental ensemble.
Women got a piece of advice, a pat on the back, a chuck under the chin and a slap on the wrist yesterday -- all from Mrs. Caroline K. Simon, Secretary of State for New York.

Prosperity and the complexity of temporary problems have combined to create complacency, the Rev. Dr. Tom Driver said yesterday. He was guest preacher at the Church of St. Paul and St. Andrew (Methodist), West End Avenue and Eighty-sixth Street.
Stanley M. Isaacs, the only Republican on the City Council, said yesterday that juvenile delinquency conditions in the city had been "grossly exaggerated."

The New York District Office of the Immigration Service, which has been edging uptown since before the turn of the century, will move downtown early next month. It will be the fifth move since an office was opened at Castle Garden near the Battery more than 100 years ago.

This week we will be thinking about our veterans, both alive and dead. An appropriate prelude to those thoughts was given us at the United Nations when Secretary General Hammarskjold and Korean Foreign Minister Cho signed an agreement under which the Memorial Cemetery near Pusan in South Korea will be placed at the permanent disposal of the United Nations.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 8 -- Secretary General Dag Hammarskjold accepted today an invitation to visit Laos. He will leave New York Tuesday and will spend up to a week in the Buddhist kingdom.

At least three books about John Dewey and his philosophy of education are planned for publication this month. One is a collection of essays edited by William %V. Brickman and Stanley Lehrer. "John Dewey: ]Iaster Educator." which the Society' for the Advancement of Education is issuing today in hardbound and paper-bound editions.

The Leah and Joseph Rubin Residence Hall, a new seven-story structure made possible through the gift of a 93-year-old Brooklyn philanthropist and business man, was dedicated yesterday afternoon at Yeshiva University, Amsterdam Avenue and 186th Street.

LONDON, Nov. 8 -- The stock market showed signs of settling back to a relaxed and healthy firmness last week. The pressure on equity prices was lightened by substantial profit-taking, and buying was more selective than the exchange has seen since the general election.

The law on perjury, on which attention has been centered by changes of testimony in the television quiz show investigations, makes it a criminal offense to give intentionally false testimony under oath.
A WOMAN as a professional taster of wines? What, never? Well, hardly ever.

HAVANA, Nov. 8 (UPI) -- A pilot employed by the American-owned King ranch, which is in process of seizure by Premier Castro's Government, has been held in custody for six days in connection with the disappearance Oct. 28 of Major Camilo Cienfuegos, army commander in Camaguey, it was learned today.
FAIRFIELD, Conn., Nov. 8 -- A New Jersey hunter who shot a doe in Maine this week-end bagged another deer, this time a buck, with his ear on the Merritt Parkway here at 5 A. M. today.
Horsemen from Canada and Argentina took out some of the sting that had been applied by American riders in the earlier going in the National Horse Show at Madison Square Garten yesterday.

The importance of the Supreme Court decision in the steel case can be measured both by what it settled and by what it hasn't settled. What it didn't settle will plague the nation for a long time to come.
The New York leadership of the American Federation of Labor-Congress of Industrial Organizations has asked Governor Rockefeller to seek a $1.50 an-hour minimum wage in the state.
For thirty years the doors of the Protestant Episcopal Church of the Ascension at Fifth Avenue and Tenth Street have been opened wide day and night, in fair or inclement weather.

The Interstate Commerce Commission is conducting an investigation in Washington of the domestic-transportation role of the growing number of "shipper associations." They are organizations of individual shipper companies that band together and consolidate small shipments into larger lots to gain freight-rate advantages.
The action to be taken by the Board of Estimate on the proposed 1960 capital budget of $658,933.792 was viewed yesterday as a test of Mayor Wagner's control of that body.

BOREL, Haiti, Nov. 7 -- Barelegged Haitian peasants wade at work today in paddies of green rice plants where only three years ago there were increasingly salty deserts specked with cactus and mesquite.
WESTPORT, Conn., Nov. 8 -- An increase in boating in this area has prompted the State Water Resources Commission to seek a state wide policy decision on dredging in the Long Island Sound.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 8 (AP) Senator Wayne Morse said today that every flag should fly at half staff during the eighty days the steel workers were forced back on the job by a court injunction.

MALINES, Belgium, Nov. 4 -- This town, once close to the American description of a distressed area, has been heavily engaged this week in negotiations that illustrate some important forces at work in the European economy. The negotiations are with Standard Motor Company of Britain (maker of the Triumph line) for the establishment of a big auto assembly plant here.
In November, many tax men begin telling their clients to think about harvesting their capital gains and losses for the best tax advantage.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 8 -- Soviet and United States representatives have taken the first steps toward closer cooperation between their two nations in the dissemination of scientific and technical information.

With the annual meeting of the member nation governors of the International Monetary Fund and World Bank at Washington a little more than a month ago and the present foregathering in Tokyo of the "contracting parties" to GATT, the reordered world trade system planned under the leadership of the United States while World War II was still in progress, entered its second decade.
The following dispatch was written by Frederick Nossal, correspondent of The Globe and Mail. Toronto.

LARCHMONT, N. Y., Nov. 8 -- Cornelius (Glit) Shields Jr., winner of the opening regatta of the Larchmont Yacht Club's winter sailing championship season, registered his second straight victory with Dainty today.

The election of Erard A. Matthiessen, Hughston M. McBain and James S. Rockefeller to the board of trustees of the American Museum of Natural History was announced yesterday by Alexander M. White museum president.

The fourth week of the Metropolitan Opera season will open next Monday with "Cavalleria Rusticana" and "Pagliacci." Jussi Bjoerling, in his first Metropolitan appearance since the 1956-57 season, will sing Turiddu in the former week.
LEOPOLDVILLE, Belgian Congo, Nov. 8 (Reuters) -- Congolese troops were rushed to the neighboring feudal kingdom of Ruanda today to check a civil war between two tribes.

The head of B'nai B'rith called on American Jews yesterday to "press vigorously" for action by the Soviet authorities to remove what he termed their restrictions upon Jewish religious and cultural activities.
The new play on which Lillian Hellman has been working for two years, and which she has re-written four times, solely at the urging of her own artistic conscience, is finally ready for production.
TITH the aid of its "little black book," Abraham Straus ca, n be transformed at any given moment into a Tower of Babel.

TEL AVIV, Israel, Nov. 8 -- Premier David Ben-Gurion said tonight he was willing to govern Israel for the next four years with a coalition of Socialists, religious groups and proponents of free enterprise.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Nov. 8 -- Wherever two Yugoslavs gathered today, they talked about electric bills. Even members of Belgrade's diplomatic corps were involved in calculations of kilowatt-hours times the number of rooms they called home.

LOS ANGELES, Nov. 8 -- The Southern California Symphony Association and Hollywood Bowl Association today appointed George A. Kuyper to the newly created position of general director for the two organizations.

SOMEWHERE between Watch Hill and New Bedford, not very far from Newport, lie a town and peninsula called Quahog Point. That is not its real name, only the imaginary one given by Theodore Roscoe to the site of "one of the strangest unsolved murder cases in New England history."
JACK BENNY starred in an hour of mirthful entertainment over Channel 2 on Saturday night.

BIRMINGHAM, Ala., Nov. 8 (UPI) -- Federal mediators met today with company and union representatives in an unsuccessful effort to settle a railroad men's strike that might keep 25,000 steel workers from returning to work after the halting of their own strike.

Louisiana State's nineteen-game winning streak has come to an end, along with North-western's perfect record, and Syracuse stands with Texas and Southern California as football's undefeated triumvirate.

Following on the heels of Britain's action in sweeping away its restrictions on all but a small hard core of imports from both the dollar countries and the non-dollar countries, France announces that it is eliminataing quota restrictions on more than 200 imported products, including such broad categories of goods as textiles, clothing, tools, refrigerating equipment and agricultural machinery.
BONN, Germany, Nov. 8 -- Two entertainment attractions opened in the capital of West Germany this week. They covered an extreme range.

The Soviet Union's celebration of the forty-second anniversary of the Bolshevik Revolution may well have been the most relaxed event of this sort in that country's history. One sign of this was the dominance of such themes as pride in recent space achievements and hope of a better living standard in the huge traditional parade through Red Square last Saturday.
ALBANY, Nov. 8 (UPI) -- Despite the nation-wide steel strike, New York State business actvity held firm during September, the Department of Commerce reported today.

President Eisenhower will recommend to Congress ways to prevent the continuation of the steel strike if there is no settlement during the eighty-day cooling-off period, Secretary of Labor James P. Mitchell said last night.

Justice Samuel H. Hofstadter of the State Supreme Court proposed yesterday that the disposition of defendants who were suspected of being the victims of mental disease be taken from judges and given to a board of judicial, medical and lay representatives.

Good things come in threes, it is said, and three times three meant 9 points for the Giants in their National Football League contest with the Chicago Cardinals at the Yankee Stadium yesterday. Ordinarily, 9 points may get a professional team through one half, but this time three field goals by Pat Summerall carried the New Yorkers to a 9-3 triumph.
SYRACUSE, Nov. 8 (AP) -- A Skye terrior owned by the Iradell Kennels of Ridgefield, Conn., today was named best in the thirty-third annual all-breed show of the Onondaga Kennel Association.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 8 (UPI) -- The National Planning Association issued a report today calling for a United States-Canadian treaty to facilitate and speed the flow of natural gas across the border of the two nations.
DETROIT, Nov. 8 (UPI) -Andy Bathgate scored a goal with less than three minutes left tonight to give to the New York Rangers a 3-3 tie with the Detroit Red Wings in a National Hockey League game.

The boarding-school football season reaches its peak this week-end. Lawrenceville and Andover risk unbeaten records in annual rivalries. Also on the schedule are at least a half-dozen other traditional games. At Lawrenceville, N. J., the Lawrentians will entertain The Hill on Friday as the schools meet for the fifty-eighth time.
Production of gold and diamonds is increasing in the Yakutsk Territory of the Soviet Union, the head of that area's Communist party has revealed.
The Port of New York handled 145,531,300 short tons of waterborne commerce last year.
HOT SPRINGS, Va., Nov. 8 -- An average increase of 10 per cent in advertising budgets for 1960 has been forecast by a large group of Rational companies.

With several exceptions, price behavior in the present recovery has paralleled that in the 1954-57 expansion, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York says in its Monthly Review published today. But it is still too early to say what effect the steel strike will have on the further course of prices.

Senator Jacob K. Javits eliminated himself yesterday as a possible fusion candidate for Mayor in 1961. A Republican, Mr. Javits has been mentioned prominently among possible choices to head a fusion drive to end the Democratic rule at City Hall.

WHEN Fairfield Osborn was only 10 years old, he was envied by most of his classmates. Whenever school was a little dull, he would slip a hand inside his jacket, where, from a special felt pocket, peered a bright-eyed squirrel. By that time the boy had had three years of

ARGUING against the selection of Ernie Banks of the Cubs as the most valuable player in the National League is not easy. Furthermore, it's completely unprofitable because the ballots are in and nothing can be done about it. The special committee of twenty-four from the Baseball Writers Association did the voting and the support of the Cub shortstop certainly was solid enough.
RIO DE JANEIRO, Nov. 8 -- Janio Quadros, an independent reformer with mass appeal, won the Presidential nomination today of Brazil's major Opposition party, the National Democratic Union.

There is something charmingly old-fashioned about New Zealand socialism. This is an antipodean Scandinavia. It is the kind of Society the English Fabians might have dreamed of at this century's turn. When Salvation Army bands assemble here to tootle on street corners, one is hauntingly reminded of George Bernard Shaw and political dialogues, once daring, that have become dull reality.

THE family who waits until after Thanksgiving to order furniture for Christmas may discover that there is no Santa Claus. A period of waiting is usually required between the time of purchase and the time of furniture delivery.

The Child Study Association of America will benefit from the Nov. 19 performance of "Cheri" at the Morosco Theatre. Tickets may be obtained at association headquarters, 132 East Seventy-fourth Street.

PANAMA, Nov. 8 -- An attempt will be made early tomorrow to re-establish United States sanitary inspection in Panama of foodstuffs processed there so that Canal Zone agencies can resume purchases for consumption by civilians and members of the armed services.
NEW ORLEANS, Nov. 8. (AP) -- A musicians' contract squabble caused a last-minute cancellation today of an opera performance.

The Rev. Dr. Karl Reiland, one of New York's leading liberal preachers more than a quarter of a century ago, returned yesterday to St. George's Protestant Episcopal Church, his old pulpit on Stuyvesant Square.

CHICAGO, Nov. 8 (UPI) -- Maj. Gen. Marshall Stubbs, chief Army Chemical officer, urged the medical profession today to prepare for defense against chemical and biological, as well as nuclear, weapons.

LAST December Mr. and Mrs. Peter Leavy spent their three-day honeymoon "house hunting" in snowy dockyards from New Jersey to Connecticut. The couple had agreed before the wedding to spend at leasti seven months of tile year living on the water.

AMSTERDAM, The Netherlands, Nov. 8 -- After a long period of lacking interest, Amsterdam Stock Exchange last week suddenly displayed very great activity for a small number of U. S. and Canadian stocks. In particular Studebaker Packard, American Motors and Inland Natural Gas were active.
ROCHESTER, N. Y., Nov. 8 (UPI) -- The Monroe County Board of Elections has been asked to investigate some registration rolls used in the Nov. 3 elections here.
Senator Stuart Symington declared yesterday while the United States must continue to press for a disarmament agreement with the Soviet Union, the Government must maintain its defenses.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Nov. 8 -- Hollywood tedium, an affliction to which New Yorkers are particularly susceptible, has driven Judy Holliday to song writing.

Once again, resolutions on the racial policy of the Union of South Africa are moving toward final action in the General Assembly of the United Nations. The Trusteeship Committee has passed two drafts, either of which would eventually bring South African control of the territory of South-West Africa under U. N. supervision.
President Eisenhower's forthcoming tour, especially in Asia areas, will focus wide attention on a special kind of economic aid being given by the United States to India.
President Sekou Toure of Guinea said yesterday he had been surprised by the good race relations he found in the United States during the two-week visit he is just concluding.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 8 -- The Soviet Union has asked the United States to support a proposed resolution under which the General Assembly would call an international scientific conference for the exchange of information on developments concerning outer space.
MOSCOW, Nov. 8 -- Premier Khrushchev declared last night that the frontier area over which India and China are feuding is unpopulated and of no strategic significance.

THOUGH it was almost inactive last season, the N. B. C. Opera Company has not become flabby. Granted a substantial budget and generous air time, it brought to the National Broadcasting Company television network a vivid production of Beethoven's opera, "Fidelio," yesterday afternoon.
Pierre Fournier and Rudolf Firkusny gave a joint recital on Saturday evening at Hunter College.

ST. LOUIS, Nov. 8 (AP) -- Today's American family is the best educated ever, but also the most insecure. It is the most experienced, but the most nervous. It is the most adaptable, the most mobile and the most married, but it is also the least stable.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 8 -- William Langer, North Dakota's insurgent Republican Senator since 1941, died in his sleep today of a heart ailment. He was 73 years old.

Fifteen more black iron and glass subway kiosks will be removed before the end of the year, Hulan E. Jack, Manhattan Borough President, announced yesterday. They will be replaced by the railing type of entrance seen at stations of the IND subway. A program to
Five high school students and a university president disagreed yesterday on the question, "Must Everyone Go to College ?"
CAPETOWN, South Africa, Nov. 8 (Reuters) -- About 500 South Africans met here tonight and condemned Government orders banishing African political leaders to remote regions in the north.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 8 (AP) -- Self-policing programs in the movie and publishing industries against overemphasis on sex and obscenity will be studied by Congress next year.
THE joint appearance by Giulietta Simionato, mezzo - soprano, and Carlo Bergonzi, tenor, at Carnegie Hall last night was a real singers' event, drawing heavily upon the operatic repertory.
Columbia University has concluded an agreement for an exchange of professors with Moscow University, Dr. Grayson Kirk, president of Columbia, announced yesterday.
J. R. Dant, president of the States Steamship Company of San Francisco, was elected last week as vice chairman of the Committee of American Steamship Lines.

LOS ANGELES. Nov. 8 (UPI) Abe Woodson returned a kick-off 105 yards for a touchdown and stood out on defense to pace the San Francisco Forty-Niners to a 24-16 victory over the Los Angeles Rams today before a crowd of 94,376.
HOUSTON, Nov. 8--A gasoline-fed fire and eight thundering explosions destroyed an oil tanker today at a dock in an industrial and petroleum storage center of this city's eastern outskirts.

ROME, Nov. 8 -- The congress of the South Tyrolean People's Party has approved a motion, moderate in tone but intransigent in substance, demanding autonomy for the prevalently German-speaking province of Bolzano (the German Bozen).

WHITE PLAINS, Nov. 8 -- Five hundred and forty-eight entries were displayed by the Westchester Arts and Crafts Guild at the opening today of its annual exhibition in the County Center. The number of entries, a record for the twentynine-year-old show, placed it among the largest held annually in the United States.

BAKER, Ore., Nov. 8 (AP)--The Republican party is so concerned with keeping things unchanged that it cannot meet the challenges of a new and revolutionary age, Senator John F. Kennedy said here tonight.
WASHINGTON Nov. 8 (UPI) -- Japan has checked a potential population explosion with voluntary birth control, a population expert said today.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 8--Canada has added her voice to the growing chorus of nations demanding to be heard--and to hear more--in the councils of the Western alliance.

SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 8 (UPI) -- Customs agency officials disclosed today that M/Sgt. Forrest Barrett of Mackinaw, Mich., had been fined $1,000 and reduced in rank by a court martial on smuggling charges.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 8 -- Secretary of Labor James P. Mitchell said today that he would keep his promise to eat his hat if the country's unemployment figures for October fail to go below 3,000,000 persons.
Arimae Burrell, contralto, gave a recital at Town Hall yesterday afternoon.
The wedding of mutual funds and the insurance industry is much closer than most people realize.
LONDON, Nov. 8 -- A British official criticized today what he termed the reluctance of trade unions to prosecute officers or members who misused union funds.

For the past several years there has been increasing public pressure for big business and big unions to consider the "social interest" in their economic decisions. This has led to more and more interference by the Government in the operations of big business and big unions.
NEW DELHI, India, Nov. 8 -- India has formally warned Communist China that her people would resist aggression "by all means available to them."
SAN MARCO D'URRI, Italy, Nov. 8 (AP) -- For centuries this remote mountain village has known only poverty. Today its inhabitants -- all 284 of them -became stockholders in the world's largest bank.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 8 -- One of the most respected students of the Supreme Court has charged the present court with professional inadequacies so serious as to jeopardize its standing with the bar.

REDWOOD CITY, Calif., Nov. 8 (AP) -- The body of a Stanford graduate student, Thomas E. Rogan, 26 years old, holder of one of the country's top scholarships, was found Friday in Huddart Park amid a number of suicide notes.
The opening of the sixth season of the Brooklyn Philharmonia Saturday night at the Brooklyn Academy was an auspicious occasion.
VANDENBERG AIR FORCE BASE, Calif., Nov. 8 (AP) -- The Air Force said today that the instrument capsule aboard its Discoverer VII satellite had failed to separate as scheduled.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 7 -The injunction in the steel strike is not the signal for the boom to resume.

Recent disclosures in The Times indicate that while much has been done for the care of the aged, much remains to be done. This is true of employers and employment agencies, who spurn the experience and sagacity of men 65 or more in favor of unknowing youth, despite a state law which forbids discrimination on grounds of age.
GARDEN CITY, L. I., Nov. 8 -- Two labor groups on Long Island merged today to form the third-largest labor group in the state.

MEXICO CITY, Nov. 8 -- Albert Freedman, who was indicted in New York City for perjury in denying that the television program "Twenty-one" was rigged, said tonight that quiz shows "were a breath of fresh air" compared with the murder and violence that "saturated" television.
The writer of the following letter is the author of "Strategy of Economic Development." He is Professor of International Economic Relations at Columbia University.

Trans World Airlines announced yesterday it favored a plan being weighed by the Post Office Department to move more first-class mail by air. But it said it regarded rates proposed by the Civil Aeronautics Board as "unrealistic."
The New York Philharmonic managed to cook up an all-Russian program yesterday afternoon at Carnegie Hall for the visit of the touring Soviet composers.
CAIRO, Nov. 8 -- The United Arab Republic and the Sudan signed an agreement today on the division of Nile waters.
LOS ANGELES, Nov. 8 -- Mayor Wagner said today that the United Nations should press for a solution to Middle East problems.
Three-hundred and sixty ruddy-cheeked and frost-nipped bird watchers, followed by a hungry flock of knowledgeable gulls, put to sea here yesterday.
MINNEAPOLIS, Nov. 8 (AP) -- Elgin Baylor scored 64 points tonight, a National Basketball Association record, and led the Minneapolis Lakers to a 136-115 victory over the Boston Celtics.

With the most dangerous traffic accident period of the year just ahead, the Columbia University report that holds that improved cars and roads are the immediate key to cutting traffic deaths and injuries takes on added significance.
GLEN COVE, L. I., Nov. 9--Parents took over the five elementary schools here today and probably learned more than the pupils they were teaching.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 9 -- The Soviet Union warned today that France's plan to explode a nuclear bomb in the Sahara could jeopardize the present improvement in East-West relations.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 9 (AP) -- The steel strike's drain on the financial resources of some families was reflected by substantial increases in aid to the needy in August and September. This was revealed today by Arthur S. Flemming, Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare.

WHEN Prime Minister Jawaharial Nehru and his Cabinet met in emergency session two nights ago on the explosive Chinese-Indian border dispute, they probably chose to hold their session in the home of Govind Ballabh Pant without giving the matter a second thought.
BISMARCK, N. D., Nov. 9 (AP) -- A Federal District Court today convicted Universal Securities, Inc., of Bismarck and all seven individual defendants of securities fraud.

MANILA, Nov. 9 -- An almost visible tension arose here today on the eve of nation-wide state and local elections. The campaign has taken sixty-one lives and resulted in 171 injuries so far, according to police reports.

NORTH HILLS, L. I., Nov. 9 -- Tommy Strafaci, Dyker Beach, and Pat Stanley, Island Hills, scored 34, 32 -- 66, six strokes under par, to win the Long Island Professional Golfers Association pro-pro championship at the Links Club today.

Alan P. Kirby, chairman and president of the Alleghany Corporation, is an infrequent visitor to Manhattan. This week, however, he expects to make at least two trips to town from Morristown, N. J., where he maintains both his home and office.
MINNEAPOLIS, Nov. 9 (AP) -- A bus drivers' strike today left the Minneapolis-St. Paul metropolitan area of 1,000,000 without public transportation for the first time in twenty-five years.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 9 (AP) -- An improvement of 109,000 bales during October has raised the Government's estimate of this year's cotton crop to 14,801,000 bales of 500-pound gross weight.

Whatever the cause or causes of the defeat of the amendment proposing a $500,000,000 bond issue to assist the construction of New York schools, the fact remains that schools must be built if we are to give our children in New York a decent education.

The Rubber Manufacturers Association and ten of its members, including three of the country's largest manufacturers and distributors of rubber products, were fined a total of $177,500 here yesterday for violating the Sherman Antitrust Act.

Maintenance crews were busy yesterday chopping out plugs to unseal the steel industry's blacked-out blast furnaces. Other workers were swiftly heating and tapping steelmaking furnaces. But the vital question of the extent of damages to these and other facilities during the long strike was still largely unanswered.

NEW DELHI, India, Nov. 9 -- Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru was reported today to have said that the Chinese Communist proposal for a mutual withdrawal of troops in disputed border areas might be more advantageous to Communist China than to India.
ST. LOUIS, Nov. 9 -- Fear was expressed here today that Federal contract grants to colleges and universities were being too heavily weighted on the side of business and national defense.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 9 -- The Interstate Commerce Commission agreed today to examine as speedily as "legally feasible" a Georgia proposal to keep Seatrain Lines, Inc., operating between Savannah, Ga., and Edgewater, N. J.
City auditors charged yesterday that the developers of two slum clearance projects had used rents collected from slum tenants contrary to their agreements with the city.

Mrs. Rose V. Russell, legislative representative of the Teachers Union, said yesterday that the proposals of Charles H. Silver, president of the Board of Education, to raise the teachers' pay, could serve as the first step in the revision of school salary schedules.

Not since the early days of sound films, when fortunes rose or fell on the spoken word, has so much hubbub surrounded a single line in a movie as that added to "Happy Anniversary." The picture will have its world premises at the Victoria Theatre tonight.
The financial transactions of Lowell M. Birrell, the fugitive financier, continued yesterday to beset the operations of companies he once controlled.

Although unable to place any of its riders better than fourth in the Royal Winter Fair international jumping class at the National Horse Show yesterday afternoon, the United States clinched the team championship.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 9 -- The Army is seeking the reversal of a policy recommendation by the National Security Council that the United States should not use chemical, bacteriological or radiological weapons in war except in retaliation.

The United States is jeopardizing both its own position of influence and the prestige of the United Nations in the prolonged American campaign of opposition to Poland's election to the U. N. Security Council.
LONDON, Nov. 9 -- Britain plans to renew her drive for a broad European free-trade area once the seven-nation zone is definitely established.

The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange moved irregularly yesterday. Prices at the close were 7 points higher to 21 points lower than on last Friday. A point is equal to 5 cents a bale.
Defense counsel in the Apalachin trial in Federal court yesterday won a hearing on the legality of the New York State Police raid on the controversial meeting.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 9 -- Following is the text of a speech today in the Political Committee by Henry Cabot Lodge of the United States on the proposed French nuclear tests in the Sahara:
YOLA, Northern Nigeria, Nov. 9 -- The Northern Cameroons has voted in favor of a continuation of British trusteeship, according to conclusive results received here today.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 9 (UPI) -- The United Mine Workers and coal operators temporarily have abandoned their efforts to enforce a contract ban on handling of nonunion coal by commercial mines, it was disclosed today.

The Protestant Council of the City of New York began a $100,000 fund-raising drive last night to expand its juvenile delinquency prevention services. The campaign was opened at a $50-a-plate dinner in the Astor Hotel.
LOS ANGELES, Nov. 9 -- Senator Stuart Symington charged today that the Administration had "wasted the taxpayer's dollar'' in areas of defense, foreign aid, agriculture and debt management.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 9 -- The Soviet Union complained to Secretary General Dag Hammarskjold today about his decision to go to Laos to look into the troubled situation there.

A recent letter-writer takes the view that quiz shows are a form of entertainment; that we should expect "hocus pocus and illusion" in entertainment, and that, consequently, the fixing of these shows is nothing to get excited about. This approach leads to some sinister results.
Two of the nation's biggest rail carriers of farm products are considering a merger. They are the Chicago, Milwaukee, St. Paul and Pacific and the Chicago, Rock Island and Pacific Railroads.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 9 (AP) -- Hearings are planned in early December on a bill providing for a concerted effort to conserve the nation's natural resources.
Arthritis sufferers were reported yesterday to be spending $250,000,000 a year on quack treatments and devices.

ROME, Nov. 9 -- By the express desire of Pope John XXIII the Catholic University of Fu Jen, which formerly had its seat in Peiping, is to reopen on Taiwan. The Most Rev. Paul Yu Pin, Archbishop of Nanking, has been named its rector.

TAIPEI, Taiwan, Nov. 9 (AP) -- President Chiang Kai-shek's Government today called a Philippine ban on Chinese immigrants regrettable and appealed to Manila to talk over the dispute involving thirty-one Chinese ordered out of the Philippines.

LONG BEACH, Calif., Nov. 9 (AP) -- "Glib talk" about getting the Government out of agriculture or any other segment of the economy was decried today by Herschel D. Newsom, grand master of the National Grange.
Stocks ran into the long-expected and well-publicized "endof-steel-strike" rally yesterday. It lasted about thirty minutes.

Indian Prime Minister Nehru's coolness toward the Red Chinese proposal of a withdrawal and demilitarized zone on the Indian frontier is quite understandable. As Mr. Nehru was quick to point out, the plan outlined by Communist Premier Chou En-lai would react to the advantage of Red China, not of India. In Ladakh, for example, the Reds propose a withdrawal of about twelve miles when they have penetrated more than forty.
Student loan funds and an anniversary cake were almost literally placed at Brig. Gen. Carlos P. Romulo's feet yesterday.

The provisions of world treaties, domestic labor statutes and international law are threatened by an organizing drive planned by United States maritime unions, the American Committee for Flags of Necessity charged yesterday.
Milk dealers and their processing and distributing employes resumed contract negotiations yesterday after the talks had become deadlocked early Sunday morning.
DETROIT, Nov. 9 (AP) -- A freak steel supply situation allowed American Motors to build more cars last week than General Motors, normally the world's biggest auto maker.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 9 (UPI) -- Mrs. Indira Gandhi, president of India's ruling Congress party and daughter of Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru, said today communism would be a danger to India in the future because of the border dispute and internal subversion.
Savings and loan associations in the United States will continue to grow at a rapid rate during the next decade, a study by a group of University of Indiana economists concluded yesterday.
BOSTON, Nov. 9 -- State and Federal mediators will meet tomorrow with the scale committee of the Boston Typographical Union to explore the strike that has closed three Boston newspaper plants.

SINCE two members of the cast have conspicuous talent for acting in the style of sensibility, Alfred de Musset's "No Trifling With Love" has an inviting appearance at the St. Mark's Playhouse, 133 Second Avenue, where it opened last evening.
CAIRO, Nov. 9 (UPI) -- "Life is approaching its end. We searched the entire area for a water source but found none."

Committees have been formed under the general chairmanship of Mrs. Robert S. Salant, for the twenty-first annual White Elephant Party. The fete to be held Feb. 4 in the new Grand Ballroom of the Pierre, will benefit the Child Adoption Service of the State Charities Aid Association.

Undefeated Doug Jones of New York, 169 1/2 pounds, won his eleventh straight fight by gaining a split decision over Juan Pomare of Panama, 172, in the ten-round main event last night at the Academy of Music.

With more than one-third of the 500,000 steel strikers back on the job, long-silent mills began shipping small quantities of finished steel yesterday. The shipments were the first since the Supreme Court halted a 116-day walkout Saturday by upholding an injunction under the Taft-Hartley Act.

Cheering is a rare sound at schoolboy cross-country meets but yesterday Fordham Prep turned out seventy yelling and banner-waving students at the Catholic High Schools championships at Van Cortlandt Park, the Bronx.
MINEOLA, L. I., Nov. 9 -- An increase of .107 cent in the Nassau County tax rate was proposed in the 1960 budget, made public today.
If medical science cannot halt the rapid cell division that typifies cancer, why not break the reproductive cycle by overstimulation ?

WASHINGTON, Nov. 9 -- Counsel for Col. Rudolf Ivanovich Abel told the Supreme Court today that his conviction as a Soviet spy should be reversed because the Government had used unconstitutional methods to get its evidence.
WASHINGTON, Nov. -- The Air Force ordered development today of a manned space glider that would be able to soar around the world at speeds of more than 15,000 miles an hour.

An audience of almost 3,000, including a ferryboat load of Manhattanites, crowded into Staten Island's St. George Theatre last night for the opening of the Richmond Opera's second season. The opera was "Il Trovatore" and it starred the island's most famous soprano, Eileen Farrell.
President Sekou Toure of Guinea completed a two-week visit to the United States yesterday with a long conference with the United Nations representative of his country's close ally, Ghana.

Each gloomy installment on the future of New York City as related to its environs in the threeyear study of the metropolitan area for the Regional Plan Association poses the challenge whether local government will have the strength and wisdom to reverse the course of events. The city is changing. A migration of people, business and industry to the suburbs is seen in past, present and future.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 9 -- The courts of the United States can extinguish or save the lives of citizens condemned to death, adjudge between claims to private property or take it away under the law of eminent domain -- all in what they deem to be the general public interest.
BONN, Germany, Nov. 9 -- West Germany protested to France tonight against the action of the French Navy in stopping the freighter Bilbao in the English Channel last Wednesday.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 9 -President Eisenhower will fly to Los Angeles on Jan. 27 to address a fund-raising dinner promoted by the Republican National Committee, the White House said today.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 9 -- In the Supreme Court of the United States Robert Jay Burton, Julian T. Abeles, and Anne E. Meyer, all of New York, N. Y., among others, were admitted to practice today and the following proceedings were had:

The young physician from India who removed the leg of Martyn Green, the British actor who was caught early Saturday in a garage elevator, resigned yesterday from his interneship at Knickerbocker Hospital.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 9 (UPI) -- American officials report that the long-discussed New Yorkto-Moscow commercial air service is being delayed by Soviet refusal to negotiate a civil air agreement.
WESTBURY, L. I., NOV. 9 -Silver Song heads a field of nine in the $27,688.51 United States Harness Writers Trot at Roosevelt Raceway tomorrow night.
CHICAGO, Nov. 9 -- The president of the American Petroleum Institute today attacked proposals that he said would lead to Federal controls on the use of fuels.

HOLLYWOOD, Nov. 9 (AP) -- The Bob Crosbys said today that they had a fight Saturday night in which Mrs. Crosby stabbed the band leader in the shoulder with a letter opener. However, they told different versions.

The prize bowl catch, with its unmatched offensive and defensive record, Syracuse, goes against Colgate as a heavy favorite this week. Texas and Southern California, its rivals for national intercollegiate football dominion and the nation's two other unbeate nteams, undertake more arduous assignments.
Favorite players among Aqueduct's crowd of 24,507 yesterday took a beating until the featured seventh race. Then Mrs. Ethel D. Jacob's 5-year-old Promised Land made good at even money.
HONG KONG, Nov. 9 -- Premier Chou En-lai of Communist China proposed today a mutual withdrawal by Indian and Chinese troops in the two countries border zone.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 9 -- Following is the text of letter, in unofficial translation, sent today by Arkady A. Sobolev, chief Soviet delegate, to Dag Hammarskjold concerning the Secretary General's forthcoming visit to Laos:
WASHINGTON, Nov. 9 (AP) -- Maj. Gen. John C. Munn was named today Assistant Commandant of the Marine Corps, effective Jan. 1. Maj. Gen. Wallace M. Greene Jr. will take over as Chief of Staff.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 9 -- The world's seventh largest church, the National Shrine of the Immaculate Conception, will be dedicated here Nov. 20.

Henry Fonda will serve as host of "The Fabulous Fifties," a special program to be produced by Leland Hayward and televised on Jan. 31 from 8 to 9:30 P. M. over the Columbia Broadcasting System network.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 9 -- The Government's shortest - term borrowing costs declined today for the third time in the four weeks since they hit a record high.

Syracuse, a survivor of the upset wave that cost Louisana State and Northwestern their perfect records, yesterday replaced L. S. U. as the No. 1 team in United Press International's major college football ratings.

FORMER President Truman and Gevernor Rockefeller want the United States to start nuclear testing again. Other Americans do not. President Eisenhower is planning to make a nine-nation tour that includes an extraordinary passage to India. Other Americans are questioning and pondering that. In short, the stages are being set again for new cycles of great debates in our foreign and domestic policies' perpetual theatre in the round.
The police arrested thirty-nine persons in gambling raids in Harlem yesterday.
ANNAPOLIS, Md., Nov. 9 (AP) -- Major-college football in Baltimore may have suffered a death blow with Saturday night's slim turnout for the Navy-Maryland game.
A study center where Protestant, Roman Catholic and Jewish scholars might engage in "dialogue" on theological questions was proposed yesterday by Dr. Jaroslav Pelikan.

BUENOS AIRES, Nov. 9 -The police of the semi-tropical northwestern Province of Tucuman say they have nipped in the bud a nationalist-Peronist guerrilla movement presumably fashioned on the one that brought Fidel Castro to power in Cuba.
TOKYO, Nov. 9 -- Japan is "playing a very dangerous game" in her business relations with the United States, a high American foreign trade official warned today.

MOUNT HERMON, Mass., Nov. 9 -- In Chinese, the words buy nothing, sell nothing, mean stock exchange and there are lots of pheasants in China. That is not the case here along the Connecticut River right now, though the buy nothing, sell nothing may be holding up all right in New York.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 9 -- The United States denounced today a Cuban campaign of "inaccurate, malicious and misleading reports" on the alleged bombing of Havana Oct. 21. The State Department assailed an "offensive brochure" that it said contained unfounded charges against the United States.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 9 -- Federal and state authorities are concerned by the long-term downward trend in the solvency of reserves for the unemployment compensation program.
Abe Stark, President of the City Council, called on the Federal Government yesterday to assist in establishing new services for the migrants who are "America's own displaced persons."
WASHINGTON, Nov. 9 (AP) -- The National Inventors Council today published a list of 300 scientific puzzles civilian inventors are invited to tackle.

BALTIMORE, Nov. 9 -- This city is the last stronghold of duckpin bowling in the nation. But today a few brave men began the move to ten-pin competition here. Six months from now they hope to have the city bowling ten pins and enjoying it.

EAST HADDAM, Conn., Nov. 9 -- A white gem of Victorian art, the Goodspeed Opera House, is to be restored as a symbol of American culture worth preserving. It has stood on the bank of the Connecticut River here since 1876.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 9 (AP) -- The Soviet Union plans to become the world's largest producer of sheep.
LONDON, Nov. 9 -- The British Safety Council has had to withdraw for "translation" a new set of driving rules because it forgot that Britons drive on the left side of the road.
CHICAGO, Nov. 9 AP -- The report of today's livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:
Music just rolls off the fingertips of Marisa Regules.

Net income of the International Nickel Company of Canada, Ltd., in the first nine months of this year was $58,222,000, equal to $3.29 a common share. In the 1958 period, the company cleared $30,321,000, or $2.07 a share.

PEIPING, Nov. 9 -- The deputy director of Communist China's Foreign Trade Department said today that Western nations following the United States' policy of imposing trade embargoes would lose China as a market forever.
CAPETOWN, South Africa, Nov. 9 (AP) -- Rioting mobs of Africans attacked Europeans last night with long knives, clubs and stones in the streets of Paarl, thirty-five miles northeast of here.

The Alabama Highway Authority is planning the sale of $10,000,000 of highway revenue obligations on Nov. 24. The issue will be dated Jan. 1, 1960, and will come due serially on Jan. 1 from 1961 to 1980.

In Arthur Krock's Nov. 3 column under the title "'The Bloody Shirt' and Its Modern Substitute," it is charged that a speech delivered by me in Madison, Wis., on Nov. 2 is "the latest indication that militantly 'liberal' Northern Democrats intend to step up the usual North-South battle at their 1960 party convention."

WASHINGTON, Nov. 9 (AP) -- Carter Products, Inc., maker of Carter's Little Liver Pills, today was denied a Supreme Court review of an order barring all advertising in which the word "liver" appears in the trade name of the product.
TOKYO, Nov. 3 -- Cotton fabrics from the Soviet Union and East European countries have begun flowing into Thailand in large quantities, the Japanese Embassy in Bangkok reports.
Veterans Day will be marked in New York City again tomorrow.
The machine age and an apparent human facility for remembering numbers better than names has brought a change in taxicab drivers' licenses here.
Following is the text of Governor Rockefeller's address last night before the Economic Club of New York:
ROME, Nov. 9 -- The Italian Government has notified the Soviet Government that it does not want Premier Khrushchev to return the visit President Giovanni Gronchi is to make to Moscow.

WHEN women's groups are faced with the problem of raising funds for some worthwhile cause, one of the most frequent decisions is to publish a cookbook. At least that would seem to be the case, judging from the number of such volumes that appear each year.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 9 (UPI) -- A school in Alabama and one in Texas are the last holdouts of segregation among institutions attended exclusively by children of military personnel.

HAVANA, Nov. 9 - The Cuban Ministry of State has issued a pamphlet in English and Spanish accusing the United States of permitting planes to leave its territory to "bombard Havana, killing two and wounding forty-five."

USUMBURA, Ruanda-Urundi, Nov. 9 (Reuters) -- Troops from the neighboring Belgian Congo hacked at roadblocks tonight as they moved into this mountainous African territory in a bid to avert a threatened civil war between more than 2,000,000 tribesmen.

ST. LOUIS, Nov. 9 (AP) -- The Eighth Circuit Court of Appeals upheld today a district court ruling denying a new trial for T. Lamar Caudle and Matthew J. Connelly, Truman administration officials convicted of conspiracy in a tax-fixing case.
WITH its production this week of Ivan Turgenev's "A Month in the Country," WNTA-TV (Channel 13) is maintaining an enviable record for quality in a dramatic series.

CHICAGO, Nov. 9 (UPI) -- Heartley (Hunk) Anderson, a former head coach of Notre Dame and former line coach of the Chicago Bears, said today he had been offered the job as coach and general manager of the New York team in the newly organized American Football League.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 9 (AP) -- A group of Negro train porters who said they also acted as brakemen today were denied a Supreme Court review of a suit against the United States for extra pay.

Governor Rockefeller suggested yesterday that a citizens' committee be set up to help settlement houses raise funds. Almost before he stopped speaking, $55,000 had been given by anonymous donors without the benefit of such a committee.

WASHINGTON, Nov 9 (AP) -- Venereal disease appears to be on the increase again throughout the nation, with "shocking" rises among youths 15 to 19 years old, a Public Health Service official reported today.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 9 -Walter P. Reuther said today the labor movement was flabby.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Nov. 9 -- Universal Pictures will withdraw from the Association of Motion Picture Producers. The company gave the association the required six months' notice of withdrawal.
SHEFFIELD, Ala., Nov. 9 -It may be only chicken feed but it has brought a new industry and new prosperity to a once-impoverished region.

ELIZABETH, N. J., Nov. 9 -The week-long strike of 3,100 workers at the Singer Manufacturing Company ended today when the union members ratified a new one-year contract and reported back to work at noon.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 9 -- The Supreme Court took the following actions today:

CHICAGO, Nov. 9 (AP) -Nearly all soybean futures climbed to new highs for the season again today but finished with only small fractional gains. The grains were mixed, oats and wheat advanced while corn and rye declined.
CLEVELAND, Nov. 9 (AP) -At ports up and down the Great Lakes today the iron ore fleet made ready for a mighty race against winter.
HOT SPRINGS, Va., Nov. 9 -- Donald S. Frost, vice president of the Bristol-Myers Company, has been elected chairman of the Association of National Advertisers.
NEW HAVEN, Nov. 9 -- Prof. Kingman Brewster Jr. of the Harvard Law School has been elected Provost of Yale University.
CHICAGO, Nov. 9 -- William H. Rentschler, 34 - year - old candy executive, announced today his candidacy for the United States Senate seat held by Paul H. Douglas, Democrat, since 1948.
LAUREL, Md., Nov. 9 -- The obstinacy of John C. Schapiro and Joe Cascarella is paying off in goodwill, prestige and affluence for the Laurel Race Course.
Mayor Wagner asked Chief City Magistrate John M. Murtagh yesterday for a "full report" on a magistrate's handling of a case in a Brooklyn court last week.

DENVER, Nov. 9 -- The Colorado Supreme Court ruled unanimously today that "systematic exclusion" from jury service of persons with Spanishsounding names was ground for reversal of a criminal conviction.
KATMANDU, Nepal, Nov. 9 -- The thirty-two-man, Japanese-led expedition reported lost on the 23,440-foot Gauri Sankar peak west of Mount Everest is safe and unharmed and is returning to Katmandu.
TORONTO, Nov. 9 -- Veterans of the Korean War have moved ahead of World War II veterans among purchasers of homes financed with G.I. mortgages, it was reported here today.
Questions raised by the resumption of steel production by major producers tended to depress prices of prime debt securities all along the line yesterday.

PUBLIC school parents in New York City will be kept hopping this week, making the rounds of their children's classrooms, talking to teachers and hearing first hand about their youngsters' reactions to the academic life.

Coach Ben Schwartzwalder of Syracuse said his team, currently ranked No. 1 in the United Press International poll, had exceeded his expectations. "Somehow this group has worked and hit harder," he told those at the football writers weekly luncheon yesterday at the Hotel Manhattan.
A new boxing organization has been formed to promote major fights in New York. Joseph Tepper, a former official of the New York State Athletic Commission, will head the six-man group.

HONG KONG, Nov. 9 (Reuters) -- Following, as distributed the Hsinhua (New China) News Agency, is the text of a letter from Premier Chou En-lai to Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru on the Indian-Chinese border dispute:
The playwriting team of Russel Crouse and Howard Lindsay was honored last night by the Society of Silurians.
SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 9 (UPI) -- Horace Stoneham, president of the San Francisco Giants, indicated today that he would fight any attempt by the Continental League to bring a franchise here.
CLEVELAND, Nov. 9 (AP) -- The German freighter Lucinda arrived here yesterday after going through heavy North Atlantic storms and unloaded a cargo of heavily damaged automobiles.
Four hundred construction workers were served champagne and caviar yesterday thirty stories above the street.

CHICAGO, Nov. 9 -- More and more people, tired of watching television, are finding their amusement in the movie theatres, 1,000 exhibitors belonging to the Theatre Owners of America agreed today. They are meeting in annual convention through Thursday in the Sherman Hotel.
HOUSTON, Nov. 9 -- Traffic on a five-mile stretch of the Houston Ship Channel was halted today to prevent gasoline leaking from the tanker Amoco Virginia from touching off new fires and explosions.
Five Soviet composers and a musicologist took a musical tour of Columbia University yesterday.

Herbert M. Stempel, the man who started all the furor about rigged television quiz shows fourteen months ago, said yesterday that he considered the entertainment and educational value of the program he had appeared on to be nil.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 9 (UPI) -- Four Soviet movie stars toured the United States capital today. They are here in connection with a movie exchange program.
The Federal Trade Commission has formed a task force to help crack down on violators of the Robinson-Patman Act.
The Midland-Ross Corporation of Cleveland announced yesterday the acquisition, for $23,000,000 in cash, of the Surface Combustion Corporation of Toledo and Columbus, Ohio.

KICKERS are like golfers. They must keep their heads down and keep their eyes on the ball until after they have completed contact. Not until this ritual is completed are they privileged to see where the shot has gone. Otherwise they foozle the act dreadfully.
ATLANTIC CITY, Nov. 9 -The Mizrachi Women's Organization of America, the major women's religious-Zionist group in the United States, tonight adopted a $1,270,000 budget for the year.
EAST LONDON, South Africa, Nov. 9 (AP) -- The head of the local Red Cross bloodtransfusion service, which serves a large African population, today challenged Dr. Scudder's report.
MUNICH, Nov. 9 -- The board of Bayerische Motoren Werke (Bavarian Motor Works) voted today to surrender control of their bankrupt automobile company to Friedrich Flick's Daimler Benz Corporation.

B'nai B'rith, the 116-year-old Jewish service organization, voted a budget of $6,389,034 yesterday for next year. The sum included a record-breaking amount of $2,920,000 for the expansion of youth activities.
The role of public housing in serving the "human social needs" of its tenants was emphasized yesterday by William Reid, chairman of the City Housing Authority.

Heavy selling of wool contracts by chartists touched off stop-loss orders yesterday on the New York Cotton Exchange. The market closed at or near the lows of the day in active trading. Scale-down short covering and light new commission house buying absorbed the offers.

A new book that depicts the people of modern Sicily will be published Jan. 14 by Dutton. Titled "The Ten Pains of Death," it was written by Gavin Maxwell and it gives a picture of a land haunted by the indifference of those in power to the real needs of the mass of "oppressed and backward" people.

COLLEEN DEWHURST, in the part of the kitchen wench who finds beauty and liberation in the imagination of Don Quixote, imparted both spirit and poignancy to Dale Wasserman's endeavor last night to find a drama in the life and work of Miguel Cervantes.

NASRALLAH, Tunisia, Nov. 8 -- Nasrallah means the Glory of God, but the glory of Nasrallah and the surrounding country known as the Zlass is a young man named Mustafa (prouounced here Most'fa) Filali.

Governor Rockefeller laid down a six-point program last night for growth in the United States. It envisioned an increase of 50 per cent in spending for defense and other national needs while cutting taxes at the same time.

The Green Box, a shop at Lexington Avenue and Seventy-third Street, is the outlet for the Rehabilitation Workshop at Mount Sinai Hospital. The twenty-sixth annual exhibition and sale of articles made by patients is now in progress there.
The growing disposition of American advertising agencies to open overseas offices or to affiliate with foreign agencies gained a new impetus yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 9 -- The Opera Society of Washington created a citizens' committee today to develop a long-range financing program for opera here.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 9 (AP)--An indicated 15 per cent dip in farmers' net realized income this year may be followed by another drop of about half as ranch next year. This would pull the figure down to the lowest level since 1942.
"The Girls Against the Boys" drops out of contention after its sixteenth performance Saturday night at the Alvin.

AN eighteenth-century room that was nearly nine years in the making for a great English mansion has been re-installed, almost in its entirety, at the Metropolitan Museum of Art. It will be open to the public today.

Use of natural gas instead of coal in generation of electric power can be increased and the contamination of New York City's air reduced under an order handed down by the United States Court of Appeals for the Third Circuit, in Philadelphia. The Consolidated Edison Company has been using gas in some boilers. This was so-called "valley gas," the surplus available under level contract when demand from gas-heat customers was light.
LONDON, Nov. 9 -- Selective buying of industrial shares in the stock market here today outweighed profit taking near the end of the bookkeeping account, and gains predominated.
Unless Charley Conerly recovers sufficiently for the Pittsburgh game on Sunday, the Giants may call upon Frank Gifford to share the quarter-backing assignment.
NICE, France, Nov. 9 -- Under fire from all sides, Maurice Herzog, France's High Commissioner of Youth and Sports, has shown himself one of the world's stanchest defenders of the amateur ideal.
The residents of Vermont's largest city and seventeen surrounding towns have used tax revenue to encourage industrial development.
The city's schools should not be used for political purposes, Mayor Wagner declared yesterday.

Brantwood Camp, a summer camp for underprivileged city boys maintained by the student body and alumni of St. Mark's School, will be the beneficiary of a theatre party at "The Gang's All Here" on Nov. 23 at the Ambassador Theatre.
HOT SPRINGS, Va., Nov. 9 -- Clean up, or give up, advertisers were warned here today.
Donald Stenberg, baritone, and JoAnn Crossman (Mrs. Stenberg), pianist, made their debuts in a joint performance at Carnegie Recital Hall last night.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 9 (AP) -- The Chicago Eastern Illinois Railroad Company today asked the Interstate Commerce Commission for authority to retire its Class A stock through an exchange of shares.

FOR any soprano the title role of "Aida" is an occasion. For a young American soprano her first Aida at the Metropolitan Opera is a tremendous challenge. Lucine Amara came to grips with that challenge last night and turned it into an accomplishment.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 9 (AP) -- Arthur S. Flemming, Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare, said today dentrifice advertising that was false or misleading did a great disservice to the public by keeping people from seeking proper dental care.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 9 -- The United States has agreed to the demands of other members of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization for closer cooperation in planning negotiations with the Soviet Union.
District Attorney Frank S. Hogan began conferences yesterday on rigged television quiz shows with "a view to a grand jury presentation," according to a spokesman.
GENEVA, Nov. 9 -- The conference for a nuclear test ban entered a phase of off-therecord negotiations here today.
HUNTINGTON, L .I., Nov. 9 -- The drive-up telephone has been added to the drive-in movie and drive-in bank in New York.

A "major link" in the traffic of marijuana between New York and Mexico was broken yesterday with the seizure of $180,000 worth of the narcotic in Greenwich Village, Federal Customs officials reported.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 9--Following is the text of a statement issued today by the State Department on recent incidents affecting Cuban-United States relations:
A new issue of 295,178 preferred shares of Tennessee Gas Transmission Company is being placed on the market today by Stone Webster Securities Corporation and White, Weld Co. and associates.

The Ford Foundation is planning soon to sell 2,000,000 more shares of its holdings of Ford Motor Company common stock to the investment public. In financial circles it is expected that a registration statement covering the offering will be filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission during the next fortnight.

PICASSO is with us again, this time in an exhibition called "Faces and Figures" at the Saidenberg Gallery, 10 East Seventy-seventh Street. For some reason the master's social aplomb is more apparent than usual.
ALBANY, Nov. 9 -- The state has granted the American Oil Company a virtual monopoly over gasoline purchased for its 3,000 motor vehicles.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 9 -- The Federal Government warned the public today that some cranberries grown in Washington State and Oregon had been contaminated by a weed-killer that induces a cancerous growth in the thyroid of rats.

WHEN a bridge expert devises a new bid or play, it is almost always one that will best inform his partner. But when a bridge expert praises a bid or play, usually it is one that deceives the opponent and incidentally deceives the partner.

Rudolf Bing, general manager of the Metropolitan Opera, received a surprise phone call from soprano Maria Callas yesterday afternoon. Miss Callas landed at New York International Airport, Idlewild, Queens, en route from Dallas, Tex., to Milan, Italy and immediately dialed the Metropolitan.
The oysters had a holiday in Gardiners Bay last Saturday. Hardly anyone bothered them. The potato fields of Greenport, L. I., were ignored. The fishing boats rocked idly in the harbor.

Fashion trends for spring are taking shape as Seventh Avenue designers present collections, the American equivalent of the Paris openings. Thhe New York Times has been barred from some showings because of its policy to report trends immediately. Reports on those showings are based on information from other fashion authorities. Most of the clothes will be in stores by January.

A Russian scientist has come up with a theory about life on Mars the contemplation of which makes one downright dizzy. This scientist, I. S. Shklovsky by name, has offered the reasoned possibility that billions of years ago there were sentient, reasoning beings on the planet Mars, and that they were forced to migrate to parts unknown in outer space by the disappearance of oxygen in the Martian atmosphere and other natural changes.
Seven members of the Columbia University Seminar on Genetics and the Evolution of Man took strong exception last night to the advocacy of a race-to-race policy in blood transfusions.

OMAHA, Nov. 9 (AP) -- Dr. Thomas Dooley, 32-year-old "jungle doctor of Laos," said today that the $10,000 he receives tomorrow from Mutual of Omaha as winner of the 1959 Criss Award would go to still another hospital in a medically under-developed portion of the world.
BERLIN, Nov. 9 -- The Communists have stepped up controls at the border between East and West Berlin to prevent East Germans from carrying butter and other foodstuffs to West Berlin.
Dr. Howard A. Rusk and Mrs. Betsy Talbot Blackwell, editor in chief of Mademoiselle magazine, received awards last night for outstanding public service.
While numerous proposals for improving our housing programs have been made in the recent past, they are somewhat anticlimactic in light of the main issue, the inadequate supply of low-rent housing.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 10 -- The Federal Communications Commission moved today to make its own inquiry into the television evils spotlighted in recent weeks by Congressional investigators. It ordered the expansion of a general investigation it has been making into network practices.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 10 (AP) -- Lloyd Barenblatt, 36 years old, who fought a long legal battle to avoid going to jail for contempt of Congress, surrendered today to begin a six-month sentence.
The City Council voted yesterday to limit alternate-side-of-the-street parking to two days a week on each side.
A special citizens' committee held a luncheon yesterday at the Roosevelt Hotel to salute the armed forces on the eve of Veterans Day. About 450 civilians and servicemen attended.

LONDON, Nov. 10 (Reuters) -- After the performance of his play "Aunt Edwina" at the Fortune Theatre here last night. William Douglas Home, playwright, made a short ap pearance on the stage in which he issued a challenge to drama critics.
What is New York? It is people -- 8,042,000 of them. It is buildings -- 786,240. And it is the sidewalks that border 5,982 miles of paved streets.
Monroe, which won two games and lost three in league competition, was yesterday named champion of Division I by the Public Schools Athletic League football committee.
OXFORD, England, Nov. 10 (AP) -- Peter Dawkins, a former West Point All-American football player, today said that English rugby was tougher than American football.
"LA GRANDE DUCHESSE DE GEROLSTEIN" was a vivacious romp when the American Opera Society presented it two seasons ago. It remained fun in a return engagement at Carnegie Hall last night.

So much has been written about Syracuse's Sizable Seven line and big, fast, hard-hitting backs that the impression undoubtedly has been created that Coach Ben Schwartzwalder's unbeaten Orange eleven relies mainly on power to move the ball.

MANILA, Wednesday, Nov. 11 -- With about a third of yesterday's vote counted, President Carlos P. Garcia's Nationalist party lagged badly in the race for eight of the country's twenty-four Senate seats.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 10 -The United States has evidence indicating that the Panamanian Government ordered the police not to interfere with the antiUnited States demonstrations last week.
CLEVELAND, Nov. 10 (AP) -- An educator, irked by Vice Admiral liyman G. Rickover's criticism of the American school system, said today it was time someone told off the admiral.

Governor Rockefeller was recently quoted as saying that one of his big problems was "personnel" -- finding the right man for the job. Recently, also, Crawford H. Greenewalt, the president of du Pont, stated that in choosing men to fill a higher post the "raised hand" wasn't always a good guide.

The National Horse Show ended in Madison Square Garden last night with a Canadian team triumph in the international jumping achieved before a crowd of 11,000. The event was the Nations Cup and its presentation ended a two-part contest in which the scores of the afternoon and the evening were added.
HOT SPRINGS, Va., Nov. 10 -- At least 90 per cent of the nation's agencies know how to prepare better advertising than their work represents, according to a former agency executive.
A report on a Brooklyn magistrate's decision to release without bail two youths accused of assaulting a policeman was sent by Mayor Wagner yesterday to state judicial leaders.

The furor over contaminated cranberries is understandable for two reasons that come close to home to practically everyone: the fear of cancer and the coming of Thanksgiving. It is useful to try for some perspective on the matter at once.
Shortly after midnight at the Fan Ball in the Astor on Friday, the birthday of Mrs. Dwight D. Eisenhower, honorary chairman of the fete, will be observed.

The latest available figures __ as of the end of 1957 -- tend to confirm the frequent plaint of Canadians that foreign interests are gaining increasing control over industry in their nation. The Canadian Bureau of Statistics reported yesterday that foreign interests in that nation's manufacturing industries rose in 1957 to 56 per cent, from 52 per cent a year before.
PEEKSKILL, N. Y., Nov. 10 -- The discovery of what may be one of the world's rarest stamps was disclosed here today by Herman Herst Jr., a stamp expert of near-by Shrub Oak.

Many persons entertained guests at a supper dance last night in the Grand Ballroom of the Plaza after the world premiere of the motion picture "Happy Anniversary" at the Victoria Theatre. Both were benefits for WAIF (World Adoption International Fund) and were sponsored by the agency's New York chapter.
The confirmation of the election of William S. Shea as Municipal Court justice touched off an impromptu celebration yesterday at New York County Republican headquarters, 54 West Fortieth Street.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Nov. 10 -- The Yale defense that shut out the first five opponents has yielded 40 points and victory to Dartmouth and Pennsylvania after the Elis led the Green by 8 -- 0 and the Quakers by 12 -- 0.
The nation's cranberry crop, estimated to have a retail value between $45,000,000 and $50,000,000, appeared likely yesterday to turn into a substantial loss.
ST. LOUIS, Nov. 10 -- Concern over the future of television as an information medium was expressed today by Dr. Frank Stanton, president of the Columbia Broadcasting System.
PARIS, Nov. 10 -- France has decided to extend to the industrial West in general, including the United States, the enlargement of import quotas due Jan. 1 under the European common market treaty.
PARIS, Nov. 10 -- President Charles de Gaulle issued today his most insistent and explicit appeal to the Algerian rebels to stop fighting and join in determining Algeria's future by free voting.
The General Motors Corporation, giant of the automobile industry, will be forced tonight to halt all passenger-car production for lack of steel.

WESTBURY, L. I., Nov. 10 -- Earle Avery and the Clearview Stable of Norman Woolworth may be the next target of the Government's antitrust investigation. They apparently have a monopoly on the United States Harness Writers Trot.

Reserves of the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development (World Bank) increased $20,400,000 in the three months ended on Sept. 30 to $440,300,000, the bank reported yesterday. The figure is made up of $13,900,000 of net earnings placed in the supplemental reserve against losses on loans and guarantees and loan commissions of $6,500,000.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 10 -- Congressional tax writers armed themselves today with three volumes of expert advice on improving the Federal income-tax system.

The fourteen-story apartment building known as the Riviera at 790 Riverside Drive at West 156th Street, has been sold by the Realty Equities Corporation of New York. The buyer, an investor, was represented by Ditmond Kreitman, lawyers. David Stein was the lawyer for the seller.
ALEC GUINNESS made his American television debut last night in a gentle and hilarious comedy perfectly tailored to his style.

Miami Copper Company yesterday declared a regular quarterly dividend of 50 cents and an extra of 62 1/2 cents on the common shares, payable on Dec. 18, and an additional extra of 50 cents payable on Jan. 8. This brings the total declared this year to $3, compared with $1.25 in the like 1958 period.
The key witness in a widow's $200,000 suit against the city turns out to have been in jail at the time he said he saw her husband killed in a collision with a police car.

A wrangle over the manner of payment for clerical work connected with the activities of the Equity Community Theatre may prevent its operation this season. It would mark the first hiatus in the project's ten-year history.
MUSCLE SHOALS, Ala., Nov. 10 -- Pointed partisan comments were exchanged here today regarding the Eisenhower Administration's attitude toward the Tennessee Valley Authority.
Stockholders of Bethlehem Steel Corporation approved a new incentive pay plan for executives at a special meeting in Wilmington, Del., yesterday.
Convictions in two criminal cases were reversed here yesterday by the United States Court of Appeals, which held that the defendants had been denied a fair trial.

The memorial that every state in the Union is observing today originally marked the end of World War I; and all but Americans of the youngest generation remember it as Armistice Day. Now, with two additional wars behind us, it is Veterans Day, a tribute to all those who have died in defense of our country and to those who fought and lived.
An electronic device in the home to detect diseases in their earliest stages was predicted last night by David Sarnoff, chairman of the board of the Radio Corporation of America.

Among the annoyances that beset legitimate promotional enterprises, such as the Continental League and expansion of the present two major leagues, there is one that really hurts. That is the almost breathless eagerness with which some folks hop on such ventures as springboards for grabbing freeI publicity.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 10 (AP) -- A volume of crops exceeding last year's record is being harvested by the nation's farmers.
Subpoena, an independent and fiery Brooklyn dog, is facing eviction because of a landscape project.

The American Assembly announced yesterday the election of three new members of the board of trustees. They are W. Averell Harriman, former Governor of New York; Marriner S. Eccles, chairman of the First Security Corporation of Salt Lake City, and H. J. Heinz 2d of Pittsburgh, chairman of the H. J. Heinz Company.

ARSENIO H. LACSON, Mayor of Manila, who won re-election to a third term yesterday, is a battling politician with a two-fisted approach and a vocabulary so pithy and profane it is often unprintable. A selfstyled Don Quixote, eager to take on all comers on any question, Mayor Lacson speaks his mind with a bluntness that keeps him barred from making any live radio or television broadcasts.
GREAT FALLS, Mont., Nov. 10 (AP) -- A Montana blizzard caused three Air Force jet fighters to crash before dawn today. Four airmen were killed and two parachuted safely.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 10 -Secretary of State Christian A. Herter and other distinguished guests filled two theatres here tonight for the premiere of the Soviet film "The Cranes Are Flying."
WASHINGTON, Nov. 10 -- The Army sent a rocket payload to an altitude of 1,050 miles today to measure the density of electrons in the outer fringes of the earth's atmosphere.
CHICAGO, Nov. 10 (AP) -- The United States Circuit Court of Appeals upheld today the constitutionality of a law prohibiting futures trading in onions.

CAIRO. Nov. 10 -- Mutinous troops fought regular army forces in Khartoum's streets last night. Casualties were inflicted on both sides. However, Lieut. Gen. Ibrahim Abboud. Premier of the Sudan, assured one of his Cabinet Ministers in Cairo today that his Government had the situation in hand and the capital was calm.
HAVANA, Nov. 10 -- Revolution, the organ of the Cuban revolutionary movement, said today that a United States protest against an official Cuban pamphlet was "lacking in respect, false and offensive."
A Staten Island woman was critically injured last night in an explosion that was set off when she opened her garage door.

A MOZART sonata tinkles gently in a music box. Plates depicting fairy tales decorate the walls. Thick pink carpets cover the floor. Crystal chandeliers dripping with cut glass pendants, suspended on red velvet-wrapped silver chains, light the scene.
The cornerstone of the Charles S. Colden Center of Music and Speech, the newest building on the Queens College campus, was laid yesterday.

Members of the worlds of society, the performing arts, business and diplomacy mingled, dined, danced and were entertained last night at the Grand Opera Ball. The Grand Ballroom of the Sheraton-East was decorated to resemble a Milanese palace for the fete, which benefited the Boys and Girls Towns of Italy.
NAIROBI, Kenya, Nov. 10 -- Gov. Sir Patrick Renison announced today that the sevenyear state of emergency in Kenya would end early in 1960.
IN Webster's Dictionary "vertigo" is defined as "dizziness or swimming of the head."

Macy's expects a good year for business in 1960. The annual meeting yesterday of stockholders of R. H. Macy Co., Inc., heard Jack I. Straus, chairman of the department store chain, tell some 600 of them at the Statler Hilton Hotel that all the indicators were on the positive side.
Metropolitan milk dealers and four teamster unions that represent processing and delivery employes agreed yesterday on a two-year contract, and a one-cent rise in the price of milk was in prospect.

PARIS, Nov. 10 -- President Charles de Gaulle announced today that Premier Khrushchev would arrive March 15 for his visit to France. This implicitly ruled out East-West summit talks before April at the earliest.

Visitors to the United States art show at the Moscow fair last summer were so entranced with the heroically proportioned bronze "Standing Woman," on loan by the Museum of Modern Art, that they wore off much of the statue's dark patina.
The American Committee on Africa has decided to take a close look at the fate of persons who enter the United States illegally in search of political refuge or economic betterment.
