The National Horse Show's annual stand here came to a close last night pretty much as it started eight days ago -- on a social note.

Net earnings of the International Paper Companies for the quarter ended on Sept. 30 were $20,252,406, equal to $1.53 a common share on gross sales of $263,334,621. In the 1958 period, the organization cleared $17,750,384, or $1.34 a share on sales of $235,208,298.

Maurice Newton's favored Egotistical displayed his best sprinting form before 21,111 Aqueduct fans yesterday in winning the $6,000 Golden Voyage by a length. Discard, owned by Stella G. Steckler, was second.
Seventy-five countries have indicated informally an interest in the New York World's Fair of 1964, Thomas J. Deegan Jr., chairman of the fair corporation, reported yesterday.

NEW DELHI, India, Nov. 10 -- Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru declared today that Indians "cannot allow China to keep a foot on our chest." He also firmly reiterated his rejection of Peiping's claims to large parts of Indian territory.
HARRISBURG, Nov. 10 (AP) -- Robert H. Collins, promotion manager of the Portland, Me., Press-Herald, was elected president of the eastern region of the National Newspaper Promotion Assoication today.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 10 -- Britain and Italy invited France today to subscribe to a possible international agreement on the suspension of nuclear bomb tests.
A police official told a City Council committee yesterday that the New York police now considered the knife to be as lethal a weapon as a revolver.
PARIS, Nov. 10 (Reuters) -following is a transcript of a news conference held today by President Charles de Gaulle:

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 10 -- Soviet sources said today that they had no comment on Premier Khrushchev's reported statement that an EastWest summit conference would be "only for the exchange of views."
The Transit Authority reported yesterday that it had lost $2,472,161 in the first quarter of the 1959-60 fiscal year. But the agency expressed neither surprise nor dismay.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 10 -- The head of the United Nations' aid agency for Arab refugees said today that assistance would be needed for a decade or more.

BRUSSELS, Belgium, Nov. 10 -- A two-phase reform program giving a wide measure of independence to the Belgian mandate territory of Ruanda-Urundi in Africa was announced in the Chamber of Deputies today.

Dr. P. Shamsuddin, still angry, refused yesterday to reconsider his decision to resign from Knickerbocker Hospital and abandon his postgraduate medical training here. He is to sail for England on the Queen Mary this afternoon.

Otto Preminger announced last night that he had bought film rights to another novel that is No. 1 on the fiction best-seller lists, Allen Drury's "Advise and Consent." Mr. Preminger's recently-released "Anatomy of a Murder" and his forthcoming "Exodus" both attained the same distinction in the world of literary commerce.

What is U. S. O.? One G. I. describes it this way: "It's the warm smile and friendly help of a pretty U. S. O. hostess -- a crowded Saturday night dance floor -- a camp show -- a guided tour of a strange town -- a ticket to the theatre or the movies.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 10 (UPI) -- Edgar Eisenhower, critic of large Federal budgets, was named today to the board of trustees of a new organization dedicated to oppose "spendthrift and inflationary" government policies.
King George Rukidi III, of Toro in the British protectorate of Uganda, East Africa, received an honorary membership yesterday in the General Organization of Sands Junior High School in Brooklyn.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 10 -- India is shopping for a small fleet of high-altitude helicopters to patrol the border regions with Communist China, authoritative sources said today.
In the Rockaways yesterday, in an unheated two-story brick building that once was a paper box factory, some men were busily preparing to move a slum.

TRENTON, Nov. 10 -- Wesley L. Lance, President of the State Senate, said today that he would introduce a resolution to have the Senate's transportation committee hold public hearings on the transit problem. The Senate reconvenes Nov. 23.

DAYTONA BEACH, Fla., Nov. 10 -- Many of America's leading sports car drivers will enjoy a new experience on Saturday and Sunday in the final national sports car championship races of the season to be held at Daytona International Speedway, America's fastest automobile racing course.
DETROIT, Nov. 10 (AP) -Claims against a seized Greekowned Panamanian freighter had climbed today to more than $20,000.

CHICAGO, Nov. 10 -- A vice president of the Chase Manhattan Bank said today that business activity would move ahead strongly in 1960, resulting in "a year of great prosperity." But, he added, there is a prospect of another recession in 1961.

TORONTO, Nov. 10 -- Good faith shown by a city's civic and business leaders in implementing and supporting urban-renewal programs will play an increasing role in the Federal Government's determination of whether continued aid should be given, the United States urban-renewal chief said here today.

LONDON, Nov. 10 -- Britain announced today that she would not ratify a convention on seafarers' wages and hours and on the manning of ships that was adopted at last year's maritime session of the International Labor Conference.
The police continued to harass known gamblers yesterday, arresting 209 persons.
Aminotriazole, the weed-killer whose contamination of some cranberries threatens to banish the traditional tartness from many a Thanksgiving dinner, is a chemical of many uses.
Two hundred Greenwich Villagers applauded a pretty young mother last night as she told a meeting: "We are proud of the Village. We want to live and raise our children here."

Fresh demand appeared in the market for United States Government securities yesterday afternoon, enabling Treasury securities to close the day on a strong note after a succession of price swings up and down. Net changes for the day were slight, but business was more active than on Monday.
COUPEVILLE, Wash., Nov. 10 (AP) -- Two mountaineers rescued today the last of three black Labrador retrievers trapped since Sunday on a Puget Sound Island cliff.

ONCE upon a time there was a boy who would enter the forest and cry, "Wolf!" The woodcutters would rush to the rescue and discover that there was no wolf. Then the day came when the boy cried, "Wolf!" and the woodcutters paid no attention. But this was no false alarm and the wolf devoured the boy.
CHICAGO, Nov. 10 -- The new chairman of the American Petroleum Institute, an organization of 11,000 oil men from companies large and small, is head man of the largest concern in the business.
Lehman Brothers and Lester Ryons Co., Los Angeles, are placing on the market today 532,549 shares of the common stock of Baker Oil Tools, Inc., Los Angeles. The stock is priced at $9.625 a share.

The Communist threat to Arab independence and unity 'takes immediate precedence over the Israeli-Arab problem among Arabs," Rabbi Elmer Berger declared last night at a meeting of the American Friends of the Middle East.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 10 -- A House subcommittee investigating the withholding of Government information accused the Internal Revenue Service today of making a secret even of its authority to impose secrecy.

MOSCOW, Nov. 10 -- More than 1,000 Russians laughed loudly and perhaps wept quietly this evening in appreciation of "Marty" at the premiere of the first major American film shown here since World War II.
"Watch out!"

Today's most exciting development in the western Pacific is the Australian boom. Only a few years ago this land was all too frequently regarded as but a strange and distant preserve of weird animals like koalas, kangaroos and wombats, situated among vast deserts speckled with gum trees.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 10 -The Eisenhower Administration disclosed today that it would present to the next session of Congress proposals for a permanent solution of the farm problem.

President Eisenhower has asked the Attorney General to study the rigging of TV quiz programs. But the basic problem seems deeper than one for the Attorney General. It involves public attitudes, and only incidentally the law.

Fashion trends for spring are taking shape as Seventh Avenue designers present their collections, which are the American equivalent of the Paris openings. Most of the clothes will be in stores by January.
There has not been a "real good gang fight" in the middle East Side for three years, the youth patrolman of the Nineteenth Precinct said yesterday.
AN inescapable problem in bridge is what to do with a strong, biddable hand when an opponent bids your best suit before your turn comes.

THE picture presented by America and Americans in tb. is era when the nation has the important role of world leadership was presented in stimulating terms last night over the Columbia Broadcasting System's radio network.
CAIRO, Nov. 10 -- Premier Khrushchev has told a Cairo editor that the Soviet Union is ready to continue aid to the United Arab Republic.

Despite sharp Soviet protests, Secretary General Hammarskjold has left for a week's visit to Laos to acquire "independent and full personal knowledge" about Communist aggression against that country and possibly leave a personal representative there as a "United Nations presence" to avert more trouble.

CHICAGO, Nov. 10 (AP) -Wheat and oats futures were bid up to new high prices for the season in spots today on the Board of Trade. Soybeans met their first resistance in more than a week and lost ground in all deliveries.
GROTON, Conn., Nov. 10 -- The atomic submarine Triton, largest ever built, was commissioned here today.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange moved 1 point off to 5 up yesterday. A point is 5 cents a bale.
PATERSON, N. J., Nov. 10 -Cities were charged today by a housing expert with a failure to include plans for moderateincome housing in urban renewal projects.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 10 (UPI) -- Bill Flanagan is alive because doctors restored his heart beat by pouring twenty gallons of warm faucet water into his chest cavity. "I feel better than I ever did," he said today.

THE state of Pennsylvania, which has been a little self-conscious since its sale of fishing licenses began to fall off, is blowing the whistle on its neighbors. Its Fish Commission has uncovered, or bared, the fact that every neighboring state except Delaware has suffered the same disgrace.
NORTHFIELD, Vt., Nov. 10 (UPI) -- Cadets at Norwich University, a private military college, rebelled today against "West Point militarism."

BERLIN, Nov. 10 -- The United States Commander in Berlin, Maj. Gen. Barksdale Hamlett, has been assigned to a post in Washington, the Department of the Army announced today. He has had twoand-a-half years of service in the four-power city.
Aircrafts and electronics stirred to life with renewed talk in Washington of heavier defense spending, but the New York Stock Exchange list as a whole was mixed and uncertain yesterday.
CHICAGO, Nov. 10 (AP) -- The report of today's livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:

Potato prices dropped 3 to 9 points (hundredths of a cent a pound) on 1,399 car lots yesterday on the New York Mercantile Exchange. Liquidation and profit taking offset short covering and scale-down trade buying.
LAUREL, Md., Nov. 10 -- The eighth running of the Washington D.C. International tomorrow will have more extensive representation than any of the previous offerings.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 10 (UPI) -- A New York woman charged in a Federal Court suit today that the Government has refused to restore her security clearance to work in a defense plant even though the Supreme Court has held industrial security program procedures invalid.
ALBANY, Nov. 10 -- The state safety director resigned today amid reports that his agency would shortly become a victim of the Rockefeller administration's economy drive.

"Not So Long Ago," a lighthearted review of the American scene from 1945 to 1950, will be the next television program for the National Broadcasting Company's "Project 20" unit. It will be presented on "Sunday Showcase" on Jan. 31 from 8 to 9 P. M.

A new volume in the series derived from the Boswell papers will be published Nov. 25 by McGraw-Hill. It is "Boswell for the Defense." Edited by William K. Wimsatt and Frederick A. Pottle, the volume takes up where "Boswell in Search of a Wife" left off.

With their coach, Phil Watson, about to undergo surgery for a bleeding ulcer and their team lodged in fifth place in the National Hockey League, the Rangers were looking hopefully yesterday to making a fresh start in the opener of a three-game home stand at the Garden tonight.

DOBBS FERRY, N. Y., Nov. 10 -- All pupils in the elementary and high schools here except one little girl knew their way home today when an unrehearsed "go-home" air-raid drill was called while classes were in session.
Senator Jacob K. Javits said yesterday that New York City was in "grave peril" from urban blight and decay.
The New York State Athletic Commission reserved decision yesterday in the case of Gus D'Amato, manager of Floyd Patterson.
COLOMBO, Ceylon, Nov. 10 -Prices of crepe rubber fell by 10 Ceylon cents (about 2 United States cents) a pound today at Colombo auctions.
Three presentations of "Which Way the Wind,' a documentary drama concerned with the menace of the hydrogen bomb, will be given in the greater New York area.

What part Abraham M. Sonnabend, Boston financier, will play -- if any -- in the direction of the Alleghany Corporation, the big railroad holding company, may not be known for another week. Mr. Sonnabend renewed acquaintance for two hours yesterday morning with Alleghany's chairman and president, Allan P. Kirby.

A Government witness told yesterday in Federal Court how he had seen men who attended the Apalachin meeting running across open fields after the state police interrupted the 1957 gathering. He stopped one, he added.
LONDON, Nov. 10 -- Selwyn Lloyd will begin a delicate and difficult mission to Paris tomorrow.

MARQUETTE, Mich., Nov. 10 -- Michigan's Upper Peninsula needs both private and governmental help in reviving its economy, according to witnesses at a hearing today of the Special Senate Committee on Unemployment Problems.

JOGJAKARTA, Indonesia, Wednesday, Nov. 11 -- President Sukarno is prepared to open the Colombo Plan conference here today by telling the twenty-one-country organization that Indonesia would welcome assistance in building a Socialist economy -- but on her own terms.

ALBANY, Nov. 10 (AP) -- The 1960 Legislature will reject any pleas from the Board of Regents for major increases in state spending for education beyond those required by law, a legislative leader said today.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 10 (UPI) -- A powerful union group sidetracked today a resolution praising the role of Senator John F. Kennedy and five other Democrats in the Congressional battle over the new labor-reform law.
Mayor Wagner opened yesterday an all-out drive to win legislative approval for his proposal to legalize and tax offtrack betting on horse races.
ROME, Nov. 10 -- A worldwide "freedom from hunger" campaign will be undertaken next year by the eighty-eight nations that are members of the United Nations Food and Agriculture Organization.
The power blackout in upper Manhattan Aug. 17 was still a mystery yesterday after the Public Service Commission reported on its investigation.
CAIRO, Nov. 10 (AP) -- Premier Khrushchev told his Cairo interviewer that a summit conference "is only for an exchange of views," and lasting settlements would only be made in the United Nations.

Governor Rockefeller in his speech before the Economic Club of New York expanded a central theme used in his election campaign of 1958, the enlargement of employment opportunity through encouragement of business, industry and agriculture. Addressing a larger audience now, he advances what he calls "a positive, realistic program to stimulate economic growth" of the nation.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 10 -- Before 5,119 fans in Convention Hall tonight, the New York Knickerbockers missed two shots at the basket in the last three seconds and dropped a 126-125 decision to the Philadelphia Warriors.

Stockholders of Unexcelled Chemical Corporation approved the acquisition of R. R. Williams, Inc., yesterday. The consolidation had been approved by stockholders of Williams, which makes pre - moistened, foil-wrapped specialty tissues for the drug and cosmetics fields.
AMMAN, Jordan, Nov. 10 -- King Hussein flew to Europe on a vacation trip today with a new spirit of confidence in the state of his kingdom.
OTTAWA, Nov. 10 (Canadian Press) -- Eight more West CoastI !shipping companies have beenI ordered to bargain collectively iwith the Canadian Brotherhood of Railway, Transport and General Workers.
The New York Heart Association yesterday elected Dr. William Goldring, heart specialist and Associate Professor of Medicine at the New York University College of Medicine, as its president.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 10 (UPI) -- Newsweek said today that a poll by its political experts showed that Gov. Nelson A. Rockefeller's chances of beating Vice President Richard M. Nixon for the Republican Presidential nomination were "very dim indeed."
WASHINGTON, Nov. 10 -The United States and India signed a tax treaty today that grants important concessions to Americans who invest in the Indian economy.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 10 -- The Food and Drug Administration announced today that it was assigning one-fourth of its field staff to make a nation-wide check of possible contamination of cranberries by aminotriazole, a weed-killer.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 10 (AP) -- President Eisenhower began clearing his desk today in the hope of getting away for a few days of rest in advance of a strenuous goodwill mission to foreign lands.
A FRIENDLESS boy, who throws nightly temper tantrums, and cheats and steals at school, is examined in "Eye of the Hurricane," a new playlet by Nora Stirling.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 10 -President Eisenhower instructed the Tariff Commision today to determine whether a "fee" of 8 cents a pound on the cotton content of imported textiles was necessary to prevent interference with domestic cotton manufactures.
Closer control over New Yorkers who persistently violate traffic laws is in prospect as a result of an Election Day decision.

The most-traveled ball-carrier in Penn history, Fred Doelling, yesterday was named Ivy League back of the week for the second time this season. The senior halfback ran for 143 yards and two touchdowns in the Quakers' triumph over Yale last Saturday.
As far as anyone has yet discovered, last night's concert of music for two harpsichords at Carnegie Recital Hall was the first of its kind in New York.
The British desire for expanded two-way trade with the United States was emphasized yesterday at ceremonies dedicating the new headquarters of the British-American Chamber of Commerce.

Frank acknowledgment by advertisers of their share of responsibility for the practices followed in producing the television programs they pay for is long overdue. Now it has come in the form of a refreshing statement by the board of directors of the Association of National Advertisers. This is one of the more hopeful developments to come from recent revelations in the TV quiz scandal.
eventually in a high Pentagon post. This view puts emphasis on the importance of his role in Berlin, which sits across the Iron Curtain from a huge force of Communist troops.
Growing apprehension over anti-American feeling in Cuba by West Indies cruise passengers has resulted so far in the cancellation of five scheduled cruise ship calls by three companies at Havana.

Stockholders of Canadian Fairbanks Morse Company, Ltd., will be asked at a special meeting on Nov. 16 to approve a rise in capital to 4,000,000 Class A and 2,000,000 Class B shares. There are now 1,000,000 shares of authorized common.
Joanna Hodges, American pianist who has just returned from her second tour of Europe, played a debut recital at Town Hall last night.
ALBANY, Nov. 10 -- The State Department of Taxation and Finance is tracking down some 30,000 employers who have so far failed to withhold state income tax from their employes' paychecks.

DALLAS, Tex., Nov. 10 (UPI) -- Tight money conditions will continue well into 1960 and take the edge off the present boom in the savings and loan field, a speaker told the United States Savings and Loan League's annual convention today.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 10 -Representatives of the trucking industry appealed to a Federal court today to reverse a recent ruling of the Interstate Commerce Commisison that permits freight forwarders to enter the growing "piggyback" freight business.
Fear was expressed yesterday that man might become an obsolete species because of the chemical, radiological and other pollutants he has produced.

SYRACUSE, Nov. 10 (AP) -Syracuse football players and fans, glowing over the Orange's No. 1 ranking in the weekly Associated Press poll, learned today they could have an Orange Bowl berth for the asking.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 10 (UPI) -- The head of the Federal Housing Administration predicted today that by 2000 the typical American family would earn $10,000 a year and spend up to $25,000 for a house.

The charge of "wash sales" in a controversial stock was leveled by the Securities and Exchange Commission yesterday against an individual buyer of stock. The S. E. C. filed a complaint in the United States District Court here seeking to enjoin Robert Bialkin, of Atlantic Beach, L. I., from further alleged violations of S. E. C. rules emanating from trading in the common stock of Artloom Industries, Inc.

PARIS, Nov. 10 -- President Charles de Gaulle's news conference today was a carefully staged production with the President as the star and everyone else in the room -- the Cabinet, senior officials and the press -- as dress extras.

Walter J. Mahoney, majority leader in the State Senate, said yesterday that several bills rather than a single omnibus measure might be needed to achieve a revision of the State Banking Law in the 1960 session of the Legislature.
LONDON, Nov. 10 -- A letter from 22-year-old George Washington accepting his commission as lieutenant colonel in the colonial army was sold at auction to an American today for 1.000 ($2.800).
Events today: "The Marriage of Figaro," Metropolitan Opera, 8 P. M.; Orchestra of America, Richard Korn, conductor, Vida Chenoweth, marimba player, Carnegie Hall, 8:30.
LONDON, Nov. 10 (AP) -British and American money will finance a bold shipping venture to put big, new supertankers and cargo ships on world trade routes.
Armco Steel Corporation will have thirty of its forty open hearth furnaces in operation by Saturday, a spokesman said yesterday.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 10 -- The Special Political Committee of the General Assembly denounced today racial segregation in South Africa as contrary to the United Nations Charter. A draft resolution deploring the Government's apertheid policy of legal discrimination between whites and non-whites was adopted 67 to 3, with 7 abstentions.
Directors of the United States Steel Corporation chose yesterday an executive with broad sales and warehousing management experience as the corporation's eighth president.

The Public Service Commission authorized the New York State Electric and Gas Corporation to issue up to 467,247 shares of no par common stock and to reclassify its 4,000,000 shares into 8,400,000 shares. This was in line with approval by stockholders of a 2.1-for-1 stock split.

I would like to compliment The New York Times on the recent Brazilian reporting. It was pleasant to read an interesting analysis of the coming elections in Rio Grande do Sul without being treated to sensational aspects of the event. My congratulations to Juan de Onis and the editors.

JEAN DUBUFFET, who held his first exhibition as recently as 1944 (and he is 58 years old), is now the subject of a retrospective at the Pierre Matisse Gallery, 41 East Fifty-seventh Street. It is a big, impressive show, and an enlightening one, too.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 10 (AP) -- Secretary of Labor James P. Mitchell is going to eat his hat on the Labor Department steps tomorrow morning because his predictions of employment improvement have not come true.
DETROIT, Nov. 10 -Executives of independent anti-cancer agencies from twelve cities met in Detroit today to discuss the problems of life in exile.
Robert Moses, speaking in a bitter mood, defended his construction policies yesterday and depicted his critics as underminers of the city's progress.
The State of Mississippi borrowed $15,000,000 in the public bond market yesterday.

BONN, Germany, Nov. 10 -- A German Jewish leader criticized the American Jewish Congress today for a study of "anti-Semitism, ultranationalism and democracy" in West Germany that it recently published under the title of "The German Dilemma."

Grocery store sales will reach $75,000,000,000 a year by 1969, according to James O. Peckham Jr., executive vice president of the A. C. Nielsen Company, research organization. Advertised brands will account for 80 per cent of the total, he said. Sales are running at about $48,000,000,000, of which advertised brands account for about 74.8 per cent, he noted.
IT is not often that a discussion of food takes on a political flavor. Yet that is what happened recently during an interview with a charming Indian woman.

TOKYO, Nov. 10 -- Under the proposed new security treaty between Tokyo and Washington the United States will continue to be able to use military bases in Japan for combat operations elsewhere in the Far East, Foreign Minister Aiichiro Fujiyama said today.
LONDON, Nov. 10 -- The stock market overcame heavy profit taking at end of the bookkeeping account here today to finish on a rising note.
An insight into ship cargo handling methods in vogue in South America was given yesterday by H. R. Glennon Jr., a vice president of Moore-McCormack Lines.
GLENS FALLS, N. Y., Nov. 10 (AP) -- Fire wiped out a family of eight today after an explosion in their home near here.
"MY aim has been to make clear what the Elizabethans contributed to the making of the greatest of modern nations." So writes A. L. Rowse in the preface to his "The Elizabethans and America."

WASHINGTON, Nov. 10 -- The White House snapped back today at a labor leader who had charged that the use of the Taft-Hartley injunction in the steel strike was a political payoff by President Eisenhower to company officials for campaign financial help.

The latest collision between two vessels in the upper New York harbor may or may not have been directly due to violation of a basic law of navigation. However, that basic law is often violated in our harbor and many collisions are in fact due to such infringements.

Mayor Wagner denied last night a request by Magistrate Anthony E. Maglio for a conference at which he might explain his recent release, without bail, of two Brooklyn youths charged with assaulting an off-duty policeman.

Most processors of food expect to continue expansion of plants or extensive modernization programs in the next ten years, it was disclosed yesterday. These views were expressed by speakers at the closing sessions of the fifty-first annual convention of the Grocery Manufacturers of America, at the Waldorf-Astroia Hotel.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 11 (UPI) -- Don Paarlberg, special assistant to the President, indicated today that the Administration had no plans to ease the tight-money situation for home buyers.
ALGIERS, Nov. 11 -- Shouts of "de Gaulle to the gallows!" echoed through downtown Algiers for nearly three hours this morning.

SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 11 -- The Union Oil Company of California and the Kern County Land Company announced today a joint venture to explore for oil in Australia in a 60,000would take place on a 60,000,square-mile area held by the Australian Oil and Gas Corporation of Sydney.
BOSTON, Nov. 11 (AP) -- The New Jersey Education Commissioner said today the only way schools improved was when teaching improved.
PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 11 (UPI) -- The Los Angeles Rams lead the National Football League in total offense for the third straight week -- and have only two victories to show for their efforts.
Man, "the ultimate weapon," dominates the sandy ranges and the scrub-pine woods of Fort Dix, N. J.

Jan Murray, owner of the National Broadcasting Company's television quiz show "Treasure Hunt," was questioned yesterday at the office of District Attorney Frank S. Hogan about reports of kickbacks by contestants.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 11 (UPI) -- Four airlines have submitted to the Government an informal proposal for reduced fares for Government cargo and personnel traveling overseas on official business.

James H. Scheuer, president of the Citizens Housing and Planning Council, attacked Robert Moses yesterday and urged that private civic groups be allowed wider participation in the urban renewal program.
RIVERHEAD, L. I., Nov. 11 -- Definite lines began forming today in the battle for control of the Suffolk County Republican party.
A ruling from Albany brought dismay yesterday to the man credited with turning harness racing from a sport of skittering horses and false starts into a multimillion-dollar producer of state revenue.

MOSCOW, Nov. 11 -- Authorities of the Russian Republic sought today to quell rumors that the Government was getting ready either to confiscate all privately owned homes or to impose heavy new taxes on the owners.
ALBANY, Nov. 11 (AP) -- The chief of the Army Engineer Corps says dredging will begin in April to deepen the Hudson River channel to thirty-two feet between New York City and Albany.
ST. LOUIS, Nov. 11 (AP) -- Secretary of the Army Wilber M. Brucker said today it was irrational to believe Soviet leaders would deliberately start a nuclear war.
HOT SPRINGS, Va., Nov. 11 -- Advertisers are not interested in relinquishing their present role in television network programing.
The airlines of Ireland and Israel are planning to share the same passenger terminal space at New York International Airport, Idlewild, Queens.
MOSCOW, Nov. 11 -- The Soviet Union delivered a note to Britain today dealing with the German question, British sources said here.
LONDON, Nov. 11 -- Britain's exports last month reached a new high of 306,000,000 ($856,800,000).
WASHINGTON, Nov. 11 -- Nicholas N. Larsen, former traffic regulator for Barber Steamship Lines, has been appointed New York representative of the Federal Maritime Board's regulation board.
New York's largest private bus operator has informed the city that it cannot make a contract offer to the Transport Workers Union without some kind of financial relief.

CHICAGO, Nov. 11 (AP) -- Harold Johnson, a light heavyweight contender, toyed with Chicago's Sonny Ray through nine rounds and then scored a technical knockout in the tenth and last round of their bout at Chicago Stadium tonight.

So Lord Alanbrooke didn't mean to say that General Eisenhower was playing golf when the war was hanging in the balance, although that is what was clearly implied in his statement that the Commander in Chief was on the links at Rheims during the Battle of the Bulge.
The supply and demand of office space in New York continues in close balance, Julien J. Studley, office leasing specialist, points out in a revised edition of "New Office Buildings in New York City."

Rubber prices soared to new highs for the life of the contracts yesterday on the Commodity Exchange of New York. Futures rose 120 to 250 points (hundredths of a cent a pound). The volume, 2,100 tons was the second largest of the year.
NEW DELHI, India, Nov. 11 -- India has sent Peiping another reminder about the Chinese Communist offer to release ten Indian policemen who were captured in Ladakh last month.
THE ideal woman of the New York Department of Air Pollution Control is the woman who complains.

VAIDEN, Miss., Nov. 11 (AP) -- Judge Henry Rodgers declined today to dismiss a murder indictment against Robert Lee Goldsby. At the request of the defense, he ordered a new trial in Jackson the week of Dec. 7.
PARIS, Nov. 11 -- French war veterans boycotted Armistice Day ceremonies today in protest against the Government's stringent policies on pensions.
PARIS, Nov. 11 -- Right-wing opponents of President de Gaulle's efforts to end the war with the Algerian rebels indicated today that they were not giving up the fight.

New York State has run out of subsidy funds for low-income public housing construction and there will be no additional state-aided projects until more money is voted, the vice chairman of the New York City Housing Authority, said yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 11--India's border dispute with Communist China will be the main order of business when President Eisenhower visits New Delhi next month, diplomatic sources here believe.

IN nearly all bridge hands played at trump contracts the declarer tries to trump some of his losing cards in dummy and the defenders try to prevent him from doing so. The defenders lead trumps when it seems likely that the dummy can win one or more tricks by trumping.
FREEHOLD, N. J., Nov. 11 -- A rigged classroom quiz in a high school here, staged by a faculty member, has shocked the entire student body into sharp awareness of what ethical conduct in volves.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 11 (AP) -- The Government's Executive Branch has 3 per cent fewer civilian employes than it had five years ago, but it pays them 30 per cent more.
The police questioned 100 persons and made a house-to-house canvass yesterday seeking clues to the booby-trap bombing of a Staten Island housewife.
LONDON, Nov. 11 (AP) -- The giant Courtaulds, Ltd., rayon concern, plans to expand its North American operation -- possibly to include chemicals and plastics.
THE Sarmi showing yesterday brought a temporary halt to the spring 1960 collections of American designers.

THE problem posed by an uncontrolled birth rate in already crowded portions of the world was examined thoroughly, forthrightly and tactfully last night in a program entitled "Population Explosion" over Channel 2. The presentation was one in a series known as "C. B. S. Reports."

Governor Rockefeller declared last night that if Senator John F. Kennedy got the Democratic nomination for President it would not be because of, or in spite of, his religion but "because he is an attractive, popular and useful public servant."
FLORAL PARK, L. I., Nov. 11 -- The planned widening of Jericho Turnpike through this Nassau County village is causing concern among many merchants who will be forced to give up their businesses.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Nov. 11 -- Huckleberry Finn's talent for taking extended leaves from school cannot be copied by Eddie Hodges, the boy who is playing Huck Finn in the movie being made at the Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer studio. For Eddie is followed by his school.
WARSAW, Nov. 11 -- The Polish Government was reported today to have brought a former Stallnist back from diplomatic exile and to have placed him in a high army post.

Now that the TV quiz show investigations have put a spotlight on private and public morality, I wonder if the public and its representatives, our Senators and Congressmen, have any second thoughts about the morality of flooding the Allegany Reservation of Seneca Indians in southwestern New York State by building the Kinzua dam.

The pent-up fury that they had harbored for so long erupted with almost devastating effect last night as the New York Rangers demonstrated they constitute a first-rate hockey team by thrashing the Boston Bruins, 6 to 3, at Madison Square Garden.

The vocational service commission of B'nai B'rith reported yesterday that one-third of the nation's 3,300,000 college students needed at least $1,000 a year in scholarship aid "if they are to get full advantages of higher education."
BIRMINGHAM, Ala., Nov. 11 (AP) -- The Navy high command sharply criticized today proposals to strip the Joint Chiefs of Staff of command over their individual services.

Your columns on Nov. 1 reported "common-market-itis" infecting yet another public figure. Senator Mansfield follows the Rockefeller study group of last year in suggesting a Western Hemisphere common market.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 11 -- The establishment of a United Nations award to encourage an international fight against cancer was formally recommended today. The disease was said to kill more than 2,000,000 people every year.

Mrs. Fiorello H. La Guardia will be guest of honor at Tuesday's preview performance of "Fiorello!" which will benefit the Henry Street Settlement. The musical based on the life of her late husband, former Mayor of New York, is scheduled to open at the Broadhurst Theatre on Nov. 23.
Stores in the metropolitan area were crowded yesterday. and merchants generally said business was good.

BOSTON, Nov. 11 -- Southeastern Massachusetts and Cape Cod, which grow half of the nation's cranberries, faced the prospect today of having 60,000,000 pounds on hand with no place to market them. Damage to the economy in the area was described as immeasurable.

IN his first full season with the Dodgers the gifted Pete Reiser, aged 22, won the National League batting championship and was hailed with complete justification as "a second Ty Cobb." A half-season later he was hitting .381 and looked like the perfect ballplayer because he could run, throw and field with enormous skill.
Expanded community services for the mentally retarded are recommended in a study made public yesterday by the New York State Association for Mental Health.

WEST POINT, N. Y., Nov. 11 -- Before the season opened, Amy's game with Oklahoma shaped up as a contest that might well decide the national championship. Now both Army and Oklahoma have been eliminated as contenders for high national ranking.

Speaking as a particular champion of both France and Continental Europe, President de Gaulle, France's "man of destiny," has now expounded his views and policies in greater detail and broader context than ever before.

TORONTO, Nov. 11 -- Senator John J. Sparkman urged today that the public exercise greater discipline in its borrowing for consumer products less essential than housing in order to conserve credit for the home market in a period of tight money.

NEW ORLEANS, Nov. 11 (UPI) -- Senator A. S. Mike Monroney, chairman of the Senate's Aviation subcommittee, said today that he favored a "common carriage rate" such as that offered by four major airlines.
INGLEWOOD, Calif., Nov. 11 (AP) -- Charming Barbara, the defender, scored an upset by winning the third leg of the $75,000 American Trotting Classic today and forced the series into a race-off.

CHICAGO, Nov. 11 -- M. J. Rathbone said today that winning better public understanding of the problems and achievements of the oil industry would be his most important job as the new chairman of the American Petroleum Institute.

MOONACHIE, N. J., Nov. 11 -- This borough will send a tax bill to the Port of New York Authority early next year. Borough officials believe that when the authority departs from using its land only as an airport and becomes a landlord to industry, it should pay taxes.
JAKARTA, Indonesia, Nov. 11 -- A vehemently nationalistic speech by President Sukarno opening the Colombo Plan's eleventh conference here today met a mixed reception.

LONDON, Nov. 11 -- Hugh Gaitskell, Labor party leader, told newsmen covering Parliament today that the British press was now depicting him as "the Mona Lisa with the mysterious smile." "Nobody knows what goes on behind it," he said in a light-hearted speech to the Parliamentary Press Gallery's luncheon club.
ALBANY, Nov. 11 (UPI) -- New York State collected $896,031,666.18 in general taxes during the first half of the 1959-1960 fiscal year, an increase of $26,772,385.13, the Tax Department said today.

The New York City Ballet, which will open a nine-week season at the City Center on Dec. 8, will present as its major novelty a full evening program called "Pan America." This will consist of short ballets by seven choreographers to the music of nine Latin-American composers.
A young Indian physician who resigned Tuesday from Knickerbocker Hospital in a controversy over his account of an emergency amputation left this country yesterday for England.

WILLIAM KIENBUSCH has always stayed close to the sea in his work, recording in thoughtfully compressed symbols its thrust at the landscape and the landscape's retort. In his show at the Kraushaar Galleries, 1055 Madison Avenue, near Eightieth Street, he adds to his previous observations by symbolizing the experiences he had while visiting the Aegean Islands.
The White House has announced that it will present to Congress in the next session "proposals for a permanent solution of the farm program."

Thousands of rush-hour subway riders were delayed up to ten minutes yesterday morning by a series of service interruptions caused by door trouble on trains. Three such failures occurred on the IND subway and one on the BMT.

MANILA, Nov. 11 -- The Nationalist party of President Carlos P. Garcia improved its position slightly today in the contest for eight Senate seats as returns continued to come in from rural areas. Final results of all yesterday's elections are not expected until tomorrow.
Sealtest Foods, one of the "Big Three" milk distributors in the metropolitan area, announced yesterday that on Sunday it would raise the price a half-cent a quart in New York and northern New Jersey.
INDIANAPOLIS, Nov. 11 (AP) -- Indiana banks expect to be able to pay 3 per cent interest to depositors soon, as a result of a shake-up in the State Department of Financial Institutions.
NEW DELHI, Nov. 11 -- The Indian Government is preparing a guarantee to foreign enterprises that would insure payment of adequate compensation in the event of nationalization.
The latest insiders' list published by the New York Stock Exchange shows some increases in stockholdings of several corporate investors in October.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 11 -- Ahmad Shukairy, Saudi Arabia's permanent delegate to the United Nations, declared today that the Palestinian Arab refugees would resort to arms unless they were restored to their former homes, which now are in Israel.
Harvey B. Jordan has been named chairman of the general administration committee and executive vice president of United States Steel Corporation, the company announced yesterday.
A design organization has come up with an idea that promises to increase the income of a Brooklyn apartment house by $1,800 a year.

The Yankees, who have been keeping discreetly silent since their third-place finish in the 1959 American League pennant race, served notice yesterday that they were back in business and out to recoup their fortunes.

The country's major producer of cranberries and cranberry products joined the United States Food and Drug Administration yesterday in a nationwide search for berries possibly contaminated with weed-killer.

TEHERAN, Iran, Nov. 11 (Reuters) -- The Soviet Union has offered Iran an 85 per cent share of profits in return for oil-exploration rights in northern Iran on condition that foreign powers are prevented from setting up military bases here, informed sources said today.

ADD to unusual concertos: one for marimba and orchestra. It was played last night in Carnegie Hall by a personable young lady named Vida Chenoweth; it had been composed by the late Robert Kurka; it was receiving its first performance, and it was programed by Richard Korn, who was leading the Orchestra of America in its second concert devoted to American music.
JEDDAH, Saudi Arabia, Nov. 11 -- The Middle East director of the International Monetary Fund pronounced Saudi Arabia nearly restored to fiscal health today after eighteen months of austerity.

PARIS, Nov. 11--The foreign ministers of France and Britain met today to try to iron out some of their differences on East-West diplomacy and European economic affairs and to adjust to those that were irreconcilable.
LITTLEFIELD, Tex., Nov. 11 (AP) -- Negro leaders have asked this West Texas city to segregate its public schools once more.

WESTCHESTER bowmen are not killing the deer that they ought to be killing in their long special archery season, but they are doing relatively better than Adirondack gunners. The Adirondack kill is very low.
The active part of the National Horse Show ended in Madison Square Garden Tuesday night, but the struggles of the executive committee in charge remained ahead.

DALLAS, Tex., Nov. 11 -- A Treasury official today defended the department's recent action in borrowing money from individuals at 5 per cent interest. Charls E. Walker, assistant to Secretary Robert B. Anderson, said the Treasury not only was pleased with the operation but would tailor occasional future borrowings along similar lines.

The U. S. O. is the only federation of voluntary agencies designated by the military U S O through which the American people assist in serving the religious, spiritual, social, welfare, recreational and educational needs of the men and women in the Armed Forces.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 11 (AP) -- The Pennsylvania Railroad proposed today that the railroads be given a chance to solve the transportation problems of metropolitan areas.
Prices of cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange advanced 1 to 6 points yesterday. A point is equal to 5 cents a bale.
A plot of vacant land on the north side of Virgil Place, 100 feet west of Castle Hill Avenue, the Bronx, has been purchased by the New York Diocese of the Protestant Episcopal Church.
MOSCOW, Nov. 11 -- The Soviet literary world is ablaze with a new controversy over a short story that seems to express compassion for a wartime turncoat.
CHICAGO, Nov. 11 (AP) -- The report of today's livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:
HAVANA, Nov. 11 -- A virulent attack on Secretary of State Christian A. Herter and the White House was made today by Antonio Fernandez, a Havana radio commentator.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Nov. 11 -- Twenty Brazilian student leaders had some new thoughts about the United States today as a result of a dinner and discussion with Ambassador and Mrs. John Moors Cabot at the embassy residence last night.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 11 (UPI) -- President Eisenhower appointed Alan S. Boyd, a Florida utilities commissioner, today to the Civil Aeronautics Board.
TEL AVIV, Israel, Nov. 11 -Premier David Ben-Gurion has been set back in his efforts to eliminate proportional representation in Israeli elections.
DRESDEN, East Germany, Nov. 11 (Reuters) -- An East German audience warmly applauded its introduction last night to modern American opera at the European premiere here of "The Good Soldier Schweik."
BOSTON, Nov. 11 (AP) -- Publishers and union representatives met tonight for the first time since a typographical strike closed six Boston newspapers six days ago. The session lasted twenty minutes.
CHICAGO, Nov. 11 (AP) -- The long and strong bullish trend in soybean futures appeared today to have been halted or slowed by the Government's November estimate of 1959 yield.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 11 -- Pakistan proposed today the creation of an international compensatory fund to cushion the financial pressures against countries producing primary commodities.

The United States Rubber Company yesterday declared a dividend of 55 cents a share on the common stock, payable on Dec. 12 to stockholders of record of Nov. 23. The company paid 50 cents in previous quarters of this year and in 1958 and 1957. No stock dividend was declared. Directors last declared a stock dividend of 2 per cent in 1957.

Elgin Baylor, the National Basketball Association's single-game scoring record holder, and Syracuse, the team that knocked New York out of the play-offs last season, are part of the season's first N. B. A. double-header at Madison Square Garden tonight.

PRINCETON, N. J., Nov. 11 -- A 250-ton Greek portico was dedicated in Princeton Battlefield Memorial Park today, honoring the common grave of unknown American and British soldiers killed in the Battle of Princeton in 1777.

BONN, Germany, Nov. 11 (Reuters) -- Chancellor Konrad Adenauer has accepted an invitation to visit Spain, it was disclosed today in a communique issued at the conclusion of a two-day visit by the Spanish Foreign Minister, Fernando Maria Castiella y Maiz.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 11 -- Five Latin-American nations proposed today that the General Assembly ask France to reconsider her proposed atomic bomb test in the Sahara.

Bank clearings in twenty-six cities amounted to $22,277,910,000 in the week ended yesterday, Dun and Bradstreet, Inc., reported. This was 9.2 per cent lower than the $24,540,962,000 of the week before, but 10.9 per cent above the $20,094,049,000 of the 1958 period. Both the latest and preceding week included holidays, Veterans Day yesterday and Election Day the week before.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 11 -- An academic investigator has reported to Congress that there is a close historic correlation between outlays for public education and increases in personal income.

A floor in the sixty-story Chase Manhattan Bank Building under construction at Pine and Nassau Streets has been leased by E. F. Hutton Co., members of the New York Stock Exchange. The lease involved 30,000 square feet of space, which will be occupied in May, 1961.
Victoria Park, a Canadian colt owned by E. P. Taylor, beat a dozen American rivals at Aqueduct yesterday to win the forty-sixth running of the $36,000 Remsen Stakes.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 11 -- Dr. Isidor S. Ravdin said today the greatest hope for cancer cures lay in drug therapy.

A two-volume condensation of Sir Winston Churchill's six-volume history "The Second World War" will be published by Houghton Mifflin on Nov. 30 to mark the statesman's eighty-fifth birthday. The edition will contain 300,000 words from the original text and will have more than 250 photographs, many of them previously unpublished.

CHICAGO, Nov. 11 -- Some of the country's scientists are mixing moral and political views into their supposedly scientific statements on the dangers of radioactive fall-out, the president of the Carnegie Institute of Technology in Pittsburgh said today.

ALBANY, N. Y., Nov. 11 (AP) -- The State Public Service Commission approved today the sale of the L. D. Dickinson Motor Coach Lines of Owego for $15,000 to the Capitol Bus Company, Inc., of Harrisburg, Pa.
GENEVA, Nov. 11 -- An agreement on holding a new conference of experts on the detection of underground nuclear explosions was within sight today.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, Nov. 11 (Reuters) -- Nations of the Arab League have proposed a joint Arab-owned oil pipeline and improved financial terms for countries granting oil concessions, it was reported to the Lebanese Government today.
A condemnation award of $2,403,000 has been made on a Lincoln Square building whose owners had set its value, for tax purposes, at only $1,100,000.

It's a fortunate thing for the rest of the National Football League and the New York Giants in particular that Pittsburgh's Bobby Layne is permitted to throw only one football at a time. Bobby throws to virtually anybody who is eligible.
Two men were rescued from seventh-story window sills of a building at 101 West Seventy-eighth Street yesterday by firemen using aerial and scaling ladders.
CHICAGO, Nov. 11 (UPI) -A spokesman for the American Dental Association charged tonight that some television toothpaste commercials were just as "rigged" as the quiz shows exposed by Congress.
CHICAGO, Nov. 11 -- The Link-Belt Company announced today that what it termed the world's longest permanent cross-country belt conveyor system was in operation in Ada, Okla.
LONDON, Nov. 11 -- A conflict over Britain's defense policy reached the House of Commons today.

NEW ROCHELLE, N. Y., Nov. 11 -- New Rochelle High School overpowered the Archbishop Stepinac High School eleven of White Plains, 40 -- 13, at McKenna Field today. The Huguenots are undefeated and untied in four games.
Deaths on New York highways totaled 231 during October -- the highest monthly toll in the state's history.
The compulsory registration of firearms purchased by persons under 21 years of age was favored yesterday by a Hi-Y Youth and Government Assembly at City Hall.

Betty Comden and Adolph Green, who were to star in "A Party" on station WNTA-TV's "The Play of the Week," have canceled plans to present the program of songs and sketches. It was to have been televised for seven performances some time this month.

THE comparison is inescapable: Norton Cooper's new play, "The Ballad of Jazz Street," which had its premiere alst night at the Greenwich Mews Theatre on West Thirteenth Street, bears some resemblance, thematic and otherwise, to Lorraine Hansberry's hit drama, "A Raisin in the Sun."
The age-old prayer for the abolition of war was voiced again yesterday as the United States observed Veterans Day, the forty-first anniversary of the end of World War I.
SAVANNAH, Ga., Nov. 11 UPI) -- Six monkeys that escaped from shipping cages turned Savannah's Union Railroad Station into bedlam today.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 11 (AP) -- President Eisenhower seems certain to extend the United States moratorium on nuclear weapons testing beyond the end of this year. The main reason is that negotiations with the Soviet Union for a permanent, inspected agreement are making some progress.

The nation's freight forwarders predicted yesterday defeat for the long haul truckers in their efforts to upset an Interstate Commerce Commission ruling of last September. The ruling enabled the forwarders to establish volume rates for a broad list of commodities shipped between New York and Chicago by way of "piggyback."

SAN JOSE, Costa Rica, Nov. 10 -- President Mario Echandi Jimenez said today that Costa Rica was completing negotiations to sell her surplus arms to a United States company in return for farm tractors.
Record sales and earnings were chalked up by the Columbia Broadcasting System, Inc. in the first nine months of this year.
AS a television viewer Joseph Stone never watched a quiz program. As an assistant District Attorney, he has probably watched more quiz shows via kinescope in recent months than anyone else.
TUNIS, Nov. 11 -- The Algerian nationalists are meeting here to consider President Charles de Gaulle's new invitation to them to come to Paris.

ST. LOUIS, Nov. 11 -- The competition between private and public colleges for students was emphasized today with a recommendation by the head of one of the country's largest private institutions that public colleges increase their tuition.
WHILE more and more Americans are sitting on floor pillows around hibachi charcoal burners, many Japanese are becoming devoted to Western tables set with stainless steel flatware.
GLEN COVE, L. I., Nov. 11 -Pete Mickens scored four touchdowns and an equal number of' extra points as Glen Cove' crushed Port Washington. 54--7, in its closing game of thei Iseason today.

LOS ANGELES, Nov. 11 -- Southern California Republican leaders braced today for Governor Rockefeller's first foray into the domain of Vice President Richard M. Nixon. The Governor left New York tonight to begin his visit tomorrow.
The National Maritime Union and the American Merchant Marine Institute will begin discussions next Thursday reviewing wage and overtime provisions of existing contracts.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 11--Visits with Generalissimo Francisco Franco of Spain and President Habib Bourguiba of Tunisia were added today to President Eisenhower's goodwill tour.

BONN, Germany, Nov. 11 -- The gap between Chancellor Konrad Adenauer and many West Germans on the question of relations with France has been illustrated by the reaction to French seizure of a West German freighter last week.

There's little doubt that hair, the mammalian equivalent of feathers, has been one of the most interesting and fussed over appurtenances in human history. It has been used by women to attract. It has been cultured, sculptured and faked -- and raised and sold.
PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 11 -- The American Philosophical Society dedicated a $2,000,000 library building today at the opening of its autumn general meeting.

Fanny May has become quite a big girl in the over-the-counter market. Fanny May is the nickname for the Federal National Mortgage Association. The agency, established in 1938, is a major factor in the market for secondary mortgages -- that is, it buys mortgages, thus providing lenders with new funds to assist in financing housing.

ALBANY, Nov. 11 (AP) -- Associated Industries of New York State will hold a special meeting here next Wednesday and Thursday to examine Governor Rockefeller's record in fulfilling his pledges to improve the state's business climate.
The city's Protestant Council pledged "all of its strength" yesterday in fighting Mayor Wagner's renewed proposal to legalize and tax off-track betting on horse races.
The Angels Ball, sponsored by the New York Section of the National Council of Jewish Women, was held last night in the Grand Ballroom of the Astor.
LONDON, Nov. 11 -- Morgan Phillips, Secretary of the Labor party, urged the party tonight to intensify its educational and propaganda work.
INDIANAPOLIS, Nov. 11 (UPI) -- President Eisenhower's Administration was accused of "unjustified secrecy" today in a report by a committee of Sigma Delta Chi, national journalism fraternity.

Three teen-agers, using a zip-gun and a loaded .25-caliber pistol last night held up two stores in Queens. Two of the suspects were arrested minutes after the second hold-up and the third was seized at his home. The police said they were seeking a fourth teen-ager who had been a lookout.
A task force of four rowboats sailed against seven pelicans at Bronx Zoo yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 11 -- Secretary of Labor James P. Mitchell ate his "hat" -- a white one, with mocha icing and a chocolate band -- on the steps of the Labor Department today, because October's employment figures were not what he had predicted.
The three-man team that will carry most of the Government's hopes for settling the marathon steel dispute was reconvened yesterday by President Eisenhower.
Although 71 per cent of New Yorkers have hospital insurance, many who are hospitalized are not using it, according to the 1958-59 report of the Hospital Council of Greater New York, issued yesterday.

The Air Force will be "at war" with the New York Air National Guard Saturday and Sunday in an operational readiness exercise. The area "under attack" will range from the Eastern Seaboard to the Mississippi River.
ONLY very young children believe that Santa Claus manages Christmas all by himself. The rest of us are aware that he has helpers.
Subpoena, the little dog that lives in a hole in front of Brooklyn Supreme Court; evaded her evictors yesterday, but her puppy, Warrant, was not so agile.

The Public Service Commission announced yesterday that it had authorized the Consolidated Edison Company of New York to invite bids on $75,000,000 of 30-year first refunding mortgage bonds. The regulatory body also authorized Rochester Telephone Corporation to issue $5,000,000 of preferred stock.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 11 (AP) -- The President's daughter-in-law, Mrs. John S. Eisenhower, is brushing up on geography and buying Christmas presents early and is "terribly excited" about her forthcoming eleven-country trip with the President.

THE butternut is one of the more popular of the winter squashes now so readily available. It is easily identified by its smooth, light tan skin. its bell-shape and elongated neck. First introduced about a decade ago, it has zoomed to high favor with those who cook and those who eat it.

Friends of the late Noel Straus gathered in the WQXR Concert Hall of The New York Times yesterday morning to pay tribute to the former music critic of The Times. The memorial took the form of an hour-long program in which music said the first and last word.
A mature view of foreign aid, but one that unfortunately is not yet fully accepted everywhere in the United States, was presented to the Colombo Plan nations by President Sukarno of Indonesia.
Every uniformed policeman has been ordered by Commissioner Stephen P. Kennedy to arrest known gamblers on sight.
LONDON, Nov. 11 -- Buyers came in strongly at the start of a new bookkeeping account today and stock market prices here advanced on a broad front.

LAUREL, Md., Nov. 11 -- Capt. Harry Guggenheim's Bald Eagle won the eighth running of the Washington D. C. International today. One of two United States representatives in the mile and a half event on the turf, Bald Eagle finished two and a half lengths ahead of the French representative, Francois Dupre's Midnight Sun.

FISKE KIMBALL was one of the great bulls in America's china shop of art. He lived with tremendous flair and he died on the brink of madness. His story is one of the most interesting, one of the most revealing, that you can find in all the annals of this country's adventures with getting, holding and displaying the masterpieces of the past.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 11 (UPI) -- David Hearne, 21-year-old son of Irish Ambassador John J. Hearne, was accused today of hitting and killing a woman pedestrian with his automobile.

Stocks gave one of their customary holiday performances yesterday, with volume down and prices litle changed. The investing public has not yet grown used to the decision of the New York Stock Exchange, made in 1954, to remain open on Veterans Day.
The roster of "Billy Barnes Revue" will undergo a drastic change next Tuesday night at the Carnegie Hall Playhouse. With the exception of Virginia de Luce, the entire troupe will be replaced.
A call went out yesterday for a Dec. 4 meeting of the Queens Democratic Executive Committee to fill the county leadership, vacant for six months.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 11 -- The Moscow radio has been taking a strong pro-Castro, anti-United States line in its comments on recent events in Cuba.

MADRID, Nov. 11 -- President Eisenhower was invited to visit Madrid in a letter from General Franco conveyed by Fernando Maria Castiella, Spanish Foreign Minister, who visited the President briefly in London Aug. 24.

Yale dressed eleven of its Bulldogs in the orange and black stripes of the Princeton Tiger for yesterday's football drill at New Haven. To add to the realism, the reserves impersonating Saturday's opponents taped numbers to their jerseys that corresponded to those worn by Princeton's key operatives.
A federal bond issue to provide low-interest mortgage money was proposed yesterday by Louis Sachar, a real estate developer and former economic adviser to Mayor Wagner.

Frederic Soderberg of Albany, who is 57 years old and can be seen easily in any crowd because he is 6 feet 5 inches tall, is an example of how a person can get into canine affairs up to his hips through buying a good dog.
The appointment of new vice presidents was announced yesterday by the American Telephone Telegraph Company and its wholly-owned operating subsidiary, the New York Telephone Company.
VIENTIANE, Laos, Nov. 12 (AP) -- Dag Hammarskjold arrived in this troubled kingdom today and was hailed by the Government for making the visit despite the opposition of the Communist bloc.

The Borden Company yesterday announced a half-cent-aquart rise in the price of milk to retail stores. It was the second major distributor to do so and the third of the "Big Three" companies indicated it, too, would make a similar announcement.

Frank H. Leslie, president of Leslie, Catlin Co., Inc., received the ninth annual award of the textile section of the New York Board of Trade at a luncheon at the WaldorfAstoria Hotel yesterday. The award is for outstanding service to the textile industry.

An issue of $13,000,000 of revenue bonds of Marina del Rey, Los Angeles County, Calif., will be offered at public bidding on Dec. 3. The issue will be dated Dec. 1, 1959, and will come due serially on Dec. 1, 1999.
LONDON, Nov. 12 -- President de Gaulle's prospective visit to Britain was welcomed here today as an opportunity to strengthen the ties of friendship between this country and France.
The statement of former producer Albert Freedman in connection with quiz program fixing is most shocking.

HONG KONG, Nov. 12 -- Communist China announced today plans for returning ten Indian policemen captured last month in Ladakh in northwestern India. The Chinese Ministry of Foreign Affairs notified the Indian Ambassador in Peiping, G. P. Parthasarathi, that Chinese frontier guards were prepared to hand back the captives tomorrow, Saturday or Sunday.

Earnings of Aluminium, Ltd., in the third quarter of 1959 were well below the 1958 level but international aluminum markets are becoming "progressively stronger," according to a report issued yesterday by Nathanael V. Davis, president.

Mayor Wagner directed yesterday that formal charges of judicial misconduct be filed against Magistrate Anthony E. Maglio of Brooklyn. The Mayor also asked that Mr. Maglio be suspended pending the disposition of the charges.
CONCORD, N. H., Nov. 12 (AP) -- The nation's first fulltime Nixon-for-President office was opened here today. This state will hold the first Presidential primary in 1960.
MOSCOW, Nov. 12 -"Marty," the first major American-made film shown here since World War II, is playing to large audiences and has impressed the critics.

TRENTON, Nov. 12 -- Gov. Robert B. Meyner declared today that a new tax must be imposed if the state was to provide financial aid to commuter rail lines. He said the only other means of preventing deterioration of railroad passenger service was Federal subsidies.

LONDON, Nov. 12 -- Queen Elizabeth II today named Viscount Dunrossil, the former Speaker of the House of Commons, to be Governor General of Australia, but the appointment promptly ran into questions from the Labor Opposition.
Dave Charnley, the 24-year-old British and Empire lightweight champion, figures his best chance to lift Joe Brown's world championship lies in a sustained attack.

Phineas T. Barnum, the eccentric who "parlayed" cynicism and a sense of fun into more than one fortune, is the subject of a biography by Irving Wallace called "The Fabulous Showman." To be published Monday by Knopf, it presents Barnum as the public man, circus impresario and swindler and the private man, whose family life was just as bizarre.
PARIS, Nov. 12--France and Britain proclaimed tonight the achievement of a better understanding on their respective policies for European organization and East-West affairs.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Nov. 12 -- Leading Social Democrats headed by Premier Tage Erlander have devised a formula that would allow research on atomic weapons to begin while putting off a decision to make the weapons until 1963.
The Government tried to show in Federal Court yesterday that the meeting on Nov. 14, 1957, at the estate of the late Joseph Barbara Sr. in Apalachin, N. Y., was a planned event.
HARROW - ON - THE - HILL, England, Nov. 12 -- Sir Winston Churchill came back to Harrow this evening to join in the old school's traditional song fest.

Action by the Food and Drug Administration against aminotriazole, a weed killer used by cranberry growers, would be "relatively unimportant" to sales of the American Cyanamid Company, Dr. Wilbur G. Malcolm, president, said yesterday.
DINING out with parents is almost automatically an exciting experience for a child. But, if the restaurant is exotic, as many are in New York, it can be doubly interesting.
Alfred George (Alf) Pike, a versatile performer when he was with the New York Rangers, yesterday was named coach of the National Hockey League club to replace the hospitalized Phil Watson.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 12 (AP) -- President Eisenhower called today for a many-sided approach to the problem of creating increased economic and social opportunities for the aged.
The United Aircraft Corporation reported yesterday that its net earnings in the three months ended on Sept. 30 declined to $7,393,032 from $8,126,824 in the 1958 quarter.

WHEREVER minks meet and mingle, Anna Maximilian Potok is a name to be reckoned with. The diminutive blonde head of the house of Maximilian, 20 West Fifty-seventh Street, brings the third generation a reputation for quality and fashion in fur.
RIVERHEAD, L. I., Nov. 12 -- Sheriff Charles R. Dominy, seeking the post of Suffolk County Republican leader, detailed his proposed code of ethics for public offices today.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 12 (UPI) -- Premier Felix HouphouetBoigny of the Ivory Coast told President Eisenhower today that the African member nations of the French Community want to develop close ties with the Western world.
General Sessions Judge Jacob Gould Schurman announced yesterday that he would retire Dec. 31.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 12 (AP) -- The 21-year-old son of the Irish Ambassador is scheduled to appear at a coroner's inquest tomorrow in the traffic death of a woman pedestrian.

BONN, Germany, Nov. 12 -The Soviet protest against West Germany's plan to build a radio station in West Berlin was seen here tonight as part of a campaign to separate the beleaguered city from the Federal Republic.

The twelve-story and penthouse apartment building at 782 West End Avenue, northeast corner of Ninety-eighth Street, has been sold by the 782 West End Avenue Corporation. The building, containing forty-four apartments, occupies a plot 50 by 100 feet.
The steel union's highest policy body voted unanimously yesterday to renew its 116-day strike if no industry-wide settlement is reached before the Taft-Hartley Act injunction expires Jan. 26.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 12 (AP) -- The Atomic Energy Commission announced today the appointment of a twelve-member advisory committee in its investigation of peaceful uses for nuclear explosives.

The 16-year-old driver of a stolen car that killed a Queens couple and one of their two children ten days ago was judged a juvenile delinquent in Queens Children's Court yesterday, but was sentenced to an institution for older youths.
A Board of Education official's alleged "lack of enthusiasm" for cultural things was blamed yesterday for the possible discontinuance this season of Equity Community Theatre activities.
THE Dorian Chorale, a professional group devoted to music for small chorus, gave a concert at Town Hall last night. It showed the charm of the particular field the chorus has staked out for itself.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 12 -- Israeli and Arab delegates clashed today in a tense debate on the Palestinian refugees. At one point Michael Comay of Israel interrupted Ahmad Shukairy of Saudi Arabia to defend the memory of the late Dr. Chaim Weizmann, first President of Israel.

SAO PAULO, Brazil, Nov. 12 -- President Juscelino Kubitschek said today that the bad feeling that exploded during the 1958 South American trip of Vice President Richard M. Nixon "unfortunately still persists."
The New York City Transit Authority in its report for the fiscal year ended last June 30 said:

BOSTON, Nov. 12 (AP) -- A charge against Alan Freed, the disk jockey, of inciting a riot was placed on file today by Superior Court Judge Lewis Goldberg. The action in effect "pigeonholes" the charge.
The commander of all military forces of the Western Allies in the Atlantic warned last night that the West must not relax its guard.

CHICAGO, Nov. 12 -- Arthur H. Dean of New York, attorney, diplomat and civic leader, was elected today chairman of the English-speaking Union of the United States. He was chosen by the board of directors gathered here for the union's two-oay annual meeting in the Ambassador West Hotel.

William P. Rosensohn, the promoter of the Ingemar Johansson-Floyd Patterson heavyweight championship fight last June 26, admitted yesterday that he had violated regulations of the New York State Athletic Commission.
The Metropolitan Opera is polling its audiences on whether they would like to hear Mozart's "Le Nozze di Figaro" sung as "The Marriage of Figaro" -in English.

IN his introduction to Nicholas Carone's exhibition at the Staempfli Gallery, 47 East Seventy-seventh Street, the philosopher William Barrett pays his respects to what he terms the first "American Style" in painting, adding that our painters are "the most live and kicking thing in the whole American culture."
There's a football game on tap tomorrow that, on its level, carries the same import as the Louisiana State-Mississippi and Syracuse-Penn State matches of the last two Saturdays.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 12 -The Air Force has warned defense officials that proposed spending limitations would weaken its contribution to the North Atlantic Treaty forces in Western Europe.
William Ryan's song recital last night at Carnegie Recital Hall showed considerable improvement over his debut program last spring in the same hall.

An off-Madison Avenue advertising agency has been selected to handle the 1960 Presidential campaign for the Democratic party.
" CARMEN" was last night's opera at the Metropolitan, with five performers making first appearances of the season and a Frasquita singing her role for the first time with the company.

The Studebaker-Packard Corporation reportedly is negotiating to buy the farm equipment business of Oliver Corporation. Harold E. Churchill, president of StudebakerPackard, commenting on reports that such negotiations were under way, said yesterday:
SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 12 -A national Jewish cultural foundation and a council of Jewish cultural agencies was proposed here today.

LONG BEACH, Calif., Nov. 11 (UPI) -- Senator Stuart Symington, Democrat of Missouri, proposed today a broad farm bill aimed at helping the small farmer. He disclosed his program in a speech before some 2,000 members of the National Grange.

SKI clothes may soon reach the point where they are worn as much off the slopes as on. This is Ohrbach's happy notion. Its new collection of indoor and outdoor ski fashions has been selected both here and in nine countries abroad was previewed to the press yesterday with this in mind.
A 16-year-old girl student at Queens Vocational High School was held in $2,500 bail in Manhattan Night Court last night on a charge of assaulting her teacher.

NEW DELHI, India, Nov. 12 -- The Indian Communist party split and discredited because of Communist Chinese aggression against India's northern frontier is groping for a formula to regain its strength. Most informed Indians feel the party will not find it.

MOSCOW, Nov. l2 -- Details of the Soviet notes to the Western Big Three requesting that they block West German plans for setting up a state-operated radio station in West Berlin were made public today.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 12 (AP) -- The Soviet Union made major gains in mineral production last year but the United States continued to lead the world by a good margin, the Bureau of Mines reported today.
ROME, Nov. 12--The United Nations Food and Agriculture Organization will open a campaign next year to raise the living standards of the Mediterranean basin by improving agricultural methods.

LONDON, Nov. 12 -- A Solomonlike decision announced by Prime Minister Harold Macmillan today promises to quiet, for twenty years at least, the bitter, forty-four-year-old controversy between London and Dublin over the Lane art collection.

TUNIS, Nov. 12 -- Informed quarters here conveyed the impression today that Algerian nationalists were favorably impressed by President Charles de Gaulle's invitation to come to Paris and were likely to accept the invitation.

The Committee on Slum Clearance submitted to Mayor Wagner yesterday a report on published statements that sponsors of two slum-clearance projects had used more than $400,000 in rents in ways contrary to their agreements with the city.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 12 -There were indications today that Dr. Charles Louis Critchfield, newly appointed director of the Pentagon's Advanced Research Projects Agency, was reconsidering his acceptance of the appointment announced last week.

The General Electric Research Laboratory made public yesterday the details of its method for making artificial industrial diamonds.
Cranberries and cranberry sauce with an official clean bill of health may be available in the New York region by early next week.

President Eisenhower's Music Committee of the People to People Program will present gifts to each member of the Polish State Folk Ballet before tonight's performance at the City Center. Mrs. Jouett Shouse will make the presentation.

Factory and store sales of television sets, picture tubes and radios in the first nine months of this year were much higher than in the 1958 period, according to a report yesterday by the Electronic Industries Association. Most important

LONDON, Nov. 12 -- Even though he is now a peer and has been named Governor General of Australia, Viscount Dunrossil is not likely to have left behind forever the nickname "Shakes." He acquired it -- a shortening of Shakespeare -- as a student at Edinburgh University after World War I.

The election of Kenneth H. Hoover and Charles B. Wade Jr. as vice presidents of R. J. Reynolds Tobacco Company was announced yesterday. Mr. Hoover is director of research and Mr. Wade personnel manager of the company. Both are members of the board.

Mayor Wagner assailed Controller Lawrence E. Gerosa yesterday for disseminating "erroneous information" about possible cuts in the proposed 1960 capital budget now being considered by the Board of Estimate.
WARSAW, Nov. 12 (Reuters) -- More work and less pay is likely to be the lot of Polish workers in 1960. Piotr Jaroszewicz, a Deputy Premier, said yesterday.

The International Bank for Reconstruction and Development (World Bank) has made two loans amounting to $44,000,000 to the two largest steel companies in Japan in order to assist them in their modernization and expansion programs, it was announced yesterday.

As part of the effort to raise funds for the construction of a new gymnasium at St. David's School, the parents association is sponsoring a private film party on Dec. 4. The event, attendance at which is by invitation, will be held at the Barbizon Plaza.

SPICED fruits have received more attention recently than is usually accorded them. The reason has been that they are one of the more satisfactory substitutes for the cranberries New Yorkers have been advised not to use while tests for possible contamination are being carried on.

The nursing shortage in New York City hospitals has recently been receiving a great deal of newspaper publicity. Most reports focus on the need for the professional nurse and indicate little understanding of the position of the trained practical nurse on today's nursing team.
