Despite its role as the solid favorite, Harvard expects a rough time tomorrow in its football game at Brown.

Any hope entertained by the New York Football Giants that two of their quarterbacks, Charley Conerly and George Shaw, would be available for Sunday's contest against the Pittsburgh Steelers at Yankee Stadium was dispelled yesterday.
Mrs. Rae Lopez was given a party and birthday cake yesterday to mark an important anniversary -- her ninth year without heroin.
FRANKFURT, Germany, Nov. 12 (AP) -- Two men accused of Nazi crimes were arrested today after dodging the law twelve years.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange rose 9 to 16 points (45 to 80 cents a bale) yesterday.

Member bank average borrowings increased $82,000,000 to $908,000,000 in the week ended Wednesday, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday. Excess reserves increased $94,000,000 to $472,000,000. This produced a $12,000,000 decrease to $436,000,000 in average net borrowed reserves -- excess reserves less borrowings.
BRUSSELS, Belgium, Nov. 12 August de Schryver, Minister for the Belgium Congo and Ruanda-Urundi, announced that a state of emergency was proclaimed today in Ruanda.
LOS ANGELES, Nov. 12 -Governor Rockefeller brought his undeclared campaign for the Presidency into the back yard of his only discernible Republican rival today.
MOSCOW, Nov. 12 -- A Russion -built helicopter was flown to the Kremlin yesterday to be photographed with Premier Khrushchev.
JOGJAKARTA, Indonesia, Nov. 12 -- Indonesia recommended today that the Colombo Plan expand its membership.

With the East-West summit meeting postponed till spring, the Soviets nevertheless continue their drive to impose their own unilateral solution of the German and Berlin problems based on a second and this time fivefold partition of Germany.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 12 -The United States Chamber of Commerce and the labor federation joined today in defense of one thing they have in common -- members who pay tax-deductible dues.
NEWARK, Nov. 12 -- A second legal attack on legislation banning Sunday sales of clothing, home and office furnishings, appliances and building materials was begun today.

LOS ANGELES, Nov. 12 -The Republican National Chairman, Senator Thruston B. Morton of Kentucky, expressed the hope today that Governor Rockefeller and Vice President Richard M. Nixon would not meet in a California primary fight.

WISCONSIN RAPIDS, Wis., Nov. 12 -- Vice President Richard M. Nixon said tonight that anyone urging a resumption of nuclear weapon testing was ignorant of the facts.
ROME, Nov. 12 -- James C. Hagerty, White House press secretary, flew here today with a party of forty to make arrangements for President Eisenhower's arrival and stay in Rome Dec. 4-6.
KANSAS CITY, Mo., Nov. 12 (UPI) -- More than 15,000 delegates gathered here today to open the four-day National Catholic Youth convention.
Two men associated with Banton L. Wyckoff when he managed run-down tenements of mysterious ownership were named in Housing Court yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 12 -- The formulae for a glowing future, with "points" ranging from five upward, which most politicians are forever proposing, omit even mention of a trend which, if unregulated, will crowd the planet by 2000 A. D. with millions more people than its resources can provide for.

BOSTON, Nov. 12 -- Secretary of Labor James P. Mitchell said today that the time had come for contract negotiators to recognize that the public interest occupied a third chair at the bargaining table.

The nation's stocks of gasoline declined by 347,000 barrels in the week ended on last Friday, according to the American Petroleum Institute. At the week-end, total supplies were 175,800,000 barrels, compared with 176,147,000 a week earlier and 169,210,000 a year ago.
The Standardbred Owners Association yesterday proposed pre-race testing of all harness horses competing at the eight tracks in New York State.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 12 -Mrs. Dwight D. Eisenhower was the guest of honor today at a "Mamie pink" luncheon in observance of her sixtythird birthday Saturday. Her favorite color dominated the festivities, even to the choice of pink table linen, rose wine and pink ice cream and cake.

There is more to diplomacy than conversations in palaces. Negotiations are important, but they aren't the whole thing. His name is John Moors Cabot and, as may be imagined, he comes from Boston.

HAVANA, Friday, Nov. 13 -Premier Fidel Castro, in a radiotelevision talk than ran over last midnight, attacked the press of the United States and the "vested interests" of that country as "enemies" carrying on a campaign against his Cuban revolution.

The Rev. Dr. Julius Mark suggested yesterday that the National Conference of Christians and Jews had shifted to an attack on racial bigotry at the expense of its original campaign for inter-religious brotherhood.

TORONTO, Nov. 12 -- The United States economic outlook appears to be good as far ahead as 1961, but it is important to prevent too rapid an accumulation of debt, President Eisenhower's chief economic adviser said here today.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 12 (AP) -- The Civil Aeronautics Board announced today a reorganization designed to improve the investigation of airplane accidents.

NEW CITY, N. Y., Nov. 12 -- The state can now boast of having a mail-woman who brooks no delay from snow, rain, heat or gloom of night in the swift completion of the Post Office Department's appointed rounds.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 12 -Panelists discussing the treatment of acute leukemia agreed today that recent drugs had prolonged the lives of young victims of the disease.

The leader of 10,000 teamsters in northern New Jersey promised a Federal court yesterday that rank-and-file rebels would receive representation on the union election committee as an insurance against "rigging."

Production activities have been accelerated to establish "Motel" on Broadway the week of Jan. 11. Siobhan McKenna and Myron McCormick will be starred in the Thomas W. Phipps play, said to resemble "Grand Hotel" in its format.

SYDNEY, Australia, Nov. 12 (AP) -- Two Canada Cup stars and an Australian playing on his favorite course tied for the first-round lead today in the 54hole tune-up for next week's international golf matches in Melbourne.
MOSCOW, Nov. 12 -- Soviet newspaper men heard themselves acclaimed as the "experienced helpers" of the Communist party today at the beginning of their first nation-wide congress.

MANILA, Nov. 12 -- Tardy returns from remote areas of the Philippines added gradually today to the strength of President Carlos P. Garcia's Nationalist party in the Senate race. However, four Opposition candidates were among the leaders for the eight seats at stake.
AUGUSTA, Ga., Nov. 12 -President Eisenhower arrived here from Washington shortly after noon today to begin a week of golfing and relaxation and a minimum of routine work on the next Federal budget.
A new depth indicator that can be installed anywhere on a small boat has been brought out by the Sonar Radio Corporation of Brooklyn. It is small and light enough to be held in one hand.

DALLAS, Nov. 12 (UPI) -J. W. Bateson, a wealthy contractor who owns the Dallas American Association baseball franchise, today withdrew his application for membership in the new Continental League because there wasn't "enough enthusiasm" for it.

MARSHFIELD, Wis., Nov. 12 (AP) -- Senator John F. Kennedy of Massachusetts carried his pre-Presidential campaign tour into Wisconsin's dairyland today with more criticism of the Administration farm program and a call for some original Democratic thinking on the subject.

One hundred and seventy-six more persons were arrested in gambling raids in the twentyfour-hour period ended at midnight Wednesday, bringing the total arrests to 659. The drive against gambling began Monday.

LAUREL, Md., Nov. 12 (AP)--The two-horse spill in the Washington, D. C., International at Laurel was "entirely unavoidable," Steward Joseph Flanagan said today.

Rubber futures soared to new highs for the life of the contracts yesterday on the Commodity Exchange of New York. The rise during the past two trading days has been more than 3 cents a pound. Yesterday's gain was 90 to 200 points (hundredths of a cent a pound).

CAMDEN, N. J., Nov. 12 (AP) -- Clermont Stable's Rick City closed with a powerful rush t. win the $20,000 added Princeton Handicap at Garden State Park today as the 1959 racing season ended in New Jersey.
The medical superintendent of Greenpoint Hospital rode an ambulance yesterday to help treat a youth whose left leg had been pinned in an elevator shaft.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 12 -The movement of inter-city freight by trucks declined more last week than in any previous week this year, not counting those in which there were holidays, the American Trucking Associations estimated today.
BONN, Germany, Nov. 12 -Finance Minister Franz Etzel proposed today a record federal budget of 41,900,000,000 marks for 1960.
SCARSDALE, N. Y., Nov. 12 -- The growing Democratic town organization called today for a major revision of Scarsdale's nonpartisan political system.

LONDON, Nov. 12 -- Derick Heathcoat Amory, Chancellor of the Exchequer, made an optimistic report tonight on Britain's prosperity and her prospects for the future. But he cautioned against renewed inflation.

SANTIAGO, Chile, Nov. 12 -The Andes Copper Mining Company officially started up a new mine today. The El Salvador is said to be the largest copperproducing operation to be initiated in the world since World War II.

TRENTON, Nov. 12 -- The Appellate Division of Superior Court today rejected a contention by Communist Poland that the bulk of a $26,474 estate left by a Passaic prelate should be distributed to his relatives in Poland.

The New York Central Railroad, the nation's second largest surface carrier, has decided to take to the air. Central announced yesterday it had acquired $5,000,000 of 5 1/2 per cent, fifteen-year convertible notes of Flying Tiger Line, Inc., pioneer in the air-freight movement and the largest all-freight air carrier in the world.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 12 -Three airlines accused the City of San Francisco and American Airlines today of improper influence on the Civil Aeronautics Board in the award to American of nonstop jet service between New York and San Francisco.

MINEOLA, L. I., Nov. 12 -- A wedge-shaped body of salt water that now occupies some of the underground formations in southeastern Queens and southwestern Nassau Counties is moving slowly inland. However, there is no immediate danger from sea-water encroachment on fresh-water supplies.
An electronic device that eyes wash-and-wear fabric and rates it exactly was put on display yesterday.
PARIS, Nov. 12 -- A golden frog entered the French Academy today at the side of Jean Rostand, writer and biologist and newest member of the "Immortals."
WASHINGTON, Nov. 12 -Following is the State Department's transcript of Secretary of State Christian A. Herter's news conference today:
BOSTON, Nov. 12--Members of the Boston Symphony Orchestra were hosts today to a group of visiting Russian composers whose works they will include in this week's concert.
BRUSSELS, Nov. 12 (UPI) -M. de Schryver told the Senate the native war grew out of a squabble at Gitarama when Watutsis murdere da Bahutu chieftain Nov. 1.

A patroness committee has been formed for the Dec. 4 preview performance of "The Fighting Cock" to benefit the United Epilepsy Association. The new Jean Anouilh comedy starring Rex Harrison is scheduled to open at the ANTA Theatre on Dec. 8.
HARTFORD, Nov. 12 -- Gov. Abraham A. Ribicoff warned the state's 169 towns today that they faced land and water shortages and "fantastic traffic snarls" if they did not undertake municipal planning.

MINEOLA, L. I., Nov. 12 -- A wedge-shaped body of salt water that now occupies some of the underground formations in southeastern Queens and southwestern Nassau Counties is moving slowly inland. However, there is no immediate danger from sea-water encroachment on fresh-water supplies.
RIO DE JANEIRO, Nov. 13 -- A Brazilian trade mission to Moscow will test the Soviet Union's ability to absorb Latin-American surpluses of raw materials and provide capital goods in return.
New capital financing in the public market will rise sharply next week on the strength of a $250,000,000 competitive sale of American Telephone and Telegraph Company debentures on Tuesday.
PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, Nov. 13 (AP) -- A five-member delegation from Cuba's revolutionary regime ended today a tour of Communist Czechoslovakia.
The General Motors Corporation announced plans yesterday to recall 12,000 workers laid off because of steel shortages. But the effects of the recent steel strike caused new unemployment elsewhere.
Twenty-four men were evacuated early yesterday morning from a BMT subway construction job under Duffy Square for treatment for carbon monoxide poisoning.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 13 (UPI) -- Secretary of Labor James P. Mitchell appointed two "watchdog" officials today to police labor-management compliance with the new union reform law that went into effect today.

LONDON Nov. 13 -- Sir Gerald Dodson, Recorder of London, sat for the last time at the Old Bailey today. He spoke proudly of the improvement in manner and decorum he had noticed in his fifty-two years in London's Central Criminal Court.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 13 -- Secretary of State Christian A. Herter sought today to disabuse the Indian Government of "any possible misconceptions" occasioned by his remarks yesterday on the border dispute between India and Communist China.

Miss Volina Fullerton Valentine, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Burnet Valentine of 530 East Eighty-sixth Street, will be one of the provisional members of the Junior League of New York honored at the league's annual Debutante Ball.

CHICAGO, Nov. 13 (AP) -Michigan State's Crawford Kennedy jogged to an easy individual triumph today as the Spartans captured their fifth successive Big Ten cross-country title with a record 17 points.

MANILA, Nov. 13 -- Charges and counter-charges of fraud and post-election vote irregularities mainly against the strong Nationalist machine of President Carlos P. Garcia, swamped the Election Commission office here today.

Directors of North American Car Corporation yesterday raised the dividend on the common shares to 35 cents a quarter from the 25 cents previously paid and voted a year-end extra of 10 cents, both payable on Dec. 10.
Penn's football team will seek to strengthen its position as the Ivy League leader in the game against Columbia at Baker Field today. The kick-off is scheduled for 1:30 P. M.
HAVANA, Nov. 13 (UPI) -- Following is the translation of the official note presented by Foreign Minister Raul Roa of Cuba to Ambassador Philip W. Bonsal today:

CLEVELAND, Nov. 13 (AP) -- The Government project to deepen the channels between the Great Lakes has resulted in higher draft limits in the upbound channel from Lake Erie to Lake Huron, the Lake Carriers Association reported today.

Champion Paper Fibre Company said yesterday it planned to acquire Montag Bros., Inc., Atlanta, Ga., and operate it as a wholly owned subsidiary. The proposal will be submitted to Montag stockholders later this month.

The Federation of the Handicapped, 211 West Fourteenth Street, New York 11, was founded in 1935 by three amputees determined to make themselves and their disabled fellows independent. It is a private rehabilitation center, supported by contributions and grants. Its services are free to all, regardless of race, color or creed.
The Federal Aviation Agency announced yesterday the allocation of $57,000,000 in airport aid to 288 construction projects in the United States and its territories.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 13 -- Supporters of Poland in the race for a seat on the Security Council have suggested that the two-year term be divided between Poland and Turkey, the candidate of the Western powers.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 13 -- It was natural for Yorkville, the lager and strudel section of Manhattan, to produce a better beer can. A German-born Yorkville woman, indeed, got a patent this week for one with a built-in opener that becomes a spout.

The scheduled visit to Mexico later this month by Mr. Mikoyan appears to signal a new Soviet drive for greater political influence and trade with Latin America. It appears likely that the Soviet visitor will also try to soothe various irritations in recent Soviet relations with some Latin nations.

Prices of prime debt investments continued generally firm yesterday with the Treasury's new high-coupon note issues -the 4 3/4s and 5s of 1964 and the 4 7/8s of 1963 -- commanding the market leadership.

ANTHONY E. MAGLIO entered a primary race against Samuel S. Leibowitz in Brooklyn in 1954 despite head-shakings by an old political hand who told him it would take a campaign costing six or seven figures to give him a chance.

The scheduled absorption of the Bayerische Motoren Werke (Bavarian Motor Works) by the Daimler Benz Corporation will increase the production capacity of Daimler Benz to 300,000 automobiles a year. In a dispatch from Munich, West Germany, appearing in The New York Times of Nov. 10, it was stated erroneously that the capacity of Daimler Benz could be raised to 3,000 cars a year as a result of that acquisition.

IT is sad but true that many a homemaker's filing system is not all it might be. This is substantiated by the number of recent letters from readers who have lost their favorite cake recipes. The request of Mrs. Mary C. Curran of New Britain, Conn., is typical. She writes:

Arthur Mayer, realty investor, has contracted to buy the one-story taxpayer occupied by a food market at 896 Jennings Street, near Southern Boulevard, the Bronx. The property, 26 by 140 feet was purchased from Jennings Market, Inc., in its first change of ownership since 1925. Schoen Spodek were the lawyers for the seller and Arthur Alfert for the buyer.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 13 -- Allen W. Dulles, director of the Central Intelligence Agency, said today that it was important to take Soviet economic ambitions and claims seriously, even though they were larded with propaganda.
TORONTO, Nov. 13 (AP) -- A new industrial association has been formed to encourage economic development through low-cost transportation on the St. Lawrence Seaway and Great Lakes.
BOSTON, Nov. 13 (UPI) -- Striking typographers voted 644 to 543 tonight to accept arbitration, thus ending an eight-day walkout that had shut down nine Boston newspapers.
AUGUSTA, Ga., Nov. 13--Roy Wilkins declared tonight that no Southerner with a record of opposition to civil rights legislation would be acceptable to Negroes as a Presidential candidate.
John C. Montana, Buffalo's Man of the Year in 1956, was a disheveled man on Nov. 14, 1957, when the police found him fleeing a meeting in Apalachin, N. Y., a jury was told yesterday.
TRENTON, Nov. 13 -- Chief Justice Joseph Weintraub of the New Jersey Supreme Court declared today that there had been a "shocking" series of money shortages in the state's municipal courts.
PARIS, Nov. 13 -- Gov. Luther H. Hodges of North Carolina indicated today a limited success for his two-week sixcity trade mission in Europe, which seeks to attract business to his state.

A spokesman for the United States chemical industry declared yesterday that acceptance of recent large Russian chemical orders would give the Soviet Union a technical shortcut far more valuable than the commodities involved.
The country's steel production rose slightly above the September level in October but fell far below the 1958 figure. In both 1959 months most steel plants were closed by the strike.
Douglas Dillon, Under Secretary of State, indicated yesterday that the State Department would approve a proposed international college and training center in Hawaii.

Consolidated net income of the Curtiss-Wright Corporation in the first nine months of 1959 dropped to $9,136,673 from $15,500,062 in the corresponding period of last year, the company reported yesterday.
INDIANAPOLIS, Nov. 13 -Vice President Richard M. Nixon asked his fellow Republicans tonight for a "moratorium on disputes within the Republican party from [next] June until election time."

The skiing season at the New York Coliseum opens today on a plastic slope under a fluorescent sky. The traditional broken legs and frost-bitten noses will be absent around the fire in the full-size Alpine lodge, however.
Gertrude Berg and Sam Levene will star in "The Wonderful World of Sholom Aleichem" on WNTA-TV's "The Play of the Week" series starting Dec. 14.

WHAT makes music American? Is it brashness, sentimentality, optimism, uncertainty, the sense of the open spaces? Is it the use of native musical elements such as jazz? Or in the last analysis is the secret rooted, as this observer believes, in the creator's emotional identification with place and people?
CHICAGO, Nov. 13 -- Roger (The Terrible) Touhy, one of Chicago's most feared gangsters during the prohibition era, was granted parole today.
CHICAGO, Nov. 13 (AP) -- The report of today's livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:

CLOTHES that draw admiration and can be worn with pleasure and ease constitute the quiet news coming out of the American ready-to-wear collections for spring 1960. This has been reported from the Seventh Avenue showings during the last two week.
For the sixty-sixth time since Edwin Booth's death in 1893, the club of The Players honored the memory of America's greatest Shakespearean actor yesterday. It was the 126th anniversary of his birth.
SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 13 -- Governor Rockefeller ended today a forty-eight-hour effort to persuade Californians that their salvation lay in his brand of Republican gospel.
The Mayor's Committee on Slum Clearance announced yesterday that the Federal Government had authorized it to proceed with the planning of the Soundview project in the Bronx.

Events today: "La Traviata" at 2 and "Il Trovatore" at 8, Metropolitan Opera; Amalia Catalani, soprano, Carnegie Recital Hall, 5:30; New York Philharmonic, conductor, Thomas L. Schippers, Leontyne Price, soprano, Carnegie Hall, 8:30; Shoshana Damari, folk songs, Town Hall, 8:30.

In these days of additives, coloring agents and other chemical ways to improve on nature by making foodstuffs grow, nourish and sell better, we need government protections against getting poisoned such as was never dreamed of by our ancestors. The Federal Food and Drug Administration is waging a continuing campaign -- as far as it can with its limited forces -- both to detect poisons and to have the Federal laws against their use enforced.
Tilden, the highest scoring team in the Public Schools Athletic League, today will send its hard-running backs against a Flushing defense that has allowed only two touchdowns this season.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 13 (AP) -- A proposed rule for denying tax deductions for lobbying expenses was denounced today by an editors' association as a threat to freedom of speech and press.
JERSEY CITY, Nov. 13 -- Day after day, week after week, No. 1706 -- a big Diesel locomotive -- dutifully shunted freight cars in the switching yards of the Jersey Central Railroad.
"Never did so many owe so much!"

A recurring theme on Broadway these days is the so-called "deep collaboration" between directors and playwrights. The situation is such that directors now are seeking added royalties through their recently organized Society of Stage Directors and Choreographers.

LAWRENCEVILLE, N. J., Nov. 13 -- Lawrenceville School's unbeaten football squad added another cheerful note to the 150th anniversary that the Lawrentians are celebrating throughout this year when it defeated The Hill School, 22 -- 14, today.

NEW DELHI, India, Nov. 13 -Ten Indian policemen who were captured by Chinese troops in eastern Ladakh last month will be turned over to an Indian border patrol there tomorrow morning, it was learned here tonight.

Some people are too harried by the press of Christmas activity to handle the addressing and mailing of their greeting cards. Two secretarial services have announced their willingness to handle such Yuletide emergencies.

KIGALI, Ruanda-Urundi, Nov. 13 (AP) -- Hundreds of huge Watusi tribesmen were fleeing today from the all-out attack of their former slaves, the smaller but more numerous Bahutus in this Belgian trust territory.

The agreement between the Kaiser Steel Corporation and the United Steelworkers of America sets up a special committee on long-range policies. It is made up of union and management representatives with three "public" members under the chairmanship of Dr. George W. Taylor, leading labor-management authority and chairman of the President's Board of Inquiry in the current steel dispute.
In a dispatch from Warsaw published in this newspaper on Nov. 6 our correspondent, A. M. Rosenthal, had this to say about Wladyslaw Gomulka, chief of the Communist party and top man in Poland:

AUGUSTA, Ga., Nov. 13 -- President Eisenhower today summoned defense and budget officials to meet here Monday in an attempt to arbitrate fund requests of the service branches. Primarily at issue is $1,000,000,000 not yet allocated in defense spending estimates for the 1961 fiscal year.

I refer to certain articles that have appeared during recent days, particularly one by Tad Szulc in The Times of Nov. 5, which might be construed as giving the misleading impression that United States capital is running out of Venezuela under pressure from political Left-Wingers, who depict United States oil and other investments there "as harmful imperialism."
WASHINGTON, Nov. 13 (UPI) -- The State Department has quietly embarked on a new test of Communist China's professed willingness to let some United States newsmen go to the Chinese mainland.
BOSTON, Nov. 13 -- Any claims that tend to create a public image of television as an educational panacea should be discouraged, the Council of Chief State School Officers warned today.

A LIVELY color scheme and distinctive, color - coordinated accessories have transformed a dungeon of a thrift shop at 1053 Third Avenue (near Sixty-second Street) into one of the most intriguing new stores on this once dingy, elshaded thoroughfare.

HUNTERS might as well be reminded one more time before the general deer season opens Monday that game protectors will be throwing road checks for loaded guns in autos. They do it every year, they are going to do it this year, and they are going to catch quite a few otherwise normal Americans riding around with death in their hands or between their knees.

MILWAUKEE, Nov. 13 -- Senator John F. Kennedy accused the Eisenhower Administration tonight of feeding American complacency for "seven gray years" while the Soviet Union was diluting this country's prestige and power throughout the world.

A long step toward the restoration of Western unity in preparation for an East-West summit meeting has been taken in frank talks between President de Gaulle and his aides and Secretary Lloyd in which, according to both sides, they reconciled their views to their mutual satisfaction.
MONTCLAIR, N. J., Nov. 13 -- Mrs. C. T. Woodford of Montclair was re-elected president of the Women's New Jersey Golf Association at the annual meeting today at the Montclair Golf Club.

AUGUSTA, Ga., Nov. 13 (AP) -- President Eisenhower told Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru of India in a birthday message tonight that many problems remained to be solved before "the realization of a just and peaceful world order."

PARIS, Nov. 13 -- The French Cabinet adopted reforms today for the Comedie Francaise that will buttress the powers of Claude Breart de Boisanger, the theatre's new administrator, at the expense of the actors.

PRINCETON, N. J., Nov. 13 -- Princeton and Yale will meet in Palmer Stadium tomorrow in the eighty-second game of their traditional football rivalry. A victory over the Tigers would keep Yale in the running for the Big Three title.

Colorado Central Power Company is offering to holders of its common stock rights to subscribe at $20 a share for 66,490 shares of additional common stock. The subscription rate is one new share for each ten held. Employes have a contingent privilege of subscribing for not more than 2,000 shares.
TULSA, Okla., Nov. 13 (AP) -- Oklahoma Baptists have approved a resolution that a church official said could be applied against prospective Roman Catholic candidates for President.
Around 8:30 every weekday morning, William Lynn McCracken boards the Staten Island ferry and gazes proudly toward lower Manhattan -- a place he considers his own special preserve.
Telephone calls threatening more bombings caused additional detectives and patrolmen to be assigned yesterday to the Port Richmond area on Staten Island.

The State Judicial Conference announced yesterday that its investigating committee would hold hearings starting Thursday on the dispute between Kings County Judges Samuel Leibowitz and Nathan R. Sobel.
I came to New York today to pay my respects to the mortal remains of the late Robert Aura Smith. In his passing the cause of Philippine-American friendship has lost a sincere and effective advocate.
LONDON, Nov. 13 (UPI)-Wimbledon has bowed to the inevitable. The pay-for-play set will mix with the amateurs in an open tennis tournament in 1961.
A proxy fight for control of the Alleghany Corporation appears to be shaping up in the wake of the discharge yesterday of its vice president, David Wallace.

Shorter work weeks and layoffs laid to the steel strike caused a slight rise in installment loan delinquencies in September, the American Bankers Association reported yesterday. Loans having an installment past due thirty days or more were still a smaller percentage of the total number outstanding than they were a year ago, however.

LONDON, Nov. 13 (UPI) -- Leaving no stone unturned, Eric Partridge has just finished revising his "Dictionary of Cliches," and he feels he can say without fear of contradiction that it is complete from A to Z.

An interne who performed an emergency amputation of the leg of Martyn Green early last Saturday violated regulations and would have been dismissed had he not resigned from Knickerbocker Hospital, authorities said yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 13 (AP) -- Three appointments to the staff of the Federal Office of Education were announced today by Dr. Lawrence G. Derthick, the education commissioner.
Briefs were filed yesterday in Supreme Court in a dispute between Sidney J. Ungar, lawyer and real estate developer, and Mayor Wagner, Commissioner Robert Moses and other city officials.

LOS ANGELES, Nov. 13 (AP) -- Fifteen fatalities directly connected with football were reported today in the annual mid-season national survey conducted by a committee of the American Football Coaches Association.
ISLIP, L. I., Nov. 13 -- A charge against State Senator Elisha T. Barrett, accusing him of leaving the scene of an auto accident, was dismissed here tonight.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 13 (AP) -- Dr. Glenn T. Seaborg, nuclear scientist and chancellor of the University of California, was chosen today to receive the Atomic Energy Commission's $50,000 Enrico Fermi Award for 1959.
HONOLULU, Nov. 13 (UPI) -- William J. Madden, a Civil Aeronautics Board examiner, has completed the first phase of a three-part hearing on airline applications for trans-Pacific air routes.

A book of information on all aspects of the Civil War period will be published Dec. 7 by David McKay. Called "The Civil War Dictionary," it has been edited by Lieut. Col. Mark M. Boatner 3d, formerly of the faculty of military history at the United States Military Academy.
The Continental League, which is still trying to get itself off the ground despite a slippery runway, yesterday managed to climb as high as the seventh floor of its new quarters at 680 Fifth Avenue.

The Jewish National Home for Asthmatic Children at Denver will benefit from the fifty-second annual dinner dance of its New York committee to be held in the Grand Ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria next Saturday.

BALTIMORE, Nov. 13 (AP) -- Solidifying her position as the leading Maryland-bred juvenile of the season, Paul A. Cresci's Creswood Dottie won the $7,500-added Pimlico Breeders' Stakes today. The race was the feature on the opening program of the Maryland Jockey Club's twenty-eight-day meeting.
The terms of the two-year contract reached last Tuesday by metropolitan milk dealers and their union employes were released yesterday following their ratification by the members of the four locals.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Nov. 13 -- Quite a few American movie stars do not qualify for film work by Russian standards. This was made clear here today by four Soviet film notables who are part of a cultural exchange program with the United States.
Intercollegiate football offers its penultimate full program of the season today and races for conference championships and bowl bids near climaxes.
The abolition of the commission's fund in the Department of Welfare was ordered by Mayor Wagner yesterday.
DETROIT, Nov. 13 -- A University of Michigan professor called today for improvement in the nation's unemployment insurance program to provide better protection in the next recession.
The National Broadcasting Company announced last night that it had stopped televising commercials for Regimen, a tablet said to be an aid in losing weight.

IT should be obvious that when the defenders hold five trumps including the queen and jack, divided Q-x-x in one hand and J-x in the other, or the equivalent, they are bound to make a trump trick and a grand slam cannot be made against them.

Stocks retreated again yesterday for the fourth day in a row. The decline pervaded most groups, with the notable exception of communications and some electronic-missile issues. Steels were particularly weak.
QUANTICO, Va., Nov. 7 -The Marine Corps, still carrying "glory in its pack," is developing at this ninety-square-mile post tactics to reconcile the irreconcilable.

A dozen families were made homeless last night by a three-alarm fire that badly damaged eight stores and several apartments on Rockaway Beach Boulevard between Beach Eightieth and Beach Eighty-first Street in Rockaway Beach, Queens.

A 27-year-old Queens man who stole $3,300 in a hold-up of a savings and loan association last August and then later surrendered voluntarily and returned the money received a suspended sentence yesterday.

A million dollars worth of free entertainment is one of the services more than 500,000 members of the armed forces receive each year when they visit the United Service Organizations' Travelers Aid Center at 132 West Forty-third Street in the heart of Times Square.
The Rev. Dr. Joseph B. Flotten, pastor of the Evangelical Lutheran Church of the Resurrection in St. Albans, Queens, was elected chairman of the Wagner College board of trustees yesterday.
RIVERHEAD, L. I., Nov. 13 -- H. Lee Dennison, the Democrat who is to be Suffolk's first County Executive starting Jan. 1, petitioned the County Board of Supervisors today for a salary increase.
LONDON, Nov. 13 -- Share prices recovered from early setbacks in the stock market here today, and closed uneven.
An "extremely hush-hush" luncheon was held yesterday by officials of New York University for members of the Mayor's Committee on Slum Clearance and its staff.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 13 -- Ireland proposed today that the United Nations act to prevent countries not now having nuclear weapons from manufacturing them or otherwise acquiring them.
CHICAGO, Nov. 13 (AP) -- A late run-up in the old-crop wheat futures contracts sent them to new high prices for the season today as gains ran to well over a cent a bushel at their best.
Two persons were injured in Brooklyn last night when their station wagon was struck and tipped over by a stolen car in which two teen-age boys were joyriding.
BALTIMORE, Nov. 13 (AP) -- A soft-spoken 27-year-old man walked through Baltimore's poorer sections today, giving away money.
Magistrate Anthony E. Maglio was suspended yesterday by the Appellate Division, Second Department, pending the disposition of charges brought against him on orders of Mayor Wagner.

GENEVA, Nov. 13 -- The conferees negotiating a ban on testing of nuclear weapons are sending to their governments a "possible compromise" plan for the proposed meeting of experts on the detection of underground explosions.

Looking remarkably like a 'cellistic Rudolf Serkin, jittering nerovusly, tensing until those moments he could place his bow on the strings, Mstislav Rostropovich gave a magnificent 'cello recital last night in Carnegie Hall.
WASN'T it Chauncey Depew who cheerfully told Will Rogers that he had held many audiences successfully and never needed the help of a rope?
A record crowd of 21,890 watched the professional wrestling card at Madison Square Garden last night. This information may interest anyone investigating civilization in the future.
ALBANY, Nov. 13 -- Proposals to outlaw speed limits under twenty-five miles an hour on all roads in the state produced sharp debate today.
President Eisenhower is planning a top-level conference of industry and union leaders to seek ways of safeguarding the country against crippling strikes.
TWO years ago tomorrow an event of some consequence took place on Fifty-seventh Street. A young woman was installed as president of Henri Bendel, long a landmark on that fabled shopping thoroughfare.
BORDEAUX, France, Nov. 13 -- About 2,000 Gaullists gathered here today in search of a program to complement their fidelity to President Charles de Gaulle.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 13 -- Arthur S. Flemming arranged today to meet with cranberry industry representatives to consider their proposals for isolating contaminated supplies.
VALLEY FORGE, Pa., Nov. 13 -- The 1,500,000-member American Baptist Convention will construct its new national headquarters here at a cost of $5,500,000.
NEWARK, Nov. 13 -- A temporary injunction was issued today against enforcement of the Sunday sales ban.
The visiting Russian composers will postpone their departure from the United States by one day to participate in a Boston Symphony concert in Carnegie Hall next Saturday afternoon.

LEON, Nicaragua, Nov. 13 -- The National Student Federation here has sent a telegram to President Luis Anastasio Somoza Debayle requesting that he free three university students arrested two days ago.
PEIPING, Nov. 13 -- The Chinese Communists have decided to start redistributing land in Tibet belonging mostly to the feudal lords and the lamaseries.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 13 (UPI) -- The Air Force has ordered private contractors to stop sending technical data of any kind to Iron Curtain countries without first obtaining Government approval, it was disclosed today.
UNITED NATIONS, N Y., Nov. 13 -- Following is the text of the draft of an Irish resolution on the prevention of the spread of nuclear weapons, put before the Political Committee today:
Joseph F. Carlino, Speaker of the Assembly, said yesterday that he was opposed to Mayor Wagner's renewed plan to legalize and tax off-track betting on horse races.

The State of California yesterday designated Dec. 9 as the date of sale for an issue of $100,000,000 of bonds to finance public buildings of construction and loan to war veterans for purchasing farms and homes.
Cotton futures advanced 5 to 8 points (25 to 40 cents a bale) yesterday on the New York Cotton Exchange.
LONDON, Nov. 13 -- Selwyn Lloyd, Britain's Foreign Secretary, said today that on his visit to Paris he had found the objectives of Britain and France to be parallel.
BONN, Germany, Nov. 13 -The Bundesrat, or upper house of the West German Parliament rejected today a bill to establish a Federal television authority and a Federal radio operation.
INDEPENDENCE, Mo., Nov. 13 (UPI) -- Former President Harry S. Truman took 250 boys and girls through his library today and interspersed the tour with comments on a variety of subjects.

Federal Judge Edward J. Dimock yesterday dismissed one of six charges against eleven men and a magazine distributing company. The charges are contained in an indictment for violating antitrust and antiracketeering laws in the wholesale distribution of newspapers and magazines in the metropolitan area.

Prices of railroad bonds have been sliding recently, and yesterday some more new lows for the year were set. On the New York Stock Exchange yesterday, for example, Northern Pacific 4s of 1997 closed at 82 5/8, a low for the day and the year, and well below the high for the year of 95.

The United Investors Corporation of New York has announced plans for a 157,-unit motel on a site adjacent to the new passenger terminal at the International Airport in Miami, Harry Seeve, president, estimated the cost at more than $2,000,000.
An oil painting atributed to Raphael will be sold at public auction next Friday in the City Sheriff's office at 31 Chambers Street.

SALT LAKE CITY, Utah, Nov. 13 -- Sugar beet farmers in twenty-two Western and Midwestern states are racing against the annual "freeze-in" of their acreage to harvest a record crop. Estimates indicate the harvest will run above 16,500,000 tons, the greatest yield of sugar beets in the eightyyear history of the industry.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 13 -- Tenants who face eviction from an apartment building doomed by United Nations construction plans have been informed that the United Nations will be unable to intervene on their behalf.

ATLANTIC CITY, Nov. 13 -Dr. Frederick M. Raubinger, New Jersey's Commissioner of Education, expressed the hope today that "the colleges and the college entrance testing services will relent in their efforts to dominate the secondary schools, to determine what is taught and to pass arbitrary judgment upon how it is taught."
RABAT, Morocco, Nov. 13 -Morocco and the Soviet Union signed a trade agreement today. It is expected to bring about a substantial increase in their commerce.
JOGJAKARTA, Indonesia Nov. 13 -- The Colombo Plan established in 1950 and sched uled to end in 1961 got a five year lease on life today.
Expectations that the three-month old copper strike would soon end resulted in heavy trading in copper futures on the Commodity Exchange.
Shipping industry leaders were reminded here yesterday that shipping -- in spite of current preoccupation with missiles, rockets and space -- was still the paramount medium of global transportation.
"MUSIC FROM SHUBERT ALLEY" resounded joyously for a delightful hour on Channel 4 last night.
BAD GODESBERG, Germany, Nov. 13 -- The German Social Democratic party met in extraordinary congress here today to bury its Marxist past formally.

Pamet of the Miroar Stable gave an impressive performance in winning the mile race that served as the feature attraction at Aqueduct yesterday. The event was a $5,000 purse called the Marriage, and it attracted a half-dozen contestants.

HAVANA, Nov. 13 -- Maj. Juan Almeida, chief of the Cuban Air Force, was appointed Chief of Staff of the army today. He replaces Maj. Camilo Cienfuegos, missing on a flight from Camaguey to Havana Oct. 28.
For the tenth annual Fan Ball last night, the Astor's ballroom was decorated in silver and shades of pink ranging to red.
Protestant Episcopal churches over the country will commemorate today and tomorrow the 175th anniversary of the bestowal of the episcopate on the church in the United States.

HAVANA, Nov. 13 -- The Cuban Government rejected today as "absolutely false" the protest of the United States that "deliberate and concerted efforts" were being made in Cuba to change the traditional friendship of the two countries into hostility.

Thibault are co-chairmen for the twelfth annual dinner dance, which will benefit the New York Travelers Aid Society.

This is a hard-bitten, thoroughly uncompromising account of an insurrection within the confines of a modern American penitentiary. In broad outline, it follows the pattern familiar to penologists and newspaper readers alike. Here once again we have the overcrowding; the inadequacy of prison facilities; the emergence of an inmate leader; the "incident"; the seizure of guards as hostages; the absolute rule of the convict clique over a portion of the prison.

SOMETIMES thermostats do not work properly because drafts from inside the wall come out through the opening through which the wires are drawn. This cold air comes into the back of the thermostat and causes the elements to switch on the furnace even though the room is warm enough. TORONTO, Nov. 15 (Canadian Press) -- The groundwork is being laid for a mammoth communications project that will link the United States with Alaska by way of Canada and may eventually bring television networks to the Northwest.

RABAT, Morocco, Nov. 15 -- A gift of $500,000 worth of United States military equipment and munitions is expected to be a surprise feature of a military parade in Casablanca tomorrow. The parade will open a three-day national holiday in honor of King Mohamed V and Moroccan independence.

ON the Island of Majorca lives one of the most talented, versatile and cheerfully contentious of living men of letters. Since 1916, Robert Graves has been a prodigiously productive writer. His poems are much admired. Several of his historical novels are brilliant and all of them are much superior to the general run of such fiction. His essays and memoirs are good.

PANAMA, Nov. 15 -- President Eisenhower's announcement yesterday of the establishment of a National Advisory Committee on Inter-American Affairs to consider problems of United States relations with Latin America gained immediate favor in Panama today.

JACQUES LIPCHITZ calls his fourteen recent sculptures at the Fine Arts Associates, 41 East Fifty-seventh Street, "A la limite du possible" because, as he says, "without any doubt it is the limit of the possibilities of what can be done with the lost wax process."

MOSCOW, Nov. 15 (UPI) -- A commentator of Tass, Soviet press agency, said tonight that Governor Rockefeller of New York and former President Harry S. Truman were "acting in step" in trying to further the "cold war."
HAVANA, Nov. 15 -- A shake-up of Cuba's diplomatic and consular service has been in progress for several weeks.

Cardinal Spellman issued his annual appeal yesterday to all Roman Catholics in the New York Archdiocese to support the Bishops' Thanksgiving collection. The money is used to send food, clothing and medicine to sixty-one countries and administer care to the sick and the needy.

Australia is perhaps more like the United States than any other country, even including our neighbor Canada. The Canadian, after all, in some respects feels like the thin filler of a high-pressured American sandwich. Therefore he is at times inclined to emphasize neighborly differences, economic chauvinism and political ties with England.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 15 -- The over-all rate of the nation's production of goods and services declined by almost $6,000,000,000 in the July-September quarter, largely because of the steel strike, according to Department of Commerce estimates.

HOLCOMB, Kan., Nov. 15 (UPI) -- A wealthy wheat farmer, his wife and their two young children were found shot to death today in their home. They had been killed by shotgun blasts at close range after being bound and gagged.

"Beria's Gardens: A Slave Laborer's Experience in the Soviet Utopia," by Unto Parvilahti, will be published by Dutton on Jan. 7. The author was arrested without charge in 1944, kidnapped from his native Finland and sentenced to serve in one of the "Gardens," the Temniskovsky prison camp.
Justice William O. Douglas is to be commended for his dissenting opinion in the recent Supreme Court decision in the steel strike.

NEWARK, Nov. 15 -- Ch. Basford Milk-Meat, 6-year-old bulldog, returned to competition today after a long absence from the show ring and captured the main award of the forty-first annual Newark Kennel Club event.
NORWALK, Conn., Nov. 15 -- A sixty-four year-old monument in East Norwalk commemorating the purchase of Norwalk from the Indians in 1640 is to undergo a face-lifting.
The Ford Foundation announced yesterday grants to twelve universities for training of advanced research scientists in meteorology, oceanography and plasma physics and for engineering education.
A 13-year-old boy tried to save a man from drowning yesterday but found the elements too strong. Finally both of them were pulled to safety by a police helicopter that happened by.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 15 -- The Israeli Embassy unfolded tonight the story of how an amateur radio operator's interception of a message between Ghana and Israel sent a United States military surgeon to help an injured child in Accra.

Senator Jacob K. Javits said last night that United States foreign policy "suffers seriously" because of the failure of Congress year after year to pass major legislation for the admission of a fair share of refugees.

HONG KONG, Nov. 15 -- Chinese who have settled outside their motherland should integrate with their adopted countries.

A Soviet physicist's theory that the flow of time from past to future is the source of vast energies in the universe is being extensively publicized in the Soviet press. There is evidence that Soviet scientists believe there has been some experimental verification of the theory.
The Unitarian Church of All Souls celebrated its 140th anniversary yesterday with a ceremony at its building on Lexington Avenue and Eightieth Street.

HILO, Hawaii, Nov. 15 -- Fountains of golden fire poured skyward today as Kilauea Iki Crater erupted on the island of Hawaii. Molten lava gushed as high as 200 feet during the night, but the spurts had dropped to about fifty feet today.

The price of milk to 12.000,000 consumers in the metropolitan area will go up a half-cent a quart today. This increase reflects contract gains made last week by 13,500 Teamster Union members employed in processing and delivering milk for 311 dairies.

The combined strength of government, industry and labor is focused on the importance of Equal Opportunity Day, Nov. 19, an annual national observance dedicated to a basic democratic belief in the equality of opportunity for all our citizens. The primary intention of the observance is to direct national attention to the established American idea of giving a decent and fair chance to all men and women in the "race of life."

The city will permit adult narcotic addicts to obtain hospital treatment without having to commit themselves to jail as they have had to do in the past.

What he needed, he said, was something to fight World War II, not World III. The young specialist who took this lecture was named Jerrold Reinach Zacharias. The gadget was the United States fighting fleet's first microwave radar.

The Museum of the City of New York, 1220 Fifth Avenue, dedicated to telling the story of the city, will be the beneficiary of the Nov. 30 and Jan. 8 performances of "Sound of Music." The musical opens tonight at the Lunt-Fontane Theatre.

NEWPORT, R. I., Nov. 15 -- St. George's School is smack between two important athletic events. Yesterday, the Red and White's football team met Middlesex in the fifty-fourth game of the series. Tomorrow, Ted Hersey, the track coach, is sponsoring a cross-country meet for the entire school.

THE gastronomic millennium has arrived in Manhattan. Anyone who does not believe it should take himself to the Woolworth establishment at 33 West Forty-second Street. There, just about midway between a frankfurter bar and a pizza stand, is an astonishing display of fine foods and exotic fare.

BOSTON, Nov. 16 -- Positive educational values "even more important than the traditional three R's of reading, 'riting and 'rithmatic" were outlined tonight by a former United States Commissioner of Education.

The United States Steel Corporation announced yesterday the appointment of J. D. McCall as president of the Columbia-Geneva Steel division, the company's major West Coast operation. Mr. McCall, formerly vice president for operations of Columbia -Geneva, succeeds Leslie B. Worthington, who was elected president of United States Steel last week.
STRATFORD, Conn., Nov. 16 -- Sixteen Army helicopters undergoing modernization were airlifted today between two plants of the Sikorsky division of the United Aircraft Corporation.

Rubber prices soared 1 1/2 to 2 1/4 cents a pound yesterday on the Commodity Exchange of New York. Volume continued heavy with 1,400 tons traded. All positions climbed to a new high for the life of the contracts.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 16 -A leading Soviet scientist told a meeting of the American Rocket Society tonight that the Soviet Union had a technical capability now to place a man in space.
The first postwar vessel to be built exclusively for the bulk transportation of sugar for this country's sugar refining industry will enter service early next year.
ELIZABETH, N. J., Nov. 16 -The Elizabeth Daily Journal, one of America's oldest newspapers, was sold today to Ralph Ingersoll, publisher of the former New York City newspaper PM.

Senator Joseph Clark is quite right, in his letter published Nov. 7, to say that under no circumstances should the Federal Reserve reduce interest rates. If there were a recession going on, they should loosen credit.

Sales of the nation's major chain and mail order companies in October topped those of the 1958 month by 7.4 per cent, according to a compilation by The New York Times yesterday. Volume for the first ten months of the year was 9.5 per cent above the level of the 1958 period.

Stockholders usually delight in stock splits, despite reminders from corporations and brokers that two pieces of paper are not necessarily better than one. In many cases, there is good reason, of course, for stockholders to be pleased, because often when a company announces a two-for-one, threefor-one or even bigger split, a higher proportionate cash dividend is declared than was paid before the split.
Medical and psychiatric missionaries for communism may become a potent influence in the "uncommitted and newly developing" nations, an American psychiatrist warned yesterday.
DETROIT, Nov. 16 (UPI) -The Detroit Red Wings scored three times in the final period, twice on power plays, to defeat the Chicago Black Hawks, 3 -- 2, tonight.

SHUSHAN, N. Y., Nov. 16 -There was no mistaking that this was the opening day of the deer season outside the northern zone. It was a matchless day, cold enough for hunting; the woods were full of hunters and deer, and the roads were clogged with cars carrying men with rifles.
ALBANY, Nov. 16 -- Mayor Wagner's plan to legalize offtrack betting in New York City was filed with the Legislature today for consideration when the new session meets in January.
There is no good reason why composers, like performers, shouldn't present themselves before the public. Ned Rorem and William Flanagan did just that last night at Carnegie Recital Hall.

Ten witnesses fenced and evaded questions on Communist activities among Puerto Ricans yesterday during a Congressional hearing here. Although they spoke of seeking "liberty," an Ohio Representative said Puerto Rico could have independence any time it wished.

BONN, Germany, Nov. 16 -The Most Rev. Aloisius J. Muench, who has been nominated by Pope John XXIII to be a Cardinal, said today that he was particularly happy that his parishioners in North Dakota were to have the honor of having a prince of the Church as their spiritual leader.

THE squalor and the splendor of Louis XIV's court are the setting for Joan Sanders' portrait of a puritanical courtesan in "La Petite: The Life of Louise de la Valliere."* It is a book written with such grace and understanding that a minor figure becomes a major one in that great gaudy tapestry of rule and misrule.
MEMPHIS, Nov. 16 -- The Federal Government asked for a court order today to prohibit "white primaries" in near-by Fayette County.
NICE, France, Nov. 16 -- A few nights ago in the corner of the Alps where France, Italy and Switzerland come together, the first snow of the season began to fall.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 16 -Secretary of State Christian A. Herter said today he had received reports from Panama indicating that further violence was threatened against United States citizens in that Central American republic.

Two young men who were released without bail last month were indicted by a Brooklyn grand jury yesterday on charges of second-degree assault. Their release had led to the suspension of Magistrate Anthony E. Maglio last Friday.
Gov. Mark O. Hatfield of Oregon said yesterday that as of now Vice President Richard M. Nixon would make a stronger candidate for President than Governor Rockefeller.
CHICAGO. Nov. 16 (AP) -- The report of today's livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows
The Statue of Liberty is an attraction unique to the City of New York. So is the Empire State Building. So is Rockefeller Center. And so is the Museum of Modern Art.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 16 -- A Congressional committee produced a stirring of hope today for an income tax reduction, possibly next year.
Governor Rockefeller has told his political advisers that he will not campaign for the Republican Presidential nomination on a Nixon can't win" platform.
Real-estate speculation has caused "racing slums" in Harlem, Borough President Hulan E. Jack of Manhattan charged yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 16 -- Industrial production slipped slightly again in October because of the steel strike, but -- contrary to the earlier estimate -- it did not slip in September, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.
Now that the head of the house, because of the shortening days and the weather, has been pushed indoors, he has discovered arranged around his easy chair a large number of periodicals and books.
LONDON, Nov. 16 -- An important union leader cautioned today that British trade unionism could be destroyed if wildcat strikes were not checked.

On Nov. 11, 1918, in a railway coach in France, an armistice was signed that was to mean an end to all war forever. Today, fortyone years and two conflicts later, it still takes nearly 3,000,000 American men and women to preserve the peace in perhaps the most critical period in world history.
BUFFALO, Nov. 16 -- Governor Rockefeller made his first major speech to a labor audience today and received a polite but noncommittal hearing.

Four city teachers, suspended without pay in 1955 for refusing to name other teachers who were former Communists, charged in Brooklyn Supreme Court yesterday that the Board of Education was illegally refusing their reinstatement. The four had admitted their own past membership in the Communist party.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 16 -- The Supreme Court cleared away today the legal obstacles that have blocked the courtappointed monitors of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters. The court's action was a simple rejection of the Teamsters' petition to review a decision of the Circuit Court of Appeals.

WESTBURY, L. I., Nov. 16 -- Billy Haughton, the nation's leading harness-horse driver, had four chances to earn $501 tonight so that he could scale the $1,000,000 mark for the second year in a row. But Haughton finished 6 -- 8 -- 6 -- 8 and didn't earn a penny.
Four youths accused in two Prospect Park muggings last June were sentenced yesterday to prison terms ranging up to fifteen years.

Following is a list of the passengers and crew members aboard the National Airlines plane that crashed in the Gulf of Mexico. The compilation was made by The Associated Press and United Press International.

The thirteenth volume of Samuel Eliot Morison's "History of United States Naval Operations in World War II" will be published next Monday by Atlantic-Little, Brown. It is called "The Liberation of the Philippines, Luzon, Mindanao, the Vasayas, 1944-1945.
Longshore union leaders and East and Gulf Coast maritime employers will resume fullscale contract negotiations at 2:30 P. M. tomorrow.
Police Commissioner Stephen P. Kennedy expects to open soon a cadet program for young men and women interested in police work as careers.
A record of $39,980,436 has been tentatively requested for operating the municipal college system during 1960-61.
Jussi Bjoerling, who has not sung at the Metropolitan Opera in the last two seasons, rejoined the company last night as Turiddu in the season's third presentation of "Cavalleria Rusticana."
The Museum of Modern Art has embarked in its thirtieth year on a $25,000,000 expansion and building program, including an eight-story addition.

" Stop watching the disk, keep your positions and let me hear you holler." Those were among the admonitions of Alf Pike, the new coach of the New York Rangers, as he took over at yesterday's practice.
TELEVISION may never be quite the same after "The Waltz of the Toreadors" completes its run on WNTA-TV (Channel 13) this week.
BONN, Germany, Nov. 16 -The Bavarian Motor Works will continue to make and market abroad at least two small cars under the B. M. W. insignia, a company spokesman said today.

In the first sale of the property since 1934, the two buildings at 342-348 Eighth Avenue, near the northeast corner of Twenty-seventh Street, has been sold by a group headed by Sidney R. Newman. The purchaser was the 363-381 Eighth Avenue Corporation.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 16 (AP) -- Mary Garden, former opera star sent word today that she had suffered a relapse after her recent brush with death. The singer cannot come here from Scotland for a planned appearance.
HAVANA, Nov. 16 -- The Confederation of Cuban Workers may withdraw from the Inter-American Regional Organization of Labor this week.

Subscribers have been announced for the Bagby Music Lovers Foundation benefit performance of "La Traviata" on Thursday evening. The entire Metropolitan Opera House has been taken over for the event, which celebrates the centennial of the birth of Albert Morris Bagby, founder of the beneficiary.

BONN, Germany, Nov. 16 -Chancellor Konrad Adenauer is hopeful of gaining British agreement to make a first-step disarmament program the main business of the East-West summit conference to be held next spring.
Benny (Kid) Paret of Cuba scored a unanimous decision over Bob Provizzi of Freeland, Pa., in the ten-round main event last night at the Academy of Music. Paret weighed 152 pounds and Provizzi 157.
WASHINGTON, NOV. 16 (UPI) -- The United States and Britain have signed a five-year agreement to exchange technical information on gas-cooled atomic reactors, it was announced today.
Two stars, Kent Smith and Robert Sterling, are set for impending attractions.
Stocks fell sharply yesterday in a general price retreat.

As usual, The Times is indignant over the way the colonial powers are treating their colonies. At the present time the Belgians are mismanaging things in the Congo and the French in Algeria. If only these colonies were granted complete independence, everything would be fine!
ROME, Nov. 16 -- Pope John XXIII will create eight new Cardinals in a consistory Dec. 14, raising the membership of the Sacred College to seventy-nine, its largest.
TRENTON, Nov. 16 -- Robert Morris announced his candidacy for the Republican nomination for United States Senator today.
ALTHOUGH the hand shown today was not played in the tournament at West Orange, N. J., last week-end, it may have been more talkedabout at the tournament than most of the hands that occurred there.

CLEVELAND, Nov. 16 (AP) Newsmen, announcers and disk jockeys went on strike today for higher pay at Cleveland radio station WHK. Service was not disrupted, and engineers crossed a picket line to go to work, a station official said.

LONDON, Nov. 16 -- In a dramatic change of front, Prime Minister Harold Macmillan identified Britain tonight with Europe's movement toward economic unity. Britain, he declared, "is part of Europe -- sharing in the life and tradition of Europe."
Prices of cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange declined 5 to 17 points (25 to 85 cents a bale) yesterday. Selling was most pronounced in the old crop months.

Many subscriptions have been reported for the Dec. 9 theatre party for the benefit of the New York Exchange for Woman's Work. It will take place at the performance that evening of "The Sound of Music" starring Mary Martin at the Lunt-Fontanne Theatre.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 16 -The interest rate on the shortestterm Government securities -- the weekly issue of ninetyone-day bills -- rose this week to a new record. Money experts ascribed the increase to the resumption of steel production.

As the first major Socialist party in the world to catch up with the twentieth century, the German Social Democrats have now officially thrown their nineteenth-century Marxist ballast overboard and adopted a new program emphasizing democracy instead of socialism.

Abraham M. Sonnabend, Boston financier, openly contesting Allan P. Kirby's control of the Alleghany Corporation, railroad holding company, tried yesterday to enlist the support of Robert R. Young's widow. Mrs. Anita O. Young's stockholdings in Alleghany are sufficient to elect two of the company's nine directors.
CHICAGO, Nov. 16 -- Archbishop Albert Gregory Meyer, one of the two Americans being elevated to the College of Cardinals, pledged today to work for unity, truth and peace.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 16 (UPI) -- The Federal Communications Commission announced today that it would begin an investigation of television quizshow scandals in early December.

A court referee recommended yesterday that the Morgan Guaranty Trust Company be awarded $750,000, or about 10 per cent of what its corporate predecessor once asked, for its services in the sale of securities of the Petroleum Research Fund.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 16 -- The United States and the Soviet Union held an unannounced meeting over the week-end to discuss the membership of a permanent United Nations body to encourage the peaceful uses of outer space.
RIYADH, Saudi Arabia, Nov. 12 -- King Saud of Saudi Arabia said through a spokesman today that he was opposed to the continued presence of a United Nations force in the Aqaba Gulf area.
It is journey's end for all but a few of the college football teams of the country this week.
Many socially prominent persons will be at Carnegie Hall this evening to hear the concert of the Vienna Philharmonic Orchestra with Herbert von Karajan conducting.

Criticizing "big business" and public officials is and I suppose always has been a popular sport. I venture to suggest, however, that what the country needs is not greater integrity in its leaders, who for the most part are honest, conscientious and hard-working, but rather a deeper sense of responsibility and a higher standard of ethics and morals on the part of many individual citizens.

SYRACUSE, N. Y., Nov. 16 -Roy Wilkins charged today that racial prejudice had influenced thinking on juvenile delinquency. He attributed such influence to "amateur diagnosticians" and the infiltration of "Dixie propaganda" in the North.
WILMINGTON, Del., Nov. 16 (AP) -- E. I. du Pont de Nemours Co., Inc., declared today a year-end dividend of $2.50 a share on the common stock, payable on Dec. 14 to stockholders of record of Nov. 23.

Boeing Airplane Company, one of the nation's largest aircraft manufacturers, is negotiating to acquire the Vertol Aircraft Corporation, Morton, Pa., makers of tandem-rotor helicopters and component parts.

A YOUNG woman who can pitch a grenade, plow a field, drive a truck and look as beautiful as Bathsheba is in New York to find out whether she will be the first Israeli actress to impress American moviegoers.
The formation of a clergymen's national advisory committee to promote birth-control information was announced yesterday at the annual meeting of the Planned Parenthood Federation of America.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 16 -- The Soviet Union said today that any United Nations debate on the Hungarian question would "undermine the spirit of cooperation" established at Camp David.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 16 -The Chief of Staff of the United States Air Force forecast today that modern weapons developments would produce smaller, harder hitting and more widely dispersed combat units.

SPRINGFIELD, Mass., Nov. 16 -- The National Municipal League examined "the challenge of the Sixties" today. It was told that by 1970 the national population will top 200,000,000, the national output of goods and services will approach $800,000,000,000 and technological advances will be "fantastic."

United Nations Secretary General Dag Hammarskjold's visit to Laos was made in spite of the comparatively mild protests of the Russians and, over the same protests, he has sent a U. N. economist, Sakari S. Tuomioja, to visit Laos and "review the economic situation" there.
Pending borrowings by the Treasury, the American Telephone and Telegraph Company and New York, Delaware and South Carolina were the bond market's major concerns yesterday.
FROM the Trapp Family Singers, the makers of "The Sound of Music" have acquired two valuable assets -- legendary personal courage and a love of singing.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 16 -- Events of this day in the realm of law enforcement recall criticisms of the operations of justice that poets, philosophers, plaintiffs and defendants have been voicing since the establishment of courts. The basis of the complaint has always been that he who directly violates the letter of the law draws the penalty which he who finds an indirect route to the same violation escapes.
The steel industry will operate at 78.9 per cent of capacity and turn out 2,233,000 tons of steel this week, the American Iron and Steel Institute estimated yesterday.

Allan T. Klots, former president of the Bar Association of the City of New York, in a letter in your Nov. 7 issue, echoes the desire of both bar and laity for a better method of selecting the judges of the New York State and local courts.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 16 -Secretary Arthur S. Flemming announced today that 324 of 337 lots of cranberries and cranberry products tested thus far had been found free of the weed-killer aminotriazole. The thirteen others either contained the chemical or are being re-checked.
Armando Agnini and Leopold Sachse, stage directors, have been announced as the first recipients of the merit awards of the American Guild of Musical Artists.

The Anti-Defamation League of B'nai B'rith will pay tribute to the American legitimate theatre through a special onehour program to be televised by the Columbia Broadcasting System on Dec. 6 at 11:30 A.M.

THE Pittsburgh Symphony conducted by William Steinberg came to New York for its annual Carnegie Hall appearance last night and bore the gift of two unfamiliar pieces. One was by the young Italian, Luigi Nono, who is far out in the advance guard.
Bowlers are in a class with golfers. They'll do nearly anything for a chance to play.

ATLANTA, Nov. l6 (UPI) -Robert Peete of Alabama, a junior college transfer from Syracuse, won the Southeastern conference cross-country championship today by running the 4-mile Georgia Tech course in 21 minutes 10.2 seconds.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Nov. 16 -- The junior varsity of the Hollywood art collecting team has taken the field to show that producers are not the only men here who accumulate paintings and statuaries along with scrapbooks.
SAN DIEGO, Calif., Nov. 16 (UPI) -- The bathyscaph Trieste plunged to a record undersea depth of 18,600 feet off Guam, the Naval Electronic Laboratory reported today.
A short, slim bank robber won two gambles in midtown yesterday morning.

The United States and other industrialized nations were urged yesterday to give less-developed nations priority in world trade of raw materials. This was the recommendation of Antonio Carrillo-Flores, Mexican Ambassador to the United States.

The Coca-Cola Company had good news for its stockholders yesterday. Directors recommended a three-for-one stock split, declared an extra yearend dividend of $2.50 on the present shares and announced substantial increases in earnings for the third quarter and nine months to Sept. 30.
OHRBACH'S fourth floor boutique, which is crammed with imported pleasures, has a splendid collection of both silk-knit and wool-knit overblouses imported from Italy.

The New York Knickerbockers, harassed by a five-game losing streak, will oppose the St. Louis Hawks in a National Basketball Association game at Madison Square Garden tonight. The 7 o'clock opener will send the Syracuse Nationals against the Cincinnati Royals.

HARRIMAN, N. Y., Nov. 16 -- The appointment of a Presidential commission on public policies for education was proposed tonight by Alvin C. Eurich, vice president and director of the Fund for the Advancement of Education.
KIAMESHA LAKE, N. Y., Nov. 16 -- A World Council of Synagogues was formally constituted here today by representatives of Judaism in twenty-two countries.
Miss Clara T. Nichols, a retired public school principal, was beaten and robbed yesterday by three men who broke into her apartment as she was taking an afternoon nap.
NEWARK, Nov. 16 -- A lone passenger, apparently impatient to get where he was going, was charged with stealing a Public Service bus at 1:50 A.M. today.
The Continental League made a new attack on the American League yesterday, in which, by implication, it revived its threat to play outside of organized baseball if necessary.

DURING his career on the right side of the law, Louis Ira Kaplan has gotten tough with gold smugglers, toy-gun toters, war veterans, narcotics rings and litterbugs, but he never has been closer to home than now -- investigating meat and those who sell it.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 16 (AP) -- Dean Acheson said today that "locomotion seems to have taken the place of policy and action" in the Administration.
DETROIT, Nov. 16 (AP) -Ford, which has steel, has passed Chevrolet, which doesn't have any in the 1959 auto production race.
Puerto Rico is planning to borrow $20,000,000 in the bond market here to finance public improvements. The securities will be put up for sale on Dec. 8.

Irving Bitz, an underworld figure, was sentenced yesterday by Federal Judge Frederick vanPelt Bryan to five years in prison and was fined $45,000 for conspiracy and extortion in the wholesale distribution of newspapers and magazines in the metropolitan area.

New York City will attempt to have the 1960 Navy-Air Force football game staged here. Representatives of Mayor Wagner and the United States Naval Academy will confer today on the possibility of shifting the contest from Baltimore.
Charles A. Rheinstrom is returning to the J. Walter Thompson Company.

TORONTO, Nov. 16 (Canadian Press) -- Tom Gayford, the leading rider at the Royal Winter Fair, took Blue Beau over an elimination puissance course for a clean round tonight, giving Canada her third international jumping victory.
PARENT-TEACHER groups in small communities are largely ineffectual organizations that reflect the biases of the principal, according to participants in a recent workshop.

LONDON, Nov. 16 (Reuters) -- Foreign Secretary Selwyn Lloyd told the House of Commons today that he understood there would be a Western summit meeting Just before the East-West heads-of-government conference next spring.
The investigation of a ring charged with cheating housewives on meat and poultry may be extended to fifteen or twenty more inspectors in the city's Department of Markets.
TRENTON, Nov. 16 -- The Assembly approved and sent to the Senate today a bill to authorize $66,800,000 in state bonds to be allocated for eight state institutions of higher education.
PANAMA, Nov. 16 -- A spokesman for the Foreign Ministry of Panama denied today reports that the Government here had asked for the recall of William E. Potter, Governor of the Canal Zone.
Your editorial of Nov. 14 "Cranberries and Mr. Flemming" prompts me to set out some of the biological facts and their relationship to the public health.
KANSAS CITY, Nov. 17 (AP) -- An agreement, reached today, to arbitrate ended a strike threat to Trans World Airlines.

The Board of Education is moving to reduce the lag in school construction and is working out operational improvements, Mayor Wagner was assured yesterday. Superintendent of Schools John J. Theobald gave the assurance, in reply to a question by the Mayor, at the opening in City Hall of public hearings on the proposed $658,933,792 capital budget for 1960.

LONDON, Nov. 17 -- Premier Khrushchev declared in a speech in Moscow Saturday that rockets with hydrogen-bomb warheads were being manufactured in at least one factory in the Soviet Union at the rate of 250 a year.

THE Vienna Philharmonic knows that this is the twentieth century, but it is proudly aware of its affinity for the composers of the eighteenth and nineteenth centuries whose careers made Vienna and musical history indissoluble.
Senator John L. McClellan warned last night that a militant effort would be made to nullify the new Landrum-Griffin law against corruption in labor unions.
JERSEY CITY, Nov. 17 -- A controversial resolution over personal property taxes, adopted by a majority of the five-member City Commission here two weeks ago, was rescinded today by a 4-0 vote.

GENEVA, Nov. 17 -- The three-power conference seeking a ban on nuclear weapons tests was stalled today as the United States delegation awaited instructions on a plan for an expert study of controls for underground explosions.

The flow of ever newer model buses along the streets of New York, bringing new comfort if not luxury, puts many a local mind into reverse motion toward idyllic rides of the past. "Your Bus of the Future" said the recent exhibit of the Fifth Avenue Coach Lines' newest design, expected to arrive with the new year no matter who ultimately gets credit for its genesis.

AUGUSTA, Ga., Nov. 17 -- President Eisenhower summoned the uniformed chiefs of the armed services to a conference here tomorrow. This move is an apparent effort to end interservice competition for a larger share in the $41,000,000,000 defense budget in the fiscal year beginning July 1.

The American Telephone and Telegraph Company will pay 5.27 per cent interest for the $250,000,000 it borrowed in the public market yesterday. The money was raised for advances to and stock purchases in Bell System affiliates, improvements in its own plant and general corporate purposes.
A leader of New York's shipping industry declared yesterday that theft at piers here was "infinitesmal compared to the volume of tonnage handled."
WASHINGTON, Nov. 17 -- Two privately owned steamship lines have asked the Panama Line to go out of business.
A public offering of $40,000,000 of debentures and 2,000,000 common shares of Transwestern Pipeline Company of Houston, Tex., was made yesterday.
VIENTIANE, Laos, Nov. 17 -- The United Nations "presence," Sakari S. Tuomioja, arrived here today by plane.

HARRIS, N. Y., Nov. 17 -- Conferees on the nation's manpower problems agreed today that experts would still be needed to end traffic congestion in city streets after scientists hitched their space vehicles to the stars.
MELBOURNE, Australia, Wednesday, Nov. 18 (AP) -Australia's Peter Thomson and Kel Nagle fired a 67 and 70, respectively, in the opening round of the Canada Cup international golf matches today.
The Queens County grand jury was charged yesterday to investigate the new Criminal Courts Building under construction since March, 1956, on Queens Boulevard in Kew Gardens.
