Charles Neider, American novelist, has been promised space in the Soviet Union's leading literary organ to reply to sharp criticism of his editing of Mark Twain's autobiography and of the so-called "official" United States attitude toward the humorist.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 17 -- Premier Khrushchev's statement that a Soviet factory was producing 250 rockets with hydrogen warheads a year confirmed a belief long held here that the Soviet Union was producing rockets of varying ranges in the same plants.

A FEW well-chosen additions to a standard baked rice pudding can transform it from an everyday dish to one that is elegant enough for a party. One delicious way to enhance the pudding is to flavor it with rum and include blanched, alivered almonds in the mixture. To accompany it, there should be a chocolate sauce also flavored with rum.
Mayor Wagner said yesterday that he thought New York's chances of getting the 1960 Navy-Air Force football game were "very good."

Something extra was visible in yesterday's Ivy League football workouts. Even in the so-called light drills, the athletes showed more determination than is customary so early in the week. The reason is that only sixty minutes of action remain this season. which to clinch varsity monograms, establish records, improve their team's positions and atone for previous mistakes.

UNIVERSITY PARK, Pa., Nov. 17 (AP) -- Dr. Eric A. Walker, president of Penn State, said tonight he would take under serious consideration an invitation for the university's football team to be the host in the Dec. 19 Liberty Bowl game in Philadelphia.
A New York City policeman testified yesterday in Federal Court that one of the defendants in the Apalachin trial had represented his visit to the estate of the late Joseph Barbara as a hunting trip.
DAMMAM, Saudi Arabia, Nov. 16 -- The Imam of Oman and the Paramount Sheik of Buraimi appealed today for United States support against what they said was British occupation of theri territories.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 17 -- Proposals for a uniform Federal excise (sales) tax were revived today at a Congressional hearing. All signs indicated that they would again be brushed aside.
An elderly inventor who apparently suffered a heart attack was believed responsible for a five-car collision yesterday on the Van Wyck Expressway at the Kew Gardens interchange in Queens.

LONDON, Nov. 17 -- "The World of Suzie Wong" received a cool reception tonight. Most of the first-night audience had expected a musical. The critics seemed to think that would have been a better idea.
PARIS, Nov. 17 -- Francis Perrin, France's High Commissioner for Atomic Energy, urged today an expansion of the country's program for peaceful uses of atomic energy to meet future power needs.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 17 -- The Interstate Commerce Commission heard oral argument today on a proposal of the New York Central Railroad to discontinue passenger service on its St. Lawrence Division.

Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer's second screen version of "Ben-Hur," adapted from the Lew Wallace novel, will have its world premiere tonight at 8:00 o'clock at Loew's State Theatre, Broadway and Forty-fifth Street.

Enkells-Rakoff Co., realty investor, has purchased the one-story building at 172 Mamaroneck Avenue, White Plains, from the Duravelle Realty Corporation. The buyer immediately resold the property to Vim Stores, retailers of household and electric appliances, for occupancy.
The National Association of Investment Companies announced yesterday that the net assets of its 155 member mutual fund companies rose above the $15,000,000,000 mark in October.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 17 (AP) -- A Government hearing examiner ruled today that three big oil companies had illegally coerced "a substantial number" of service stations

NEW DELHI, India, Nov. 17--The Indian Foreign Ministry said today that the Communist Chinese had used threats and duress to extort statements from ten Indian policemen who were captured in eastern Ladakh last month.

Investigators for a Congressional subcommittee that recently studied television quiz shows plan to question Dick Clark, American Broadcasting Company disk jockey whose program is a favorite of teenagers.

One more case of considerable corruption within a city department was the last thing the Wagner administration needed or wanted. But it has one, of dimensions still apparently growing, in the disclosure that housewives have been cheated of several millions of dollars in the past year in an illicit protective partnership between butchers and inspectors within the city's Department of Markets.
Events tonight: "Carmen," Metropolitan Opera, 8; Boston Symphony Orchestra, Charles Munch conducting, Samuel Mayes, 'cellist, Carnegie Hall, 8:30; Augustin Anievas, pianist, Town Hall, 8:30.

The National Advertising Service, Inc., has leased a floor for its executive offices at 18 East Fiftieth Street through Gallant-Roth Co., brokens. The lessees have been in business for more than fifty years and handle national advertising for college newspapers throughout the country.

TORONTO, Nov. 17 (AP) -- Argentina's Pedro Mayorga, on Stromboli, swept over a tricky thirteen-jump course for the only clean round in tonight's Royal Winter Fair international horse jumping event for his country's first victory here. United States riders placed second and third.
A landlord was sentenced yesterday to a year in the City Penitentiary for rent gouging.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 17 (UPI) -- The labor federation will present a charter of affiliation tomorrow to the International Longshoremen's Association. George Meany, president of the American Federation of Labor and Congress of Industrial Organizations, will make the presentation.

LONDON, Nov. 17 -- West German Government officials are deeply concerned over a reported proposal to reduce the size of the United States Army overseas. They believe the concern is shared by all Western European governments.
BUFFALO, Nov. 17 -- Senator Jacob K. Javits called today for a major White House conference on productivity next year.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Nov. 6 -- Counterpart funds, the by-product of past United States aid, are still helping to finance Yugoslavia's development.

Stocks rebounded yesterday after several recent sinking spells. It was widely considered a technical reaction, though favorable dividend news might have helped to spur the advance. Stock splits -- this will be a record year for them -- propelled individual issues onward and upward.

Latvians all over the world will be commemorating today the forty-first anniversary of the proclamation of Latvian independence. Today that small Baltic country lies behind the Iron Curtain, absorbed by the Soviet Union. But Latvian traditions are durable and Latvian memories long, and one cannot fail to believe that the spirit of independence still burns strongly.

The Burroughs Corporation has won the contract for production of the Airborne Long Range Input (ALRI) radar system, Maj. Gen. Beverly H. Warren, commander, Air Materiel Command, Aeronautical Systems Center, announced yesterday. The Air Force official said in Dayton, Ohio, that early stages of the contract would call for an outlay of about $35,000,000.

SHE sells sea shells far from the seashore. Jane Henderson, a petite, blond, brown-eyed English woman, creates sea shell paintings by day and plays a leading role in "The World of Suzie Wong" by night.

Your editorial of Nov. 13 "Fair Play to Bus Lines" omits an essential element in the controversy over who should subsidize transportation for school children. That element is the history of the subsidy. The subsidy for transportation of children to school was the price public and private transportation lines originally agreed to pay in order to obtain relief from the strait-jacket of a 5-cent fare.

CHICAGO, Nov. 17 -- It was said in LaSalle Street, Chicago's financial district, that the down payment for the 44,000 shares involved in the transaction was $11 a share, and that the balance was due on Feb. 4, the date on which Zeckendorf would assume control.

MIAMI BEACH, Fla., Nov. 17 -- Sharp criticism of Jews who avoid civil rights issues by moving from cities to suburbs was heard here today. The television industry was also attacked for what was termed its "failure" to enlighten people on current issues.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 17 -- Sir Lesile Munro asked the General Assembly today to put the Hungarian question on its agenda.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 17 (UPI) -- John J. Hearne, Irish Ambassador to the United States, said today that he had ordered his son, David, to return to Ireland. Recently, the son invoked diplomatic immunity after his car had struck and killed a Negro woman.

Good as Gold gleamed pleasantly through the drab atmosphere at Aqueduct yesterday for the fans that liked her in the feature race. The event was the Whetstone Handicap, a purse for fillies and mares and Good as Gold received only so-so support from the 17,297 punters in attendance.

Six weeks before the Congressional election of 1954 this newspaper commented: "The attempt of a handful of dissident Republicans in New Jersey to force Clifford P. Case to withdraw as his party's Senatorial nominee is a clear recurrence of the suicide drive from which the G. O. P. occasionally suffers."

GULFPORT, Miss., Nov. 17 (AP) -- An official of the Civil Aeronautics Board said today that it was impossible at the moment to determine if there had been an explosion on the National Airlines plane that crashed in the Gulf of Mexico with the loss of forty-two lives.
NEW HAVEN, Nov. 17 -- Yale and Harvard Universities teamed tonight to withdraw from the Federal student loan program in protest over the loyalty affidavit that it requires.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 17 -- About six weeks from now the war-born United Nations Korean Reconstruction Agency is scheduled to go out of existence. But the help it generated for the shattered economy of the Republic of South Korea will survive for some time to come.

ALF PIKE assumes full command tonight as coach of the New York Rangers. The Broadway Blues will meet the Black Hawks in Chicago, thereby facing the only team in hockey with a worse record than their own. Thus will begin, it is hoped, the upward climb toward Pike's Peak, the Stanley Cup play-offs.

Abraham M. Sonnabend's contest for control of the Alleghany Corporation, railroad holding company, was derailed temporarily yesterday by the United States Government. Mr. Sonnabend is a Boston real estate and hotel investor who heads a group assertedly holding 700,000 shares -- about 14 per cent -- of Alleghany common.

The investment world's eager reception of the new $250,000,000 issue of American Telephone and Telegraph Company debentures on terms yielding 5.22 per cent stimulated all parts of the bond market yesterday except the Government securities section.

TARRYTOWN, N. Y., Nov. 17 -- Governor Rockefeller was asked today by the entirely Democratic Village Board here to appoint a special investigator to study conflict-of-interest charges against three former Republican village officials.

Anthony (Fat Tony) Salerno, an underworld figure who reportedly played a part in the promotion of the last heavyweight championship fight, was ordered yesterday in Florida to show cause why he should not be forced to testify before a New York County grand jury next Tuesday.

TUNIS, Nov. 17 -- Serious contacts between the Algerian nationalists and the French Government to clear the way for peace talks may coincide with the United Nations debate on the Algerian question, informed observers indicated today.

Four of the five visiting Soviet composers were guests of the Metropolitan Opera House at last night's performance of Puccini's "Madama Butterfly." The exception was Dmitri Shostakovich, who begged off because he was tired.

Imports of typewriters are causing the domestic industry "grave corfcern," stockholders of the Royal McBee Corporation were told at the Astor Hotel yesterday by Allan A. Ryan, chairman. He told the annual meeting that imports had risen to 24 per cent domestic sales in 1958 from only 1.9 per cent in 1948.

KIAMESHA LAKE, N. Y., Nov. 17 -- An unexpected controversy erupted today at the biennial convention of the United Synagogue of America. The issue was whether the body should affiliate with the World Zionist Organization.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 17 -- If the eighty-day injunction expires without a settlement of the steel strike, the Justice Department will recommend that President Eisenhower ask Congress for several alternative powers to end it.
If there is any offensive department in which Syracuse does not lead in major college football, it probably is just an oversight that will be corrected shortly.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 17 -- Secretary Arthur S. Flemming and George C. P. Olsson, president of Ocean Spray Cranberries, Inc., agreed today on the procedure for a public conference tomorrow on the issue of the contamination of some of the nation's cranberries.
The New York Knickerbockers came mighty close to making Fuzzy Levane, their coach, an old man before his time last night.
WORKING women who occasionally feel spasms of self-pity because they are too busy to be well dressed will not find a sympathetic ally in Senora Ana Figueroa of Santiago, Chile.
CHICAGO, Nov. 17 (UPI) -- A bitter cold wave rewrote the record books and created misery for millions of persons from the Rocky Mountains to the Appalachians today.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 17 (UPI) -- The chairman of the Senate rackets committee accused James R. Hoffa, president of the Teamsters Union, today of trying to "deliver" millions of dollars in union bonding business to an agency with racket ties.
The New York City Housing Authority yesterday announced plans for a Harlem housing project that would embrace what the Authority described as a complete civic unit.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 17 -- Poland regained the lead over Turkey today in the race for a two-year term on the Security Council.

LONDON, Nov. 17 -- Chancellor Konrad Adenauer agreed with Prime Minister Harold Macmillan today that the future of West Berlin would have to be included on the agenda of a summit conference with the Soviet Union, diplomatic sources said.
HAVANA, Nov. 17 -- The tenth congress of the Cuban Confederation of Labor will open here tomorrow night and on Nov. 28 Havana will be host to the National Catholic Congress.

Speed, speed and more of the same appears to be the picture for the New York University basketball team this season. Whether the speed will be channeled in the proper direction at the important moments is a question Coach Lou Rossini will have to help answer.
Mayor Wagner ordered the dismissal last night of the city's director of the Bureau of Weights and Measures because of disclosures in the meat-market investigation.

ON the theory that there can't be too much of a good thing, Bergdorf Goodman presents the work of, not one, but three designers in its new collection of holiday and spring hats. Previewed for the press in the second floor made-to-order salon this week, the collection combines the talents of Marcelline, Milita and newcomer Halston.
The Columbia Broadcasting System is considering introducing the "magazine concept" of television programing to assure better balance in different types of shows on its evening schedule.

The success of public-health programs and control of diseases have combined to make overpopulation an emergency condition in many areas of the world, a Johns Hopkins professor said here yesterday. He was Dr. Ernest Stebbins, director of the School of Hygiene and Public Health at the Baltimore university.
BLOOMINGTON, Inr., Nov. 17 (AP) -- A huge, swirling core of hydrogen gas has been found in the heart of the Milky Way, a Dutch astronomer said today.
A campaign to raise $1,000,000 annually for the next three years was opened yesterday by the Council for the Advancement of Small Colleges.

CHICAGO, Nov. 17 (AP) -A heavy volume of short covering rallied soybean futures today and all contracts finished well ahead for their first general gains in four trading sessions on the Board of Trade.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 17 -- In The Supreme Court of The United States today the following proceedings were had:

HARRISON, N. Y., Nov. 17 -- Many of the taxpayers in this suburban town of 16,999 received a shock today. The five chief town officials filed a proposed 1960 budget that would reduce the pay of the jobs they hold.
The annual exhibit of the Package Machinery Manufacturers Institute opened at the New York Coliseum yesterday amid predictions of a sharp surge in orders next year.
Blood will be given to the Red Cross today at the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company, 1 Madison Avenue.

PRINCETON, N. J., Nov. 17 -- Nine Russian scientists toured the thermonuclear research facilities at Princeton University's James Forrestal Research Center today and commented, "We've seen many new and interesting things here just as the Americans did when they were in the Soviet Union."

Arthur Loew Jr. and Jule Styne have formed a partnership to produce plays, motion pictures and television programs. Their first project will be "Lady in Waiting," a new drama by Evan Hunter. David Alexander has been engaged to stage the play.
A new workshop for professional writers, performers and directors will be started this month by the Columbia Broadcasting System television network.
A Congressional committee indicated yesterday that it had undercover reports about Communist plans aiming at violence to "liberate Puerto Rico."

WASHINGTON, Nov. 17 -- Attorney General William P. Rogers denounced Mississippi's handling of the Mack Charles Parker lynching case today as a "travesty on justice." He said the case might lead to proposals for new civil rights legislation.

It is forty years since the United States formally adopted a policy of isolation in a world already far too small to be ignored. On Nov. 19, 1919, this lunacy began when the Senate rejected the Versailles Treaty ending the first great war.

Football linemen perform their laborious chores in virtual anonymity while the backs grab the headlines. But when it comes to electing captains, most teams give credit where it is due and pick their leaders from the line.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 17 -- A shift from liquid to solid fuels was urged today for the massive rocket launchers that will be used in the exploration of space.
BOSTON, Nov. 17 -- A new American foreign policy is needed to meet "the ugly fact of mass poverty in Asia and Africa," Senator Wayne Morse, Democrat of Oregon, said here tonight.

AT this time of year there is a special competition in tournament bridge, usually with no more than three or four players involved. At Stake is the William E. McKenney Trophy, which goes to the player who has the best tournament record of the year.
LONDON, Nov. 17 -- The general principles of the Government's bill to legalize off-track betting received an overwhelming endorsement in the House of Commons tonight.

As part of the preparation for an East-West summit meeting, Chancellor Adenauer is visiting London for talks with Prime Minister Macmillan aimed at removing recent misunderstandings between Britain and Germany as a contribution toward Western solidarity. But the visit is taking place against a divided background which makes its results somewhat problematical.

In the early stages of his fight to retain control of the Alleghany Corporation, railroad holding company with multi-billion dollar investment company interests, Allan P. Kirby may have alienated one of his chief allies -- the widow of his long-time comrade in corporate battle.
CHICAGO. Nov. 17 (AP) -- The report of today's livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture Follows:

TRENTON, Nov. 17 -- New Jersey Republicans were told today to substitute young candidates of impeccable character and ability for "boss-controlled party hacks" and persons with "skeletons in their closets" if they wished to win future elections.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 17 -- Ceylon exhorted the Arab countries today to accept Israel's offer of negotiations on the Palestinian refugees.
FORT BENNING, Ga., Nov. 14 -- This home of the doughboy has become a military mecca of the western world.

Although Julie Harris' career in the theatre spans a period of fifteen years, she will be making her professional Shakespearean debut next summer in "Romeo and Juliet." She will portray Juliet for the Stratford (Ont.) Shakespeare Festival on June 27.

There's nothing wrong with the millinery industry that two good seasons in a row wouldn't cure. This is the general consensus of manufacturers in New York's millinery center on West Thirty-ninth Street. Unfortunately, however, it has been hard to line up even one good season in recent years, much less two.
KANSAS CITY, Nov. 17 (AP) -- Organized labor gave a medal to Harry S. Truman last night and got some advice in return.
Hanson W. Baldwin's tribute of Nov. 12 to Fort Dix will reawaken some quiescent memories in the minds of thousands of veterans who heard the first bark of a sergeant at that post.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 17 -- Federal prosecutions may result from the Justice Department's study of television frauds, Attorney General William P. Rogers said today.
American business was warned yesterday that it must intensify its battle for foreign markets. Both economic necessity and a need to counteract the Communist challenge were cited.

PARIS, Nov. 17 -- Edouard Leclerc, the grocer from Brittany whose price-lowering tactics have put him in the national spotlight, extended his operations to the Paris region today to the hostile cries of his competitors.

EVERY autumn when the annual flooding of the river of new books takes place a number of good, or promising, or newsworthy books are in danger of being overlooked. "Malcolm" by James Purdy, which was published last September, belongs to the second classification just mentioned. Already some critics have hailed it as a work of comic genius.

A new book by Sally Carrighar, "Wild Voice of the North," will be pubished tomorrow by Doubleday. It is the story of Bobo, a part-wolf Siberian Husky dog, which she took into her house while living in Nome, Alaska. Part of the book's material appeared as an article in The Saturday Evening Post.

ENDICOTT, N. Y., Nov. 17 -- The theft of cash and clothing with a total value of $68,200 from a Weber Heilbroner store in New York City was revealed here today after the police arrested a woman charged with disposing of stolen suits.
SYRACUSE, Nov. 17 -- The end of construction of low-income public housing in New York City was advised here today. The proposal was strongly opposed by a New York City Housing Authority official.

A banker with a flair for new ideas, Lloyd D. Brace, chairman of the First National Bank of Boston, told the New York Security Analysts yesterday that banking was not as static as most people believed. More than 45 per cent of his bank's revenues come from services not in existence twenty-five years ago, he said.
Three stock splits, along with increases in dividends, were among favorable dividend actions taken yesterday by company directors.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Nov. 17 -- President Juscelino Kubitschek said today that a new United States advisory group on hemispheric relations must realize that "the problem of pan-American understanding is not based on purely economic issues."
The proposed baseball stadium in Flushing Meadows, Queens, will probably be equipped with a retractable roof so that it can be used during bad weather and the winter months.
SPRINGFIELD, Mass., Nov. 17 -- Gov. Mark O. Hatfield of Oregon declared tonight that states must develop a partnership to cope with the phenomenal growth forecast for the next decade.

FLORAL PARK, L. I., Nov. 17 -- An experimental program to shorten the conventional seven-week summer high school program by two weeks has been viewed favorably by school officials and pupils here and by the State Education Department.
George Meany said last night that charges of Jim Crow practices by the International Longshoremen's Association on the New York waterfront would be investigated.
A suggestion that advertiser and agency groups establish "internal courts" to police the advertising industry's activities, was made yesterday by Thomas D'Arcy Brophy.

Stockholders of the Gulf Oil Corporation at a special meeting held yesterday In Pittsburgh approved an increase in authorized capital stock to 150,000,000 shares with a par value of $8.331/3 each from 50,000,000 shares with a par value of $25 each.
The Zeckendorf interests announced yesterday the acquisition of three Chicago hotels -- the Sherman, the Ambassador East and the Ambassador West.

Copper futures dropped for the fifth consecutive trading day on the Commodity Exchange of New York yesterday. The decline was 25 to 88 points (hundredths of a cent a pound). Volume was 1,100 lots (50,000 pounds to a lots, the second largest total, since trading in the commodity opened twenty-six years ago.
NEW HAVEN, Conn., Nov. 17 -- In 1875 Harvard and Yale met for the first time in football under "concessionary rules."

DENVER, Colo., Nov. 17 -- Officials of chain grocery stores that fatten and slaughter their own livestock denied before a Congressional subcommittee here today that they integrated their meat operations vertically in order to squeeze the farmer and consumer.
As head coach of the Giants Jim Lee Howell knows better than anyone what's wrong with his team.
LISBON, Portugal, Nov. 17 (Reuters) -- All Manuel Ferreira wanted was to go to the United States. Instead, the 16-year-old youth wound up a hero -- and under arrest.

HAVANA, Nov. 17 -- The Government "intervened" in fourteen tobacco farms totaling 10,274 acres in Pinar del Rio Province yesterday. Intervention is a preliminary step to expropriation under the Agrarian Reform law.
The State of Delaware borrowed $16,350,000 in the bond market yesterday to finance school construction, highway improvement and other public improvements.
TWO exhibitions, open today to the public, are rewarding on the double score of the material exhibited, and the manners of exhibitions.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 17 -- Secretary of State Christian A. Herter pledged today that the United States would continue to give full support to the North Atlantic Alliance.
Ralph Votapek, a winner of this year's Naumburg Musical Foundation Award, gave his piano recital under the foundation's auspices yesterday afternoon in Town Hall.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 17 -- The General Assembly expressed today "deep regret and concern" over racial conflict in South Africa.

Stockholders of Conde Nast Publications, Inc., have voted at a special meeting here to increase the authorized common from 1,050,000 shares to 2,000,(}00 shares. The share owners also voted to change the stock, which is without par value, $1 par.
AUGUSTA, Ga., Nov. 17 -- President Eisenhower is considering a proposal that former President Harry S. Truman or some other Democratic leader accompany him on his tour of eleven countries.
HANOVER, N. H., Nov. 17 -- Governor Rockefeller sent his blessings tonight to a rally supporting his candidacy for President in 1960.

LONDON, Nov. 17 (UPI) -- Henry Cooper of England kept his British Isles and British Empire heavyweight championships tonight by scoring a technical knockout over Joe Erskine of Wales in the twelfth round at Earls Court Stadium.

The Composers Group of New York City offered a program at Carnegie Recital Hall last night that, except for five songs by Juliette Perez, consisted entirely of new works having their first performance.

The price of men's suits probably will be unchanged next spring and summer but popular-price garments are heading for a $5 increase at the retail level next fall, according to Jerome I. Udell, chairman of Max Udell Sons Co., Inc., producer of men's clothing.
PARENTS and children may combine an afternoon in the crisp autumn air with a visit to the city's most controversial structure, the Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum, Fifth Avenue and Eighty-eighth Street.
BONN, Germany, Nov. 17 -West Germany and Guinea set up a technical cooperation program today and laid plans to negotiate a commercial treaty.
The Armstrong Rubber Company set a new sales record for the fifth consecutive time and raised earnings by 54 per cent in the fiscal year ended on Sept. 30.

THE Museum of Modern Art, which announced a campaign to raise funds for a new wing Monday, should have the sympathy of every apartment dweller who has tried to make a hall closet do the work of an attic and basement combined.
A medical committee here has recommended a return to two-year interneships in municipal hospitals to alleviate an expected shortage of qualified physicians.
SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 17 -- "Nixon for President" supporters swung into action today in Northern California.

Net income of International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation and its consolidated subsidiaries in the nine months ended on Sept. 30 rose to $19,001,874, or $1.31 a share, from $18,014,686, or $1.25 a share in the 1958 period, it was announced yesterday.
Dr. Edward Teller, the nuclear physicist, said last night that "freedom is not the natural state of human life" but must be fought for.

DAYTONA BEACH, Fla., Nov. 17 -- The tremendous success of the Sports Car Club of America national races at the Daytona International Speedway last week-end has resulted in a surge of planning for similar events there next Year.
LONDON, Nov. 17 -- Stock market prices here sagged again today, although losses among industrials were generally smaller than yesterday's.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 17 (AP) -The Securities and Exchange Commission lifted an order today that had barred the sale of common stock and debentures by Sports Arenas, Inc., of Great Neck, N. Y., and some of its stockholders.

HAVANA, Nov. 17 (UPI)-The Panamanian Ambassador protested to Cuba today against permitting "subversive activities'' in Cuba aimed at a second invasion of Panama, informed diplomatic sources reported. They said Ambassador Alberto Obarrio charged at a meeting with the Cuban Foreign Yzinister, Dr. Raul Roa, that the same man who led an invasion of Panama from Cuba last spring was preparing another. Dr. Roa was said to have promised to investigate.
JAKARTA, Indonesia, Nov. 17 -- Indonesia and Communist China clashed today over Jakarta's ban on trading by aliens in rural areas beginning Jan. 1.

The Supreme Court decision in the case of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters has cleared up any doubt that Federal Judge Letts has the legal power to compel James R. Hoffa, the union's provisional president, to obey the clean-up recommendations of the Board of Monitors. And the board's chairman, Martin F. O'Donoghue, has left no doubt that it is going to press with the utmost energy this crucial advantage in the battle for teamster reform.

Commissioner Ford C. Frick, normally a mild-mannered fellow who doesn't lose his temper easily, is developing a slow burn. Those potshots Branch Rickey and his Continental League colleagues keep firing at the commissioner, accusing him of interfering with their efforts to establish themselves as that long-awaited third major league, gradually are getting under Ford's skin.
ALPINE, N. J., Nov. 17 -- Bids were taken in Trenton today by the State Highway Department for the demolition of an extraordinary monument to personal privacy.

SHUSHAN, N. Y., Nov. 17 -Nothing illuminates the genius of the modern American hunter better than his resolute use of his most efficient weapon, which has brought a new and expressive word into English: to carhunt.

Four Queens teen-agers pleaded guilty to second-degree assault with intent to commit rape in Queens County Court yesterday, six months after they were accused of attacking a 14-year-old Corona schoolgirl.
Of all the annoyances of New York City, one of the most shattering is the new horns on fire equipment which blast one from sleep, nay, from bed, a ham dozen times a week.
WESTBURY, L. I., Nov. 17 -- Billy Haughton passed the million-dollar mark in trainer-driver earnings tonight for the second year in a row.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 17 -- Technological progress on the farm is producing meat at such a rate that not even a bumper crop of Americans will be able to consume it.
Steels, motors and some of the electronic issues led the stock market yesterday in an advance that added about $3,300,000,000 to the market value of stocks on the New York Stock Exchange.
Columbia University announced a major historical find yesterday -- the original draft, in John Jay's handwriting, of essay No. 64 in the Federalist Papers.
SAN JUAN, P.R., Nov. 18 -A Congressional subcommittee witness today described a $100,000,000 Communist propaganda program designed to spread anti-American feeling in Latin America.

Copper futures rose yesterday for the first time in six consecutive trading days. The market was nervous throughout the day on the Commodity Exchange of New York. Trading was influenced by rumors of settlements of strikes at domestic mines and denials of the reports.

In your renewed editorial stand against off-track betting last week ("Mr. Wagner Rides Again," Nov. 12) you asserted: "There is certainly a big dose of hypocrisy in present law and practice, when gambling is approved on one side of a fence to the large enrichment of the state's revenues, and illegal on the other."

WHITE PLAINS, Nov. 18 -Twenty-seven residents of Pelham Manor told a State Supreme Court justice here today that the New England Thruway had become such a nuisance that sleep, conversation, health and recreation were impaired.
Columbia has virtually the same squad this season as it had in 1958-59. Last season the Lions won only three games and lost twenty-one.
Governor Rockefeller proposed last night the establishment of a Western Hemisphere economic union comparable to the European Economic Community and similar regional trade groupings.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 18 -The Federal Reserve Board reported today that the statement of condition of weekly reporting member banks in leading cities showed the following principal changes for the week ended Nov. 11:
There will be a theatre party at the Dec. 18 performance of "The Sound of Music" at the Lunt-Fontanne Theatre for the benefit of Hamilton-Madison House.

The licensed officers on the twenty-seven ships of Esso's American-flag tanker fleet will have a paid day off for every two days of work. These terms were part of a new contract that becomes effective today.
TRENTON, N.J., Nov. 18 (AP) -- The latest traffic counts in a final engineering report indicate that the Garden State Parkway will operating in the red in five years.
The city's new pilot project for treating adult drug addicts was described yesterday as "a pathetic little ward of twenty-five beds" by the Rev. Norman C. Eddy.
A rehabilitation expert said here last night that "no nation can afford the luxury of wasted manpower" resulting from neglect of the crippled and the disabled.

WALLACEBURG, Ont., Nov. 18 -- Harlow H. Curtice, former president of the General Motors Corporation, accidentally shot and killed Harry W. Anderson, a retired vice president of the company, while hunting ducks near here today.

VIENTIANE, Laos, Nov. 18 (Reuters) -- A Laotian Army spokesman said today that Communist Chinese had formed the bulk of an attacking force that captured an army post five miles from the Chinese border Nov. 9.

LONDON, Nov. 18 -- A Soviet physicist's theory that the passage of time can be regarded as a source of mechanical power was the subject of a widely publicized broadcast in English by the Moscow radio tonight.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 18 (AP) -- The House Ways and Means Committee heard suggestions from economists today that Social Security retirement benefits be made subject to Federal income tax.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 18 (AP) -- Transportation in the United States presents "a picture of obsolete equipment, nineteenth-century economics and laws and antiquated thinking," a Congressional subcommittee said today.

DETROIT, Nov. 18 (AP) -Creditors whose suits for debts have tied up the Panamanian freighter Theodoros-A have agreed to pay $56 a day to the end of this week to provide food for the twenty-four officers and Greek seamen stranded on the ship.
Eighteen Public Schools Athlethic League basketball games will be televised on Channel 7 Saturday afternoons this season starting Nov. 28, the American Broadcasting Company announced yesterday.
THE College Clubs Bridge League of New York is in its thirty-fourth season and is probably the oldest bridge league of its kind in the country, perhaps in the world.
SYRACUSE, Nov. 18 -- In contemporary society father is too often regarded as "the bully, the sap or the absentee landlord," a psychiatrist said here today.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 18 -- It is seldom noted that, in addition to two living former Presidents of the United States, there are three living citizens whom their political parties unsuccessfully offered for the Presidency. Thomas E. Dewey and Adlai E. Stevenson, each of whom was twice chosen by his party, have remained in the public eye.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 18 -- The Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare and officials of the cranberry industry jointly announced tonight agreement on a plan to assure consumers cranberries free of the weed-killer aminotriazole.
MOUNT KISCO, N.Y., Nov. 18 -- A high school teacher's revolt against what he asserts are administrative restraints on his classroom freedom has stirred wide interest in northern Westchester.
QUEBEC, Nov. 18 -- The Quebec Legislature embarked today on a new session with a new Premier, amid portents of a new era at home and in relations with the Federal Government.
Icy winds swept the Atlantic seaboard yesterday, bringing the first freeze of the season to New York and a record November cold snap to parts of the deep South.

LONDON, Nov. 18 -- Reginald Maudling, President of the Board of Trade, declared today Britain believed the projected European free trade association would prevent deterioration in the free-trade system in Europe.
HONG KONG, Nov. 18 -- Communist China stepped up a propaganda campaign today in favor of Premier Chou En-lai's proposals for a settlement of the China-India border dispute.

MIAMI BEACH, Fla., Nov. 18 -- The Union of American Hebrew Congregations went on record today as opposing the use of gambling "as a means of raising funds for the synagogue." A resolution was passed after sharp debate.
PARIS, Nov. 18 -- The French ready-to-wear manufacturers showed their collections for spring and summer 1960 to 1,200 persons in the lavish salons of the Hotel George V today.
Steel plants in the Philadelphia area were approaching full production yesterday as the back-to-work order under the eighty-day Taft-Hartley injunction passed its eleventh day.

FAIRFIELD Conn., Nov. 18 -- Bobby Whitbread, a 9-year-old pupil in Mrs. Veronica Gleason's fourth grade class at the Osborn Hill School, will be thankful on Thanksgiving Day because he is not a turkey.

Hunter College's undefeated soccer team took sole possession of first place in the Metropolitan Soccer Conference yesterday and ended City College's string of forty-nine league games without a loss. The Hawks whipped the Beavers, 1 -- 0, on the Hunted Field in the Bronx.

TRENTON, Nov. 18 (UPI) -Rutgers and Princeton Universities, while expressing a common distaste for Government loyalty oaths, split today on the question of participating in a Federal student loan program that requires the oath.
The New York Stock Exchange reported yesterday a decline of 120,482 shares in the short interest in listed stocks as of Nov. 13, to 3,318,559 shares from 3,439,041 on Oct. 15.
KIAMESHA LAKE, N.Y, Nov. 18 -- A leading Jewish theologian said here tonight that Alfred E. Smith's loss of the Presidency in 1928 was a "blot on the conscience of America."
BUFFALO, Nov. 18 -- The head of 2,000,000 unionized workers in the state accused the Rockefeller Administration today of "eroding the social insurance system by administrative decree."
WASHINGTON, Nov. 18 -The Administration answered today the critics of its new policy of "tied loans" to underdeveloped nations.

Stockholders in the Automatic Canteen Company of America approved an increase in the authorized common shares to 6,000,000 from 3,000,000, at a special meeting in Chicago yesterday. The vote cleared the way for a 100 per cent distribution of common stock to present holders.

A new move to rescind the city's 10-cent-a-ride taxicab tax was made in Albany yesterday by State Senator MacNeil Mitchell, Manhattan Republican, and Assemblyman Samuel I. Berman, Brooklyn Democrat. They pre-filed a bill to repeal the city's power to levy the tax.
The American Public Health Association for the first time in its eighty - seven - year history warned yesterday of the danger of an unchecked rise in world population.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 18 -The Atomic Energy Commission announced today the development of a 220-pound nuclear reactor to supply electrical power for advanced space vehicles.
From this evening on, Eugene O'Neill, whose plays earned him the Nobel Prize and four Pulitzer Prizes, will be honored nightly by Broadway in a blaze of neon.
A warrant for the arrest of Cus D'Amato, Floyd Patterson's manager, was obtained by the State Attorney General's office yesterday.
NEWARK, Nov. 18 -- A 23-year-old former hospital orderly who posed for six weeks as a medical student in Newark's Martland Medical Center is being sought by the police.
Two days in November at the Apalachin farm and estate of the late Joseph Barbara Sr. were described yesterday to a Federal court jury.
HARRIMAN, N. Y., Nov. 18 -- How much must a bureaucrat be prodded to make him jump to a new policy?
LAST February Pat Hingle, then appearing in the Broadway drama "J.B.," was critically injured in a fall. He was hospitalized and incapacitated from that time until recently.

AUGUSTA, Ga., Nov. 18 -President Eisenhower quickened the pace of his budget meetings today in the hope of having all estimates for the 1961 fiscal year "locked up" before his departure on an extended tour Dec. 3.

The next breed to be accepted for registration by the American Kennel Club will be the Australian terrier, a coarse-haired little dog from Down Under who is rough on rats and snakes. When the time of acceptance will arrive, though, not even the A.K.C. officers know.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 18 -- Livingston T. Merchant, Deputy Under Secretary of State, will leave Friday to discuss with Panama the issues underlying the recent deterioration in United States-Panamanian relations.
CONCORD, N. H., Nov. 18 -- Fifty supporters from all ten New Hampshire counties began rolling the Nixon-for-President bandwagon here tonight.
The ousted director of the city's Bureau of Weights and Measures was arrested yesterday and charged with involvement in meat-market frauds.
PARIS, Nov. 18 -- Senator Francois Mitterrand beat off a move to lift his Parliamentary immunity today after having linked Premier Michel Debre with a two-year-old case of assassination in Algiers.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 18 (UPI) -- Congressmen studied a report today on a Soviet crackdown on "high living on the expense account."

Investment bankers headed by William Blair Co. are ofifering today 133,600 shares of common stock of Barber-Greene ICompany, Aurora, Ill., asphalt mixing plant and paving machine maker. The stock has a [par value of $5 and is priced at 1517 a share.

BONN, Nov. 18 -- West Germany will run up a rare surplus in its financial dealings with the United States this year. Conceivably the figure could reach $500,000,000, which would represent most of an expected rise in the United States 1959 deficit in its international balance of payments.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 18 -- A man who had denied handling teamster pay-off money for his employer was indicted today by a Federal grand jury on a perjury charge.
Your editorial of Nov. 16 applauding the steps being taken for a Lower Manhattan Expressway includes a paragraph expressing "hope the Thirtieth Street project will also come to life now."

The investment world's absorption of the $250,000,000 issue of new 5 3/8 per cent debentures of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company continued to influence bond prices substantially yesterday.
New York State borrowed $55,125,000 in the bond market yesterday to finance advances to the New York City Housing Authority for the development of low-rent housing projects.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Nov. 18 -- United States investments in the Union of South Africa have grown from $450,000,000 in 1956 to $600,000,000 in 1959, a spokesman for that country today informed the General Assembly's Economic Committee.

If Commissioner Ford Frick conferred his immediate blessings on the Continental League and told the world there wasn't a chance of expansion by the two existing leagues, the Continental League would be ready to close ranks within three weeks.

" LITTLE MARY SUNSHINE," a new musical that brought light and cheer last night to the Orpheum Theatre on Second Avenue and Eighth Street, is a merry and sprightly spoof of an era when "justice always triumphed," when "good meant good" and when "bad meant bad."

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 18 --- French sources said today that the Algerian nationalists were stalling on their reply to President Charles de Gaulle's offer to come to Paris for cease-fire talks to end the five-year-old war in Algeria.
Serious shortcomings in the physics program of many New York City high schools were reported in two independent studies released yesterday by the Board of Education.
COPENHAGEN, Denmark, Nov. 18 AP) -- Vilhelm Sorensen brought a dozen eggs, laid by a fine strain of New Hampshire hens, home from a visit to West Germany two years ago.
The United States must maintain in its Army forces that can fight either nuclear or non-nuclear war, the Army Chief of Staff said yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 18 -- Dr. Winfield W. Riefler, a leading authority on monetary affairs, will retire at the end of the year as assistant to the chairman of the Federal Reserve Board of Governors.

Stockholders of manny companies will have special reason to celebrate Thanksgiving Day next week, what with extra year-end dividends or increased payments voted by directors yesterday. In many instances the distributions this year well exceed the amounts paid out to shareowners in 1958.
The Girls Service League will benefit from the third annual Gold and Silver BaH, to be held in the Grand Ballroom of the Plaza Dec. 30.

Middle South Utilities, Inc., and subsidiaries reported yesterday a gain of 7.5 per cent in operating revenues for the twelve months ended on Oct. 31. Electric operating revenues were up 8.9 per cent. Revenues for the first ten months of 1959 rose 8.1 per cent, with electric operating revenues pacing the gain, up 9.3 per cent.
PHOENIX, Ariz., Nov. 18 (UPI) -- Zora Folley scored a unanimous ten-round decision over Alonzo Johnson tonight in a nationally televised heavyweight bout.
The three major television networks are united in opposition to Governor Rockefeller's system of separate press conferences for newspaper reporters and TV-radio correspondents.

The latest insider's report published by the New York Stock Exchange shows that Sidney M. Schramm, a director of Artloom Industries, Inc., sold 2,400 shares in October to reduce his holdings to 2,700 shares.

Bonds bearing the backing of the French Government will be offered soon for the first time since 1930 in the United States public market. There is no French Government public dollar debt now outstanding.
MINNEAPOLIS, Nov. 18 (AP) -- New York held off a closing drive by Minneapolis and registered a 106-105 National Basketball Association victory tonight.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 18 -- A trail of sodium vapor, from fifty to 150 miles above the earth, lighted a wide area of the Atlantic seaboard at dusk today.

OMAHA, Neb., Nov. 18 (AP) -- Three pacifists were sentenced today to six months in a Federal correctional institution and fined $500 and costs each for having re-entered a military establishment after they had been warned not to.
LONDON, Nov. 18 -- Chancellor Konrad Adenauer and his Foreign Minister, Dr. Heinrich von Brentano, have allayed British concern on two policy points that were a source of disagreement.
CHICAGO, Nov. 18 (AP) -- The report of today's livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:

Our West European partners in the North Atlantic alliance are now holding top-level meetings to iron out their differences and restore a united front before facing Premier Khrushchev in an East-West summit meeting. It is encouraging that they are putting the common ties that bind them above any differences that divide them, and that after the Paris agreement between Britain and France like agreement is being reached in the London talks between Britain and Germany.

The city's Salute to Fall ended yesterday on a wintry note. The temperature was freezing and there was a spanking northwest breeze as New York received five concrete tubs of red, yellow and white chrysanthemums.
Two major prepaid health insurance plans acted yesterday to broaden their medical and surgical coverage for some of their subscribers.

ONE of baseball's towering bastions of strength is its resistance to change. Its rules and its methods impart homey feelings of comfort and familiarity. But this arch-conservatism is also one of its weaknesses. It needs an occasional adventuresome move to jolt it from a humdrum pattern and to quicken new interest.
WESTBURY, L.I., Nov. 18 -An Air Force surplus jet engine and an Army surplus truck provided a day-time double that paved the way for the evening double at Roosevelt Raceway tonight.
OMAHA, Neb., Nov. 18 (UPI) -- Nebraska and Iowa leaders gave a house subcommittee their ideas today on legislation to "stop New York publishers from sending their filth" to the Midwest.

" I have just come from the frontier visting the encampments there while cannon were booming on the Algerian side of the border. The condition of the people is so pitiful that I can find no words to tell you. * * * Many will surely die."
PARIS, Nov. 18 -- France will budget the equivalent of $308,000,000 next year as a down payment on an atomic striking force that will begin to be operational in 1963.
LONDON, Nov. 18 -- Small though persistent selling again depressed all industrial sections of the stock market here today.
Felix Houphouet-Boigny, Premier of the Republic of the Ivory Coast, charged yesterday that communism had begun a drive to penetrate Africa from Guinea.
Cold weather across the nation last week cut stocks of light fuel oil, used mainly for home heating, to the lowest level since last winter.
JAKARTA, Indonesia, Nov. 18 -- Indonesia told Chinese Communist Embassy officials today to stop sabotaging her domestic economic policies.

The head of the Soviet atomic energy program proposed yesterday that the United States and the Soviet Union share the costly burden of developing nuclear power by joining in a comprehensive program of research.

A blanket $1.50 statutory minimum wage in New York will be the top legislative demand of the state A.F.L.-C.I.O. next year. So its top officers told Governor Rockefeller the other day. This proposal focuses on an issue that calls for wide discussion next year.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 18 -- The Administration has lifted its ban on new starts in Western power and reclamation projects.

CHICAGO, Nov. 18 (AP) -The grain futures market managed some firmness in spots on the Board of Trade today but it appeared to be linked mainly with shifting of technical trade positions rather than any commercial demand.
The National Maritime Union yesterday called upon the National Labor Relations Board to extend the union's jurisdiction to labor contracts covering Honduran-flag ships.

Safety first? Or salability first? These are questions inexperienced investors who are thinking of registering certain new Treasury notes must answer. Three note issues are involved. They are the 4 3/4s sold in July, the "Magic 5s" sold in September, and the 4 7/8s sold two weeks ago.
LONDON, Nov. 18 -- Home Secretary R.A. Butler acknowledged tonight that there was public anxiety about the condition of the police force.

We admire the action of Harvard and Yale Universities in withdrawing from the Federal student loan program because of the loyalty-oath requirement. In doing so, they join Princeton and several of the country's leading smaller colleges, such as Amherst and Oberlin, in the one way of effectively protesting the insult to American youth that is implicit in the National Defense Education Act of 1958.

CHICAGO, Nov. 18 -- The New York Rangers were dealt several cruel blows tonight at Chicago Stadium. Alf Pike, in his first time out as full-time coach, saw his debut ruined and the Black Hawks continued their mastery of the New Yorkers.

James Felt, chairman of the City Planning Commission, denied a charge yesterday that his agency and the Board of Education were shrouding the city's billion-dollar school-construction program in secrecy.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Nov. 18 -- The Soviet Union told the United Nations today that it would not resume testing nuclear weapons as long as the West refrained from such tests.
THOMAS GEORGE, who has not exhibited in New York since 1954, shows recent abstractions at Betty Parsons' Section Eleven Gallery, 11 East Fifty-seventh Street.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 18 (AP) -- The Eisenhower Administration has shown more open support for military strong-man regimes in Latin America than the Truman Administration did, according to a report prepared for Senate study.

CHICAGO, Nov. 18 -A railroad spokesman charged today that union opposition to the industry's demand that firemen be eliminated from Diesel locomotives in freight and yard service was a "smokescreen of misrepresentation."

MELBOURNE, Australia, Thursday, Nov. 19 (AP) -- Australia's Peter Thomson and Kel Nagle teed off today for the second round of the Canada Cup matches with a 7-stroke lead, the biggest margin any country had ever enjoyed at any stage of play since this pro golf tourney was inaugurated seven years ago.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Nov. 18 -Gov. Robert B. Meyner assailed President Eisenhower and his Administration today in terms far more harsh and direct than he had ever indulged in before.

A big plant for the direct reduction of iron ore to sponge iron is being constructed at Monterrey, Mexico. It will reduce iron ore by direct contact with hot, reformed natural gas in batch-type reactors to produce 500 tons a day of sponge iron.
ALBANY, Nov. 18 -- New York business men served notice today that they would strongly oppose any attempt to enact a state-wide compulsory system of major medical insurance.

SPRINGFIELD, Mass., Nov. 18 -- The question of establishing a Federal Department of Urban Development produced today the liveliest debate of the National Municipal League's sixty-fifth annual conference.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Nov. 18 -Since gossip is often more important than food in this diet-conscious community, there was a great deal of comment here today about Gregory Peck, Marilyn Monroe and a movie called "The Billionaire."
CHICAGO, Nov. 18 (AP) -A red-haired baby girl was born today in the Union League Club, a men's retreat that women may enter only if accompanied by their husbands.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 18 -The head of the trade protectionist movement declared today that the United States' balance-of-payments problems require that this nation not cut its tariffs further, and that it prepare instead to raise tariffs and other barriers against imports.
A man jumped or fell to his death early yesterday morning under a BMT subway train at the Sheepshead Bay station, Brooklyn.
Once he was past Beethoven's C minor Sonata, Op. 111, Agustin Anievas settled down to some exciting playing.

MOSCOW, Nov. 18 -- The case of the Soviet writer who seemed to have expressed compassion for a wartime turncoat has taken a new turn. There is compassion for him and outrage over the "cruelty" of those who condemned him.
The International Longshoremer's Association was welcomed back into the House of Labor yesterday, ending an exile of six years one month and twenty-seven days.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 18 -House investigators planned today a series of forays into major cities after receiving reports from "all over the place" on "plugs," phony commercials in television and "payola."

AS a change from large, baleful books about the doom of dynasties and such, we recommend today "The Small Mosaics of Mr. and Mrs. Engel,"* by Patricia Collinge and "A Moose in the Hoose," by Frank Sullivan.
The National Broadcasting Company confirmed yesterday that it was studying the question of whether to continue the Friday night prize-fights on radio and television.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 18 -Dean Acheson warned today that talks with the Soviet Union on the basis of terms now being considered could represent a major defeat for the West.

WOMEN'S love of gossip is paying for college scholarships, camp vacations for poor children and a host of other worthy causes. For the phenomenal success of the "house tour," a money-raising device, is generally attributed to the womanly urge to peek at and discuss someone else's housekeeping.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Nov. 18 -- The United States supported today a request for a discussion on Hungary in this session of the General Assembly.

Anastas I. Mikoyan has become the first high Soviet official ever to visit Canada and the first such official ever to visit Mexico. His stop in Halifax, of course, was nominally only a halt for a night's rest, but more realistically it may be assumed that Mr. Mikoyan was hinting to our Canadian friends that Moscow is ready to do business with Ottawa any time Ottawa is ready.
Operating revenues of the Getty Oil Company in the first nine months of this year increased by $6,158,768 from the 1958 level, but earnings fell $6,676,123, according to the report issued yesterday.

OTTAWA, Nov. 18 (Canadian Press) -- Prairie farmers apparently will have to wait until next spring before attempting to harvest more than one-quarter of Canada's 1959 wheat crop of 413,500,000 bushels.

AFTER more than half a century of seeking statehood, Hawaii this year will celebrate her first Thanksgiving as the fiftieth state. To express her gratitude and happiness for becoming a full-fledged member of the Union and as a gesture of friendliness, the Aloha State invites the world to join her in a four-day Admissions Day Celebration beginning on Thursday, Thanksgiving Day.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange advanced 3 to 9 points yesterday. (A point equals 5 cents a bale.)

THE Soviet composers have reason to be satisfied with their American tour. Though they have had to deal with some touchy questions, they have been received everywhere with cordiality. Their music has been played by our best orchestras, and the public has greeted it with warmth.

For the first time since 1954, thoroughbred racing was canceled in New York yesterday. A frozen track at Aqueduct caused the action to be taken and it disappointed about 20,000 fans who otherwise would have spent the day at the new Queens plant.
American Broadcasting-Paramount Theatres, Inc., is planning to enter the publishing field, further diversifying its activities.

TORONTO, Nov. 18 (AP) -United States riders placed first and third in the international horse jumping two-and-two individual class at the Royal Winter Fair tonight. The team thus took second place in the over-all standing, behind Canada. Mexico placed second and Canada fourth in the event.

THE wheel of fate turned yesterday to put Frederick James Loughran, former director of the City Bureau of Weights and Measures, on the other side of the law. He was arrested on a charge of extortion in the investigation of city butchers.
Members of a recently victorious reform Democratic club and tenants of two slum buildings on the West Side collaborated yesterday to save the buildings from being closed by the Fire Department.
KANSAS CITY, Nov. 18 (AP) -- Bob Elliott, 42, manager of Sacramento of the Pacific Coast League and a former major league player, was signed today to manage the Kansas City Athletics.
ALBANY, Nov. 18 (AP) -Bingo returned a profit of nearly $5,000,000 to its operators from total receipts of $21,000,000 during its first two years as a legal game in New York State.

SHUSHAN, N.Y., Nov. 18 -Hunting in the rain is an important part of the outdoor life, as nature lovers love to call it, in New York State, and the pursuit of deer around here yesterday brought this sharply into focus.
Helen Hayes yesterday stepped into a familiar element -- the limelight -- but in an unfamiliar setting -- City Hall.
PRINCETON, N.J., Nov. 18 -- For the past two years Princeton and Dartmouth have met here for the Ivy football championship, the Tiger winning in 1957 and the Green last November.

Harold Tepper, a 17-year-old Lafayette senior who started running only a year ago, capped an outstanding season yesterday when he took the Public Schools Athletic League cross-country title at Van Cortlandt Park, the Bronx.
Norman Thomas, who will reach the age of 75 tomorrow, was campaigning as vigorously as ever last night. His cause was controlled disarmament and international planning to wipe out poverty.

It is true that a large network of laws has been enacted which are beneficial to veterans, their widows and orphans, and we are thankful for this legislation. However, we of the Disabled American Veterans and other responsible veterans' organizations know from personal experience in our service work that there are still many inequities in veterans' legislation and we are constantly striving to eliminate them.

The six-story building containing fifty-eight apartments at Bay Twenty-ninth Street in the Bensonhurst area of Brooklyn has been sold by the 69-29 Realty Corporation. The plot is 96 by 140 feet. The deal for cash over mortgages amounting to $290,000 was negotiated by Jac Convisser of Caserta Co., brokers.

Dmitri Kabalevsky, one of the five Soviet composers visiting the United States, said yesterday that there had been "injustice and unfairness in criticism of certain works" in the Soviet Union. But such instances of unfairness to compositions, he added, had been written about openly in all the Russian newspapers.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 18 (UPI) -- Twelve rank-and-file members of the Teamsters Union asked a Federal judge today to remove James R. Hoffa as provisional president, pending a trial on corruption charges before an impartial panel.
Ten electric utilities and a research laboratory have joined in a project that they say could some day revolutionize electric power generation.

American editions of two novels that received considerable attention when they were published in France will be issued this month. Grove Press will publish on Monday Alain Robbe-Grillet's "Jealousy," in a translation by Richard Howard. The story, set on a tropical banana plantation, tells of a jealous husband whose suspicion of his wife and neighbor takes possession of his mind.

BOSTON, Nov. 18 -- Dr. Joachim Prinz, president of the American Jewish Congress, warned today against "the new assimilationism". He called this a kind of vicarious Jewish living by those who believed in international Jewish philanthropy and other good works without having any Jewish commitment themselves.

Burton Pugach, a lawyer indicted in a lye attack last June 15 on a 23-year-old woman, was released from the Bronx County jail yesterday after obtaining bail of $105,000. The bail was said to be the highest ever posted for an individual in a Bronx criminal case.

A BIG moment for any mezzo-soprano is her first Carmen with a major company, and last night Rosalind Elias had her opportunity at the Metropolitan Opera. Miss Elias was a replacement for the indisposed Rise Stevens.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 18 (UPI) -- Secretary of Labor James P. Mitchell granted most unions today a period of grace before they must comply with complex bonding provisions of the new labor-reform law.

At Forty-second Street and Fifth Avenue New York City has one of the great cultural institutions of the world. The New York Public Library's beginnings go back to a conversation in upper Manhattan in 1838 with John Jacob Astor, which led to a gift of $400,000 and the opening of a library named for him in 1854 in Lafayette Place.

Is Manhattan dying? It is understandable for a loyal New Yorker truly concerned over the fate of his city to ask this question. For with one eye he reads, in the first published report of a three-year study of the metropolitan region, about the spectacular growth of the suburbs, achieved in large part at the expense of his city -- the so-called core area, of which Manhattan itself is perhaps an inner core.

THE "magazine concept" of television programing that the Columbia Broadcasting System has under study differs from the usual thinking along such lines. Yet the proposal may contain the germ of an idea that could assure much better balance in programing without radically disrupting the medium's present commercial structure.
Some white families who are eligible for public housing do not apply because they have the mistaken idea that it is only for minority groups, a city consultant said yesterday.

Dr. Roy L. Reierson, vice president and chief economist of the Bankers Trust Company, urged yesterday that Congress reduce or eliminate the requirement that compels the Federal Reserve Banks to immobilize almost $12,000,000,000 of gold as a 25 per cent reserve against their note and deposit liabilities.
Excessive breakage of school windows by vandals has caused the Board of Education to make a major change in school building design.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Nov. 18 -- Yugoslavia's Communist leadership heard a glowing report today on the economy.

The Navy is kinder than many landlords. This sea dog service, which favors such shades as battleship gray, navy and white afloat, now offers the wives of Navy men a selection of "decorator" colors for their homes.
