Production of tools and dies, which often is considered a barometer for industry generally because it indicates mass-production trends well in advance, is holding up better than had been expected. This is disclosed by a survey of several hundred executives of leading tool and die concerns in this country and Canada.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 18 -The Foreign Service officers who represent the United States here and abroad are showing considerable improvement in their mastery of foreign languages.

PIMLICO, Md., Nov. 18 (AP) -- Mrs. H.C. Phipps' High Bid came within four-fifths of a second of the track record while carrying the top weight of 120 pounds to victory in the $22,900 Gallorette Stakes today.

The Department of Sanitation is testing a device that may sweep away many street sweepers. Valued at $10,500, it is a vacuumized sweeper designed to inhale cigarette butts, paper and other light litter that normally would be scooped up by men.

The Board of Estimate was asked yesterday to reverse the City Planning Commission's refusal to include $40,000,000 on its 1960 capital budget for a pier redevelopment program along lower Manhattan's East River waterfront.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 18 (AP) -- World steel production declined to a rate of 317,000,000 tons a year in the first nine months of 1959 because of the steel strike in the United States.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 18 (UPI) -- The Commerce Department said today it had blocked a Soviet effort to buy $15,556,207 worth of American stainless steel.
The Velvex Parking Corporation has taken title to three properties at 306-14 West Forty-fourth Street, 316-18 West Forty-fourth Street and 307-09 West Forty-third Street, west of Eighth Avenue.

MOSCOW, Nov. 18 -- The Soviet Union declared tonight that it was confident East-West summit negotiations would lead eventually to conclusion of a German peace treaty along the lines prescribed by the Kremlin.
The need to carry moves toward greater freedom of trade beyond the lifting of quota barriers and to a more general reduction of tariffs was stressed yesterday by a leading European spokesman.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 18 (AP) -- The Federal Trade Commission today accused ABC Vending Corporation of Long Island City, Queens, of violating antitrust laws by buying out major competitors.

Benjamin Cymrot moved for reinstatement yesterday to his $12 000-a-year post as acting director of the Bureau of Real Estate. He was dismissed for his alleged failure to explain how he could spend $27,000 more than his admitted earnings.
LONDON, Nov. 18 -- A portrait by Peter Paul Rubens, "Head of a Bearded Man," was sold at auction today for 35.000 ($98,000).
A "gimmick" promotion to sell automobiles through the alleged savings resulting from "word of mouth advertising" is being offered to residents in the metropolitan area.

Willie Toweel, of Johannesburg, South Africa, the former British Empire lightweight champion, will make his American ring debut tonight against Len Matthews of Philadelphia in the ten-round main event at Madison Square Garden.

Pelham Syndicate, Inc., has sold the six-story apartment house at 2070 to 2076 Bronx Park East, the Bronx, to the McWaltend Realty Corporation. Robert P. Sheldon, Inc., was the broker. The building, 225 by 100 feet, contains 105 apartments and six stores and is assessed at $450,000.
Three rabbinical leaders were honored yesterday by the Federation of Jewish Philanthropies of New York for "outstanding religious, communal and civic leadership."
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 19 -- India and Indonesia emphasized today that Palestinian refugees were entitled to return to what is now Israel.

Fluctuations in bond prices related to the market impact of the new $250,000,000 issue of American Telephone and Telegraph bonds subsided yesterday. Few price changes of importance were noted among either the taxable obligations of corporations and the United States Government or among the tax-exempt-interest securities of state and local governments.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 19 -- Railroad freight business jumped 13.9 per cent last week in the wake of resumed steel production, while truck loadings declined 1 per cent from the level of the preceding week.
The City of Philadelphia, Pa., borrowed $24,780,000 in the bond market yesterday on water and sewer bonds, due serially from 1961 to 1990.
LONDON, Nov. 19 -- The stock market here took a brighter turn today.

In all the recent discussion of proposals dealing with juvenile delinquency one important requirement seems to have been overlooked -- the need for a single, unified planning and executive authority with the necessary funds and power to carry out the plans adopted.
From estimated advertising billings of $10,000,000 a year two years ago, to virtually nothing in recent months -- this is the marketing and advertising story of the short, costly life of the Edsel.

TOLEDO, Ohio, Nov. 19 -- Paul M. Butler, National Democratic Chairman, attempted today to placate Democrats who did not like his announced policy for seating delegations at the party's 1960 convention in Los Angeles.

BEVERLY HILLS, Calif., Nov. 19 -- The discovery of ten paintings said to be by Italian and French masters was announced here today. The collection was described by a Chicago art appraiser and restorer as worth "perhaps $10,000,000."
Mayor Wagner described as "demagogic" yesterday a move by a Republican State Senator and a Democratic Assemblyman to abolish the city's 10-cents-a-ride taxicab tax.
Cotton futures moved 3 points (15 cents a bale) up to 5 points (25 cents) off yesterday on the New York Cotton Exchange. The distant months were easiest.

The Soviet spokesman at the United Nations professes to be confused by what he thinks is the inconsistency between Secretary Herter's advocacy last Monday evening of a "common language" between the communistic and the non-communistic world, and the American support of a resolution to discuss Hungary at the present session of the General Assembly.

KANSAS CITY, Nov. 19 (AP) -- David Sarnoff, board chairman of the Radio Corporation of America, forecast tonight a time when a single teacher will instruct 100,000 students at one time on a nation-wide education network.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 19 -- The National Shrine of the Immaculate Conception, a majestic pile that now dominates much of Washington's northeastern skyline, will be dedicated tomorrow in the presence of more than 200 members of the Roman Catholic hierarchy.

Hopes for peace in the steel industry sent the stock market up for a time yesterday. Then labor rejected an industry offer and prices crumbled. According to the yardstick used, the net result was either a moderate gain or a small loss for the day.
Governor Rockefeller praised the American Legion last night for "its unremitting vigilance against atheistic communism."
JAKARTA, Indonesia, Nov. 19 -- Indonesia has restricted the travel of Chinese Communist diplomats here to curb what she has called meddling in her internal affairs.

A growing "cult of easiness" in this country, which holds that knowledge and understanding may be made easy to acquire, is actually hurting intellectual achievement, a science education conference was told yesterday.

KANSAS CITY, Mo., Nov. 19 (UPI) -- Senator John F. Kennedy spent thirty minutes talking privately with Harry S. Truman today, then took a forty-five-minute tour around the memento-filled Truman Library.

That pleasant series named Music Forgotten and Remembered gave a four-composer concert of unusual works last night at the Metropolitan Museum. The soloist was Lillian Fuchs, in Telemann's Viola Concerto and the Vaughan Williams "Flos Campi."
WASHINGTON, Nov. 19 (AP) -- Assets of the Federal Housing Administration have topped the billion-dollar mark, Commissioner Julian H. Zimmerman announced today.
ANAHID AJEMIAN'S second Carnegie Recital program this season consisted of four contemporary violin works, two of them expressly written for her and heard in first performances.
SHUSHAN, N. Y., Nov. 19 -- The lesson for today would be "How to Keep Warm While Deer Hunting" if an authoritative teacher could be found. But even the eloquent talk nothing but vanities.
CHICAGO, Nov. 19 (AP) -- Heavy selling spread through the grain futures market today and at the end of trading on the Board of Trade only one plus sign remained in a broad list of losses.
Joseph H. Ream has been appointed vice president in charge of the Columbia Broadcasting System's newly created department of television program practices.

Jacob M. Alkow, an allied member of the New York Stock Exchange, yesterday was suspended by the exchange for five years. Mr. Alkow also holds voting stock in Alkow Co., Inc., a member of the exchange.
Rutgers has been changing its starting football line-up for every game this season. The same procedure will be followed tomorrow in the finale, or ninth game, against Columbia at Baker Field.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 19 -- The Political Committee of the General Assembly urged this evening that all nations refrain from nuclear weapons tests while Britain, the United States and the Soviet Union are negotiating on outlawing such experiments.

The Bronx District Attorney's office said yesterday that it was considering grand jury action in a court case in which charges were reduced against two reform-school inmates accused of stabbing a policeman.

WITH the approach of the holiday season, there is an increasing interest in caterers for private parties. One of the most recent to enter the field is 29-year-old John Clancy, who has a talent that almost matches his enthusiasm for the culinary art. His basic training in food preparation began, oddly enough, when he was a corporal in the Marine Corps.

The "Man of the Year" award will be presented by the Piece Goods Buyers Association of the Dress Industry to Roger Milliken, president of Deering, Milliken Co., Inc., and Milliken Woolens, Inc., at a dinner at the Astor Hotel on Feb. 13.
Ingemar Johansson, the heavyweight champion, indicated a definite break with Vincent J. Velella, the promoter, as the fighter boarded a plane last night for Paris and Geneva.
The endorsement of the so-called "buy-American" policy recently incorporated in United States foreign assistance loans was announced yesterday by the National Foreign Trade Convention.

Vincent J. Squillante and his brother Nunzio, the two former leaders of the racket-tainted garbage collection industry in the metropolitan area, were indicted yesterday on charges of conspiracy to rig bids for Government contracts.
JACKSON, Miss., Nov. 19 (UPI) -- Hodding Carter, editor and publisher of The Greenville Delta Democrat-Times, refuted today a suggestion that he belonged to a Communistic group.

PARIS, Nov. 19 -- A special Senate committee reaffirmed today its recommendation that Senator Francois Mitterrand's parliamentary immunity be lifted so that he might face a charge of contempt of justice.

Rubber futures continued to register sharp price movements in active trading on the Commodity Exchange of New York. Speculator and dealer selling, profit-taking and stop-loss selling lowered prices 100 to 140 points (hundredths of a cent a pound) on 1,690 tons, the eighth largest volume of the year.
The annual dinner and dance of the Virginians Society will be held this evening at the Park Lane.

The Dec. 21 performance of "The Sound of Music" at the Lunt - Fontanne Theatre will benefit the National Scholarship Service and Fund for Negro Students. Dr. Harry J. Carman, Dean Emeritus of Columbia College, is board chairman of the beneficiary and Mrs. Nathan Straus heads the benefit committee.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 19--Soviet and United States space experts have held preliminary discussions looking toward a cooperative program for the exploration of space.
Larry Adams, a tall blond-haired jockey from New Orleans, took the riding honors with four winners at Aqueduct yesterday as racing was resumed after a one-day layoff because of a frozen track.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 19 (UPI) -- The Civil Aeronautics Board refused today to rescind an order granting American Airlines authority to fly non-stop jet service between New York and San Francisco.

A realignment of management structure in American Airlines, Inc., elevates G. Marion Sadler to a new post of vice president and general manager, according to an announcement yesterday by C. R. Smith, president.
A Nicaraguan opposition leader asserts that three "columns'' of rebels are carrying on guerrilla fighting in his country.
NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., Nov. 19 -- The need for increased salaries to attract capable teaching staffs was stressed today by Dr. Mason W. Gross, president of Rutgers University.
FLINT, Mich., Nov. 19 (AP) -- "I have been hunting about thirty years and there never was an accident before," Harlow H. Curtice said today.
LONDON, Nov. 19 -- To one passer-by, it began to look like a Woolworth store. To another it had "grandeur." To the architect's resident assistant, it is "a wonderful mixture of guts and elegance."

The kind of "flagrant and calculated * * * miscarriage of justice" that, in Attorney General Rogers' words, has just taken place in Mississippi affords the strongest argument we know for adoption of Federal anti-lynch legislation. The United States Government now has but feeble powers to deal with such an outrage when, as in this instance, the local authorities and citizenry refuse to act.
The parallel circulation of the bloodstreams of a woman and a sheep through semipermeable cellophane has reportedly relieved the woman of acute uremia.

The American Field Service has sold the five-story building at 113 East Thirtieth Street, at Park Avenue South, to Joseph L. Ennis Co., realty operators. The sale was for cash and was negotiated by the Malcolm E. Smith Company, broker.
Secret negotiations here last week-end resulted in a new contract offer by the steel industry and its speedy rejection by the United Steelworkers of America.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 19 (AP) -- The Navy assigned the construction of two ships to its own yards today. It also decided to award contracts for eight vessels to private yards, to be selected by competitive bidding.

The Ford Foundation announced yesterday that a registration statement had been filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission covering a proposed offering to the public of 2,000,000 shares of common stock of Ford Motor Company owned by the foundation. This confirms reports published early last week that such a transaction was in the offing.
YOKOHAMA, Japan Friday, Nov. 20 (AP) -- A chemical plant blew up in a densely populated Yokohama suburb today, injuring at least 300 persons.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 19 (AP) -- President Eisenhower said today it would be impractical for a top Democratic leader such as former President Harry S. Truman to accompany him on his forthcoming foreign tour.

Average borrowings of member banks declined $52,000,000 to $856,000,000 in the week ended Wednesday, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday. Average excess reserves declined $65,000,000 to $430,000,000 from a revised figure of $495,000,000 the week before.

Freshman football players at Hanover suffered rough treatment yesterday as Dartmouth's three varsity units turned in the kind of Jarring tackles they hope will beat Princeton in tomorrow's Ivy League finale a Palmer Stadium.

CINCINNATI, Nov. 19 (AP) -- The New York Knickerbockers, leading all the way and profiting handsomely by the ragged play of their opponents, sent the Cincinnati Royals reeling to their eighth straight National Basketball Association defeat tonight, 130 -- 109.
HONOLULU, Nov. 19 (AP) -- The Kilauea Iki volcano shot flaming boulders and lava 1,150 feet aloft last night and today.
Sir Julian Huxley, the British biologist, proposed yesterday that a United Nations agency be formed to cope with the rapidly rising world population.

A macaca mulatta (rhesus) monkey from Kanpur, India, speaking to the New York Academy of Sciences on the troubles that beset it, could hardly have done a better job than the one turned in yesterday by Dr. Donald G. DeValois of Indianapolis, Ind.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 19 -- A greater volume of grain cargoes in the Federal agriculture aid program may be diverted to tankers as a result of a decision of the Department of Agriculture that was made known yesterday.
MOBILE, Ala., Nov. 19 (AP) Jerry Pittman, who turned 23 today, celebrated by shooting a five-under-par 67 for the opening-round lead in the $15,000 Mobile open golf tournament.
CHICAGO, Nov. 19 -- Guy L. Brown, chief of the Brotherhood of Locomotive Engineers, ordered a strike vote today.

VIENTIANE, Laos, Nov. 19 (AP) -- Conflicting reports about a new rebel-Communist attack in northern Laos circulated today as Dag Hammarskjold, United Nations Secretary General, ended his personal fact-finding visit to this Southeast Asian kingdom.
GENEVA, Nov. 19 -- The three-power conference for a ban on nuclear weapons tests bypassed today at its first formal session in two weeks the main issue before it.

WHITE PLAINS, Nov. 19 -- Westchester officials reported today that they would buy a $10,000 band wagon to send to all parts of the county's 448 square miles as a weather-protected, illuminated stage for outdoor concerts and plays.
Some practices of the city's Slum Clearance Committee were sharply criticized yesterday by Controller Lawrence E. Gerosa.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 19 (UPI) -- The National Labor Relations Board used its new powers under the labor reform law today for the first time to crack down on what it called illegal picketing.

IN a remote Korean village where the houses are clay and wattle and thatch, with domestic animals free to circulate in them, H. Harvard Arnason, director of the Walker Art Center in Minneapolis and chairman of the Art Department at the University of Minnesota, sat with a local painter discussing events in the art world -- literally the whole art world.

MINEOLA, L. I., Nov. 19 -- Joseph Baer, president of the Newspaper and Mail Deliverers Union, received a ten-day jail sentence in County Court here today for disorderly conduct during a deliverers' strike at Newsday, a Garden City publication.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 19 -- The conference of NATO parliamentarians in session here will need to make only a few inquiries to discover that small support has been revealed in this country for the position former Secretary of State Acheson urged upon the Western nations in his speech to the conference.

WESTBURY, L. I., Nov. 19 -- An electronic system to identify aircraft, said to have many applications in commercial and military aviation, was announced here today by the General Instrument Corporation.

THE "Four Aces" were the most powerful American bridge team for more than ten years, from 1934 until the end of World-War II. For the first three or four of those years they seemed almost invincible in national and international play.
LONDON, Nov. 19 -- The Archbishop of Canterbury, Dr. Geoffrey Fisher said today that adultery ought to be made a criminal offense in Britain.

TOKYO, Nov. 19 -- United States price supports for farm products came under fire in the next to last meeting of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade (GATT) today. The conference of about forty nations asked that the United States Government to give "serious consideration" to the problem.

Hofstra, edging up on the first undefeated season of its twenty-year football history, will try to tuck away the Long Island title tomorrow. That honor will go to the Flying Dutchman if they beat the United States Merchant Marine Academy.
The annual Lane Bryant awards of $1,000 each were presented yesterday to Mrs. Jessie Hughes of St. Louis, Mo., and to the Chagrin Falls Park Community Center of Chagrin Falls, Ohio.
HONG KONG, Nov. 19 -- The new United States effort to obtain voluntary regulation of local textile exports to the United States encountered strong opposition here today.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 19 -- Cranberries free of contamination were promised today for Thanksgiving by the industry and the Government.
ENGLEWOOD CLIFFS, N. J., Nov. 19 -- Col. Morrie de Pass of Pass Christian, Miss., showed up here the other day to claim his lost lion hunter -- a dog named M-bwana.
ALBANY, Nov. 19 (AP) -- The state's new law to curb labor-management racketeering remains in full force despite Federal action in the same field, the State Industrial Commissioner said today.
A new color film, "From Generation to Generation" tells the story of human reproduction through imagery and symbolism.
The report of a New York grand jury's investigation of the rigging of television quiz shows here was ordered permanently sealed and impounded yesterday.

BOSTON, Nov. 19 -- Dr. Charles F. Phillips, president of Bates College in Maine, was elected president today of the New England Council. He succeeds William W. Wren, vice president of the Southern New England Telephone Company.
LONDON, Nov. 19 -- The Bank of England announced today that it was to issue newly designed banknotes bearing the likeness of Queen Elizabeth II.
George Kaufman, president of the Kaufman Realty Corporation, has purchased fifteen acres in Parma Heights, a suburb of Cleveland. Don Loftus of Cleveland was the seller.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 19 -- The Department of Defense ordered today that manufacturers with military contracts of $1,000,000 or more subcontract with smaller concerns whenever possible and report their actions to the Pentagon.

THE most popular fashions of today and yesterday will be companions Tuesday at an auction to benefit Irvington House. The annual sale, to raise funds to care for children with heart disease, will be held at 8 P. M. at the Parke-Bernet Galleries, 980 Madison Avenue near Seventy-sixth Street.
The Colgate-Palmolive Company, a leading manufacturer of soaps, detergents and toilet preparations, plans to enter the ethical drug field.

ROME, Nov. 19 -- The Italian Government is believed to be preparing to appeal the question of the Upper Adige, or Southern Tyrol, to the International Court of Justice at The Hague. The court would be asked to decide whether Italy applied the letter and spirit of her international commitments affecting the Upper Adige.

ALBANY, Nov. 19 (AP) -"Something is wrong" with New York State's workmen's compensation system, an industry spokesman declared today. The spokesman was Thomas H. Fogarty of Binghamton, chairman, of the workmen's compensation committee of Associated Industries of New York State.
NORWALK, Conn., Nov. 19 -- A $310,000 project to provide access to a tract being developed by an aircraft corporation will be deferred, the new Mayor of Norwalk said today.

LONDON, NOV. 19 -- Dr. Per Jacobsson, executive director of the International Monetary Fund, predicted tonight that Britain soon would be able to remove the last vestiges of currency exchange restrictions.
NEW DELHI, India, Nov. 19 -- Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru was reported to have voiced confidence today that India could meet any eventuality arising from Chinese Communist aggression.
East and Gulf Coast ship operators yesterday faced a demand for a 10 per cent "across the board" wage increase by the National Maritime Union.

Whenever Dr. Walter H. Jacobs sees a fighter get banged on the mouth, hit in the teeth for butted on the gums, he immediately begins to worry -- not about the fighter, but about the fighter's mouthpiece. Dr. Jacobs is a dentist who makes mouthpieces and nothing disturbs him more than to see somebody knock his dental work.

TORONTO, Nov. 19 (AP) -Bill Steinkraus of Westport, Conn., the captain of the United States team, tonight won the individual class in the international jumping competition at the Royal Winter Fair when he registered the only perfect round with Trail Guide.

The head of the house lately was given an electric train for his son's birthday. This, of course, was not the theory under which the train was purchased, but realistic fact not always follows theory. The origin of the project is now wrapped in obscurity, which perhaps is as well.
The city has installed brighter lights in twenty playgrounds in areas where the control of juvenile delinquency is considered most urgent, Mayor Wagner reported yesterday.
District Attorney Frank S. Hogan said yesterday that he had subpoenaed the books and financial records of eleven recording companies.

CAIRO, Nov. 19 -- Ahmad Jamal, United States Negro Jazz pianist, took Cairo in tow today without playing a note. He talked of investing his rising fortune in African real estate and of his devotion to the Moslem faith.
Tenants who cleaned up two slum buildings on the West Side to avert eviction by the Fire Department were rewarded yesterday with remission of rents and arrears.

Are we approaching the day of the window-less school in New York City? The question is raised by the disturbing news story telling how, because of the amount of glass breakage by vandalism, architects for the city school system will reduce the size and number of windows in new schools. They will also install protective wire-mesh screens, steel panels and fences, making buildings look like jails.
LONDON, Nov. 19 -- Chancellor Konrad Adenauer conceded today that an interim settlement for West Berlin could not be excluded from summit conference negotiations.

An exhibition illustrating the life and dramatic work of Friedrich von Schiller, German dramatist, poet and historian, will open today at 5 P. M. at the Brander Matthews Dramatic Museum of Columbia University. Prof. Walter Silz will deliver the opening address.

Miss Lynne Fales Lomasney, debutante daughter of Mr. and Mrs. David Arms Lomasney of Syosset, L. I., will be among the provisional members of the Junior League of New York to be honored at the league's Debutante Ball at the Plaza on Wednesday.
CHICAGO, Nov. 19 -- A Treasury spokesman assailed as "irresponsible" today economists who contend that the United States can continue to run a foreign-trade deficit without danger.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 19 -The Treasury announced today two offers to owners of savings bonds designed to keep those investors in the fold.

PEIPING, Nov. 19 -- The hostility between Communist China and the West is reflected in the faces and in the behavior of Western diplomats in Peiping. On the whole, the envoys of the West seem to be unhappy, frustrated men.
Felix Houphouet-Boigny, Premier of the Republic of the Ivory Coast, pursued yesterday his charge that Guinea might become a base of Communist subversion threatening other African states.
UNIVERSITY PARK, Pa., Nov. 19 (AP) -- Penn State football players voted unanimously at a secret meeting in favor of playing in the Liberty Bowl game at Philadelphia Dec. 19, it was learned today.
DETROIT, Nov. 19 -- Richard T. Gosser, one of four vice presidents of the United Automobile Workers, has been relieved of his principal duties and asked to take a six-month leave.
MONTICELLO, N. Y., Nov. 19 (UPI) -- A pet deer, raised on spaghetti and meatballs, dog food and bananas, was killed here this week by a trespassing hunter.

An outboard-powered boat that provides two launching ramps for water skiers has been brought out by Standard Boat, a division of the Inter-american Standard Corporation, New York. The motor is amidships.

Record sales and substantially larger earnings were achieved by Gimbel Brothers, Inc., and its subsidiaries in the three, nine and twelve months that ended on Oct. 31. The unaudited financial statement was issued for publication today by Bruce A. Gimbel, president of the big department store chain.

Events today: New York Philharmonic, conductor, Thomas S. Schippers, Tossy Spivakovsky, violinist. Carnegie Hall, 2:15 P.M.; "Il Trovatore," Metropolitan Opera, 8; Jazz for Moderns, Carnegie Hall, 8:30 and midnight; Amor Musicae, Town Hall, 8:30; David Garney, music and mime, Carnegie Recital Hail, 8:30.

Please let me suggest to the TV industry that the simplest way to prevent future scandals is to adopt the policy of the British commercial Independent Television Authority, to sell time on the air to advertisers, just as newspapers sell space, but to give advertisers no control over programing, just as newspapers do not permit advertisers to influence their policies.
IND subway riders and New York Central commuters were delayed yesterday mourning in a series of mishaps.
DETROIT, Nov. 19 -- The Ford Motor Company dropped its Edsel line of cars today. It blamed poor sales and the steel shortage.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 19 (AP) Secretary of Labor James P. Mitchell announced changes today in regulations governing the supply of migrant workers to farmers.
The memory of the architect of Brazil's independence, Jose Bonifacio de Andrada e Silva, was honored last night at a ceremony in Bryant Park.
The city's Department of Investigation is being flooded with complaints from housewives who believe they are being cheated by their food markets.
Parzinger Originals is trying to lessen the leg work in shopping for furnishings in showrooms that sell through decorators.

CALL it "payola," "kick-back," "pay-off" or "ice." The semantic nuances vary from one branch of show business to another but the practice of buying or giving commercial favors on an extra-curricular basis has been part of the entertainment world for years.
Eastman Dillon, Union Securities Co. and Smith, Barney Co., and associates offered yesterday 200,000 shares of the common stock of Atlantic City Electric Company. The stock is priced at $29 a share.

PARIS, Nov. 19 -- Partisans of the Continental European unification movement agreed tonight that current economic rivalries in Europe could be resolved fairly and effectively only with full and active United States participation.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 19 -Paul-Henri Spaak, Secretary General of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization, called today for an ambitious program among the Western allies to meet the problems of less advanced nations.
BOSTON, Nov. 19 (AP) -- Boston became the eighth and final member of the new American Football League today.

Election of William L. Butcher as chairman of the County Trust Company, White Plains, largest bank in Westchester County was announced yesterday. President since 1957, Mr. Butcher will succeed Dr. Joseph E. Hughes, who will retire on Dec. 31, at the age of 65, under the bank's retirement plan.
HARRIMAN, N. Y. Nov 19--Young suburbanites were advised today to organize medical cooperatives that would set up well-equipped local health centers.
The New York Rangers returned Parker MacDonald, a left wing, to the Springfield Indians of the American Hockey League yesterday. They brought back big Eddie Shack, also a left wing.
The serious and the sunny sides of the Austrian musical temperament formed the argument of yesterday's Carnegie Hall matinee program of the Vienna Philharmonic under Herbert von Karajan.

"Eva Wants to Sleep," the first of three programs of new Polish-made films, will be presented by Cinema 16 in a membership screening 11:15 A. M. Sunday at the Murray Hill Theatre. The performance will be repeated Wednesday evening at the Fashion Industries Auditorium and again the following Sunday at the Murray Hill.

HAVANA, Nov. 19 -- Premier Fidel Castro told Cuba today that all property of counterrevolutionists would be confiscated. He said the workers and peasants would be trained and armed to fight any "foreign intervention" or any attack on the revolution at home.
ALBANY, Nov. 19 (AP) -- Governor Rockefeller will make a four-day trip to the Middle West beginning Dec. 12.
Trustees of the New York Racing Association elected Edward T. Dickinson as their president and chief operating officer at a meeting at Aqueduct yesterday.
NEWARK, Nov. 19 -- A 23-year-old former hospital orderly, who for six weeks passed himself off as a medical student at Martland Medical Center here, surrendered today.
BAHREIN, Nov. 18 -- Awakened but also confused by the wealth of oil revenues, Saudi Arabia is undergoing a drastic economic and social change.
STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Nov. 19 -- Final negotiations toward forming a seven-nation free-trade area in Western Europe opened here today and ran into a snag.
SYDNEY, Australia, Nov. 19 (UPI) -- Neale Fraser and Roy Emerson of Australia reached the semi-finals of the New South Wales tennis championships today, along with Marty Mulligan and Rod Laver.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 19 (AP) -- The income of all Americans rose in October despite the steel strike, the Commerce Department said today.

Another and possibly decisive step toward the restoration of Western unity has been taken in what are described as highly successful talks between Prime Minister Macmillan and Chancellor Adenauer in which they reached basic agreement on the two main issues between them -- the program for the East-West summit meeting and the two European trade zones.

Elveta Hall is very responsible and obedient for a little girl only 6 years old. She takes excellent care of her four younger brothers and never disobeys her mother. But since yesterday Mrs. Anna Hall thinks her daughter's steadfastness may be a mixed blessing.
MEXICO CITY, Nov. 19 -Anastas I. Mikoyan, a First Deputy Premier of the Soviet Union, spoke for nearly an hour and a half this afternoon with President Adolfo Lopez Mateos.

WESTBURY, L. I., Nov. 19 -- The Champagne pacing feature tonight produced the fifth dead heat for first during the Roosevelt Raceway season. The horses who shared the victory were Golden Goose, driven by Vernon Dancer, and Ship Ahoy, handled by Jimmy Jordan.

JAMES A. MICHENER'S new novel, "Hawaii,"* may never make literary history, but for some time it has been making publishing history. It is a selection of both the Book-of-the-Month and Reader's Digest condensed book clubs. It has been sold to a motion-picture company for a reputed price of $600,000.
PARIS, Nov. 19 -- President Charles de Gaulle told the people of Belfort and Alsace today that France was on the road to peace in Algeria.
BERLIN, Nov. 19 (UPI) Sports leaders from East and West Germany reached agreement today on a common flag and emblem to be used by the German team in the 1960 Olympic Games.
BUFFALO, Nov. 19 (UPI) -- A $5,000,000 office building was dedicated here today, marking the first phase of a redevelopment program for downtown Buffalo.

MANHATTAN, Kan., Nov. 19 (UPI) -- Senator Hubert H. Humphrey of Minnesota told the annual convention of the Kansas Farmers Union today that the Eisenhower Administration's new program for agriculture is a "fraud."

The tribulations of two Endicott, N. Y., men who attended the mysterious 1957 meeting at the estate of the late Joseph Barbara Sr. were read into the record of the Apalachin trial in Federal Court yesterday.
The Long Island Rail Road petitioned the Public Service Commission yesterday for passenger fare increases averaging 4.6 per cent. The rise, which would cover all riders, would go into effect Dec. 10.
A police investigation of an $8.000 safe burglary has disclosed that twelve policemen were employed by the company that reported the robbery. Policemen are not permitted to hold extra jobs.
Wilson Brothers, New York, has dropped its attempt to acquire the Virginia Iron, Coal and Coke Company through an exchange of shares, it was announced yesterday.

Although injuries to five key players plagued the Manhattan College basketball squad last season, the Jaspers had a remarkably fine record. They won fifteen games on their regular schedule, while losing only five.
VIENNA Nov. 18 -- An economic report from Prague indicates that in relation to population Czechoslovakia ranks among the countries that have the highest rates of industrial expansion.

DOROTHY MAYNOR, who had only given one recital here in the last twelve years, returned to Town Hall last night for a concert of special significance. It marked the twentieth anniversary of her New York debut in the same hall, on Nov. 19, 1939.

AUGUSTA, Ga., Nov. 19 -- A Federal budget deficit for the current fiscal year and Government spending of more than $81,000,000,000 in the year beginning July 1 were indicated today by Budget Director Maurice H. Stans.
The chairman of President Eisenhower's special committee on military aid sounded a warning yesterday against attempts to stem the outflow of gold by slashing foreign aid.

COLOMBO, Ceylon, Nov. 19 -- Mrs. Vimala Wijewardene, a former Government minister, and F. R. de Zoysa, brother of Finance Minister Stanley de Zoysa, were remanded in custody until Nov. 30 today in connection with the assassination of Prime Minister S. W. R. D. Bandaranaike Sept. 25.

I quite agree with Robert Moses that New York has benefited greatly by the "bridges, tunnels, parkways, expressways and thruways built to open it up by those who had to beat and hack down opposition" (Times, Nov. 11). I am somewhat reluctant, however, to accept the implication that our city would have long since fallen apart at the seams had it not been for his own leadership and his own methods of attacking civic problems.

OXFORD, England, Nov. 19 (AP) -- Injuries to team-mates on Oxford University's Rugby Union squad today robbed Pete Dawkins of any chance to shine on offense in one of the team's last matches before the selection of the squad that will meet Cambridge Dec. 8.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Nov. 19 -- Next Wednesday will be Thanksgiving Eve in the United States. But in Hollywood it will be Christmas Eve as well.

WHEN Edward Thomas Dickinson, the new president of the New York Racing Association, was enrolled at Yale in 1928, he planned to become an architectural engineer. As he was to learn later in life, plans often never get beyond the drawing-board stage.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 19 (UPI) -- The administrator of the Federal student-loan fund said tonight that needy students would suffer if more colleges dropped out of the program because of the loyalty-oath requirement.
A new union president, who will receive one-eighth the salary of his predecessor, was elected Wednesday by members of the Motion Picture Machine Operators Union, Local 306.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 19 -- A request for a debate on Hungary in the General Assembly will be considered by its steering committee next Monday. The twenty-one-nation committee was scheduled to meet today, but a postponement was obtained by the Soviet Union.

Fun and laughter can be important "cold war" weapons too. That is why forty-seven times a year another show of the United Service Organizations leaves the Continental United States to take cheer and diversion to homesick G. I.'s stationed at isolated military bases overseas.

The Pennsylvania Railroad's shareholders are going to collect a dividend again this year, just as they have in every year since 1848, even though the carrier experienced a loss of $266,325 through October.
The Eastman Kodak Company yesterday gave its stockholders and employes reason for rejoicing in the coming holiday season.
The consumption and production of newsprint continued at record levels in October, according to reports issued yesterday.

WOMEN walk their feet off and wear their family's temper to a frazzle finding just the right fabric color or pattern for their decorating scheme. To protect their investment in time, emotion and money, they should consider factors other than color and design. Here is a check list of practical points, drawn up by Harry Paulsen, buyer and stylist for Schumacher:
The new political group known as New Yorkers for Nixon opened headquarters yesterday in a narrow ground-floor store at 555 Madison Avenue between Fifty-fifth and Fifty-sixth Streets.

IN a Yale-Harvard game just before the war, the Crimson quarterback was racked up with impolite violence right at the start. He was dazed. That much was obvious. But he rattled off signals in brisk, authoritative fashion. Ten other members of the team stared ahead, uncomprehendingly.
SINCE "Only in America" is based on Harry Golden's book of the same title, the book and the play naturally resemble each other.
BISAMARCK, N. D., Nov. 19 -- A three-time Governor of North Dakota was appointed today to the United States Senate to fill the vacancy created by the death Nov. 8 of Senator William Langer.

The drafting of a twelve nation treaty banning nuclear tests and all military activity from Antarctica has reached the point where some of the participants hope a signature will be possible next Wednesday.
WHEN teen-agers endorse a look, create a vogue or discard an old favorite for a new, the reverberations are felt across the country.

The nation's investment companies, a major factor in the stock market, hold more than $800,000,000 in railroad securities. That represents about 4.8 per cent of the mutual funds' assets, according to a report by the National Association of Investment Companies.
CHICAGO, Nov. 19 (API) -- The report of today's livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:

MIAMI BEACH, Fla., Nov. 19 -- A three-year campaign to raise $15,000,000 for the development of Reform Judaism's two main institutions in the Western Hemisphere was started here today with contributions of $3,860.000.
Eleven Federal mediation officials, all experienced in waterfront contract disputes, will confer today in a new forum designed signed to prevent surprise pier strikes.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 19 -- The broadcasting industry received a new warning today to clean house or face legislation to outlaw program "fixing" and false advertising when Congress reconvenes in January.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 19 (AP) -- A Federal grand jury indicted a New York City lawyer today on charges of violating the conflict of interests statute while serving as a member of the Government's Foreign Claims Settlement Commission.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 19 (AP) -- The Bureau of the Census estimated today that construction activity in October dropped 5 per cent below the September level, partly because of the steel strike.

The performance of "La Traviata" at the Metropolitan Opera House last night was a benefit for the Bagby Music Lovers Foundation, Inc., and was dedicated to the memory of the late Albert Morris Bagby, its founder.
A historic carpet was auctioned for $10,000 yesterday in a sale of rare and unusual rugs at the Parke-Bernet Galleries, 680 Madison Avenue.
Plans to resume publication of The Brooklyn Eagle under new ownership were announced yesterday by Robert W. Farrell, a former columnist on the newspaper.

The lead paragraph of a Nov. 14 dispatch from Madrid by your correspondent, Benjamin Welles, says: "President Eisenhower's decision to visit here as a guest of Generalissimo Franco is being widely interpreted as evidence of the correctness of the Spanish chief of state's policies over the last twenty years."
The Mayor's Committee on Slum Clearance heard a proposal yesterday for a combined theatre and housing project that would take its name from Duffy Square.
THE compact but powerful framework of Ernest Hemingway's short story, "The Killers," was the basis for a television drama over Channel 2 last night.
LEOPOLDVILLE, Belgian Congo, Nov. 19 -- Preparations for elections in the Belgian Congo next month are being made in an atmosphere of nervous tension.

MELBOURNE, Australia, Nov. 19 (UPI) -- Sammy Snead mounted a serious challenge for the Canada Cup individual golf championship today with the tournament's best round, a five-under-par 65, but Cary Middlecoff's 75 all but wrecked Yank hopes for the team crown.

Loans to business by fifteen large New York City banks rose $72,000,000 to $10,346,000,000 in the week ended on Wednesday, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday. Loans to sales and personal finance companies, factors and other business credit companies rose $22,000,000 to $1,317,000,000.

SAN JUAN, P. R., Nov. 19 -Representative William M. Tuck, presiding at a House investigation into Communist propaganda, said today that he would recommend that eleven witnesses who had appeared before the subcommittee here be charged with contempt of Congress.

"The Highest Tree" vacates the Longacre tomorrow night. The play stars Kenneth MacKennia, who resumed his Broadway acting career after an absence of twenty-two years spent in Hollywood; Diana Douglas, Howard St. John and William Prince.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Nov. 20 -- President Tito has called for a halt in the drift toward freedom of speech in Yugoslavia.

TURNWOOD, N. Y., Nov. 20 -- People have been killing buck deer pretty briskly on Ellis Newman's leased hunting land in the last few days and it is sad to report now that this did not happen today, so far as four hunters were concerned.
A racket in which drivers allegedly paid some persons of the Department of Motor Vehicles to avoid the suspension or revocation of licenses was reported yesterday to have been uncovered.

The Appellate Division yesterday unanimously ordered the release from Civil Jail of Michele A. (Mike) Miranda, one of the men who attended the 1957 meeting at Apalachin, N. Y., that was raided by the State Police.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 20 -- The Wm. Wrigley Jr. Company of Chicago received patents this week for methods of making false teeth to which chewing gum will not stick.

A spokesman for a section of the Opposition to Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru in India called yesterday for a new Indian policy for dealing with Chinese Communist border encroachments. He advocated a policy based on a firm stand, a joint defense with Pakistan and solidification of Western support.

Bishop Walter P. Kellenberg of the Roman Catholic Diocese of Rockville Centre will officiate at a groundbreaking ceremony Wednesday for the new St. Pius X Preparatory Seminary. The seminary will rise on Front Street near Meadowbrook Parkway at Uniondale, L. I.

Massachusetts is planning the sale of $21,601,000 of serial bonds on Dec. 3 to finance public improvements. The obligations will be dated Oct. 1, 1959, and will come due serially on Oct. 1 from 1960 to 1989.

WELLINGTON, New Zealand, Nov. 20 (Reuters) -- Two geologists were rescued today after a twenty-hour ordeal in the frigid depths of an Antarctic crevasse, but a third member of the expedition was found dead.
First apprehensions about possible adverse market consequences from the Treasury's proposal to reopen new subscriptions to the 4 3/4 per cent notes due in 1964 proved unfounded yesterday.
VANDENBERG AIR FORCE BASE, Calif., Nov. 20 -- The Air Force thrust Discoverer VIII into orbit today in its seventh attempt to retrieve a twenty-seven-inch nose cone.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 20 -- The General Assembly unanimously adopted today the Declaration of the Rights of the Child. This children's charter proclaims that mankind owes children "the best it has to give" and spells out what the young generation is entitled to receive in terms of education and welfare.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 20 -When juvenile delinquents and other emotionally disturbed youngsters have relapses after they have been "cured," do not blame the treatment, a prominent child psychologist counseled here today.

The head of a company with a major advertising budget told his stockholders yesterday that it paid to avoid exaggerated or questionable claims in trying to sell products. W. B. Murphy, president of the Campbell Soup Company, said at the annual meeting of shareholders in Camden, N. J.:

LOS ANGELES, Nov. 20 (UPI) -- Bob McBride today resigned as head coach of the Los Angeles Chargers of the proposed American Football League -- less than forty-eight hours after he was named to the post.
New Dorp and Tilden will play today for the first official Public Schools Athletic League football championship. The game will be televised by Channel 7 at 12:30 P. M. from Randalls Island.
If Richard Karp succeeds in fulfilling all of his intended theatrical projects, he easily could earn the sobriquet of "the offBroadway David Merrick."

WASHINGTON, Nov. 20 (AP) -- The Post Office Department received authority today to increase parcel rates by about $88,000,000 a year.
MOSCOW, Nov. 20 -- In an unusual move, the two leading Soviet newspapers reproduced today the text of Secretary of State Herter's address in New York Monday.
PRINCETON, N. J., Nov. 20 -- Dartmouth will meet Princeton in Palmer Stadium tomorrow at 1:30 P. M. The outcome will have a heavy bearing on the Ivy League football championship.

MOUNT KISCO, N. Y., Nov. 20 -- Two young mothers and a 19-year-old youth were killed early today when a car pursued by the police at ninety miles an hour crashed head-on into a station wagon carrying six women.
LONDON, Nov. 20 -- Various sections of Britain are putting in strong bids for the new 50,000,000 ($140,000,000) plant planned by the British Ford Motor Company.
TEL AVIV, Israel, Nov. 20 -- The Israelis took leave today of a Frenchman who made them regard his country as their best friend in the world.
Prices of cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange yesterday were unchanged to 16 points (80 cents a bale) up, with the far months showing the most strength.

The growth of private pension plans has been one of the most sensational economic developments of the last quarter century -- from insignificance in the early Thirties to one of the nation's most important financial institutions today. More than 16,000,000 workers, one-quarter of the nation's labor force, are now covered by plans the funds of which total more than $30 billion and are still burgeoning.

There is evidence that Khrushchev has begun to regard Mao Tse-tung's persistent belligerence as dangerous. Mao has been reported as remarking unconcernedly that China can afford to lose 300,000,000 people.

MIAMI, Nov. 20 (AP) -- Fran Curci led Miami to an 18-13 victory over Michigan State tonight, putting the Hurricanes within one victory of an Orange Bowl invitation.

The United Nations General Assembly is approaching the end of its debate on disarmament with the adoption of five resolutions. They put the Assembly on record as being in favor of total disarmament and against a resumption of nuclear weapons tests or a spread of nuclear arms but do little to enhance its prestige or authority in this life-or-death matter.

SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 20 -- Yehudi Menuhin and his sister Hephzibah returned last ni[ht: for the first time in' twelve years to the War Memorial Opera House, scene of some of their early triumphs. The violinpiano team drew heavy applause from a large audience in a recital that included the Brahms Sonata No. 3 in D minor, the Bart6k Sonata No. 1 and the Sonata in A major by: Beethoven.
YOKOHAMA, Japan, Nov. 20 (AP) -- The death toll in the explosion today of a ton of TNT at the Toyo Chemical Company has risen to three, with 386 persons injured.

Events today: New York Philharmonic Young People's Concert, conductor, Howard Shanet, Carnegie Hall, noon; "Tosca," at 2 and "Manon" at 8, Metropolitan Opera; Boston Symphony Orchestra, conductor, Charles Munch, Carnegie Hall, 2:30; National Association for American Composers and Conductors, Carnegie Recital Hall, 2:30; Gertrude Janssen, soprano, Carnegie Recital Hall, 5:30.

HARRIMAN, N. Y., Nov. 20 -- Out of six days of discussion and deep thinking on a mountaintop there emerged today a declaration that the Federal Government must give increasing attention to many problems formerly regarded as primarily of local concern.
KANSAS CITY, Nov. 20 -(UPI) -- The Kansas City Athletics dipped into the National League today to hire Fred Fitzsimmons, a former manager of the Philadelphia Phillies, as pitching coach.

TORONTO, Nov. 20 (AP) -The United States equestrian team took a commanding lead in Royal Winter Fair international jumping competition tonight by winning the Prix de Nations team challenge trophy. Canada was second and Mexico third.
Twelve men are known to have died since 1949 of a mysterious infection caught from the small monkeys used for research and for the production of poliomyelitis vaccine.
LOS ANGELES, Nov. 20 -Considerable dispute arose here today about the authenticity of alleged art masterpieces found in the home of a television repairman in Pasadena.

"Jazz for Moderns," a bill of popular jazz acts, was offered twice at Carnegie Hall last night. The performers included the Chico Hamilton Quintet, the Dave Brubeck Quartet, Maynard Ferguson's orchestra, Lambert, Hendricks and Ross, a vocal trio, and Chris Connor, a singer.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 20 -- The counsel for the United Steelworkers of America said today that the Government was neglecting to stockpile steel essential for national defense while it had the opportunity.

World production of synthetic rubber will more than double in the next ten years, while natural rubber output will remain at about its present levels, a top industry official predicted here yesterday.

SYDNEY, Australia, Saturday, Nov. 21 (AP) -- Roy Emerson entered the final of the New South Wales tennis championships today with a five-set victory over a fellow Australian Davis Cup player, Rod Laver.

The response of the Algerian rebel leaders to General de Gaulle's latest effort to end the murderous Algerian war is disappointing. Their counter-proposal has now been rejected; but the final word has not yet been spoken.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 20 -- The Navy reported today two successful firing tests, from land and at sea, in the program to develop the Polaris underwater missile.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 20 -The State Department denied today that Dr. Milton S. Eisenhower, the President's brother, had made a statement in 1958 committing the United States to recognize Panamanian sovereignty over the Panama Canal Zone.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 20 -- The level of average wholesale prices in primary markets fell 0.3 per cent to 118.9 per cent of the 1947-49 base during the week ended last Tuesday, the Bureau of Labor Statistics reported today.

The Ford Motor Company any Allstate Insurance Company, a wholly owned subsidiary of Sears, Roebuck Co., are negotiating a contract under which Allstate would share some of Ford's proposed insurance business.

OTTAWA, Nov. 20 (Canadian Press) -- Canada's export trade climbed to a record of $471,900,000 in October, almost entirely because of a 9 per cent gain in shipments to the United States, the Bureau of Statistics reported today.
Marine insurance policies have been rewritten to cope with the hazards of the missile and nuclear age, shipowners reported yesterday.

TOKYO, Nov. 20 -- Foreign trade difficulties of the world's neediest nations shared attention with a similar problem of one of the richest countries, the United States, at the fifteenth session of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade (GATT), which ended here today.
Six large, animated scenes of carnivals in Naples, Rome, Cadiz, Canton, Persia and Venice are being installed on the Broadway facade of Macy's department store.

Nimmer of the Cockfield Stable took the feature at Aqueduct with little opposition yesterday. The 3-year-old son of Sun Again led most of the way in the seven-furlong race to score by a half-length over Leo Edwards' Moon Age.

WHITE PLAINS, Nov. 20 -An increase of 3.43 per cent in the assessed valuations of real estate in Westchester in the last year was reported today by the County Tax Commission. The new total, to be used as a base for 1960 taxes, is $2,672,109,711.

A television singer turned bricklayer and a Congregational minister turned stone mason recently to provide personal missionary aid for the building of a tuberculosis ward at a church hospital in Bailundo, Angola.

MIAMI, Nov. 20 (UPI) -Judge Marshall Wiseheart refused today to return Tony Salerno, an underworld figure, to New York for questioning in an investigation of racket influence in boxing.

Two more cruise lines operating out of the Port of New York announced here yesterday that the West Indies winter itineraries had been altered to omit calls at the Port of Havana.

State Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz conferred yesterday with a group of builders and realty men about "an alarming increase" in the number of cases in which buyers have lost their investments in new homes because of builders' defaults.

New York University-Bellevue Medical Center has received a grant of $196,950 to continue the search for the type of person most likely to suffer a stroke or heart attack in early middle age.

AT the recent annual meeting of the Theatre Owners of America in Chicago there was a disagreement about the "soft" and "hard" sell in publicizing movie. Sales of school bond issues for construction are suffering a marked decline as the classroom shortage continues and public school enrollments increase. According to Arthur S. Flemming, Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare, this "unfortunate downward trend" throughout the country indicates reduced construction of classrooms in the months ahead.

PITTSBURGH, Nov. 21 -- The University of Pittsburgh has a new triple threat, which is coming to be known as the C Men Combine. The power of this group was too much for Penn State today and the resulting play by the Combine and others of the Pitt team enabled the Panthers to upset the Nittany Lions, 22 -- 7.

BLOOMINGTON, Ind., Nov. 21 (AP) -- Bernie Allen kicked a 39-yard field goal, his first in five attempts this year, today as Purdue defeated its ancient football rival, Indiana, 10 -- 7. The last-period kick helped Purdue keep the Old Oaken Bucket for the twelfth straight year.

WHEN one with a limited budget, who never owned a record, finally finds the money to buy a phonograph, he may feel, as I did, that now his major expense is over. Actually, unless he just wants to sit and look at his new equipment, his expenses are just beginning.

FOR nearly 4,000 years the hides of a surprisingly large number of people have been decorated by tattoo artists, a durable breed of craftsmen whose interest in mankind may be only skin-deep, but whose impressions usually last a lifetime. Throughout the world tattooists have made points with everybody from savages to sailors, and even people in high places have been soft touches.
The National Association for American Composers and Conductors presented the first concert of its twenty-seventh season at Carnegie Recital Hall yesterday afternoon.

There is strange irony in the fact that we come to Thanksgiving week faced by problems provoked by our own plenty. Another huge farm crop has been harvested and the result is an even bigger and more troublesome surplus. In Washington and elsewhere brains are being searched for solutions to the problem of excessive plenty.
The latest of the group debuts, a type of party that has become increasingly popular for charity fund-raising, is the Doric Debutante Cotillion. It will be held Friday in the Metropolitan Club.
PATCHOGUE, L. I., Nov. 21 -- Two joy-riding teen-agers were captured here early today when their stolen car crashed after a police chase in which more than fifty shots were fired.
Patients at the Memorial Center for Cancer and Allied Diseases will benefit from a luncheon and fashion show to be held Feb. 16 in the Grand Ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria.

HOBOKEN, N. J., Nov. 21 -- An alumnus of Stevens Institute of Technology here protested today that the Alumni College Council, governing body of the Stevens Alumni Association, had refused at a meeting this week to allow a report to be made from the floor on an unofficial poll among the alumni concerning the demolition of Castle Stevens.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 21 -- Initial plans for a $61,000,000 national cultural center on the bank of the Potomac were displayed today by Edward Durell Stone of New York, the architect.

LOS ANGELES, Nov. 21 -- The University of California at Los Angeles capitalized on a disputed 46-yard pass play in the fourth period today for the game's only touchdowns and a 10-3 victory that knocked Southern California from the ranks of the undefeated.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 21 (UPI) -- Lawyers for Roy R. Torasco, who was denied a notary public commission in Maryland because he had refused to swear belief in the existence of God, vowed today to take the case to the United States Supreme Court if necessary.

WHEN Zino Francescatti steps on stage this week to play the Beethoven Violin Concerto with the New York Philharmonic, it will be with a certain amount of trepidation. He always feels a little nervous about the Beethoven, and he considers it the hardest concerto in the repertory.

TO those who knew her in recent years Cathinka Venth was an elderly San Antonio piano teacher whose husband had been dead a long time. But Mrs. Venth was no ordinary piano teacher. She was sitting on an opera and her whole soul was bent on getting it produced.
TOLEDO, Ohio, Nov. 21 -- Harry S. Truman sketched his picture today of the kind of fighting liberal he felt the Democratic party should nominate for President in 1960.

SYDNEY, Australia, Nov. 21 (UPI) -- Jan Lehane of Australia pulled the biggest women's upset of the 1959 tennis season today. She defeated Maria Bueno, the Wimbledon and United States champion from Brazil, 6 -- 2, 4 -- 6, 7 -- 5, in the semi-finals of the New South Wales championships.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 21 -- State Department officials said today that the reasons alleged for Mr. Rosenthal's ouster did not square with those that the Polish Foreign Ministry had given Ambassador Jacob D. Beam, nor with the reasons given the department by the Polish Ambassador. Romuald Spasowski.
WARSAW, Nov. 21 (AP) -- The expulsion of A. M. Rosenthal, correspondent of The New York Times, from Poland more than a week ago was mentioned for the first time today by the Polish press.

ALBANY, Nov. 21 -- In furtherance of his undeclared Presidential campaign, Governor Rockefeller is trying to project a favorable image on the national political screen. It is turning out to be one of the most complex and contradictory images of a candidate yet undertaken.
WHITE PPLAINS, Nov. 21 -- Protests by homeowners are causing Westchester County to proceed cautiously in developing children's camps in North Salem and Lewisboro.

POLAND is a country in intellectual ferment. Just leafing through the variety of literary weeklies appearing in Warsaw, Cracow, Lodz and Poznan -- including the brilliantly edited Catholic ones -- is enough to give the perspicacious reader of Polish a sense of the universal search for new forms of expression.
QUEBEC, Nov. 21 -- A new voice speaks for Quebec, but Premier Paul Sauve himself has said that "the policies and principles will remain the same."
BONN, Germany, Nov. 21 -A thinning of United States air power in Western Europe is likely, according to responsible Allied military officials in West Germany.

WHATEVER doubts or misgivings this sideline observer may have had at the prospect of a modern-day film version of the old Gen. Lew Wallace novel, "Ben Hur," were thoroughly dissipated with the opening of the picture here last week. It comes through, to our way of thinking, as the sturdiest "Bible movie" ever made.

DOBBS FERRY, N. Y., Nov. 21 -- The forty-two-foot shell in which the four Ward brothers of Cornwall-on-Hudson became the "rowing champions of the world" eighty-eight years ago will be assigned a permanent berth in the Smithsonian Institution.

ON Nov. 24, it will be 100 years since Charles Darwin published his great work "On the Origin of Species by Means of Natural Selection." The American Museum of Natural History will mark the centenary with an exhibition of Darwiniana, some glimpses of which are shown here. The quotations with each picture are from Darwins own writings.

Thirty-nine persons were injured yesterday -- one seriously -- when a Manhattan-bound Sea Beach express hit a stopped BMT work train near the Fifty-ninth Street subway station in Bay Ridge, Brooklyn, at 4:56 A. M.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 21 -- Two Senators touring the Middle East charged today that an estimated total of 100,000 babies of refugees in Jordan were being denied rations.

LAKEWOOD, N. J. -- Jersey's famous seashore is little more than eight miles from here and last week, along the boardwalks of many a shore resort, concessionaires were completing the boarding up of their shops for the winter. Yet here in inland Lakewood, in the heart of the Jersey pine forests, a new season was just getting under way.

LET communities everywhere take heart from what has been achieved in Dallas. COLUMBIA, S. C., Nov. 21 (UPI) -- South Carolina's co-captain, John Saunders, came off the bench today to lead the Gamecocks to a last-period 12-7 victory over North Carolina State.

CECIL BLOUNT De MILLE died Jan. 21, 1959. By August 12, which would have been his seventy-eighth birthday, "The Ten Commandments" had grossed, according to Paramount, $83,600,000, more than twice as much as "Gone With The Wind."

PACKAGE rail tours with all or nearly all expenses included continue to grow in popularity. They appeal in particular to elderly or inexperienced travelers and to special parties. They go a long way toward eliminating such vexations of travel as baggage transfers and meal and hotel arrangements, thus permitting the traveler full time to enjoy the trip without worry as to details.

Practically everybody has been just as good as has been practicable most of the year, and so Santa Claus' work is heavier than ever. The stores, cooperating with the ruddy-cheeked gentleman from the North Pole, are beginning their efforts to help out earlier than ever.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 21 -- A European refugee who made a home for refugee bees has been offered a job and a home by one of Italy's delegates to the United Nations.

A 9-year-old boy was pushed into a sewer through an open manhole yesterday. Forty-five minutes later he was washed into the Harlem River and rescued by two policemen.

My compliments on Mr. Stone's article against ugliness.

Since my possessions number high on Mr. Stone's list of condemned fripperies, such as a washing machine and an automobile, I must resign myself to the crass role of materialist and leave Mr. Stone to stick pins in himself and others who want to renounce the greatest standard of living ever attained in the history of the world.
JAKARTA, Indonesia, Nov. 21 -- Communist China demonstrated to many neutralist Indonesians this week that the Bandung spirit was far from sacred to Peiping if Chinese interests were affected.

MANY home gardeners, remembering the severe plant damage of last winter, are giving greater thought to the hardiness of their ornamental evergreens. Questions now are frequently asked about the factors causing winter injury, the likelihood of damage occurring again, and the preventive measures which should be taken.

FROM its gay Christmas cover and jacket, you might be pardoned if you got slightly the wrong idea of "A Moose in the Hoose." YANKEL ADLER (Chalette): A retrospective exhibition of the work of this Polish-born artist who died in London in 1949, having established an international reputation as a semi-abstract painter.
TO THE SPORTS EDITOR: I noticed an article saying that a man named Tyng introduced the catcher's mask for baseball in 1875. I must correct this.

THE most important single step in removing a stain from fabric is to do the job promptly. A stain that can be cleaned when fresh will often be difficult (or even impossible) to remove after the material has dried or the stain has been "set" by heat.

THIS is a very good novel -- not just a good first novel (which it is), but a good any novel. What James Ballard has done is to create a really decent person, run him through the wringer of the first twenty-one years of his life and then have his experience amount to something.

After touching a new low since September 23, the stock market rebounded last week, and the recovery erased all of the earlier losses. The quick reversal in trend followed reports of a more hopeful outlook for a negotiated settlement in the steel dispute; an abundance of favorable dividend announcements, and optimistic forecasts for the economy next year.

CARACAS, Venezuela, Nov. 20 -- An open letter to President Romulo Betancourt from Gen. Jose Maria Castro Leon, former Minister of Defense, was condemned here today by leaders of the chief political parties. They called it "provocative" and "open incitement to rebellion."

MOSCOW, Nov. 21 -- Premier Khrushchev has uttered not a single word of protest against Western-enforced delays in the summit meeting for which he has been so arduously campaigning. This is not interpreted in Moscow, however, as meaning that the Soviet leader's yearning has waned.

IN 1924 Bertha Mahony Miller and Elinor Whitney Field of The Bookshop for Boys and Girls in Boston founded The Horn Book probably the first and now the only magazine devoted entirely to children's books.

CHARLEY CONERLY limped noticeably as he moved around the Yankee Stadium gridiron during practice sessions last week. He winced every time he threw a forward pass. His wrenched right ankle still was bothering him. But the fierce inner compulsion that has lashed him ever onward during his football career won't let him take the rest he needs.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 21 -Persons writing to the Department of Health, Education and Welfare on the cranberry issue have backed Secretary Arthur S. Flemming, 7 to 1.
HAVANA, Nov. 21--The Government approved a new petroleum law today to reduce the size of claims for exploration. The law will halt large-scale explorations for oil...

A "ferroelectric converter" that can produce high-voltage electricity directly from heat was announced last week by the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation at the annual meeting of the American Rocket Society in Washington. Unlike solar batteries, which supply only direct current at low voltages, the new device can supply both direct and alternating current at high voltages.

The American Assembly has received an $85,000 grant from Carnegie Corporation of New York for a study of "The Federal Government and Higher Education."

KNOXVILLE, Tenn., Nov. 21 -- Tennessee Valley Authority power operations produced revenues of $237,500,000 for the fiscal year that ended June 30. Financial statements released today reported net income of $50,800,000.

Two basic areas of school and college study -- mathematics and English -- have recently been subjected to severe but diffuse criticism. Attempts to focus this criticism and improve the curriculum have been initiated independently by two professional organizations.

THE night drive from Stratford-on-Avon to More-cambe Bay, which Sir Laurence Olivier has lately been making at regular intervals, is 150 miles, but it is also from one world to another. Soon after curtain-fall on Shakespeare's "Coriolanus" the actor has been setting off and arriving at the Lancashire seaside resort with a few hours in hand before emerging at 8:30 for location filming on John Osborne's "The Entertainer."
