Alf Pike, the new coach of the New York Rangers, had the Blues skating on high last night at Madison Square Garden. For some reason that escaped the 12,248 onlookers, however, the Rangers lost to the Detroit Red Wings, 5 -- 3.

MOSCOW, Nov. 22 -- For once there is no crowing here about another Soviet victory over the United States. So decisive was the trouncing suffered by the American amateur ice hockey team from Brockton, Mass., in all of its five games at Moscow's Luzhniki Sports Palace that even Soviet fans and sports commentators feel no special joy.
This is one of those weeks when assorted bits of information make a lot more sense than does a single commentary on the industry.
BAY SHORE, L. I., Nov. 22 -- Work is being rushed to convert a private estate's former athletic house to an edifice for St. Peter's by the Sea Episcopal Church in time for Christmas services.

An analytical study of China's change from a patriarchal government and feudal agrarian economy to a world power is given by Helmut G. Callis in "China: Confucian and Communist." To be published by Holt Dec. 14, the book looks at China's "turbulent" past, her present power and her role in tomorrow's world.

BEGINNER in bridge usually finds it difficult recognize the many cases in which a player can gain by needlessly giving up a trick. The point is, of course, that by this apparent sacrifice of one trick he gets back two tricks.
Kum Hee Mah, an attractive soprano from Korea, made her local debut Saturday night at Carnegie Recital Hall in a program sponsored by the Korea Society.
DHAHRAN, Saudi Arabia, Nov. 16 -- An American traveler in the Middle East finds Dhahran much like home.
BABYLON, L.I, Nov. 22 -- A low bid of $7,155,655 has been submitted for extending the six-lane Long Island Expressway eastward from Nassau County into Suffolk County.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 22 (AP) -- Senate investigators will look next month into complaints that big corporations are gaining a competitive advantage over small concerns by getting patent rights on vital devices and processes developed at Government expense.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 22 (UPI) -- Senator Henry M. Jackson, Democrat of Washington, denounced President Eisenhower's defense budget policies today as nonsensical. He called for an increase in military spending of $4,000,000,000 to $5,000,000,000.

"THE LONGEST DAY: June 6, 1944," by Cornelius Ryan, is by no means the first stirring account of the first day of the Allied invasion of Normandy, but I would be much surprised if it were not the best written. Mr. Ryan has assembled a host of dramatically interesting facts and hundreds of startlingly vivid personal stories.
A new report by a Rockefeller Brothers Fund panel on long-range objectives of United States foreign policy will be issued early next month.

CHICAGO, Nov. 22 (UPI) -- Henri Richard scored twice tonight to pace the Montreal Canadiens to a 3-1 victory over the Chicago Black Hawks. The triumph stretched the Canadiens' unbeaten string in the National Hockey League to fifteen games.

D. Woodson Ramsey Jr., a marketing executive, has been invited to join the top management of the Humble Oil and Refining Company. The company is scheduled to take over all domestic operations of the Standard Oil Company (New Jersey).
The United States' rate of economic growth has slowed to the point where it trails that of most major nations, a group of economists reported yesterday.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Nov. 22 -- Labor strife that could cripple the motion-picture industry became a possibility over the week-end.
LONDON, Nov. 22 -- A British physician has traced the downfall of Napoleon not to Waterloo but to the Emperor's unruly pituitary gland.
Supersonic airliners will probably appear before 1970 and most likely in 1967, according to a prediction by Robert F. Six president of Continental Airlines.
Factory automation has arrived for the small manufacturer.
A Soviet magazine has published the first recent clues as to the identities of the men primarily responsible for the Russian space triumphs in the last two years.

Robert W. Sarnoff, chairman of the board of the National Broadcasting Company, accused Time, Inc., yesterday of attacking quiz shows in Time magazine while carrying the same programs on its own television stations.

Governor Rockefeller declared yesterday that it would be "poor sportsmanship" for him to suggest that a rival for the Presidential nomination could not win. Furthermore he said, it would be distasteful to the American people.
Dr. Mordecal M. Kaplan proposed last night that the Jewish Reconstructionist Foundation affiliate with the World Zionist Organization.
Two films are scheduled to arrive in first-run theatres this week. The programs follow:

PITTSBURGH, Nov. 22 -- The last pick-up in production at steel open hearths, blast furnaces and at many finishing mills has raised hopes that steel users will either call off shutdown plans or start up sooner than expected. Steel output last week approached 80 per cent of capacity.
VIENNA, Nov. 22 -- Col. Pawel Monat, one of Communist Poland's top intelligence agents, has fled Poland and is reported to have turned himself over to United States representatives in Vienna.
The curtain was lowered on Southern California's hopes of challenging Syracuse for national dominion as the season ended Saturday for all but a few college football teams.

TEL AVIV, Israel, Nov. 16 -- I A five-year plan for the development and modernization of Israel's transport services provides for the construction of a new Mediterranean harbor, a shipyard, a runway for international jet airliners, a chain of domestic airports and the extension of the national railway network into the barren Negev.
HAVANA, Nov. 22, -- The Cuban Confederation of Workers withdrew today from the anti-Communist Inter-American Regional Organization of Labor.
CHICAGO, Nov. 22 -- Lord Goddard, former Lord Chief Justice of England, came in today with a verdict on judges.

CARLE PLACE L.I., Nov. 22 -- In a public referendum yesterday voters approved the expenditure of $275,000 to add nine classrooms to the Rushmore Avenue School and to tear down the Roslyn Avenue School. Both are elementary schools.
COLOMBO, Ceylon, Nov. 22 -- Prime Minister Wijayananda Dahanayake conceded today that his dissension-ridden Government might be forced out soon.
Brooklyn patrolman, suspended from the force on Saturday, was held in $5,000 bail yesterday on charges of kidnapping, extortion and illegal possession of a firearm.

Mayor Wagner's ten-point legislative program is aimed beyond mere delinquency to get at "the youthful criminal, the really dangerous young person," according to Alexander Aldrich. Deputy Police Commissioner in Charge of the Youth Program.
Mayor Wagner has been told that it is feasible "from a technical and engineering stand-point" to fluoridate the city's water supply, but that the cost would be high.
NEWARK, Nov. 22 -- A city wide examination of housing quality in Newark has determined that more than half of all residential blocks are in need of some degree of renewal.
The story of Dr. Albert Schweitzer and his medical achievements in Africa is being repeated in the jungles of Peru by a determined physician from Europe.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 22 -- John A. McCone, chairman of the Atomic Energy Commission, said today that he believed the United States' voluntary suspension of tests of nuclear weapons should be extended on a week-to-week basis in the absence of a firm test-ban agreement with the Soviet Union.
The Luckenbach Steamship Company has asked the International Longshoremen's Association to exempt the ship line from strike action to "save" intercoastal shipping from disaster.
Hospital workers contended yesterday that nonprofessionals were doing the work of nurses in the city's hospitals.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 22 -- The General Accounting Office has declared that there are "basic shortcomings" in the United States aid program for India, including the "ineffective use of certain aid goods."

THERE is one perfume sold in New York that ought to make women treat men more kindly. The reason is that only men can buy it for them. The perfumes, available at F.R. Tripler and Rogers Peet stores in New York, are by Chaqueneau. There are three scents -- Nos. I, III and IV -- that any woman can wear but never purchase herself.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, Monday, Nov. 23 -- The Communist party stood alone today as Indonesia's only major political party that has failed to give full support to Jakarta in its dispute with Communist China over treatment of alien Chinese in Indonesia.
Contemplation of the Last Judgment was presented yesterday by Msgr. Thomas A. Donnellan as "a help in deterring us from what is wrong and spurring us to what is right."

The program that Gina Bachauer played Saturday evening in Hunter College had virtually every aspect of the piano in it. There were polyphonic writing, the classic style, ultra-virtuosity, childlike simplicity. And all of these Miss Bachauer, in her only New York recital of the season, handled with her usual finesse.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 22 -- Soviet scientists may be the first in things that matter in futuristic machinery, but recently they have been walking advertisements for the superiority of American futuristic trinketry.
That the plight of wage workers on American farms -- especially the seasonal migrants -- has become an urgent national issue is attested by several current developments.

Of the nearly 3,000,000 men and women now in the armed forces more than 1,250,000 are serving overseas. The United Service Organizations is assigned the task of for ming a bridge of understanding between these foreign-based G. I.'s and the civilians in the communities where they are stationed. This understanding may well be of the greatest importance in developing a united free world because impressions resulting from firsthand contacts are basic.
LONDON, Nov. 22 -- The prevailing mood on the stock exchange last week was one of caution.

TRENTON, Nov. 22 -- Republican leaders in New Jersey said today they were overwhelmingly in favor of Vice President Richard M. Nixon as the party's candidate for President. They plan to have the thirty-eight-member delegation from this state go to next year's convention uncommitted, as it traditionally has, but solidly for Mr. Nixon.
SYDNEY, Australia, Nov. 22 (UPI) -- Neale Fraser won the men's singles crown in the New South Wales tennis championships today by defeating Roy Emerson, a fellow Australian, 11 -- 9, 8 -- 6, 6 -- 3.
Dan Henning led St. Francis Prep to a 14-6 victory over Archbishop Stepinac for the Catholic High Schools Football League championship at Boys High Field, Brooklyn, yesterday.

NEW MILFORD, Conn., Nov. 22 -- The state police said today that they were seeking a second suspect in the kidnapping and murder of Francis J. Gavell of Litchfield, a supermarket manager whose body was found yesterday in the Housatonic River.
DETROIT, Nov. 22 (AP) -- The Detroit Pistons tonight vaulted into first place in the Western Division of the National Basketball Association as they whipped the New York Knickerbockers, 115 -- 104.

A Lost ART Walking, an art that becomes more and more lost as the efficiency of our machines increases, has its best chance during these in between seasons. Only in the few rare weeks that separate summer heat and winter cold, the weeks of the fall and spring, when nature is at her best and makes our surroundings such a delight, do many of us emerge at all from our machines.

Communist China is likely to concentrate its trouble-making potential on South and Southeast Asia during future months while remaining quiescent in the Formosan Strait. For, as already explained in this space, Mao Tse-tung's forces have a qualitative weapons inferiority to those of Chiang Kai-shek and Russia is not making up the difference.

AUGUSTA, Ga., Nov. 22 -- President Eisenhower will return to Washington tomorrow afternoon for further discussions on next year's budget before leaving for his Gettysburg farm, where he will observe Thanksgiving.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 22 (AP) -- Senator Clifford P. Case of New Jersey called today for the elimination of overlapping and apparently conflicting jurisdiction of Government agencies dealing with chemical food additives and insecticides.

There were two schools of thought yesterday on the City College campus about the Lavender's basketball prospects. Nat Holman, starting his thirty-seventh season as head coach, said the future was not bright. Raymond the Pretzel Man was more optimistic.
COLOMBO, Ceylon, Nov. 23 -- Government and Opposition leaders, editors, business men and diplomats here agree that Ceylon badly needs strong leadership.
Stockholders of Loew's, Inc., will be treated to good news today in the form of a sharp comeback in earnings and the discovery of a new oil field on the motion picture company's studio property.
CHICAGO, Nov. 23 (UPI) -- Roger Touhy, once one of the most feared gangsters in Chicago, will leave Joliet prison tomorrow after twenty-five years behind bars.

SO strong is the trend to indoor planting areas and artificial flower arrangements that the lone philodendron perched on the mantelpiece is not enough in today's decorating scheme. The following tips from four experts may help the indoor gardener.
Visiting Prof. Robert A. Leflar travels 1,400 miles each week to New York University's School of Law.

PANAMA, Nov. 23 -- President Ernesto de la Guardia Jr. and Livingston T. Merchant, Deputy Under Secretary of State, conferred today in an attempt to ease the tension between Panama and the United States.

At a moment when the West is closing ranks for a summit meeting with Soviet Russia free Europe has divided itself into two blocs which could do much to advance European unity and prosperity, through cooperation, but could also, through rivalry, plunge Europe into a suicidal trade war.
BERLIN, Nov. 23 -- "They should have shot you up to the moon with the Soviet rocket," a weary East German farmer told a Communist party worker.
MOUNT KISCO, N. Y., Nov. 23 -- A northern Westchester teacher who revolted against filing detailed plans for classroom studies was discharged today.
ALTHOUGH trains are somewhat outmoded in this day and age, they were responsible for the early popularity of celery in America.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 23 -- The United States announced today that it would join in sponsoring a resolution restating United Nations principles with regard to Korea.
Opponents of fluoridation reorganized yesterday for a renewed fight against Mayor Wagner's proposal to treat the city's water supply.
VIENNA, Nov. 23 -- The Central Committee of the Hungarian Socialist Workers (Communist) party has confirmed the expulsion of eleven party members for advocating revisionist ideas.

Marco Wachter's line-drive goal with twenty-seven seconds remaining lifted City College to a 1 -- 0 victory over Williams yesterday in the opening round of the first National Collegiate soccer tournament.

Even an experienced politician might be helped by a course in dramatic acting, one of them conceded yesterday. This tribute to the theatrical arts was written by James F. Byrnes, former Governor of South Carolina, who was twice elected to the Senate and who served seven terms in the House of Representatives and is a former Secretary of State and former justice of the United States Supreme Court.
CHICAGO, Nov. 23 -- Secretary of Labor James P. Mitchell said today that the Cuban labor movement had failed to recognize the strength of the nonCommunist forces in international labor.

NEWARK, Nov. 23 -- An officer of the Jersey Central Railroad told the Public Utilities Commission at a hearing today that a locomotive that made a solo run of twenty-two miles from the Jersey City yards Nov. 12 had been sabotaged.

IN the year 2000, only forty years hence, it is predicted that the typical American family will earn $10,000 annually and will spend up to $25,000 for a house. This prophecy was made recently in Washington by Julian H. Zimmerman, head of the Federal Housing Administration.
A big talent from across the ocean graced Town Hall last night with a wealth of elegant and beautiful violin playing.

BIRMINGHAM, Ala., Nov. 23 (AP) -- The United States District Court today upheld the Birmingham Transit Company's right to require segregated seating on city buses, but warned that police enforcement amounted to a violation of civil rights.
The Transit Authority told Michael J. Quill yesterday that it would have no money next year for the wage improvements he had demanded.

What Is Warm Enough? The season of thermostatic confusion is here again. Cooler weather is at hand, and instead of solar heating there is central heating. Memory points out that the solar system overworked itself quite a bit last summer, but that is all in the past.

Business men are not quite so optimistic about the first three months of next year as they were a few months ago when they looked ahead to the fourth quarter of 1959. Dun Bradstreet, Inc., reports as the result of a survey that "this decline in optimism was most likely due to uncertainties regarding the steel dispute and its effects on business acivity in the early months of 1960."
Stocks edged up yesterday in fairly active trading. Electronic-missile issues stood out, along with a spate of specialties.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 23 (UPI) -- The Defense Department made an exception to its economy drive today and authorized the Air Force to increase production of Mace missiles by about $100,000,000.
The International Longshoremen's Association yesterday rejected the Luckenbach Steamship Company's plea for a no-strike pledge.

SEATTLE, Nov. 23 -- Western Washington's worst floods in twenty-six years crested tonight after having turned lowlands into inland seas and crippled land travel across the Cascade Mountains. New trouble was dispelled as a ridge shunted aside another rainstorm moving in from the Pacific.

STAMFORD, Conn., Nov. 23 -- The Autumn Ball, a dance sponsored by the local alumnae associations of three women's colleges, will take place on Saturday evening at the Stamford Yacht Club. Proceeds from the entertainment will be divided equally for donations to the building funds of the institutions.

SIDNEY FOSTER, who was the first winner of the Edgar M. Leventritt award and one of the bright young whirlwinds of the early Forties, returned to Carnegie Hall last night. Because illness forced the pianist to cancel his concert in 1955, this was his first New York recital in almost ten years and his first appearance here since he played with the New York Philharmonic in the spring of 1951.

A Japanese opera, conducted by its composer and sung in Japanese by a cast of American students headed by a leading Japanese soprano, will be heard in its American premiere on Jan. 27 at Hunter College.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 23 (AP) -- Currently licensed private airplane pilots will not be required to learn instrument flying but those licensed after next March 16 must master fundamentals of such flying.
TRENTON, Nov. 23 -- The State Supreme Court ruled here today that a tavern owner who serves or permits an employe of his to serve a "visibly" intoxicated person or a minor may be sued.

Net profits of the Canadian Bank of Commerce, Toronto, increased $906,033, to $11,118,380, or a gain of 8.9 per cent, in the year ended on Oct. 31, the bank reported yesterday. After providing for $12,050,000 in income taxes and payment of dividends of $9,163,828, the balance of undivided profits amounted to $3,121,636, up $1,954,552 from the year before.
CHICAGO, Nov. 23 (AP) -- Sporadic buying stiffened grain futures prices at times today but the market closed with more weakness than strength.

ROCKY MARCIANO was in town last week, bursting with health, vitality and peace. The retired, undefeated heavyweight champion of the world has trimmed his poundage from 232 to a more workmanlike 210. But it doesn't mean a thing.

IMPORTANT papers have a diabolic tendency to get lost. Anyone who has ever searched for a canceled check or a birth certificate knows that. For this is one of the prime hazards of our infinitely ordered yet intricately disheveled civilization.
CHICAGO, Nov. 23 (AP) -- The report of today's livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:
The Frank G. Shattuck Company is expanding its activities through entry of the Schrafft's chain into the franchise operation of restaurants on a national scale.

The Jan. 21 performance of "Silent Night, Lonely Night" will benefit the Hackley School. Robert Anderson's play starring Henry Fonda and Barbara Bel Geddes is scheduled to open at the Morosco Theatre on Dec. 3.

Picking up where it left off on Saturday's program, the Cain Hoy Stable of Capt. Harry Guggenheim won the feature race at Aqueduct yesterday. The event was a $6,000 purse called the Rosetown, and was for fillies and mares at six furlongs.

LONDON, Nov. 23 -- Derick Heathcoat Amory, Chancellor of the Exchequer, said today that formation of the European Free Trade Association opened the way for increased sales of British exports to the other member countries.

Legalizing off-track betting would provide new opportunities for illegal bookmakers and increase rather than reduce "police corruption," according to a report to Mayor Wagner that became available yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 23 -- President Eisenhower has selected Edward Page Jr., a career Foreign Service officer, as United States Minister to Bulgaria.
BOSTON, Nov. 23 -- Boston is going to challenge New York for some of the Canadian shipping business that is expected to pile up when the St. Lawrence Seaway becomes ice-bound this winter.

The program sung by John Langstaff, baritone, at Carnegie Recital Hall last night had as an interesting feature the first New York performance of "Billy in the Darbies" by Robert Evett, a work for baritone, clarinet, string quartet and piano.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 23 -- President Eisenhower returned to the Capital tonight to begin preparations for the "series of summit meetings" that will undoubtedly dominate his final year in office.

The Rand and Foshay Towers, two of Minneapolis' largest office buildings, have been sold by Robert K. Lifton, Ira Hechler and Howard Weingrow, New York realty investors, to the Apache Realty Corporation and the Apache Oil Corporation of Minneapolis.

RECOGNIZING that some women panic at the prospect of Christmas shopping, many of the stores have started making it painless -- and even fun. They have instituted little shops within the stores in which Yuletide merchandise is gathered.
DETROIT, Nov. 23 (AP) -- Domestic automobile manufacturers apparently will build near their original estimate of 5,500,000 cars this year despite the crippling effects of the steel strike.

"THE PLAY OF THE WEEK" continues on its triumphant course. The production of "The White Steed," by Paul Vincent Carroll, which opened a week's run last night on Channel 13, is further confirmation that station WNTA-TV belongs in the company of the producing elite on television or off.

DANVERS, Mass., Nov. 23 -- For forty-eight hours, Alton T. White, a 60-year-old paint salesman, went through the near South on a selling trip unaware that five members of his family had died early Saturday morning in a flash fire at Bay Shore, L. I.

Sales of E. J. Korvette, Inc., in the discount chain's first fiscal quarter, which ended on Nov. 2, topped volume a year earlier. This was reported to stockholders yesterday at the annual meeting by Joseph H. Lamm, executive vice president and controller.

Directors of the American Express Company yesterday proposed a two-for-one split of the common stock and also raised the quarterly dividend by 10 cents a share. The dividend of 60 cents a share voted yesterday on the present shares is payable on Jan. 2 to holders of record of Dec. 4.

A meat salesman said yesterday that the late Joseph Barbara Sr. had ordered $432 worth of expensive cuts a week before the gathering at his Apalachin estate was raided by state police on Nov. 14, 1957.
The Pierpont Morgan Library, bequeathed to the nation by two financiers, the elder and the younger J. Pierpont Morgan, opened a national drive last night to raise $3,000,000.
A light, cheap, efficient internal combustion engine with only two moving parts was announced yesterday.

Two of the many subjects being studied by a number of agencies here are the growing potential represented by regional accounts, and the problems involved in the handling of franchise or dealer advertising.
Artists eating taffy apples and sucking lollypops for inspiration painted Greenwich Village red and blue and green and yellow yesterday afternoon.

NEW DELHI, India, Nov. 23 -- Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru was reported to have told members of the ruling Congress party today that he would welcome frank criticism of his foreign and defense policies, with particular reference to Chinese Communist incursions on the northern border.
Dillon, Read Co., Inc., and Johnston, Lemon Co., Washington, D. C., are offering to the public today $15,000,000 first mortgage bonds of Potomac Electric Power Company due in 1994.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 23 -- The British wool textile industry pointed to Japan and Uruguay today as unnoticed sources of some of the united state import problems.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Nov. 23 -- Anthony Quinn, winner of Oscars for his performances in "Viva Zapata" and "Lust for Life," will be leaving for Europe soon to make a film "because I have status there."
CARACAS, Venezuela, Nov. 23 (AP) -- The armed forces, concerned over a misfired leaflet raid from the north last week, have taken precautions against a possible attack from the Dominican Republic.

The Controller General of the United States, financial watchdog for the Congress, has sharp things to say about the way the American aid program to India is being carried out. Reports of the Controller General are taken with seriousness on any subject, because of the objectivity and independence that clothe the General Accounting Office, of which he is the head.

A three-alarm fire on the top floors of two old apartment houses at 153 and 155 West Sixty-sixth Street injured two firemen yesterday. Two elderly women in adjoining top-floor apartments were rescued from No. 153.

HAVANA, Nov. 23 -- Cuba's organized labor movement rejected today a Communist bid for representation in its executive committee and elected a pro-Castro slate. It is headed by David Salvador as secretary general.

THERE is no hiding place for a composer of chamber music. When he confides his thoughts and emotions to a handful of instruments, he had better be sure that they are meaningful thoughts and affecting emotions. If they are not, the handful of instruments will betray him.

LOS ANGELES, Nov. 23 (UPI) -- The next President of the United States will be nominated on the fifth ballot of the Democratic party at its convention here next July, the Democratic National Chairman predicted today.
NEW HAVEN, Nov. 23 -- Yale University announced today that an increase in the salaries of professors and associate professors had been voted by the Yale University Corporation.
ROME, Nov. 23 (UPI) -- The United States has ordered the commanders of all American units at the NATO base in Izmir relieved of their jobs, it was learned here.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 23 -- The State Department confirmed today, that one of Poland's leading intelligence agents had sought political asylum in the United States.

A reporter for The World-Telegram and The Sun told the District Attorney yesterday that he had lied when he charged that a city official had offered him a bribe to stop investigating the Title I slum-clearance program.
THE first invitations have gone out for the second annual invitational pair tournament of the Cavendish Club of New York, to be played next February.
Closer cultural and spiritual ties between Israel and Jews the world over were called for last night by national and world Zionist leaders.
A quiet and stable bond market is awaiting the Treasury's $2,000,000,000 cash borrowing today.
HONG KONG, Nov. 23 -- Communist China charged the United States today with paying lip service to peace while pursuing policies of aggression.

EVERYTHING is working out just right in the Putnam County (Game) Cooperative Area, which the Conservation Department is watching as a pilot project. If that is the case when the facts are all in, the department presumably will establish other cooperative areas throughout the State.
ALBANY, Nov. 23 (AP) -- Hunters appeared to have had good luck on the opening day of New York State's special ten-day season on anterless deer in the Adirondacks.
Five men and four youths were accused of beating and stabbing an off-duty patrolman early yesterday in the Bronx after he had stopped their car for an alleged traffic violation.

Virginia Electric and Power Company reported yesterday it had added 23,000 electric and 3,400 gas customers in the twelve months ended on Oct. 31. This raised the number of customers served to 740,000 and 96,000, respectively. A. H. McDowell Jr., president, commented that "company growth and operating economies have helped to offset the rising operating costs due to inflation."

Emile Griffith, New York middleweight, scored his twelfth victory in thirteen bouts, stopping Ray Lancaster of Spartanburg, S. C., in the seventh round of the scheduled eight-round feature last night at the Academy of Music. Griffith weighed 147 1/2 pounds and Lancaster 147.
A spokesman for the Guatemalan Consulate denied last week that his Government had begun a "flag discrimination" campaign to support the development of a national merchant marine.

Station WNEW-TV formally notified Alan Freed yesterday that the contract covering his disk jockey program would be "terminated by mutual consent" on Dec. 6. The notice added that his services would not be required by the station after Sunday.
TORONTO, Nov. 23 (Canadian Press) -- Members of a United States-Canadian commission to make a five-year study of alcoholism were announced today.
ALBANY, Nov. 23 -- Governor Rockefeller will ask the 1960 Legislature to pass a stringent new set of restrictions against careless and unqualified drivers.

VIENNA, Nov. 23 -- Communist China has refused to permit Premier Khrushchev to negotiate Far Eastern controversies at the proposed summit conference, according to Polish Communists recently returned from Peiping.

MINNEAPOLIS, Nov. 23 (AP) -- The owners of the Minneapolis-St. Paul entry in the new American Football League said tonight they had no intention of shifting to the National League and planned to operate and A. F. L. team here next year.

UNIVERSITY PARK, Pa., Nov. 23 (UPI) -- Penn State, which lost only to top-ranked Syracuse and arch-rival Pitt, today accepted a bid as host team in the first Liberty Bowl game in Philadelphia, Dec. 19. The game will be played in Municipal Stadium, with a seating capacity of 102,000.
BUENOS AIRES, Nov. 23 -- Argentina received assurance today of the foreign financing necessary to carry on her monetary stabilization program through 1960.
In confirming that "My Fair Lady" will be seen in the Soviet Union, Alan Jay Lerner, who wrote the international musical hit with Frederick Loewe, said yesterday that plans were being formulated.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 23 -- If those who regularly read the transcripts of news conferences, and watch the video questioning of public characters by reporters, decided yesterday that their screens had shown them an unusually candid and able public servant in the person of John A. McCone, they were right.

WESTBURY, L. I., Nov. 23 -- With a drive in the final sixteenth, Frisco Rebel scored a head victory over Knight Pilot in 2:06 2/5 in the mile pacing feature at Roosevelt Raceway tonight. A crowd of 16,655 was on hand.

NICE. France. Nov. 23 -- To a fight manager a gimmick can be worth more money than a strong right. When Philippe Filippi brought Marcel Cerdan Jr., aged 15, to Paris in June, he knew he had a gimmick. Now Filippi has begun to exploit it.

Senator Kenneth B. Keating suggested last night that the contest between Vice President Richard M. Nixon and Governor Rockefeller for the nomination for President might be resolved before the Republican convention met next July.

CHICAGO, Nov. 23 -- Spokesmen for Archbishop Albert G. Meyer said today that the Cardinal-designate would soon establish in Chicago a national office to protect and promote the welfare of Roman Catholic migratory workers.
Net income of North American Aviation, Inc., in the fiscal year ended on Sept. 30 rose $3,939,840 above the 1958 level on a sales gain of $140,860,732.

The high costs of research and development have caught up with manufacturers of electric power transformers.
Trans World Airlines started passenger jet service across the Atlantic yesterday.
Bond Stores, Inc., clothing chain, announced yesterday several top-level management changes following a meeting of the directors.
WEST JEFFERSON, N. C., Nov. 23 (UPI) -- Five convicts overpowered a guard, seized rifles and pistols and killed a prison foreman here today in a break to freedom.

Dental decay is man's most widespread chronic disease. It is also one of the costliest. About 97,000,000 Americans have decayed teeth in need of treatment. Our family dental bills total $1,700,000,000 a year, but only 40 per cent of us have dental care.
Our country's armed forces have requested that the U. S. O. expand and extend its morale-building services to our military personnel.

"I won't come back." That's what Gump Worsley told Muzz Patrick, the general manager of the New York Rangers, yesterday when he was informed that the National Hockey League club had called up Marcel Paille to replace Gump as goalie.

Steamship conferences were said yesterday to be increasing a drive to eliminate malpractices, particularly in Europe.
An adoption agency here has flouted tradition and publicized the plight of six children in need of homes.
Belling the cat in an ancient mouse civilization presented no more formidable a problem than curbing the dog today.

Many highly placed executives, well versed in the customs and methods of modern business dealings, appear to be uninformed about the role of the real estate broker in finding new office space for large companies, a leading realty agent has found.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 23 (AP) -- The Army said today it was studying, and putting into effect, proposals to merge active, Reserve and National Guard units into a unified force.
TRENTON, Nov. 23 -- The State Senate today approved and sent to Gov. Robert B. Meyner a bill that would authorize $66,800,000 in bonds for eight state schools of higher education.
LEOPOLDVILLE, Belgian Congo, Nov. 23, (Reuters) -- The two leading African parties in the Belgian Congo announced today they would boycott communal elections next month.
The New York State Athletic Commission knocked out Constantine (Cus) D'Amato yesterday. It also scored a technical knockout over William P. Rosensohn.

The case of Magistrate Anthony E. Maglio, who was suspended in Brooklyn ten days ago on charges of "conduct unbecoming a member of the judiciary," was turned over yesterday to a referee for a hearing.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 23 -- The United States has decided to make a special additional contribution of $3,000,000 toward the $19,000,000 cost of maintaining the United Nations Emergency Force in Egypt next year.
Earnings of Litton Industries, Inc., electronics equipment manufacturers, in the first fiscal quarter ended on Oct. 31 rose 35 per cent above the 1958 level on a sales gain of 34 per cent.
TUPELO, Miss., Nov. 23 (UPI) -- Three Negro teen-agers, accused in the stabbing of three white men, were indicted today on charges of armed robbery and assault and battery with intent to kill.

PARIS, Nov. 23 -- Gen. Jean-Etienne Valluy, commander of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization's forces in Central Europe, complained today that some member states were not meeting their promised military contributions.
PASADENA, Calif., Nov. 23 -- The owners of ten reputed and disputed Renaissance paintings said today they intended to exhibit them soon for expert appraisal.

NAPLES, Nov. 23 (UPI) -- A priest-archaeologist asserted today that one of the ten paintings discovered in the home of an Italian emigrant in California was merely a copy of a painting in a Naples gallery.
THERE are three ways in which "Fiorello!" is the ideal monument to our beloved Little Flower: it is exciting; it is enjoyable and it is decent.

Burlington Industries, Inc., the nation's largest textile manufacturing and distributing organization, announced yesterday the acquisition of Princeton Knitting Mills, Inc., an integrated producer of knitted fabrics and rugs of natural and man-made fibers.
MADRID, Nov. 23 -- The Gulf Oil Company has received the first foreign concession to explore for oil in Spanish Africa under Spain's new oil law.

HACKENSACK, N. J., Nov. 23 -- Prosecutor Guy W. Calissi of Bergen County was notified today by the attorney for Two Guys From Harrison that he would seek to have the prosecutor held in contempt of court for yesterday's enforcement of the Sunday-closing law.
POUGHKEEPSIE, N. Y., Nov. 23 -- John Jacob Astor 3d accepted $250,000 today to settle out of court his suit to break the will of Vincent Astor, his half-brother.
Only one "nyet" was heard from the Russian men's and women's basketball players who arrived here yesterday for a six-game tour of this country.

The traditional Army-Navy game at Philadelphia on Saturday may break with the past in at least one respect. Army's coach, Dale Hall, believes it could be one in which the forward pass will be used more extensively than ever.

A youthful driver parades his new car in a former girl friend's neighborhood. The neighbors, disturbed by the noise, call the police. A police car arrives, spots the noisemaker and gives chase. The youth flees at full speed. Another police car joins the chase of the culprit long enough to cause the youth to crash into a party of young mothers coming from church.
BISMARCK, N. D., Nov. 23 (AP) -- Four persons convicted in the Universal Securities stock sales fraud received Federal prison terms today.
One of the New York Giants' key defense players, Roosevelt Grier, may be out of the Washington Redskins game at the Yankee Stadium on Sunday.
New York University will dedicate its Loeb Student Center at Washington Square today. The ceremony will begin at 4 P.M. at the center, West Broadway and Washington Square South.

The extraordinary intensity of Cuban emotions these days was exemplified in the Confederation of Cuban Workers' congress and elections which ended yesterday. In the generally confused and stormy picture one good feature emerged in the defeat of the Communist effort to get a few members on the executive committee. What Communists there are in the Cuban labor movement are leftovers from the Batista regime, but they are, as always, a well-trained and potentially dangerous element.
The New York Produce Exchange moved back to 2 Broadway yesterday, the site it occupied from 1884 to 1956.
Ron Bliey sat erect in the large wooden chair, his muscular hands folded on his lap and a serene, almost detached expression on his face.
ALBANY, Nov. 23 (AP) -- Willie Reid lost his fight today to stay in New York and out of a Florida jail. Governor Rockefeller is sending him back.

General selling and liquidation induced stop-loss selling of rubber futures yesterday on the Commodity Exchange of New York. Prices tumbled 70 to 300 points (hundredths of a cent a pound) on 1,360 tons. Scale-down short covering absorbed the offers.

BONN, Germany. Nov. 23 -- The Government used a Foreign Ministry newsletter today to make the point that the abandonment of "present Western rights" in Berlin would mean the surrender of all Berlin to the Communists.
LONDON, Nov. 23 -- Leading industrial shares responded here today to some optimistic company reports and the opening of new bookkeeping account with rises of about 1 shilling (14 cents).

PATERSON, N. J., Nov. 23 -- Five hundred members Teamsters Local 560 have voted to oppose the local's officers and the union president, James Hoffa, in an election to be held between Jan. 10 and Jan. 20.

The six-story apartment house at 3750 Broadway, at the corner of 157th Street, has been sold after a brief ownership by the Estate Securities Company, of which Alvin A. Levy and Irving Magot are executive officers. The property was purchased by Harmony Syndicate, Inc., for cash over an institutional first mortgage of $96,000 and a long-term second mortgage.
After two weeks of convalescence, Army and Navy will tear into each other Saturday in the battle of the walking wounded.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 23 -- The Justice Department charged a group of steel producers and fabricators today with conspiring to eliminate competition in the sale of steel bars in seven Western states.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 23 (AP) -- The Supreme Court denied today a hearing to Randolph Phillips in litigation developing from his unsuccessful effort to win a place on the board of the Pennsylvania railroad's long history.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 23 (AP) -- Seizure actions against three lots of cranberries found to contain aminotriazole were instiuted today, the Food and Drug Administration announced. The actions involve 116,630 pounds of cranberries.
MEXICO CITY, Nov. 23 -- The Soviet fair, barely a day old, has become an ideological battleground here.

Eastern Air Lines dedicated yesterday its $20,000,000 passenger terminal at New York International Airport in a ceremony attended by Mayor Wagner, Capt. Eddie Riekenbacker, chairman of the board of Eastern, and other civic and business leaders.
CHICAGO, Nov. 23 -- One of the chief causes of divorce is the divorce trial itself, Louis H. Burke, Presiding Judge of the Superior Court of Los Angeles, said tonight.

BUENOS AIRES, Nov. 23 -- Alvaro Carlos Alsogaray's friends recall that as a schoolboy he organized a neighborhood soccer team for which he acted as manager, ticket-taker and treasurer. He was also a good sprint runner.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 23 -The Government's shortest-term borrowing costs fell back today from the peak established last week.

GENEVA, Nov. 23 -- United States, British and Soviet scientists were ready here today to begin a study of the problem of detecting underground nuclear explosions, but the go-ahead signal was still being awaited from Moscow.

PRINCETON, N. J., Nov. 23 -- A five-year graduate program in plasma physics has been established at Princeton University under a $205,000 grant from the Ford Foundation. Robert F. Goheen, Princeton's president, announced the program today.

ROCHESTER, N. Y., Nov. 23 -- The State Education Commissioner declared tonight that the recent television scandals had underscored the need for schools to give special attention to the development of moral and spiritual values.

Close relatives of officers and trustees of savings banks in New York State would be barred from holding similar offices in the same banks if a bill being prepared by the State Banking Department should be passed by the Legislature.

TWO familiar names, Lee Gatch and Lee Bontecou, are the top award winners in the Second Biennial of American Painting and Sculpture opening today at the Detroit Institute of Arts. In painting, Mr. Gatch won the Joseph E. Temple Gold Medal for his "Fish Market," describable as about three-quarters abstract.
A SOJOURN in a French political prison made him a skilled cook, M'Hammed Yazid, chief spokesman for the Algerian Nationalists at the United Nations, explains.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 23 -- The General Assembly's Steering Committee overruled Soviet protests today and recommended the addition of the Hungarian question to the Assembly's agenda.

ROME, Nov. 23 -- Thirteen senior United States officers involved in a major shake-up of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization command in Turkey passed through Naples today on their way home for reassignment.

One hundred years ago today the London publishing house of John Murray issued the first edition of Charles Darwin's "Origin of the Species." That small green volume, of which the entire edition of 1,250 copies sold out on the first day, changed man's concept of himself and of his place in the universe as no other literary work in history.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 23 -President Eisenhower returned to the White House today after a twelve-day golfing vacation in Georgia and immediately abandoned plans to spend the Thanksgiving holiday at his farm in Gettysburg, Pa.

Judge Sylvester J. Ryan of the United States District Court here signed a preliminary injunction yesterday enjoining two California banks, Guild Films Company and Hal Roach are from further violating the Registration provision of the Securities Act of 1933.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 23 (AP) -- The Supreme Court declared today that suspicion alone was not sufficient reason for a police officer to make an arrest.
LONDON, Nov. 23 -- The plight of Britain's nationalized coal industry was highlighted today by a suggestion that it sell its huge surplus at low prices.
DETROIT, Nov. 23 (AP) -- Abolition of industry-wide collective bargaining was urged today by the president of the National Association of Manufacturers.

EAST LANSING, Mich., Nov. 23 (AP) -- Al Lawrence, a slight but sturdy sophomore from Sydney, Australia, representing the University of Houston, won the twenty-first annual National Collegiate cross-country run today. He was timed in 20:35.7 for the four miles.

In a matter of days in Brooklyn a man 42 was named a rookie and a court injunction was granted to stop a televised bowling show. Thus the borough retained its pre-eminence as a place of unusual happenings.
NEW ORLEANS, Nov. 23 (AP) -- An official of the American Bankers Association today warned commercial bankers to adjust their thinking to the changes that had taken place in our economic structure.
In your recent editorial "Challenge of a Changing City" you point out the sad plight of New York City government, and give encouragement for a 1961 fusion movement.
A pre-dawn inspection of the ten largest wholesale poultry dealers in the city yesterday disclosed that seven of them were short-weighting their retail customers.

"The Facts About Nixon: An Unauthorized Biography," by William Costello, will be published by Viking on Jan. 8. Although Mr. Costello was not given access to the Vice President's papers, nor was he accorded an interview, his book outlines his subject's upbringing and analyzes his political growth.

THE tidbits that accompany cocktails can be devastating to low-calorie diets. Just a few tiny sausages wrapped in a rich, flaky pastry can undo all the good that might have accrued from a Spartan lunch of cottage cheese, fresh fruit and melba toast.
TRAVELING to Grandmother's house for the holidays is not the family safari it used to be, even when Grandmother lives as far away as the Netherlands, which is only ten hours from New York by air.

Churches and synagogues over the city will observe Thanksgiving Day tomorrow with their traditional mid-week services. Many altars and chancels will be decked with fruits of the harvest that will later be distributed to the needy.
The floor of the basketball court at Madison Square Garden may not have enough resiliency for the Russians and the backboards may have too much for them.
" Fiorello!", a musical account of Fiorello H. La Guardia's early years, is the town's latest stage hit.

New York City has borrowed $50,000,000 on tax anticipation notes due April 28, 1960, at an interest rate of 3 per cent, Controller Lawrence E. Gerosa announced yesterday. The issue was sold by allotment to eighteen banks and trust companies, as follows:

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 24 -- A new Western formula for a solution of the deadlock over the membership of a permanent United Nations body to regulate the peaceful uses of outer space has been presented to the Soviet Union.
The City Council approved a bill yesterday to give the police a new weapon in the war against juvenile crime.

SEATTLE, Nov. 24 (UPI) -- Rivers swollen by heavy weekend rains and melting snows on the Cascade Mountain range started to recede slowly late today. Officials hoped they had passed the crisis in western Washington's worst flood in twenty-seven years.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 24 -- Secretary of State Christian A. Herter has explained to France that United States laws would not permit withholding visas from three Algerian nationalist leaders desiring to come to the United Nations.

ROCHESTER, N. Y., NOV. 24 -- The state Education Commissioner was urged today to delay carrying out a plan to place more emphasis on subject matter for future secondary school teachers. Proposals on the matter were made last week by special advisory committees of the state Education Department.
WARSAW, Nov. 24 (AP) -- Frederick H. Mueller, United States Secretary of Commerce, said today that his Government wanted to help Poland increase her trade with the United States.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 24 (AP) -- Hearst Consolidated Publications, Inc., today filed a $6,000,000 damage suit against the American Newspaper Guild.
TWO short verse plays -- one by a poet who last season took Broadway by storm, the other by a poet who certainly could, if he would -- were presented yesterday afternoon by the ANTA Matinee Series.

The Associated Dry Goods Corporation turned in record sales and earnings in the three and nine months ended on Oct. 31, according to the results announced yesterday by Robert J. McKim, chairman of the big retail chain.
Record third-quarter earnings of the Tennessee Corporation lifted its net income for the first nine months of this year by 53 per cent, to $7,078,300 from $4,615,700 in the 1958 period.
HONG KONG, Nov. 24 -- A continuing campaign against "rightist opportunists" has brought into sharp relief a basic conflict in the Chinese Communist party.

Investment bankers headed by Stone Webster Securities Corporation are marketing today $16,000,000 of first mortgage bonds of Gulf States Utilities Company. The bonds carry 5 1/4 per cent interest coupons, fall due in 1989, and are priced at 102.603 for a yield to investors of 5.08 to maturity.

The U.S.O. is basically an extension of local community services. Through it the wholesome influences of the home, church and school are continued while our young men and women are serving in the armed forces.
SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 24 -- A plan to merge the two oldest banks in the West was renewed today by the directors of the Wells Fargo Bank and the American Trust Company.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 24 -- The late Senator Robert A. Taft's confidential analysis of why he lost the Republican Presidential nomination to Dwight D. Eisenhower in 1952 came to light here today.

The nation's stores were urged yesterday to remain closed on Sundays. The National Retail Merchants Association and the Variety Stores Association issued statements timed to coincide with the start of the Christmas selling season, which follows Thanksgiving in most areas.
GUATEMALA, Nov. 24 -- Drastic measures to cut imports and stop the drain in dollar reserves were announced last night by President Miguel Ydigoras Fuentes.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 24 (UPI) -- Financial experts clashed at a Congressional hearing today over whether interest on state and municipal bonds should continue exempt from Federal income taxes.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 24 -- The court-appointed monitors of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters won a point in Federal District Court today in their attempt to show that James R. Hoffa should be removed as provisional president of the union.
WEST POINT, N. Y., Nov. 24 -- Army's football team has just about completed heavy preparations for Saturday's meeting with Navy at Philadelphia.
The chemical industry appears to be headed for a record $24,000,000,000 sales year, Gen. John E. Hall, president of the Manufacturing Chemists Association, said yesterday.

Harry Canelstein, New York and Florida realty investor, has contracted to buy the shopping center at 224-01 to 224-09 Linden Boulevard and the professional office building adjoining at 116-51 224th Street, Cambria Heights, Queens. The deal was negotiated by David Israel, broker.
BOSTON, Nov. 24 -- A Thanksgiving cargo of calves and turkeys will be airlifted tomorrow from the Logan International Airport here to Iran. The consignment is a gift from Congregationalists.
RABAT, Morocco, Nov. 24 -- Morocco's new five-year plan, which is to go into effect early next year, provides for widespread state intervention in and control of industry.

Potato futures rose yesterday on the New York Mercantile Exchange in what was termed a technical advance following recent weakness. Futures were up 3 to 4 points (hundredths of a cent a pound) on 1,111 car lots. Short covering and hedge lifting in the near months met liquidation and hedge selling of deferred positions.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 24 -- The United States and the Soviet Union signed an agreement today for a cooperative program of nuclear research. Among the projects to be considered is the construction of a large atom smasher for use by scientists of all the world.

A "basis" for settlement of the waterfront contract dispute without a resumption of the East and Gulf Coast dock strike was accepted yesterday by representatives of the International Longshoremen's Association.
The American Guild of Authors and Composers told the Federal Communications Commission yesterday that payola to disk jockeys was "merely a symptom of a disease."
JOLIET, Ill., Nov. 24 (AP) -- Nearly twenty-six years' imprisonment ended today for one of the Prohibition era's toughest gangsters.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, Nov. 24 (AP) -- A Democratic Congressman from Los Angeles addressed the Parliament of his forefathers today and lived, as he put it, a moment to be forever treasured. Representative George A. Kasem, 40 years old, the son of a Lebanese immigrant, appeared as the honored guest of Parliament. In his own words he came as a living symbol of the ties of blood friendship between Lebanon and the United States.
Argentine representatives headed by their Finance Minister, Eustaquio Mendez Delfino, began talks yesterday with New York banks on financing the Argentine stabilization program for 1960.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 24 -- The Treasury announced tonight that it was paying the highest short-term rate since 1929 for a cash borrowing of $2,000,000,000.

The owners have reclaimed four of seven stray dogs captured in the Hunts Point section of the Bronx last Friday by the police and dog catchers from the American Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals.

A bill to force the retirement of savings bank trustees over seventy-five years of age drew opposition yesterday from several leading savings bankers. The bill is one of three relating to savings bank officers and trustees being readied for introduction in the Legislature by the State Banking Department.

SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 24 (AP) -- An association accused of conspiring with steel companies to restrain West Coast trade in steel-reinforcing bars said today that it had helped "small companies to complete more effectively and efficiently."
LONDON, Nov. 24 -- Prices generally receded in a quiet session on the stock market here today.
HAVANA, Nov. 24 -- Revolucion, the official newspaper of Dr. Fidel Castro's movement, attacked his older brother Ramon in a front-page editorial today.

THE French Bridge Federation (Federation Francaise du Bridge), which this year began to rank its players by the master-point system that has proved so popular in the United States, has just this month published its ranking of players.

Superior speed carried the Syracuse Nationals to a 120-107 triumph over the Knickerbockers at Madison Square Garden last night, dropping the New Yorkers deeper into the cellar of the Eastern Division of the National Basketball Association.
PANAMA, Nov. 24 -- A United States official reaffirmed today that "titular sovereignty over the Canal Zone remains in the Government of Panama."

BERKELEY, Calif., Nov. 24 -- The acquisition of radio station WBAI-FM in New York by the Pacifica Foundation of this city, operator of two non-commercial FM stations in California, was announced today.
Trading in United States Government securities slowed yesterday as the financial district awaited the outcome of the Treasury's auction of $2,000,000,000 of 320-day discount bills due next October.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 24 -- A special committee of the Council on Foreign Relations called upon President Eisenhower today to provide the nation with "effective leadership" and "a sense of purpose" in foreign policy.

POOLING their taste, talent, education and responsibility for the culture of the community, the good people of the Phoenix have tried to kick a little life into Aristophanes' "Lysistrata," which opened on the home grounds last evening.
Recommendations on relocating tenants from slums will be ready for Mayor Wagner in about a month, J. Anthony Panuch, special adviser to the Mayor on housing and city renewal, announced yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 24 -- Secretary of State Christian A. Herter defended today the Administration's policy of negotiating with the Soviet Unionon the status of West Berlin.
DOHA, Qatar, Nov. 24 -- King Saud of Saudi Arabia and his retinue will arrive here Thursday in five planes for a four-day state visit to Sheik Ali Bin Abdullah al Thani, ruler of Qatar.

ONE of the most magnificent physical specimens to stride across the sports horizon in the past thirty years was Maximilian Adelbert Baer. He stood 6 feet 3 inches and weighed 220 pounds. But his shoulders were so wide that he instinctively went through a doorway sideways. His waist seemed almost as slim as a girl's.

The board of directors of the Associated Hospital Service of New York yesterday named David W. Brumbaugh of Time magazine as its chairman and chief executive officer of Blue Cross, as the service is known.
A year ago next month a barefoot African youth defeated a white British track star in a three-mile race in Salisbury, Southern Rhodesia.

The pictorial biography of Sir Winston Churchill, "Churchill: The Walk With Destiny," which had been postponed because of the recent strike in England, will be issued by Macmillan on Dec. 14. Compiled and designed by H. Tatlock Miller and Loudon Sainthill, he volume contains almost 250 illustrations, some in color, showing Sir Winston throughout his life and the momentous events with which he has been identified.
Australia may be famous for its kangaroos but when night falls other strange specimens rove.

The City Planning Commission refused yesterday to approve the inclusion of $3,516,000 for pier development in the city's 1960 capital budget. The money would pay for a start on the proposed $40,000,000 redevelopment of lower Manhattan's East River waterfront.

HEMPSTEAD, L. I., Nov. 24 -- George Dempster, co-captain of Hofstra's unbeaten football team, underwent an emergency appendectomy early this morning at Doctors Hospital in Freeport. He was reported in good condition.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange moved 2 points off to 2 points up yesterday after holding in a narrow range all day. (A point equals 5 cents a bale.)

CROTON FALLS, N. Y., Nov. 24 -- James R. Worley, who was discharged yesterday as a teacher and chairman of the English Department at Fox Lane High School, near Mount Kisco, was busy at his home here today answering offers of aid from parents, teachers and a lawyer.
NEW DELHI, India, Nov. 24 (Reuters) -- Defense Minister V. K. Krishna Menon received overwhelming support today at a parliamentary caucus of the ruling Congress party.

The Thanksgiving season is close at hand and with it the independent but parallel appeals of the three great religious faiths for assistance in seeking to meet the needs of hungry, homeless and disaster-stricken people overseas.

Only four 3-year-old fillies competed in the $6,000 Parading Lady at foggy, soggy Aqueduct yesterday, but it took a photo finish to select Velvet Acres' Tanbrook as a neck winner over Dean Alfange's Speedy Contessa.

Stockholders of General Dynamics Corporation and Material Service Corporation of Chicago will be asked at separate special meetings on Dec. 29 to approve the merger of the Chicago company into General Dynamics. If approved, it will become the material service division of General Dynamics.

A few days ago three of the Soviet Union's most distinguished scientists used Pravda as a forum to denounce the incompetence and sensation mongering of Soviet science writers and to brand as worthless two "scientific discoveries" widely acclaimed in the Soviet press recently.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 24 (AP) -- President Eisenhower named Franklin B. Lincoln Jr., a New York lawyer, today to be Assistant Secretary of Defense in charge of financial matters.

Wellington Equity Fund's first annual report, released yesterday, showed net assets of $40,542,059, or $12.03 a share on 3,369,690 shares outstanding, on Oct. 31, the end of the fiscal year. This compared with initial capital of $33,124,630, or $11.04 a share on the 3,000,000 shares outstanding on Oct. 23, 1958.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 24 -- The Soviet delegation issued today a toned-down version of the speech delivered yesterday by Vasily V. Kuznetsov, a Soviet First Deputy Foreign Minister, on the Hungarian question.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 24 -- Countries that fought under the United Nations flag in Korea asked the international organization today to seek a Korean settlement, in the face of bitter Communist opposition.
The World-Telegram and The Sun yesterday dismissed two staff members who were involved in a false charge of attempted bribery against an unnamed public official.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 24 -- Israel and Jordan clashed today over an appraisal of the Jewish religion.
Edith Eisler, Vienna-born violinist who made her debut here in 1951, appeared at Carnegie Recital Hall last night.
LONDON, Nov. 24 -- The British Labor party refused today to serve on an advisory commission on Central Africa until ambiguity in its terms of reference was clarified.

ETHEL MERMAN'S hour of song on Channel 4 last night was a keen disappointment. The exuberant queen of the Broadway musical-comedy stage simply found herself in one of those mistakes that from time to time are bound to occur in show business.

LONDON, Nov. 24 -- A study group of the unofficial Army League, qualified experts on military affairs, stated today that Britain's first priority must be "to help defend Western Europe" under the North Atlantic Treaty Organization.

CHICAGO, Nov. 24 -- A four-engined Trans World Airlines Constellation cargo plane crashed in the pre-dawn darkness today and tore a flaming swath through an area of small homes and apartments near Midway Airport, in the southwestern section of the city.

A second major airline broke industry ranks yesterday in subscribing to an outside credit plan.

The New York Central Railroad, the nation's second largest carrier, earned the equivalent of only 3 cents a share on its 6,500,000 shares of stock last month. October normally is Central's second most profitable month of the year.
The Jones Laughlin Steel Corporation and Ketchum, MacLeod Grove, Inc., are terminating an eleven-year relationship.
Dr. James B. Conant, president emeritus of Harvard University, urged yesterday an increase in state aid to public schools in most parts of the country so that teaching standards could be improved.
It was a bad day for tankers here yesterday. Two 523-foot oil carriers, both 16,000-ton T-2 types of ships, got into trouble.

Following a program of economic orthodoxy often has the same painful effects for a nation that following a doctor's strict regimen has for an individual. Yet the process does pay dividends in both cases.

UNITED NATIONS, N Y., Nov. 24 -- The Laotian delegation credited today the efforts of Secretary General Dag Hammarskjold and a Security Council subcommittee with having brought stability to its country's troubled frontier.
PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 24 -- Dr. Robert L. Johnson, chancellor of Temple University, supported tonight the loyalty-oath requirement for students participating in the Federal student loan program.
A labor arbitrator has found the State of Connecticut responsible for a labor dispute in which it was not directly involved.
DETROIT, Nov. 24 -- The General Motors Corporation will resume passenger-car assembly operations Dec. 7 after a lapse of three and a half weeks because of the steel shortage.

Art is for the few, according to the majority of women shoppers yesterday in a fashion boutique in Queens.

The first Metropolitan Opera performance of Verdi's "Nabucco" ("Nabucodonosor") will open the Metropolitan's 1960-61 season on Oct. 24. The announcement was made yesterday by Rudolf Bing, general manager.
The musical gamut of opera is broad, as the Metropolitan's Rudolf Bing has demonstrated, its range extending from, shall we say, "Parsifal" on one rim to extravaganza on the other.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., Nov. 24 -- Damning the torpedoes, the Navy Brigade of Midshipmen broke down the practice field fence to watch and cheer the varsity football team at work today. That is the spirit in which the academy is approaching the sixtieth game with Army in the Philadelphia Stadium Saturday.
Forecast of Thanksgiving Day in New York and Detroit: two parades followed by Santa Claus and, possibly, by process servers in pursuit of the Columbia Broadcasting System.
ATLANTA, Nov. 24 (UPI) -- The city school board gave details today of its gradual pupil-assignment plan. It will submit it to a Federal court in reply to an anti-discrimination order.

Drab black dresses, white caps and ever-present knitting are all part of the legend. But the exceptions, who bore no resemblance to this stereotype, were numerous and varied.
LONDON, Nov. 24 -- The Engineering and Allied Employers' Federation rejected today a demand by forty unions representing about 3,000,000 factory workers for a pay increase of u1 ($2.80) a week.
