NEWARK, Nov. 24 -- In the battle over New Jersey's ban on Sunday sales, the principal target today was Bergen County's prosecutor, Guy W. Calissi.

The Rev. Dr. John Vernon Butler, rector of Trinity Protestant Episcopal Church in Princeton,. N. J., was named yesterday to succeed the Right Rev. James A. Pike as Dean of the Cathedral Church of St. John the Divine.
Two areas within the new European Free Trade Association -- Norway and Wales -- made strong bids yesterday to attract private American industrial investment.
If one is to believe the New York Rangers' current goalie and the goalie who was dropped, it would appear that Marcel Paille will be tending the Ranger nets for some time to come.
A dinner dance on New Year's Eve in the ballroom of the Sheraton-East will be a benefit for the International Rescue Committee.
A three-year contract covering 4,500 employes of 150 hotels in the city was signed yesterday by Local 144 of the Hotel and Allied Service Employes Union and Associated Hotels, Inc.

COLOMBO, Ceylon, Nov. 24 (Reuters) -- Parliament restored the death penalty today and the Government extended the state of emergency declared after the assassination of Prime Minister S. W. R. D. Bandaranaike Sept. 25.

Directors of the Borden Company yesterday recommended a two-for-one split of the common stock, voted a year-end dividend of $1 and announced plans to raise the dairy company's quarterly dividend rate.

Nearly half the motor vehicle inspectors in the New York metropolitan area are being investigated in an inquiry into a racket to obtain drivers' licenses, the State Attorney General's office said last night.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 24 (AP) -- President Eisenhower will pass up a news conference this week but will hold one Dec. 2, the day before leaving for Europe, Asia and Africa.

NEW YORK often imposes cruel restrictions on a child, but there are wondrous compensations within its concrete boundaries. Perhaps no other city in the world can both in-cite and satisfy a child's curiosity so well.
PARIS, Wednesday, Nov. 25 -- Premier Michel Debre moved early today to stamp out rebellion in the French National Assembly by inviting it to throw him out of office if it dared.

PALISADES PARK, N. J., Nov. 24 -- Three men were killed here today in the flaming collision of two trucks on rain-slickened Route 46. Seven fatalities have occurred in the last eighteen months within 1,000 feet of the scene, Police Chief Leonard L. Cottrell reported.
Ugo Galassi of Milan, executive vice president and a director of Olivetti, of Italy, yesterday was elected president of the Underwood Corporation. He succeeds Frank E. Beane.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 24 -An interfaith campaign for "decency" in motion pictures was proposed today by a spokesman for the Roman Catholic Church.

A bumper crop usually means prosperity for the producers. But the price of corn on the farm is about $1 a bushel, less than half that of twelve years ago. And, in the interim, the cost of producing the cereal has advanced substantially.
ALBANY, Nov. 24 -- Governor Rockefeller and the Republican legislative leaders have agreed on a plan to provide more equal treatment for taxpayers who work in New York but live in other states.

LANSING, Mich., Nov. 24 (UPI) -- John D. Voekler, a Michigan Supreme Court Justice and the author of the best-selling "Anatomy of a Murder," said today he wanted to resign from the bench to continue his writing.

A dividend of 15 cents and an extra of 10 cents has been declared by Certain-Teed Products Corporation on common shares payable Jan. 4. This is the company's first cash dividend since 15 cents was paid in December, 1958.

The Appellate Division yesterday ordered a third trial of a nine-year-old suit for $400,000 in damages brought against members of the Board of Elections by Max M. Schwartz. He contends that they illegally threw out his designating petition as an Assembly candidate.

Your Nov. 20 editorial "Vandals Redesign Schools" points up a serious problem which, however, is only one small part of the general delinquency picture. May I differ with you on your conclusion that the parents should be made responsible, up to $25, for their children's vandalism.
BOSTON, Nov. 24 -- A $3,000,000 grant to the Woods Hole Oceanographic Institution for a new research vessel was made known today by the National Science Foundation.
MINNEAPOLIS, Nov. 24 (UPI) -- American Football League owners scattered today to try to sew up their top draft choices before the National Football League contacts the players.

Any and all suggestions that the remainder of the National Football League schedule favors the Giants, Eastern Conference leaders, are rejected -- resented, in fact -- by Jim Lee Howell, their head coach.

SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 24 (UPI) -- Italy's "Il Generale della Rovere," directed by Roberto Rossellini and starring Vittorio De Sica, swept top honors as the best film of the third International Film Festival tonight.

The Food and Drug Administration had found that a certain weed-killer used with cranberry crops contained aminotriazole, a substance capable of producing cancer in mice as demonstrated by experimental procedures. The agency therefore issued a public warning to that effect while simultaneously bidding the producers and sellers of cranberries to suspend sales pending corrective measures.
Reports of low morale at the United States Merchant Marine Academy at Kings Point, L. I., will be investigated by a Congressional committee.
Stocks rose yesterday for the sixth straight session in active trading. The advance was paced by issues in the aircraft-missile field. Motors and office equipment stocks also displayed strength.

Reaffirming a fundamental American position, the United States yesterday joined thirteen other nations that fought with the United Nations force in Korea in sponsoring before the General Assembly a resolution calling for the reunification of Korea into one independent and democratic state by the means of free elections.

The state opened an inquiry yesterday into savings-and-loan associations that it said had fraudulently jeopardized more than $100,000,000 of their funds by insuring them with a one-room insurance company in Morocco.

GUANTANAMO NAVAL BASE, Cuba, Nov. 24 (AP) Cuban Army officials announced today that the bodies of three men had been found in the wreckage of a United States Navy plane that crashed yesterday about thirty-five miles from here in the mountains of Oriente Province.
SEBRING, Fla., Nov. 24 -Sebring already is bustling with preparations for the first full-fledged Grand Prix of the United States, to be run over a 5.2-mile course here on Saturday, Dec. 12.

Postmaster General Arthur E. Summerfield said last night that the Post Office Department was planning a citizens' advisory committee to help it decide which publications should be banned from the mails as obscene.
Thirty three-man teams from the Markets and Investigation Departments visited retail meat markets in four boroughs yesterday and reported widespread cases of cheating on weight and price.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 24 -- The National Labor Relations Board issued today its first policy decision on the voting rights of so-called economic strikers under the new labor-reform law.

The possibility that Ingemar Johansson will defend his heavyweight title against Floyd Patterson in New York was strengthened last night when Patterson said he would fight the champion even without Cus D'Amato in his corner.

STRASBOURG, France, Nov. 24 -- The six nations of the European common market decided today to give other Western nations, including the United States, the benefits of import-quota liberalization they will give one another Jan. 1.
Joseph G. Luberda, the retired police sergeant in whose car $18,000 was found last March after an auto accident, was sentenced to two years in jail yesterday for criminal contempt.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 24 (AP) -- Martin Popper, 50 years old, of New York, a former secretary of the National Lawyers Guild was indicted today on charges of contempt of Congress for refusing to tell the House Committee on Un-American Activities whether he was a Comunist.
HOBOKEN, N. J., Nov. 24 -- The election of John H. Muller as chairman of the executive committee of the Stevens Institute of Technology board of trustees was announced today.

IF Ross Lee Finney was not in a confident, extrovert mood this year when he wrote his Second Symphony, the music makes a brave show of a composer full of thrust and vigor. It was pleasant to encounter a work so sure of itself when it had its New York premiere at Carnegie Hall last night.

OTTAWA, Nov. 24 -- This Saturday the eyes of sports-loving Canadians will be on Toronto. The annual professional football game between the West and the East will be played there before some 33,000 fans and televised across the country.

INBAL, DANCE THEATRE OF ISRAEL, which won all our hearts on its first New York visit two years ago, returned last night for a fort-night at the City Center and proved that our original response to its charming art was entirely well founded. Such an engaging stageful of people,, fairly bursting with creativeness, would be very hard to resist.
CARACAS, Venezuela, Nov. 24 -- Governor Rockefeller arrived here today with Mrs. Rockefeller for a week's vacation at his Monte Sacro farm.

The thousands of persons served by Greenwich House may well give thanks tomorrow to the late Mary Simkhovitch, who founded the settlement on Thanksgiving Day in 1902. Paying tribute in a more concrete way, a committee is planning a theatre party to help carry on her work.
A contract for the sale of Peter Doelger, Inc., of real estate valued at more than $20,000,000 was announced yesterday.
A decision by the Supreme Court on Monday that banned arrests on mere suspicion may affect the outcome of the Apalachin trial, it was indicated yesterday.

CHICAGO, Nov. 24 -- A five-day Darwin centennial celebration began today at the University of Chicago, with 2,500 scholars, students and others attending. There are delegates from nearly 200 colleges and learned societies in twenty-seven countries.
NEW DELHI, India, Nov. 24 -- The Indian Government extended today to foreign oil companies an invitation to help in finding and producing petroleum in this country.

THE reports of hunting deaths are sifting in every day now, and they make sorry reading. They also make first-class propaganda for the proposition that all hunters, not just minors, should be required to pass a safety course before buying their first licenses.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 24 -- A few years ago Vasily Simonovich Yemelyanov decided he would learn English.

GENEVA, Nov. 24 -- The Soviet Union agreed with the United States and Britain today on a program for a study of the detection of underground nuclear explosions. The study, by technicians, is to begin here tomorrow.

One of the principles most frequently, violated by us is the principle of free trade and free competition. The Administration's decision to tie loans from the Development Loan Fund to the purchase of United States' goods is a recent violation of this principle despite all alibis and arguments to the contrary.

TWO painters, Grace Hartigan and Larry Rivers, submit themselves to the hegemony of the word in an exhibition at the Tibor de Nagy Gallery, 24 East Sixty-seventh Street. Both artists have based their compositions on poems written by their contemporary, Frank O'Hara.
The State Labor Relations Board yesterday barred an independent, self-chartered local union from using a "misleading, deceptive and confusing" legend after its name in appearances before the board.
SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 24 -- The first strike in the lithographic industry in this country since 1921 was in progress today in San Francisco.
WHITE PLAINS, Nov. 24 -- The adoption of the first uniform employment policy for the public schools in Westchester was reported today by the County Council of Chief School Officers.
SANTIAGO DE CUBA, Nov. 24 -- A large sign near the airport here proclaims that Santiago is the "Cradle of the Revolution."

WASHINGTON, Nov. 24 -- Following is the text of an analysis of the 1952 Republican Presidential contest, prepared in the fall of that year by the late Senator Robert A. Taft, Republican of Ohio, who lost the nomination to Dwight D. Eisenhower:

SEOUL, Korea, Nov. 24 -- Delegates of the Democratic party, the principal opposition to President Syngman Rhee's Government, will meet here Thursday to choose candidates for the Presidency and Vice Presidency against Dr. Rhee and his running mate, Lee Ki Poong, in the national election next spring.
A vigorous defense of teacher education was offered yesterday by Dr. John H. Fischer, the new dean of Teachers College of Columbia University.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 24 -- Following is the State Department's transcript of Secretary of State Christian A. Herter's news conference today:

The members of the Soviet Union's men's and women's national basketball teams, which will make their first appearance in this country at Madison Square Garden tonight, were fortified for a day of sightseeing yesterday with a typical capitalist's breakfast -- apelsinovni sok, sosiski i yaitsa i moloko (orange juice, sausages, eggs and milk).

SAN ANTONIO, Tex., Nov. 19 -- This old Army town, birthplace of the modern Air Force, is the gateway today to an Air Force career for more than 100,000 persons annually. But most of them will never fly.

Pravda, official voice of Soviet communism, has published a New York straphanger's plaintive plea to Premier Khrushchev to "come visit us soon again" so that "decent lighting" may be provided in the city's subways.
HALIFAX, N.S., Nov. 25 (AP) -- Transport Minister George Hees says the Nov. 30 closing date for the St. Lawrence seaway won't be changed.

A scale model of a famous brig in the newly opened show on Charles Darwin at the American Museum of Natural History was built by a woman who is as comfortable managing ships that sail as those that shine in museum cases.
Thanksgiving will have an added meaning for a Bronx mother today because her 3-year-old son will give her a morning kiss -- something he has just learned to do.

There was a chance last Sunday to watch what appeared to an inexperienced eye to be a case of controlled confusion. The event was the hunt of the Sandanona Beagles over the high pastures and small woods of Millbrook, N. Y., in Dutchess County.

The latest "insiders' list" released by the New York Stock Exchange shows that R. Walter Graham Jr., a director and large stockholder in the New York Central Railroad, sold all of his holdings of 5,100 shares of the Alleghany Corporation's stock.

Three floors in the office building being constructed by Uris Brothers at 320 Park Avenue, at Fiftieth Street, have been leased by Scudder, Stevens Clark, investment counsel. The lease, covering 50,000 square feet, is for twenty-one years.

LAKE SUCCESS, L. I., Nov. 25 -- Povl Bang-Jensen, senior political affairs officer for the United Nations Secretariat until his dismissal in July, 1958, has been reported missing from his home here since Monday.
PARIS, Nov. 25 -- The Senate agreed today to strip Senator Francois Mitterrand of his parliamentary immunity.
Outplaying a team is one thing, but beating the opposition is another problem.
WARSAW, Nov. 25 (UPI) -- Premier Jozef Cyrankiewicz outlined today a new austerity program for Poland but insisted that the Government was still following its own "road to socialism."
Solar Aircraft Company, San Diego, Calif., has purchased 124,000, or about 17 per cent, of its own shares from Fairbanks, Morse Co., a Chicago concern.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 25 -The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in leading cities showed the following principal changes for the week ended Nov. 18:
LONDON, Nov. 25 (AP ) -Prospects of an open tournament at Wimbledon in 1961 faded today with the publication of the official agenda for the annual meeting of the British Lawn Tennis Association.

May I suggest that enough attention has been paid to cranberries, and too little to the truly special significance that Thanksgiving has this year. It happens to fall on the 170th anniversary of the first one celebrated by all the people of the United States.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 25 -- The Federal Court of Appeals reversed today a decision by the National Labor Relations Board affecting the newspaper industry.
HAMBURG, Germany, Nov. 25 (AP) -- Germany's first atomic-powered freighter will make test runs in two and a half to three years.

The Pamplona Choir from Spain which is making its second United States tour, gave a program last night at the Lexington Avenue Young Men's and Young Women's Hebrew Association. The group, consisting of eight women and seven men, was led by Luis Morondo, who formed it twelve years ago.
EDWARDSVILLE, Ill., Nov. 25 (AP) -- Paul H. Blackmon of Edwardsville was awarded $97,000 in a judgment returned today in Madison County Circuit Court on a suit over a stock transfer.
For the first time in four years the New York Football Giants will practice on Thanksgiving Day.

The dwindling in the gold supply of the United States brought about by the building up of reserves by foreign nations was noted yesterday by J. S. Proctor, president of the Imperial Bank of Canada, at the annual meeting in Toronto.

THE character-building value of getting up before dawn and working into the next night for $6 a week can be mildly overestimated, R. L. Duffus suggests in the second volume of his Vermont memoirs, "The Waterbury Record."* Yet I don't think he would go so far as to say that austerity brings out the best in a man -- sometimes by the roots.

DAYTON, Ohio, Nov. 25 (AP) -- A United States District Court jury returned today a directed verdict of acquittal of two former Montgomery County sheriff's deputies accused of having beaten prisoners to obtain confessions.
SYRACUSE, Nov. 25 (AP) -- Syracuse University's football team, No. 1 in the nation, worked out for two hours today and then headed home for the holiday.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, Nov. 25 -- The Soviet Union is striving to solidify its relations with Indonesia while the latter has been quarreling with Communist China. Moscow has informed Indonesia that it does not want to be identified with China's opposition to the Indonesian ban on trading by Chinese in rural areas.
GENEVA, Nov. 25 -- United States, British and Soviet scientists began today a study of ways to identify underground nuclear bomb explosions.
The Transit Authority completed yesterday an investigation into the causes of the BMT subway crash last Saturday morning in which thirty-nine persons were injured.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 25 -- The National Security Council discussed today the military budget for the fiscal year starting next July 1. Some major policy issues were reported to be still unresolved.
HONG KONG, Nov. 25 -- The Peiping radio gave ample warning today that the Chinese people would soon be called upon for further sacrifices.

Under the ticker symbol MCA, trading commenced on the Big Board yesterday in 3,995,735 common shares of MCA Inc. The company produces television films. The shares opened at 28 3/8, closed at 29 3/8 with 9,200 shares changing hands.

Following are the texts of letters by Dr. Frank Stanton, president of the Columbia Broadcasting System; Robert W. Sarnoff, chairman of the National Broadcasting Company, and Sigurd S. Larmon, chairman of Young Rubicam, Inc., dealing with a proposal by Mr. Larmon for charting television's future:

WASHINGTON, Nov. 25 -- Federal mediators, still hopeful for a steel settlement without a renewed strike, announced today that new industry-union negotiations would resume here next week, probably Tuesday.
The appointment of Philip J. Monaghan as vice president in charge of the process development staff of the General Motors Corporation was announced yesterday by John F. Gordon, president.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 25 (AP) -- The Interstate Commerce Commission today authorized the Lackawanna Railroad to drop two of its daily passenger trains between Hoboken, N. J., and Scranton, Pa., effective Friday.
BABYLON, L. I., Nov. 25 -- A State Supreme Court order directed Babylon town officials today to tax the town's forty square miles of controversial "wetlands" for school purposes this year.
The jury in the Apalachin trial was told yesterday that the Nov. 14, 1957, gathering at the estate of the late Joseph Barbara Sr. was so large that women had to be excluded.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 25 -The Ivy League football championship will be settled tomorrow in the sixty-sixth meeting between title-bidding Pennsylvania and fifth-place Cornell before a crowd of 25,000 at Franklin Field.
A Moroccan insurance concern that the New York State Attorney General accused on Tuesday of "having an insubstantial number of assets" replied to the criticism yesterday.

JOSEPH Meraglia, a young man who lives at 3608 Twenty-ninth Street, Astoria, Queens, and works in the publications department of The Times, lost a deer by armed robbery in the woods a few days ago. There is an ugly pattern in this.

Today, the U. S. O. pauses with the rest of America to offer reverent thanks for the USO many blessings bestowed upon our nation. We realize again on Thanksgiving Day that only through the efforts and sacrifices of our young men and women in uniform have we been able to preserve our freedoms throughout the years.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 25 (AP) -- The General Accounting Office said today that the Government was paying $1,000,000 or more a year too much for telephone service.

GRAVY spots on fine white damask, coffee splashed on the newly cleaned rug, an upturned wine glass or a stubborn fruit stain are, regrettably, a familiar part of the holiday scene. Dealt with quickly, the damage is only temporary. Neglected, it can be irretrievable.
The liquor license of the Statler Hilton Hotel has been suspended for Christmas week on a charge of serving to minors, the State Liquor Authority announced yesterday.
New York's subway system is safe and getting safer, in the judgment of an engineering firm engaged by the city to inspect the system.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 25 -- The Treasury granted today a conditional extension of the time limit for exchanging F and G savings bonds for 4 3/4 per cent notes.

CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla., Thursday, Nov. 26 -- The United States failed early this morning in an attempt to send a 372-pound payload to the moon powered for the first time by an Atlas intercontinental ballistic missile.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 25 (UPI) -- The Civil Aeronautics Board was urged today by one of its examiners to veto a stock exchange between Pan American World Airways and National Air Lines as contrary to the public interest.

Directors of the Curtiss-Wright Corporation yesterday reduced the quarterly dividend on its common stock by 25 cents with a declaration of 37 1/2 cents, payable on Dec. 4. In previous quarters shareholders received 62 1/2 cents a share.

OPERETTA, like fairy tales, will always have its enchanted public. Since the classics in the genre get scant attention these days, the Metropolitan Opera invites them into its august quarters. The latest guest of this kind, Strauss' "The Gypsy Baron," arrived last night.
NEW DELHI, India, Nov. 17 -- Nearly 10,000 workers are busy here on a 120-acre international effort to glorify scientific farming.

Stocks moved irregularly upward yesterday in active trading. The key averages have now risen for seven straight sessions. Wall Street analysts were encouraged by the minor run-up. They felt the market did quite well for the day before a holiday.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 25 (AP) -- Political strategists tried today to figure out what bearing a long-secret memorandum by Robert A. Taft might have on the 1960 political contests.
Increased sales and earnings were reported for the quarter and nine months ended on Sept. 30 by the Royal Dutch-Shell group of companies in the report issued yesterday.
ON the surface, today's hurried way of life may not appear conducive to building traditions. Some cynics declare contemporary families have no traditions, no roots.
Police Commissioner Stephen P. Kennedy denounced dishonest policemen yesterday and called upon his high-ranking officers to root out graft and corruption.
Stronger cash markets and continued reports of rain damage to the early winter potato crop in Florida buoyed potato futures prices on the New York Mercantile Exchange yesterday.
BURBANK, Calif., Nov. 25 -The Hollywood touch, not to mention Disneyland's fey wand, will convert Squaw Valley into a spectacular California setting for the 1960 Winter Olympic Games.

An agreement was reached yesterday by the Pennsylvania Railroad and two unions of maintenance-of-equipment employes to submit issues in dispute to impartial review. The unions had threatened to call out their 25,000 members at midnight Dec. 20.

GAP, France, Nov. 25 -- In the last nine days the waters of the Durance and Ubaye Rivers have formed a greenish blue lake that a year from now will be a rival in expanse and scenic beauty to the Lake of Annecy in the department of Haute-Savoie not far from Geneva.

HOUSTON, Tex., Nov. 25 (AP) -- Stockholders in the Humble Oil and Refining Company approved today plans for reorganization. Under the plan a new Humble concern will become the operating affiliate for all domestic producing, refining and marketing activities of the Standard Oil Company (New Jersey).
HAVANA, Nov. 25 -- The Cuban Cabinet approved early today an offering of savings bonds to the public.
Scientists at Columbia University have taught thumbs to twitch so subtly that their owners were unaware that they had twitched or that they had learned anything.

CARACAS, Venezuela, Nov. 25 -- The economic situation of Venezuela is "fundamentally prosperous" and its future "brilliant" but the country is necessarily going through "a process of adjustment," Dr. Jose Antonio Mayobre, Minister of Finance, said in a televised speech here last night.

Indian Head Mills, Inc., plans to acquire all of the assets of the 109-year-old Bates Manufacturing Company. This was learned yesterday from a reliable source. The transaction would involve more than $25,000,000.

ST. JOHN, N. B., Nov. 25 (AP) -- Shipping officials expressed concern today over an announcement from Boston that the Massachusetts Port Authority would meet Canadian shippers in Montreal Dec. 3 in an attempt to attract millions of dollars worth of business to Boston.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., Nov. 25 -- Amid mounting enthusiasm and excitement over the approach of Saturday's game with Army in the Philadelphia Stadium, the Navy football team went through its last workout in pads today.
The smashing of twin hold-up gangs operating in Manhattan and Brooklyn was announced yesterday by District Attorney Frank S. Hogan.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 25 -- The United States Consumer Price Index rose to another record in mid-October, the sixth in seven months.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 25 -- That big rangy man from Texas, Senator Lyndon B. Johnson, is heading north this week-end, and whenever Lyndon moves anywhere, Washington pays attention.

The current investigation of alleged pay-offs to motor vehicle examiners by applicants for drivers' licenses has unearthed scandals believed to be "much worse" than those in a similar case in 1957, it was learned yesterday.

Lewis Meyer, author of "Preposterous Papa" (World), was singularly honored last month in Sapulpa, Okla. The town celebrated the publication of the book about his father with a parade. On one of the floats, made in the shape of a house Papa built in Sapulpa, sat Papa flanked by two ping-pong queens.

A jazz concert celebrating the fiftieth anniversary of the Amsterdam News Welfare Fund and intended to benefit the Roy Campanella Foundation enticed a slim audience to Carnegie Hall last night. The performers were Dinah Washington, singer; the Billy Taylor Trio and Count Basie's band.
Formation of the International Maritime Workers Union to represent 70,000 seamen sailing on ships flying the flags of Panama, Liberia and Honduras was announced yesterday.

CIUDAD TRUJILLO, Dominican Republic, Nov. 25 (AP) -- A Dominican court sentenced Premier Fidel Castro of Cuba today to thirty years at hard labor because of an attempted invasion of this country last June.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 25 (UPI) -- The Government reported tonight that more than 2,000 packages of contaminated fresh cranberries were sold this week in grocery stores at Kansas City, Mo.
MOSCOW, Nov. 25 -- After four years of determined but quiet effort to bring simplicity and modernity to construction here, the Soviet architect has spoken up.

County Judge Samuel S. Leibowitz of Brooklyn has received editorial praise from Harper's magazine for his recent stand that New York City should discourage newcomers until housing and other facilities are adequate.

WARMTH seems to emanate from a package of California fruits received in the chill of New York's winter; the excitement of New Orleans clings to a parcel of Creole specialties, and nature herself seems to arrive with a gift of rainbow trout straight from Colorado's mountain streams.
Mrs. Aristotle Onassis filed suit here yesterday for a divorce from her husband, the wealthy Greek shipowner, who has been a frequent companion of Maria Callas, the opera singer.
MOSCOW, Nov. 25 -- Soviet circus clowns convened in solemn conference today to see what they could do about being funnier.

An Associated Press story datelined Atlanta, Nov. 6, and appearing in the Nov. 7 issue of The New York Times, reported that Negro nurses had not been admitted to sessions of the Georgia State Nurses' Association annual meeting. The story noted that Negro nurses had requested permission to attend two sessions, including one at which Miss Mathilda Scheuer, R. N., president of the American Nurses' Association, was to speak.
A national air college to train airline pilots from scratch is being set up by the British Government. It will offer two years of basic flight training to young men between 18 and 23 years of age.
WESTBURY, L. I., Nov. 25 -Maximilian, driven by Scotty Welch, scored a neck victory over Mighty Signal in the feature at Roosevelt Raceway tonight before 20,230 fans.

NEW HAVEN, Nov. 25 -- Selected works by Thomas Paine are on view in the Yale University Library. The exhibit commemorates the death 150 years ago of the author of "The Age of Reason" and "Rights of Man."

One can have no quarrel with Dean Acheson's proposal for a rigid control of those nuclear weapons with the "dreadful capacity to reach across continents and across oceans in a matter of fifteen minutes to destroy vast areas * * * crushing out all life." In fact, every knowledgeable and sane person knows that such control is a categorical necessity if modern civilization is to survive.
TRENTON, Nov. 25 -- Gov. Robert B. Meyner may formally enter the race for the Democratic Presidential nomination.
UNITED NATIONS, Nov. 25 -- The General Assembly decided today to postpone for another year consideration of amendments to the United Nations Charter.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 25 -- The Roman Catholic Bishops of the United States announced their opposition today to the use of public funds to promote artificial birth control at home or abroad.
The eight-story Broadway Central Hotel at 663 to 667 Broadway and 234-44 Mercer Street has been sold by the 673 Broadway Corporation, Harry Weinstein, president.

The eighty-day Taft-Hartley injunction that stayed the pier strike will run out Dec. 27 and, if no agreement has been reached, the docks will be tied up again -- with another threat to the national health and safety. But the course of the dockside negotiations shows signs of progress and has significance for the labormanagement relations of every industry during these difficult days when machines are rapidly replacing jobs.
ONE of the controversial questions in bridge came up in a New York club in the play of the deal shown, but there was much else worthy of mention.
The Los Angeles Dodgers are baseball's new box office champions.

The city editor of The WorldTelegram and The Sun said yesterday that three years ago one of the reporters involved in an alleged bribe offer had told him that pressures were being put on him "in the form of job offers and favors proffered by one or more press agents who were close to Tammany Hall."
Directors of the Philco Corporation resumed the payment of cash dividends with the declaration yesterday of 25 cents, payable to common stockholders on Dec. 18.

GUANTANAMO BAY NAVAL BASE, Cuba, Nov. 25 -- Political tensions have shut in this United States Navy community behind a tall wire fence. But the human and economic ties between the base and the surrounding region remain almost intact.
LONDON, Nov. 25 -- The British Government was reported today to be planning to send an advisory commission to Central Africa even if the Labor party continues to boycott the commission.

HASSI MESSAOUD, Algeria, Nov. 18 -- This sprawling desert camp of trailers, "prefabs," derricks, storage tanks and flaming gas torches is approaching its greatest day without breaking its feverish stride.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 25 (AP) -- Government action was sought today to settle a dispute over the hiring of Negroes for construction on the Capitol and other Government buildings.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 25 -Livingston Tallmadge Merchant, Deputy Under Secretary of State, has celebrated birthdays in Germany and China, in France and Canada, and in other spots around the world.
NEW DELHI, India, Nov, 25 -- Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru made an impassioned appeal today for national unity in facing the "grave problems" of India's dispute with Communist China.
CHICAGO, Nov. 25 (UPI) -- The American Football Coaches Association selected today their 1959 all-America team, chosen by coaches at more than one hundred and fifty colleges.
LONDON, Nov. 25 -- Sarah Maden, mother of T. E. Lawrence -- Lawrence of Arabia -- died in Oxford Nov. 16 at the age of 93.

Consumers Power Company reported yesterday that its sales of electricity rose 21 per cent in October to 757,745,000 kilowatt hours. Natural gas sales increased 18 per cent to 754,000,000 cubic feet. The gains were traced to the improvement of industrial conditions in the company's service area.
MIAMI, Fla., Nov. 25 (AP) -- Negroes swam today at an oceanfront playground in an apparent effort to back up earlier demands for an immediate end to segregated parks and beaches.
A sharp split in the television industry over how to chart the medium's immediate future course became known last night.
CHICAGO, Nov. 25 (AP) -- The market in grain futures raced well ahead, then back and finally finished the day about where it had started.

UTICA, N. Y., Nov. 25 (AP) -- The President of Oneida, Ltd., says a high-ranking Department of State official told him that, if he could not compete with foreign trade, he should go into another business or become a sales agent for the Japanese.

The consumer price index of the Bureau of Labor Statistics rose an additional three-tenths of one point from the September level of 125.2 to 125.5. This is the sixth rise recorded by the index (which takes the 1947-49 price average as 100) in the past seven months.
The Commission on New York City Governmental Operations has announced the roster of witnesses, headed by Mayor Wagner, who will be heard at public conferences scheduled to start Dec. 7.

RUTHERFORD, N. J., Nov. 25 -- "If they get in close, they'll play volleyball with us," said Coach Dick Holub today in summing up Fairleigh Dickinson University's outlook for the 1959-60 basketball season.
With ideal weather in prospect, Aqueduct expects a banner crowd today for its final holiday stakes, the twelfth running of the $27,550 Firenze, a mile-and-an-eighth handicap for fillies and mares.

NEWARK, Nov. 25 -- The question of the relative position of the State Attorney General and the County Prosecutor as law enforcement agents dominated a contempt proceeding today against Guy W. Calissi, Bergen County's Prosecutor.
Paul Choquette of Brown, Jake Crouthamel of Dartmouth, Fred Doelling of Penn and Yale's Tom Singleton were selected yesterday for the back-field positions on the all-Ivy League football team.
LONDON, Nov. 25 -- Prices declined in virtually every section of the stock market here today.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 25 -- The United States is promoting an interim move designed to reach a permanent settlement of the Palestine refugee problem, a United States delegation source indicated today.
" SECURITY RISK," last night's drama on the "Armstrong Circle Theatre" over Channel 2, told the story of an innocent man suspected of disloyalty.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 25 -- South Korea suggested today that the Soviet Union prove its willingness to relax world tensions by agreeing to free elections in North Korea and unification of the long-divided country.

PITTSBURGH, Nov. 25 (UPI) -- The Westinghouse Electric Corporation announced today it had teamed up with the Koppers Company and the Blaw-Knox Company to supply $144,000,000 worth of equipment and engineering services for the proposed construction of the first flat-rolled steel mill in Turkey.
BIRDS, man should be comforted to learn, have their housing problems too.
Two-story houses built in rows with red-brick exteriors, and each house with a back yard, are included in a $10,000,000 project announced by the City Housing Authority yesterday.

The New York, New Haven and Hartford Railroad suffered a net railway operating deficit of $6,658,996 in the first ten months of this year and reported an income deficit, before fixed charges, of $531,197. Fixed charges for the period were $5,573,219.
BONN, Germany, Nov. 25 -- Defense Minister Franz Josef Strauss has laid down a new set of principles to govern West Germany's $1,000,000,000-a-year spending program for arms and military equipment.
A youth accused of driving a stolen automobile was shot and killed yesterday by a policeman during a chase in Ozone Park, Queens. Another youth who was in the car was arrested.

Open hearings will begin Monday on charges that Magistrate Anthony E. Maglio had engaged in "conduct unbecoming a member of the judiciary" in his handling of a case involving two youths accused of attacking a policeman.

BLAIRSTOWN, N. J., Nov. 25 -- A department store owner here was fatally beaten today. Two hours later a state trooper and a suspect in the slaying wounded each other in a pistol duel in near-by Johnsonburg.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Nov. 25 -- Leo the Lion, the triumphant, roaring symbol of Metro-GoldwynMayer, has been silenced for "Ben-Hur," the most expensive movie ever made by Metro.

MAN RAY: He likes verbal puns and conceits, and has spread them through his photographs and paintings and drawings for close to fifty years. In an exhibition of his drawings and water-colors at the Gallery Mayer, 762 Madison Avenue at Sixty-sixth Street, the erstwhile dadaist and one of the founding fathers of surrealism shows the flexibility of his fancy, taking us wherever it took him from 1912 to the present.

The sensational disclosure just before Thanksgiving Day that part of the nation's cranberry crop had been tainted by a possibly cancerproducing weed-killer may have wreaked havoc on some innocent growers; but it has unquestionably served a useful public purpose.
The Government yesterday dropped its seven-year-old perjury case against Earl Browder, former head of the Communist party in the United States.

WALKERVILLE, Ont., Nov. 25 (Canadian Press) -- Hiram Walker-Gooderham and Worts, Ltd., cleared $23,694,387, or $2.76 a share, in the year ended on Aug. 31, compared with $21,845,494, or $2.54 a share, in the preceding year.

NAN MERRIMAN has been active in this country and abroad for many years, and she has sung in New York in the past with Toscanini and many orchestras. But apparantly the mezzo-soprano never took time to give a New York recital.

The visit of Deputy Under Secretary of State Livingston Merchant to Panama appears to have been successful. It deserved to be. It was a friendly mission whose objective was to try to satisfy any legitimate complaints that Panama had while defending equally legitimate American interests.

The year-long boom in large household appliances -- halted slightly by the steel strike -- is on in full force again. At least one important maker of refrigerators, washing machines, cooking ranges and similar equipment is experiencing difficulty filling orders.
CHICAGO, Nov. 25 (AP) -- The report of today's livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:
WASHINGTON, Nov. 25 -- The head of a Congressional survey team reported today that the Soviet bloc was doing "a very fabulous propaganda job" in Southeast Asia and the Middle East.
Not only is Thanksgiving the most American of all our national holidays and days of special observance, it is the only holiday ever subjected to the peculiarly American situation of a "local option.

A star of Shirley Booth's popularity is not permitted to remain idle long. On Nov. 12 she relinquished her role in the imminent "A Loss of Roses," and it was taken over by Betty Field. Yesterday it became known that Miss Booth was definite for "The Other One," to be introduced by Leonard Sillman.
DUBLIN, Nov. 25 -- An independent member of the Dail Eirann (Parliament) questioned today the right of David Patrick Hearne to claim diplomatic immunity.
Secretary Herter has given the Administration's foreign policy a new definition which may be summed up in the words "survival without surrender."

WASHINGTON, Nov. 25 -- The United States Chamber of Commerce questioned today the Government's new policy on foreign aid. The policy requires that aid funds for development projects be used primarily to buy American-made goods.

The World Zionist Organization is revising its constitution to permit non-Zionist Jewish groups to affiliate with it. This departure from the practice of sixty-two years is designed to strengthen cultural and spiritual activity among Jews.

IF you have ever shaped up before the Paramount Theatre at dawn to worship the high priests of popular music during the last twenty-five years, it's quite probable that they played your song on Channel 7's "Golden Circle" show last night.

The Pennsylvania State Public School Building Authority will sell its bond issues in the public market in the future, rather than directly to state pension funds managed for school teachers and other state employes.
BEIRUT, Lebanon, Nov. 25 (AP) -- George A. Kasem, a United States Congressman of Lebanese origin, defended Washington today against charges of favoritism for Israel.

CHICAGO, Nov. 25 -- Sir Julian Huxley told the Darwin centennial celebration today that if Charles Darwin were still alive he would be "excited and bewildered" by developments in the study of evolution since he published his "Origin of Species" 100 years ago.

ROME, Nov. 25 (UPI) -Pope John XXIII celebrated his seventy-eighth birthday today. At a spirited general audience he jokingly told 6,000 persons that so many years were dangerous but he hoped to see more.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 25 (AP) -- A merger of the Erie and Lackawanna Railroads into the nation's twelfth largest rail system would raise serious anti-trust questions, the Interstate Commerce Commission was told today.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 25 (AP) -- Officials of the Department of State said today there was no knowledge here of any high-ranking official ever advising the president of Oneida, Ltd., to become a sales agent for the Japanese if he could not compete with foreign trade.

Mayor Wagner stepped up the city's campaign against chiseling by meat and poultry stores yesterday. Fifty teams of three men each were sent out to check on prices and weights, an increase of twenty teams over the day before.

CHICAGO, Nov. 25 -- Preliminary examination of the wreckage of the heavy cargo plane that crashed into a residential community here yesterday disclosed today that one of the four engines had stopped. However, the three others were developing higher horsepower at the time of the crash.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 25 -- The General Assembly voted today to hold a full-fledged discussion on the question of Hungary.
The Plaza's Grand Ballroom with its stately Edwardian decor was animated last night by the swirl of bouffant ball gowns as the first of the Thanksgiving Week debutante parties got under way.
The Board of Estimate ignored yesterday a threat by Controller Lawrence E. Gerosa to cast his four votes against a 1960 capital budget that allocated less than $100,000,000 for school construction.
NECKARSULM, Germany, Nov. 25 (UPI) -- Germany's giant NSU Motor Works will start production of its new internal combustion engine in several months, a spokesman said today.

WEST POINT, N. Y., Nov. 25 -- Army's football team went outdoors under bright blue skies again after a day of rainy confinement to the Field House. The cadets took a last, long hard look today at the things Navy is expected to do on offense and defense in the sixtieth game between the service academies on Saturday.

THE main idea in Henrik Ibsen's infrequently done play, "John Gabriel Borkman," which was revived last night at the Sullivan Street Playhouse in Greenwich Village, is that the worst kind of infamy a human being can perpetrate on another is the denial of love.
The increase in juvenile delinquency has been cited by a psychotherapist who has worked with delinquents as a "symptom of a major deficiency in our educational system."
The Treasury's new $2,000,000,000 issue of discount bills was accorded a good reception yesterday in the first full day of market trading in the new issue.

Cultural-exchange programs "have proved to be an astonishingly potent force in the promotion of international good-will," Frances Fuller, president of the American Academy of Dramatic Arts, said yesterday.
PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 25 (UPI) -- The Baltimore Colts maintained their leadership in total yardage for the second week in a row in the National Football League, official statistics showed today.
Alan Freed, the disk jockey recently dismissed by two broadcasting stations here, was served yesterday with a grand jury subpoena by detectives from the office of District Attorney Frank S. Hogan.
Arthur Godfrey will leave for the island of Jamaica this weekend to tape an hour-long television show.

LANSING, Mich., Nov. 25 (UPI) -- The Michigan Supreme Court said today that power brakes on 1953 Buicks were defective and that the General Motors Corporation had failed to warn Buick owners that they were driving a "dangerous instrument."
Oil production and refining in the nation increased last week as fuel oil stocks continued their seasonal decline.
NEW ORLEANS, Nov. 25 ((AP) -- The United States Fifth Circuit Court of Appeals has overruled the use of Florida's pupil assignment law as a means of postponing integration of public schools.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 25 -- The civil complaint which the Department of Justice has filed in Federal court against units in the steel industry enumerates charges of practices which, if proved, are plain violations of the antitrust acts as a conspiracy in restraint of trade.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 25 -- New trouble arose between the United States and the Philippines today over a report by a member of Congress here to the effect that the Philippine Government was "graft ridden" and was harassing United States forces in the islands. A Congressional investigation was promised as a result of the report.

THIS has been a strange and unhappy football season for both Army and Navy. The service teams will rendezvous in the Philadelphia Stadium on Saturday, a date that is now grimly regarded at West Point and Annapolis as Redemption Day. Each has much to redeem, unexpectedly so.
The New York Board of Rabbis announced yesterday that it would establish a Jewish museum at its International Synagogue, for which ground has been broken at the New York International Airport.
Americans will attend church services and sit down to Thanksgiving feasts today at home and over the world, including the bottom of it.
The State of New Jersey yesterday designated Dec. 16 as the date of sale for the issue of $66,800,000 of higher education bonds that the state's voters had authorized.

PANAMA, Nov. 25 -- President Ernesto de la Guardia Jr., has given assurances that his Government is determined to prevent further anti-United States violence Saturday, the anniversary of Panama's independence from Spain.
NEW HAVEN, Conn., Nov. 26 -- Yale researchers believe they have found an answer to the nation-wide teacher shortage -send young mothers back to the classroom as teachers.

MOST editors of newspapers were outstandingly able reporters before they were promoted to private offices and managerial responsibilities. But for reasons unknown (at least to me) most editors of book publishing houses and of magazines are editors only, although they may be thwarted writers. The exceptions, however, have been notable.
COLOMBO, Ceylon, Nov. 26 -- Seven persons were formally accused today in the murder of Prime Minister S. W. R. D. Bandaranaike Sept. 25.
COCOA BEACH, Fla., Nov. 26 -- Experts strove today to learn why the United States' most ambitious moon probe so far had failed early this morning.
The schism between religion and psychiatry has been being bridged in recent years by a broadening of outlook on both sides, a recent symposium on the subject has found.
MAJ. ERNESTO (CHE) GUEVARA, who has just been named president of the National Bank of Cuba, is the enigma of the Castro regime.
Large high-school classes tend to produce specialists in the physical sciences, while small schools produce biological scientists, a nation-wide study suggests.

In a tradition 338 years old, Americans gave thanks yesterday for peace and bounty in the land. Thanksgiving Day, the nation's great family festival, was observed across the country in a manner now rich with custom.

The basic responsibility for what appears on TV networks lies just where Dr. Frank Stanton, president of the Columbia Broadcasting System, says it lies: on the TV networks. And in an exchange of views with the president of the other TV giant, the National Broadcasting Company, Dr. Stanton explicitly -- and refreshingly -- states that "we accept that responsibility."
NORFOLK, Va., Nov. 26 (AP) -- Four disk jockeys suspended after they played a single record 320 times in one day have been reinstated.

Ronald Kulik, a 22-year-old senior from Montclair (N. J.) State Teachers College, won the forty-ninth annual City Hall to Coney Island handicap race sponsored by the Walkers Club of America yesterday. His comment after finishing the grind, which measures just short of eleven miles: "I've got blisters all over my feet."
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 26 -- Dr. Conor Cruise O'Brien of Ireland suggested today that an experimental group of 100 Palestine refugees be permitted to return to their homes.
An enterprising Bostonian has started a one-man campaign to restore what he terms the "true meaning of tips" in restaurants and other public places.

CAIRO, Nov. 26 (Reuters) -- President Gamal Abdel Nasser made his strongest personal attack yet on Premier Abdul Karim Kassim of Iraq tonight, but still urged General Kassim to cooperate with him against Israel.
BERNARDSTON, Mass., Nov. 26 -- This was the kind of day when the experience of the adult was to no avail and the blundering luck of the child brought home the venison.
SENDING and receiving Christmas cards is one of the pleasantest parts of the holiday season. Inevitably, it brings with it certain questions of protocol.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., Nov. 26 -- Navy ran through its final practice today in preparation for the Army gain. Coach Wayne Hardin said, "if we put 60 minutes of good football together, I feel that we can pull an upset." Army is a 6-point favorite.
The Zim Israel Navigation Company of Haifa has ordered a 10,000-gross-ton passenger liner for its Mediterranean service.
CHICAGO, Nov. 26 -- Sir Julian Huxley told the Darwin Centennial Celebration today that the world needed a new ideology centered on evolution.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 26 -- Three of the prevailing traits of the late Senator Taft were emphasized in his analysis of why Dwight D. Eisenhower defeated him for the Republican nomination for President at the party convention of 1952. These traits were generosity, personal loyalty and stubbornness.

Lyman Bryson was one of the best teachers of a generation which, with the rapid spread of significant knowledge, had an almost desperate need for teachers. At Columbia University, on radio and television and elsewhere he exemplified his belief that "most really great ideas can be grasped by anyone who pays attention to what is said about them."
DURHAM, N. C., Nov. 26 (UPI) -- North Carolina's Tar Heels reached the football heights expected of them this season in their final game today, crushing their arch-rival, Duke, by a 50-0 score.
LOS ANGELES, Nov. 26 -- Paul Ziffren, Democratic National Committeeman from California, urged today a revision of Federal income tax laws to aid writers and "creative people generally."
MIAMI, Nov. 26 (AP) -- Peeping Tom and Roman Colonel won the two divisions of the Hurricane Handicap today as Tropical Park opened Florida's long racing season before 19,075 fans.
A tea dance was given at the Colony Club yesterday afternoon by Mrs. June Blossom of 1175 Park Avenue and Southampton, L. I., to honor her daughter, Miss Valerie Blacque-Bey.

TOKYO, Nov. 26 (AP) -- The United States high command estimates that the Soviet Union and Communist China have more than 120 submarines in their Pacific fleets. The command believes it possible that missile-firing underwater craft may join the Soviet force before long.
HONOLULU, Nov. 26 (AP) -Hawaii, celebrating its admission as the fiftieth state of the Union, today remembered the war dead who helped make statehood possible.
BUENOS AIRES, Nov. 26 -- Argentina and Brazil broadened their trade treaties today to promote the exchange of goods from their growing industries.

In 1912 when the Ch'ing (Manchu) Dynasty was overthrown in China, Mao Tse-tung and Siao-yu were students in the same school in the city of Changsha in Hunan. They became close friends and were founders of the Hsin Min Study Association, which later served as the embryo organization for the Chinese Communist party.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 26 (UPI) -- The National Education Association said today America would get better schools when it provided better "working conditions" for teachers.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 26 (AP) -- The American Council on Education formally reaffirmed today its opposition to the loyalty affidavit required from students who receive loans or fellowships under the National Defense Education Act.
LONDON, Nov. 26 -- The British Labor party faces a choice this week-end between old-time socialism based on nationalization and a new policy molded to meet contemporary conditions.
EL PASO, Tex., Nov. 26 (AP) -- Max Conrad ended a 6,911-mile nonstop flight from Casablanca, Morocco, to El Paso today, rested four hours and then took off for Los Angeles.
Many of them yawning and sleepy-eyed and obviously out of their time element, 31,082 horse players attended the program at Aqueduct yesterday.
LONDON, Nov. 26 -- The Government announced today an inquiry into the laws governing British companies.

PROVIDENCE, Nov. 26 -- Alva Kelley, who had coached Brown elevens to victory in the three previous Turkey Day games with Colgate, sat on the opposite bench this morning as the Bruins tangled with the Red Raiders in the forty-first meeting between the schools.
If a wife works in her husband's business, can she legally claim title to real estate bought by the husband with profits of the business?
WASHINGTON, Nov. 26 -- American space officials believe that the Soviet Union has an active man-in-space program despite the denials by prominent Soviet space scientists.
Federated Department Stores, Inc., reported yesterday for the three, nine and twelve months ended Oct. 31 higher sales and earnings than a year earlier.

HUNTSVILLE, Ala., Nov. 26 (AP) -- The Army took the blame today for Dr. Wernher von Braun's failure to appear on a television show earlier this month. But it said the current shift in missile operations had nothing to do with the decision.

A report by the American Jewish Congress showed yesterday that sixteen states have established specialized agencies to enforce laws prohibiting discrimination. Two other states have created anti-discrimination agencies without enforcement powers.

PARIS, Nov. 26 -- During his visit here next month, President Eisenhower is likely to encounter close questioning on the role of the United States in French African areas.
COLLEGE STATION, Tex., Nov. 26 (UPI) -- Texas blasted its way into the Cotton Bowl and a tie for the Southwest Conference football championship today with a 20-17 uphill victory over Texas A. and M.

A comparative study of maternity cases cared for under the Health Insurance Plan of Greater New York has shown a lower infant mortality rate than among private patients generally, the organization reported yesterday.

Miss Lucile Hamlin was honored at a dinner dance given last night in the Starlight Roof of the Waldorf-Astoria by her stepfather and mother, Mr. and Mrs. Morton M. Palmer of New York and Buffalo.
LONDON, Nov. 26 -- Industrial share prices moved aimlessly in the stock market here today.
HONOLULU, Nov. 26 (UPI) -- The police warned drivers today when gusts of up to 100 miles an hour roared through the Pali Gap and tumbled two light vehicles.
PRINCETON, N. J., Nov. 26 -- Salary increases of $500 to $1,000 a year for the Princeton University faculty were announced today.

Philip D. Reed, chairman of the board of the General Electric Company from 1939 through 1958, will sever his connections with the company on Monday. He will retire as a director, chairman of the finance committee and consultant to his successor as chairman, Ralph J. Cordiner.
Forty-eight families in a Bronx apartment house had to cancel or shift their Thanksgiving plans yesterday when a leaky pipe cut off water to the building.
Boys Towns of Italy will benefit from a theatre party next Thursday at the motion picture "Ben-Hur" at Loew's State and at a midnight supper dance In the Versailles Suite of the Astor.
DALLAS, Tex., Nov. 26 (AP) -- A Navy wife who cares for eleven children and still finds time to win awards for service relief work was announced here today as "servicewoman of the year."
RIO DE JANEIRO, Nov. 26 -- Tanio Quadros, Opposition candidate for the Presidency, threw Brazil's early starting campaign into confusion today by announcing his withdrawal from the race.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Nov. 26 -- In Hollywood, where children rarely leave the house after dinner, the annual exception occurred last night, allowing them to be out on the streets after 10 o'clock.

LEOPOLDVILLE, Belgian Congo, Nov. 26 (Reuters) -- Belgium went part of the way today to meeting demands of African nationalist leaders in the Congo for an immediate round-table conference in Brussels to discuss the colony's future.
The Northern Pacific Railway reported yesterday a ten-month income of $19,461,870, or $1,119,364 above the 1958 level. Earnings were equal to $3.25 a share and compared with $3.05 in 1958.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 26 -- A Senate panel studying the problems of 15,000,000 aged and aging Americans will move next week to Florida, where more than one person in ten is 65 years of age or older.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 26 (AP) -- The Census Bureau estimates that the nation's population will pass 179,000,000 sometime during the pre-dawn hours tomorrow.
The owner of an East Side office building, mindful of the desire of many business men for homelike decor in their offices, has treated the building's lobby in a similar manner.

The North Country Shopping Center, a thirty-four-acre retail mart on Route 9 north of Plattsburgh, N. Y., will open today. The $3,500,000 center is the largest concentration of retail stores between Montreal and Albany.
The establishment of the Atlantic Cargo Inspection Bureau as an independent corporation with wider tasks has been announced here by Alexander P. Chopin, chairman of the New York Shipping Association.

LONDON, Nov. 26 -- Ernest Marples, Britain's Minister of Transport, offered an emergency plan in the House of Commons today by which he hopes to deal with the expected crush of Christmas traffic in London's West End.
CHICAGO, Nov. 26 (AP) -- The International Harvester Company has announced tentative plans to acquire the Solar Aircraft Company, San Diego, Calif., through an exchange of stock.
LONDON, Nov. 26 (AP) -- The Moscow radio announced today a shake-up in the Supreme Soviet, or parliament, of the Russian Republic, largest in the Soviet Union.

The nation's 518 mutual savings banks experienced a decline in deposits of $187,000,000 to $34,700,000,000 in October, according to the National Association of Mutual Savings Banks. The drop, the largest since the association began compiling deposit statistics in mid-1947, was laid to competition from the Treasury's offering of 5 per cent notes, maturing in 1964.

NEWARK, Nov. 26 -- If New Jersey's Anti - Discrimination Law in housing is upheld by the State Supreme Court, Levitt Sons, Inc., the builder of Levittown, N. J., will sell houses to two Negroes who charged they had been barred.
Scheduled airlines on the North Atlantic passed the million-passenger mark in the first nine months of 1959 -- the first time the million mark has ever been reached that early in the year.
A DRAMA based on an Australian murder trial provided a suspenseful telecast on "Playhouse 90" over Channel 2 last night.
LONDON, Nov. 26 -- Admiral of the Fleet Earl Mountbatten, chief of the defense staff, speaking tonight at a Thanksgiving Day dinner of the American Society in London, praised President Eisenhower.
TORONTO, Nov. 26 -- Composers from thirty countries will attend the first International Composers Conference sponsored by the Stratford Shakespeare Festival and the Canadian League of. Composers.

The Department of Commerce has begun a survey of the financing of residential properties. Data are being sought from the owners of nearly 6,000 apartment buildings and developments in the New York-New Jersey metropolitan area.
Two youths terrorized a Queens home yesterday by whipping a man with a dog chain and attempting to rape his sister.
The body of Povl Bang-Jensen, who had been dismissed by the United Nations after shielding the identities of Hungarian refugees, was found yesterday in Alley Park, Queens.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 26 -- The late Senator Robert A. Taft's self-analysis of his 1952 defeat for the Republican Presidential nomination stirred a lot of political talk, but little agreement, this week.

HAVANA, Nov. 26 -- Thousands of Roman Catholics poured into Havana by bus, train and plane today in preparation for the Catholic Congress to be held in Havana Saturday in honor of the Virgin of Charity, patron saint of Cuba.

BOSTON, Nov. 26 (UPI) -- The Boston Bruins held off a last-period rally by New York tonight and won, 4 -- 3, extending the Ranger streak to six National Hockey League games without a victory. The Bruins had gone seven games without a triumph.
MEXICO CITY, Nov. 26 (AP) -- The world's movie spotlight centered on Mexico last night with the opening of a film festival in which only winners of other film festivals are entered.

A DIVIDEND for the faithful is in store for those doing the downtown junket this week: free movies. Composed by Carmen D'Avino, the films are shown daily at 2 and 4 P. M. at the Art Fair Gallery, 123 Second Avenue, near Seventh Street, together with Mr. D'Avino's oil paintings.
ALBANY, Nov. 26 -- Mayor Wagner's plan to legalize off-track betting on horse races in New York City is dead.

For the last decade the annual Gotham Ball has served to introduce young women of prominent Roman Catholic families to society. So, it was not surprising that among the thirty-two young women presented last evening at the event in the Plaza nine had been preceded in other years by one or more of their sisters.
LOUISVILLE, Nov. 26 (AP) -- The University of Houston won the Amateur Athletic Union's national cross-country championship today.
For one man from Cunningham Walsh, Inc., the question of whether advertising men should participate in politics is academic. He is the mayor-elect of Harrington Park, N. J.

New Dorp, recent winner of the Public Schools Athletic League football championship, was upset by its traditional foe Curtis, yesterday before an overflow crowd of 8,000 at Weissglass Stadium, Port Richmond, Staten Island. The score was 6 -- 0.

ROME, Nov. 26 -- A five-year Government plan for the revival of Italian agriculture, hard hit by the lowering of protective barriers between the European Common Market countries, has been adopted, Premier Antonio Segni announced today.
ON SULTRY July days, scouting antiques shops upstate and in New England, Mrs. Madelyn C. Hoey was thinking, not about the heat, but about Christmas.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 26 -- The Democratic Advisory Council will meet in New York Dec. 5, 6 and 7 in what it called today the "kick-off" for the 1960 Presidential election.
The first stage of construction of the fifty-nine-story Grand Central City skyscraper has begun below the surface of the railroad tracks that will run beneath the structure.
MOSCOW, Nov. 26 -- Soviet propagandists gave Secretary of State Christian A. Herter a mark of "poor" today on the subject of foreign policy.
NEW DELHI, India, Nov. 26 (Reuters) -- India's controller and auditor-general, Asok Chanda, denied today that India had withheld information from the United States on the use of American aid goods.
NEW DELHI, India, Nov. 26 -- Defense Minister V. K. Krishna Menon strongly defended himself today against charges that he had underestimated the dangers in Communist Chinese aggression.
New Yorkers offered thanks to God yesterday in prayer and worship at churches and synagogues.
DAMASCUS, United Arab Republic, Nov. 26 -- Syria has a central executive again after months of operating like a state without a governor.

SEOUL, Korea, Nov. 26 -- Dr. Chough Pyong Ok, 65-year-old former National Police administrator, was nominated by the Democratic party today to run against President Syngman Rhee in the South Korean election next spring. Dr. Rhee, who was 84 last March, will be seeking his fourth term.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 26 -- Communist and "uncommitted" nations told the General Assembly's Political Committee today that a settlement in Korea could not be brought about by repeated United Nations resolutions condemning the North Korean regime.

DETROIT, Nov. 26 (AP) -- The Green Bay Packers cashed in on early mistakes, then hung on today for a 24-17 triumph over the Detroit Lions in a National Football League game watched by 49,221 chilled spectators and a national television audience.

A good portion of the population of New York appeared yesterday to be about four feet tall. Or so it seemed in midtown, where hundreds of thousands of goggle-eyed, grinning and shrieking children, backed by their parents, lined the route of Macy's thirty-third Thanksgiving Day parade.

ACCRA, Ghana, Nov. 26 -- Ghana will not observe her third birthday until March. But on every side there are signs of a race to shake off her backward past and achieve a position of leadership among the emerging nations of Africa.

Increases in sales were reported by the Allied Stores Corporation and its subsidiaries in the quarter, nine and twelve months ended with October. Earnings improved in the latter two periods, but third-quarter income was slightly below that of a year ago.

The National Committee for Labor Israel reported yesterday that in the last five years it had raised $16,711,847 for Histadrut, Israel's labor federation. The money was used for medical and social-welfare projects.

Lehman Brothers and G. H. Walker Co. are offering today 60,000 shares of the common stock of Gulton Industries, Inc., Metuchen, N. J. The stock is priced at $20 a share.

HAVANA, Nov. 26 (UPI) -- A Government prosecutor demanded the death penalty today for one of two Americans accused of attempting to overthrow the Castro Government. He asked thirty years in prison for the other.
