It seems certain that Robert L. Joseph and Lester Osterman have outbid a number of rival producers to bring over "The Aspern Papers," said to be London's biggest dramatic hit at present. Audrey Wood, who represents Michael Redgrave (adapter of the play, co-star and co-producer), confirmed the report yesterday. However, contracts have not been signed yet.
LONDON, Nov. 26 -- The Government and the Labor party clashed in the House of Commons today on the Radcliffe Report on the British monetary system.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 26 -President Eisenhower believes that the risks of non-agreement on disarmament are "enormous" compared with the danger of evasion involved in any arms pact.

OTTAWA, Nov. 26 (AP) -- The St. Lawrence Seaway Authority faces the threat of a strike when it reopens the waterway next April. It is already under pressure from grain men to put off next Monday's scheduled closing.

BONN, Germany, Nov., 26 (AP) -- A recommendation that the Western Allies give up trying to force the German industrialist Alfried Krupp to break up his steel and coal empire is being prepared by an international commission, diplomatic sources said tonight.

Trans-Canada Air Lines and the British Overseas Airways Corporation announced yesterday that they had signed an agreement calling for schedule integration on flights between Canada and the United Kingdom and for other working arrangements designed to improve service.

Three of the season's debutantes, the Misses Linda Cheney Childs, Pamela Spence Richards and Jacgueline M. Clairmont, were honored at a dance given jointly by their parents last evening in the St. Regis Roof.
HEMPSTEAD, L. I., Nov. 26 -- Hofstra College's smartly drilled football team staged a second-half stampede that overwhelmed a rugged University of Scranton eleven by 35 -- 0 today.
NEW ROCHELLE, N. Y., Nov. 26 -- The New Rochelle Committee of the Adoption Service of Westchester will hold a dessert bridge and fashion show Dec. 4 at the New Rochelle Women's Club.
THERE is a new shop down on Thirty-fourth Street that should lure the woman with an eye for handsome decorative objects away from Third and Madison Avenues.
MONTREAL, Nov. 26 (Ca-principle subsidiary of Alumin-Company of Canada has sold about 5,000 tons of aluminum to Red China this year and hopes to make additional sales there, it was learned today.
Rex Harrison and Julie Andrews, who created the co-staring roles in "My Fair Lady" on the New York and London stage, soon will be reunited for a television program.
The United States men's basketball team cut down Yan Kruminsh, the 7-foot 3-inch woodcutter from Latvia, and his Russian cohorts at Madison Square Garden last night. But it wasn't easy.
The largest surviving manuscript of Washington Irving's work, an unpublished 40,000-word epic, has been put on display by Columbia University to mark the 100th anniversary of his death.
CARACAS, Venezuela, Nov. 26 -- Governor Rockefeller is preparing to offer New Jersey and Connecticut a package deal on the revision of New York State's income tax on nonresidents.

TANGIER, Morocco, Nov. 26 -- The International Sugar Conference was opened here this morning. It found itself hopelessly deadlocked immediately, and agreed to discuss only non-controversial questions until further instructions were received from the Governments of some members.
STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Nov. 26 -- The seven Swedish Communists in Parliament have it in their power to overthrow the Government in the next five days.

Rough weather on the Atlantic is slowing the progress of two inbound passenger liners. They are the Saturnia of the Italian Line, which will be twenty-four hours late, and the Exeter of American Export Lines, at least four days late.
WEST POINT, N. Y., Nov. 26 -- Army may be in for trouble Saturday against Navy in their big football game in Philadelphia, if past predictions are near correct.

Alex Miteff will be seeking to even the score with Billy Hunter when the heavyweights meet in the ten-round feature bout at Madison Square Garden tonight. The bout will be televised nationally by the National Broadcasting Company.

HAVANA, Nov. 26 -- Maj. Ernesto Guevara was appointed president of the National Bank of Cuba today. He also was recently named to head the industrial division of the Agrarian Reform Institute, which has charge of expropriating and distributing land and of forming cooperatives of various kinds.

Four silent pictures by Sergei M. Eisenstein, the late Russian film-maker, will be shown afternoons during the week beginning Sunday in the auditorium of the Museum of Modern Art. The program is as follows: 3:00 and f0nday at :30; 'otemkin" (1925), Tues.day, at 5:80; "Ten Days That Shook the Vrld" (1928), Wedneslay and %'hur.sday at 5:30;,-and "O1t and ew" (1929), Friday at 5:30 and Saturday at 3:00.
STORRS, Conn., Nov. 26 -- City College's dream of a National Collegiate soccer championship ended on the turf of the University of Connecticut's Memorial Stadium today.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 26 -- In a startling transformation, a futile, helpless Pennsylvania football team turned on Cornell when trailing by 13 -- 0 in the third quarter and won the Ivy League championship with a 28-13 victory today.
Someday the Charter of the United Nations will be amended to bring it into line with such changes as the growth of the organization from fifty-one members to eighty-two and eventually more.

It would be ironic if it were not tragic that India, which has so often criticized Western resistance to Communist aggression, is now forced to face the possibility of war with Communist China. But that is what Prime Minister Nehru has been compelled to consider in view of Communist aggression against Indian territory. "If war is thrust upon us," he said before the Indian Parliament, "we shall fight with all our strength."
ALBANY, Nov. 26 -- The Democratic leader of the Assembly predicted today that Governor Rockefeller would lose Republican support during the 1960 session of the Legislature.

SEVERAL years ago the Washington Redskins were about to play an exhibition game with the San Francisco Forty-Niners and the 'Skins were hurting grievously in the quarterback department. Eddie LeBaron had a torn cartilage in a knee, Al Dorrow had cracked up in an auto accident and Ralph Guglielmi was in the Army.
CAIRO, Nov. 26 -- United States Development Loan Fund financing for at least seven projects here and in Syria will be given "expeditious consideration" by both Governments.
Ragamuffins ran in penny-hunting bands throughout the city yesterday, as their parents and grandparents had done on bygone Thanksgivings, but at least 1,500 of them were otherwise engaged.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 26 -Filter-tip cigarettes have not proved effective in materially reducing the hazard of lung cancer in smokers, Dr. Leroy E. Burney, Surgeon General of the Public Health Service, said today.

Some parents Parents Deplore have come out Educational openly against an Confusions overabundance of theory and a famine of agreement among professional educators. They voice their protest in an article headed "Confusion Reigns" which appears in The School Parent for October, 1959, a publication sponsored by the United Parents Association representing a large and influential membership in New York City.

"I AM afraid of nothing any place, anywhere," commented Margit Pinter in a recent interview after her biannual trip to the Berber Casbahs in Morocco, where she bought magnificent handwoven fabrics and colorful, one-of-a-kind tribal rugs for the American home.

BLAIRSTOWN, N. J., Nov, 26 -- State Trooper Lester Pagano, 29 years old, underwent surgery today in Newton Memorial Hospital for the removal of a bullet in his spine. His condition was termed critical.
The Jewish Teachers Association asked yesterday that the public schools avoid religious ceremonies, symbols or hymns in any programs marking the forthcoming holidays.

The Cuban Revolution took another radical spurt yesterday with the latest Cabinet shake-up. Two of the most valuable, expert and moderate officers were pushed aside for young and inexperienced men who will be more disposed to drive determinedly ahead along the revolutionary path.

An Italian presentation of a new antibiotic recently at the Washington Symposium of Antibiotics marked another milestone in the remarkable development of the $200,000,000 drug industry in Italy and the research work being carried out by Italy's largest pharmaceutical manufacturer.

The Rev. Edward O. Miller, rector of St. George's Protestant Episcopal Church on Stuyvesant Square, yesterday described Macy's Thanksgiving Day parade as the "final triumph of commercialism over God."
MARSHALL, Tex., Nov. 26 (AP) -- Small fires still flickered in east Texas today after vast grass and forest blazes swept over parts of three states yesterday and destroyed almost forty residences.
RABAT, Morocco, Nov. 27 -- Crown Prince Moulay Hassan expressed the gratitude of King Mohamed V and the royal army today for the first gift of arms from the United States.
Eric Johnston sharply criticized Americans yesterday for "going soft" and lacking vision, thrust and drive for world leadership.

BUDAPEST, Hungary, Nov. 27 (AP) -- The Soviet Embassy announced today that Premier Khrushchev would attend the Hungarian Communist party's congress opening here Monday. He is expected to fly here Sunday.

MOSCOW, Nov. 27 -- The Soviet Communist party conceded today that its hopes for cooperation of Communists and Socialists throughout the world had been badly disappointed by failures in Western Europe and the Middle East.
Sharp advances were registered yesterday in hide futures on the Commodity Exchange. Prices rose 40 to 100 points (hundredths of a cent a pound) on 146 lots.

The United States Chamber of Commerce has taken its position, unofficially at least, with those who have questioned the Government's recently announced modification of its foreign aid policy, under which it would place increased emphasis, in its foreign lending, on "tied" loans -- that is, loans advanced subject to the provision that the proceeds of them be spent in the United States.
PARIS, Saturday, Nov. 28 -- A majority of the French National Assembly condemned the Government of Premier Michel Debre today but refrained from voting it out of office.

A large volume of new senior debt securities is scheduled to reach the public capital market next week. More than $200,000,000 of bond issues of corporations and gov ernmental bodies are slated for offering.

CHICAGO, Nov. 27 (AP) -- Light steady selling weakened the prices of grain futures today and the market closed with only one small plus sign in the entire list. Most of the losses, however, were small.
Government shipping experts and private industrial designers will meet in Washington on Tuesday to plan new land vehicles to carry atomic waste and atomic fuel to and from the nuclear ship Savannah.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 27 -- Muscles are being flexed at United Nations Headquarters these days in a system of exercise evolved in China nearly a thousand years ago.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 27 (UPI) -- A scientist at the Smithsonian Institution praised the mosquito today as "really an elegant insect."

SEOUL, Korea, Nov. 27 -- The Korean Democratic party, the principal opposition to President Syngman Rhee's Government, attempted today to heal its factional rifts. It acted under pressure from numerous convention speakers to "show the world that democracy can work smoothly" in this eleven-year-old republic.

We were pleased to read on Nov. 16 Petr Zenkl's letter replying to the opinions of Cyrus Eaton. As president of the Assembly of Captive European Nations Mr. Zenkl expressed the feelings of all peoples oppressed by the Soviet Union when he refuted Mr. Eaton's arguments in support of the seating of Poland in the Security Council.

Hopes of fluoridating the city's water supply in the near future were virtually killed yesterday when three more members of the Board of Estimate announced their opposition to the controversial proposal.

Holiday motorists created an enormous traffic jam yesterday afternoon on virtually all Manhattan thoroughfares. Angry complaints poured into the Police Department's Traffic Division and weary officers acknowledged that they were "all too aware" of the situation.

GENEVA, Nov. 27 -- The United States and Britain urged the Soviet Union today to present its views on the functions of the proposed seven-nation control commission for supervising a ban on the testing of nuclear weapons.
CLEVELAND, Nov. 27 -- An atom smasher more than twice as powerful as any yet developed has gone into operation in Geneva, Switzerland.

Should plans move on schedule, a feature-length movie version of "A Child's Christmas in Wales," one of the best-known works of the late poet Dylan Thomas will go before the cameras overseas in January.

TANGIER, Nov. 27 -- The International Sugar Council concluded its fourth session tonight after two days of executive meetings. A decision was reached to reduce basic export quotas by 12 1/2 per cent. This decision was based on a report of the statistical committee that the world's needs in the coming year would be 5,700,000 tons against a reported supply of 6,800,000.

The Outlet Company plans to split its common stock five for one, subject to approval of stockholders at a special meeting. Shareholders also will vote on increasing the authorized common stock from 99,420 shares to 497,100 shares without par value.

I should like to support the views expressed in a letter to The Times on Nov. 12, written by Theodore B. Hetzel of the Indian Rights Association, questioning the morality of flooding the Alleghany Reservation of the Seneca Indians in southwestern New York State by the building of the Kinzua Dam.
PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 27 -- The sixtieth edition of football's prize spectacular will be staged here tomorrow with Army the favorite over Navy.
Local 88 of the International Organization of Masters, Mates and Pilots, one of the nation's most trouble - ridden unions, should be enjoying self-government by next March.

BOMBAY, India, Nov. 27 -- A United States marine serving as a consulate clerk was seized by Chinese Communist Consulate officials here today and held in their consulate for six hours. The Indian police obtained his release.

TOKYO, Nov. 27 -- More than 20,000 Leftist-led unionists and university students broke through police lines and stormed into the Diet (Parliament) grounds today to demand an end of Japan's security alliance with the United States.
YESTERDAY afternoon's program of the New York Philharmonic at Carnegie Hall had two soloists: one scheduled, Zino Francescatti, violinist, and one unscheduled, Leonard Bernstein, harpsichordist.
With their defense department handicapped by injuries, the New York Rangers yesterday recalled Irv Spencer, a defense man, from Springfield of the American Hockey League.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 27 -- The General Assembly's Political Committee called on North Korea and Communist China again today to agree to free elections to bring about a democratic all-Korean government.

The aftermath of gyrations in Curtiss-Wright Corporation stock earlier this week was a matter of tightly buttoned lips yesterday. The Securities and Exchange Commission said that Roy Hurley, president of the company, had been called in to explain and that it was continuing to investigate.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 27 -- Following is the text of a report on Hungary submitted to the General Assembly today by Sir Leslie Munro of New Zealand, the United Nation's special representative on the Hungarian question:

As a nation, it has been observed, we loathe war -- and love to read about it. The eminence of such writers as Shakespeare, Tolstoy and Homer suggests that there is a timeless appeal at the heart of the matter. And, naturally, there is a special interest concerned when the wars are part of the history of our own country.

TORONTO, Nov. 27 (UPI) -- Two inches of snow fell on Toronto this morning, providing a wintry setting for pre-Grey Cup festivities and leaving little chance of the muddy field at the Canadian National Exhibition Stadium drying out before the game tomorrow.
"It's disgusting," snapped Mrs. Lynn Percy, a Bronx housewife, to a dozen of her friends who clustered on the sidewalk yesterday. "No water. No heat. Disgusting!"
SANTA CLAUS guided his reindeer down Channel 4 last night to inaugurate the Christmas season on television.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 27 (AP) -- Brown Shoe Company, Inc., of St. Louis asked today dismissal of charges that it had illegally barred retailers from handling competing shoes and had fixed retail prices.

THE memorial exhibition of animal and figure sculpture by John B. Flannagan (1895-1942), organized by the American Federation of Arts and now on view at the Time-Life Reception Center, 9 Rockefeller Plaza, honors an artist who, esthetically as well as in years, died before his time.

CARACAS, Venezuela, Nov. 27 -- Governor Rockefeller visited his Palo Gordo farm near Valencia today and found that his agricultural experts had found a way to outsmart voracious Texas rice birds, known locally as pajaros arroceros.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 27 -- Hungarian patriots are believed to have been tried and executed recently and more are feared to be awaiting death, according to Sir Leslie Munro of New Zealand.

Peter F. [allon, Inc., print- ers, of Long Island City, have subleased th plant at 528 Ferry Street, Newark, IV..r., from the Westinghouse Electric CorporaLion. The building, containing 105,000 square feet of space, was acquired through the Archie Schwartz Company, broker.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 27 -- Four squadrons equipped with early-model F-104 Starfighter jets will be inactivated earlier than planned to cut expenses, the Air Force said today.

SYRACUSE, N. Y., Nov. 27 (AP) -- The Lamson Corporation of Wilmington, Del., and Syracuse said today it had acquired the business assets of the Jampol Company, Inc., manufacturer of newspaper conveying equipment.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 27 (AP) -- A drive for a cut in income taxes was opened today by the United States' Chamber of Commerce.

PARIS, Nov. 27 -- The Soviet Union is willing to attend a summit conference whenever the West is ready, either before or after the mid-March visit to France by Premier Khrushchev, Soviet Ambassador Sergei A. Vinogradov said today.

Opposition to a Consolidated Edison Company merger with its wholly owned subsidiary, the Consolidated Telegraph and Electrical Subway Company, was expressed yesterday by the New York City Housing Authority.

CHICAGO, Nov. 27 -- The Trans World Airlines cargo plane that crashed Tuesday near Midway Airport, killing eleven persons, was in good condition when it arrived from Philadelphia three hours earlier, a coroner's jury was told today.

MANILA, Nov. 27 (AP) -- United States and Philippine military commanders conferred for two hours today. They were reported to have agreed on new joint security measures for the United States bases here.
Billy Hunter, Detroit's sharp-shooting heavyweight, seems to have the measure of Argentina's Alex Miteff.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 27 (UPI) -- The political arm of the American Federation of Labor and Congress of Industrial Organizations said today that it had accounted for only 2.6 per cent of the spending reported by forty-three political organizations during the first eight months of 1959.

THE last big bridge tournament of the year, the winter national championships of the American Contract Bridge League, begins today at Coronado Beach, at San Diego, Calif., and continues through Sunday, Dec. 6. It will be played at the Del Coronado Hotel.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 27 -- Two professors at Washington University, St. Louis, have invented apparatus for recording the speed of human movements with sound waves.

CLEVELAND, Nov. 27 -- The first long look at the radiation belts enveloping the earth has revealed that, when struck by solar clouds, they shed vast quantities of electrons.
STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Nov. 27 -- The Government's proposal for a 4 per cent sales tax was approved today by the Upper House of Parliament, but defeated by the lower chamber.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 27 -- Freezing weather cut into iron ore shipments last week and contributed to a decline of 1.4 per cent in loadings of railroad freight cars from the level of the preceding week.
Teams of inspectors from the city's Department of Investigation and Department of Markets yesterday continued their spot checks of retail food stores, but no results of their findings were announced.

Members of the Utility Workers Union voted yesterday to accept the terms of a new two-year contract with the Consolidated Edison Company. The union represents about 22,000 production, clerical and technical employes.

A 35 cent dividend Was declared on the new stock of the Aetna Life Insurance Company for payment on Jan. 2. This is equal to 93 1/3 cents on the old shares, which were recently split two for one, after which a 33 1/3 per cent stock dividend was distributed.
ACCRA, Ghana, Nov. 27 -- Ghan's new Academy of Learning was inaugurated today by Prince Philip, the Duke of Edinburgh, and Prime Minister Kwame Nkrumah.
SWEIDEH, United Arab Republic, Nov. 25 -- A friendly field marshal in a gray flannel suit captured this Syrian mountain town today with a smile and a speech.

Paul Ford's skill at portraying pompous Senators, harmed Army officers and vexed political hacks has made him one of the most successful actors on stage, television and in movies. The 56-year-old performer is not ungrateful for all this, but in recent months he has quietly been shopping about for an assignment that would demonstrate the variety of his talents.

Your recent editorial on "State Wage Proposals" arrives at the conclusion that a flat statutory minimum wage for all workers within the State of New York would be desirable simply because procedures under the existing industry-by-industry minimum wage law, which has been in effective operation in this state since 1937, involve time, expense and complexity.
SARANAC LAKE, N. Y., Nov. 27 (AP) -- George Victor Martin, the novelist, killed himself last night by slashing his arms with a razor, the police reported.
OF all the thousands of women who live alone in New York, Mrs. Marion Supportis is one of the most enviable.

Stockholders of Empire Millwork Corporation have authorized the company to exercise the option that it now holds to acquire 124,014 shares of common stock of E. L. Bruce Company, hardwood floor maker of Memphis, Tenn.

A four-story garden-type apartment building at 40-40I Elbertson Street, Elmhurst, i Queens, has been sold by Daniel H. Cohen to an investing client of Herbert Schrank. It contains thirty-two apartments. The deal was for cash over mortgages[l lamounting to $159,000.

SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 27 (AP) -- Phil Woolpert, who coached the University of San Francisco basketball team to two national collegiate championships, today took a year's leave of absence for health reasons.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 27 -- The Government rejected today a union proposal that it build stockpiles of steel for defense while it had the opportunity.

Allan P. Kirby, chairman and president of the Alleghany Corporation, disclosed late yesterday that he had withdrawn an offer of a directorship he had made on Nov. 12 to Abraham M. Sonnabend, Boston real estate and hotel operator.

LONDON, Nov. 27 (Reuters) -- West Germany has become Britain's biggest export market outside of North America and the Commonwealth, James Marjoribanks, British Economic Minister in Bonn, reported here today.
WEEHAWKEN, N. J. Nov. 27 -- Another Diesel engine escaped unattended today. But it went only two miles, taking forty minutes, and stopped ingloriously in a pile of rubble and old railroad ties.
TEL AVIV, Israel, Nov. 27 -- Premier David Ben-Gurion sided today with Premier Abdul Karim Kassim of Iraq in his conflict with President Gamal Abdel Nasser of the United Arab Republic.

LIMA, Peru, Nov. 24 -- The Peruvian Congress has approved an industrial promotion law aimed at attracting domestic and foreign capital and decentralizing industry by granting special benefits to new enterprises away from the Lima and Callao area.

PANAMA, Nov. 27 -- The United States Embassy here has warned United States citizens to stay away from the center of the city during Panamanian Independence Day demonstrations tomorrow.

MEXICO CITY, Nov. 27 -- Anastas I. Mikoyan, a First Deputy Premier of the Soviet Union, ended the first week of his ten-day visit to Mexico last night with a television interview during which he denied that Moscow was seeking world domination.

ATLANTIC CITY, Nov. 27 -- Arthur S. Flemming, Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare, said today that the future of higher education depends upon the willingness of higher, education to participate in political action.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 27 -- (UPI) -- Senator Stephen M. Young, Democrat of Ohio, said today that Governor Rockefeller was "undermining the average American citizen's yearning for peace" by advocating that atomic tests be resumed.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 27 -- Senator John F. Kennedy, Democrat of Massachusetts, commented today on a statement by the Roman Catholic Bishops of the United States, who recently opposed the use of public funds to promote artificial birth control at home and abroad.
COLOMBO, Ceylon, Nov. 27 -- The Government of Prime Minister Wijayananda Dahanayake survived a motion of censure by one vote today. The close outcome has renewed pressure on the Government to resign.

The Rev. Dr. Edwin T. Dahlbeg, president of the National Council of Churches, will leave here Dec. 15 on a world mission for the Protestant and Eastern Orthodox interchurch body. It will be the first round-the-world trip ever undertaken by a president of the National Council.
A bill exempting a large number of landlords from the requirement to provide central heating has been sent to Albany by Mayor Wagner.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 27 (AP) -- The Civil Aeronautics Board proposed today to permit airlines to carry ordinary mail during the Christmas rush.

CHOOSING meat with a butcher's aid is difficult enough if you are not conversant with the different cuts. In the bustle of a supermarket, with no one to give advice, the task becomes almost impossible. The blank stare of the cellophane wrapper gives nothing away, and usually the only markings to be found are the name of the cut, the price and tax weight.

Loans to business by fifteen large New York banks increased $8,000,000 to $10,354,000,000 in the week ended on Wednesday, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday. This compared with an increase of $14,000,000 a year ago.

ELAINE SHAFFER, the American flutist who has been very active overseas, made her Town Hall debut last night. Word-of-mouth notices had apparently preceded her, for the hall was comfortably filled, and the audience contained some prominent musicians -- a rare event at a flute recital, and a debut at that.

Stocks rose yesterday for the eighth straight session. Bullish sentiment prevailed in Wall Street and many analysts were convinced that a year-end rally was in the making. Over the years, December has been a month in which industrial issues, on average, have been strong.
BONN, Germany, Nov. 27 -- Chancellor Konrad Adenauer said today that "if" an East-West summit conference was held it would take place toward the end of April or the beginning of May.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 27 -- Ambassador Carlos P. Romulo of the Philippines suggested today that the United States investigate its military representatives in his country.

A new volume of Americana, "The Great American West," will be published next Thursday by Crown. The author is James D. Horan. His volume describes all aspects of life in the West from the first white men to the "last frontier." The book contains 650 illustrations, many in color.

President Eisenhower is not visiting Yugoslavia on his trip abroad next month, and there seems to be not a little annoyance in Belgrade over that fact. Some of this annoyance appears to have cropped out in two major speeches by President Tito. The Yugoslav leader lashed out at his people for talking too much to foreigners about the country's economy and its economic secrets.

ARTUR RUBINSTEIN played three brief pieces by Heitor Villa-Lobos at his Carnegie Hall recital last night. They were gay, charming, atmospheric and were played with the utmost grace. This was the pianist's tribute to the Brazilian composer, who died last week, and he had every reason to remember Villa-Lobos with an affectionate smile.
LONDON, Nov. 27 (Reuters) -- Vilis T. Latsis resigned today as Premier of Latvia "for health reasons," the Soviet press agency Tass reported from Riga.
ATLANTA, Nov. 27 -- A request by the Atlanta Board of Education for permission to delay the presentation of a school desegregation plan was denied here today in Federal District Court.

The police made slight progress yesterday in tracing the Monday movements of Povl Bang-Jensen, the former United Nations official whose body was found Thursday in Alley Park, Queens. His death was called an apparent suicide.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 27 (UPI) -- David Hearne, 21-year-old son of Iirish Ambassador John J. Hearne, has returned to Ireland, a spokesman for the Irish Embassy said today.

BY virtue of its glowing coat, the orange is a restive fruit at any season. It is particularly welcome now that ingredients for fresh fruit salads are somewhat limited, and it adds a happy touch of color to arrangements in the fruit bowl.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 27 (AP) -- Thirty years ago a personable young lawyer in Ardmore, Okla., was asked to become the legal adviser to the new Independent Petroleum Association of America. The offer came from Wirt Franklin, Ardmore oil man and the association's first president.
NEWARK, Nov. 27 -- The constitutionality of New Jersey's ban on Sunday sales of certain merchandise was upheld today.
RIVERHEAD, L. I., Nov. 27 -- Three militars., absentee bal-{ lots brought the re-election of: Evans K. Grilling as Supervisor of Shelter Island today by a two-vote margin.

KANSAS CITY, Nov. 27 (AP) -- Six coaches and former coaches averaging more than thirty years experience were named today to the football hall of fame of the National Association of Intercollegiate Athletics.

BALTIMORE, Nov. 27 (AP) -- The Idle Hour Farm of Lexington, Ky., sent out the winner of the feature Sparrows Point purse at Pimlico today in Julmar, a stakes-winning colt who traveled a mile on grass in 1:45. Julmar paid $4.60 as the program's fifth winning favorite.
PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 27 -- Steve Sebo, head coach of Pennsylvania's Ivy League football champions, was advised last December that his contract would not be renewed, it was reported tonight.
The Treasury's new issue of $2,000,000,000 of 320-day discount bills sustained a substantial setback yesterday. Longer issues of United States Government securities also were marked down.
The first of this season's Junior Assemblies was held last night in the Grand Ballroom of the Plaza.

THE man who is trying to head off a strike by drivers of private bus lines in the city has had four years of experience with city strike problems. He is Harold Arthur Felix, the city's Commissioner of Labor since 1957 and deputy commissioner for two years before that.
The Communist party of the United States is maintaining a tight security on arrangements for its seventeenth national convention, scheduled to be held here Dec. 10-14.
Beginning Dec. 31, the port of Havana will levy higher charges on all general cargo import shipments.
The financial records of Alan Freed, the disk jockey, were subpoenaed yesterday by the office of District Attorney Frank S. Hogan.

ROME, Nov. 27, (UPI) -- A Texas merchant marine captain who was held for thirty-four months under $2,000,000 bond by Turkish authorities after his ship had collided with a Turkish vessel has been released because of his mother's death in the United States, it was learned here today.

BOSTON, Nov. 27 (UPI) -The president of the Amateur Hockey Association said today he would write to the Russian Ice Hockey Federation apologizing for the conduct of the Brockton (Mass.) team that recently played four games in Moscow.

The Department of Parks gave a gold watch yesterday to 13-year-old Gerard Daggett Jr. of 361 Freeborn Street, Midland Beach, S. I., for heroism. He helped to rescue James Gardner, 55, of 149 Hamden Avenue, Grant City, S. I., on Nov. 15.
HAVANA, Nov. 27 -- University student brigades with rifles added a military note to the annual parade to the student monument on the Prado promenade today.
Charles J. Bensley blamed the City Planning Commission and the Board of Estimate yesterday for the lag in buying sites for schools.

The Georgia and Georgia Tech elevens are rated even money in their battle at Atlanta today, with scouts from the Orange Bowl, Gator Bowl, Liberty Bowl and Bluebonnet Bowl tripping over one another in the stands. If Georgia, the southeastern conference champion, is the loser, both teams could wind up with bids.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 27 -- The National Aeronautics and Space Administration has decided to postpone until well into next year another attempt to place a satellite into orbit around the moon.

In a recent letter Frederic N. Firestone seeks to teach a lesson on financing costs and interest rates. He states that a $5 loan, repaid at the rate of $1.02 monthly for five months, is subjected to 9.6 per cent annual interest on an average debt of $2.50.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 27 -- Algerian nationalists held strategy sessions today with their Asian and African supporters, planning for a full-scale debate Monday in the General Assembly's Political Committee.
WEST POINT, N. Y., Nov. 27 (AP) -- The United States Military Academy will accept a gift of 1,000 acres of Orange County woodland from Gene Leone, New York City restaurateur, next Monday.
TAMPA, Fla., Nov. 27 (UPI) -- The head of an electronics company here said today his company had developed a "revolutionary'' method of producing electrical energy from noise.

The Transport Workers Union ruled out any contract extension yesterday with New York's seven private bus lines. A full day of meetings provided no solution to the threat of a strike when the present contract expires at midnight Monday.

Directors of Butte Copper and Zinc Company yesterday approved an agreement with the Anaconda Company providing for the sale of Butte's Montana mining assets, termination of the companies' joint operating agreement and settlement of all accounts between the companies for a total cash consideration of $1,325,000.

A grim basis for the new United Nations debate on Hungary has been provided by Sir Leslie Munro, former President of the General Assembly and now its special representative, in its effort to end the terror with which the Communists seek to exterminate the last smoldering remnants of the 1956 revolt.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 27 -- The State Department was unable today to piece together a clear picture of what had happened in the Bombay kidnapping case.

The winter winds are beginning to sweep the Great Plains farmlands. In many areas the force of the winds and of the snow they often carry is being softened by stands of trees clustered around farmhouses and barns and along roads and fields.

CORAL GABLES, Fla., Nov. 27 (AP) -- Twenty-two promising juveniles were entered today for the $10,000 added Alligator Handicap tomorrow. Tropical Park officials said the feature would be run in two divisions.

Events today: "Aida" at 2 P. M. and "The Marriage of Figaro" at 8, Metropolitan Opera; Marcia Baldwin, mezzosoprano, Carnegie Recital Hall, 5:30; All-Star Jazz Festival, Town Hall, 8 and 11, New York Philharmonic, Carnegie Hall, 8:30.

Mount Beacon, a 200-acre tractat Beacon, N. Y., with cable railway running to its summit 1,540 feet high, iJ under contract of sale to Herman B. Dranoff of New York. The Realty arket of Fishkill, N. Y., was the broker.

OTTAWA, Nov. 27 (Canadian Press) -- The exemption six months ago of Canada from United States oil import restrictions so far has brought few -- if any -- of the industrial benefits foreseen at the time.
LONDON, Nov. 27 -- The stock market ended the week today on a firm note. The light selling of industdials in recent days declined further and the slightly increased demand raised prices moderately.
"The Lineup," a police series on the Columbia Broadcasting System television network, has fallen victim to deadly ratings.

The slate headed by James Rousmaniere of Cold Spring Harbor, L. I., scored a one-sided victory in the election of the International Blue Jay Class Association at the New York Yacht Club last night. It won, 263 votes to 48, from the ticket headed by James Grover of Babylon, L. I.
After losing their two latest games with the Philadelphia Warriors, the New York Knickerbockers will face Wilt (The Stilt) Chamberlain for the third time tonight.

MELBOURNE, Australia, Nov. 27 (UPI) -- Maria Bueno, the Wimbledon and United States champion, beat a young Melbourne player, Val Roberts, 6 -- 2, 6 -- 1, in the second round of the Victorian women's tennis championship at the Kooyong Courts today.

Secretary of Labor Mitchell has done well to give the public a report on the first two months of his formidable job of administering the Labor-Management Reporting and Disclosure Act. That some 70,000 international, national and local unions are subject to the law gives a measure of the task which the Labor Department now has on its hands.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 27 -- The General Assembly's Budgetary Committee approved today a new scale of assessments for maintenance of the United Nations Emergency Force in Egypt.

Mrs. Wallace Gilroy's Greek Page won the main race at Aqueduct yesterday with little opposition and in good time. Engaging four others in the seven-furlong event, Greek Page came along with a rally in the stretch to take the award by three and a half lengths over Theodora A. Randolph's Sutler.

DETROIT, Nov. 27 (AP) -- Ward's Automotive Reports estimated today car production in 1959 at 5,530,500 units, or 30 per cent more than last year.
HAVANA, Nov. 27 -- The Government intends to bid on the Nicaro nickel plant on the north coast of Oriente province that the United States put up for sale several months ago, it was reported today.

Lyman Jr. of Boston and Mr. and Mrs. Benjamin S. Clark of New York and Pound Ridge, N. Y.

Negotiations between the port's longshoremen and their employers remained near dead center last night after a day-long union session that failed to produce a counterproposal on the port's prime labor problem.
NEW DELHI, India, Nov. 27 -- Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru extended to Nepal today his pledge that India would protect neighboring states against aggression.

DETROIT, Nov. 27 (UPI) -- Iron ore carriers were coming through the locks at Sault Ste. Marie today almost as if it were still summer.

The Amalgamated Sugar Company reported yesterday that its net income for the fiscal year ended on Sept. 30 rose to $3,967,248 from $3,408,813 cleared in the preceding fiscal year.

A CHRISTMAS card idea for families with young, would-be artists is offered by Young Rembrandts. This company suggests sitting your "Young Rembrandt" down with crayon, pencil or paint to draw a fanciful tree, a reindeer or whatever Christmas scene strikes his or her fancy. This concern will reproduce the result as the family's Christmas card.

The International Brotherhood of Teamsters charged in Federal Court here late yesterday that Godfrey P. Schmidt, the court-appointed former monitor of the union's affairs, was receiving aid from leaders of industry in his efforts to oust top Teamster officials.

There is an enthusiastic do-it-yourself spirit surrounding basketball at St. Francis College of Brooklyn. At this small college, which has an enrollment of 563, basketball is the big sport.

THE current retrospective exhibition at the Tate Gallery provides an opportunity to come to grips with the fascinating and, in some ways, controversial art of Jacques Lipchitz. His work is intriguing just because he is one of those rare twentieth-century artists in touch with modern trends who has sought to embody concepts of a religious and mythological character in his art.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 28 -The United States asked India today to make a full investigation of the detention of a United States marine in Bombay yesterday by Chinese Communists.

One hundred years ago last Tuesday the London publishing house of John Murray issued the first edition of Charles Darwin's "Origin of Species." That volume changed man's concept of himself and of his place in the universe. Since its first publication in an edition of 1,250 copies, countless millions in various languages have been sold, and the book is reckoned as second only to the Bible in circulation.

Stock prices rose every trading day last week in surprisingly high volume for a holiday week. The sustained advance pushed The New York Times combined average of fifty representative issues to 396.79, for a gain of 3.34 points. It was the largest gain shown by the index for any week this month.

KNOXVILLE, Nov. 28 (UPI) -- Halfback Tom Moore ripped through Tennessee's defenses for one touchdown and a Vanderbilt yardage record today, leading Vandy to a 14-0 victory over the Volunteers.

United Nations demographers predict that world population, estimated at 2,852,000,000 in mid-1958, will reach 6,267,000,000 by the year 2000. They say that Asia, which today has 56 per cent of the world population, will have 62 per cent by the end of the century.
The Bulova Watchmakers will meet the Brooklyn Whirlaways tomorrow night at the Flushing Armory in the first game of the Eastern Wheelchair Basketball League season.

Morton D. May holds a $135,000-a-year job partly because of the care with which he chose his parents. He is doing his job, however, in a fashion that would be creditable to any leader of commerce who came up the hard way.

Albert Ktrwan's anthology, intended to focus sharply on the social and political history of the Confederacy, is the first in a series of books under the general editorahip of George F. Scheer designed to provide in inexpensive editions "comprehensive and well-rounded" collections of the principal documents of American history.

The Christmas shopping season got under way in earnest yesterday as New Yorkers and out-of-towners swarmed along the city's streets. The atmosphere was only mildly festive. Although many of the midtown department stores were already glittering with the greens, reds and golds of the Christmas season, their special Christmas raiment shed but a modicum of cheer under a sullen gray sky.
HACKENSACK, N. J., Nov. 28 -- Industry has employed 144 of the 377 physically handicapped persons trained by Associated Craftsmen here since May 1, 1953.

THE comic who advances diffidently into the baby spotlight is a Frenchman with billing which says he can "make millions laugh," and of course he is not really as unsure of himself as he pretends to be. That's just part of his act, and it will pay the audience to watch closely, because this man is said to be very funny.
GENEVA, Switzerland, Nov. 28 -- The abolition of the winter Olympic Games was suggested today by Marc Hodler and Otto Mayer, two of the world's top international sports officials.
An office worker from Connecticut came to work last week in New York City with three boxes of cigars that he had purchased in Westport.

AT her death last Aug. 16, Wanda Landowska was midway through a recording of Bach's ThreePart Inventions. She had finished seven of the fifteen in the set when she was stricken. Figuring that it would be a loss to the musical community if the completed seven pieces were withheld, Victor has brought them out, together with the older Landowska recording of the complete Two-Part Inventions.
STARKVILLE, Miss., Nov. 28 -- Jake Gibbs, a quarterback, scored two touchdowns and passed for two more today as the Mississippi Rebels smashed Mississippi State, 42 -- 0, and won a Sugar Bowl bid.
TRENTON, Nov. 28 -- The State Department of Institutions and Agencies this week approved the allocation of $3,278,000 in Federal funds to twelve New Jersey hospitals and medical institutions.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 28 -- Secretary of Labor James P. Mitchell is getting ready to make an appeal for a minimum wage for the migrant farm worker.

Beau Diable exhibited a liking for the muddy track and for the long distance in taking the Display Handicap at Aqueduct yesterday. The race, at two miles on the dirt, attracted a dozen contestants and had a gross value of $58,600.
PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 28 -Four food store chains started a campaign this week to reduce the annual $250,000 loss of shopping carts from supermarkets in the Philadelphia area.

HIS conservative clothes and air of confident informality proclaim the banking and Government background of Thomas Sovereign Gates Jr., who is expected to succeed Neil H. McElroy as Secretary of Defense. What is also immediately noticeable about Tom Gates, in addition to the fact that he really is tall, dark and handsome, is the peculiar tilt of his head.
A $500,000 experiment in New York harbor tugboat design will be put to work here early next year by the Dalzell Towing Company.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 28 -- Next month the President will put to the test his capacity to accomplish two of the most important tasks he or any predecessor has ever undertaken. The first, which is presented by his schedule of visits to nations leagued with the United States and some uncommitted in the cold war between the Communist and non-Communist governments, will be a massive public relations job.

Getting into college is only half the battle: the other half is staying there. Gene R. Hawes, editor of the College Entrance Examination Board, offers a key to both the difficulty of becoming a freshman and of remaining one. He does this in a paperback book. "The New American Guide to Colleges," published this week by the New American Library of World Literature, Inc. (256 pp; 75 cents).
AHMADABAD, India, Nov. 28 (Reuters) -- Prime Minister Jawaharial Nehru said today "a very critical moment is devoloping" in India's border dispute with Communist China.
MINNEAPOLIS, Nov. 28 -Minnesota's preparations for the 1961 White House Conference on Aging have been called by a conference staff member the most "exhaustive and extensive" of any state.

THE dedicated spirits who are building the Opera Society of Washington into a permanent ornament for the nation's capital are not interested in easy solutions. If they were, they would turn to the unfailing crowdpullers of the standard repertory, hire a big name or two, thirty together a scenic production with the left hand and call it a season.

William M. Parke 3d of Scarsdale, N. Y., became the first winner of the Delafield Trophy last week as the outstanding skipper of last summer's Great South Bay Race Week. He sailed in the junior division of the Blue Jay Class and took five first places and a second among thirty-six starters.

YEARS ago T. E. Lawrence, introducing St. John Philby's classic account of a journey across Arabia, lamented that there were almost no more virgin spaces left on the earth. According to Lawrence the world has been discovered, boxed, compassed.
ROME, Nov. 28 -- The people who complain that the many billions of dollars spent for foreign aid have bought nothing but dislike for the Americans are clearly not talking about Italy.

WITH two completed pictures on hand and two others in preparation, Raoul Levy is not, strangely enough, suffering from an embarrassment of riches. The French producer, who arrived here last week for a brief visit, revealed that he was about to start production wheels rolling on a fifth film.
PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 28 -Three personal-foul calls were made during the Army-Navy football game today. In each case Navy was the offending squad.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 28 -- Delegations to the United Nations were understood today to have decided to give immediate precedence to discussion of the question of Algeria.

JACKSONVILLE, Fla., Nov. 28 -- Dick Allen rallied Florida in the final period with a field goal and a touchdown pass for a 23-14 victory over Miami today. The loss knocked the Hurricanes out of the Orange Bowl.
CORAL GABLES, Fla., Nov. 28 (AP) -- April Skies and Ira Eaker scored impressive victories today in the two divisions of Tropical Park's Alligator Handicap for 2-year-olds.

WHEN in the last century Francis James Child of Harvard made his great collection of English and Scottish popular ballads, he published only a few tunes and collected his texts almost entirely from printed sources. In this century British and American collectors, notably Cecil Sharp and Phillips Barry, began to collect ballads from oral sources, teaching us that music is as much a part of a ballad as it is of a song.
VIENNA, Nov. 27 -- Vulko Chervenkov, the Communist ruler of Bulgaria during the last years of Stalin's life, is reported to be staging a political comeback.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 28 -- A fresh wave of farm rumblings is moving toward the nation's capital. The head of the wave is likely to lap against one of the Administration's greatest bulwarks in Chicago next month.
Rabbis in several synagogues declared yesterday that religion was the only answer to the great crisis of this age -- the widening gap between science and morality.
SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 28 (UPI) -- Bishop Pike said today that many United States Catholics used artificial birth control methods.

GLOUCESTER, Mass., Nov. 28 -- The final step in making Gloucester the nation's headquarters for research in fishery problems and in the wider subject of oceanography was taken this week with the opening of the Gloucester Technological Laboratory of the United States Bureau of Commercial Fisheries.
WHITE PLAINS, Nov. 28 -Westchester will celebrate its historical past Wednesday with pageantry and exhibits at the County Center here.

THE presentation in the same week of television adaptations of "Don Quixote" and "A Doll's House" raises questions concerning the propriety of laying hands on classic works without investigating the full depth of responsibility entailed.

The most striking, and encouraging, feature of the American Jewish Congress' report on laws barring racial and religious discrimination is the fact that today, for the first time in history, a majority of Americans live in states where such discrimination is against the law.
The art world seems to have joined the pre-Christmas rush as many openings in the galleries are scheduled for this week.

ONCE a bowling "alley" -- a word which makes today's statusminded bowling proprietors wince -- was a dingy, grimy, smokefilled refuge for men and for boys who thought they were men. Today it is a swank, plushly fitted "supermarket" aimed at enveloping the entire family.

WE are about to run out of regular hunting seasons in this part of the world, and from this fact flows another: The preserve hunting seasons are about to start seriously. Until the general seasons are over the preserve seasons are not serious.
JAKARTA, Indonesia, Nov. 27 -- Rising prices have contributed to pessimism in many areas of Java.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 28 -- The Army foot soldiers had to do it alone today. They had no air arm for reconnaissance strafing or heavy bombing sorties. But Navy launched overhead attacks off the carrier decks and blasted away with the heavy guns to upset the West Pointers, 43--12, in the sixtieth annual service classic on an afternoon of rain, overcast and--right at the end--furtive sunshine.

THE slogans and catchwords for the 1960 campaign are passing through their experimental stage. Republicans and Democrats alike have been running tests on trial models, and have been making adjustments in the light of market research. Soon, however, the managers will reach a decision. The switch will be turned on. And the slogans and catchwords, suited to every taste, will roll off the political assembly lines.

Despite the extravagant publicity heralding the invasion of plastics into home construction, many top plastics officials apparently are growing a bit impatient over the progress of their versatile product.

Holiday merchandise was in demand last week as stores sought to peak their stocks for the Christmas season. Resident buying offices reported that cruise lines and dressy clothes were strongly ordered.
PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 28 -A tactical decision to use four halfbacks on defense was cited by Coach Wayne Hardin as a key factor in Navy's recordsetting victory over Army today.

ALMOST since 1905, when New Hampshire, Maine and California became the first states to require that motor vehicle drivers obtain licenses, state officials and safety experts have been debating how to determine the bases for the granting and withdrawing of the privileges conferred by such licenses.

NOW that travel and allowance restrictions have been lifted between Great Britain and the United States, I am suggesting in the interest of visitors on both sides of the Atlantic that they would benefit considerably if someone acted as an inquiry bureau.
PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 28 -- Navy perpetrated another of its shocking uprisings against a favored Army football team today. This time it was a massacre.
BATON ROUGE, La., Nov. 28 -- Louisiana Democrats go to the polls next Saturday to choose the probable Governor for the next four years and the state officials who will serve with him.
NEW DELHI, India, Nov. 28 -- The United States Embassy strongly protested to the Indian Government today against yesterday's detention of a marine at the Chinese Communist Consulate in Bombay.
BEIRUT, Lebanon, Nov. 17 -The United States Government's new Arabic magazine is off to an uncertain start in a crowded field.

MAY I suggest that Paul Sklar [Mailbag, Nov. 22] from Bayside, Queens, who needs a bare leg to entertain him, find "delightful" entertainment at much cheaper prices on some of our newsstands or at some obscure movie house on Fortysecond Street.

SIR WINSTON CHURCHILL was born eighty-five years ago tomorrow. He has become a character in history -- and in legend, too. Today, all the animosities he created over half a century through fierce invective phrase and controversial deed have faded away; what remains is the unstinted affection of a nation -- indeed, of the English-speaking peoples throughout the world.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 28 -President Eisenhower will speak in public about thirty times during his eleven-nation goodwill tour of Europe, Asia and Africa. The trip is to begin next Thursday.
A blossoming new electronics industry, with every prospect of booming in the next decade, is dominated at the moment by three companies.

Charles Frankel's concern with the country's moral climate is shared by sensitive teachers all over the land. The history teacher who recently "rigged" a classroom quiz to shock his students into an awareness of the ethical implications involved is a good case in point.
SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 28 -- The broadening of California's civil rights law by the 1959 Legislature makes it applicable to real estate brokers and salesmen, it was ruled this week.
DEERFIELD, Ill., Nov. 28 -- An action committee was organized this week in this Chicago suburban village to block a proposed integrated housing project.

BRAZZA VILLE, Congo Republic, Nov. 27 -- Premier Fulbert Youlou called tonight on his neighbors, Gabon, Chad and the Central African Republic, to plan together for their common needs and to maintain economic and ethnic ties with the Congo Republic.

Imports of alcoholic beverages will probably set a record this year. This is the word from the National Association of Alcoholic Beverage Importers, Inc., Washington, D. C. The association keeps tabs on all such imports entering this country until after they are withdrawn from customs bonded warehouses and placed into distribution channels.
A GOOD thing Anthony Comstock is not around these days to study the windows of Broadway record shops.

Miss Ursula Wolcott Griswold and Miss Wendy Wick were honored last night at a dinner dance given jointly by their parents in the Georgian Suite 1A East Seventy-seventh Street. The debutantes are the daughters of Mr. and Mrs. John Sloane Griswold of Greenwich and Old Lyme, Conn., and Mr. and Mrs. Myron A. Wick Jr., also of Greenwich.

Just how many books have been written about the three flaming days of July, 1863, at Gettysburg would be hazardous to guess. The battle stands apart: it is unique; here, where Lincoln rededicated the nation to its historic mission in world polities, probably more people tramp hill and dale and gape at battle monuments than on any other historic site in America.
The Grand Ballroom of the Plaza was gay with clusters of pink and green balloons against masses of eucalyptus and Canadian cedar for the annual Grosvenor Ball last night.

THE country's youngest important exhibition of American painting and sculpture, the Second Biennial at the Detroit Institute of Arts, is also the most venerable, or will be on January 24 when it moves to the Pennsylvania Academy of the Fine Arts in Philadelphia to become that institution's One Hundred and Fifty-fifth Annual. In either case it is a big, sprawling, confused, spotty cross-section admirable for its tolerant catholicity but puzzling in its lack of flavor.

TOKYO, Nov. 28 -- Premier Nobusuke Kishi said today that both the Government and Parliament must take "responsible measures" to prevent the recurrence of riots in the vicinity of the Diet and the law courts.

The latest round in the behind-the-scenes fight for control of Alleghany Corporation came on Friday when Allan P. Kirby, company chairman and president, said he had withdrawn an offer of a seat on the board made on Nov. 12 to Abraham M. Sonnabend, Boston real estate and hotel operator.
NEW ORLEANS, Nov. 28 (AP) -- W. Hal Bishop's Pete's Folly posted an easy victory today in the $10,000 Crescent City Handicap at the Fair Grounds.

Since August, 1947, when India became independent of Britain, Jawaharlal Nehru has held power in India as Prime Minister and Minister of External Affairs. His political position has never been seriously challenged. His Congress party, an amalgam of left and center holding about 350 of 500 seats in Parliament, has dominated India's party life, and Mr. Nehru has dominated the party.
EVERY now and then a musical comedy turns up that suits New York down to the ground. In "Fiorello!" everything drops into place with the happiest precision.
TORONTO, Nov. 28 -- Canadians are becoming aware that they speak and write English in a distinctive way.

PARIS. AFTER four years of theatrical, if not literary, silence Jean-Paul Sartre is once again examining the problems of human existence through a play. "Les Sequestres d'Altona" ("The Secluded Ones of Altona") is one of the longest, most difficult and most controversial plays of the current season.
HAMBURGER, a humble immigrant meat that came to this country from Germany and soared to fame on a bun, has lately been causing a stir among the French, who have always snubbed it as parvenu.

THE age-old bit of folklore that attributes great wisdom to the owl was dealt a severe blow the other day. A scientist who has been studying owls reported that in fact these birds are extremely stupid -- that they couldn't even learn to find their way around his laboratory without constantly bumping into things.

A WEEK ago today was the hundredth anniversary of the birth of Cecil Sharp, who set in motion the whole English folkdance revival, and the event was celebrated fittingly, and as genially as anybody could ask, by the Country Dance Society of America.
The country's thirteen localservice airlines will carry more than 5,000,000 passengers and gross more than $100,000,000 in revenues in 1959, the Air Transport Association has estimated.

SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 28 -A fourteen-month study at Mount Zion Hospital here has assertedly proved that acute alcoholics can be treated successfully without segregation, without restraint and with no more trouble than any other acutely ill patients.

MADRID, Nov. 28 -- Spain's feelings toward the United States are genuinely friendly despite the history of a war, diametrically opposed systems of govern ment and large-scale American aid to the Franco regime.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 28 -- Navy's football team tonight was invited to play Penn State in the new Liberty Bowl game here Dec. 19. Naval Academy officials said that a statement issued earlier in the day saying that Navy would reject the bid, had been premature and unauthorized.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 28 -- If the Republican national convention were to be held this week -- or any week in the near future -- there is no question in anyone's mind that its choice by acclamation for the Presidential nomination would be Vice President Richard M. Nixon.
Of the many recent travelers to the Bahamas, few have found the Islands more interesting than have certified public accountants and tax lawyers.

What Sir Winston Churchill once called "the measured tramp of time" has brought him today to his eighty-fifth birthday. His place is now so secure that it takes an effort of will to remember it was not always so.
Zionist leaders warned yesterday of what they termed a "rising tide of assimilation" that was leading to a decline of Jewish cultural life in this country.
Most automotive manufacturers are expected to reinstate, by the middle of next month, advertising that they had cut from their schedules.
I should like to express my opinion about the problems which have arisen in connection with the interne situation here in the New York area as well as throughout the United States.
PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 29 -- Senator Lyndon B. Johnson of Texas accused the Eisenhower Administration tonight of cutting the "people's dreams out of the budget."

BAL HARBOUR, Fla., Nov. 29 -- The nation's investment securities specialists were urged here today by a California banker to study the way the sprawling of cities into suburban areas is changing long- established means for dealing with such public services as transportation, sewerage, water supply and other public ultilities.
The Rev. Dr. Ralph W. Sockman preached yesterday on the presence of God in the problems of man. He said: "God is not off aloof above the struggle. He is in the struggle with us."
ST. PETERSBURG, Nov. 29 -- As the baseball clans began assembling today for the opening of the annual minor league convention tomorrow, one word seemed to transcend all else --expansion.

Charley Conerly, the Giant quarterback, received an estimated $25,000 worth of gifts at Yankee Stadium yesterday prior to the game between the Redskins and Giants. The occasion was "Charley Conerly Day," a time for paying tribute to the senior member of the Giants as a man and as a football player.
ALBANY, Nov. 29 -- Governor Rockefeller called today for a law to clear the state's highways of drivers who are dangerously intoxicated but not legally drunk.
MANHATTAN, Kan., Nov. 29 (AP) -- Two balloonists who went fifteen miles into the sky to study the planet Venus made a rough landing today in a northeast Kansas pasture.
NASSAU, Bahamas, Nov. 29 -- John Cuevas of Miami touched off Nassau's annual Speed Week today with an outstanding triumph in the 112.5-mile Nassau Tourist Trophy race.

UNITED NATIONS, Nov. 29 -- A desire to encourage an end of the differences between the French Government and the Algerian rebels appeared to be the dominant theme of Asian thinking here on the eve of debate on Algeria.
DENVER, Nov. 29 (UPI) -The American Smelting and Refining Company reached a virtual agreement today on a new contract affecting 5,000 striking workers in eight states.
American universities are in danger of surrendering their independence in return for research dollars, the American Civil Liberties Union charged yesterday.
Curtailment of the administrative powers of the city's five Borough Presidents was advocated yesterday by Stanley M. Isaacs, the only Republican on the twenty-five member City Council.

A concert in memory of Bohuslav Martinu, the Czechoslovak composer who died last Aug. 28, was given on Saturday evening at the Mannes College of Music. Martinu for many years had been a member of the Mannes faculty.
WHEN first-rate butchers bring home the bacon, what do they have in the bag? Do they feast each night on fabulous fillets or pamper their palates with porterhouse? They do not.

The mutual fund business showed again last week its ability to tailor its product to investors' needs.

There has been too much emphasis on "the bad mother" in childhood mental disorders and too little on development of new techniques for testing constitutional and physiological bases of the disorders, a psychiatric researcher said here yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 29 -- Vice President Richard M. Nixon is gradually shedding the anonymity that has surrounded his office operations for the last seven years.
VIENNA, Nov. 29 -- The story of Poland in the autumn of 1959 is the realization of her Communist leaders that they have failed to establish effective Communist rule and direction in the country.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 28 (UPI) -- Business leaders were found today to be confident that the economy would shake off the effects of the steel strike and rise to record heights next year and in 1961.
The beginning of the season of Advent was marked yesterday in churches over the world. Advent is a period of four weeks before Christmas. During it Christians reflect on the coming of Christ.
TRENTON, Nov. 29 -- A check of the twelve counties in which New Jersey's Sunday Restricted Sales Law is in effect showed three arrests on charges of noncompliance.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Nov. 29 -- A full-length American movie will have a premiere in Moscow. It is believed here to be the first time this has happened.

LONDON, Nov. 29 -- Sir Winston Churchill. fighter in war and peace, has given in to his wife and agreed to a family party tomorrow for his eighty-fifth birthday. While tributes poured in from all over the world, "the greatest Englishman of our time," as The Observer termed him today, was driven to London from his Chartwell estate. but his wife, who is 74, persuaded him to have a family party.
Recently a small squib appeared in your paper, captioned Bonn to Build U-Boats." Its appearance was inconspicuous, but its implications now loom large.
Christa Ludwig, German mezzo-soprano, will make her Metropolitan debut on Thursday, Dec. 10, as Cherubino in Mozart's "Le Nozze di Figaro."

Private pension funds are growing faster than any other form of investment and are a major factor changing the nature of the capitalist system in this country, the Twentieth Century Fund reported yesterday.

Charley Conerly never had it so good and his Giants rarely had it so easy as they did in the cold and the wind before 60,982 fans at Yankee Stadium yesterday. The 38 - year - old quarterback helped make his "day" a memorable one as he fired three touchdown passes while directing the Giants to a 45-14 rout of the Washington Redskins.
Claude Frank made his long overdue debut with the New York Philharmonic yesterday afternoon at Carnegie Hall in the Beethoven Piano Concerto No. 3 in C minor.
HAVANA, Nov. 29 -- The final session of Cuba's first National Catholic Congress this afternoon erupted in shouts of "Down with Communism" by thousands who crowded the Tropical Stadium.
PINAR DEL RIO, Cuba, Nov. 29 -- An American will go on trial here tomorrow with thirtyeight other persons accused of counter-revolutionary activities.
BOSTON, Nov. 29 -- The validity of a celebrated historical shrine was challenged today by a Boston minister.

A United Nations agency representing seventy-four nations will study the technical, economic and social consequences likely to arise from the expected introduction of supersonic airliners in the 1965-70 period.
LONDON, Nov. 29 -- Britain and the United Arab Republic have agreed to resume diplomatic relations, it was learned on good authority here today.

LARCHMONT, N. Y., Nov. 29 -- Jack Sutphen sailed Rum Dum through a seven-race program today without winning once. But he was consistently near the front and triumphed in the Larchmont Yacht Club's championship series frostbite regatta.

THIS is the start of the party season when more women have a chance to issue or accept invitations. Dressing up is never a matter of hard-and-fast rules, but there are certain appropriate strategems to follow.
Heavy orders from abroad are continuing to support the domestic machine tool industry.
MANILA, Monday, Nov. 30 (UPI) -- The Japanese Government gave up today its final attempt to help the Allies subdue the last two imperial army soldiers who are still fighting World War II.

It is startling to learn, from a suit just filed in Brooklyn Supreme Court, that the five teachers suspended without pay by the New York City Board of Education more than four years ago for refusing to disclose names of other teachers who were Communists have still not been reinstated despite repeated judicial and administrative decisions in their favor.

THE midshipmen who handled the sideshow gimmicks for the Army-Navy game let themselves be carried away beforehand by a wave of optimism that seemed to border on the ridiculous. Their plans called for the release of a balloon whenever the future admirals scored a touchdown.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 29 (AP) -- Kenny Sears sank a twenty-foot jump shot as the final buzzer sounded today, enabling the New York Knickerbockers to gain a 127-126 victory over the Philadelphia Warriors in a National Basketball Association game.
Irmgard Seefried, soprano, sang her only New York recital of the season at Hunter College Saturday evening, as the fifth event of the college's 1959-60 subscription series.
Proposed legislation to restrict the power of grand juries won qualified support yesterday from District Attorney Edward S. Silver of Brooklyn.

ATLANTIC BEACH, L. I., Nov. 29 -- A 200-foot section of shoreline on the northern side of this narrow strip of land was washed out here today. Dredging is being done in Reynolds Channel.

"No Protestant could proclaim that one method of birth control is a fundamental breach of the moral law, while another is perfectly all right," the Rev. Dr. David H. C. Read declared yesterday in a sermon at the Madison Avenue Presbyterian Church at Seventy-third Street.

LONDON, Nov. 29 -- The Government focused its attention last week on corporate law and monetary policy. Developments in these two related fields had no immediate bearing on markets, which were unsettled for other reasons.

LONDON, Monday, Nov. 30 (AP) -- About 14,000 power-plant workers began a twenty-four-hour wildcat strike at midnight. The state-owned power industry said it was confident it could provide enough electricity for essential services. London, Birmingham, Manchester and Southhampton were affected by the walkout.

PARIS, Nov. 29 -- Labor agitation is growing here as a reaction to rising prices. The Government is trying to stem the inflationary trend by fighting to hold the line on prices while preventing an increase in general wage levels that would compromise the nation's finances and its export program.
Fred H. Hill, realty investor and builder, has purchased the northeast comer of Third Avehue and Forty-eighth Street from Harry Horwitz.

BONN, Germany, Nov. 29 -- The West German Defense Ministry is urging Chancellor Konrad Adenauer to intervene with President Charles de Gaulle to ease French objections to further integration of the military forces within the Atlantic alliance.

The world's non - Catholic churches have abandoned "all hope" of participation in the ecumenical council announced early this year by Pope John XXIII, the Rev. Dr. John Sutherland Bonnell declared yesterday.

BETHLEHEM, Nov. 29 -- The Bethlehem Steel Company reported today that it had distributed $2,118.000 to assist sixty-seven privately endowed educational institutions since 1953. This money is in addition to research grants by the company for work of direct benefit to the steel industry.

In a notable address at the recent Chicago conference sponsored by the Catholic Council on Working Life, Secretary of Labor Mitchell called the migrant farm worker "the excluded American" -- half a million of them "outside the protection of most laws that protect other American working people." And so are the million and a half other wage workers on farms who don't follow the crop harvests each year as the seasons travel north.

CORONADO, Calif., Nov. 29 -- Teams headed by Oswald Jacoby of Dallas and by Mrs. John Simon of St. Louis won the opening events in the American Contract Bridge League's national championship tournament here today after three sessions of play.

ACCRA, Ghana, Nov. 29 -- The Government here takes the position that strong measures are necessary to protect Ghana from internal plots and conspiracies that might destroy the young West African state.

A mantle of snow, varying in depth from one to three inches, covered lilac and forsythia buds in parts of Westchester County early yesterday morning after this season's first appreciable snowfall. But the snow melted quickly on the warm ground, leaving only untidy patches of white.
A major revision of the alternate -side-of-the-street parking program was announced yesterday. It will ease restrictions on about 70 per cent of the 9,694 blocks now covered.

Record sales and increased earnings were achieved by the West Virginia Pulp and Paper Company m its fiscal year ended Oct. 31, David L. Luke, president, reported in the preliminary annual statement issued for release today.

The New York Rangers and the Chicago Black Hawks are still tied for fifth place. Bruised and obviously tired from having played four games in five nights, the Rangers managed to hold the Hawks to a 2-2 tie in a National Hockey League game at Madison Square Garden last night.
A Columbia University official warned yesterday that more colleges and universities might withdraw from the Federal student loan program unless Congress repealed the antisubversion oath requirement.

The appointment of Rabbi Jacob J. Weinstein of Chicago as chairman of the National Committee for Labor Israel, was announced yesterday as the committee ended its thirty-sixth annual convention at the Commodore Hotel.
The use of ritual and ceremonial is increasing in all non-Roman Catholic churches, the Rev. Charles H. Graf, rector of the Protestant Episcopal Church of St. John's in the Village, said yesterday.

PETER A. SERKIN has made the grand leap from page turner to piano soloist in an extraordinarily short time. Only a few months ago he was acting as a modest aide to his father, Rudolf Serkin, and yesterday afternoon -- and again in the evening -- he appeared as guest artist in a Haydn program at the New School for Social Research.

Samuel L. Raines has sold two five-story buildings with forty-two apartments on a plot 100 by 100 feet at 2380-86 Grand Avenue, adjoining the northeast corner of West 184th Street, the Bronx. The property /s assessed at $140,000 and vras sold for cash over mortgages amounting to $140,000.
BOSTON, Nov. 29 (UPI) -The Montreal Canadiens closed in on a National Hockey League record tonight as Claude Provost scored twice in a 4-2 victory over the Boston Bruins.
Army's shocking loss to Navy by the biggest score for either team in their sixty-game rivalry provided a finale typical of the discombobulating developments of the intercollegiate football season.
POUND RIDGE, N. Y., Nov. 29 -- This rural town of grayflannel-suit commuters is wondering if it should shed its reputation as the only town in Westchester County without a real Town Hall.
OLD WESTBURY, L. I., Nov. 29 -- The Cornelius Vanderbilt Whitney estate, largest residential property remaining on the Long Island "Gold Coast," has been sold to a real estate developer.
EVERY woman wants some of it. No woman ever has enough of it. We are speaking of fur, of course. The Christmas gift giver who thinks along the line of fur is certain to make a lasting impression.

A 60 to 75 per cent rise in the Negro and Puerto Rican population of the twenty-two counties in the New York metropolitan region by 1980 has been forecast as "most probable." This would raise the total from 2,000,000 to 3,200,000 or 3,500,000.
Governor Rockefeller said last night that he favored having the United States Government supply information on birth control to foreign countries if the countries requested it.
Ch. Crikora Commotion, a black miniature poodle owned by Mrs. J. Donald Duncan of New York, became the winner of best in show last night in the Brooklyn Kennel Club's competition.

Proceeds from a holiday sale to be held in the Central Branch of the Young Women's Christian Association, 610 Lexington Avenue, on Wednesday will go to the annual campaign of the Y. W. C. A. of the City of New York.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 29. -- The Administration has increased its efforts to persuade West European countries to do more for themselves militarily, especially in manufacturing certain weapons.
JEROME ROBBINS made one of his infrequent contributions to television last night, endowing the "Ed Sullivan Show" on Channel 2 with a magnificent ballet segment.

SCARSDALE, N. Y., Nov. 29 -- Chappaqua, a 10-year-old gray gelding owned by Mr. and Mrs. Henry D. Paxson of Holicong, Pa., won the open working hunter championship of Boulder Brook Club's thirty-seventh annual fall horse show tonight.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 29 -- Cranberries were only the beginning. There will be more of the same arguments, for and against rigid law, when Congress gets back to work on a pending bill on color additives -- for food, drugs and cosmetics.

PITTSBURGH, Nov. 29 -- Shipments of finished steel moved better last week than had been expected. But many producers and users of steel still had their fingers crossed. The demand for steel was much greater than most steel sales people had expected.
BUENOS AIRES, Nov. 29 -Summer is in, schools are out and the scented, sultry days are stilling the political hubbub that is the winter style of this capital.
PANAMA, Nov. 29 -- Panama counted the cost today of the five-hour riot that broke out last night when a mob tried to gain entry to the Canal Zone.
Senator Jacob K. Javits implied yesterday that Governor Rockefeller was better qualified for the Presidency than Vice President Richard M. Nixon.
The vegetable parchment industry, one of the smaller segments of the huge pulp and paper industry, is working on ways to get bigger.
BLACKPOOL, England, Nov. 29 -- Aneurin Bevan, deputy leader of the Labor party, declared today that British socialism could not abandon its principles because of a temporary election reverse.

THE deal shown was bid to a slam that would have gone down two tricks if a spade had been opened instead of a diamond. Since a diamond was opened, the slam was made. The question is: Was it a good slam contract even though it could have been beaten?
MOSCOW, Nov. 29 -- Twelve of the correspondents and officials who accompanied Premier Khrushchev to the United States in September are about to publish a book called "Face to Face With America."
The day after Thanksgiving Day, Thomas Weaver, a Mamaroneck High School senior who will graduate next June, began shopping for a college.
