The new appeal of Monteverdi was demonstrated last night at the Lexington Avenue Young Men's and Young Women's Hebrew Association. Almost 900 persons, including forty standees, crowded into the association's hall to hear a program of works by the once almost forgotten composer.
HONG KONG, Nov. 29 -- Communist China charged today that United States officials kidnapped Chang Chien-yuh, an official of the Chinese Consulate, in Bombay Thursday.

The widow of Povl BangJensen, the former United Nations official who took his own life last week, will fly his ashes to Denmark within the next day or two. A funeral service will be held in Copenhagen on Thursday.
Waterfront employers in the port warned yesterday that time was running out in negotiations with the International Longshoremen's Association.

One of the largest fuel oil storage depots and pier facilities for docking oil tankers along the Eastern seaboard is planned on. a 500,000-square-foot site at the foot of Fifty-third Street, Brooklyn.
The atomic age holds the hope of power resources so plentiful that there will no longer be have-not nations, William L. Laurence, the science editor of The New York Times, declared yesterday.

Town Hall swarmed with jazz musicians Saturday, several of them in groups that were making their first concert appearances in New York. The newcomers were the Jazztet, featuring Art Farmer, trumpet and Benny Golson tenor saxophone; the Ornette Coleman Quartet and Ernestine Anderson, singer.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 29 -- President Eisenhower will discuss his forthcoming goodwill tour of eleven nations with legislative leaders of both parties at a White House breakfast tomorrow.

An American edition of] James Pope-Hennessy's biog-i Zraphy "Queen lary" will be published by Knopf on Feb. 15. Covering the eighty-six years of] the Queen's lifetime (1867-I 1953), the biography not only gives a portrait of a great public figure but also gives a panorama of nineteenth and twentieth-century European royalty and a social history of a changing world.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 29 (UPI) -- The 17-year-old son of an Iranian diplomat slapped an American high school girl and fired several shots in the air last night. Today he invoked his diplomatic immunity.
PITTSBURGH, Nov. 29 (AP) -- Bobby Layne today led the Pittsburgh Steelers to a 31-0 victory over the Philadelphia Eagles.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 29 -- President Eisenhower will request slightly more than $4,000,000,000 for foreign aid in the budget he will send to Congress next January, State Department officials said today.

James Scheuer, president of the Citizens Housing and Planning Council of New York, predicted yesterday that Mayor Wagner andthe Board of Estimate would make broad and constructive changes in the city's present methods of handling housing and slum clearance problems.
PARIS, Nov. 29 -- Robert Pesquet, already involved in a sensational political shooting last month, was formally charged today with an attempt to blow up the National Assembly building last year.

CHICAGO, Nov. 29 (AP) -- The Chicago Bears bore down on the fumbling Chicago Cardinals for a 31-7 victory today that kept alive the Bears' Western Division title hopes in the National Football League.
It is pure accident that within the past week two events occurred which, together, impinge upon our uncertain future in Outer Space. On the surface these events appear to be entirely unrelated.

John Haynes Holmes, minister emeritus of the Community Church of New York and a leading liberal figure in the stormy history of American civil liberties, was honored here yesterday on his eightieth birthday.
Members of the cast of "The Billy Barnes Revue," who were involved in a dispute with the producers of the stage presentation, will be seen on television here Saturday night.
The Fund for the Advancement of Education spent more than $12,000,000 in the last two and a half years trying to take the "lock-step" out of education.

Harriman Ripley Co., Inc., and Wood, Gundy Co., Inc., are joint managers of a group of investment bankers that has negotiated a direct placement with institutional investors of $20,000,000 of 5% per cent debentures of Province of Manitoba (Canada) dated Nov. 15 and due in 1984.

CLEVELAND, Nov. 29 (AP) -- San Francisco rode a six-minute scoring spree to a 21-20 victory over the Cleveland Browns today and remained tied for the Western Conference lead in the National Football League.
According to a group of well-established off-Broadway producers, who claim this time of the year as the half-way mark for their season, things are looking glum -- almost as glum as on Broadway.
A father in Brooklyn died early yesterday after having been struck on the head with a baseball bat by his 16-yearold son, who had interceded in a dispute between his parents.
The State Division of Housing has announced its approval of the conversion of a statessubsidized public housing project in Buffalo to an unsubsidized middle-income cooperative.

Phil King, a Giant back, got lost in his work yesterday. The Giants knew where to find him, but the Redskins sometimes didn't. This enabled King to score the Giants' fifth and last touchdown of the first half.
A police patrol car rescued two young couples yesterday after they spent thirty minutes aimlessly touring Brooklyn in a sports car as the prisoner of a former mental patient.
THANKSGIVING Day is past, Christmas is coming and the typical feminine heart is warm with the spirit of giving.
ALBANY, Nov. 29 -- Increasing voter resistance to school building bond issues was indicated in a report released today by Dr. James E. Allen Jr., State Commissioner of Education.
Two composers of greatly differing esthetics were on display at Saturday night's Composers Forum at the Donnell Library.
WHAT Dr. Spock is to freshman parents, the Consumers Union is to bewildered housewives.
As the United Nations General Assembly nears the end of its fourteenth regular session, due in a little over two weeks, it has at least four major issues with which to deal.

PHILADELHPIA, Nov. 29 (AP) John Stiegman, the football coach at Rutgers, will replace Steve Sebo as the head coach at the University of Pennsylvania, a reliable source told The Associated Press today.

JUST the feel and weight of the report of the Inter-departmental Committee on Traffic Safety together with its attached documents gives one some idea of the vigor of Dr. William John Ronan, Secretary to the Governor and chairman of the committee that submitted the report.

Not so long ago loyalty was a civic virtue, rooted in a sense of obligation to country. A citizen's readiness to express his loyalty, impelled by a conviction as deep as religious faith, was a natural response to recognition of this obligation. But increasing now is the number of those who think loyalty must be bought daily and to whom an oath is a ritualistic gesture.

The American Heart Association announced yesterday that Charles R. Cox, president of the Kennecott Copper Corporation, would serve as national chairman for the 1960 heart fund drive. The campaign will start in February.
BALTIMORE, Nov. 29. (UPI) -- The Baltimore Colts beat the Los Angeles Rams, 35 -- 21, today to remain tied with San Francisco for the Western Conference lead in the National Football League.
FOUR interesting young vocalists were presented by Aristo Artists at Town Hall yesterday afternoon.
STRASBOURG, France, Nov. 29 -- Probably the hottest news item during last week's session here of the parliament of the European common market was the word from Washington that "Dillon is coming."
The United States may change its schedule of space launchings, which at present does not include another lunar probe of the type that failed Thursday morning.

In the soccer season just ended, Eaglebrook School's varsity team won eight of its nine games and scored fifty-one goals, a school record. The students at Eaglebrook range in age from 9 to 16, but the team showed the kind of coordination that would have done credit to many an older squad.
JERUSALEM (Israeli Sector), Nov. 29 (AP) -- A 10,000-yearold village has been excavated in the Hula area of upper Galilee by a French-Israeli team of archaeologists.
A glance at the lively program of the Gramercy Chamber Ensemble's concert at Carnegie Recital Hall late yesterday afternoon will help to show the enterprise of this group of fine young musicians.

On the surface, an instantaneous (virtually) coast - to - coast transmission of facsimile first-class mail by an electronic scanning device -- disclosed the other day as under study by the Post Office Department -- appears to be a boon to the letter writer who still may be fretting under the onemail-delivery-a-day in his neighborhood.
VIENNA, Nov. 29 -- Premier Khrushchev arrived in Budapest this afternoon to attend the seventh congress of the Hungarian Communist party and the first to be convened since the 1956 uprising.
Mayor Wagner took a personal hand yesterday in trying to avert a strike at midnight tonight against New York's seven private bus companies.
The Carnegie Foundation for the Advancement of Teaching announced the election of three new trustees yesterday.
PARIS Nov. 30 -- Robert Pesquet, a French Right-winger accused of having illegally defended "patriotic" causes, continued a hunger strike today in protest against his arrest yesterday.

A State Labor Department official denied yesterday that the elimination of "abuses" in the payment of unemployment insurance benefits would improve substantially the competitive position of New York State employers.
Thousands of rush-hour passengers yesterday morning were affected by a series of delays on all three divisions of the subway system.
The Hilton Hotels Corporation increased its sales and profits in the first nine months of this year, according to the report of Conrad N. Hilton, president, issued for publication today.
The world invitation tournament, one of bowling's two major match-game individual tourneys, starts tomorrow in Chicago and will end Dec. 11.

ALBANY, Nov. 30 -- Many Republican Senators plan to take "a very careful look" at Governor Rockefeller's 1960-61 budget to see if it can accommodate an income-tax reduction, the Republican Senate leader said today.
Who would want to buy a century-old inland lighthouse?
BUDAPEST, Hungary, Nov. 30 (AP) -- All Soviet bloc nations favor "simultaneous and mutual withdrawal of troops stationed in foreign countries," Mr. Kadar said today at the Communist party congress.

ACCRA, Ghana, Nov. 30 -- A lone clarinetist sat on a bar stool in an Accra hotel the other night and played the blues. He was one of several American Negroes who have come to Ghana to live and work with varying success.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 30 -The Administration is not now planning any accelerated effort to develop the Saturn, the superthrust rocket that could catapult the United States into the lead in the space race.

LONDON, Nov. 30 -- The illuminated Christmas decorations on London's principal shopping streets were the chief casualties today of a wildcat strike of power-plant workers. The lights were put on limited schedules.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 30 (UPI) -- The Senate Republican leader, Everett McKinley Dirksen, predicted today that Congress would enact "some kind" of a civil-rights bill after the first major battle of its election-year session.

The city's campaign against chiseling on weight and price in retail meat shops eased yesterday. But Commissioner of Investigation Louis I. Kaplan warned would-be cheaters that the let-up was only temporary.

DENVER, Nov. 30 -- Spokesmen for leading commuter railroads and seven of the nation's big cities hammered out agreements here today on a four-point program that they will present to Congress in an effort to save deficit-ridden suburban rail service.
PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 30 -Stockholders of Artloom Industries, Inc., voted at their annual meeting here today to change the name of the organization to Trans-United Industries, Inc.
LONDON, Nov. 30 -- Sir Winston Churchill returned to the House of Commons today on his eighty-fifth birthday and received lively acclaim from both sides of the chamber.

NOW that one of the biggest party seasons is in full swing, even women who avoid entertaining earlier in the year are steeped in guest lists. According to veteran party-givers, advance planning is the most important requisite for a painless party -- short of hiring a cook, butler and maid. The following schedule is designed to help the novice and avoid last-minute turmoil.

WESTBURY, L. I., Nov. 30 -- The 29,085 fans who came out to Roosevelt Raceway tonight to make a last-ditch stand in the fight to get even for the season set a world record and ten track marks at the mutuel machines.
A tea dance on Sunday afternoon in the Embassy Club of the Sheraton-East will augment the welfare fund of the Russian Nobility Association in America.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 30 -- The purchasing power of the farmer's dollar stood today at its lowest figure in nineteen years, as measured by the parity yardstick. The Depart ment of Agriculture's monthly farm price report showed that prices received by farmers for crops and livestock fell 2 per cent in the month ended on Nov. 15.

The Chemical Construction Corporation, builder of chemical and petroleum plants, has leased 117,000 square feet of space in the thirty-three-story office building being erected by Uris Brothers at 320 Park Avenue. The structure is going up on the west side of the avenue, between Fiftieth and Fifty-first Streets.

ATLANTA, Nov. 30 (UPI) -The Atlanta school board, in compliance with a Federal court order, proposed today that the city's 116,000 school children be admitted to classes "without regard to race or color."
DENVER, Nov. 30 -- Senator John F. Kennedy declared here today that it might be necessary to abate Federal income taxes to offset in part real estate taxes the individual pays to local government.
Is Alex Olmedo in the professional ranks? Did Jack Kramer's office in Los Angeles let the cat out of the bag prematurely?
Some of the crowd noises heard in television coverage of President Eisenhower's trip to Europe last August were dubbed in by technicians in New York.
Mayor Wagner supported yesterday the position taken by Senator John F. Kennedy, Democrat of Massachusetts, on the use of foreign-aid funds to promote birth control.

ATLANTIC CITY, Nov. 30 -A Westinghouse leader today hailed the United States' advances in atomic naval propulsion as an example of a "sustained, stable" program in the competition with the Soviet Union.

NORFOLK, Va., Nov. 30 (UPI) -- Four amateur salvagers who worked for five months to raise the sunken hulk of a tanker stood in the bitter cold here today and watched their dreams of a fortune all but vanish.
PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 30 (AP) -- The University of Alabama today appeared as the most likely opponent for Penn State in the first Liberty Bowl football game.
ST. PETERSBURG, Nov. 30 -- The log-jam in trading among the major leaguers finally gave way today at the opening of the minor league baseball convention.

Chunky Eddie Armstrong of Elizabeth, N. J., folled the dancing tactics of Chico Velez of Puerto Rico and scored a unanimous decision in the ten-round main event last night at the Academy of Music. Armstrong weighed 139 1/2 pounds and Velez 134 1/2.

INDIANAPOLIS, Nov. 30 -Martin B. McNeally, national commander of the American Legion, moved tonight to challenge in court the racial discrimination policy followed by the 40 8, the Legion's "fun and frolic" subsidiary.

CORONADO, Calif., Nov. 30 Long-time bridge stars led a field of 280 pairs tonight into the second session of play in the mixed pair contest of the American Contract Bridge League's thirty-fourth annual winter national tournament.
A seventy-foot Norway spruce, chosen after its dimensions were scrutinized like those of a beauty queen, was raised at Rockefeller Center yesterday.

SCARSDALE, N. Y., Nov. 30 -- Rubber posts installed on treacherous Breakneck Hill a week ago to reduce accidents have created a new sport for hot rod drivers and vandals, Westchester County highway officials reported today.
A dock-labor seniority plan was put in effect as a trial yesterday at the Hudson River luxury liner piers.

After the usual display of threatening bluster Michael J. Quill has withdrawn the strike call against privately owned bus companies in New York City. In doing so he yielded to Mayor Wagner's somewhat belated intervention.

HOWARD MITCHELL is curious about the world he lives in, and the programs of the National Symphony Orchestra of Washington reflect his alertness to the contemporary scene. In the visitors' program at Carnegie Hall last night, everything but the opening "Magic Flute" Overture belonged to the twentieth century.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 30 -- The Interstate Commerce Commission agreed today to co-sign Lehigh Valley Railroad notes for fifteen-year loans totaling $5,923,000.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Nov. 30 -- The problem of building the box-office appeal of a Biblical story was explained today by Samuel G. Engel, producer of "Story of Ruth," which is being filmed at the studio of Twentieth Century-Fox.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 30 (AP) -- Twenty-three persons urged the Supreme Court today to order a new trial for Caryl Chessman.
Fankie Carbo, the man called the "underworld boxing commissioner" by the District Attorney's office, was sentenced yesterday to two years in jail.

FOR better or for worse, 1959 will long be remembered as the year of the cranberry. Although at this late date the picture is not entirely clear, the fact remains that berries without taint are available in most grocery stores throughout the city. Here are ways to relish them.

Tony Genovese, the strongest boy in Bishop Loughlin High School, huffed once and pushed 180 pounds of weighted barbell over his head. His chest heaved slightly. Then he gently set the barbell down. "I used to lift the front ends of Volkswagens in my spare time," he said.
Louis W. Holschuh will retire as chairman of Moody's Investors Service on Dec. 31. No successor has been named. Donald B. McCruden cotinues as president and chief executive officer.
Five blocks of Nassau Street in the Downtown financial district will be for pedestrians only, from noon to 2 P. M. on business days, beginning tomorrow.
The proposal to fluoridate the city's water supply will be pushed to an open showdown vote in the Board of Estimate, Mayor Wagner made clear yesterday.

The New York thoroughbred racing season came to an end yesterday, with 31,545 fans attending the program at Aqueduct. Occupying the feature spot was the Queens County Handicap, a mile race that had a gross value of $28,300.

The British Labor party ended its annual conference on Sunday without falling apart or swinging to the Left or Right. In the circumstances, this was a satisfactory result for the Socialist movement, which suffered its third electoral defeat in a row on Oct. 8. There are still obvious differences of opinion, especially on the subject of nationalization or public ownership, but they are not fundamental and the debate will continue within the Labor party.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange moved irregularly to close 6 points off to 13 points up. (A point equals 5 cents a bale.)
BUENOS AIRES, Nov. 30 -- Blank protest ballots, attributed mainly to Peronists, dominated the returns counted today in the Jujuy provincial elections.

The impact of present steel shortages has forced 25 per cent of all manufacturing companies to curtail production, according to a survey of 415 purchasing executives. The report was issued yesterday by Purchasing Week, a trade paper.
A study of New York slum conditions will be shown in a telecast on WRCA-TV (Channel 4) on Sunday, Dec. 20, from 2 to 2:30 P. M.
BOSTON, Nov. 30 (AP) -- School safety has increased measurably in the year since Dec. 1, 1958, when ninety-five children and nuns died in a fire at Our Lady of Angels School in Chicago.

Investment bankers headed by F. Eberstadt Co. offered yesterday 250,000 shares of the common stock of Seligman Latz, Inc., operator of a chain of beauty salons. This was the first public distribution of the company's stock .The offering price was $12.75 a share.
WARSAW, Nov. 30 (AP) -Poland's United Peasant party wound up a four-day congress today with a resolution underlining close support of the Communist party.

Victor M. Camacho, the 49year-old grocer who shot and killed a robber on Sunday, was released in $500 bail yesterday on a charge of violating the Sullivan Law. He had no permit for the pistol he used.
MIAMI, Fla., Nov. 30 -- Congress was urged today to increase financial assistance to the aged so that they could live out their lives in health.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 30 -- The statement of the Roman Catholic Bishops of the United States opposing any American Governmental assistance to birth control anywhere has had the immediate and invaluable effect of moving the topic from the areas of private morals and theology into the realm of public discussion of political action.
SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 30 -- The forty-eighth season of the San Francisco Symphony Orchestra, opening Wednesday night in the War Memorial Opera House, came precariously close to cancellation.
A shop for the sale of gifts made by the blind throughout the state was opened yesterday by Mrs. Nelson A. Rockefeller at 4 West Fifty-fourth Street.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 30 -- The Navy opens a new chapter in its history tomorrow as the Bureau of Naval Weapons goes into operation several months ahead of schedule.
Two men were fatally injured and another was critically hurt yesterday in a transformer explosion in a Consolidated Edison Company powerhouse at Seventy-fifth Street and the East River.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 30 -- The Government's short-term interest costs took an unusually sharp jump to another new high level this week.

JERUSALEM (Jordanian Section) Nov. 30 (Reuters) -- Archbishop Athenagoras, Patriarch of Istanbul and spiritual leader of the Eastern Orthodox Church, has held talks with church leader here aimed at a union of the Eastern and Western churches, it was announced here today.
LONDON, Nov. 30 -- Prices moved aimlessly on the stockmarket here today. Buyers remained cautious and very selective.
Five of the ten inductees to the Football Hall of Fame were introduced at the Manhattan Hotel yesterday during the season's last luncheon of the New York Football Writers Association.

TWENTY - EIGHT minutes (from Times Square) spent on the Seventh Avenue subway will take you to the door of the Brooklyn Museum and just about as fine an installation of first-rate sculpture as you are likely to see in some time.
LONDON, Nov. 30 -- Central London's "pink zone" traffic speed-up plan went into effect today and was promptly termed a success.

SACRAMENTO, Calif., Nov. 30 (UPI) -- Gov. Edmund G. Brown of California, a Roman Catholic, said today that he favored giving other countries a free hand in spending United States foreign aid for or against birth control.

VIENNA, Nov. 30 -- Poland's Communist party, placed in power and kept in power only by Soviet might, has been thrown into confusion and bitterness by a leader it once followed out of hope and now follows out of desperation.
BONN, Germany, Nov. 30 -- Chancellor Konrad Adenauer and Mayor Willy Brandt of West Berlin agreed today that any change in the Allies' status in Berlin should be resisted.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The day is not far distant when something will have to be done to relieve congestion at New York's vast airport. On a recent occasion many people to our personal knowledge experienced delays in transferring from one terminal to another and quite a number missed connecting planes because of the tardy arrival of airport buses.

The lawyer for Magistrate Anthony E. Maglio, who went on trial yesterday for conduct unbecoming a judge, said the magistrate had become provoked when a probationary policeman behaved "fresh and nasty and said something in the nature of an oath" to him in open court.

SYRACUSE, Nov. 30 (UPI) -- The frozen and snow-covered turf of Archbold Stadium forced Syracuse to drill indoors today as the nation's top collegiate football team began final drills for the last game of the regular season.

Public utility borrowing dominated new financing in November for the second successive month. Public offerings of bonds here for such corporations were the largest since April, 1958. Stock flotations were the second largest since that month.

The Montgomery, Ala., Water Works and Sanitary Sewer Board sold yesterday $10,000,000 of water bonds due 1960 to 1981 to investment bankers led by Smith, Barney Co.; Blyth Co., Inc., and Equitable Securities Corporation.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 30 (UPI) -- Scientists reported today evidence of water vapor in the atmosphere of Venus. This raised the possibility of life on the bright planet.
BLACKPOOL, England, Nov. 30 -- "Labor, What Now?" asked a newspaper poster.
A regular patron of the IRT West Side Subway recently boarded his customary morning rush-hour train at Seventy-ninth Street and Broadway on its way to midtown Manhattan and his waiting desk.

TRENTON, Nov. 30 -- Five major drug concerns were exonerated today of price-fixing and criminal conspiracy in the sale of $53,600,000 worth of Salk polio vaccine to Federal, state and local government agencies.

Directors of the Universal Pictures Company, Inc., voted yesterday a dividend of $1 a share, payable to common stock holders on Dec. 24. This is the first distribution to be made on the common stock since December, 1957, when an extra of 25 cents and a year-end dividend of 25 cents, brought the total that year to $1.25 a share.

Short covering strengthened potato futures early yesterday on the New York Mercantile Exchange. The buying was influenced by reports of cold weather in Florida which might damage the early spring harvest.
NEWARK, Nov. 30 -- The head cashier of the Essex County Probation Department was indicted today by the county grand jury on a charge of embezzling $26,575 in department funds.

Tentative plans for golf courses, an equestrian center, facilities for tennis, swimming and skeet-shooting or private homes were outlined yesterday by the buyer of the 530-acre Cornelius Vanderbilt Whitney estate in Old Westbury, L. I.
DETROIT, Nov. 30 -- The auto industry is tentatively scheduling a record output of passenger cars for the first quarter of 1960.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 30 -- Israel offered today to negotiate with her Arab neighbors on aspects of the problem of Palestinian Arab refugees displaced by the ArabIsraeli war eleven years ago.
The second annual Merit Award Dinner for the benefit of Casa Italiana of Columbia University will be held in the Men's Faculty Club of Columbia on Thursday.

NICE, France, Nov. 30 -Twelve days and many thousand miles from the final event of the 1959 motor racing season, the United States Grand Prix at Sebring, Fla., on Dec. 12, sides are already being chosen up for next year.
" CRIME OF PASSION," this week's offering on "The Play of the Week" over WNTA-TV (Channel 13), provided some absorbing ideas about cynicism and opportunism in a Communist cell.

The film version of the Tennessee Williams drama, "Suddenly, Last Summer," has been booked into both the Criterion Theatre, Broadway and Forty-fifth Street, and the Sutton Theatre, Third Avenue and Fifty-seventh Street. It will have its world premiere at the Criterion Dec. 22 and continuous screenings will start the following day at the Criterion and the Sutton.

COLOGNE, Germany, Nov. 30 -- The critics and the audiences are in disagreement over Nicolas Nabokov's three-act opera "The Death of Rasputin." It had its world premiere here last week and has been sung once since.
Market values on the New York Stock Exchange rose about $3,200,000,000 -- 0.8 per cent -- yesterday as prices advanced for the ninth successive day.
CHICAGO, Nov. 30 (UPI) -Joe Foss, a former governor of South Dakota and Marine World War II flying hero, was named today as commissioner of the American Football League.

NEW DELHI, India, Nov. 30 -- Four and one-half busy days of conferences, receptions, formal dinners and a bit of sightseeing await President Eisenhower here, according to a program announced by the Indian Government tonight.
BENGHAZI, Libya, Nov. 30 -"The Prime Minister is at a party in the hotel saying goodby," a receptionist told the visitor.

DOAK WALKER arrived in town early. He's here primarily for his induction tonight into football's Hall of Fame, but he couldn't resist the opportunity for a week-end visit with his old buddy from Southern Methodist, Kyle Rote of the Giants. At the dinner that capped the Charley Conerly Day festivities, Kyle was proudly introducing the Doaker to his team-mates.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The two letters in your Nov. 16 and 17 columns asked why branch libraries don't open at 9 A. M. and regretted that "they are closed on Saturdays and holidays." Such queries are reassuring for the interest they indicate in library service, yet regrettable for the situation which gives rise to them.

" Self Help" might well be the motto of the occupational therapy program at the Hospital for Special Surgery, 535 East Seventieth Street. The program will benefit from the handiwork of participating patients at the annual Christmas sale on Thursday.

A dramatization of Thomas Wolfe's 912-page novel, "Of Time and the River," has been added to Roger L. Stevens' prospects for next season. The book is the late novelist's sequel to his "Look Homeward, Angel," which Ketti Frings adapted.

ST. LOUIS, Nov. 30 -- Attorneys for Matthew J. Connelly asked the Eighth Circuit Court of Appeals here today to reconsider its denial of his motion for a new trial. They petitioned the court to rehear certain points of their arguments.

PARIS, Nov. 30 -- A British minister proposed today that quarterly political consulations among the six members of the European Common Market be regularly followed by a ministerial meeting including Britain.

A contract made by a subsidiary of Webb Knapp, Inc., to purchase the 260-acre Los Angeles studio property of the Twentieth Century-Fox Film Corporation has been extended ninety days. The contract became effective May 1 and was due to expire today.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 30 -- Rear Admiral Paul David Stroop's new job, in his own words, is to merge the Navy's Bureaus of Ordnance and Aeronautics and "keep the final products from smelling too much like an elephant."

The failure of both ships to slow to a moderate speed was the main cause of the crash of the Grace liner Santa Rosa and the tanker Valchem in fog off Atlantic City last March, the Coast Guard reported here yesterday.
Construction is scheduled to start in about ten days on a 293-family middle-income cooperative apartment house on Bronx Park East in the Bronx.
An impressive debut recital was sung at Town Hall last night by the Peruvian soprano Juanita Porras.
HEMPSTEAD, L. I., Nov. 30 -- Close on the heels of its most successful football campaign, Hofstra opens its basketball season here tomorrow against Long Island University.

The chairman of the Board of Higher Education declared yesterday that to the best of his knowledge no persons belonging to subversive organizations were in the employ of the municipal colleges as of Oct. 31.
The Communist party's state convention has criticized Governor Rockefeller, former President Harry S. Truman and former Secretary of State Dean Acheson for their stands on the atomic bomb.
An executive title rarely seen among the many that dot agency rosters is that of "vice president in charge of new business."

WASHINGTON, Nov. 30 -- Banks with particularly large holdings of cash in their vaults will be permitted to count part of that cash in the reserves they are required to maintain, beginning this week, the Federal Reserve Board announced today.
Alan Freed, the rock 'n' roll disk jockey, refused yesterday to testify before a grand jury under rules that would have made him liable to prosecution on the basis of his own testimony.
MONTGOMERY, Ala., Nov. 30 (UPI) -- The Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr., Negro integration leader here, will move to Atlanta in the hope of expanding the fight for integration in the South.
Chief Judge-elect Charles S. Desmond, who has been an advocate of all-out state court reform, endorsed last night the compromise reorganization plan approved by the Legislature last spring.
The Ford Foundation will give grants totaling $559,000 to four professional repertory the atres to help them retain firstrank performers on long-term contracts. will
Stock prices on the New York Stock Exchange managed to eke out a slight gain last month.

Congressional leaders of both parties yesterday pledged support to President Eisenhower on his forthcoming world tour. In the words of Democratic Senate Leader Johnson, the President will take with him our prayers and our hopes for success in his quest for peace.

A special group of seventyfive uniformed patrolmen, all at least six feet tall and under the age of 30, will be asigned to any city area where unusual crime conditions prevail. Commissioner Stephen P. Kennedy announced yesterday.

The New York Coliseum was transformed yesterday into a jungle of hissing valves, clanking pumps and blinking computers. The occasion was the opening of the twentyseventh Exposition of Chemical Industries, which is expected to draw some 40,000 industry officials from the United States and abroad.
The first of four special Christmas stations for the sale of stamps was set up yesterday by the New York Post Office.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 30 -- Afghanistan's chief delegate complained today about reporting on his country's affairs.

Miss Margaret O'Meara, 77 years old, was found dead in bed yesterday in her first-floor apartment at 277 Washington Avenue, in the Clinton Hill section of Brooklyn. The police said she apparently had been raped and murdered.
ROME, Nov. 30 -- Premier Antonio Segni flew to Paris today on his way to London, where he will arrive tomorrow with Foreign Minister Giuseppe Pella for a three-day official visit.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 30 -- Democratic and Republican Congressional leaders gave bipartisan approval today to President Eisenhower's forthcoming venture into personal diplomacy in an eleven-nation tour.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Your post-election editorial noted the serious defects of the present New York State Constitution, which requires the voters almost every year to decide on a large number of constitutional amendments, many of which are difficult to understand and relate to matters which have no business being in a constitution.
A strike threatened against the city's seven private bus companies was averted last night four and a half hours before the midnight deadline.
CHICAGO, Nov. 30 -- A reduction of the taxation burden is one of the big jobs facing the nation as it enters the Nineteen Sixties, Maurice H. Stans, the Federal budget director, said here tonight.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 30 -- After seven weeks of intensive negotiations, the twelve nations active in the Antarctic regions agreed today on a treaty banning military activity in that continent and providing a new type of inspection system to enforce it.

St. Thomas' Protestant Episcopal Chapel will observe the beginning of its second century with a benefit bazaar, to be held at 229 East Fifty-ninth Street tomorrow and Thursday from noon until 10 P. M.

BELHAVEN, N. C., Nov. 30 -- Whatever the population of winter geese on Lake Mattamuskeet may be, this area and the gooselands of Cairo (pronounced Kayroe), Ill., are almost surely the two best in the country.
The real estate industry here rejected yesterday as "fundamentally wrong" the new zoning plan drafted for the City Planning Commission.

LEOPOLDVILLE, Belgian Congo, Nov. 30 -- The Belgian Minister of the Congo, Auguste de Schrijver, returned to Leopoldville today for a series of meetings with Leopoldville nationalist parties to seek their participation in local elections next month.
A fellowship offering $3,000 for study abroad in 1960 has been established by the New York chapter of the American Institute of Architects.
INDIANAPOLIS, Nov. 30 (AP) -- Two Baltimore members of the huge Carpenters Union asked a court today to appoint monitors for their union to halt what they described as widespread corruption.

BAL HARBOUR, Fla., Nov. 30 -- The "socialist pattern of society" to which India is dedicated is rooted in age-old respect for the freedom of individuals and for the investment capital imported from the outside world, the nation's investment bankers were told here today.
RICHMOND, Va., Nov. 30 -- The Virginia Museum of Fine Arts will open nightly next year.
VIENNA, Nov. 30 -- The First Secretary of the Hungarian Communist party announced today that Soviet forces would remain in Hungary as long as the international situation required their presence.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 30 -- Tunisia urged France today to agree to negotiations with Algerian rebel leaders on a cease-fire and arrangements for a referendum that would decide Algeria's status.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 30 -- Neil H. McElroy's resignation as Secretary of Defense will be announced tomorrow.
The Nation, a weekly magazine, declared editorially yesterday that The New York World-Telegram and The Sun had been "grossly unfair" in discharging Fred J. Cook.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 30 -- Eleven large commercial banks of the United States will participate in a $40,000,000 revolving credit for the Union of South Africa, due to be signed tomorrow. The agreement, for a two-year period, will supersede an existing revolving credit of $20,000,000, which expires next Jan. 23.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 30 (AP) -- The Air Force announced today an unofficial endurance record of 80 hours 36 minutes by a B-47 jet bomber. It said the plane had covered 39,200 miles, also a record.

WHEN Mortimer Phillips, proprietor of the Leonard Baking Company, brought his newest creations to this department recently there was an unprecedented rush of volunteer tasters. As the cakes rapidly vanished, everyone expressed unqualified approval and happily ignored the thought of the extra pounds gained.

EASILY the nicest part of Christmas is the children. The wonder and delight they bring to the holidays enable friends and relatives to enjoy a vicarious visit to childhood, the land of the marvelous Now.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 30 (AP) -- The case of the 17-year-old son of an Iranian official who slapped his 16-year-old girl friend was closed today without prosecution.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 30 -The Federal Communications Commission questioned today whether Jack Barry and Dan Enright were qualified to own a Florida radio station, because they had operated rigged television quiz shows.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 30 (AP) -- The Department of Commerce said today that United States imports of semi-fabricated aluminum products doubled in the first nine months of 1959.

Ever since 1955 the U. N. Assembly has had "the question of Algeria" on its agenda at each annual meeting. This year the so-called "question" is again on the Assembly's bill of fare. The item was introduced by twenty-five Asian and African states ranging all the way from Afghanistan to Yemen.
Weakness in Treasury bills extended throughout the market for fixed-interest obligations yesterday.
Because two Westchester County business men are basketball buffs, the East is going to be represented for the first time by an industrial team pointing for an Olympic berth.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 30 (AP) -- The continuing "bumper baby crop" is a potential threat to future United States living standards, an economist told Congress today.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 30 (AP) -- In order to compete with the Defense Department in hiring research contractors, the civilian space agency is seeking the right to release patents readily to private concerns developing space age inventions on Government jobs.

An American edition of Andre Gorz's "The Traitor" will be published Dec. 14 by Simon Schuster. It has been translated by Richard Howard. The author is a member of Jean-Paul Sartre's circle. In his book he examines the individual in relation to the forces that move "our complicated" world.

NEW DELHI, India, Nov. 30 -- Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru told Parliament today that the Bombay incident involving a United States marine and a Chinese Communist official was an "extraordinary occurrence" that sounded "more like some piece of fiction than reality."
CHICAGO, Nov. 30 (AP) -- The report of today's livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:

Local truckers and shippers are opposing a proposal that the Interstate Commerce Commission exercise jurisdiction over all local truckers who move goods to or from terminals as part of interstate shipment.
PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 30 (AP) -- The National Football League won the first round of the expected player war with the new American Football League today, drafting and tying up two top college stars.
MELBOURNE, Australia, Nov. 30 (UPI) -- Neale Fraser, Australian Davis Cup tennis star, announced today he had turned down a $41,000 offer from Jack Kramer to turn professional.

" THERE now appeared upon the ravaged scene," Sir Winston Churchill wrote, "an Angel of Deliverance, the noblest patriot of France, the most splendid of her heroes, the most beloved of her saints, the most inspiring of her memories, the peasant Maid, the ever-shining, ever-glorious Joan of Arc."

GENEVA, Nov. 30 -- The United States, Britain and the Soviet Union agreed today on a detailed plan for a control organization to be set up as soon as a treaty outlawing nuclear weapons tests is signed.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 30 -- The United States Senate made public its payrolls today for the first time in eleven years.

Abraham M. Sonnabend, Boston real estate and hotel operator, said yesterday he "was not and is not" prepared now or in the foreseeable future to conduct a proxy contest against Allan P. Kirby for his control of the Alleghany Corporation.

The State Banking Department proposed yesterday that banks and trust companies be permitted to make a $10 minimum interest charge on installment loans made to finance insurance premiums. Richard S. Simmons, Deputy Superintendent of Banks, said the charge should encourage banks to engage actively in this business, particularly in financing assigned risk motor vehicle insurance.
CHICAGO, Nov. 30 -- Fifty-six persons were injured this morning in a rush-hour crash of two elevated trains. A similar accident at the site three years ago took eight lives and injured 200.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 30 (UPI) -- Vicious crimes such as murder, rape, stabbings and violent assault are increasing, J. Edgar Hoover reported today.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 30 -- The State Department said today that a complaint by Communist China that one of its diplomats had been kidnapped by United States Authorities in Bombay was "absurd."

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Ambassador Henry Cabot Lodge gave an authoritative and truly eloquent interpretation of the so-called "spirit of Camp David." His assurance that "nothing happened at Camp David which requires us to condone evil" is particularly gratifying.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 30 (UPI) -- The Board of Immigration appeals today upheld an order to deport William Heikkila, a San Francisco draftsman, to his native Finland.

TRENTON, Nov. 30 -- Gov. Robert B. Meyner outlined a program today that he said could enable the Federal Government to end the nation's major migrant-labor problems. He called on Washington to undertake the program without delay.
DETROIT, Nov. 30 -- The directors of the American Motors Corporation recommended today a three-for-one stock split.

PINAR DEL RIO, Cuba, Nov. 30 -- The Cuban Government of Fidel Castro revived its military trials today with two United States citizens among thirty-nine persons accused of counterrevolutionary activity.
DENVER, Nov. 30 -- The 13,000 municipalities represented in the American Municipal Association will be asked to use a uniform sign to designate public parking areas.

The earnings of the Standard Oil Company (New Jersey) in the first ten months of this year rose 17.6 per cent above the 1958 level, virtually assuring earnings for the year "well above" those of 1958. Last year $562,475,239, or $2.72 a share, was cleared.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 1 -- An Arab speaker called on the United Nations today to take a stronger attitude on Algeria.

MONTOURSVILLE, Pa., Dec. 1 -- A twin-engine airliner, swinging away from the airport after trying an instrument approach, rammed a 1,400-foot mountain today in a snowstorm. Twenty-five of the twenty-six aboard were killed.
The Justice Department has started a nation-wide investigation of the shipping industry for possible violations of the antitrust laws and the Shipping Act of 1916.
The future is bright for sellers of cotton textiles, it was asserted yesterday by W. Ray Bell, president of the Association of Cotton Textile Merchants of New York.
THE 1959-60 television season may be remembered as one in which the "Ford Startime" series presented Ingrid Bergman and Alec Guinness in two successful dramas.

Mrs. Norman J. Block, gift chairman of the May Festival Ball, gave a tea yesterday afternoon in the Gold Suite of the Sheraton-East for members of the various committees who are working for the success of the ball.

LONDON, Dec. 1 (UPI) -Nino Valdes scored a technical knockout over Brian London and Mike De John gained an unpopular decision over Dick Richardson of Wales tonight in feature bouts on an all-heavy-weight program.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 -- Following is the text of the Antarctic treaty signed here today: ...
CHICAGO, Dec. 1 -- A sculptor won first prize in the sixtythird American Exhibition of Painting and Sculpture that opens tomorrow at the Art Institute of Chicago.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 (AP) -- Following are the texts of letters exchanged by retiring Secretary of Defense Neil H. McElroy and President Eisenhower and of the citation accompanying today's award of the Medal of Freedom to Mr. McElroy:

The appointment of William T. French as president and chief executive officer of the Associated Merchandising Corporation, effective Jan. 1, was announced yesterday by A. H. Burchfield, chairman of Associated Merchandising and president of the Joseph Horne Company, Pittsburgh department store.
TRENTON, Dec. 1 -- Gov. Robert B. Meyner signed a bill giving the state a green light today to proceed with the sale of $66,800,000 in bonds to expand eight of its institutions for higher education.

LONDON, Dec. 1 -- The Soviet Union and Britain signed an agreement today on the expansion of cultural exchanges. The accord foreshadowed the end of Soviet jamming of British Broadcasting Corporation programs.

General of the Army Douglas MacArthur, Syracuse University's top-ranking team and the ten new inductees in the Hall of Fame were warmly toasted last night as football's hot stove was ignited with a roar at the biggest local gridiron gathering of the winter circuit.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 -- Robert Murphy, Under Secretary of State, warned today that instability or weakness in the non-Communist world could lead to Soviet miscalculations that might produce disaster for mankind.

ST. PETERSBURG, Dec. 1 -Bobby Thomson, who once struck one of the most dramatic home runs in baseball history, was traded out of the National League yesterday for a young pitcher who has yet to make his mark in the majors.

HOBOKEN, N. J., Dec. 1 (UPI) -- The Delaware, Lackawanna and Western Railroad Company reported a net loss today of $3,536,536 in the first ten months of 1959, and said it expected a deficit of close to $4 million for the year.
LONDON, Dec. 1 -- Premier Antonio Segni of Italy confered with Prime Minister Harold Macmillan today on European cooperation in the fields of diplomacy and economics.

NEW ROCHELLE, N. Y., Dec. 1 -- The Board of Education here decided today to replace the outmoded Lincoln School with a spacious modern structure. Some Negroes objected to the plan and others endorsed it.
NEWPORT NEWS, Va., Dec. 1 (UPI) -- Federal District Judge Walter E. Hoffman ordered the Newport News School Board today to submit a desegregation plan to supplant one he termed "meaningless."
LISBON, Portugal, Dec. 1 -A pro-monarchist statement published in three Lisbon newspapers today raised speculation that the monarchy might be restored in Portugal.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 (AP) -- The Parcel Post Association, a business organization, asked the Federal District Court today to cancel an increase in parcel post rates that is scheduled to take effect Feb. 1, 1960.
The chairman of the City Planning Commission hit back yesterday at the Metropolitan Association of Real Estate Boards for its rejection on Monday of the zoning plan drafted for the commission.
A Harvard historian warned yesterday that any move to restrict the right of Puerto Ricans to migrate here would tend to pervert the democratic character of the city.
Leo Burnett dropped a bombshell on the magazine industry yesterday.
BELHAVEN, N. C., Dec. 1 -John Jefferson, a Confederate to the death, found out at length today why the Confederates lost: the Yankees could not shoot, but starved them out.

CORONADO, Calif., Dec. 1 -- The American Contract Bridge League today selected two of the four teams that will represent the United States in the next world championship tournament, which will be played next April at Turin, Italy.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 (AP) -- The Federal Government has put together a comprehensive inventory of the areas throughout the country over which it has exclusive jurisdiction.

Optimistic statements about the outlook for the economy in 1960 -- such as "it will be the best year ever" -- are being issued on all sides as this year nears its end. A sharp note of caution, however, has been sounded by the First National City Bank in its latest monthly survey of business conditions.

PINAR DEL RIO, Cuba, Dec. 1 -- The Cuban lawyer for Austin Frank Young, an American being tried here for sedition, told a court martial today that the execution of his client would give the United States a pretext to attack Cuba.

MOSCOW, Dec. 1 -- A group of Soviet university students back from a month's tour of the United States said today they thought the cultural level of their own comrades was higher than that of American students.
GREENWICH, Conn., Dec. 1 -- A protest by a civic group is forcing this town to spend $6,000 tomorrow on a public referendum.

The privately owned Canadian Pacific Railway for the first ten months of this year reported a net operating income of $27,358,864, but the Government-owned Canadian National Railways in the same period sustained a net operating loss of $1,327,000.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 -- The Antarctic treaty signed here today culminates a dozen years marked, at times, by naval demonstrations, some gunfire and repeated negotiations.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 (UPI) -- Victor Perlo, a former Government economist once described at a Congressional hearing as a Communist, filed suit today in an attempt to force the Statee Department to issue him a passport.
LONDON, Dec. 1 (AP) -- A huge meteorite is believed to have struck the Outer Hebrides in the last few days.

CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla., Dec. 1 (AP) -- A movie camera soared 300 miles into space today in the nose cone of a Thor missile, but was lost at sea with perhaps the first high-altitude color pictures of the earth.

WASHINGTON, .Dec. 1 -- Raymond J. Saulnier, chairman of the President's Council of Economic Advisers, has been appointed to the five-man board of directors of Fanny May -the Federal National Mortgage Association.
The Citizens Watchdog Committee, which Borough President Hulan E. Jack set up for the Penn Station South slum clearance project, has split into two camps.
LAWRENCE, L. I., Dec. 1 -Senator Jacob K. Javits defended the United Jewish Appeal here tonight against charges that it raised money for the State of Israel.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 -- Five anti-Castro Cubans were arrested Sunday as they were about to load three bombs into a rented plane on a little-used airstrip south of Miami.

Angel Rosario of 725 Fox Street, the Bronx, a 19-year-old messenger convicted Monday of unlawful assembly and of amassing an arsenal of weapons for a gang war, was placed on five years' probation yesterday.
Nothing is quite as transitory as a transit crisis.

Enkells-Rakoff Co., realty operators, have contracted to buy the three-story store and apartment building at 30-87 Brighton Beach Avenue and Brighton Fourth Street, Brooklyn. The property is being sold by Sarah Frankel in its first change of ownership in thirtytwo years.

HOUSTON, Dec. 1 (UPI) -The world lightweight champion, Joe Brown, was a 12-to-5 favorite today to retain his title in his eighth defense tomorrow, even though his foe, Dave Charnley, is the type the title-holder has found hardest to beat.

I wish to register vigorous protest to the spirit of the Nov. 21 editorial entitled "The Disarmament Debate," particularly at the point of the final sentence, where the editorial speaks of "pious resolutions" to describe United Nations action in connection with nuclear disarmament.
Protestant leaders and Hungarian exiles here denounced the acting Hungarian chief delegate at the United Nations yesterday as a tool of the Communist police.
Charles R. Sligh Jr., executive vice president of the National Association of Manufacturers, said yesterday that a major crisis was at hand in labor-management relations.

THE earnest young instrumentalists who refine their ensemble skill by working with the National Orchestral Association are a likable lot. Last night at Carnegie Hall in their first appearance of the season in public, they gave a likable concert.

MAMARONECK, N. Y., Dec. 1 -- During the past year, golf courses reportedly suffered the worst season since 1928. A. M. Radko, eastern director of the United States Golf Association greens section, with headquarters at Rutgers University, declared every course was affected by the humid summer weather in the northeast section of the United States.
The 1960 campaign of the Greater New York Councils of the Boy Scouts of America was opened yesterday. The fund drive was begun at the nineteenth annual Dawn Patrol breakfast at the WaldorfAstoria.

It seemed as if everyone at the weekly bread-breaking gettogether the New York Football Giants stage each Tuesday at the Yankee Stadium was in a joke-telling mood yesterday. That went for Jim Lee Howell, the head coach, and John V. Mara, the president of the Giants, and for Harold Sauerbrei, the advance man for the Cleveland Browns.

CHICAGO, Dec. 1 -- Congress will have to adopt eventually measures to protect the public against the monopoly power that labor and industry hold in the work-contract field, Joseph L. Block, chairman of Inland Steel Company, said here today.

Heavy buying and sampling was reported yesterday at the four - day Popular Price Shoe Show of America. Attendance at the event, which closes tomorrow, is expected to reach 8,000, about equaling last year's figure.

Charles Brackett, one of Hollywood's veteran writer producers, calls himself a movie fan, and not without reason. With his first sciencefiction entry, "Journey to the Center of the Earth," due at the Paramount Dec. 16, and two new projects on his agenda, Mr. Brackett has arrived on the local scene in connection with the premiere.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 1 (AP) -- The Federal Trade Commission asked three judges of the United States Third Court of Appeals today to convict three New York brothers of criminal contempt charges for unauthorized solicitation of advertisements from business men for their labor publication called Trade Union Courier.
Control of Hazel Bishop, Inc., now held by Television Industries, Inc., may pass next week to the Daniel Van Dyke interests, it was learned yesterday from usually reliable sources.

Events tonight: "Pelleas et Melisande," Metropolitan Opera, 8; Robert Goldsand, pianist, Carnegie Hall, 8:30; Bach Aria Group, Town Hall, 8:30; Paul Jordan, organist, Protestant Episcopal Church of the Transfiguration, 8.

School has been in session for some time now, but in many instances the parents are just catching up with the youngsters in realizing it. The first P. T. A. meeting has rolled around, and it is time to acquaint ourselves once again with that most American phenomenon.

MELBOURNE, Australia. Dec. 1 (UPI) -- Mimi Arnold of Redwood City, Calif., the only United States player in the Victorian tennis championships, and Betty Holstein were beaten in the women's doubles quarterfinals today by Lorraine Coghland and Margaret Smith, 6 -- 2, 6 -- 1.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 (AP) -- The appointment of four field representatives of the Office of Education was announced today.
The National Broadcasting Company will go on the air Saturday with a half-hour television show designed to outline in detail the diversity of its schedule.
The city took the first step yesterday to ready the nearly moribund Staten Island waterfront for the commercial resurgence expected to result from the completion of the Narrows Bridge in 1965.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 -President Eisenhower appointed Thomas S. Gates Jr. today to succeed Neil H. McElroy as Secretary of Defense. Mr. McElroy resigned today, as expected.
ARCHITECTURALLY speaking, says Max Abramovitz, who rarely speaks from any other point of view, a chapel should "feel" like a chapel and an auditorium should "feel" like an auditorium.
PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 1 (AP -- Alabama today agreed to meet Penn State in the first Liberty Bowl football game Dec 19.
The eight major department stores in the New York metropolitan area rolled up a good advance in November over the level of the 1958 month.

SOUTH ORANGE, N. J., Dec. 1 -- John (Honey) Russell, a man with a wry sense of humor and a sharp eye for athletic ability, wants to leave Seton Hall University on the "bright side" when the 1959-60 basketball season ends.

NASSAU, Bahamas, Dec. 1 -Next Sunday's big sports car race here for the International Nassau Cup and a bundle of prize money will serve as a tune-up for a number of drivers entered in the world championship Grand Prix at Sebring, Fla., on Dec. 12.
A telephoned threat involving the child of a foe of the Dominican Republic regime of Generalissimo Rafael L. Trujillo caused 1,400 pupils to be evacuated yesterday from Public School 87.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, Dec. 1 -- President Sukarno has told Parliament that until a People's Congress is formed he will continue to govern Indonesia by decree even though he is not expressly empowered to do so under the 1945 Constitution.
A tenement owner with a long record of fines for violations of the Multiple Dwelling Law was sentenced yesterday to 120 days in the workhouse.

NEW HYDE PARK, L. I. Dec. 1 -- Through the efforts of Scotland Yard, the United States Embassy in London and the Nassau County Police Department, a $100 camera stolen from an American tourist in England last spring was returned yesterday.

PARIS, Dec. 1 -- The principle of military integration of forces of the North Atlantic alliance, under attack by President Charles de Gaulle, received powerful support today from Chancellor Konrad Adenauer, General de Gaulle's principal European ally.

Five five-story apartment buildings at 544 to 556 St. Paul's place and 1415 Fulton Avenue, the Bronx, have been purchased by Soltzer-Lampert, realty operators. The houses occupy a plot 241 by 100 feet and contain 128 apartments and four stores.
ALBANY, Dec. 1 (AP) -- Governor Rockefeller named his secretary, Dr. William J. Ronan, today as chairman of the sponsoring committee for the New York State Public Administration Training Program.
Returns to investors on commercial paper and bankers acceptances were increased yesterday in the wake of Monday's sharp rise in the Treasury bill rate to another record.

LONDON, Dec. 1 (Reuters) -- Following are excerpts from a speech by Premier Khrushchev at the Hungarian Communist party congress in Budapest today, as issued in English by the Soviet press agency Tass:

At the corner of Broadway and Sixty-fifth Street there is now a large, muddy hole. During this week, construction men will begin preparing the hole in the ground for the foundation of Philharmonic Hall. Plans for the structure, the first one scheduled to be finished in the Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts, have been completed.
LONDON, Dec. 1 (AP) -- Britain announced today that its booming industrial production jumped by 9 per cent in a year. Automobiles and steel are in the forefront of the advance.
MEXICO CITY, Dec. 1 -Trouble in Panama arising from her relations with the United States and from her own internal problems appears far from over.

STAMFORD, Conn., Dec. 1 -The Board of Education approved last night the use of the paddle as a disciplinary measure. Today it confessed that it did not know what kind of paddles to use or where to buy them.
Thirteen ninety-minute sports specials will be televised by the Columbia Broadcasting System starting in January.
Borough President John T. Clancy of Queens declared last night that the State Constitution's limit on New York City's borrowing power was "unrealistic."
PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 1 (AP) -- A puzzled Steve Sebo, the head coach of the University of Pennsylvania football team, was dismissed today and Rutgers' John Stiegman named to succeed him.

A number of prominent New York women are contributing to an exhibition of holiday decorating that will benefit the Exhibition Program of the American Craftmen's Council of the Museum of Contemporary Crafts.

VIENNA, Dec. 1 -- The ration of liberty doled out in Poland is becoming more meager. It is still so much larger than the degree of liberty permitted in the other Communist countries that a Pole returning from Moscow bent a knee to kiss the ground of the Warsaw airport. His friend stopped him, laughed and said: "I know what you mean."

TO one who has heard David Davis several times since his debut in 1954, the young violinist's recital last night in Town Hall was rather disappointing. For despite the fact that he plays well, there has been little perceptible musical growth.

CORONADO, Calif., Dec. 1 -Mr. and Mrs. Oswald Jacoby of Dallas were still in the lead as the national contract bridge mixed-pair contest entered its final round in the American Contract Bridge League's tournament here last night.
Billy Cannon of Louisiana State led the balloting for United Press International's allAmerican football team, which was released yesterday.
CHICAGO, Dec. 1 (AP) -- A sudden late rally today gave soybean futures their broadest gains in a week while the grains generally displayed a firmer trend.
ALBANY, Dec. 1 -- The State Commission on Economic Expansion filed its first report with Governor Rockefeller today. It was promptly branded "unrealistic" by a union leader on the commission.

LEOPOLDVILLE, Belgian Congo, Dec. 1 -- Leaders of nationalist parties here were preparing tonight to fly to Brussels tomorrow for a last-minute round-table conference before the first Congolese elections.
Carmine G. De Sapio was reelected last night to his fourth term as president of the National Democratic Club, Madison Avenue and Thirty-seventh Street.
The Transport Workers Union and seven private bus companies took their time yesterday about renewing negotiations after Monday's strike crisis.

Short-covering and dealer and commission-house buying of hide futures induced stoploss purchasing yesterday on the Commodity Exchange of New York. Profit-taking supplied the contracts. Trading was influenced by a rise in prices for actuals in Chicago.

A relief chiseler who swindled $5,811 from the Department of Welfare was sentenced yesterday to a year in jail by General Sessions Judge Inwin D. Davidson. She is Mrs. Mary Simpkins, 27 years old, of 159 Harlem River Drive.
A spokesman for organized labor attacked the chairman of the State Workmen's Compensation Board yesterday as a "defender of industry and the insurance companies."

ALBANY, Dec. 1 -- Governor Rockefeller regards any campaign he might wage to wrest the Republican Presidential nomination from Richard M. Nixon as a contest between popular citizen support and professional politicians.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 (AP) -- The General Accounting Office urged the Air Force today recover $543,000 from the Northern Radio Company, Inc., New York.

VIENNA, Dec. 1 -- Premier Khrushchev declared today that the Soviet program for general and complete disarmament, his visit to the United States and his meetings with President Eisenhower had resulted in a certain lessening of international tensions.
ANKARA, Turkey, Dec. 1 -- One of the welcoming banners President Eisenhower will see when he drives through Ankara Sunday afternoon reads: "Peace, Yes -- Concessions, No."
PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 1 -Pennsylvania's ban on the sale of certain items on Sundays was upheld today by a special three-judge Federal court.
The Director of the United States Bureau of the Budget warned last night that Government spending was gaining a momentum that threatened to wreck the economy.

When Admiral Byrd flew over the South Pole in 1928 he dropped an American flag. Nineteen years later, when he repeated the feat, he dropped the flags of all the United Nations. More recently, the station established there at great peril by the United States has flown both the American and United Nations flags.
The Western Union messenger boy is slowly disappearing from the American scene, and nobody sems to care -- not even the Western Union messenger boy.
The formation of a group whose object is to promote the return heavyweight title match between Ingemar Johansson and Floyd Patterson in New York in June was announced yesterday.
Consolidated Edison's $75,000,000 offering of mortgage bonds dominated the market for fixed-interest securities yesterday.

A RECENT Federal study disclosed a marked increase in the worldly wisdom of children between the ages of 9 and 11. It found youngsters in the fourth, fifth and sixth grades "going steady," wearing lipstick and nylon stockings, and acting less like the Bobbsey Twins and more like fugitives from a story by F. Scott Fitzgerald.
BOSTON, Dec. 1 -- Ten years from now it will be possible literally to speak to an electronic computer and have it answer right back, a specialist predicted today.
KUALA LUMPUR, Malaya, Dec. 1 -- The Singapore Government announced tonight that Queen Elizabeth had approved the appointment of Yusof Bin Ishak as Singapore's first Malayan -born head of state.

Tickets are still available for the Jan. 4 performance by the Moscow State Symphony at Carnegie Hall, which will assist the Scholarship Fund of the Manhattan School of Music. Emil Gilels will be piano soloist in an all Tchaikovsky program.

Mary K. Frank has returned from London, where she completed negotiations for the purchase of "One More River," the Beverley Cross play, against the bidding of seven other New York producers. Losing hardly any time, Mrs. Frank has scheduled rehearsals for it late this month under the direction of Windsor Lewis.
The Kleban Realty and Construction Corporation, bidders, announced plans yesterday for a twenty-story apartment house at Third Avenue and Fiftyseventh Street to cost $15,000,000.
PARIS, Dec. 1 -- Paul-Henri Spaak urged the democracies today to coordinate their economic efforts to meet the threat of communism.

The most interesting aspect of the Algerian question as it again comes before the U. N. is that it need no longer be considered imminently explosive. The Afro-Asian states, speaking on behalf of the nationalist rebels, have somewhat tempered the wording of their resolution.
Benjamin Cymrot, former acting director of the city's Bureau of Real Estate, has joined the Jarc Realty Corporation, 350 Broadway, a management company owned by Sidney J. Ungar.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 -- The board of directors of the American Public Welfare Association endorsed today a proposal that the states have the option of receiving lump-sum instead of categorical Federal grants in public assistance.

FROM California, world leader in the production of dried fruits, comes at least moderately encouraging word on this year's crop. Supplies of two of the most popular varieties, prunes and apricots, are modest but certainly adequate to meet anticipated demand.
Mayor Wagner last night ordered the suspension "forthwith" of Joseph F. Conlon from his Civil Service post as chief inspector of the Market Department's Bureau of Weights and Measures.

LONDON, Dec. 1 -- Labor Members of Parliament called upon Prime Minister Harold Macmillan today to take a public position on racial segregation before setting out on his trip to Africa later this month.
ALBANY, Dec. 1 (UPI) -Robert P. Aex, the director of Governor Rockefeller's new state Office of Local Government, has resigned, it was disclosed today.

NORMAN SHETLER, pianist, played a debut performance at Carnegie Recital Hall last night. Perhaps the evening's most spectacular feature was his bravura performance of the Prokofieff Sonata No. 7, Op. 83.

Earnings of Sears, Roebuck Co., big mail order and merchandising organization, were at a record high in the nine months ended on Oct. 31 on gross sales that topped $3,000,000 for the first time in the company's history.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 -- The Department of Defense is opposed to concessions that the State Department would like to make to Panama, Pentagon sources said today.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 -- The steel industry said today that the contract proposal it made more than two weeks ago to the United Steelworkers of America was its "last offer."

A two-for-one split of the common stock was proposed yesterday by directors of the American Manufacturing Company, Inc. The company makes Manila, sisal and nylon rope, twines, jute, drilling cable, electrical yarn and synthetic cordage.

Three Los Angeles County school districts sold $21,500,000 of bonds yesterday to the Bank of America, National Trust and Savings Association, San Francisco, and associates. The bid for $13,500,000 of city high school district bonds was 101.382, with a net interest cost to the district of 3.8937 per cent.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 (AP) -- Economists and spokesmen for the oil and mining industry clashed before Congressional tax writers today over retention of oil and mineral depletion income tax preferences.
MINEOLA, L. I., Dec. 1 -The Long Island Lighting Company filed a proposed reduction of $1.200,000 in electric rates with the Public Service Commission today. The new rate would be effective Jan. 1.

ATLANTIC CITY, Dec. 1-The Army's former scientific research chief said here today that preoccupation with missiles for solely military aims was as shortsighted as an earlier view of the airplane as exclusively a military vehicle.

DETROIT, Dec. 1 (UPI) -The General Motors Corporation said today that the bulk of its laid-off employes would return to their jobs by Dec. 9, when production of 1960 Buicks, Oldsmobiles and Pontiacs will be resumed five days ahead of schedule.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 -Space scientists said today that their planned exploration of the moon might solve the mystery of the origin of the solar system and provide clues to whether life existed on distant planetary systems.
LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Dec. 1 -- Voters of the Little Rock school district returned two school board members to office today. Both are moderates on the issue of racial integration.

Dr. Frank Stanton, president of the Columbia Broadcasting System, warned C. B. S. employes yesterday that they would face discharge if they were found to have participated in any form of commercial bribery.

In what must be regarded as their worst showing of the season, the New York Knickerbockers fumbled away a lead in the last few seconds last night and dropped a 103-100 decision to the Minneapolis Lakers.

ALBANY, Dec. 1 (AP) -- The death toll today, as the biggame hunting season ended for most of New York State, was thousands of deer, fewer bear and twenty-seven hunters, including two who were found drowned today.

CAMILLE PISSARRO, whose superb sense of values in painting was enhanced by his constant recourse to drawing, is represented at the Schoneman Galleries, 63 East Fifty-seventh Street, with drawings, watercolors and pastels, mostly from his pre-Impressionist years.
LONDON, Dec. 1 -- A world's record price for a bound manuscript sold at public auction was set today by the sale of a thirteenth century Apocalypse for u65,000 ($182,000).

WASHINGTON. Dec. 1 (UPI) -- The Department of Agriculture today proclaimed marketing quota controls for the 1960 rice crop and announced that support rates would average not less than $4.36 a hundredweight, the lowest price permitted by law.

DENVER, Dec. 1 -- Spokesmen for the nation's bigger cities expressed considerable interest here today in dual-purpose expressways that cater to rapid-transit rail service as well as automobile traffic.

BUFFALO, Dec. 1 (AP) -A Roman Catholic priest who was a member of the Navy's Antarctic expedition in 1955 said today that the world could meet its expected population boom by cultivating all available land and storing surplus food in the Antarctic ice.

Billy Cannon, for three years an outstanding halfback at Louisiana State University yesterday was named the winner of the Heisman Memorial Trophy as the outstanding collegiate football player in the nation this season.
Sir Ian A. Johnson-Gilbert, Lord Provost of Edinburgh, announced here yesterday that the Leningrad Symphony Orchestra would take part in next year's Edinburgh Festival.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 (UPI) -- The physical volume of building in 1980 will match the 1959 record, providing a stabilizing force in the economy, the Department of Commerce forecast today.

Coconuts are linked, in many people's minds, with palm trees swaying in a tropical breeze. But they are the basis of a major industry. The oil from the fruit of the palm goes into many household and factory items.

In your editorial of Nov. 27 you misconstrued the position of the National Broadcasting Company in supporting and amplifying a recent proposal for a public policy committee of distinguished citizens to evaluate television's problems.

The directors of the Bates Manufacturing Company expect to give Indian Head Mills, Inc., an answer within the next two weeks on its offer to purchase at $16 a share the 1,690,778 shares of Bates common stock outstanding. This was confirmed yesterday by David Finkelstein, attorney for Mrs. Lester Martin.

Wellington Management Company, investment adviser to Wellington Fund, announced yesterday the filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission of a registration statement for an offering to the public of 450,000 shares of its Class A non-voting common stock.
ALEXANDRIA, La., Dec. 1 (AP) -- A barge line official accused railroads and their allies today of seeking cutthroat rates along waterways that would destroy river traffic.

ALGECIRAS, Spain, Dec. 1 (AP) -- The 17,000-ton British liner Braemer Castle, with 650 persons aboard, was hauled almost undamaged today from rocks near Gibraltar where she had grounded in a violent storm.
LONDON, Dec. 1 -- The tone of the stock market improved today, helped by yesterday's advance in Wall Street.
An assistant Kings County District Attorney testified yesterday that he had protested against action taken by Magistrate Anthony E. Maglio in a case for which the judge is now on trial.

The Roman Catholic Bishops of the United States have brought the birth-control issue into the national political arena with their statement that "United States Catholics * * * will not * * * support any public assistance, either at home or abroad, to promote artificial birth prevention * * * whether through direct aid or by means of international organizations."

The Crane Company, maker of plumbing fixtures and accessories, has acquired more than 10 per cent of the stock of the Briggs Manufacturing Company and is interested in acquiring the Briggs assets, Crane announced yesterday.

BAL HARBOUR, Fla., Dec. 1 -- The widely held conviction of the securities industry that a reduction in the capital gains tax would increase Treasury revenues and invigorate the whole economy was reiterated here today at the annual convention of the Investment Bankers Association of America.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 (AP) -- The Government today tightened and simplified its basic allocation order for timely delivery of needed materials for the military, space and atomic energy programs.
If employers need statistics to prove that older workers are productive, the Bureau of Labor Statistics will have some early next year, Ewan Clague, the bureau commissioner, said yesterday.
Seventy-five young, strapping patrolmen were sent on their first assignments yesterday in an experiment in cutting crime.
A leading Jesuit moralist has expressed the view that "it would clearly be wrong" for a Roman Catholic President to approve a bill sponsoring a program of birth control.

GENEVA, Dec. 1 -- The Soviet Union responded yesterday to United States and British appeals for its views on the functions of the projected seven-nation control commission for supervising a ban on the testing of nuclear weapons.

Stocks continued their sustained advance into the tenth successive day yesterday. The aggregate market value of New York Stock Exchange issues rose more than $2,300,000,000, despite a last-hour decline for motors and electronics.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 1 -- Turkey regained the lead over Poland today in the race for a seat on the Security Council. However, the necessary two-thirds majority appeared to be beyond the reach of either and a compromise is thought to be inevitable.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 -- A region equal in area to Europe and the United States combined was made into a preserve for scientific research today, immune from political and military strife.

BUDAPEST, Hungary, Dec. 1 -- Premier Khrushchev said again today the Soviet Union had enough rockets to destroy all its foes, but declared world disarmament must be solved along with the Berlin question.
BONN, Germany, Dec. 1 -The Social Democratic party joined with Chancellor Konrad Adenauer's Government today to form a united front against Soviet attempts to separate West Berlin from West Germany.
CHICAGO, Dec. 1 (AP) -- The report of today's livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:

WHITE PLAINS, Dec. 1 -- A state plan to build a $5,000,000 feeder from the new CrossWestchester Expressway in Greenburgh into the commercial center of White Plains, where it would end abruptly, was endorsed today by this city, Greenburgh, Westchester County and local business leaders.

In your issue of Nov. 20 Arthur Krock takes issue with Dean Acheson's speech to the Conference of NATO Parliamentarians, which incidentally was received with enthusiastic applause and whose main points were supported by the overwhelming majority of delegates taking part in the discussion.

LONDON, Dec. 1 -- Britain and the United Arab Republic established diplomatic relations today. Relations between London and Cairo were severed three years ago when Britain took part in the invasion of Suez.

Mr. Acheson's text, in my judgment, permitted no other analysis of his proposed Berlin policy than mine, which Professor Morgenthau quotes (as if I had attributed the words to Mr. Acheson) in the second sentence of his letter. The same analysis was made elsewhere.
