Consolidated Edison Company of New York, Inc., sold $75,000,000 of thirty-year first and refunding mortgage bonds yesterday to a nation-wide syndicate of investment bankers headed by Morgan Stanley Co. at an interest cost to the utility of 5.198 per cent. A similar issue sold on May 27 cost the company 5.103 per cent interest.
The National Citizens Council for Better Schols, which has been active in the last decade in arousing citizen interest in school improvement, will cease operations at the end of the year.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 (AP) -- The B-70 heavy-bomber program, on which a half-billion dollars has been spent, was practically eliminated today by the Air Force.
Cotton futures moved 2 points up to 3 off in light trading on the New York Cotton Exchange yesterday. (A point equals 5 cents a bale.)

WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 -Senator Homer E. Capehart, Republican of Indiana, said today that the Eisenhower Administration had failed "to act quickly" to forestall crises in United States relations with Latin America.

The agreement between the United Arab Republic and Great Britain to resume diplomatic relations is good news because it makes good sense. Lord Palmerston expressed a universal rule of international relations when he said that Britain has no permanent friends or enemies but merely permanent interests.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 (AP) -- President Eisenhower designated Mrs. Pearl C. Pace today to be chairman of the Foreign Claims Settlement Commission. She has been a commission member since 1954.

THE United States will outscore the Soviet Union in the final round of the Olympic basketball championships in Rome next summer, but the disparity between the national teams will be far less than it was at Melbourne four years earlier. By the time of the 1964 Olympics in Tokyo, it may have disappeared.

Following is the text of an article entitled "Can a Catholic Sign . . . ?" to appear in the Dec. 12 issue of America. The author is the Rev. John R. Connery, Professor of Moral Theology at West Baden College, a Jesuit institution.
MIAMI, Dec. 1 -- An overhaul of the nation's old-age assistance program was advocated here today at the opening session of a Senate subcommittee hearing on problems of elderly persons.
THE biggest building boom in New York City's history offers local youngsters ample opportunity to observe buildings in various stages of construction.

The Communist chieftains gathered in Budapest proclaim that Soviet forces will remain in that country. An announcement to this effect was made at a Communist party congress dominated by Premier Khrushchev, who in a speech yesterday restated all his known positions, from total disarmament to forcing the Western powers out of Berlin.

BALTIMORE, Dec. 1 (AP) -- The American Credit Indemnity Company of New York today announced the election of James L. McCauley as president. He succeeds August F. Stone, who is retiring after eight years as president.
The International Longshoremen's Association and a major group of waterfront employers reached a basic agreement yesterday on three-year contracts.

TRENTON, Dec. 1 -- Federal Judge Phillip Forman said today that checks totaling $8,354,157 had been sent to seventy-two insurance concerns and lawyers in a settlement of claims that arose from the South Amboy explosion of May 19, 1950.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 -- The Administration has decided to postpone any decision on the resumption of atomic tests until it can see what progress is made in the talks in Geneva on a prohibition of such tests.
BOSTON, Dee. 2 -- The Soviet Union has a wealth of ideas but a shortage of hardware in the field of electronic computers, an American expert said today.

WHEN a single person of marriageable age appears profoundly unhappy, friends and relatives often counsel: "Get married." When a childless marriage begins to flounder, these advisers urge: "Have a child."
SAN JUAN, P. R., Dec. 2 -- Senator Hubert H. Humphrey praised Puerto Rico today as "a living symbol of democratic government, of free enterprise, of progress and other characteristics of democracy."
DALLAS, Dec. 2 (AP) -- Lanar Hunt, the founder of the American Football League, said tonight that the proposed league had completed its draft by naming an additional 161 college players.
Cases involving Banton L. Wyckoff and his former rent collector, Solomon Chodorov, were delayed yesterday by Magistrate Edward J. Chapman in Housing Court.
The magazine industry was less than happy yesterday about the sweeping criticism of its work made by Leo Burnett on Tuesday.
NEWARK, Dec. 2 -- Four long, squat and plain buildings were dedicated at Newark Airport today to an unromantic but promising side of the airline industry -- air cargo.
The problem of how to give a Chopin concert and come up with something unusual was solved last night in Carnegie Hall by Robert Goldsand, who played the C minor Sonata.

President Eisenhower embarks tonight on a history-making world tour which by the miracle of modern transportation will take him within the brief period of only twenty days over 22,000 miles to eleven or more nations on three continents and bring him home in time for the Christmas holidays.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 -- Installment buying reached another peak in October, apparently undeterred by the steel strike and possibly even spurred by it. The Federal Reserve Board reported today that the volume of installment credit outstanding rose a half-billion dollars during the month.

An increase of 202 per cent in earnings and of 35 per cent in sales in the latest fiscal year made it the best in the history of the Aeroquip Corporation, makers of flexible hose lines, self-sealing couplings, clamps, load control and tie-down equipment.

Three Ohio school districts announced yesterday that they planned to offer bond issues totaling $6,007,500.

SALERNO, Italy, Dec. 2 (UPI) -- Two American Protestant churchmen reported today that they had been arrested and detained for several hours by Italian policemen who broke up a Baptist rally they were attending.

VIENNA, Dec. 2 -- Peaceful coexistence with the West does not mean any fundamental political compromise or ideological truce with opponents of the Communist regime in Hungary, according to the party line laid down today at the Communist party congress in Budapest.
BUDAPEST, Hungary, Dec. 2 -- Premier Khrushchev said today that some of his Kremlin comrades opposed his decision to use the Soviet military to crush the 1956 Hungarian revolt.
St. John's and New York University, two of the better rated metropolitan teams, will help open the twenty-sixth season of collegiate basketball at Madison Square Garden tonight.

A retired inspector with forty-two years' service in the Bureau of Weights and Measures has given "important and valuable" information to the Kings County grand jury investigating the organized cheating of housewives in city food stores.

TELEVISION'S high-pressure audience-participation shows were satirized in rousing style last night by a comedy group headed by Sid Caesar. The program, shown on Channel 2, was entitled "Marriage, Handle With Care," and co-starred Audrey Meadows, Jose Ferrer and Marge and Gower Champion.

Thomas J. Watson Jr., president of the International Business Machines Corporation, said yesterday that higher taxes must be accepted if they proved necessary to keep ahead of the Soviet Union in world leadership.

The American Ballet Theatre will appear in the Soviet Union early next summer under the sponsorship of the President's Special .International Program for Cultural Presentations, which is administered by the American National Theatre and Academy.

BRUSSELS, Belgium, Dec. 2 -- President Eisenhower's planned visit to Madrid this month was criticized today by George Meany at a meeting of the executive board of the International Confederation of Free Trade Unions.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 -- The Atomic Energy Commission increased its spending on development and production of atomic weapons in the last fiscal year despite the cessation of nuclear tests.
BAL HARBOUR, Fla., Dec. 2 -- The investment world has a right to be confident about the growth of the electronics industry, the nation's investment securities specialists were told here today.

VIENNA, Dec. 2 -- In the life of Poland, fundamental power belongs to the Soviet Union, but fundamental influence still belongs to the Roman Catholic Church. The existence of the Soviet Union and the existence of the Church are the two overriding realities in Poland. Everything else stems from them.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 -- President Eisenhower said today that his eleven-nation tour, which starts tomorrow, was part of a design to use his prestige to dispel doubts about this country's peaceful intentions.
The General Telephone Company of California sold $30,000,000 of first mortgage bonds yesterday at an interest cost of 5.04 per cent.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 -- The Justice Department, in an unusual move, has asked the Supreme Court to set aside a criminal conviction that the department won from a jury and successfully defended on appeal.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Dec. 2 (AP) -- Mickey Rooney declared war on Jack Paar today, but they were at peace before sundown.

CORONADO, Calif., Dec. 2 -- John R. Crawford of Philadelphia and Mrs. Dorothy Hayden of Hastings-on-Hudson, N. Y., won the Masters' Mixed Pair title in the American Contract Bridge League's National Tournament here after three sessions of play that ended early this morning.

SAN DIEGO, Calif., Dec. 2 (AP) -- The board of directors of Solar Aircraft Co. has voted not to declare the quarterly dividend of 25 cents a share customarily payable in January. The board also reported a net loss of $567,300 for the six months ended on Oct. 31.

An attack on American educators for allowing science students to fall behind those of the Soviet Union and Europe generally was made yesterday by the assistant administrator of the National Aeronautics and Space Administration.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 -- The Federal Home Loan Bank Board has established a ceiling on the volume of savings that a savings and loan association may acquire through brokers.

A curb on extra television commercials that are not related to the sponsor of a program, including a ban on identifying the donors of articles used as prizes, will be put into effect Dec. 31 by the Columbia Broadcasting System.
GARDEN CITY, L. I., Dec. 21 -- Students in Seoul, Korea, will soon receive 4,000 books through the work of a Bronx girl, the Marine Corps and private transportation concerns.

PEIPING, Nov. 30 -- Across China, billions of young trees have been planted. In the cities and on the land, on mountain sides and in the valleys you see the spindly saplings growing -- with only inches between them at times.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 -- The Federal Trade Commission will take action soon against several record companies for payola deals.

PARIS, Dec. 2 -- President Charles de Gaulle succeeded today in calming West German fears that France was seeking revisions of the military doctrines of the Atlantic Alliance that would jeopardize the United States contribution to European defense.
NEWARK, Dec. 2 -- Two applications for a temporary ban on the enforcement of New Jersey's Sunday Restricted Sales Law were denied today by Federal Judge Mendon Morrill.

A Brooklyn car-washer was accused yesterday of unlawfully obtaining $16,982 in Welfare Department funds in what was said to be one of the largest relief frauds uncovered by the office of the Kings County District Attorney.

GAINESVILLE, Fla., Dec. 2 (AP) -- Bob Woodruff stepped down as athletic director and football coach of the University of Florida today.

TOKYO, Dec. 2 (AP) -- The Bank of Japan raised bank discount rates today in a "preventive measure" designed to cut the threat of a year-end inflation.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 (UPI) -- The Department of the Interior said today that there were at least 5,000,000 tons of low-grade red iron ores in northwest Georgia, northeast Alabama and east Tennessee.

WHITE PLAINS, Dec. 2 -- Four hundred singers, band and orchestra members, narrators, actors and dancers participated in "Inheritors of the Dream" tonight in the County Center here.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 -- The Federal Reserve Board of Governors announced today a round of new assignments for its top staff, following the resignation of Dr. Winfield W. Riefler as assistant to the chairman.
A nation-wide survey of outstanding school systems will be undertaken by the National School Boards Association.

CLEVELAND, Dec. 2 (AP) -- The touring Russian men's basketball team used a fast break and superior rebounding tonight to beat Akron of the National Industrial Basketball League, 87 -- 73. The victory snapped a string of eight losses to American teams.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 (UPI) -- Pope John XXIII has filled the vacant sees of Norwich, Conn., and Manchester, N. H., and appointed an auxiliary bishop for the Diocese of Trenton, N. J., it was announced here today.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 2 -- The leadership of the American Federation of Labor and Congress of Industrial Organizations was attacked today by directors of the independent International Longshoremen's and Warehousemen's Union.
COLD windy weather puts roses in a woman's cheeks. It also reddens her nose, roughens her skin, chaps her lips and makes her eyes tear.
LEICESTER, N. Y., Dec. 2 (AP) -- The Democratic state chairman said tonight that Governor Rockefeller was a "political opportunist" with an "obsession to being the Republican Presidential candidate."

The Graham-Paige Corporation reported yesterday stockholders' equity of $16,566,692 as of Sept. 30. After deducting $3,500,000 of preferred stock issued last April, the equity was $13,066,692, equal to $2.16 a share. This compared with $11,258,063, or $1.86 a share, a year earlier and $11,448,410, or $1.89 a share, on Dec. 31, 1958.
All Democratic state Assemblymen have been requested by the minority leader to avoid causing Mayor Wagner political embarrassment by introducing measures that the city will be forced to oppose.
CHICAGO, Dec. 2 (AP) -- The grain futures market mustered a strong push late today and most contracts were at or near their day's peaks at the close.
The United States Maritime Administration effectively bol-gred yesterday the position of American shipowners with vessel operating under the flags of Panama, Liberia and Hondoras.

ATLANTIC CITY, Dec. 2 -- An expert on the Navy's Polaris missile program said here today that the United States would benefit from "unique strategic advantages" after that submarine-based weapon becomes operational next year.

Pennsylvania, the Ivy League champion, placed four men -- Barney Berlinger, Bruce Cummings, John Marchiano and Fred Doelling -- on the league's all-star football team chosen by the Ivy coaches yesterday.

The Anti-Defamation League of B'nai B'rith criticized yesterday what it termed "a clear pattern of discrimination against Jews" by life insurance companies in restricting the employment of Jews in executive posts in the home offices.
ONE of the most incredible works on food ever printed is Alexis Soyer's "Pantropheon," subtitled "The History of Food."

The election of William H. Avery Jr., J. Raburn Monroe, and David Rockefeller as directors of the Equitable Life Assurance Society of the United States, effective on Jan. 1., was announced yesterday by James F. Oates Jr., president.
DENVER, Dec. 2 -- The American Municipal Association called on Congress today to undertake "a comprehensive investigation of all phases of the housing and urban renewal program."
CHICAGO, Dec. 2 (AP) -- The report of today's livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:
Early holiday shoppers will find many items to choose from at the annual Christmas Bazaar at the Lenox School at 170 East Seventieth Street on Saturday from 11 A. M. to 6 P. M.
MADRID, Dec. 21 -- President Eisenhower will introduce Generalissimo Francisco Franco to the American institution of the business breakfast.

The American Stock Exchange issued yesterday its latest insiders' list of important changes in stock ownership. Among other transactions, it showed that H. C. Orton, a director and treasurer of the New Haven Clock and Watch Company, who previously owned no shares of the company's stock, recently acquired 15,000 shares directly and 29,400 shares indirectly.
Plans are being completed by members of the Sweet Briar Alumnae Club of New York for a theatre party for the benefit of a newly established scholarship fund.

The Department of Public Works will place before the Board of Estimate today a draft plan for the construction of a $25,000,000 wholesale produce market on a 126-acre site in the Hunts Point area of The Bronx.

DETROIT, Dec. 2 -- The head of the major Protestant relief organization took an opposite view from President Eisenhower today on the use of foreign-aid funds to disseminate information on artificial birth control.
Judge Irving R. Kaufman ruled yesterday that the police action that broke up the 1957 Apalachin meeting was legal.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 -- Dr. Glenn T. Seaborg, a discoverer of the plutonium, used in atomic bombs, received the $50,000 Enrico Fermi Award today for his leadership in the development of nuclear chemistry and atomic energy.
A research center for the study of muscular dystrophy and allied diseases will be dedicated here on Dec. 12.

The 1960 capital budget to be adopted by the Board of Estimate today is expected to allocate sufficient funds to start nineteen or twenty of the twenty-nine new school projects originally scheduled for next year by the City Planning Commission.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 (UPI) -- American woolen textile manufacturers urged the Tariff Commission today to impose "adequate tariffs" to permit them to compete with soaring imports from low-wage countries.
The Wagner College basketball team closed with a rush last season, but Coach Herb Sutter hopes the rush will start before Christmas this time.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 -- Secretary Arthur S. Flemming outlined today a 1960 legislative program to reduce costs and social ills in the field of public assistance.
Textron, Inc., plans to expand its heavy-industry activities through entry into the steel car manufacturing and steel forging business.
BELHAVEN, N. C., Dec. 2 -- In spite of the weather today, the geese came right, as they say it here, and everybody limited out early, as they say it here. There is no reason in a wild goose.

Directors of Middle South Utilities, Inc., yesterday proposed a two-for-one split of the common stock. Stockholders at a special meeting here on Feb. 15 will vote on increasing the authorized common stock to 25,000,000 shares from 12,000,000. Stockholders of record of Jan. 8 will be entitled to vote.

Tickets are still available for the Dec. 14 performance of "The Fighting Cock" at the ANTA Theatre that will benefit the Jacob A. Riis Neighborhood Settlement. They may be obtained from Miss Jessie Fanshawe of 136 East Sixty-fourth Street.
THE verve and purposiveness of young adults of past generations is often absent in their descendants, community center officials have observed here.
WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W. Va., Dec. 2 -- Governor Rockefeller extended his "Midwestern" political tour today to include visits to Missouri, Oklahoma, Texas and Florida.

PALM SPRINGS, Calif., Dec. 2 (AP) -- Willie Goggin of San Jose, Calif., the defending champion, shot a 6-under-par 66 today for a course record and a 3-shot lead in the first round of the $20,000 United States senior open golf championship.
SYRACUSE, Dec. 2 (AP) -- The Cincinnati Royals scored a 135-118 National Basketball Association victory over the New York Knicks tonight at War Memorial Auditorium.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y. A SOVIET woman delegate was trapped in a Manhattan pavement grill the other day and broke one of her Western-style heels. The emergency found her helpless. In despair she telephoned the United Nations.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 -- President Eisenhower indicated today that he would favor repeal of the non-Communist affidavit required for Federal student loans.

For a time yesterday morning, stocks seemed likely to advance for the eleventh successive day. But the afternoon brought profit-taking in almost all sections of the list and the net result was a modest loss.

BERKELEY, Calif., Dec. 2 -- When Glenn Theodore Seaborg shared the Nobel Prize in chemistry in 1951, the news did not cause a ripple in the junior population of neighboring Lafayette, where he lives, eleven miles east of the University of California campus.
The New York Times is to be congratulated for its fine editorial of Nov. 26 "Cranberries Are Peanuts" with its summary of the dangers inherent in the use of chemical poisons.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 2 (AP) -- The Right Rev. James A. Pike, Protestant Episcopal Bishop of California, commented today that President Eisenhower's statement had ignored recommendations of his own and other governmental committees.

One of the most damaging traffic offenses against the public interest in New York City, and one that is too little pursued and punished, is the double-parking of automobiles. In a typical situation, in many areas of Manhattan especially, a motorist drives up, finds all curb space occupied, then parks his car somewhat distantly parallel to the curbed cars, and leaves it while he goes about his errand.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 (AP) -- Ezra Taft Benson, Secretary of Agriculture, announced today that the Federal grading service for lamb and mutton would be suspended for one year, effective on Jan. 4.
Cardinal Spellman will again spend the Christmas holidays with United States servicemen overseas, the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of New York announced yesterday.

An official watchdog committee on ambulance-chasing reported yesterday that it had found "various abuses and violations of professional ethics by a sizable number of attorneys" in New York and Bronx Counties.

"France -- The New Republic," by Raymond Aron, will be published by Oceana for the Fund for the Republic on Jan. 21. The book is the result of a series of discussions between M. Aron and the consultants to the Fund for the Republic on the new Constitution adopted by the Fifth Republic.

A site has been assembled for a twenty-two-story apartment house at the northwest corner of Third Avenue and Thirty~ second Street. it was announced yesterday by Brett, Wyckoff, Potter, Hamilton, Inc., the bro- kers who acquired the property for the builders.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 -- President Eisenhower summoned Alexander Pope out of the eighteenth century today to help silence his critics.
PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 2 (AP) -- A fraction of an inch separates the two leading passers today in the National Football League.

Stocks of light heating oils, used mainly for heating homes, declined in the week to last Friday in the wake of a cold wave in the Midwest. They fell to 170,886,000 barrels from 174,571,000 a week before and compared with 161,439,000 barrels a year ago.

ST. PETERSBURG, Dec. 2 -- Though big league trading has been slow at the minor league convention here, all hands appear certain that trades will begin popping when the majors begin their own meetings in Miami next week.
Narcotics addiction has become a "practically negligible" problem among the 1,250,000 children in the city's public, parochial and private schools, a Board of Education official testified yesterday.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 2 -- The Trusteeship Committee of the General Assembly put off tonight a vote on a draft resolution congratulating the United States on the admission of Alaska and Hawaii as states.

"The Tempest" will be brought to the East Seventy-fourth Street Theatre, 334 East Seventy-fourth Street, on Dec. 28. The comedy will be put on in the 199-seat house, equipped with an open stage, by a new outfit, Festa Productions. Its founders are Rolf Forsberg and his wife, Josephine, and Marc Reyna, who will act the role of Stephano.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 (AP) -- The Government is pressing a program of keeping from interstate commerce milk containing any residues of penicillin, or presticides such as DDT and chlordane.

With all of his key operatives in shape, Coach Jim Lee Howell put the New York Giants through a long, hard drill yesterday. The National Football League's Eastern Division leaders will play the Cleveland Browns at Yankee Stadium Sunday.
CHICAGO, Dec. 2 -- The Chicago Board of Health began today an intensified milk-testing program to detect the presence of antibiotics in milk.

ONE quick tour of the reception room before the $50-a-plate National Football Foundation dinner at the Waldorf-Astoria the other night and a name-dropper would have had enough ammunition to supply him for months. The gathering of the gridiron Hall of Fame immortals represented more than a million dollars worth of talent by professional standards. It was a notable occasion and the graying heroes of yesteryear made it all the more notable.

CINCINNATI, Ohio, Dec. 2 (UPI) -- Procter Gamble Company said today it would dissolve the Procter Gamble Defense Corporation, a subsidiary created during the early days of World War II to load shells for the Government.
MOSCOW, Dec. 2 -- There has never been much doubt about the serene comfort and high living standard of Soviet writers and artists as a whole.

The case against Magistrate Anthony E. Maglio charged with conduct unbecoming a member of the judiciary, was completed yesterday in State Supreme Court, Brooklyn. Mr. Maglio is expected to take the witness stand in his own defense today.
BOSTON, Dec. 2 -- A masterpiece of French early Gothic sculpture, which went unrecognized for centuries, has been purchased by the Boston Museum of Fine Arts here after four years of negotiation.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 -- President Eisenhower said today that the Government would have to provide a substitute for collective bargaining in the steel dispute if management and the union did not come to terms voluntarily.
Manhattan Borough President Hulan E. Jack intervened yesterday in the dispute that has divided his Citizens Watchdog Committee for the Penn Station South slum-clearance project.

A warning that the Soviet Union may be far ahead of the United States in chemical and biological weapons, was given yesterday by a high Defense Department official. The weapons were seen as possessing the potential of "an absolutely crucial military advantage" in future wars.
David Wallace, who was discharged as vice president of Alleghany Corporation on Nov. 13, has resigned as a director.
The United States itself was partly responsible for Soviet attempts to censor the American book exhibit at last summer's exhibition in Moscow, according to its American general manager.

FRONT ROYAL, Va., Dec. 2 (UPI) -- A troop-carrying Army helicopter developed trouble over the Blue Ridge Mountains today, flashed a distress signal and crashed. Thirteen of the fifteen men aboard were injured, one seriously.

In his revealing speeches in Budapest, Premier Khrushchev seemed to lose his judgment as he enthusiastically rubbed the noses of the battered Hungarian people into the very sands where Russian troops and tanks three years ago destroyed their hopes of liberty.
The Board of Estimate, meeting in executive session yesterday, began to study possible financial relief for New York's seven private bus companies.
The heads of two state agencies in the labor-management field pledged yesterday the use of all the powers of their offices to drive out racketeers and racket unions.

THE last of the big bow-wow war books for this year is published here today. It is "Triumph in the West," by Arthur Bryant, a curiously layered chronicle of 1943-46, based on the diaries and afterthoughts of Field Marshal Lord Alanbrooke, chief of Britain's Imperial General Staff at the time, with a rather ardent commentary by Mr. Bryant.

Many socially prominent persons entertained at a dinner dance held at the St. Regis Roof last night for the benefit of the Visiting Nurse Service of New York, a voluntary public health nursing agency which provides part-time home nursing care.

CORONADO, Calif., Dec. 2 -- Mrs. Dorothy Hayden of Hastings-on-Hudson, N. Y., who, with John R. Crawford of Philadelphia, won the Masters' Mixed Pair championship yesterday, is a newcomer to the ranks of bridge experts.
A truck that broke down while turning from Forty-third Street into Seventh Avenue delayed traffic in Times Square for more than two and a half hours yesterday.
LONDON, Dec. 2 -- Britain will not sell Cuba the jet fighters she has been seeking here, it was announced today in the House of Lords.
LONDON, Dec. 2 -- The Soviet Union has about 100 principal missile bases and a missile service of about 200,000 men, according to a pamphlet issued by the Institute of Strategic Studies.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 -- A recent State Department study shows that food production in the less-developed areas of the world has apparently been outpacing population growth for the last decade, and may continue to do so for the next fifteen years.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Dec. 2 -- Current and impending labor negotiations in the movie industry have assumed international implications.
News that a fresh dock strike had been averted depressed coffee futures yesterday on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange. Lower spot prices also influenced trading.

A Chicago-New York investment banking group yesterday lost its appeal for a rehearing by the Circuit Court of Appeals on the legality of a 1955 stock repurchase agreement the group has with the New York, New Haven and Hartford Railroad.
LONDON, Dec. 2 -- The weakness of the British pound compared with the United States dollar had an unsettling effect on the stock market here today.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in leading cities showed the following principal changes for the week ended Nov. 25:

WHEN David Hare began to make sculptures more than seventeen years ago, his dominant interest was surrealism. Like fellow exhibitors at the Art of This Century Gallery in the early Nineteen Forties, Mr. Hare was exhilarated by his encounter with French surrealists who made New York their wartime headquarters.
Male pedestrians over 25 years old will be the principal targets of the holiday safety program by the Mayor's Committee on Pedestrian Safety.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 (UPI) -- Secret Service Chief U. E. Baughman warned today that the Christmas shopping season was the busiest time of the year for passers of counterfeit money.
BONN, Germany, Dec. 2 -- Informed Allied diplomats here are making gloomy assessments of the results that may be attained at the Western heads-of-government meeting in Paris later this month.

DETROIT, Dec. 2 (AP) -- The Chrysler Corporation suspended today all car production because of steel shortages. However, Chrysler announced it would resume building its Valiant and Imperial passenger cars and Dodge trucks one week from today.

In reading the statement of the Roman Catholic Bishops against assistance to birth control programs in foreign countries, one is struck by the inadequacy of the remedies proposed to deal with the colossal population problem.

ST. JOHN, N. B., Dec. 2 (Canadian Press) -- A protest charging Japanese ships with upsetting "traditional East Coast port parity" has gone from a meeting marking Atlantic Port Day here to the Japanese-Atlantic and Gulf Freight Conference in Tokyo.
The Bach Aria Group opened its subscription series at Town Hall last night with a program composed of familiar elements.
HOUSTON, Dec. 2 (UPI) -- Joe Brown made one flurry pay off tonight for a technical knockout victory over Dave Charnley, and retained the world lightweight boxing championship.

A large part of this country's industrial machine is approaching or is already at the point of obsolescence, judging from a recent survey. Some 240 companies in the metal-working field were polled by Iron Age, the trade publication, to ascertain the condition of their equipment.

FILLED to the brim with turkey? It is just as well because prices are up this week. Supplies are no longer plentiful, but there should be enough turkeys to go around at Christmas -- even though prices are likely to be a good bit above preThanksgiving levels.

Events today: New York Philharmonic, Leonard Bernstein, conductor, Isaac Stern, violinist, John Wummer, flutist, Leonard Rose, cellist, Carnegie Hall, 2:15; "Madama Butterfly," Metropolitan Opera, 8; Vicente Grisolia, pianist, Carnegie Recital Hall, 8:30; David Oistrakh, violinist, Hunter College Assembly Hall, 8:30; Budapest String Quartet,

COLOGNE, Germany, Dec. 1 -- While economists and Government officials ponder the theoretical affects on trade of the split of Europe into two trading blocs, working business often paint a practical picture that is somewhat different.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 3 -George V. Allen, director of the United States Information Agency, said today that the Soviet Union's propaganda war against this country had diminished since Premier Khrushchev's visit here.

Offering to the public of 350,000 shares of $2 convertible preferred stock of International Utilities Corporation is being made today by Butcher Sherred, Philadelphia investment banking concern, and associates.

ZITA CARNO, who gave her debut, Town Hall piano recital last night, is what musicians describe as "a natural." She plays the piano in an effortless manner and obviously is an all-around musician. Her style is neat and finished, her technique one of complete security.
NOT a matter of quixotic taste but of historical good sense, the new exhibition at the Museum of Modern Art is a detailed report on its past year's acquisitions.
In a new diversification move, Minneapolis-Moline Company, a leading maker of farm and industrial power equipment, has formed a finance company, J. Russell Duncan, president, announced yesterday.

If at first you don't succeed, try, try and try again. Figuratively, at least, the New York Joint Legislative Committee on Banks will have that motto before it when it meets today to try to work out a new inclusive banking bill for introduction at next month's meeting of the Legislature.
LOGAN, Utah, Dec. 4 (UPI) -- Gene Fullmer will make the first defense of the National Boxing Association's version of the world middleweight crown tonight against Lanky Ellsworth (Spider) Webb.
WASHINGTON. Dec. 3 (AP) -- The chief of Alaska's defenses was quoted today as having said that, "as things now stand, it would take only two enemy bombers to put Alaskan bases out of action."

Food Fair Stores, Inc., the nation's sixth largest food chain, operating 408 supermarkets in nine states from Connecticut to Florida, turned in record sales and earnings in the twentyeight weeks that ended on Nov. 14.
The Transport Workers Union asked City Labor Commissioner Harold A. Felix yesterday to help get negotiations going again with seven private bus companies.
NEW DELHI, India, Dec. 3 -- Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru called today for the rapid development of a dynamic and "self-generating" Indian economy.

The Port of New York Authority is ready to propose the construction of a major commercial airport to meet the expanding needs of the jet age. The site is reported to be a New Jersey swamp twenty-five miles west of Manhattan.
The Central Park Zoo is observing its twenty-fifth anniversary this week but nobody is bothering with birthday cakes.

THE Union Theological Seminary has opened its new season of religious drama with a difficult verse play-Charles Williams' "Cranmer of Canterbury." Public performances will he given tonight and tomorrow at the Seminary's James Memorial Chapel.
Following are the texts of Mr. McDonald's letter to President Eisenhower and Mr. Cooper's statement rejecting the plan:

WASHINGTON, Dec. 3 (AP) -- President Eisenhower named Fredrick M. Eaton, New York lawyer, today as chairman of the United States delegation to the tennation disarmament committee scheduled to meet early next year in Geneva. Mr. Eaton will hold the rank of ambassador.
Governor Rockefeller said yesterday that Premier Khrushchev's use this week of "nuclear blackmail" should rouse Americans out of their apathy toward civil defense.
NEW DELHI, India, Dec. 3 -Neelam Sanjeeva Reddy, Chief Minister of the state of Andhra, was unanimously elected today president of the ruling Indian National Congress party.
LOS ANGELES, Dec. 3 -- Syracuse's unbeaten Orangemen arrived by plane tonight for their Saturday gridiron clash with the University of California at Los Angeles.
DETROIT, Dec. 3 -- The National Council of Churches offered its services here today as a mediator in the steel strike.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 3 -President Eisenhower addressed a new plea and a new warning to the steel industry and the union tonight to settle their dispute.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 3 -- The Federal Communications Commission today stepped into the growing investigation of undercover payments for favored treatment on radio and television.
LANSING, Mich., Dec. 3 (UPI) -- Republicans hailed today the State Senate's passage of a $34,000,000 tax package as the beginning of the end of Michigan's eleven-month fiscal struggle.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 3 (AP) -- About 150,000,000,000 barrels of underground oil lie untapped in this country, and a slug of alcohol may be just what is needed to give them a lift, an expert asserted today.
The Board of Education said yesterday that it had dismissed a substitute teacher during the last year for refusing to answer questions about possible past membership in the Communist party.

In calling attention to an alleged error in The Times' account of the finding of a draft of Federalist No. 64 in John Jay's handwriting, Irving Brant, in his letter published Nov. 27, is guilty of an oversimplification of the evidence.

" THE only valid reason for my existence as a writer is to take the reader by the scruff of the neck and rub his nose in doom so he'll get the idea that he's fooling around with the future of the human race." This curious, to say the least, interpretation of the novelist's role was made by Harold Louis Humes in an interview with Joseph Wershba of The New York Post. Mr.

The Eisenhower Administration was accused yesterday by a leader of the Planned Parenthood Federation of remaining "willfully ignorant" of what should be done to harness what he termed the population explosion.
The Department of Labor is setting something of a record this year in its handling of reports on two new laws that require data affecting workers.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 3 -- Pakistan moved today to preserve her interest in Ladakh, now in dispute between India and Communist China.

THE new president of the National Association of Manufacturers, Rudolph Frederick Bannow, could serve as the exemplar for one of those Hollywood productions in which Spencer Tracy plays a nice, friendly, bluff, self-made business man.
The Brotherhood of Railroad Trainmen yesterday called a strike on the Long Island Rail Road for next Monday morning. But a delay is expected with Federal mediation.

THE complaint all during the football season has been that the Saturday television fare has been much too sparse in attractive offerings. The rigid scheduling of the National Collegiate Athletic Association has no provision for substituting a sure-fire spectacular for the occasional clinker it put on the program months earlier.

ST. PETERSBURG, Dec. 3 -- Tom Sturdivant, a former pitcher for the New York Yankees, was traded by the Kansas City Athletics today to the Boston Red Sox. The Athletics received in return Pete Daley, a second-string catcher.
SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 3 -Shipbuilders and their allies in Coast states met today to unify efforts to win a "fair share" of merchant construction.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 3 -- Almost eight years ago Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower went to Rome on his tour of farewell as commander of the Allied powers in Europe.
MEXICO CITY, Dec. 3 -- President Adolfo Lopez Mateos has broken an official silence of thirty-two years over the position of religion in Mexico.

PARIS, Dec. 3 -- At least 270 persons died last night and early today after the Malpasset Dam had burst. Millions of tons of water hurtled down a valley to plunge into the Mediterranean on the Riviera.

In the extraordinary financial and economic recovery France has made under the de Gaulle regime the one great defect has lain in the disproportionately heavy burden carried by lowsalaried and low-wage workers.

In rejecting Sigurd Larmon's plan for a "citizens' committee" to study television program service, Dr. Frank Stanton (president of Columbia Broadcasting System) has reached the right conclusion for the wrong reasons.
There will be fewer cases of laryngitis in New York University's male cheering section this season.

THE assertion of those "South Pacific" Seabees that there is "nothing like a dame" to occupy the interests of men plagued by the tediousness of war is frantically illustrated in the Music Hall's Christmas-show film, "Operation Petticoat," which opened there yesterday.

Three adults and two children were hospitalized last night after fire swept three-story frame tenement in the Williamsburgh section of Brooklyn. Thirteen others, including two firemen, were overcome by smoke and were treated at the scene and released.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 3 -- The United States and the Arab states have reached a compromise agreement on continuing United Nations aid to Palestinian Arab refugees for three years.
The agent for a tenement at 2 West 118th Street in which the stairway collapsed last August was charged yesterday with violating the terms of her probation by failing to repair the stairs.
A work for jazz quartet and orchestra by Dave Brubeck's brother will be a feature of the New York Philharmonic's programs next week.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 3 (AP) -- The United States Court of Appeals ruled today that General Motors Acceptance Corporation was liable for acts of its employes in the wrongful repossession of a soldier's automobile.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 3 -- The French delegation indicated today that it considered "unacceptable" the draft resolution on Algeria laid before the General Assembly's Political Committee by twenty-one Asian and African nations.
Whitney North Seymour, presidentelect of the American Bar Association, said last night that many lawyers were concerned about the place of the legal profession in American society.

Suggestions for organizing courses of instruction in the use of boats and motors have been assembled in printed form by the Outboard Boating Club of America, which has headquarters in Chicago. The material is intended as a help in setting up classes by marine dealers, clubs, schools and other groups.

The Board of Estimate unanimously defeated yesterday a City Council-approved bill that would have mandated a reduction from five to four days a week in the city's alternate-side-of-the-street parking program.

Three New York City members of Congress lent a sympathetic ear yesterday to the major problem at the United States Merchant Marine Academy at Kings Point, L. I.: a budget insufficient to improve morale.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 3 -- Dr. Loren Eiseley, Professor of Anthropology and provost of the University of Pennsylvania, has won the 1959 Phi Beta Kappa Science Prize of $1,000 for his book, "Darwin's Century."

Thomas J. Taylor, a city markets inspector since 1930, was arrested yesterday on a perjury charge after testifying before the Kings County grand jury investigating meat frauds. Mayor Wagner immediately suspended him.

" On a typical day I get up late and have a leisurely breakfast, and then I sit down to read the paper," the Rev. Dr. Arthur Judson Brown said yesterday, his 103rd birthday. "I turn first to the obituary pages, and if I don't see my name there, I go on to read the rest of the paper."

LOS ANGELES, Dec. 3 -- Gov. Edmund G. Brown, Democrat, and Representative Edgar Hiestand, Republican, have been doing some verbal sparring about the propriety of a $15,500 contribution by the Teamsters Union to Mr. Brown's campaign last year
CORONADO, Calif., Dec. 3 -Leo Pressberg of Hawthorne, Calif., won the Life Masters' individual championship today in the American Contract Bridge League's national tournament here.

The other day this newspaper printed an advertisement sponsored by the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People and depicting an appealing and exhausted 6year-old napping in a bus during a long trip home from her segregated school. She was a Yancey County, N. C., child; one of the twentyeight Negro pupils forced to travel to Asheville, forty miles away, for their education.
A 16-year-old youth who wounded his foster mother with two shots from a rifle Tuesday night was charged with felonious assault yesterday.
IN Robert Anderson's "Silent Night, Lonely Night," which opened at the Morosco last evening, Barbara Bel Geddes and Henry Fonda conduct a long discussion of love, marriage and adultery.

MOSCOW, Dec. 3 (UPI) -The Russians plan to present their own version of "West Side Story" next year, leaving out most of the music and dancing to emphasize the theme of racial conflict in the United States.

The Grand Jury Association instructed its counsel yesterday to appeal the decision of General Sessions Judge Mitchell D. Schweitzer suppressing the presentment drawn by the grand jury investigating television quiz shows.

Massachusetts incurred an interest cost of 3.5215 per cent yesterday to borrow $21,601,000 for various purposes on bonds with maturities ranging from one to thirty years. A syndicate headed jointly by the Chase Manhattan Bank and Halsey Stuart Co., Inc. entered the successful bid of 100.04119 with 3 1/2 and 3.60 per cent coupons.

BROCKVILLE, Ont., Dec. 3 (AP) -- The bulkheads in the hold of the grounded Norwegian freighter Vilja are being crushed by the cargo of dried beans. The beans were dampened and started to expand Sunday when a hole was ripped in the freighter's hull.

A ninety-second "commercial" to persuade pedestrians to cross the street carefully sounded through the intersection of Fifth Avenue and Forty-second Street yesterday. The message, recorded on tape and repeated through a loudspeaker on a traffic-light post, was synchronized with the red and green "Walk-Don't Walk" signals.
LONDON, Dec. 3 -- Dullness descended on the stock market today. However, selling was not heavy and losses generally were about 1 shilling (14 cents).
MONTREAL, Dec. 3 (UPI) -The lowly New York Rangers spoiled Doug Harvey Night at the Forum tonight, routing the league-leading Montreal Canadiens, 7 -- 4.
State Senator William Steelman Mathis of New Jersey pleaded not guilty yesterday in Vehicle Accident Court to a charge of driving while drunk.
Although she retains the lead with 2 1/2 points, Lisa Lane of Philadelphia drew last night in the women's national championship chess tournament at the Marshall Chess Club.
SAYREVILLE, N. J., Dec. 3 -- Twenty-eight persons were injured early this morning in a series of collisions that involved fifty-nine cars in a thick fog on the Garden State Parkway.
PALM SPRINGS, Calif., Dec. 3 (AP) -- Laborn Harris and Ernie Catropa today shared the half-way lead of the $20,000 U. S. senior open golf tournament with 145 for thirty-six holes.
Yields of 5 per cent became more common yesterday as United States Government securities continued to decline.

Representative Joseph W. Martin Jr. of Massachusetts declared here last night that unless Congress and the Eisenhower Administration began a systematic reduction of the budget the country would continue on "a joy-ride to a disastrous crash."
Gross revenues and earnings of the Western Union Telegraph Company in October and the first ten months of this year were higher than in any comparable periods in its 108-year history.
MIAMI, Dec. 3 (UPI) -- Vince Martinez of Miami Beach jabbed and counter-punched to a split decision over Chico Vejar tonight in a ten-round bout.
The New York Giants limbered up yesterday for the giant step that would take them to their second straight Eastern Conference title in the National Football League.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 3 (UPI) -- The Labor Department today predicted a year-end increase in jobs and a possible January spurt in factory hiring if steel supplies are adequate.
Jerry Blaine, a record manufacturer, said yesterday that he had tent Alan Freed $11,000 in 1955 in return for a second mortgage on the disk Jockey's Stamford, Conn., home.

In lamenting the presence of advertising displays in Grand Central Terminal, Blythe Morley Brennan has overlooked the conditions that forced the terminal's owners to rent every possible foot of space.

BONN, Germany, Dec. 3 -- West Germany will cooperate in the development of Britain's new ground-to-ground artillery rocket, the Bluewater, it was announced today after talks between the two countries' defense ministers, Franz Josef Strauss and Harold Watkinson.

Appointment of Delbert L. Mills as vice president -- home instrument operations -- of the Radio Corporation of America, as of Jan. 1, was announced yesterday. He had been president of International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation's Federal division since 1958.
NEWTON, Mass., Dec. 3 (UPI) -- Mike Holovak, a former Boston College backfield star, resigned today as head football coach at his alma mater. He indicated that the resignation had been forced.

Joseph A. Gimma, a stockbroker and treasurer of the New York County Republican committee, was sworn in yesterday as a member of the unpaid State Racing Commission. The ceremony took place in Governor Rockefeller's New York office at 22 West Fifty-fifth Street.

Irving Ferman, executive vice chairman of the President's Committee on Government Contracts, said here yesterday the "most basic and crucial problem" confronting minority groups was discrimination in employment.

BAL HARBOUR, Fla., Dec. 3 -- Even though there may be no deficit financing in 1960 by the Federal Government, the bond market next year could well remain under pressure, securities experts told the convention of he Investment Bankers Association of America here today.

Production of lumber dipped in the Thanksgiving holiday week to 210,011,000 board feet from 263,222,000 board feet in the preceding week, according to reports from regional associations. This compared with the output of 196,390,000 board feet in the similar 1958 week.

Throughout its thirty-eight years of providing seagoing library units for the crews of American flag vessels and Coast Guard craft the American Merchant Marine Library Association has successfully geared its program to meet the literary needs of our seafarers. To maintain its service the A. M. M. L. A., better known as The Public Library of the High Seas, is currently appealing for books and funds.
OXFORD, England, Dec. 3 -- Prime Minister Harold Macmillan returned to Oxford University tonight to take part again, after forty-five years, in a debate at the Oxford Union Society.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Dec. 3 -- Twentieth Century-Fox will considerably expand its production of films in Europe. The movies, which will cost approximately $15,000,000, will be for the United States as well as foreign markets.

FORT MONMOUTH, N. J., Dec. 3 -- An improved highaltitude test chamber that duplicates conditions 100 miles above earth has been put into use at the Army Signal Corps Research and Development Laboratory here.

STAMFORD, Conn., Dec. 3 -Among the last of the annual Christmas fairs held by church organizations in this area will be two on Saturday. One is the "Jingle Bells Fair" at the North Stamford Community House, for the Congregational Church there, and the other is the "Maze of Months" in the social hall of the Union Memorial Church in Glenbrook.

CHICAGO, Dec. 3 (AP) -After two days of moderate to good gains, soybean futures ran into profit taking today and most contracts fell about a cent a bushel. The decline erased about half of the two days' gains on the Board of Trade.
Billy Cannon, the No. 1 choice professional draft choice and the 1959 Heisman Trophy winner yesterday was named for the second straight year to The Associated Press all-America football team.
Five young men who had banded together as a hold-up team and had set up a basement shooting gallery to practice their shots were behind bars yesterday, charged with homicide.
The signing, on Tuesday, of twelve-nation treaty on Antarctica has given new courage to those seeking agreement on the peaceful exploration of outer space.

WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W. Va., Dec. 3 -- Gov. Abraham A. Ribicoff of Connecticut today termed "very, very unfair" one provision of the Rockefeller Administration's plan for settling the nonresident income tax problem.

The American Ship Building Company, Cleveland, announced yesterday it had purchased Automobile Transport, Inc., Wayne, Mich., a carrier of new cars, primarily for the Ford Motor Company. American Ship Building said it purchased all the outstanding stock for an undisclosed amount from the three principals of Automobile Transport. Donald L. Wartina, Carsten Tiedman, and John W. Harrington.
Following is the text of President Eisenhower's televisionradio address last night from Washington, as recorded by The New York Times:

WASHINGTON, Dec. 3 (AP) -- The Food and Drug Administration disclosed today that it planned to study possibilities that human health might be affected by residues of a female hormone in meat and poultry.

VIENNA, Dec. 3 -- The Polish Communist Government is faced with the fact that its international role is dwindling. It is dwindling as a sort of conduit between East and West and it is dwindling within the Soviet bloc.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 3 (UPI) -- Dave Beck, former national Teamsters Union president, accused the Senate rackets committee today of having created so much publicity unfavorable to him that it was impossible for Beck to get a fair trial in his tax case.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 3 -- Vice President Richard M. Nixon's legal position, with President Eisenhower out of the country, remains the same, but his political position is greatly enhanced.
SAN JUAN, P. R., Dec. 3 (AP) -- Gov. Luis Munoz Marin said today statehood for Puerto Rico was currently "an economic impossibility."
LOS ANGELES, Calif., Dec. 3 (AP) -- Mickey Cohen, six feet away when an underworld figure was killed in a restaurant last night, was jailed today on suspicion of murder.
WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W. Va., Dec. 3 -- A sampling of opinion among Republican Governors indicates that Vice President Richard M. Nixon is far in the lead for the Republican Presidential nomination.
JUST by window-shopping it is possible to get in the festive spirit these days, and lavish Christmas displays are by no means confined to department stores.
Formulas are being changed constantly on all sorts of products, and there are headaches a plenty for manufacturers and merchandisers as a result.
Colleagues and old friends of Dr. Alfred E. Cohn, the heart specialist, honored his memory and dedicated the library named for him at Rockefeller Institute yesterday afternoon.
The Board of Estimate adopted a 1960 capital budget of $613,646,619 yesterday.

PARIS, Dec. 3 (Reuters) -The dollar shortage that has troubled most European economies for many years "is no longer a problem," the eighteennation Organization for European Economic Cooperation reported today.
A member of Congress urged an amendment to the TaftHartley Act yesterday to deal with "national emergencies" such as the threatened railroad strike and a possible renewal of the steel strike.
A drum and bugle corps provided loud but most appropriate entertainment at a charity ball in the Grand Ballroom of the Astor last night.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 3 (AP) -- Vice President Richard M. Nixon was made a "Li'l Tiger" today by two smiling Korean newsboys who visited his Capitol office.
LONDON, Dec. 3 -- Hugh Gaitskell denied tonight that his position as leader of the Labor party was in danger.
CHICAGO, Dec. 3 (AP) -- The report of today's livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:
The National Legion of Decency announced yesterday that it had rated the forthcoming Columbia film, "Suddenly Last Summer," as being "separatedclassified."

The Board of Estimate killed yesterday the sharply debated local bill to make parents responsible for acts of vandalism by their children. The vote was 18 to 4. The bill would have held parents financially liable for damage up to $25.

SCARSDALE, N. Y., Dec. 3 -Handmade gifts and homebaked favorites will be offered for sale at the annual Christmas bazaar of the Scarsdale Women's Exchange. The fete will be held tomorrow at the Scarsdale Woman's Club.
CORONADO, Calif., Dec. 3 -- The Masters' Individual contest at the American Contract Bridge League's National Tournament here can be reassuring to the average bridge player.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 3 (AP) -- Continental Airlines offered today to provide nonstop jet service to Hawaii from five western and midwestern cities at a 33 per cent fare reduction.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 3 -- Reliable sources said today that Soviet-Western differences over a United Nations body governing the peaceful uses of outer space had narrowed.
Fuller Smith Ross, Inc., has acquired a Los Angeles agency with billings estimated at $5,000,000 a year.

The death of Aaron Sapiro ends the career of a man who rendered outstanding service to the whole nation. He had the courage to enter into combat with a powerful individual who had been misguided into using his great wealth for activities that were undermining the foundations of our country.
BAL HARBOUR, Fla. Dec. 3 -- The Export-Import Bank today invited investment banking interests to become an equityfinancing partner of the Government lending institution.
Presidential politics was injected into the Apalachin trial yesterday for a brief but stormy period.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange moved 1 point (5 cents a bale) off to 7 points (35 cents a bale) up yesterday. The July, October and December new positions showed the most strength.

A new book of nonfiction by Christine Arnothy, author of "I Am Fifteen -- And I Don't Want To Die," will be published Feb. 18 by Dutton. Called "It Is Not So Easy to Live, " the book continues the author's story after her escape from Hungary.

The general church fund of the Protestant Episcopal Church of the Heavenly Rest and the scholarship fund of its Day School will benefit from two theatre parties to the Christmas stage show and the film, "Operation Petticoat," starring Cary Grant and Tony Curtis at the Radio City Music Hall.

LATE today at headquarters of the Louise Wise Services, one of the city's major adoption agencies, a group of couples will meet to discuss what it means to become, by choice, the parents of a handicapped child.
RIO DE JANEIRO, Dec. 3 -A small group of air force officers seized five Brazilian planes today and set up revolutionary headquarters in a jungle town.

The new collection of furniture designed by Darell Landrum is as precisely tailored as ever. But this modern designer is softening some of his T-square shapes with built-in lighting and inlaid wood. The collection is available through decorators at Avard, 66 West Fifty-fifth Street.

Armour Co., the nation's second largest meat packer, is sharing the results of a successful year through a quarterly cash dividend of 30 cents. In addition it has declared a special dividend of one-fortieth of a share of capital stock of International Packers, Ltd., for each share of Amour common.

The election of four top officials was announced by William A. Blount, president of Liggett Myers Tobacco Company, following a meeting of the directors. Zach Toms, senior vice president, was named executive vice president.
MOSCOW, Dec. 3 -- Soviet clowns returned to the arenas this week with a heavy ideological burden.

Broadway will see two of Hollywood's top stars, Charlton Heston and Anthony Perkins, in "The Tumbler" and "Greenwillow," respectively. "The Tumbler" is headed for the Helen Hayes, where it will open Feb. 24. "Greenwillow" is due March 3 at the Alvin.
PIERRE FOURNIER, cellist, and Ralph Kirkpatrick, harpischordist, gave a joint recital of nothing but Bach and drew an S. R. O. crowd to the Rogers Auditorium of the Metropolitan Museum.

The American Committee on Africa urged the United States Government yesterday to encourage negotiations for a peaceful settlement in Algeria. The committee statement, signed by forty-six persons, also was presented to three ministers of the Algerian Provisional Government at the Algeria office, 150 East Fifty-sixth Street.

Trading in commodity futures was dull yesterday on the New York exchanges. Prices drifted down on most markets. Copper, hides, potatoes, cottonseed oil, soybean oil rubber and platinum declined. Price movements for cocoa, coffee, sugar, wool, lead and zinc were mixed.
CORAL GABLES, Fla., Dec. 3 (AP) -- Julius Boros hit long, low tee shots into the wind and carded a four-under-par 67 today for a one-stroke lead in the $25,000 Coral Gables open golf tournament.
An ancient compilation of remedies for ills ranging from ague to yaws was added to the library of the Methodist Hospital of Brooklyn yesterday.

WILLIAMSBURG, Va., Dec. 3 (UPI) -- Winthrop Rockefeller, board chairman of Colonial Williamsburg, predicted today that before the end of the century, the United States would need forty times the land now set aside for national parks and scenic areas.
A nineteen-member paid staff, with salaries totaling $124,610 a year, was set up for the controversial Slum Clearance Committee yesterday by the Board of Estimate.
ROME, Dec. 3 -- Rome is in a mounting fever of excitement over President Eisenhower's arrival tomorrow.
The final entrant in the 1960 domestic passenger car field, the Superba, made its appearance yesterday.
PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 3 (UPI) -- Cincinnati's late rally fell short tonight and Boston edged the Royals, 114 -- 111, in a National Basketball Association game.
Leaders of the International Longshoremen's Association and officials of the New York Shipping Association yesterday signed a "memorandum of settlement" on terms for a new three-year contract.

Two small colleges that had football squads strong enough to upset a major team during the 1959 season -- Delaware and West Chester (Pa.) State -- each placed two men on their Eastern collegiate athletic conference divisional all-star team.
HEMPSTEAD, L. I., Dec. 3 -Paintings, sculpture and other objects of art were taken from attics in homes to Hofstra College here today by anxious owners seeking fame or fortune.

NASSAU, Bahamas, Dec. 3 -- Richie Ginther of Los Angeles in a new 4.1 Ferrari, Sterling Moss of England in an Aston Martin 4.2 and Phil Hill of Santa Monica, Calif., in a 3-liter Ferrari made the fastest lap times today as more than 100 practiced for the series of international races scheduled over the week-end.
Stocks moved irregularly upward yesterday as Wall Street apparently decided that the outlook was good for a speedy settlement of the steel strike.
LONDON, Dec. 3 -- The British Labor party formally refused tonight to participate in an advisory commission on the future of three British territories in central Africa.
Just when Placido Gomez was envisioning the sunniest basketball season in his sevenyear stand as Brooklyn College's head coach, three key injuries cropped up to darken the picture.

FREJUS, France, Dec. 3 -- From a light plane flying 800 feet over the devastated valley below the broken Malpasset Dam the impression is that the wall broke like a flower pot in huge shards along the lines of the seams in the concrete.

CHRISTMAS decorations this year look good enough to eat. An abundant harvest of fake and preserved fruits; vegetables and nuts is giving a new and fanciful appearance to wreaths, trees, swags and centerpieces.

Supreme Court Justice Arthur Markewich heard arguments yesterday in a suit involving the $10,000,000 cooperative housing project that would be sponsored in Queens by New York Typographical Union No. 6.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 3 -- The United States, Britain and other Western countries have agreed upon a resolution that would "deplore" the refusal of the Soviet Union and Hungary to comply with General Assembly resolutions on the Hungarian question.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 3 -Proposals for a "Super-Secretary of State" and a traveling foreign minister were made in a Congressional staff report today.

KEENE, N. H. Dec. 3 (UPI) -- Health officials said today that a lumberjack was the carrier of typhoid fever, which has put thirteen persons in this city of 45,000 in the hospital. The outbreak is believed to be under control.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 3 -President Eisenhower departed tonight on a journey to three continents after he had told the nation that his purpose was to acquaint the world with the American ideal of "peace and friendship, in freedom."

THE Fashion Group, an organization of professional women involved in the fashion business, celebrated thirty years of existence at luncheon yesterday by: announcing a new president, Sarah Tomerlin Lee (vice president of Hockaday Advertising Agency); revealing that its chapters from Hawaii to New York to Paris now number thirty; and by showing twenty-two fashions for children designed to illustrate nursery rhymes.

A stirring performance by New York University's hardworking quintet and a shocking reversal of shooting form by St. John's marked the opening program of the twenty-sixth season of college basketball at Madison Square Garden last night.
Dramatic differences in scholastic achievement have been found among the city's public schools.

The Federal Home Loan Bank Board has agreed to the establishment of a new statechartered savings and loan association in Oceanside, L. I., by approving Federal insurance of its savings accounts. At the same time, the agency has turned down the application of a federally chartered institution in Long Beach, L. I., seeking to set up a branch in Oceanside.
The Christmas season and year-end factors dominated the money market in the week ended Wednesday.

A post-debutante committee headed by the Misses Ann Dana and Melissa A. Travis, co-chairmen, has been chosen to assist in plans for the annual Mistletoe Debutante Ball in the St. Regis Roof on Dec. 23. Young women from New York, Westchester County and Connecticut will be presented at the event.

Maurice E. Olen, former head of a large variety department store chain, was indicted here yesterday on conspiracy charges in connection with an alleged $6,000,000 fraud that led to a public issuance of stock and the 1958 merger of the Olen Company, Inc., into H. L. Green Company, Inc.

A New York University basketball originally intended for the N. Y. U.-Marquette game at Madison Square Garden last night was diverted during the afternoon to a patient on the seventh floor of the Hospital for Special Surgery, 535 East Seventieth Street.

Magistrate Anthony E. Maglio conceded yesterday that he had reduced the charges against two hoodlums accused of severely beating a young policeman on his own discretion without benefit of any statute.
NORTHAMPTON, Mass., Dec. 3 (AP) -- Gov. Robert B. Meyner of New Jersey said today that legislators, on occasion, had asked him to veto their own bills.

TENAHA, Tex, Dec. 3 (UPI) -- The assistant cashier of the First State Bank confessed today that he "started taking a little" three or four years ago and wound up with a total embezzlement of $340,000. This was more than a third of the bank's total deposits.
Two Russian-born brothers were accused yesterday of offering for sale "a completely phony art collection" that they said was worth $25,000,000.

BELHAVEN, N. C., Dec. 3 -This could be a note of consolation to Gov. Luther Hodges of North Carolina, who last night cheerfully admitted to goose skunkage on Lake Mattamuskeet. There was desperate skunkage along the lake today: in the midst of plenty one party starved.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 3 -- The Thanksgiving Day holiday had its usual effect in reducing both railway car loadings and truckloadings to less than normal levels.

When President Eisenhower arrives today in Rome he will find a Europe in which the old order that plunged the Continent for centuries into suicidal strife and led to its relative decline is at odds with a new order just emerging.
A survey conducted by the Gallup Organization, Inc., shows that 66 per cent of those polled believe television needs stricter regulation in the wake of the scandal over rigged quiz shows.
CLEVELAND, Dec. 3 (AP) -- Iron ore shippers, hurrying to bring ore down from upper Great Lakes ports before the winter freeze, moved 5,065,942 gross tons in the last three weeks of November.
Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt will be the guest on a special "U. N. in Action" telecast observing Human Rights Day Sunday, Dec. 13.
Two men were captured last night and were accused of raping two girls at knife-point in an automobile in Brooklyn.

A proposal to reintroduce public opinion as a curb on both labor or management in subway or bus wage disputes was laid before the Joint Legislative Committee on Industrial and Labor Conditions yesterday.

ST. PETERSBURG, Dec. 3 -Moving with alacrity and, for a change, with surprising clarity, the minor leagues today voted to continue the "one-year" section of the major-minor draft rule for twelve months.
LONDON, Dec. 3 -- Blaming United States "intervention," Cuba struck back angrily today at Britain's refusal to sell fifteen jet fighter aircraft to the Havana Government.
DETROIT, Dec. 4 (AP) -Ward's Automotive Reports said today that the auto industry had begun the slow return to volume production after a six-week decline because of steel shortages.

The head of the Anti-Defamation League of B'nai B'rith asserted yesterday that American Jews must share the responsibility "for hindering social relations" between themselves and their non-Jewish neighbors.

Administration proponents of Civil Service status for the United States Merchant Marine Academy at Kings Point, L. I., clashed yesterday with faculty members who are fighting to retain their quasi-military standing.

This has been a remarkable year in the stock market in regard to investor interest and trading activity. Just how remarkable is emphasized by the report that the New York Stock Exchange and the American Stock Exchange will pay a Christmas bonus of four weeks' salary to employes with a year or more service.
PIMLICO, Md., Dec. 4 -- With an unruly black forelock draping his forehead, 17-year-old Frank Northcutt tried to explain today how he became the nation's leading apprentice rider in less than a year.

On Nov. 15 you carried an item by Jack Raymond from Washington, stating: "High Army officials have been outraged by a Budget Bureau proposal to deprive the Army of its general war mission and bring back from overseas at least two divisions, an authoritative source said today."
The National Broadcasting Company announced last night it had taken control of all arrangements for obtaining merchandise prizes given away on shows on its television network.
MILLBURN, N. J., Dec. 4 -The police chief here today proposed a code of conduct for teen-age parties during the Christmas season.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 4 (AP) -- The Defense Department announced today that it would concentrate future manufacture of boron high-energy fuels at the Callery Chemical Company plant at Muskogee, Okla.
The wife of Willie Mays last night denied reports that she and her husband had sold their $37,500 house in a fashionable San Francisco neighborhood because of racial difficulties.
Borough President Hulan E. Jack, after a stormy meeting in his office yesterday, dissolved the Citizens Watchdog Committee for the Penn Station South slum clearance project.
Three physicians were arrested and charged with being part of a $6,000-a-week abortion ring late Thursday night.
CHICAGO, Dec. 4 (UPI) -Members of the executive board of the United Packinghouse Workers today picketed the board of directors of strike- bound Wilson Co.
HAVANA, Dec. 4 -- A high Cuban official said today that he had obtained for Cuba credits of $100,000,000 in Europe despite efforts of United States interests to prevent it.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 4 (UPI) -- The San Francisco Forty-Niners, battling for their first divisional pennant, will meet the champion Baltimore Colts in Kezar Stadium tomorrow before a sell-out crowd of 60,000.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 4 (AP) -- The Association of American Railroads today estimated that the net income of class I rail carriers for October fell to $50,000.000, reflecting the sharp decrease in freight volume resulting from the steel strike.
INDIANAPOLIS, Dec. 4 -The American Legion cut its public ties with its fun-making 40 8 Society today over racial membership restrictions.
CHICAGO, Dec. 4 (AP) -Trading in soybeans at firm prices accounted for most of the futures business again today on the Board of Trade. Grains generally were steady to weak in meager transactions.
Stocks moved uncertainly yesterday and ended irregular, with only the steels, drugs and electronics showing much more than average strength. There was some excitement also in low-price issues.
At the Park Theatre one evening eighty years ago a young actor was cast to play a minor role in a piece with Edward Askew Sothern, the man who made Lord Dundreary famous in "Our American Cousin."
SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 4 -The Western Shipbuilding Association came into being today. It was formed by the Pacific coast shipbuilding industry to fight competition from the Atlantic and Gulf coasts.
A Moroccan insurance company that has been accused of fraud is under investigation in this state to determine whether it has entered the savings bank deposit field in New York.

PERTH AMBOY, N. J., Dec. 4 -- The series of early-morning multiple collisions in the Garden State Parkway south of here yesterday resulted in one death and a second motorist has now been listed in critical condition.
VIENNA, Dec. 4 -- The Austrian Government is considering requesting the United Nations General Assembly to put the Alto Adige (South Tyrol) question on its agenda.
Allen W. Dulles, director of the Central Intelligence Agency, warned yesterday that the Soviet bloc was trying to dominate the entire free world under cover of its "peaceful coexistence" slogan.

Directors of the Beatrice Foods Company voted a 25 per cent stock dividend yesterday and proposed an increase in the cash rate on the additional shares. Following announcement of the two actions the stock rose to a new 1959 high of 53 5/8 and closed at 53 1/8 for a gain of 1 5/8 points.

THE "little woman" at home is a big factor to the United States Postal Service according to both the New York and Brooklyn postmasters. The post office officials hope housewives will help materially in assisting mailmen to meet the Yuletide deadline by bringing in Christmas packages and cards -- now -- if they are to reach their destination prior to Dec. 25.
CIUDAD TRUJILLO, Dominican Republic, Dec. 4 (AP) -The Dominican Government says it has spent an extra $50,000,000 for armaments this year.

A 486-seat auditorium in midtown Manhattan continues to show movie history and to make it. Starting tomorrow a new series, "American Film Comedy," will be presented by the Museum of Modern Art at the regular daily hours of 3 and 5:30 P. M.
Maureen O'Hara, film actress, has been signed by Oscar S. Lerman and Martin B. Cohen to star in their forthcoming musical, "Christine."
ISAAC STERN worked hard for his fee at the New York Philharmonic concert at Carnegie Hall yesterday afternoon. He appeared in all three of the concertos that made up the program.

A MIXED bag of letters yielded this week's reader column. One tells of a homemaker's efforts to make a poundcake, which were greeted with dismal failure. Another is from a reader who was successful in inventing a tasty accompaniment for poultry or game and was kind enough to share her recipe.

In an editorial titled "Intolerance, 1959," the newspaper of the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of New York said today that "Protestant misrepresentatives like Bishop [James A.] Pike" differ from the Ku Klux Klan "only in degree."
Three new members and a new president have been selected by the American Academy of Arts and Letters.
CHICAGO, Dec. 4 (AP) -- The climb of the nation's traffic death toll has been halted.
A new inspection has found tracks on the seven-mile Jamaica line of the BMT subway in safe condition.

The Consolidated Edison Company appealed yesterday to the Public Service Commission for immediate authorization of a rate increase and other changes that would bring $16,500,000 additional revenue annually.
MOST hairdressers love helpless women who can barely open a bobby pin. The exception is a man named Mr. Albert.

KANSAS CITY, Mo., Dec. 4 (AP) -- Christmas shoppers groped around darkened stores, firemen got frantic calls, traffic became snarled and many persons were trapped in elevators today during an earlyafternoon power failure that blacked out much of the greater Kansas City area.
The new president of the National Association of Manufacturers proposed yesterday a return to company-level bargaining to remove the "distrust and surliness" in labor-management relations.
SQUAW VALLEY, Calif., Dec. 4 (UPI) -- If there is big medicine in the Indian snow dance, there should be snow on the slopes of Squaw Valley within two weeks.
WASHINGTON, Dec 4 -- Mediation of the steel dispute limped along today while top bargainers for the United Steelworkers of America held side talks with important elements of the can industry.
A strike of Long Island Rail Road trainmen, scheduled for early Monday morning, was deferred yesterday after the National Mediation Board intervened in the dispute.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 4 -The United States is withdrawing its naval mission from the Dominican Republic at the request of the Government there.

TORONTO, Dec. 4 -- The Northern Ontario Natural Gas Company decided today to intervene in Trans-Canada Pipe Lines' ap- plication to Canada's National Energy Board for permission to export Alberta gas to the United States.
MINEOLA, L. I., Dec. 4 -The American Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals scored a legal victory for a dog here today.
Governor Rockefeller urged yesterday that New Yorkers place more emphasis on religious teaching, especially in the home.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 4 -- Lieut. Gen. E. L. M Burns of Canada has resigned as commander of the United Nations Emergency Force in the Middle East. He will represent his Government at disarmament commission talks in Geneva early next year.

BLUE POINT, L. I., Dec. 4 -R. Ford Hughes announced this afternoon that he would resign as chairman of the Suffolk County Republican party next Wednesday. At the same time, the choice of a successor was narrowed to two candidates as Sheriff Charles R. Dominy withdrew from the race.
Three detectives of the narcotics bureau -- employing a Santa Claus costume, a Christmas bell and lollipops for children -arrested seven narcotics suspects in Harlem yesterday.

May I express my heartfelt support of your Nov. 23 editorial on New York City's need for a museum of science and technology. I have discussed this matter with students, faculty colleagues and our college president, Dr. Otto Klitgord. It is favored unanimously.
