UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 4 -- The Algerian Provisional Government will not discuss a cease-fire with France without first having guarantees of an impartial referendum in Algeria, the Algerian representatives here said today.

President Eisenhower is now asserting a personal control over American foreign policy never displayed before the death of Secretary Dulles. Since last June he has taken a new interest and initiative in this all-important field. Today's United States foreign policy is thus an Eisenhower policy in appearance as well as constitutional fact.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Dec. 4 -- Gov. Edmund G. Brown of California asserted today that it would be "rough and expensive" for an outsider to campaign for his state's 81 Democratic convention votes next spring.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 4 -- The Government's politically controversial offer to exchange $150,000,000 of the 4 per cent Veterans Administration - guaranteed mortgages it owns for 2 3/4 per cent bonds owned by investors has attracted $282,881,300 of bids.
MIAMI BEACH, Dec. 4 -- The major league meetings, which open here Monday, may go off quietly, but there also is a chance of one jarring note. That involves the presence of the new Continental League.

LOS ANGELES, Dec. 4 -- The pride of the East, Syracuse's mighty Orange eleven places its national chamiponship hopes on the line tomorrow against one of the West's best, the University of California at Los Angeles.
ROME, Dec. 4 (Reuters) -Following are the texts of the welcoming speech by President Giovanni Gronchi of Italy and the reply by President Eisenhower on the latter's arrival here today:
A series of daytime specials for National Broadcasting Company television is well into the planning stage.
The Jan. 11 performance of "Saratoga" has been chosen by the Bargain Box, Inc., for its annual theatre benefit.

Though President Eisenhower cannot extend his world tour to the Far East, he demonstrated America's equal concern with that vital region by beginning his pre-departure press conference with the announcement that Premier Kishi of Japan is coming to Washington next month to complete and presumably sign a revised American-Japanese alliance pact.
LONDON, Dec. 4 -- The Iraq Petroleum Company's office here has not yet received Premier Kassim's demand for the surrender of 60 per cent of the company's concessionary areas, an informant said.
Two 14-year-old Korean newsboys arrived here from Washington yesterday for a three-day visit.
ART CARNEY enjoyed a delightfully irreverent romp on Channel 4 last night.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 4 -John L. Holcombe, a lawyer and career civil servant, will head the new Bureau of Labor-Management Reports in the Department of Labor.
On a recent Saturday I took my young son to the Wollman Memorial Skating Rink in Central Park to give him his first skating lesson.
City College will begin its fifty-fifth intercollegiate basketball season tonight when it faces Columbia University in the Beavers' Wingate gymnasium, 139th Street and Convent Avenue.
The formation of a nationwide protective network similar to the Thoroughbred Racing Protective Bureau is being considered by Harness Tracks of America.
PANAMA, Dec. 4 (UPI) -Panama's Superior Court ordered trials today for seven Cubans and three Panamanians on charges arising from an abortive invasion of Panama last April.
A compromise settlement of differences threatening an economic split of Western Europe was forecast yesterday by a leading West German industrialist.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 4 -- The Federal Aviation Agency put a 60-year limit today on the age of airline pilots.
We have noted with great interest the editorial entitled "The Excluded American" in your paper of Nov. 30.
CONTEMPORARY Canadian painting being comparatively little known south of the border, the current exhibition of work by twentysix artists at Canada House, 680 Fifth Avenue, is most welcome.

An unusually heavy volume of new capital issues of diverse origin is scheduled to reach the market next week. Stocks and bonds valued at more than $350,000,000 are listed on the calendar. The largest deal in the offing is an offering of 2,000,000 shares of common stock of Ford Motor Company, which Blyth Co. and associates are marketing on Wednesday.

LOGAN, Utah, Dec. 4 (UPI) -- Gene Fullmer, the champion, won a unanimous decision over Ellsworth (Spider) Webb tonight in their fifteen-round fight for the National Boxing Association middleweight title.
The sale of Butler Brothers, a leading variety stores chain to the City Products Corporation has been approved by directors of both companies, it was announced yesterday.
NASHVILLE, Tenn., Dec. 4 (UPI) -- Officials of Hoover Motor Express announced yes- terday they had signed an aooTeement to sell the trucking company to the Ryder System, Inc., of Miami, Fla.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 4 (AP) -- Retail sales in October rose to $19,100,000,000, mainly be- cause of a spurt in automobile bu)irig, the Department of Commerce reported today.
Governor Rockefeller will receive a report from his task force on youth problems and juvenile delinquency in time for him to recommend measures early in the 1960 legislative session.
BAGHDAD, Iraq, Dec. 4 -Premier Abdul Karim Kassim's Government has asked the Iraq Petroleum Company to give up 60 per cent of its concession. This would amount to about 100,000 square miles.

Events today: "The Gypsy Baron." Metropolitan Opera, 2; New York Sinfonietta, conductor. Max Goberman, Carnegie Hall, 5:30; Paulina Ruvinska, pianist, Carnegie Recital Hall, 5:30; "Cavalleria Rusticana" and "Pagliacci," Metropolitan Opera, 8; New York Philharmonic, conductor, Bernstein, Isaac Stern, violinist, John Wummer, flutist, Leonard Rose, 'cellist Carnegie Hall, 8:30; Frans Brouw, pianist, Carnegie Recital Hall, 8:30.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 4 -After five lively weeks with Shaw's "Major Barbara," Arena Stage has allocated three weeks to a new playwright.
LONDON, Dec. 4 (AP) -- A Soviet broadcast announced today a new radio series linking the Krasnaya region, 200 miles northeast of Moscow, with Oneida County, New York.
BRUSSELS, Belgium, Dec. 4 -- August de Schryver, Minister of the Belgian Congo and Ruandu-Urundi, denied today a request by three African leaders that elections in the Belgian Congo be postponed.
Two hundred and seventy-two Harlem landlords have been directed to appear in court next week to answer charges that they failed to rid their buildings of rats or conditions causing rats.
Soviet scientists are expected to rejoin next month the international scientific committee that plans to coordinate the exploration of outer space.
A personality distinction between persons who tolerate pain differently was described here yesterday by a Harvard University scientist.

STRATFORD - ON - AVON, Dec. 4 (AP) -- Trustees of William Shakespeare's birthplace have spurned the thatched-cottage style of architecture and announced that a new memorial to the bard will have a modern look.
A major American steamship company yesterday moved to promote the sales overseas of its customers' products.
LARCHMONT, N. Y., Dec. 4 -- A commuters' parking area on a concrete slab above the New England Thruway here was called "completely successful" today by village officials.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 5 -When James P. Mitchell, Secretary of Labor, appointed two hard-working bureaucrats to be Assistant Commissioners of Labor-Management Reports without filling the top job, the wise guys guessed that he was saving it for a political hack.
Large awards for housing and industrial building in the opening week of December con-[ tinued the. recent strong show- ing of heavy construction contracts, The Engineering News-Record reports.
TROY, N. Y., Dec. 4 -- A pledge of $1,000,000 to Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute has been made by Mr. and Mrs. John Erik Jonsson of Dallas.

UTICA, N. Y., Dec. 4 (AP) -Oneida was the top dairy-producing county in the New YorkNew Jersey marketing area last year. It had the highest income from milk, $21,000,000. The county has 1,800 dairy farmers.

Speaking of America's scenic and natural resources, someone has aptly said that "what isn't saved in the next few years isn't going to be saved at all." A man who has spent most of his lifetime saving them, and persuading others they should be saved, is Horace M. Albright, former director of the National Park Service and one of the best known and most respected conservationists in the country.

On Flatbush Avenue Extension in Brooklyn, Long Island University is involved in an ambitious construction program in the midst of an asphalt jungle. Buck Lai, the athletic director, also is building. His project is a basketball squad.

Vincent A. Schiano, Immigration Service agent, charged the agency yesterday with attempting to force him to resign by transferring him to Alaska. He said this was because he had figured prominently in an investigation that resulted in a smuggling indictment against Arthur Lem, a prominent restaurateur of Hempstead, L. I.
BOSTON, Dec. 4 -- Dr. James R. Killian Jr. asserted tonight that problems of arms limitation posed one of the greatest intellectual challenges of the times.
PALM SPRINGS, Calif., Dec. 4 (AP) -- Playing flawless golf for seventeen holes today, Olin Dutra fired a 4-under-par 68 to take a one-stroke lead in the $20,000 senior open golf tournament.
Some ruffled local Democratic feelings were soothed yesterday in preparation for the big gathering of Democratic Presidential aspirants and party dignitaries that starts here today.

Sixty shouting pickets demonstrated for two hours yesterday in front of the City Labor Department, 93 Worth Street, to call attention to a union demand that five job titles covering 7,500 city employes be revised upward, with corresponding wage increases.
Work-bound Brooklyn and Queens subway riders were delayed yesterday morning by disruptions affecting all three transit divisions.

A BEWILDERED gentleman, shopping for the women on his Christmas list in Bergdorf's recently, was heard to say, "All these little things for women make me dizzy. Every year they change the top on the cigarette boxes and add a new gimmick to the lighters.

LONDON, Dec. 4 -- The stock markets were appreciably steadier today than yesterday, but still generally unsettled. An indication of the steadiness was industrial share prices which seemed to be rising in late business.

BELHAVEN, N. C., Dec. 4 -Even Columbus Hudson couldn't do much with wild geese this morning, and in these parts that means that wild geese weren't flying. There are people around here who believe Hudson can call geese off another man's decoys five miles upwind.
Two ex-convicts were charged in Brooklyn Felony Court yesterday with rape, kidnapping and other crimes. They were arrested Thursday in an attack on two young girls.

CORONADO, Calif., Dec. 4 -New York and Miami players shared the lead as the Masters' Team of Four contest entered its final round in the American Contract Bridge League's National Tournament here today.
City investigators shifted from meat to gasoline yesterday in surprise visits to 315 gasoline stations and garages in every borough except Richmond.

Buster Keaton, who began a career in vaudeville at the age of 3 and became one of the great comics of the silent screen, has written an account of his life called "My Wonderful World of Slapstick." The book recalls Keaton's "golden years" -- the Twenties -- and relates anecdotes of Chaplin, Durante, Laurel and Hardy, Fatty Arbuckle and other great comedians.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 4 -- The National Institute of Mental Health will recommend to the next session of Congress that Federal aid be given to some urban projects for curbing juvenile delinquency. The programs favored would be long - range ones in crisis areas of a few large cities.

THOMAS DUNN led the Cantata Singers through two contrasting works last night at St. Michael's Protestant Episcopal Church. They were Purcell's "Coronation Anthem" of 1685 and Benjamin Britten's "St. Nicholas Cantata" of 1948: two British choral works spread almost 300 years apart.

CORONADO, Calif., Dec. 4 -When a tournament has as close a finish as this year's Life Masters' Individual contest, which ended here yesterday, nearly any of the leaders can think of one or two hands on which he could have won the championship by different choice of bids or plays.

SALISBURY, Southern Rhodesia, Dec. 4 -- Sir Roy Welensky, Prime Minister of the Central African Federation, and other white leaders here criticized the British Labor party today for its boycott of the Monckton Commission.
The old refrain, "Stop No. 32 and you stop Cleveland," receives no support among them braintrust of the New York Football Giants.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 4 -- A university professor has, he believes, eliminated the need of woofers and tweeters in highfidelity sound reproduction.

MOSCOW, Dec. 4 -- The Soviet Minister of Geology reported today that discoveries of oil and gas deposits in Uzbekistan and Turkmenia promised to make those Far East areas among the richest in the Soviet Union.

LOGAN, Utah, Dec. 4 (UPI) -- Sullen and dejected Spider Webb claimed he was "robbed" by partisan ring officials tonight. He said he would like another crack at Gene Fullmer's title "anyplace outside of Utah."

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 4 (UPI) -- Two Pennsylvania backfield stars, Fred Doelling and Jack Hanlon, today cancelled plans to play in post-season games. Their participation might have cost Penn its Ivy League championship.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 4 (AP) -- Three new products for removing wax from the ears are causing painful injuries and are being voluntarily withdrawn from the market, the Food and Drug Administration announced today.
PARIS, Dec. 4 -- France rallied today to the aid of the Reyran River valley, devastated Wednesday night when the Malpasset Dam, north of the Riviera town of Frejus, burst.

MORRISTOWN, N. J., Dec. 4 -- A report that the Port of New York Authority proposes to build a major commercial airport in Morris County's Great Swamp got a New Jersey reception today that varied from cool to very cold.

NEWMARKET, England, Dec. 4 (AP) -- The five-day sale of Britain's best racing bloodstock closed today with the unfamiliar spectacle of American buyers beating a retreat before British pounds. The sales totaled a record $4,547,648.
Third-quarter earnings of the Morrison - Knudsen Company, Inc., this year were well above the 1958 level. However, earnings for the nine months declined.
BUTTONS, buckles and bows are big business to Miss Mary Kaltenbruner. For thirtytwo years, "Miss Mary" has been an integral part of Delman, one of Fifth Avenue's most elegant shoe salons.

What better place could there be to start a world-wide "mission of peace and goodwill" than Rome? Geography made it convenient for President Eisenhower to have his first stopover in Rome; history made it apt.
ATLANTA, Dec. 4 -- Two unidentified men, saying "Merry Christmas and God bless you," gave away thousands of dollars in $50 bills today.
ROME, Dec. 4 (AP) -- Mrs. John S. D. Eisenhower summed up her impression of Rome tonight by saying, "It's exciting."

It was in the "Roaring Twenties" that followed World War I that a 24-year-old New Englander, a nominee of one of the established names in United States finance, took his place on a lower rung of one of the nation's most renowned investment banking houses, only to be slapped down rudely by the financial catastrophe of 1929 and the ensuing long and bitter sequel of a depression.

BONN, Germany, Dec. 4 -For the first time since World War II, the idea of an eventual United States military withdrawal from Western Europe is being discussed openly by Continental officials and newspapers.
The striking physical and mental recovery of a child severely depressed and physically ill at the age of 16 months was reported here yesterday.

The reported opposition of four presidents of the boroughs of New York City and Controller Lawrence E. Gerosa to the fluoridation of the city water is gratifying and heartwarming to many people. They are thus reassured that the thoughtful majority of the Board of Estimate will eliminate the possibility of exposing the population to drinking water containing a chemical which is a powerful poison.
Dull trading prevailed on most New York commodity exchanges yesterday. Evening of positions prior to the week-end accounted for most of the volume.
The culmination of Leif Ericson's storied voyage to the New World is the theme of a mural that will be unveiled tonight in the Norwegian Children's Home, 1355 Eighty-fourth Street, Brooklyn.
Reasons ranging from sheer weight of numbers to the psychology and physiology of the adult male have been advanced to explain why men pedestrians are the principal victims in holiday accidents.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 4 -A rise of 23 per cent in ship traffic through the Golden Gate since 1950 was reported today by the Marine Exchange, Inc. The volume of import and export tonnage increased but intercoastal volume dropped during the period.

"Too many books about the United States are written by men who have spent only a few weeks in the country," Alex Atkinson believes. "This one is different: it is by a man who has never been there in his life."
The market for United States Government securities staged a rally in the final half hour of trading yesterday. The upturn, the first this week, lifted prices 4/32 to 8/32.

DALLAS, Tex., Dec. 4 (AP) -- A Veterans Administration scientist today said tissue studies of 238 men who smoked more than a half pack of cigarettes daily showed cell changes that "probably represent a change toward cancer."
HONG KONG, Dec. 4 -- Communist China announced today the pardon of Henry Pu Yi, former Emperor of China and the Japanese puppet state of Manchukuo, who had been imprisoned as a war criminal.
SALT LAKE CITY, Dec. 4 -Without all the usual fanfare, pandemonium and speculative activity usually associated with a major oil discovery, Utah is in the midst of a quiet but substantial oil boom.
The cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange advanced 2 to 11 points (10 to 55 cents a bale) yesterday, with the far months strongest.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 4 -- President Eisenhower's trip to eleven countries in the next three weeks will serve to introduce him to, among other things, several different pronunciations of that American household word, "Ike."
WASHINGTON, Dec. 4 -House investigators made public today a list of twenty-seven high military officers who had enjoyed the hospitality of a leading missile contractor during the last three years.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 4 -- The United States does not assign Negroes to its Air Force or Army bases in Iceland, a Defense Department spokesman said today.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 4 -- The wife of a Polish diplomat was beaten and left unconscious last Sunday afternoon by three assailants who broke into their apartment while the husband was away.
Parents will be able to find out how their children did on a special achievement examination that was given here last spring to fourth-grade pupils.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 4 (AP) -- The White House announced today the appointment of Eugene James Lyons, now Assistant Postmaster General in Charge of Personnel, as special assistant to President Eisenhower for personnel management.

MOSCOW, Dec. 4 A Cuban Communist leader said in an article in Pravda today that his country should establish trade relations with the socialist camp, and "first of all" with the Soviet Union and Communist China.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 4 (AP) -- The Government announced today its first use of authority in the new labor law to seek a court injunction against a union's demanding a "hot cargo" clause from an employer.
ROME, Dec. 4 -- President Eisenhower arrived in Rome shortly after noon today on the first leg of his goodwill tour of eleven countries on three continents.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 4 -- The Federal Trade Commission today accused three record manufacturers and six independent record distributors of deceiving the public and restricting competition by making pay-offs to radio and television disk jockeys.

ATLANTIC CITY, N. J., Dec. 4 (AP) -- State taxes on cigars resulted in sales of 200,000,000 fewer cigars in 1959 than had been anticipated, the president of the Cigar Manufacturers Association asserted today.
A Coast Guard hearing into negligence charges against the second mate of the tanker Valchem ran into a legal fog yesterday.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 4 (AP) -- The head of an organization that screens graduates of foreign medical schools coming to hospitals in the United States said today that the testing program had created a problem for the State Department.

"Rapid social change" at home and abroad will be the basic concern of the first joint assembly of the Divisions of Home and Foreign Missions of the National Council of Churches. The meeting will be held in Atlantic City Tuesday through Friday.
BOSTON, Dec. 4 (AP) -- Bill Russell, playing on a healthy ankle for the first time in a month, sparked Boston to a 122-107 National Basketball Association victory over New York tonight.
NASSAU, Bahamas, Dec. 4 -Stirling Moss of England and Robert Holbert of Warrington, Pa., were the heroes in an afternoon of thrilling racing on the 4.5-mile international course today.
Dealers in bankers acceptances increased their rates yesterday one-eighth of a percentage point on all maturities. The new rates will become effective Monday.
PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 4 (AP) -- New Mexico's Governor said today there was still as much undiscovered oil in the United States as already had been found.
DETROIT, Dec. 4 -- Plans for a new office-building develop- ment adjacent to one of Detroit's major shopping centers, North- land, were announced today.

Lisa Lane of Philadelphia retained her lead in the national women's championship chess tournament at the Marshall Chess Club last night by defeating Mrs. Mabel Burlingame of Phoenix, Ariz. Miss Lane now has a score of 3 1/2 -- 1/2.
LONDON, Dec. 3 -- Britain and the European Atomic Energy Community (Euratom) took another step today toward close collaboration in the development of the peaceful uses of atomic energy.
The Democratic State Committee has scheduled its annual hearing to receive legislative proposals for next Thursday at the National Democratic Club, Madison Avenue and Thirtyseventh Street.
ATLANTIC CITY, Dec. 4 -Japan is the first nation to make substantial use of the sun's radiation for household heating, an American engineer reported here today.
CORAL GABLES, Fla., Dec. 4 (UPI) -- Don Bisplinghoff shot a 69 today to tie Bill Johnston and Dow Finsterwald at 138 for the halfway lead in the Coral Gables open.

NEW HAVEN, Dec. 4 -William Rosenwald, a former general chairman of the United Jewish Appeal, asserted here tonight that the appeal was not a "political organization," or involved in Israel's domestic or foreign policies.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 4 -- A seven-pound monkey named Sam survived a rocket trip fifty-five miles into space today to chart the way for future human astronauts. The trip of the little cinnamon colored rhesus took only thirteen minutes.
THE infamy and horror recorded in the pages of "Oliver Twist" were captured dramatically in a television adaptation of the novel last night.

WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W. Va., Dec. 4 (AP) -- Leaders of thirty-five states agreed today to let a Governors' committee take their fight to restore cuts in highway funds directly to President Eisenhower and Congress.
COLOMBO, Ceylon, Saturday, Dec. 5 -- Sir Oliver Goonetileke, Governor General, dissolved Parliament today. He scheduled a new election for March 19. Nominations will be made Jan. 4.
Contract negotiations between the Transport Workers Union and the Fifth Avenue Coach Lines, Inc., and its wholly owned subsidiary, Surface Transit, Inc., will be resumed Tuesday morning.

LONDON, Dec. 4 -- Britain announced today the firing of three instrument-bearing Skylark rockets last Monday and Tuesday from the Woomera range in Australia as part of an international program of high-altitude research.

CONCORD, N. H., Dec. 4 (AP) -- Quakers prayed and pleaded at the Statehouse today for Dr. Willard Uphaus, a 68year-old pacifist, who faces an indefinite jail term for refusing to answer questions during a state inquiry on communism.
ROME, Dec. 4 -- The legend that even the weather smiles for President Eisenhower was discredited today as a driving rainstorm washed out what was to have been the triumphal opening of his world tour.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 4 -- News must be "accurate, objective and comprehensive," the General Assembly's Social Committee decided tonight.
LONDON, Dec. 4 -- Airlines of three British Commonwealth countries have agreed to pool some their services.
RIO DE JANEIRO, Dec. 4 -A two-day revolt by fewer than two dozen Brazilian officers appeared tonight to have collapsed, with some members captured and others taking refuge in Argentina.

Some orchestra seats are still available for the Talbot Perkins Adoption Service benefit theatre party Saturday night at Robert Anderson's play "Silent Night, Lonely Night," starring Henry Fonda and Barbara Bel Geddes, at the Morosco Theatre. They may be obtained from the beneficiary's offices at 108 Willow Street in Brooklyn.

The $50,000 Enrico Fermi Award and the Enrico Fermi Medal, authorized by the Atomic Energy Act of 1954, to be granted in recognition of "especially meritorious contributions to the development, use or control of atomic energy," were presented in Washington last week to Dr. Glenn T. Seaborg, chancellor of the University of California at Berkeley.

The head of the National Council of Churches declared yesterday that the decision of a Roman Catholic President on whether to veto a birth-control bill "should not be determined for him by the Catholic Church."
VIENNA, Dec. 5 -- The seventh Hungarian Communist party congress in Budapest has clarified important questions for the Western powers and for the Hungarian people.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 5 -- The birth-control problem, which has just taken a political turn, is also heading slowly toward the Supreme Court in legal guise.

Some 50,000 Pennsylvania workers were still idle this week because of the 116-day steel strike, which was interrupted on Nov. 7 by an eighty-day Taft-Hartley injunction. The State Bureau of Employment Security reported, however, that the unemployed numbered 14,256 fewer than those out of work because of the dispute on Oct. 20.

NORFOLK, Va., Dec. 5 (UPI) -- Sam, the monkey astronaut, hungry, frisky and apparently unimpressed with his fifty-five-mile rocket flight into space, shook hands with his personal physician today, munched an apple and headed for home.

WITH Christmas fast approaching, many home freezers are already stocked with fruit cakes, plum puddings and other holiday specialties. However, it is wise to keep in mind that a freezer can serve equally well as a temporary pantry for the storage of home-cooked foods for service on any crowded day during this busy season.

EARLY in "The Joy of Music" Leonard Bernstein takes the position that "the only way one can really say anything about music is to write music." And like countless musicians before him, who have also deprecated the capacity of words to deal with music, he proceeds to commit thousands of them to the subject. Unlike many others who wrestle with the problem of verbalization, he uses words and ideas that make sense.
ROME, Dec. 5 -- From an international public relations point of view, the first stop on President Eisenhower's eleven-nation tour has been a mixed success.

One hundred and four young women will be honored at the twenty-fourth annual Debutante Cotillion and Christmas Ball, New York's oldest and largest mass presentation fete for charity. It will be held on Dec. 21 in the Waldorf-Astoria as a benefit for the New York Infirmary, of which Mrs. Frank A. Vanderlip is president.
Calvin D. MacCracken of the Princeton Club will head the A team of the Metropolitan Squash Racquets Association that will compete in the Tri-City championships.
BONN, Germany, Dec. 5 -- West Germany was angry with Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru of India today.
The March 22 performance of "Greenwillow" will benefit the Madison Square Boys Club. The musical will open March 3 at the Alvin Theatre.

Gov. Ernest Vandiver's rejection of the gradual plan for the desegregation of the public schools adopted by the Atlanta Board of Education under Federal court orders poses in Georgia the issue of moderation versus massive resistance.
Dr. Frank Henry Netter has made art out of the upper digestive tract -- and become a wealthy man.
RIO DE JANEIRO, Dec. 5 -- The revolt by a dozen Brazilian air force and army officers ended today as its leaders took refuge in Asuncion, Paraguay.
WHITE PLAINS, Dec. 5 -- Westchester planners advocated a revolving state fund today to purchase highway rights-of-way years before actual construction.
Congratulations to The New York Times and George Barrett for the thoughtful article on nursing.

PARIS, Dec. 5 -- Rescue teams thus far have dug 261 bodies out of the mud and wreckage of the southern French town of Frejus since the Malpasset Dam burst Wednesday night. The break sent more than a billion and a half cubic feet of water rushing over the Reyran River valley and the town in a matter of minutes.

The annual dinner of the Loyal League Philanthropies, Inc., will be held in the Grand Ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria on Dec. 19. Phil Harris and Louis Pitofsky are co-chairmen for the event, which will benefit underprivileged children.

The number of books written this year about advertising will likely set a new record. Admittedly, this feat may not create a stir along Madison Avenue, or even cause an eyebrow to be raised at the Harvard Graduate School of Business.

This week's exhibition program, largely made up of Christmas group shows, is dominated by the Whitney Museum's Annual exhibition of Contemporary American Painting, opening on Wednesday and continuing through Jan. 31, 1960. One painting each by 145 artists will be shown.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 5 -- For two months now, since the quiz show scandal began breaking on Capitol Hill, television has been under broad attack for deceptive, tasteless or just plain inferior programing and advertising.

PHOENIX, Ariz. -- Tourists who concentrate on a stay-put dude ranch or resort vacation in such Arizona localities as Phoenix and Tucson, or who speed across the Grand Canyon State, ticking off the "musts," usually miss many of the most fascinating spots.

Armed with the influence of the most powerful office in the world, the President of the United States last week embarked on an extraordinary enterprise in personal diplomacy. He left on a nineteen-day trip that will cover 22,000 miles by air, ship, train and motor car and will take him to eleven countries.

JAMES KEENE is back with a forceful, colorful, frequently amusing account of captain of cavalry who, in the Civil War, made the mistake of attacking when he had been ordered to retreat. Taking a position against overwhelming odds, he made a fool of his superior.

SEVENTEEN years ago, John Kieran -- the Gene Tunney of all sports columnists -- retired undefeated from his space in The New York Times to devote his time more fully to the pleasures of bird-watching and other games of chance.
The world merchant marine scored several growth records in the year ended June 30, 1959.

NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 5 (AP) -- The Crabgrass Stables' Beauguerre, a 33-1 shot, passed the pace setters in the stretch today and won a five-length victory in the $6,000 Baton Rouge purse at the Fair Grounds.
The New York Knickerbockers ended their long string of home defeats last night by walloping the Detroit Pistons, 124 -- 108, in a National Basketball Association game at Madison Square Garden.

Mr Barrett's moving description of a day in the life of a nurse makes the point that the supply of fully trained nurses today is nowhere near the demand, and that the gap is growing rather than narrowing.

In connection with William L. Laurence's interesting article in The Times of Nov. 22 entitled "Radio Astronomers Listen for Signs of Life in Distant Solar Systems," I should like to make the following comments:

INFORMATION regarding the promised 10-cent air mail stamp was made public yesterday by Postmaster General Arthur E. Summerfield. This is the stamp which will be required primarily on letters flown to Central America (exclusive of Mexico), and South America and the West Indies.

SOON after the close of the second World War, when General Eisenhower was being urged on all sides to run for the Presidency, he quieted an importuning friend by saying: "Every man has a certain peak he reaches in history. If he is wise, he will not try to go beyond it. I've had my peak in the war years."
ANYONE experienced in making satisfactory black - and - white prints can make good color prints, too, and with little additional equipment and effort.
LOS ANGELES, Dec. 5 -- That classic conflict of American politics, the power struggle between rural and city people, is jiggling California again.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 5 -- President Eisenhower will arrive tomorrow afternoon at Ankara, the second stop on his goodwill tour of eleven nations. His seventeen-hour stay in the Turkish capital will be the kind of state visit all too rare in these days of scantling peace -- a lot of ceremony and few problems.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla. -- Seven weeks and more on this Florida Gulf Coast next February and March, the peak of the Florida winter season, will pack eight major fiestas within their scope among eight jubilant communities.
Paulina Ruvinska, pianist, demonstrated at Carnegie Recital Hall yesterday afternoon that there has been no falling off in her technical ability since she was last heard here.

The pursuit of happiness has been joined by the pursuit of quality education as one of America's preoccupations. Those taking part in the chase find both objectives elusive: it is hard to define either happiness or sound education until it has been achieved, and even then it is not easy to chart a path for others who seek it.

PEOPLE continue to write about Franklin Delano Roosevelt as though there were some danger he might again become a candidate for the Presidency. It is, in fact, difficult to be indifferent to him or to his memory. George N. Crocker is a California lawyer who was once an Assistant United States Attorney, a wartime army officer and if you believe what it says on the jacket. "a profound student of history."

CIUDAD TRUJILLO, Dominican Republic, Dec. 5 (Reuters) -- Gen. Hector Bienvenido Trujillo Molina, 51-year-old President of the republic, will marry Miss Alma McLaughlin Dec. 12, it was announced today.

HARTFORD, Dec. 5 -- Connecticut Republicans expect Meade Alcorn, former G. O. P. national chairman and the party's National Committeeman from this state, to have a high place in the Presidential nomination campaign of Vice President Richard M. Nixon.

ROME, Dec. 5 (AP) -- President Eisenhower had a truly wonderful time. That is the way the President put it in expressing thanks to his hosts, Italy's President and Signora Giovanni Gronchi, after dinner and a reception in his honor last night at the 400-year-old Quirinal Palace.

HILTON HEAD, S. C. -- This island, which was almost inaccessible until 1956, when a toll bridge linked it with the mainland, is now awaking from a centuries-old slumber which was most violently disturbed by the Civil War. That was when a Union fleet captured the island and established the base for blockading Southern ports, thus strangling the Confederacy's lifeline.

The Soviet people last week were given a preview of a full-length book about Premier Khrushchev's United States trip. No publication date has been set for the twelve-chapter book titled "Face to Face With America", but on Sunday Pravda and Izvestia carried about 10,000 words excerpted from three of its chapters.
African coffee has been granted trading recognition in this country. The New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange voted last week to deal in African coffee for future delivery.

YOUSUF KARSH'S lenses have a wide range. Scientists and theatre folk, writers and royalty, artists and religious, politicians -- or as he likes to call them, statesmen, make up his PORTRAITS OF GREATNESS (Nelson, S17.50).

COLORADO SPRINGS, Colo. -- The idea of a Rocky Mountain resort hotel only a short whoop from Pikes Peak and lacking snow would appear, on the surface, as ridiculous as a Miami Beach hotel without a swimming pool. But such has been the case at the Broadmoor Hotel here, which is spending more than $500,000 to create a skiing area that will depend for its existence almost entirely on man-made snow.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 5 -- Britain called today for another plebiscite in the Northern Cameroons "as soon as possible." The British trust territory voted last month to delay a decision on its independence.

THE festivities had ended and the day honoring Charley Conerly had been a heartwarming success. Jim Lee Howell and Kyle Rote departed together last Sunday, pleased with the affectionate tributes to the man they admired so much, and aglow with satisfaction that the Giants had clinched at least a tie for the Eastern Conference championship of the National Football League.
ATLANTA, Dec. 5 -- The Southern Regional Council asserted today that the use of pupil-placement plans to block or delay school desegregation would postpone racial peace in the South.

When 100,000 shares of Infrared Industries, Inc., came to market in September, underwritten by Lehman Brothers, the price to buyers was $5 a share. Two days after the offering the shares sold as high as 13 1/2.

NORWALK, Conn., Dec. 5 -- Plans for three of Fairfield County's traditional Christmas dances for young women in college or advanced classes in preparatory school have been completed by the sponsoring organization, the Board of the County Assemblies.

NORTH HAVEN, Conn., Dec. 5 -- The State Highway Department found itself in an unaccustome dsituation today. Its selection of a route for thirteen miles of Interstate Highway 91 has met with unqualified public acceptance.

In spite of mounting competition and poor lines of communication in the college admissions field, a recent report from the College Admissions Assistance Center, 535 East Eightieth Street, reveals that students who want to go to college and colleges who want students can successfully be brought together.
Lawrence Davidson, bass-baritone of the Metropolitan Opera Company, has been elected cantor of Congregation Shaaray Tefila.

MONTPELIER, Vt. -- There are likely to be many cold, bleak, dreary days ahead, but the outlook for operators of Vermont's ski lodges and those who partake of winter sports is bright. In the first place, snow already has fallen in the state, thus causing lodge operators to race the calendar to get their areas ready for the coming invasion of skiers.

THE stately ceremony at which Jean Rostand, writer and biologist, was recently admitted to the ranks of the forty "Immortals" of the French Academy was, for all its serenity, a reminder of days of turbulence, even uproar, in the august academy.

SAN JUAN, Puerto Rico, Dec. 5 (AP) -- The Puerto Rican Communist party tried to testify today at a hearing of the House Committee on Insular Affairs, but was turned down by Representative Leo O'Brien, the chairman.
If President Eisenhower makes an unscheduled stop in Israel on his tour abroad it will be an impressive gesture for peace and democracy, the Rev. Dr. Zev Zahavy said yesterday.

More than a score of times, President Eisenhower has appealed publicly to the steel industry and the United Steelworkers union to settle their contract dispute with "statesmanship." Last week, with the Taft-Hartley injunction that suspended the 116-day steel strike on Nov. 7 nearing the midpoint of its eighty-day duration and no contract in sight, the President made his most forceful appeal yet.

Syracuse completed its football season unbeaten in ten games by routing the University of California at Los Angeles, 36 -- 8, before 46,436 in Memorial Coliseum, Los Angeles, yesterday. The Orange was led by Dick Easterly, who passed for two touchdowns and scored on a quarterback sneak. Maryland downed North Carolina State, 33 -- 28.
A psychoanalyst who has been watching people blush for several decades reported yesterday on his theories of why they do and why they suffer from the fear of it -- erythrophobia.

THE electronics department of Kyoto University in Japan recently reported development of a typewriter that takes dictation According to the report the typewriter transforms sound vibrations into electric waves and instantly prints in Roman letters whatever is said

The Bethlehem Steel Company's Sparrows Point, Md., shipyard has been named by the Federal Maritime Board as low bidder for construction of three combination cargo-passenger-container ships for Grace Line, Inc.
HELSINKI, Finland, Dec. 5 -- A careful Finland celebrates tomorrow the forty-second anniversary of her independence from Russia.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 5 -- In taking over his new job this week Secretary of Defense Thomas S. Gates Jr. had to face, in the words of his predecessor, no "accumulation of problems" but rather "a continuing flow of problems."
The full-rigger Joseph Conrad was back at Mystic Seaport in Connecticut yesterday, after a twelve-day visit to a shipyard in New London.
COLLEGE PARK, Md., Dec. 15 -- Maryland, at home every time opportunity knocked, outlasted North Carolina State, 33 -- 28, today in the season finale for both Atlantic Coast Conference football teams.
Columbia's quintet had an easy time last night in downing City College, 65 -- 54, in the loser's bandbox gymnasium. It was the opening game of the season for both teams.

THE homeowner who sets out to hire a contractor for any large home improvement project is often confused by a wide variety of estimates and recommendations. All too often he finally hires his man on the basis of price alone -- or because of sales talk.

ORIGINAL prints from 'Yolla Niclas' "The Island Shepherd" (New York: Viking Press. 91 pp. $3) are hanging through this month in Parents' Magazine Gallery, 52 Vanderbilt Avenue. The exhibit offers a welcome change of pace for this gallery, and for Miss Niclas an opportunity to demonstrate her ability as craftsman as well as photographer and story teller for children.
SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 5 -- Johnny Unitas, passing for three touchdowns and running for another, led the Baltimore Colts to a 34-14 victory over the San Francisco 49ers today.

A Knight (Mr. Barrett) has come to the aid of a Maiden in Distress (The Nursing Profession). At long last this "situation" -- very popular of late with the tree lancers -- has been observed with a clear eye and written of without the usual dramatic overlay.

FEW incidents in American history are better known than the disastrous and ignominious defeat of Gen. Edward Braddock's British and colonial troops by the French and their Indians near the forks of the Ohio in 1755.

NOT many years ago the space rocket was a part of science fiction, with a credibility rating on a par with ghosts and Martians. Now it is a part of reality. It is no longer idle fancy for a young mind to dream of a career in rocketry.

A Soviet First Deputy Premier, Anastas I. Mikoyan, has indicated that a sharp increase has taken place this year both in the Soviet Union's total foreign trade and in its commerce with the non-Communist world.

FREEPORT, L. I., Dec. 5 -- More than 10,000 spectators lined a mile and a half of curb today to see a three-hour parade observing the holiday season and the opening of this community's first autoless shopping mall.

ALBANY, Dec. 5 (AP) -- The state's Little Hoover Commission recommended to Governor Rockefeller today a sharp cut in the funds for the Division of Safety and other changes designed to save $1,134,455 a year for the state.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 5 -- The United States' offer to help its North Atlantic allies in the development of atomic submarines is foundering on the shoals of diplomatic differences, nationalistic status-seeking, secrecy and squabbles within the Administration.

IF much that passes for poetry is primary nonsense, much that poses as poetical criticism is secondary nonsense -- nonsense once removed, say, like Charles Lamb's poor relation, whom he described as "the most irrelevant thing in nature * * * a piece of impertinent correspondency * * * an odious approximation."

THE pursuit of high fidelity in the Soviet Union took this visitor several times to large radio shops on Gorki Street, Moscow's Fifth Avenue; to the radio department of the gargantuan GUM; to a radio specialty shop on Petrovka Street, amid wine shops, linen shops, and "national" food shops; and to the officially operated "Commission Shops" which sell second-hand articles.

IMPORTANT introductions are made at the Staempfli Gallery's current exhibition of work by fourteen European sculptors, most of whom are little if at all known in this country. English, French, Swiss, German and Greek, these men, thanks to the rapid interchange of esthetic ideas nowadays, represent a kind of sculptors' freemasonry and not national styles.
The 23-year-old wife of a Navy lieutenant was slashed with a pocket knife yesterday morning by a man who tried to rape her in the basement of her apartment house in Kew Gardens Hills, Queens.

NO American who visited the Ruhr in the months immediately following World War II left except in wonder at the awful spectacle of its industrial grandeur. Even in desolation, the Ruhr spoke of Teutonic power.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 5 -- Strong opposition to total disarmament as proposed by Soviet Premier Khrushchev was raised today in a special Congressional study on foreign policy. The study, dealing with the effects of military technology on strategy and policy, was prepared for the Senate Foreign Relations Committee by the Washington Center of Foreign Policy Research of The Johns Hopkins University.

At 12:13 P. M. yesterday three-and-a-half tons of top-grade sirloin landed at La Guardia Field. At the same time, five miles northwest of the airport, this shipment of imported beef was being inspected via motion picture films by two members of a rival beef trust.

Miss Elizabeth Brackett Jennison, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Brackett Jennison of Worcester, Mass., was married here yesterday afternoon to Hugh Michael Troop Brady. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Michael Brady of Need-ham Heights, Mass.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 5 -- Douglas Dillon, the Under Secretary of State, embarks Monday on a week of cautious inquiry and counseling among "the six" and "the seven" of Europe. His counsel seems likely to disappoint the seven.
Following the sun down turnpikes, throughways, parkways and highways to Florida are a growing number of vehicles that would have looked strange a decade ago.
WITH all respect to the brilliant Arthur Miller, I take exception to his view as expressed in a letter in your section last Sunday, in which he castigates adaptation of classics on television. * * *

LESS than a month ago, nearing the Agate Beach stop on the Oregon coast, I looked out of the bus window toward the spot where for many years the familiar black-caped figure of my father, Ernest, had waited to greet me. No longer would he be there, to drive me a little ways to the rambling house perched on a cliff overlooking the Pacific.
Patrons of the theatre benefit that will mark the 125th anniversary of the Seamen's Church Institute will attend a prefatory buffet reception at the New York Yacht Club.
WARSAW, Dec. 5 (AP) -- The New York Times was accused today of conducting a "cold war" campaign against Poland, and sale of the newspaper was shut off at Polish newsstands.

BELHAVEN, N. C., Dec. 5 -- Lake Mattamuskeet and its shores present one of the great mass-hunting pictures of the United States. Hundreds of hunters pursuing geese, deer, quail and other game there every day and dozens of establishments catering to them.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 5 (UPI) -- A wire-guided French missile fired from helicopters was described today as potentially one of the most effective additions to the Army's anti-tank arsenal.
The Russia Orthodox Theological Fund will benefit from a concert to be given by the Russian Cathedral Choir next Saturday afternoon in St. Thomas Protestant Episcopal Church.

A combination of circumstances is working in favor of retailers in this Christmas season. As a result, store volume is well ahead of that in 1958 and in many instances it has surpassed advance predictions. Department store volume will show more than 5 per cent year to year gain, while chain store and mail order houses will go ahead by even a wider margin.

DENVER, Colo. -- This year marks the thirteenth anniversary of Aspen as a major ski resort, a move that elevated Colorado from a role of comparative obscurity in the nation-wide skiing picture to one of prominence. Since that now-historic winter of 1946-47, eight ski areas valued at a total of $50,000,000 have been developed in the state.

There is no reason to doubt that Malcolm Muggeridge made a fairly accurate observation of the use made of the new leisure time in England today. An American has only to look around himself here to acknowledge the plausibility of all that he said.
The annual luncheon of the Huguenot Society of America will be held in the Roof Garden of the Pierre on Saturday.

Joseph Papp seems about to accomplish what Billy Rose once projected for Central Park -- a midway. After the Shakespeare theatre, the devotees of Ibsencan demand a "festival" theatre. Then followers of Chekhov will want their theatre in the park.

IN some ways it is as difficult to be 12 years old, or 15, as it is to be 10; but the age of 10 is a turning point, from small boy to big boy, from dream to reality, and the hurts are as hurtful as the joys are ecstatic. Ten is a difficult age to endure, difficult to remember, and particularly difficult to reconstruct when one has grown and become a writer.

The Young Women's Christian Association of New York has named Dorothy Bollard associate executive director for programs. She succeeds Miss Briseis Teall, who has become associate general secretary of the Y. W. C. A. National Board.

The 200-man Brooklyn morals squad is being reorganized. Police Commissioner Stephen P. Kennedy said yesterday, "I am not satisfied with the way it is handling gambling, prostitution and liquor-law violations."

THE Oscar virus, against which there is no cure, since it feeds on both vanity and the pocketbook, has made its annual attack on Hollywood and should soon be approaching the epidemic stage. The final announcements will be made on April 9, but symptoms of the Oscar syndrome are now unmistakable.

ROME, Dec. 5 (AP) -- Following are the texts of a communique issued following talks here between President Eisenhower and Giovanni Gronchi, President of Italy, and of remarks by General Eisenhower to the staff of the United States Embassy in Rome:

HOW could you be so blind as to publish that ugly statement by T. S. Matthews about Max Reinhardt and "The Miracle" in the review of "The Light of Common Day," by Diana Cooper. [Mr. Matthews wrote that "The Miracle" was "a flashy, murky, elephantine spectacle."]

NILA and her Boswell have done it again, and it is clear that Russia will never be the same -- at least, for the thousand-and-one Russians who met them on their journey through Nila's native country last year. The pitch of their duet is lighthearted soprano almost all the way -- all surface and very little depth.
BABYLON, L. I., Dec. 5 -- School tax bills are being prepared for the first time against 300 summer homes on bay islands and beach lands in Babylon township.
Life is not as folksy as it used to be for Grant Sawyer, freshman Governor of Nevada.
This country's large deficit in international payments may not be the last of such unpleasant novelties in store for the United States.
Two steamship lines operating regularly out of New York were ready last week to withdraw from steamship conferences.

ARTISTIC independence seems to be bursting out all over. Not long ago a dozen British producers banded together to sponsor one another's -- and outsiders' -- films so that adjudication on subjects should not always be in the hands of commercial men.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 5 -- Coy is still the word for the Democrats' five leading but undeclared Presidential possibilities of 1960.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 5 -- France declared today that she would accept no resolution of the United Nations on a settlement of the war in Algeria.

BACH: Erbarme dich, mein Gott, from St. Matthew Passion; Cantatas Nos. 53, 54, 200; Helen Watts, contralto; Philomusica of London. Thurston Dart conducting (London, editions do l'Oiseau-Lyre, stereo). Difficult, florid music sung with skill and sympathetic comprehension.

In a classroom in Emerson, N. J., pupils watched a visitor from Trinidad execute the quick, rhythmic dance steps of his country.

FOR THIS WEEK: Clean, oil and store those garden tools no longer needed. . . . Soil of hardy bulbs rooting in pots outdoors must be kept moist. . . . Pot rooted cuttings into the containers which will be wrapped for gifts. . . . Keep bird feeders well stocked; check them daily. . . . Order gift certificates from nurseries. . . . Put garden hose away.

BALTIMORE, Dec. 5 -- Howell E. Jackson's Cross Channel carried the oldest registered racing silks in America to a three-length victory in the mile-and-a-half Pimlico Cup today, winning virtually as he pleased.
A plan to make the Health Department a more effective guardian of health in the city's neighborhoods has been approved by the Board of Estimate.

IT was a friend who suggested to Emmet Crozier that the American correspondents of World War I were "as varied, resourceful and worthy of historic study" as those of the Civil War, about whom he had written.

TAICHUNG, Taiwan, Dec. 5 (UPI) -- Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek said today that the exchange of visits between President Eisenhower and Premier Khrushchev would deal a "serious blow to the will to resist" of peoples behind the Iron Curtain.

IF it were possible to tote up the contents of a play, as in the inventory of a shipment of goods, William Inge's "A Loss of Roses" would compare favorably with his other works. Item by item it does, although the total impression is disappointing.
PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 5 (AP) -- A chlorine derivative has shown promise of preventing the spread of operative cancers of the colon and rectum, a Temple University surgeon reported today.

WESTERN appreciation of Byzantine art has developed by slow stages, only gradually overcoming imperfect sympathies and lack of knowledge. Its splendor is austere; its rigidly theocratic character far more remote from us in spirit than the humanism of Greece and Rome, and it survives, physically, in no more than fragments of what must once have been one of the most magnificent corpuses of architecture, painting, mosaic and the decorative arts ever seen.
An era of pioneering in safety developments is in store for the New York Thruway, according to Clinton B. F. Brill, chairman of the three-man authority that operates the 541-mile toll road.
SUMMIT, N. J., Dec. 5 -- Fourteen young women, all college freshmen, will make their debuts at the Summit Cotillion on Dec. 28 at the Canoe Brook Country Club here.
How fifteen young men endured flash burns from simulated atomic explosions and carried the scars for as long as five years is told by a team of British scientists in an American medical journal.

ST. THOMAS, V. I. -- Eight bids have been received by the Interior Department in Washington for construction of a water distillation plant to convert sea water into fresh water for drinking and household purposes for the island of St. Thomas.
HASANOGLAN, Turkey, Dec. 3 -- The men of this village want it known: They like Ike in Hasanoglan, too.

NEW HAVEN, Dec. 5 -- Ira V. Hiscock, one of the nation's leading authorities on public health, will retire Jan. 1 as chairman of the Public Health Department at Yale University. He has been on the Yale faculty thirty-nine years.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 5 (AP) -- The Air Force will retire up to 900 aircraft under Administration pressure to save money for missiles and other atomic-space-age equipment.
Following is President Eisenhower's official program for his world tour. All times are regional (Rome is six hours, Ankara seven hours and Karachi ten hours ahead of Eastern standard time).

MELBOURNE, Australia, Dec. 5 (UPI) -- Neale Fraser and Maria Bueno won the singles titles today at the Victorian lawn tennis championships, capturing two of the most closely contested finals in recent years.
Friedrich Nietzsche says: "In the man there is hidden a child who wants to play. Get up, then, you women end wake me the child in the men!"
Two boys died in two fires in the Bedford area of Brooklyn early yesterday. Two tenants were injured. Two patrolmen and a fireman required first aid.

CORONADO, Calif., Dec. 5 -- A California team composed of Lewis Mathe, Edward Taylor and Meyer Schleifer of Los Angeles and Don Oakie of San Francisco last night won the national Master's Team-of-Four championship in the American Contract Bridge League's tournament here.

New York State is trying to decide if it should honor Polish claims against estates and other moneys held by city and state authorities. An affirmative decision would open the way for Polish citizens to sue for funds estimated at "possibly several million dollars."

LOS ANGELES, Dec. 5 -- The mighty Syracuse Orangemen, national champions right down to the third string, romped over the University of California at Los Angeles today, 36 -- 8, to complete their all-winning regular football season with ten vctories.

MARC SLONIM in his review of two recent volumes of English translations of Pasternak's poems ("Poems," translated by Eugene M. Kayden, and "The Poetry of Boris Pasternak," translated by George Reavey) fails to acknowledge the superior renditions of some of these poems by C. M. Bowra and Babette Deutsch in "Safe Conduct," issued by New Directions. * * *
THE Reichstag, like the palace at Versailles and the Tower of London, is one of those buildings which embody part of the history of a nation.

EARLY this year The Christian Science Monitor's Washington correspondent, accompanied by his newspaper's top photographer, made a trip around the world interviewing and taking pictures of twenty-one world leaders.
LONDON, Dec. 5 (Reuters) Non-league Peterborough United and Bath City fought to another round in the Football Association Cup play today by upending fourth division teams.

THIS is the first English rendition of the Encyclopedia of Astronomy originally published by the famous house of Larousse in Paris, translated by two Fellows of the Royal Astronomical Society, revised by a Professor of Astronomy at the University of Manchester, England, and introduced by a Professor of Astronomy at Harvard University.
May I say that I thought Arthur Miller's article on the folly of adapting the classics for TV unnecessarily severe. * * *

REPORTS on political history tend, in these days especially, to produce discouragement and pessimism. We console ourselves with the thought that the matters dealt with are transient ones and will be in a different state tomorrow. Reports on the progress of science, on the other hand, have a different character and effect.

SWIMMING pools are becoming an accepted facet of suburban living. Abundant proof of this will be on display at the third annual National Swimming Pool Exposition which opens a four-day run in the New York Coliseum on Saturday.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 5 -- Just before he left on his eleven-nation trip last Thursday President Eisenhower again urged the two sides in the steel dispute to settle their differences voluntarily. He coupled with his plea a warning that unless union and management came to terms the Federal Government would have to step in.

Newspaper editors, writers, reporters, cartoonists, photographers and readers have been asked to be mindful of the changing nature of journalism in nominating winners for the 1960 Pulitzer Prizes in journalism.
NAIROBI, Kenya, Dec. 5 -- Weather experts agreed here today that a better job could be done of reporting and forecasting Africa's weather.

FORT MYERS, Fla. -- Great interest has been generated in this area of southwest Florida by the recent announcement of the United States Corps of Engineers in Jacksonville that work will begin around April 1 on the new West Coast Inland Waterway.

STRING - OF - HEARTS or hearts-entangled are appropriate popular names for a sophisticated clan of easily grown window garden vines -- the ceropegias. Tropical members of the milkweed family, they also are closely related to the wax plant (hoya) and stephanotis.

ONCE again, as Christmas approaches, The New York Times presents the stories of New York City's Neediest Cases. They are stories about people who are neighbors of yours, struck down by accidental misfortune or the sudden disaster that overwhelms and terrifies. On their behalf The Times today makes its forty-eighth annual appeal.

STURDY wooden sawhorses can be put to many uses around the home and workshop. They can help set up many kinds of scaffolding, erect almost any size table or workbench, and support projects at a convenient height (when away from the workbench) for sawing, drilling, painting or cleaning.
MIAMI BEACH, Dec. 5 -- The major league trading mart broke afresh today. Two deals, involving seven players and with the Phillies taking part in both, were completed.
ALBANY, Dec. 5 -- The New York Assembly, which likes to think of itself as one of the leading deliberative bodies in the country, will adopt a touch of British parliamentary technique next year.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 5 -- Ch. Cote de Neige Sundew, a 3-year-old Pembroke Welsh corgi owned by Mrs. William B. Long of Concord, Mass., won best in show of one of the East's major dog competitions tonight.

Japanese investment companies with offices in this country are playing a long-range game, but so far an unprofitable one, according to Kenjiro Ikeda, director and chief of research for Yamaichi Securities Company, Ltd. They are, he said in an interview last week, looking forward to the day when restrictions on foreign investments in Japan shall have been materially eased.

THE commission pennant whipping from the gigantic sail (superstructure) of the U. S. S. George Washington -- first of the world's undersea battleships, which will be commissioned before the year's end at Groton, Conn. -- will signal the beginning of a new era of maritime history.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 5 -- A movement to take over the area's Citizens for Eisenhower organization of 1956 has been started by Northern California supporters of Governor Rockefeller of New York. Their aim is to develop the hard core of a drive for Governor Rockefeller the day "after he is nominated at Chicago" for President.

MIAMI BEACH, Dec. 5 -- Player representatives of baseball's two major leagues made it clear today that there were no differences between themselves and Commissioner Ford C. Frick with regard to the signing of a new world series and All-Star radio and television contract when the present one expires in 1961.

NEWARK, Dec. 5 -- If Essex County is to maintain a high place among top-ranking industrial counties in the country, it must provide a separate technical school for post-high school and adult students, the county was told today.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 5 -- The General Assembly postponed adjournment of its 1959 session for a week today and decided to begin debate on Hungary Monday.
Four records were set as the local schoolboy indoor track season opened with the tenth annual Catholic High Schools Athletic Association relay carnival yesterday at the 102d Engineers Armory.

TRUMAN CAPOTE'S A Christmas Memory (United Artists) has a double hold on the coming season. First, it summons up the spirit of Christmas past, and its excellences should put it on everyone's shopping list.
Plans have been completed for the Debutante Assembly and New Year's Ball that will be held in the Grand Ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria on Jan. 1.

HERE we are again with Santa Claus in Shubert Alley. And what has dear old Santa got in his bag for the holiday theatre-goer this year? Pretty much the same as usual -- which is to say, a limited number of choice tickets to the big hits, a big number of choice tickets to the limited hits, and no tickets at all to "The Sound of Music."
Floyd (Ben) Schwartzwalder, who built a hard-hitting team at Syracuse University, yesterday was named football coach of the year by Scripps-Howard newspapers.

OTTAWA, Dec. 5 -- Publicity should be used as a weapon against food retailing practices that increase the cost a Government-appointed commission suggested this week. The chief targets of its report were promotion, fancy packaging and nonessential services.

LAKE HARMONY, Pa. -- Automation is making its presence felt in virtually every field today, and skiing is no exception, and neither are Pennsylvania's Pocono Mountains. For the last decade, nature has been unkind to this part of the state in the amount of snowfall. The problem was overcome at Split Rock Lodge's Big Boulder several winters ago, when snow machines were introduced.
ROME, Sunday, Dec. 6 (AP) -- The United States' national anthem will echo today within the Vatican when President Eisenhower arrives for his meeting with Pope John XXIII.
A year in Italy on a Fulbright Scholarship will be described by Jules Maidoff, an artist, at 6:15 P. M. Tuesday in the last lecture of a series sponsored by the New York Public Library.
As the airlines zoom into the jet age, they are heading not only for bigger business but for much bigger problems.

VIRTUALLY every boy sometime in the course of growing up has asked for a chemistry set for Christmas. This year, if current signs are correct, the amount and variety of science materials parceled out to youngsters over the holidays will be staggering. In many a household what once were toy shelves will be loaded with more complicated equipment than many a small school can boast.
The six scheduled airlines at La Guardia Airport last week completed the diversion or cutback of ninety daily flights at the field to ease traffic during its modernization.

MOST countries have a favorite Christmas bread. All bear a holiday resemblance in that they are made from rich, rather sweet yeast doughs and are flecked with citron, raisins and often candied peels and nuts.
BABYLON, L. I., Dec. 5 -- The Army Corps of Engineers last night completed its multimillion dollar Fire Island Inlet stabilization plan.

VIENNA, Dec. 5 -- The seventh congress of the Hungarian Socialist Workers (Communist) party ended in Budapest today with a determination to intensify the ideological campaign against opponents and accelerate land collectivization and industrial expansion.
DETROIT, Dec. 5 -- The automobile manufacturers plan to offer a device on their 1961 models that would eliminate substantial portions of the hydrocarbon emissions of the cars.

A WATERPROOF masonry sealer for basement walls and floors consists of a special powder and a liquid latex rubber which is mixed together immediately before use. Claimed to resist over one ton of water pressure per square foot when used as directed, this coating is suitable for use either above or below ground, and can also be used for sealing leaking concrete swimming pools.

CORAL GABLES, Fla., Dec. 5 (UPI) -- Arnold Palmer of Ligonier, Pa., and Dow Finsterwald of Tequesta, Fla., who won two of the pros' biggest tournaments in 1958, tied for the third-round lead today in the $20,000 Coral Gables open championship.
Resident buying offices reported last week that holiday business was brisk and slightly above the 1958 level.

WHAT is it that certain foreign writers have -- which we too often lack? Is it their direct way of going to the heart of an experience? Or is it the simplicity with which they let their characters speak for themselves? This short allegorical novel by the Greek writer Margarita Liberaki shows both these qualities so disarmingly at work that we can take its underlying symbolism in stride.
The appetizing aroma and the soft pop of bursting corn kernels seem out of place in a lamp-manufacturing plant, in Flushing, Queens.

Engineers and technicians of the Chromalloy Corporation are busy developing new methods of production using metals and superalloys that were practically unknown to the public just a few years ago. They are doing their work in the company plants in White Plains, N. Y., and Edwardsville, Ill.

BABIES are now arriving in Communist China at the rate of some 55,000 a day. At this rate, China's population soon will be increasing each year by more than two Australias, and in a dozen years may have added the population of a United States of America.

AMONG other criminous distinctions, 1959 may well be known as The Year the 87th Precinct Appeared in Hard Covers. Admired as paperback originals since 1956, these excellent Ed McBain novels-about-policemen have come out this year in four hard-bound books: an omnibus of earlier stories, two new novels and now KING'S RANSOM (Simon Schuster, $2.95).

CORAL GABLES, Fla., Dec. 5 (AP) -- Anselmo Dorato's Argentine invader Petare, closed strongly on the outside to win today's $10,000 added City of Miami Handicap at Tropical Park. He broke the track record in the process.

THERE are many avenues along which to feel a profound sense of pride in our country. One is to study America's achievements in science, industry, art and engineering. American government and history can stir our ego, too. Still another method to make the pulse beat faster is by leafing through the pages of this stirring new book about our National Parks.

ALTA, Utah -- Vacationists visiting Utah's two-mile high Wasatch Range winter resorts this season will see more and more Western skiers bearing knapsacks, packs and assorted duffle. After ascending any of a half-dozen chairlifts, the pack-carrying skiers set slowly off for the high country extending beyond the lift-lines. In other words, they ski uphill before sliding down.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 5 -- The United States has decided to withdraw from Iceland a 1,300-man Army combat team that has been stationed there as part of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization forces.

A QUARTER-CENTURY has passed since the late Federal Judge John M. Woolsey permitted the publication in this country of a novel describing twenty-four hours in the lives of a number of characters who lived in Dublin. Today that book is recognized as a masterpiece throughout the world.

BACK in 1898 -- a long time ago in the world of science - a Dutch botanist named Martinus Willen Beijerinck showed that tobacco mosaic disease, a disease of the tobacco plant, is caused by an agent so small it passes through a filter impermeable to bacteria.
DETROIT, Dec. 5 -- Republicans in Michigan's House will attempt to increase the Senate's $34,000,000 tax package next week in a way acceptable to Democrats.

That neither Mr. Adams nor Mr. Frost should have mentioned Woodrow Wilson appears very curious, indeed. Surely Wilson's concept of a family of nations as the means of preserving world order and some semblance of tranquility has been shown to be farsighted.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., Dec. 5 -- The Tennessee Republican Executive Committee will meet here Dec. 14 to set up machinery for naming the state's delegates to the G. O. P. National Convention next July. Vice President Nixon is a heavy favorite for the Presidential nomination among state G. O. P. leaders.

THE awful fascination of seeing an inept person win against all rules is available to the reader of "Preposterous Papa," affectionately written by a Tulsa bookseller and reviewer, Lewis Meyer. It begins in 1906, when the young Arkansas Jew, Max Meyer, came with ample family money to Sapulpa, Indian Territory, the year before Oklahoma statehood.

The New York Sinfonietta, a small group of indomitable players conducted by Max Goberman, gave a Vivaldi concert yesterday at the late afternoon hour in Carnegie Hall. They are indomitable because they have announced a project of recording all the music of Vivaldi.

Glamorous moments from the theatre during the last 100 years will highlight the entertainment at the Rialto Ball. The dinner dance, sponsored by Joseph E. Seagram Sons, will be held Jan. 27 in the Grand Ballroom of the Plaza.

HENRY COMMAGER'S brilliantly comprehensive and discerning review of Van Wyck Brooks' "Howells," quotes Henry James as saying of Howells, "He adored the real, the natural, the colloquial, the moderate, the optimistic and the democratic," and Mr. Commager adds, "because he [Howells] disliked everything that was sensational and violent."

THE penlight-battery-powered motor in the Graphic 35 Electric advances the film, cocks the shutter and counts the exposure. To take a picture, one presses the release button on the front, then waits a rather noisy second or so -- while the motor is advancing the film and recocking the shutter -- before another picture can be exposed.
BUFFALO, Dec. 5 -- Dick McCann sank two free throws with one second remaining to lift Canisius to a 62-60 victory over Fordham tonight before 3,825 fans.

OYSTER BAY, L. I., Dec. 5 -- Work will start next year on a project to develop 500 acres of South Shore wetlands as "a conservation model and showpiece for the entire state and nation." The State Conservation Department and the Town of Oyster Bay will cooperate.

HE was a thin, brown-eyed, sad-looking boy, one of ten children of a poor Italian fisherman who had been drowned at sea. Sometimes he begged a little, and sometimes he stole, but hunger grew in him every day.

DOES mankind face extinction because of genetic radiation damage? In "Radiation, Genes, and Man," geneticists Bruce Wallace of Cornell and Th. Dobzhansky of Columbia answer "no -- but." Their "but" is cautious and low-pitched to avoid alarmism: it offers no comfort to reckless men who would like to make free with radiation. either in peace or in war.

THE schooner Polynesia sailed out of Miami harbor at midnight and soon began to roll majestically before the power of the Gulf Stream. At about that time, we began to realize what we had get ourselves in for.

For the first time in the ninety-four-year history of the Fire Department, the number of fires recorded in October and November dropped below the figures for the corresponding months of the previous year.

GUATEMALA, Dec. 5 -- An atmosphere of intense animosity and suspicion prevails here as Guatemala prepares for an election tomorrow that will decide whether Rightist or Leftist parties will control the single-chamber legislature.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 5 -- Friends of James H. Douglas, Secretary of the Air Force, called attention today to the fact that he had paid his own bills on a golfing trip to Eleutheria Island.

CEDARHURST, L. I., Dec. 5 -- Dave Watts, 27-year-old New Yorker and one of the tallest players in the game, scored an upset in the Gold Racquet Squash racquets tournament today. He vanquished the defender, Calvin MacCracken, in the quarter-final round, 15 -- 9, 15 -- 11, 15 -- 18, 15 -- 7.

ROME, Dec. 5 (UPI) -- A former mental patient lunged at President Eisenhower's limousine as it was leaving the residence of Ambassador James D. Zellerbach tonight. The man was seized immediately by the Italian police.
THE Atlantic Coast Line Railroad and the Seaboard Air Line Railroad last week announced plans for handling the increased Florida traffic over the Christmas holidays.

Names for apartment houses are nothing new, but in Manhattan they have traditionally been associated with the older sections of the West Side; thus, the Dakota. the Beresford, the Majestic, the Century, the San Remo and E1 Dorado Towers.

This season, as always, the odds are roughly eight to one and immutable as the tides of Fundy that the reviewers will accuse any given dramatist of fouling telephone poles or profaning noble old oaks.

A broad indictment of the Eisenhower Administration's economic, monetary and fiscal policies was issued yesterday by the National Democratic Advisory Council.

PITTSBURGH Dec. 6 -- Some of the recent optimism anticipating fast shipments of finished steel began to wane somewhat last week. More and more concerns were finding that they had been over confident that they would get the steel they needed.

THE Mayor of New Orleans, deLesseps Story Morrison, is a man not easily deterred from his purpose -- and he wants to be Governor of Louisiana. Therefore, many who know him well feel sure that he will win the Democratic nomination in the run-off election Jan. 9.

Another conference championship was neatly wrapped up by the Giants yesterday before a howling crowd of 68,436 at Yankee Stadium. The title was the Giants' second straight and third in four years in the Eastern Conference of the National Football League.

A year ago today Romulo Betancourt, leader of the Accion Democratica party, was elected President of Venezuela.
