NEWARK, Dec. 7 -- The Public Utility Commission today upheld an $11,000,000 rate increase it granted to the New Jersey Bell Telephone Company 1957.
Former President Harry S. Truman will discuss the United Nations and various aspects of the current international situation in an interview to be televised Sunday.
The United States Communist party announced yesterday that its seventeenth national convention would open Thursday at the Theresa Hotel, 125th Street and Seventh Avenue.
Four feet of a 109-year-old Staten Island house -- in which an octogenarian was born, has lived all his life and intends to die is about to yield to progress.

The American people are not only adding to their numbers. They are also shifting around inside their frontiers. They have always done this. The habit used to be called the westward movement, and the late Prof. Frederick Jackson Turner based a whole theory of history on it. The latest detailed census reports for each state between 1950 and 1958 show some peculiar results.
Although they were glowing over their 6-0 defeat of the Toronto Maple Leafs Sunday night, the victory-starved New York Rangers were still hungry yesterday.
Thirteen of fifteen witnesses told a Senate subcommittee yesterday that migrant farm workers were grossly exploited and needed new Federal laws for their protection.

The eleventh and final professional wrestling show of 1959 was held at Madison Square Garden last night. It attracted 12,751 fans for a total of 165,676 who have attended the comedy fighting there this year.

Arthur M. Luley has been appointed vice president of Gotham Builders Supply Corporation of Queens. Mr. Luley was formerly a director of General Builders Corporation and a vice president of the Dennings Point Brick Works.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 7 -- Guy Farmer, chairman of President Eisenhower's Board of Inquiry in the longshore dispute, said today that he regarded all Atlantic port negotiations as successful. An understanding between the Norfolk, Va., employers and the International Longshoremen's Association was reached today.

CHICAGO, Dec. 7 -- Robert M. Buddington, vice president of sales of the Inland Steel Company, said today that the in crease in foreign steel competition was part of a broad change rather than an isolated phenomenon caused by the steel strike.

In an unusual twist in a trial that has become known as "The Circus" in General Sessions Court, the assistant district attorney prosecuting the case was called to the stand yesterday as a defense witness.
Lowell M. Birrell, fugitive financier, was charged yesterday with further "depredations and larcenies" that caused the Swan Finch Oil Corporation additional losses of $8,516,989.
JACKSON, Miss., Dec. 7 (UPI) -- An all-white jury was picked today for the second murder trial of Robert Lee Goldsby.
COLOMBO, Ceylon, Dec. 7 -- Prime Minister Wijayananda Dahanayake resigned today from the ruling Sri Lanka (Greater Ceylon) Freedom party.
WITH sharpened observations and a softened technique, Alexander Dobkin, in his show at the ACA Gallery, 63 East Fifty-seventh Street, offers more than thirty-five recent canvases.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 7 -- President Eisenhower will fly Wednesday from Pakistan to neighboring Afghanistan, a country that is a primary target of Soviet economic penetration.

IT was Tallulah Bankhead, I believe, who after rending Maeterlinck's "The Blue-bird" said: "There is less here than meets the eye." The same sort of judgment might apply to "Short Term," a large, remarkably overwritten novel by Jay Richard Kennedy. But it certainly is readable in its pell-mell way.
To trap interstate scofflaws, the Bureau of Motor Vehicles is going to stamp "Valid in New York State Only" on all licenses it issues to drivers who also hold permits from other states.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 7 -- A resolution calling for discussions between France and the Algerian National Liberation Front was approved tonight by the Political Committee of the General Assembly.
ALBANY, Dec. 7 -- The Governors of New York. New Jersey and Connecticut will meet on Dec. 29 in another attempt to thrash out the nonresident income tax issue.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 7 -- The General Assembly decided today to hold a conference in Vienna next year on diplomatic privileges and immunities.
More government control was sought yesterday over what was described as deceptive advertising practices on television and in print by the toothpaste industry.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 7 (AP) -- The American Trade Association for British Woolens contended today that the present tariff system for imported woolens and worsteds caused "dislocation, disruption, distortion and damage to important segments of American small business."

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 7 -- The Economic Commission for Europe reported today that increased competitiveness of western European steel exports with those of the United States constituted "a factor of lasting importance" in international trade.
Paul G. Hoffman, managing director of the United Nations Special Fund, said yesterday that a good part of the world was in active revolt against chronic poverty, illiteracy and ill health.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 7 (UPI) -- Dr. Erwin N. Griswold, dean of Harvard University Law School, called today for public disclosure of the tax benefits that some corporation executives were getting from stock options.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 7 (UPI) -- The Senate Democratic whip declared today he doubted that the birth-control controversy would hurt the chances of Senator Kennedy or any other possibility for a Presidential nomination.
Fines totaling $4,650 were imposed yesterday on twenty-eight Harlem landlords who had failed to rid their buildings of rats or to alleviate conditions in which rats thrived.
A woman Democrat, looking over the field of Presidential hopefuls at the party's three-day meeting here, sighed the wistful conclusion of a spectator concerning party members.

PARIS, Dec. 7 -- President Charles de Gaulle is expected to visit the stricken French Riviera town of Frejus later this month. The town was heavily damaged when the near-by Malpasset Dam burst last Wednesday night, killing at least 323 persons.

" Spot" shortages of large household appliances will occur all over the country around Feb. 26 if the steel strike is resumed. This was predicted yesterday by Bernard A. Chapman, executive vice president and general manager of the American Motors Corporation's Kelvinator division.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 7 (AP) -- The Supreme Court speeded today its handling of a Louisiana case that had tied up the Civil Rights Commission.
GUATEMALA, Dec. 7 -- The moderate leftist Revolutionary party continued to gain in returns today from yesterday's legislative election.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 7 (UPI) -Housewives are expected to have plenty of safe cranberries to serve during the Christmas Holidays, Food and Drug Administration officials said today.
ANKARA, Turkey, Dec. 7 (AP) -- Following is the text of President Eisenhower's farewell remarks on leaving Turkey today:

JERSEY CITY, Dec. 7 -- A year ago Bill (Something) Smith of St. Peter's' was the leading, scorer in metropolitan college basketball ranks. He finished the season with 521 points, well ahead of any of his team-mates.
Heavy rain and soggy snow, driven by gale-force winds up to forty-five miles an hour, caused power failures, ripped off cornices and produced other disruptions here yesterday.

HANDEL'S "Ezio," as presented by Actors Opera at the Gate Theatre, was one of the most interesting features of the city's Handel Festival last season. And now the enterprising young singers have brought their production uptown.

A power failure at the Consolidated Edison Company's generating plant at Kent Avenue in Brooklyn, caused a service slowdown yesterday on all BMT subway lines in that borough at the peak of the evening rush hour. The situation was complicated by the stalling of a train on the Manhattan Bridge.

A jury of eleven men and one woman was selected yesterday in Federal Court to try Alexander L. Guterma, an associate and two corporations on charges of conspiring to de- fraud by flouting Securities and Exchange Commission requirements for protecting stockholders.

BALBOA, C. Z., Dec 5 -- With ship transits at a peak, gross revenues of the Panama Canal Company were up more than $4,000,000 during the 1959 fiscal year. But net operating revenue rose only $327,150 above the previous year's figure.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 7 (AP) -- The Federal Power Commission asked the supreme court today to brush aside a last legal obstacle to construction of a reseroir on Tuscarora Indian lands in western New York.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 7 -- The Supreme Court refused today to interfere with the Administration's ban on travel to Communist China.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 7 -- New moves are in prospect for further unification of the armed forces. High Administration officials as well as some democratic leaders are understood to be sympathetic to most of the proposals.
There is still plenty of time to enter the annual American Bowling Congress tournament and a better chance of squeezing into the competition with a five-man team.
TRENTON, Dec. 7 -- New Jersey observed the eighteenth anniversary of the Japanese attack on Pearl Harbor today with an air raid drill -- the first since May.
HELSINKI, Finland, Dec. 7 -- "If Westerners are really concerned about Finland's position, why don't they do something about it by buying more Finnish goods?"

IN the early days of the National Football League, almost forty years ago, the games provoked no riotous demonstrations such as marred the fading minutes of the Giants-Browns rabble-rouser at the Yankee Stadium on Sunday. There were two reasons for this: 1, there were too few spectators to do any damage: 2, the customers didn't care much who won.

In a dual transaction, the Estate Securities Company, real estate operators, purchased the six-story apartment house at 2-14 Elton Street, at the corner of Jamaica Avenue in Brooklyn, and resold it to the 2-14 Elton Street Corporation.
The city Investigation Commissioner has opened an intensive inquiry into reports of an ambulance-chasing racket involving lawyers and some employes of the Fire Department.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 7 (AP) -- The Supreme Court refused today to block a second trial for Richard A. Mack and Thurman A. Whiteside on charges that they had plotted to fix a Miami television channel award.

KEEPING up with Anna Eleanor Roosevelt is fatiguing, but it can be done by a young whirling dervish. For she is a traveler, lecturer, newspaper and magazine columnist, book writer, teacher, television performer and, in her own words, "common soldier with the many."

LONDON, Dec. 7 (AP) -- A leading British banker today urged the restoration of full convertibility for the pound sterling and removal of all restrictions on its use in international trade and finance.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Dec. 7 -- The movie industry learned long ago to be wary of the firepower of the typewriters of Civil War buffs. But television's commanders here are younger and brasher.

The New York State Banking Department has filed a new bill with the Legislature that proposes to amend the personal property law. It is aimed at eliminating the failure of repairmen to carry out promised alterations or improvements on property after the owner has signed an installment contract.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 7 -When Sir Oliver Franks, former British Ambassador in Washington and now chairman of Lloyds Bank, was in this country a few days ago, he left a paper with Secretary of State Christian A. Herter that is being carefully studied by the Administration.

FRANKFURT, Germany, Dec. 7 -- An event that would have shaken European money centers a year or two ago has been taking place here for the last two months. In the new conditions of European financial stability, it has produced only raised eyebrows and so far only a mild sense of concern.
The H. L. Green Company, Inc., va,'iety store chain, yesterday reported a net profit of $389,958 on sales of $32,995,342 for the quazer ended on Oct. 31.

Syracuse University's unbeaten football team yesterday was named the nation's top eleven in the ratings of the two major wire services. The Orange gained 134 of 201 first-place votes in the Associated Press poll of writers and broadcasters and thirty-one of thirty-five firsts from United Press International's board of coaches.

Federal Judge Edward Weinfeld refused yesterday to dismiss a $150,000,000 civil antitrust suit brought by thirty-three members of the American Society of Composers, Authors and Publishers against Broadcast Music, Inc.

Negotiations for the sale of the Roxy Theatre to Webb Knapp are still under way, it was learned yesterday. The property has been owned by Rockefeller Center, Inc., for the last four years, and the film house has been operated by a subsidiary of Rockefeller Center since October of this year.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 7 (AP) -- The Air Force announced today a new type of research rocket -- the 1,700 pound, twenty-nine-foot-long Jaguar.

LOS ANGELES, Dec. 7 -- Directors of the Times-Mirror Company today declared a 4 per cent dividend and raised the quarterly cash dividend rate to 25 cents a share from 20 cents a share paid previously, according to Norman Chandler, president.

The ten-story apartment house at 780 Madison Avenue, Between Sixty-sixth and Sixty-seventh Streets, has been sold by Gar-Bar Realty Company to Soltzer-Lampert in the first change of ownership of the property in twenty years.

The Arab refugee problem in the Middle East will not be solved at the present-session of the U. N. General Assembly. It does seem certain, though, that the U. N. Relief and Works Agency for Palestine Refugees, set up on Dec. 8, 1949, will have its life extended for at least another three years.

The hierarchy of the Roman Catholic Church fails to appreciate the most serious aspect of the population explosion. The short-run problem is not food to feed the new mouths, although that will become crucial in time.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 7 (AP) -- Independent producers of natural gas received an average of 13 cents a thousand cubic feet for their 1958 sales to interstate pipeline companies. This compared with an average of 12 cents for 1957 sales.

The story of the search for St. Peter's remains under St. Peter's Basilica in Rome is told by Dr. Margherita Guarducci in "The Tomb of St. Peter." The author, who is Professor of Greek Epigraphy at Rome University, tells of her discoveries and researches during the excavations and "corroborates" the New Testament and the traditions of the crucifixion and burial of the Apostle.

Lisa Lane of Philadelphia. a newcomer in the American women's world of chess, retained first place last night with a victory in the sixth round of the national championship tournament at the Marshall Chess Club. She scored a well-earned victory over Mrs. Mildred Morrell of Gary, Ind., on the black side of a King's Indian defense lasting thirty-one moves. Mrs. Morrell dropped to fourth place in the standings.

Wool prices were sharply higher yesterday on the New York Cotton Exchange. Early trade buying induced commission house purchasing and chart buying. Profit taking supplied the contracts. The market closed at or near the highs of the day.
Columbia University will increase its tuition and fees by as much as 21 per cent, from about $1,100 to 61,450 a year, starting next September.

Cus D'Amato, whose manager's license was revoked by the State Athletic Commission, yesterday moved in State Supreme Court for a review and annulment of the commission's decision. A hearing on his motion was set for Dec. 15.
The market for United States Government securities resumed yesterday the rally begun in the final half hour on Friday.

Three Soviet regional officials have been replaced in the wake of a strike reported to have taken place in the Republic of Kazakhstan, in Central Asia.

Sponsors have been announced for the theatre party to "Saratoga" at the Winter Garden Theatre and the after theatre supper party at the Basildon Room of the Waldorf-Astoria on Thursday. Proceeds will further the work of the Auxialiary of the James Ewing Hospital.
The New York Central System announced yesterday it had sold its Rochester, N. Y., terminal and given a long-term lease, with an option to purchase, on its Buffalo terminal and office building.

CORONADO, Calif., Dec. 7 -Sidney Lazard and Paul Allinger did not win the pair championship in the tournament that just ended here. But their score of 473 1/2 match points, in the semi-final session, which was 72.8 per cent of maximum, was the highest ever made in this event. It was the second-highest on record in major national-pair tournaments.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 7 -- The Federal Communications Commission opened hearings today on television's programing standards. The agency was immediately beset by complaints of too much crime and violence on the home screen.

LONDON, Dec. 7 -- One of the year's fiercest storms continued to lash out at Britain and Western Europe from the Atlantic today, battering ships at sea and flooding coastal villages in South Wales and Southwest England.

Uncertainty in the final ninety minutes of trading trimmed prices on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday. At the end of the session the net advance was modest for the industrials and the rails had a small loss.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 7 -- Reporters should "gather" rather than "seek" news, the General Assembly's Social Committee decided today.

The Midland (Tex.) Independent School District is planning an offering of $3,500,000 school house bonds secured by general taxes, maturing December, 1960 to 1986.

The New York Central Railroad has turned to the jet aircraft manufacturing industry to help it keep its yards clear of snow this winter.

ROME, Dec. 7 -- With the Rome Olympic events less than nine months away, approximately 20,000 beds in private homes and apartments have been put at the disposition of the Italian Olympic Committee. These have now been inspected and graded and prices assigned.

This has been a banner year for securities markets not only in New York but around the country. The Midwest Stock Exchange is a case in point. Volume there in the fiscal year ended on Nov. 30 exceeded a billion dollars for the first time, the exchange announced yesterday.

Now that aspirants for West Point don't have to stop growing at 6 feet 4 inches, better days seem to be in store for Army basketball. LONDON, Dec. 7 -- Pete Dawkins will be in the Oxford lineup tomorrow in Britain's biggest college rugby football game of the year, the contest with Cambridge at Twickenham.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 7 -- Senate antitrust investigators produced evidence today showing that the wholesale price of a wonder drug to combat arthritis had been increased more than 1,000 per cent over cost by a major drug producer.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 7 -- Interest rates on short-term Government borrowing rose to new record levels again today. It was 4.638 per cent on the regular weekly issue of 91-day bills, and 4.969 per cent on the companion issue of 182-day bills.
THE late Philip Barry lost none of his stature as a playwright when his comedy, "The Philadelphia Story," was televised last night on Channel 4.

Arrangements are being made for a theatre party to aid St. Johnland Home for the Aged in Kings Park, L. I. The event will take place at the Jan. 12 performance of Jean Anouilh's comedy, "The Fighting Cock." The play, starring Rex Harrison, is scheduled to open at the ANTA Theatre tonight.

Motorola, Inc., plans to exchange an undisclosed number of its common shares next month for all business and assets of the LearCal division of Lear, Inc. This was announced jointly yesterday by Robert W. Galvin, president of Motorola and William P. Lear, chairman of Lear.
A twenty-count indictment was returned in Kings County Court yesterday charging two ex-convicts with the kidnapping and rape of two girls in Brooklyn last Thursday evening.
Senator Hubert H. Humphrey whirled through the city yesterday presenting a catalogue of his views on everything from poetry to the Presidency.

Former President Truman and three other top-ranking Democrats joined yesterday in praise of the Rockefeller Brothers Fund report on United States foreign policy. They also saw in it support for Democratic criticisms of foreign policy conduct.

NEW HAVEN, Dec. 7 -- The president of Yale University, citing recent world developments, particularly in the Soviet Union, declared today that it was "essential to strengthen our nation's position in pure science, from which stems all technological advance."

MANHASSET, L. I., Dec. 7 -- Two men were arrested today after a three-mile chase and charged with stealing $5,300 from the cashier of Patricia Murphy's Candlelight Restaurant. The money was recovered.
A pair of gunmen fired six shots at a manager and his clerk near a supermarket, missed, and escaped with $975 in a hold-up yesterday. They overlooked $5,652.
ALBANY, Dec. 8 -- Governor Rockefeller's last political tour as an undeclared candidate for the Republican Presidential nomination will take him to twelve cities in seven states.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 -- The Soviet Union is closer to self-sufficiency in minerals vital to industry and defense than the United States is, a Senate committee was told today.
An offering of $22,500,000 of new, twenty-year debt securities of James Talcott, Inc., industrial finance company, is being made today by underwriters headed by F. Eberstadt Co. and White, Weld Co.

The second Spoleto Festival Ball will be held in the ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria on Jan. 8.
Adlai E. Stevenson proposed yesterday a new labor law that would recognize the public welfare and give the President far greater powers than under the Taft-Hartley Act.

STEVE SEBO has escaped from that bastion of rectitude, the Ivy League, into heaven - knows - what. Shamefully fired last week by Penn after his skillful coaching had brought the Quakers their first championship of football's most exclusive circle, Sebo has signed as general manager of the New York Titans, the new professional team that hopes to challenge the Giants for the customer's dollar.

MORE than half a million men and women have the heady privilege of saying "charge it" to Tiffany's.

Y. The suit centered on a method of making cream cheese.

Twelve women, whose identities are virtually unknown to the average theatregoer but whose apostolic business fervor has made them an all-pervading force on Broadway, have sold about $7,000,000 worth of theatre tickets this season.

Mayor Wagner announced yesterday that he would appoint a three-man committee of "prominent people" to help reach a new transit agreement well in advance of the expiration of present contracts at midnight Dec. 31.

REYKJAVIK, Iceland, Dec. 8 (UPI) -- Neither reduction nor withdrawal of United States forces in Iceland is under consideration, Foreign Minister Gudmundur I. Gudmundsson told the Althing (Parliament) yesterday.
A dockside "steal-to-order" business -- apparently foundering for lack of sales even before the police moved in -- was described yesterday by the Waterfront Commission.
ROME, Dec. 8 -- Pope John XXIII called today for laws to curb freedom of the press lest lust and criminality poison the religious and moral soundness of mankind.
CHICAGO, Dec. 8 (AP) -- The report of today's livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:
LONDON, Dec. 8 -- The Advisory Council on Scientific Policy cautioned Britain today against the "folly" of seeking national prestige through costly programs of space exploration.

Tony Brooks, a 27-year-old Englishman, is a cautious man. His philosophy of life is likely to be expressed in phrases such as: "Never force anything." He has often remarked: "Some people really slick their necks out. You feel it's only a matter of time."
Two top-level changes in the management of the Armco Steel Corporation were made yesterday at the meeting of directors in Middletown, Ohio.

BONN, Germany, Dec. 8 -- Foreign Minister Heinrich von Brentano said today that the Indian Government had given an "unsatisfactory" explanation of Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru's news conference remarks on German reunification last week.

VIENTIANE, Laos, Dec. 7 -- The majority party of the Laotian National Assembly issued a communique today recommending that a special session be called this month to iron out internal government difficulties.

Speculative enthusiasm took firm hold of the standard blue chip issues yesterday, with the result that The New York Times combined average of fifty stocks made its best oneday gain since Oct. 23, 1957.
EAST ORANGE, N. J., Dec. 8 -- "We've lost our first three games, but this is still the best ball club I've had in my four years at Upsala," Coach Fred Wieboldt said today.
Recently there has been a great deal of excitement over the Russian photographs of the back side of the moon. The pictures obtained, however, showed little that was surprising.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 -President Eisenhower's visit to New Delhi tomorrow comes at a time when relations between India and the United States are at a friendly high. Officials here see it as a time of promise for even better understanding, closer cooperation and progress to the benefit of both countries.

For the next few years, the world's greatest oil-exploration and development program will be centered in Libya and Algeria, over an area of 2,000,000 square miles. The results of this effort will have an important impact on the world market for petroleum and its products.

This is the season of half-tones and increasing silence as nature goes into repose for a season. The sounds and colors that make spring exciting and summer beautiful have faded back into the landscape and autumn slowly congeals into winter.
Whitney North Seymour, president-elect of the American Bar Association, last night received the Medal of the Association of the Bar of the City of New York.
CHICAGO, Dec. 8 -- "As 1960 approaches, the nation's economy is poised on a springboard," James M. Symes, chairman of the Pennsylvania Railroad Company, said to day in summing up his expectations.

The cold weather caused a sharp decline last week in the nation's light fuel-oil stocks, used mostly in heating homes. According to the American Petroleum Institute, supplies in the week ended last Friday dropped 6,793,000 barrels to 164,093,000. A year ago, stocks were 155,826,000 barrels.

Eight B coffee notices and four M deliveries were posted yesterday on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange. The deliveries were fairly well received and the B months rose 15 to 34 points (hundredths of a cent a pound) on 18,500 bags and the M futures gained 20 to 69 points on 24,000 bags.

Prices swung erratically yesterday but the trend on the New York Stock Exchange was generally downward. The aggregate market value of stocks fell more than $2,000,000,000, almost as much as it gained on Tuesday.
The conduct of the primary election held Sept. 15 in Long Beach, L. I., was severely censured yesterday by Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz.
HAVANA, Dec. 9 -- The Cuban Government tightened control of foreign exchange and imports tonight to prevent the outflow of dollars.
The Fire Commissioner has ordered the transfer of all 200 district fire inspectors to avoid the possibility of their being tempted by Christmas gifts from "unscrupulous" property owners.

Considerable publicity is being given to the announcement of the Roman Catholic Bishops that United States Catholics may not support public assistance at home or abroad to promote artificial birth prevention. However, little if any publicity has been given to a birth control assistance that Roman Catholics may in conscience use.
A move toward widening the public ownership of Ford Motor Company stock was made yesterday with the offering of 2,000,000 shares of common stock owned by the Ford Foundation.

Columbia rallied in the second half to beat a new basketball opponent last night. After trailing the University of Baltimore at half-time, 32 -- 26, the Lions seemed to get accustomed to their home court and went on to win, 69-62.

CLEVELAND, Dec. 9 (UPI) -- Senator Kenneth B. Keating of New York said today that the nation's cost of crime had climbed to an "alarming" $22,000,000,000 a year, or nearly one-third the annual cost of running the entire Federal Government.

Cardinal Spellman, who has established a tradition of spending Christmas with American servicemen overseas, renewed another annual custom yesterday by sending the fund for New York's Neediest Cases a check for $500.

The road is beckoning "Sweet Bird of Youth," the Martin Beck's prosperous tenant since March 10. Cheryl Crawford, sponsor, said yesterday that she hoped to start the post-Broad-way tour in Los Angeles in the spring. But no date for the departure of the Tennessee Williams drama, staged by Elia Kazan, has been fixed.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 -- The Federal Reserve Board reported today that the condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in leading cities showed the following principal changes for the week ended Wednesday, Dec. 2:

An 85-year-old retired merchant yesterday unveiled a plaque on the marble front of an eight-story building at Third Avenue and Fifty-sixth Street The inscription noted that on April 17, 1872, "Bloomingdale's started here."

JASCHA HEIFETZ reminded us last night how much he has been missed. In an appearance at the United Nations, his first in New York in almost four years, the violinist made it clear that he was still the unsurpassed master of his art.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 9 -- The General Assembly "deplored" today the failure of the Soviet Union and Hungary to honor previous resolutions of the United Nations on the Hungarian situation.

The prospects for an agreement on a two-year contract covering 1,600 private sanitation men brightened yesterday as industry Negotiators raised their wage offer. Negotiations were scheduled to resume today.
NEW DELHI, India, Dec. 9 (AP) -- Mrs. John S. D. Eisenhower took a back seat today during the reception given her father-in-law on his arrival in India.
News spread yesterday in Brooklyn of a mailman who didn't ring twice. He often didn't ring at all.
KARACHI, Pakistan, Dec. 9 (AP) -- Following is the text of President Eisenhower's farewell statement to President Mohammad Ayub Khan of Pakistan at Mauripur Airport today:

TO a Frenchwoman, going without perfume is like walking down the Champs Elysees barefooted. It is not only foolish, it is unthinkable.
The Zim Israel Navigation Company confirmed yesterday reports that it had ordered a new passenger liner for its Mediterranean service.

CHICAGO, Dec. 9 (AP) -- Billy Golembiewski of Detroit and Ray Bluth of St. Louis were in a virtual tie for first place tonight as the sixteen men finished the seventh round in the world invitation bowling tournament finals.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 (AP) -- Labor Secretary James P. Mitchell issued an opinion today to the effect that the labor reform law did not abolish Santa Claus in the labor-management field.
NEW DELHI Thursday, Dec. 10 (AP) -- Changing to cloth sandals, President Eisenhower placed a huge floral wreath early today on the shrine to Mohandas K. Gandhi.

Jack Clarke, a 48-year-old Englishman, walks 106 fox-hounds every morning in a park adjacent to the Crawley and Horsham hunt in Sussex, England. They belong to the 200 members, who never refer to the pack as containing 106 hounds.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 -- The steel industry rejected today an Administration suggestion that deadlocked negotiations be submitted to arbitration. Noting that President Eisenhower had said that any settlement should make full provision for the public interest, the companies declared that third-party intervention could only result in recommendationsthat the union had refused to accept or for a more costly settlement "which could clearly be inflationary."
DETROIT, Dec. 9 -- Senator Pat McNamara issued declaration of rights for older Americans today.
Controller Lawrence E. Gerosa's emphatic dissent yesterday from Mayor Wagner's recommendations for reorganizing New York City's governmental structure took no one by surprise.
PANAMA, Dec. 9 (AP) -- Planes of the Caribbean Air Command's Air Rescue Service reported today they had found no trace of a Colombian airliner that vanished with forty-six persons aboard.

Sales of A. E. Staley Manufacturing Company for the fiscal year that ended on Sept. 30 increased to a record of $168,704,309 from $161,468,002 in the preceding fiscal year. Earnings of the corn, soybean and chemical processor fell slightly.

Corporation money kept bidding on a broadened scale yesterday for the Treasury's discount bills, shrinking yields on these prime short-term investments by as much as eight one hundredths of 1 percentage point.
BIRMINGHAM, Ala., Dec. 9 (UPI) -- A leading Negro integration leader called last night on Southern Negroes to practice civil disobedience if necessary to weaken segregation.
ATLANTIC CITY, Dec. 9 -- A long-range program for cooperative Protestantism to make the United States "a truly Christian nation" was urged tonight by a leading church spokesman.
ALBERT LEA, Minn., Dec. 9 (AP) -- Nearly 1,000 pickets barred nonunion workers from leaving the Wilson Company packing plant for three hours today before yielding to pleas by the police.
Spokesmen for sixty organizations concerned with state business and civic and political activities are to address a Democratic program conference today.

CHICAGO, Dec. 9 (UPI) -- John (Jake The Barber) Factor sued Roger Touhy and others today for $3,000,000. He charged that Touhy's book about old days in the underworld libeled him and invaded his privacy.
Thomas J. Taylor, a former city markets inspcetor, was indicted on a perjury charge yesterday in the investigation of the Bureau of Weights and Measures in the Department of Markets.

A hearing was held yesterday by an examiner of the Public Service Commission on a plan to continue the Long Island Rail Road's package-freight service in Suffolk and eastern Nassau Counties. The examiner reserved decision.

JACKSON, Miss., Dec. 9 (UPI) -- Robert Lee Goldsby, a Negro, was convicted for the second time tonight for the slaying of a white woman in 1954. He was sentenced to die in Mississippi's gas chamber Jan. 22.
NEW HAVEN, Conn., Dec. 9 (AP) -- DeLaney Kiphuth, Yale's athletic director, said today that all full-time head coaches at the university now have what amounts to lifetime appointments.
Miss Jane H. Todd of Tarry-town, who served as vice chairman of the Republican State Committee prior to her resignation last summer, was honored at a testimonial dinner last night at the Astor Hotel.
Eleven of the twenty convicts who fled from the Ivy Bluff, N. C., prison on Tuesday were captured yesterday. Another had been seized near the prison several hours after the break.

PATCHOGUE, L. I., Dec. 9 -- Arthur M. Cromarty, Supervisor of Babylon Township, took control of the Suffolk County Republican organization here tonight.
Judge Irving R. Kaufman yesterday acquitted one of the twenty-one men being tried for conspiring to lie to the Government about the purpose of the 1957 Apalachin meeting.
MOSCOW, Dec. 9 -- Soviet readers were told today that the United States election campaign had begun. They also received lesson No. 1 in American politics: the "Moneybags" will decide.

KABUL, Afghanistan, Dec. 9 -- President Eisenhower spent six hours here deep in ancient Asia today after a flight from Karachi, and witnessed the force of Soviet influence along the historic conquerors' route to India.

AS this department has noted on occasion, there are trends in food as well as in fashion. During the last eighteen months more than a score of oriental restaurants have opened in Manhattan. Prior to that, a Polynesian influence had asserted itself.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 -- Imports of foreign - made steel products continued at a high level in October and exports of American steel products declined again, the Department of Commerce reported today. The steel strike has been a large factor in both trends, but both were under way before the strike started.

President Eisenhower's recent discussion of the affidavit and oath required of student applicants for Federal loans authorized by the National Defense Education Act of 1958 deserves comment in two respects.

Charles F. Preusse's resignation as City Administrator is a serious loss to the people of New York and a damaging departure from the Wagner administration. When he came to office four years ago as successor to Dr. Luther Gulick we questioned whether he could fully maintain the tradition of nonpolitical detachment essential to the success and prestige of the Division of Administration.

IRWIN ROSS has something to sell to us. He has an image he wants to place in our minds. The gods may smile to see how well he has used for his purposes the techniques of what he has for sale -- and its attendant persuasiveness of imagery.

PITTSBURGH, Dec. 9 (UPI) -- Federal Judge John McIlvaine signed a temporary injunction order late today ordering brakemen and flagman of the Pittsburgh and Lake Erie Railroad, who went on strike this morning, to return to their jobs immediately.
REMSEN, N. Y., Dec. 9 -- Representatives of Oneida County dairy farmers elected a committee here tonight to coordinate a proposed exchange of information and experience with Soviet farmers.
GREENWICH, Conn., Dec. 9 -- The Bridgeport Diocese of the Roman Catholic Church, which embraces Fairfield County, appealed today for lay teachers for its parochial schools.
NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., Dec. 9 (AP) -- New York University's undefeated basketball team outshot, outmaneuvered and outrebounded Rutgers tonight for a 82-56 victory.

Justice Vincent A. Lupiano heard arguments in a Supreme Court suit yesterday by four stockholders of Doeskin Products, Inc. They are seeking to recover for the corporation 1,000,000 shares of stock now in the hands of two Canadian concerns and a Liechtenstein trust.
PHOENIX, Ariz., Dec. 9 -- Early improvement in Federal policies concerning the country's half-million Indians was hopefully forecast today by Arizona's two Representatives.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 -The president of Merck Co. told antitrust investigators today that the drug industry was "highly competitive" and was giving the American public "a reasonable bargain."
It was confirmed at City Hall yesterday that Thomas J. Shanahan, who is vice chairman of the Mayor's Committee on Slum Clearance, was under "continuing investigation."
Madison Avenue agencies are straining their eyes and their research facilities to obtain a clearer picture of marketing opportunities on the West Coast.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 -- A slim pamphlet called "The Blue Book," now out of print but once the target of violent abuse by the nation's broadcasters, may yet turn out to be something of a prize volume -- thirteen years late.
The Christmas look spread to a new area of the city yesterday when the lights were turned up on the green-garlanded Pulitzer Memorial.
The life-insurance industry was warned yesterday that the time had come to emphasize life insurance as a channel for savings.
PASADENA, Calif., Dec. 9 -- The reciprocal destruction of American and Soviet hydrogen bombs was proposed tonight by Thomas E. Murray, former Atomic Energy Commissioner.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 (AP) -- Several independent wholesalers testified today that major oil concerns were crowding them out of the tires, batteries and accessories market through pressure on auto service stations.

A special dividend of 25 cents and the regular quarterly of 25 cents were voted on the common stock of Bickford's, Inc., for payment on Dec. 30. No cash extra was paid last year, but a 2 per cent stock dividend was distributed, in addition to the regular cash dividend, in 'December, 1958.
A two-year research project has determined that ultra-high-speed drills can be used with safety on teeth when "employed judiciously under accepted techniques."
ROME, Dec. 9 -- Msgr. Enrico Dante, the Vatican's Prefect of Apostolic Ceremonies, has issued notice of consistories for the creation of Cardinals next Monday and Thursday.
Statements ridiculing Cuba's out-cries regarding United States laxity in preventing Havana's bombing a few weeks ago are tarnished in light of recent news.

TRADITIONALLY, and bafflingly, the English-speaking poet has been indifferent to the visual arts. A rare exception is the Pulitzer-Prize winning poet Stanley Kunitz, who has conducted his life more nearly in the French tradition, keeping close to the world of painters, writing occasional art criticism and acknowledging the "cross-pollination between the arts."

NEWBURG, N. Y., Dec. 9 (AP) -- New York City residents are the worst drivers on the New York thruway, a State Police officer said today. He reported that a safety campaign had reduced Thruway accidents.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 -- Bernard Goldfine, New England industrialist, pleaded. his constitutional privilege against self-incrimination today in refusing to answer a question put to him by a House investigating subcommittee.

NEWARK, Dec. 9---The State Board of Public Utility Commissioners gave the Erie Railroad Company permission today into discontinue 'its passenger Iservice on the Orange branch of the Greenwood Lake division.
DAKAR, Senegal, Dec. 9 -- The transformation of the French Community into an association resembling in some aspects the British Commonwealth is expected here in the near future.
Some phases of the proposed $83,000,000 Lower Manhattan Expressway were assailed by many persons from the Canal Street area at a City Hall public hearing yesterday.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange moved 1 to 11 points (5 to 55 cents a bale) up yesterday.
S. J. Kessler Sons, the architects Mayor Wagner said should never again get any city work, are still listed on an official list of architects approved to do work for the city.

LONDON, Dec. 9 -- A group of Britons, just back from their first trip to the United States, reported tonight that they had found the Americans hospitable, religious and, except for the language, rather like the British.

IF men customers seem to get more attention in department stores than women shoppers do there are valid reasons for it. The male shopper, according to an Abraham Straus survey of Christmas shoppers, is an "easier" customer because he usually knows just what he wants, only briefly examines the merchandise and then makes the purchase quickly.

Fairbanks Whitney Corporation announced yesterday that it had repurchased its former Pratt Whitney property in West Hartford, Conn., for about $12,000,000. This was said to represent $6,000,000 cash over mortgages.

"Celebrity Register," a new book by Cleveland Amory, will be published Monday by Celebrity Register, Ltd., an affiliate of Earl Blackwell's Celebrity Service, Inc. The volume is an alphabetically arranged collection of biographies of 2,240 living "celebrities" in the arts, sports, politics, society, religion, science and other fields.

HAS been described as "the busiest woman in the United States." . . . Small (5 feet 3, 110 pounds), pert, hard-working. . . . Still carries trace of her native Budapest in her voluble speech. . . . Born there in 1902, came to this country at 10, married at 19, now separated from Julius Rosenberg, rug merchant.

ALBANY, Dec. 9 -- New York City's continuation schools for 16-year-old "drop-outs" were described today as archaic, custodial and time-serving institutions. The accusation was made in a report by the State Department of Education.
MILWAUKEE, Wis., Dec. 9 (UPI) -- The National Council of the Protestant Episcopal Church ended its three-day quarterly meeting today by approving a $20,000 stewardship training program.

The Orchestra of America last night played another chapter in its history of American symphonic music. Like the first two, it was given at Carnegie Hall under the direction of Richard Korn. Eleanor Steber, Metropolitan Opera soprano, was the guest soloist.
LONDON, Dec. 9 (UPI) -- British rugby experts today said that the American style of passing displayed by Pete Dawkins in yesterday's Oxford-Cambridge match might revolutionize the sport.

WICHITA, Kan., Dec. 9 -- Senator Hubert H. Humphrey returned to the Midwest today on his final campaign swing of the year. What he saw and heard at Wichita, the first stop, was moderately encouraging to his Presidential aspirations.

LONDON, Dec. 9 -- Two Royal Air Force helicopter, struggling against a sixty-mile-an-hour wind, picked the crew of seven men from a lightship drifting off the east coast of Scotland today and carried them to safety.
It is getting along toward Christmas now, but the yard is a long way from being in order. There are various reasons for this, and not a single one of them is the fault of the caretaker.
The scholarship fund of the America-Israel Cultural Foundation will gain as the result of a concert by the Israeli violinist Zvi Zeitlin in Town Hall on Monday.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 (UPI) -- The American Veterans Committee complained today that the United States was "bowing in abject humiliation" to foreign governments by agreeing not to station Jewish soldiers in Arab countries or Negro troops in Iceland.
Deogracia Cortez, a 40-year-old plasterer with six children whose wife is in a hospital, stamped in wild, helpless fury yesterday from the office of the Brenn Realty Corporation on West 104th Street.

The Lou Nierenberg Corporation, manufacturer of imitation fur coats, has purchased the six-story building it occupies under lease at 239-41 West Thirtieth Street. The building is on a plot 37.6 by 100 feet between Seventh and Eighth Avenues.

The Eger Players, Joseph Eger, French horn, Dixie Blackstone, violin, Madeline Foley, cellist, and Lawrence Smith, piano, appeared at the Kaufmann Concert Hall last night. It was an event of the Wednesday night chamber music series of the Ninety-second Street "Y."

WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 -- The New York Central Railroad received permission from the Interstate Commerce Commission today to terminate passenger service between Weehawken, N. J., and West Haverstraw, N. Y.

Under Secretary Dillon is now visiting European capitals to enlist support for policies that will take account of the changes in the world economic picture wrought by the Marshall Plan that sparked West European recovery.

MIAMI, Dec. 9 -- Life continued to move pleasantly today at the Fontainebleau's fantastic fourteen acres. Bathers sunned themselves around the spacious pool or strolled in the enchanting gardens. Still, there was a void.

PALM BEACH, Fla., Dec. 9 (AP) -- A revolution in American transportation, based on development of container units, was cited today by a speaker at the convention of the American Association of Port Authorities.

The State of California yesterday postponed a scheduled borrowing of $100,000,000 in the bond market for reasons of interest cost. An effort to raise the money will be made again on Jan. 13, State Treasurer Bert A. Betts said.

LONDON, Dec. 9 -- Stock market prices moved up on a broad front today and the Financial Times index of industrial common stocks rose to a new peak. The index, based on thirty blue-chip stocks, rose 2.9 points to 310.6.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Dec. 9 -- The Air Force's junk has become a movie company's art. It has cost $77,000 to make the transformation, but Twentieth Century-Fox considers it a bargain.

DUMONT, N. J., Dec. 9 -- The New York Central was posting notices in trains and stations today telling passengers that service on the West Shore Line would end at 11:59 P. M. tomorrow. NEW DELHI, India, Dec. 9 (AP) -- Some Indian villagers said today that they thought President Eisenhower was a reincarnation of Vishnu, protector in the Hindu trinity.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 -- As often occurs in so-called debate, particularly in the forum of politics, former President Truman and Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt dealt with two different propositions at the Democratic fundraising dinner in New York City Monday night. He was protesting against one thing and she was endorsing quite another, so that her views on Mr. Truman's position and his views on Mrs. Roosevelt's were not disclosed.

Although the nation is faced with the prospects of another budget deficit in 1960, and a budget of around $81 billion in 1961 that may or may not be balanced, the National Democratic Advisory Council would expand spending in almost every direction. The council proposes a higher minimum wage, higher unemployment pay and sickness insurance, more Federal aid for schools.

Directors of the Marine Midland Corporation declared a 2 1/2 per cent stock dividend on the common shares, payable on Feb. 26. The board also voted the regular quarterly dividend of 25 cents a common share, payable on Jan 2, and the regular quarterly of 50 cents a share on the 4 per cent convertible preferred, payable on Jan. 15.

NEW CANAAN, Conn., Dec. 9 -- A gala after-theatre supper party aboard several special cars of a New Haven Railroad train will be held after a performance of "Sarafoga" on Friday evening for the benefit of the Silvermine Guild of Artists here.
A new method of attacking advanced cancers by giving the cancer itself a killing dose of drug while shielding the rest of the body with an antidote was described here yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 -- Hope for passage of stronger civil rights legislation at the next session of Congress was voiced today by Senator Jacob K. Javits.

BORN on New York's West Side of Irish parentage sixty-four years ago. . . . He and Mrs. Miley now live on the East Side. . . . Prides himself on coming up the hard way. . . . Once drove a taxi in New York, got his education in bits, managing some time at Columbia.

JACK SCOTT was a big, rawboned tobacco farmer from North Carolina and Blondy Ryan was a fiery football player from Holy Cross. Neither attained stardom in baseball but each had brief periods of brilliance as members of the New York Giants. They did it eleven years apart, Scott in 1922 and Ryan in 1933. Death took them within two days of each other not long ago.
HAVANA, Dec. 9 -- Austin Frank Young of Miami, Fla., escaped from prison this morning at Pinar del Rio, where he had been sentenced to thirty years at hard labor.

CHICAGO, Dec. 9 (AP) -- Titus Haffa, Chicago industrialist, sued the Columbia Broadcasting System and others today for $10,000,000 damages, alleging he was libeled in a television play based on the St. Valentine's Day massacre.
TEL AVIV, Israel, Dec. 9 -- Fairbanks Morse Co. of Chicago and the Israeli Government agreed today on a partnership for the development of a machine designed to sweeten sea water.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 -- The Administration's foreign - aid program is running into unexpected trouble on two fronts.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 9 -- A person in close touch with the question predicted today that Senegal and the Sudan Republic, two of the African members of the French Community, would be granted independence early next year. If this is done, they are expected to join the increasing number of African members of the United Nations.

A five-alarm fire with wind-whipped sparks scattering for long distances destroyed an unoccupied building at the Mount Loretto Orphange in Pleasant Plains, S. I., early today. No injuries to any of the 1,000 boys and girls at the orphange were reported.

Stock options, which recently were criticized in testimony before a Congressional committee, accounted for many of the major purchases by company officials according to the latest insiders' list of the New York Stock Exchange. For example, Felix N. Williams, a vice president of the Monsanto Chemical Company, bought 27,858 shares under a stock option, raising his holdings to 28,572.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 -- Five labor unions, acting nearly a year in advance of new contract deadlines with General Electric and Westinghouse Corporations, have taken a step toward confronting the two concerns with a united front.

LONDON, Dec. 9 -- The United States will defer its suggestions for sharing the costs of the military burdens of the Atlantic alliance until the alliance has surmounted its present difficulties, American sources said today.

The Board of Education announced yesterday that it would reinstate two teachers, both former members of the Communist party, who were suspended from the school system four years ago for refusing to name other Communists.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 9 -- Yugoslavia and Mexico suggested today that money saved by disarmament, if only "symbolic" amounts, should be channeled into the world's underdeveloped areas.
