NEW DELHI, India, Thursday, Dec. 10 -- President Eisenhower was welcomed here yesterday with all the color, clamor, ceremony and confusion that India could offer.

The operation of a foreign-flag fleet by an affiliate of a subsidized American-flag company was vigorously defended yesterday at a public hearing conducted by the United States Maritime Administration.
A major move to coordinate programs for citizen traffic safety is under way here.
Cardinal Spellman held homeless children on his knees and greeted their benefactors with smiles and nods yesterday at his fourteenth annual Christmas party for the New York Foundling Hospital.

The Eastern College Athletic Conference approved two major changes yesterday in the sprint rowing championships for next year. In 1960, for the first time, all the crews will row the Olympic distance of 2,000 meters and both classes will compete at the same site.
Mayor Wagner named a citizens' committee yesterday to seek a formula that would prevent a strike on New Year's Day on the city's subway and bus lines.
Patent medicines that claim to rejuvenate are causing aging persons to waste money and should be investigated, a physician said yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 -- State Department officials said today that the drafting of Swiss citizens in the United States into the United States armed forces was an old and vexa tious issue between the two governments.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 9 -- The United States warned today against inviting a "repetition of the disastrous Communist aggression of 1950" in Korea.
Adlai E. Stevenson emerged today as the choice for President next year in a poll of fifty-four prominent Americans conducted by Esquire magazine.
KAMPALA, Uganda, Dec. 9 -- In the race of East African countries toward independence Uganda has dropped behind Tanganyika and Kenya, her neighbors.
The Port of New York scored foreign trade gains at a rate three times faster than the nation as a whole in the first six months of this year.

Back in 1933, Arthur H. Dean, a partner in the law firm of Sullivan Cromwell, hailed the new Federal Securities Act regulating the securities markets as salutary. Writing in the latest Columbia Law Review, Mr. Dean, who has been general counsel to various corporations and investment banking concerns, calls his optimism justified.
Longshoremen from Maine to Virginia will vote today on new three-year contracts with waterfront employers.

A securities corporation, described as a "boiler room" that published "deceptive" market letters, was asked yesterday to show cause why it should not be barred permanently from the securities business in New York State.
The city school system will need 12,451 more teachers in the next four years.

Sales of the Chain Belt Company for the fiscal year ended on Oct. 31 were $66,405,925, the highest in the concern's history, and 16.8 per cent above the $56,873,531 in the preceding year. Net income also set a record of $4,704,403, equal to $4.17 a share. This represented a gain of 19.5 per cent above the $3,878,699 in the year to Oct. 31, 1958.

FOR the second night of its new season at the City Center the New York City Ballet last night offered the Bertolt Brecht-Kurt Weill morality play. "The Seven Deadly Sins," as the principal item on the bill.
Alexander L. Guterma never refused to supply information to independent auditors, but they never got all the information they wanted, one of them testified yesterday.
KARACHI, Pakistan, Dec. 9 (AP) -- President Mohammad Ayub Khan declared today that he was happy about the visit of President Eisenhower to Pakistan, and this view was echoed in the press here.
NEW DELHI, India, Thursday, Dec. 10 (AP) -- In banner headlines India's newspapers declared today that President Eisenhower's welcome was epochal and that he was a messenger and builder of peace.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 -Following is the text of a statement issued today by R. Courad Cooper, chief negotiator for the steel companies' coordinating committee:
NEW DELHI, India, Thursday, Dec. 10 (AP) -- In banner headlines India's newspapers declared today that President Eisenhower's welcome was epochal and that he was a messenger and builder of peace.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 -Following is the text of a statement issued today by R. Courad Cooper, chief negotiator for the steel companies' coordinating committee:

Lisa Lane of Philadelphia strengthened her hold on first place in the national women's chess championship last night at the Marshall Chess Club. She defeated Mona N. Karff of New York in seventy-one moves, thereby attaining a score of 5;-1/2.

The Edison Electric Institute reported yesterday that electricity output in the nation last week rose to 13,907,000,000 kilowatt hours from 13,173,000,000 the week before and 13,017,000,000 kilowatt hours in the like 1958 week.
ST. PAUL, Minn., Dec. 9 (AP) -- Mayor Wagner of New York charged tonight that the Republicans' "tight money" thinking as a remedy for inflation "is so obsolete as to approach the asinine.

WILLIAMSTOWN, Mass., Dec. 9 -- This country at the headwaters of the Little Hoosiz River along the New York border is of a certain steepness, which is no advantage to the deer hunter. These Berkshires seem to be higher than the Catskills and there is no downhill among them.

GARDEN CITY, L. I., Dec. 9 -- Last season the Adelphi College basketball team reached the small-college division of the National Collegiate Athletic Association play-offs. The Panthers were selected as the leading small-college team in the Eastern College Athletic Conference and for the second straight time won the title in the Tri-State League.

EACH year busy shoppers scurry through crowded stores in search of the ideal gift for each faraway loved one. When found, the selections are wrapped in a flurry of tissue and tinsel, then sent bravely on their way.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 9 -- Another appeal was made to the Union of South Africa today to negotiate on treatment of persons of Indian origin living in South Africa. The appeal was made in a resolution approved 58 to 0 by the General Assembly's Sepcial Political Committee.
KABUL, Afghanistan, Dec. 9 (AP) -- Following is the text of a communique issued jointly today by President Eisenhower and King Mohammad Zahir of Afghanistan:
CLEVELAND, Dec. 9 (UPI) -- Sonny Liston registered a technical knockout over Willie Besmanoff in a scheduled ten-round bout tonight. Referee Mike Minnich stopped the fight after the sixth round.
The drug industry has become a whipping boy for those who desire socialized medicine, an industry spokesman suggested yesterday.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 9 -- Secretary General Dag Hammarskjold said today that the Universal Declaration of Human Rights, proclaimed eleven years ago, had become a "practical instrument."

WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 (UPI) -- The average wages of unionized building trades workers in major cities rose by 16 cents to $3.51 an hour in the year ended last July 1. Reporting this today, the Bureau of Labor Statistics said the advance was I cent more than that of the preceding twelve months and one of the largest since the end of World War II.

The election of H. P. Davison as chairman and Dale E. Sharp as president of two new subsidiaries in the international field has been announced by the Morgan Guaranty Trust Company of New York. Mr. Davison is vice chairman and Mr. Sharp president of the parent bank.

The si-story apartment house for ten families at 4 East Eighty-second Street has been sold by Edwin Swan to an investing client of Robert P. Sheldon, Inc., broker. The house is on a lot 22 by 100 feet and contains an elevator. It was sold for cash over mortgages amounting to $205,000.
The American and Continental Can Companies said yesterday that they would raise can prices slightly.
BLOOMFIELD, Conn., Dec. 9 (AP) -- A helicopter piloted by an Air Force captain established today an unofficial world altitude record for its class by climbing to 30,000 feet.
ONE of the classic musical stories concerns the Carnegie Hall debut, on Oct. 27, 1917, of a 17-year-old violinist named Jascha Heifetz.
There should be plenty of "stolen" footballs when Washington and Wisconsin clash in the Rose Bowl Jan. 1.

HARRISBURG, Pa., Dec. 9 (AP) -- Harsco Corporation said today it would sell the business and substantially all the machinery and inventory of its Ainsworth-Precision division to Fulton Cotton Mills, Inc., of Atlanta, Ga. The amount involved in the cash transaction was not disclosed.

There showed up last night in Town Hall another of those talented American pianists who have been springing up all over the place the last three years or so. This time it was Phillip Evans, who devoted himself to a program of Shapero's Sonata No. 1, Schoenberg's Op. 19 Piano Pieces, the C minor Sonatas by Schubert and Beethoven (Op. 111), two fugues from Bach's "Kunst der Fuge" and three Brahms piano pieces.
GENEVA, Dec. 9 -- Switzerland accused the United States today of having constantly violated its treaty obligations by inducting Swiss citizens into its armed forces.
LAGOS, Nigeria, Dec. 9 -- An election important to all west Africa will be held Saturday in Nigeria.
MARSHALLTOWN, Iowa, Dec. 9 -- Senator Lyndon B. Johnson of Texas accused the Administration and the Republican party tonight of gambling with the security of the country.

There is only one major area of disagreement about Billy Cannon, who, as this year's outstanding college football player, accepted the Heisman Memorial Trophy from Vice President Nixon last night at the Downtown Athletic Club.
Two agents charged with permitting hazardous conditions in tenements they operated were dealt with severely in Housing Court yesterday.

Subscribers have been announced for the twentieth anniversary benefit theatre party of the American Ballet Theatre. The event will take place at the Jan. 9 evening performance of "The Sound of Music" starring Mary Martin at the Lunt-Fontanne Theatre.

Controller Lawrence E. Gerosa split again with Mayor Wagner yesterday. He declared that Controllers should retain the power to make key revenue estimates for the city budget, rather than let a Mayor's budget director "tailor-make" estimates that might leave the city "financially embarrassed."

TOKYO, Thursday, Dec. 10 (AP) -- Communist North Vietnam's Premier, Pham Van Dong, charged that a unit of the Laotian Army crossed the border Dec. 6 and killed five persons, wounded three others and set fire to houses of North Vietnamese villagers.

A DAZZLING glitter of synthetic snow and tinsel paper is slowly settling over Paris as the Christmas rush gathers momentum. The weather is catching up with the season, and animal life such as fox, skunk, mink, beaver and lamb, is running wild in the form of snug hats and collars and cuffs on women's coats.
MOSCOW, Dec. 9 -- According to Moscow's weather reporters, Old Man Winter has advanced by at least two weeks his normal schedule for putting most of the Soviet Union into its annual deep freeze.
Bob Hope complained yesterday about an attempt by the National Broadcasting Company to horn in on his act.
The committee set up by Governor Rockefeller to chart a coordinated attack on crime heard a plea yesterday for mandatory jail sentences for multiple violations of the gambling laws.

BOSTON, Dec. 9 (UPI) -- The National Basketball Association's champions, the Boston Celtics, scored 14 straight points early in the third period tonight and trounced the Philadelphia Warriors, 137 -- 116, in the second game of a doubleheader.
LEWISTOWN, Pa., Dec. 9 (AP) -- The engine and thirteen cars of a Pennsylvania Railroad express were derailed twenty miles southwest of here today. Three persons were injured.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 -Business investment in its own plant and equipment -- a basic factor in economic activity -- is continuing its gradual upward trend, according to reports issued by the Government today and by private agencies in recent weeks.
IN an age that is awestruck by the spectacular achievements of nuclear energy, the more startling feats of traditional forces sometimes go unnoticed.
The National Social Welfare Assembly, a central planning and coordinating body, elected Stanley C. Allyn president yesterday.

The New England Power Company sold yesterday 100,000 shares of $100 cumulative preferred stock. The stock was placed with a syndicate led by Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner Smith, Inc., and Eastman Dillon, Union Securities Co. on a bid of $100.26 with a dividend of $5.52 a year.
SOUTH ORANGE, N. J., Dec. 9 -- Two men posing as "reporters from The New York Times" yesterday stole three mink coats valued at a total of $11,000, according to the police here.
The Board of Education was accused yesterday of slowing the process of integration by perpetuating the so-called "neighborhood school" concept.
Bobby Fischer, the 16-year-old United States chess champion, has until Sunday to reconsider his refusal to play in this year's championship unless the pairings are redrawn in his presence.

Golf clubs with nine-hole courses will no longer be eligible for membership in the Metropolitan Golf Association. At the annual meeting of the organization held yesterday at the Princeton Club, the delegates voted unanimously for this action.

FOR two decades, Macadamia nuts were an esoteric cocktail tidbit from Hawaii stocked by Schrafft's and delicacy shops here. Now Macadamias (pronounced mac-ah-DAY-mee-ahs) are beginning to appear on grocery shelves throughout the country.
IVY BLUFF, N. C., Dec. 10 (AP) -- Thirteen escapees were behind bars tonight among the twenty who fled from the maximum security prison here Tuesday.

Brig. Gen. John Reed Kilpatrick, a Yale man who is endeared to the Elis and the New York Rangers, and George (Red) Sullivan, the captain of the Blues, told the New York Hockey Writers Association yesterday that the team would make the National Hockey League's Stanley Cup play-offs this season.

Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz of New York State said yesterday that he had urged the Committee on Ways and Means of the House of Representatives not to recommend legislation aimed at making the interest income from bonds of local governments liable to Federal income taxation.

At last accepting the ruling of the Commissioner of Education and the highest court of the State of New York, the city's Board of Education has recognized that it has no right to compel teachers to become political informers.

RIVERHEAD, L. I., Dec. 10 -Special Prosecutor Edwyn Silberling charged today that the Long Island Lighting Company had illegally obtained secret grand jury minutes from the State Public Service Commission.
Righteous indignation, an exhilirating, though often onesided, state of mind is currently being enjoyed both by some drug manufacturers and by some of those on Capitol Hill investigating them.

Asa Smith Bushnell, the commissioner of the Eastern College Athletic Conference for the last twenty years, received the annual James Lynah Memorial Award from the conference last night for his contribution to college athletics.
Bargaining talks between the National Maritime Union and East and Gulf Coast shipping operators were recessed yesterday subject to a call by the union.

VIENNA, Dec. 10 -- West German, Belgian, French and Italian banking representatives are reported to have visited Prague recently with offers of long-term credits. Apparently attracted by the huge investments the Czechoslovak Government intends to make in the third Five-Year Plan (1961-65), the West European commercial banks offered the long-term credits to finance the sale and shipment of machinery.
FORGET "The Gambler" and "Island of Goats." As produced on Broadway they made Ugo Betti seem willfully bizarre.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 10 -- The managing director of the United Nations Special Fund said today he did not think the United States could suggest birth control to underdeveloped nations.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 -- The United States and Japan have reached full agreement on the main provisions of a new defense treaty.
Revised and expanded plans for two major Port Authority projects were approved yesterday.

Events today: New York Philharmonic, Leonard Bernstein, conductor, Gold and Fizdale, duo-pianists, William Lincer, violist, Dave Brubeck Quartet, Carnegie Hall, 2:15; "Tosca," Metropolitan Opera, 8; New York University Glee Club, Town Hall, 8:30; Ralph Kirkpatrick, harpsichordist, Carnegie Recital Hall, 8:30.

The World Bank announced yesterday the granting of a loan equivalent to $50,000,000 to assist in financing the construction and operation of a 400-mile pipeline from the Hassi Messaoud area in the Sahara to the Algerian port of Bougie on the Mediterranean Coast.

East coast longshoremen voted 4 to 1 yesterday in favor of a new three-year contract with shipping companies. The ratio was announced last night by Capt. William V. Bradley, president of the International Longshoremen's Association.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 -- Secretary of State Christian A. Herter said today the United States planned to talk with its allies next week about their carrying a larger share of North Atlantic Treaty costs.
NEW DELHI, India, Friday, Dec. 11 (AP) -- Following are the texts of an address by President Eisenhower to the Indian Parliament yesterday and of his speech today at the University of Delhi:

WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 -- The importance of the international agreement on Antarctica and the value of the treaty provisions to the objectives of world peace and scientific progress were so obvious that the contributions of the American citizens who led in the negotiation have generally been overlooked.

The Norfolk and Western Railway, which absorbed the Virginian Railway last week, will start 1960 with $25,000,000 more cash in its till than it had at the start of 1959, according to Stuart T. Saunders, president of the consolidated company.

WHEN Bill Shea returned the other day from the winter baseball meetings at Miami Beach he looked like a fellow who had just been hypnotized. As a matter of fact, that's exactly what had happened to him. The man who has been the driving force behind the formation of the new Continental League had been caught in the mesmeric spell woven by his own league president, Branch Rickey.
Lawrence Winters, well known as a baritone, has decided to tackle the drama in his next Broadway appearance. He will be starred in a non-singing role in "The Long Dream."

BOSTON, Dec. 10 (UPI) -Guy Gendron and Doug Mohns scored twice each tonight as the Boston Bruins gained their first victory in their last six National Hockey League games. They beat the Toronto Maple Leafs, 6 -- 5, before the smallest Garden crowd of the season.

A new work by the late Ernest Bloch was introduced to New York last night by Yehudi Menuhin. It was the Suite No. 2 in A, for unaccompanied violin. Mr. Menuhin played at the Grace Rainey Rogers Auditorium of the Metropolitan Museum of Art.

THE Far East is getting nearer all the time. Christmas shoppers can find a plethora of sake cups, wind chimes, paper lanterns and teapots wherever they turn. There also are some more interesting oriental-inspired or genuinely Asian things to be found.

The new "compact" cars promise to halt, if not reverse, the prolonged downward trend in this country's automotive exports, according to Victor Z. Brink, head of Ford Motor Company's foreign distribution.
CHICAGO, Dec. 10 (AP)-The heaviest selling in several weeks hit soybean futures today and prices slumped as much as 4 cents a bushel in spots on the Board of Trade.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 (UPI) -- The Senator was criticized indirectly by Republican Representative Gordon H. Scherer of Cincinnati, a member of the House Committee on UnAmerican Activities.
Stocks thrashed about some-what aimlessly yesterday and ended the session virtually unchanged. It was a day of adjustments following the sharp Tuesday advance and the set-back on Wednesday.

The increasingly frequent visits to the New York financial district by officials of Capital Airlines, Inc., has started some speculation in Wall Street that Capital soon may be dropping in also on the Securities and Exchange Commission. The purpose would be to detail some new financing plans.

CHRISTA LUDWIG, a German mezzo-soprano who has made an impressive career in Germany and Austria in the last decade or so, joined the Metropolitan Opera last night. Because of miscasting, she did not do so well in her local debut as one had a right to expect.
CHICAGO, Dec. 10 -- "Peace and Prosperity with Freedom and Justice" was proposed today as a new Republican party slogan.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 -- The Internal Revenue Service announced today a drive to help cut the tax losses of $500,000,000 a year to the Government by taxpayers who do not report interest and dividends paid to them.

DETROIT, Dec. 10 -- The plight of the worker too old to get a job but too young to receive Social Security was explored today at a hearing of the Senate Subcommittee on Problems of the Aged and Aging.

LONDON, Dec. 10 -- Britain's "gap" in visible trade widened in November to nearly 50,000,000 ($140,000,000), it was announced today. The "gap," the excess of imports over exports, rose from 39,300,000 ($110,000,000) in October to 49,300,000 ($1,380,400,000).

WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 -Senator Stephen M. Young today called a group of Ohio American Legion members "loud-mouthed, publicity-seeking, professional veterans" for saying he planned to address a "Communist front" organization in New York."
LONDON, Dec. 10 -- A Government advisory council reported today that the education provided for the great mass of children in England was inadequate in quality and too short in duration.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 -- The White House announced today he appointment of James H. Douglas, Secretary of the Air Force, as Deputy Secretary of Defense.

Duke Ellington's orchestra, which has been heard in concert by itself in New York infrequently in recent years, was provided with one of these rare opportunities last night at the Hunter College Assembly Hall. Unfortunately Mr. Ellington chose a program of dog-eared, unadventurous selections for the occasion.

MANILA, Dec. 10 (AP) -- The Philippines today reacted sharply and officially for the first time to mounting criticism of its "Filipino First" economic policy and the charge that it was hostile to foreign business.
SYRACUSE, N. Y., Dec. 10 -A state-wide conference on water resources was urged here today to start planning now on a "long-range, unified, multipurpose" basis for rapidly growing water needs.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 -- The Senate Antitrust Subcommittee sought to show today that Merck Co., one of the leading pharmaceutical houses, had resorted to misleading advertising to promote a new antiarthritic drug.
Dentists with offices in the heart of New York may be ordered to install lead wall shielding as a protection against radiation from X-ray machines.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 -The International Bank for Reconstruction and Development is making plans to send observers from three countries to India and Pakistan to survey economic needs.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 (AP) -- President Eisenhower issued a proclamation today which will result in cutting oil imports to the West Coast.
Miles F. York, president of the Atlantic Mutual Insurance Company and the Centennial Insurance Company, was re-elected president of the American Institute of Marine Underwriters yesterday.
ALL the things that drawings have been called -the "chamber music of the arts" and the "probity of art" among them -- can be tested this holiday season in an unusually rich group of exhibitions.

SUVA, Fiji Islands, Dec. 10 (UPI) -- Rioting Fiji Islanders, shouting "down with whites!", smashed property and stoned Europeans' cars in this British Pacific colony today before being subdued by troops and an appeal from a union leader.
TOKYO, Dec. 10 -- More than 300 Koreans left tonight for a new life in the Communist half of their native land.

SAINT-LOUIS, Senegal Republic, Dec. 10 -- President Charles de Gaulle foreshadowed the transformation of the French Community into a much looser commonwealth in a series of speeches he made today here and in Nouakchott, the capital of neighboring Mauritania.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 10 -- At the Government Printing Office in Pakarta Indonesia one-third of its available modern printing equipment stands idle for lack of personnel sufficiently skilled to operate it. Yet communication through printed material is needed to keep the population informed through-out the country's 3,000 Island.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 -Members of the Federal Communications Commission were told to their faces today that appointments to that regulatory agency should not be based on politics, but upon evidence of "proven integrity, high intelligence and distinguished public service."

Since the New York Giants already have clinched the Eastern Conference title in the National Football League, their coaches are on guard against a letdown in Sunday's contest with the Redskins in Washington.

WAY back in 1972, when Maud I was Queen of England and the Benevolent party had long had everybody and everything under firm control, a ditch-digger named Cibber Brown went rabbit hunting in a copse near the ruins of Glastonbury Cathedral.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Sir Julian Huxley's discussion of evolution, especially in its bearing upon religious belief, at the Chicago Darwin Commemoration (New York Times, "Quotation of the Day," Nov. 27) can hardly be regarded as novel or newsworthy.

EAST MEADOW, L. I., Dec. 10 -- A former high school history teacher who is serving a six-month sentence on a narcotics charge is teaching a group of youngsters in a pilot educational program at the Nassau County jail.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 -Secretary of State Christian A. Herter gave little hope today for improved relations with Cuba, but indicated that talks with Panama were going well.

The bond market put on a show yesterday little different from those in recent trading sessions. As the years draws to a close, investors seem to be more considered with making adjustments in portfolios for tax purposes than with shopping for new merchandise.

Eugene Picker, president of Loew's Theatres, Inc., has offered to take a reduction of 15,000 shares in the 50,000 granted him by the board under the stock option plan. His decision followed criticism of the plan, which was presented to stockholders at the first annual meeting here yesterday The theatre chain was separated last march from the motion picture-producing Loew's, Inc.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 -The Government announced agreement today with the drug and poultry industries to halt the production and sale of chickens treated with a cancerinducing hormone.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 -The Food and Drug Administration warned today that claims that certain fats and oils would reduce blood cholesterol were "false and misleading."

NEW DELHI, India, Friday, Dec. 11 (AP) -- President Eisenhower started his third day in New Delhi today by telling the men and women of the United States Embassy staff to work for better relations in all contacts with foreign countries.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 -Kevin McCann is back at his White House ghost-writing job for still another temporary assignment, which makes him the most durable of all the speech writers President Eisenhower has tried.
BONN, Germany, Dec. 10 -Chancellor Konrad Adenauer and his press chief, Felix von Eckardt, were rediscovering today the dangers of an open microphone.
STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Dec. 10 -- Four Americans, a Czech and an Italian received Nobel prizes here today in a glittering ceremony whose traditional solemnity was broken by laughter.
Mike Fleischer, Hunter College's basketball coach, calls his team "a second-half-of-theyear club that should get better as we go along."

NEWARK, Dec. 10 -- A Newark lawyer disclosed tonight that he had recently won a case in the Federal Tax Court permitting him to deduct the costs of transportation and lodging for two winters in Florida as medical expenses from his Federal income tax return.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 10 -The United States Circuit Court of Appeals, in a 2-to-1 decision, upheld today the $852,074 damage verdict awarded the trucking industry in a five-year legal battle against twenty-four Eastern railroads.

TRENTON, Dec. 10 (AP) -- People who want to start small business investment companies in New Jersey will have to get their charters from the Federal Government, the State Attorney General's Office ruled today.

DALLAS, Dec. 10 (UPI) -Joe Foss, Commissioner of the new American Football League, showed up in Dallas today to try to set up commission headquarters and announced he planned to ask for meetings with his counterparts in the National and Canadian football leagues.
The New York World's Fair of 1964 Corporation announced at a meeting yesterday that it was seeking a full-time, paid president of the fair.
DETROIT, Dec. 10 (AP) -The Chrysler Corporation announced today that it would resume production of all car and truck lines next week.
Dr. John J. Theobald, the Superintendent of Schools, said yesterday that he was considering requesting "in the neighborhood of $25,000,000" for pay rises for teachers and other school employes.
A top American Communist yesterday placed President Eisenhower and Premier Khrushchev on a par as symbols of "the thaw in the 'cold war' and of peace."
NEW DELHI, India, Dec. 10 (AP) -- The Indian Government called in thousands of extra policemen from areas near New Delhi today to help keep future Eisenhower admiring crowds under control.
JERSEY CITY, Dec. 10 -Two shotgun blasts tonight interrupted a meeting of antiHoffa teamster members in the basement of a private home. The pellets riddled garage doors but no one was injured.

CHICAGO, Dec. 10 (AP) -The Journal of the American Medical Association said today that there was insufficient evidence "to warrant the assumption" that cigarette smoking was the principal factor in the increase in lung cancer.
A new exception to rules governing outside employment by Fire Department officers was announced yesterday by Fire Commissioner Edward F. Cavanagh Jr.

LULUABOURG, Belgian Congo, Dec. 10 -- The latest outbreak of warfare between the Lulua Baluba tribes has left a toll of seventeen dead, sixty wounded, many burned-out huts and streams of fearful refugees.

HAVANA, Dec. 10 - Austin Frank Young, the American flier who escaped from prison yesterday, was recaptured here this afternoon. He was sentenced to thirty years' imprisonment by a military court in Pinar del Rio Tuesday.
The Silver Cross Day Nursery at 451 East 120th Street will receive the proceeds of the Christmas Ball, which will be held at the Waldorf-Astoria this evening.
CORNWALL, Conn., Dec. 10 (AP) -- A research balloon released in Akron, Ohio, yesterday dropped a parachute bearing a gondola with radar and photographic equipment on this community last night.

GOTEBORG, Sweden, Dec. 10 (UPI) -- Edwin Ahlguist, Ingemar Johansson's adviser, today warned American boxing groups interested in a Johansson-Floyd Patterson rematch to "clean up the situation quickly."

The Lesnor-Maehr Marine Company of Floral Park, L. I., has developed a new variablepitch propeller for outboard motors that it guarantees will cut trolling speed in half. With the new propeller, a fisherman can get the exact speed needed for the best trolling and still have his motor running fast enough for smooth operation, the firm claims.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 10 (AP) A rookie. Bob Ferry, and the seasoned Cliff Hagan sparked the St. Louis Hawks to a 129-111 victory over the Detroit Pistons tonight in the first game of a National Basketball Association doubledeader.
Opposition to much of Governor Rockefeller's proposed highway safety legislation was voiced yesterday by the New York State Automobile Association.

The state inquiry into this city's affairs was urged yesterday to recommend the ending of sweatshop conditions to help save $100,000,000 a year in the city budget. The appeal was made by I. D. Robbins, president of the City Club of New York.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 (AP) -- The Department of Agriculture estimated this season's citrus fruit crop at 194,895,000 boxes today. This was compared to 190,460,000 boxes last season and 175,291,000 for the ten-year average.

NEWPORT, England, Dec. 10 (Reuters) -- A British subsidiary of an American concern, BlackClawson International, has received an order for more than 4,000,000 ($11,200,000) from Russia for the construction of two high-speed newsprint machines, it was announced today.
The nation's third largest defense contractor is little concerned about cuts in military expenditures.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 -The chairman of a Senate investigating panel charged today that the Government's patent policies were creating monopolies at tremendous cost to taxpayers.

A subway token seller who had twice before fought off hold-up men was shot dead last night in his booth at the 109th Street entrance to the IND station at 110th Street and Central Park West. No money was taken.
The 15,000 Tibetan refugees in India are in good physical condition but will need help for a long time, Dr. Walter H. Judd, Republican Representative from Minnesota, said yesterday.
Three major banks here yesterday announced the election of officers.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 -Following is the State Department's transcript of Secretary of State Christian A. Herter's news conference today:

AN appetite-teasing booklet called "Frankly Fancy Foods" recently emerged from the Bettty Crocker kitchens. It should prove of great value to the would-be hostess planning anything from a stand-up party to candlelight suppers. Useful hints are given on what to serve, how to prevent gaps in proceedings while attending to last minute preparations, and even how to arrange the furniture.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 (AP) -- The Republican National Committee branded as "preposterous" today the 1960 program adopted last week by the Democratic Advisory Council.

Record net earnings of $3,938,-717 for the fiscal year ended on Sept. 30 and the highest sales for any peacetime year were reported yesterday by the Emerson Electric Manufacturing Company in its sixty-ninth annual statement.

Trading was light and featureless yesterday on the New York commodity futures exchanges. Prices moved in narrow ranges. The markets closed irregular. Rubber and zinc rose; potatoes, hides and sugar declined, and price movements for copper, coffee, cocoa, cottonseed oil, wool and lead were mixed.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 -- The national secretariat of the country's Roman Catholic Bishops questioned today whether the United States had "done all within our power to aid the homeless and the hungry" of other nations.
Edward O. Reid, a staff lawyer for the Securities and Exchange Commission, jumped or fell to his death yesterday from the twenty-third floor offices of the agency at 225 Broadway.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 -Federal mediators suspended today their efforts to make peace between the United Steelworkers of America and the steel industry.

BRUSSELS, Belgium, Dec. 10 -- A resolution submitted today to the International Confederation of Free Trade Unions urged that practical steps, including boycott measures, be taken to combat the regime of Generalissimo Rafael Leonides Trujillo Molina of the Dominican Republic.

Control of one of the most modern and largest fleets of specialized bulk carriers in the world was obtained by three Norwegian ship operators from an American company without a down payment, a Federal Maritime Board examiner was told yesterday.
Barnard College trustees have approved a $240 tuition increase and a general improvement of faculty salaries for the 1960-61 academic year.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 (AP) -- A former Ambassador said today that pinch-penny entertainment allowances were causing United States diplomats to lose face abroad.
Operators of the big New York State-owned Whiteface Mountain area in Wilmington were preparing for their first big week-end of the skiing season yesterday.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 10 -- The General Assembly postponed today until tomorrow afternoon its scheduled discussion of Algeria, pending the introduction of a compromise resolution.
Messages to the Neediest Cases scrawled in large, wavering letters came yesterday from children barely old enough to write.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Dec. 10 -- One of the axioms of Hollywood -- that contract negotiations with stars are, like love, rarely smooth -- has just been violated by Ingrid Bergman.

GLEN RIDGE, N. J., Dec. 10 -- This morning Robert Brown, a senior, sat in a classroom at Glen Ridge High School and by telephone talked for forty minutes with an investment bankers in his Wall Street office.
NEW DELHI, India, Dec. 10 -- In the new age of suitcase diplomacy, you tell the score with an applause meter.

NOUAKCHOTT, Mauritanian Republic, Dec. 10 -- This new desert capital of the Islamic Republic of Mauritania welcomed President de Gaulle today with Saharan splendor Although the town has a population of only 100 permanent inhabitants, more than 5,000 Moorish nomads gathered to see the French President.

Market demand for common stock of the Transitron Electronic Corporation carried the price of the shares up to $49 in the over-the-counter market yesterday at the same time that investment bankers were offering 1,000,000 shares at $36 each.

GENEVA, Dec. 10 -- Steel production in eighteen countries of Western Europe rose by 3 per cent during the first nine months of this year, to total 67,400,000 metric tons, the United Nations Economic Commission for Europe reported today.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 (UPI) -- House investigators were told today that some major oil companies "steadily but surely are making a captive business" of the sale of tires, batteries and automobile accessories by dictating terms to filling stations.
OTTAWA, Dec. 10 (Canadian Press) -- The interest rate of the Bank of Canada rose to 5.27 per cent today from 5.18 last week with the sale of $100,000,000 in 91-day Treasury bills.
The Province of Alberta, Canada, borrowed $20,000,000 in the United States yesterday to finance the growth of provincial communities.

Awards to twenty-eight organizations and individuals for their participation in the city's recent "Salute to Fall" were given out at City Hall yesterday. Deputy Mayor Paul T. O'keefe made the presentations.
The defense in the Apalachin trial rested its case yesterday. None of the twenty men charged with lying to the Government about the 1957 upstate gathering took the stand.

WARSAW, Dec. 10 (AP) -Trybuna Ludu, the newspaper of Poland's Communist party, said today that reports in The New York Times on Poland showed "a willful tendency to disturb the relations between Poland and the United States."

The autobiography of Paul B. Magnusen, widely known as an orthopedic surgeon will be published Jan. 21 by Little, Brown. It will becalled "Ring the Night Bell." The author was chosen to prepare a report on the nation's health for President Truman.

NEW DELHI, India, Friday, Dec. 11 -- President Eisenhower told the Indian Parliament yesterday that the armed forces of the United States were prepared to defend its friends and allies against aggression.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: In his letter published Dec. 7 on Tippers Anonymous, E. Sarni Zucca argues that tips should be generous when service is poor on the grounds that it is unfair to rob waiters of an essential part of their income and that waiters cannot help it if a restaurant is at sixes and sevens.
The C. I. T. Financial Corporation is planning to raise $75,000,000 in the bond market next month on long-term debentures.

Check transactions of $24,748,968,000 in the week ended on Wednesday were 3.3 per cent higher than in the week before, which included Thankgiving. In that week the total was $23,954,725,000. Dun Bradstreet, Inc. reported yesterday. The latest figure was 14.1 per cent above the $21,689,127,000 turn over for the similar week of last year.

THE New York City Ballet pulled a little surprise on us last night at the City Center. Though a restoration to the repertory of Lew Christensen's "Con Amore" after a considerable absence was duly scheduled, there was no advance indication that it would reappear in such a lively reincarnation.
AN hour of captivating folk music was provided last night on Channel 2 by Harry Belafonte and a company of singers, dancers and musicians.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 10 -- Cuba's Foreign Minister said today that his government would be willing to discuss with the United States the amount of compensation for expropriated American-owned land.

ONE morning each week, Mrs. Graham Madison, whose six children attend private schools, journeys to Public School 129, on the edge of Harlem, to teach French songs and games to second, third and fifth graders.

Bert Harmon and Al Feit, realty investors, have bought the six-story apartment house on lot 28 by 100 feet at 1008 Fifth Avenue, adjoining the southeast corner of Eighty-second Street. The buyers paid cash over mortgages amounting to $200,000. They plan to renovate the building. The brokers were Robert P. Sheldon, Inc., Carl Silverman and John Blesch.
A HISTORICAL footnote was forged into a forceful historical drama on Channel 2's "Playhouse 90" last night.
For the man who has everything, what possible gifts remain? One, surely: the privilege of giving. And there are many, many gifts to be given.

The wholehearted approval of the city's proposed zoning resolution by local architects yesterday points up a basic difference approach to the problem of regulating the physical development of New York.
Directors of the New York Central Railroad voted yesterday to pay stockholders a dividend of twenty-five cents a share on Jan. 25, 1960. The payment will be made to holders of record of Dec. 28.

LONDON, Dec. 10 -- Industrial shares continued to advance on the stock market here today in most of principal sections. Gains on balance were small but some of the blue chips rose 1s. 6d. (21 cents) to 2 shillings (28 cents).
A lawyer who has won appeals on convictions for housing violations and a verdict of $9,000 for false imprisonment was back in Housing Court Yesterday.

Money is easier at the large New York City banks. In the week ended on Wednesday, the: fifteen weekly reporting member banks in the city were able to reduce their average net borrowings to zero, according to figures published yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.
ONE of the rarest plays in bridge, perhaps the rarest, is the one called in bridge literature the "smother play."
Private sanitation men voted unanimously last night to ratify a two-year contract with wage increases of $6 and $8 a week.

CHICAGO, Dec. 10 -- Billy Golembiewski, a slim Detroit bowler who is one of the stars of the Pfeiffer team, held his first-place spot by a narrow margin in the third annual world invitation bowling tournament at the Coliseum tonight.
Seton Hall and Iona played host to college fives from distant parts at Madison Square Garden last night. Both local entries went down to defeat and disappointed many of the 6.230 fans.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 (AP) -- The American Civil Liberties Union today urged the F. C. C. to ask Congress for authority to regulate radio and TV networks.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: It is entirely welcome that the subject of birth control -- of crucial importance for the future of mankind -- should at last be frankly discussed. That it divides the Catholic Church from other denominations and philosophies is deeply to be regretted. Yet it is not impossible that an open discussion of the issues, based on respect for different beliefs, will be of some help.
The warm reds and yellows of Spain's Goya period were used in the decor of the Grand Ballroom of the Astor last night for the Imperial Ball.

The Syracuse Nationals, who knocked the New York Knickerbockers out of the Eastern after losing nine straight reguDivisions play-off last year lar season games to them, will face the Knicks tonight at Madison Square Garden.
The manufacture and sale of anquilizers by drug concerns under investigation by a Federal grand jury here for possible violations of the antitrust laws.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 (UPI) -- The International Cotton Advisory Committee predicted today "a marked increase" in world cotton trade this season.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 -- The Defense Department confirmed today that a United States Army combat team would be withdrawn from Iceland in the first six months of 1960.
The citizens' transit mediation committee went to work yesterday to try to avert a New Year's Day strike on city-owned subway and bus lines.
ALBANY, Dec. 10 (AP) -- Education Commissioner James] E. Allen Jr. today designated] Desc. 13-20 as Bill of RightsI Veek in New York State] schools.
Heavy construction awards 000, from $383,400,000 the week before and compared with $353,300,000 in the 1958 period, The Engineering News-Record reported yesterday.
A college professor told Democratic party leaders and lawmakers yesterday that tri-state legislation was needed to relieve the metropolitan transportation muddle.

The U. N. General Assembly's vote on Hungary on Wednesday was a test of Soviet Russia's attitude toward what Moscow likes to call "the spirit of Camp David." The Russians seemingly stand where they stood three years ago when they crushed a popular revolution in Hungary and set up a contemptible puppet government of their own.
Arthur Godfrey's second television show of the season, which had been scheduled tentatively for Jan. 15, has been postponed. No other date has been set.
TEHERAN, Iran, Dec. 9 -- In his first interview since leaving the hospital Premier Abdul Karim Kassim of Iraq revealed more about himself yesterday than about his policies.

CHICAGO, Dec. 10 (UPI) -The Big Ten will ask the National Collegiate football rules committee to reinstate free substitution for the 1960 season, coaches and athletic directors agreed today at the opening of the Conference's winter meeting.
SEBRING, Fla., Dec. 10 (AP) -- Tuning up for Saturday's world championship Grand Prix of the United States, the world's greatest road-racing drivers showed Sebring fans dazzling speeds today.
The city's 1,700 organized architects gave their enthusiastic support yesterday to the zoning resolution being considered by the City Planning Commission.
BRUSSELS, Belgium, Dec. 10 -- Douglas Dillon, Under Secretary of State, opposed today any solution of Europe's trade problems that would hamper a developing political unity of the continent.

CHICAGO, Dec. 10 (UPI) -Negotiators for the United Steelworkers Union and the Aluminum Company of America, traditional bellwether of the aluminum industry, debated seniority clauses today and postponed talks on money matters.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 -Secretary of State Christian A. Herter said today that President Eisenhower's threecontinent tour thus far had "exceeded our greatest expectations."
IF Peck Peck piped music into all their stores this month, shoppers would be serenaded by sambas not Christmas carols.
Vincent J. Velella, the lawyer, who was a central figure in the promotion of the heavyweight championship match last June, was indicted yesterday for perjury.

An inspector of the Bureau of Weights and Measures in the Department of Markets was dismissed yesterday after he had refused to sign a waiver of immunity before a Brooklyn grand jury. The jury has been investigating short-weight sales in meat stores and other retail outlets.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 -Railroad and truck loadings of freight rose last week largely because the preceding week's loadings had been reduced by the Thanksgiving Holiday.

With a forehandedness unusual as it is commendable in this city's perennial transit crises Mayor Wagner has appointed a citizens' committee of mediation to deal with the year-end expiration of contract between the Transit Authority and the unions. While the committee does not have jurisdiction over a similar dispute involving privately owned bus lines, the two problems march together and a settlement in one invariably affects the other.
The holiday season brings out the "meeting" instinct in many advertising men.
The Aeolian-Skinner organ being built for Philharmonic Hall at the Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts will have 5,498 pipes, ranging from thirtytwo feet to a fraction of an inch in length.
Cinerama, Inc., has leased the thirty-fifth, or top, floor in the new building at 575 Lexington Avenue, at a corner of Fifty-first Street, from Sam Minskoff Sons, the builders and owners.

MUSHROOMS are still reversing the trend associated with their name, having dropped another 6 cents a pound. They are in good supply and, if you shop around, can be purchased for as low as 40 cents a pound.
The Joint Distribution Committee yesterday adopted a budget of $29,142,000 to carry out its programs of aid next year among 250,000 Jewish men, women and children in twentyfive countries and Israel.

GREEN RIVER, Vt., Dec. 10 -- A hunter who gets turned around a little in this region, or doesn't count his steps, may wind up in the wrong state. If he doesn't know it, and shoots a deer at the wrong moment, he may be in deep trouble.
Christmas shoppers looking for bargains in perfume may be defrauded, the Better Business Bureau warned yesterday.

Herbert Ravka was the broker in the recent sale of the block-front on the east side of Broadway from Thirty-first to Thirty-second Street to Ben Kaufman and Nathan P. Jacobs. The site will be improved with and office and showroom building containing a basement garage.

Mrs. J. Horton Ijams, chairman of the benefit committee, has announced that the Federation of Protestant Welfare Agencies will be the beneficiary of the Jan. 19 performance of the Moscow State Orchestra at Carnegie Hall. A Tchaikovsky program will be played.
ENDICOTT, N. Y., Dec. 10 -Should Santa Claus be arrested? That was a question here until today.
Improvement of Buttermilk Channel beyond the scope of a current Federal project was urged here yesterday by maritime interests.

Once again, as for the last dozen years, and by the same overwhelming majority against only Communist opposition, the United Nations General Assembly calls on the "Communist authorities" to agree to the creation of a "unified, independent and democratic Korea" by means of genuinely free elections under United Nations supervision. This has always been the objective of the United Nations.

IBADAN, Nigeria, Dec. 10 -A chief apprehension about the impending independence of Nigeria is that the vast West African country of 35,000,000 will fall apart after the British yield sovereign power to the new Federal Government Oct. 1, 1960, is the date set for Nigerian freedom.

The Bible, in historical and artistic perspective, will go on exhibition in the form of printed books, manuscripts and illustrations next Tuesday at the Pierpont Morgan Library, 29 East Thirty-sixth Street.

PITTSBURGH, Dec. 11 (AP) -- The University of Pittsburgh and Duquesne University basketball teams whittled the annual Steel Bowl down to a strictly hometown affair tonight.

OVERCOOKING green vegetables is a sin -- and most homemakers are guilty of it. Not only does it destroy many of the vitamins, it also mars both flavor and texture.

IN rubber bridge the first object of play is to get a plus score. There is seldom a case in which declarer should risk his contract, or a defender should delay taking the setting trick, in the hope of winning one trick more.

MOUNT VERNON, N. Y., Dec. 11 -- Dr. James E. Allen Jr., State Commissioner of Education, today refused to interfere with this city's referendum next Wednesday on a Board of Education proposal to issue thirty-year bonds for a new high school.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 11 (AP) -- A political science professor suggested today that the Government provide millions of dollars to find out what people really wanted to see on television, and what raised or lowered standards of taste.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange rose 5 to 18 points, with July showing the most strength. A point is equal to 5 cents a bale.

WEARY Christmas shopper will find a welcome relie at Hammacher Schlemmer this holiday season. On the men floor between 12:30 and 5:30 P. CHICAGO, Dec. 11--The Republican National Committee mapped an intensive big-budget campaign today to win control of the House of Representatives. The committee plans to use the theme of "Prosperity and Peace."

WASHINGTON, Dec. 11 -- The number of Americans holding jobs in November declined by 1,191,000 compared with the preceding month. This drop was slightly greater than usual for the month. Even so, the total of 65,640,000 with jobs was the highest for any November.

THE most accomplished actor who ever played a royal part is the subject of "Louis XIV: An Informal Portrait," by W. H. Lewis. The book is written with a spare, dry skill. It makes an entertaining contribution to the great world of the theatrical arts.
NEW DELHI, India, Dec. 11 -President Eisenhower appealed today for a "world-wide war against hunger."
TRENTON, Dec. 11 -- The New York, Susquehanna and Western Railroad asked the State Public Utility Commission today for permission to end all its passenger service in New Jersey.

An Old Custom The lighting of the towering Christmas tree in Rockefeller Center, an annual spectacle witnessed by thousands, serves to remind us that it was here in New York in 1912, in Madison Square, that the city's first illuminated Christmas tree was erected. On the Common at Boston a similar community tree was lighted for the first time that Christmas season. Philadelphia erected its first lighted community tree in Independence Square in 1914.

IT has become a habit with many people to toss down a tiny glass of orange juice each morning, in the belief that this will take care of their vitamin C for the day. Others are even more optimistic, assuming that their need for the vitamin will be filled one way or another among the foods they consume.

The Yankees finally broke the trading barrier yesterday and no one need more than a single guess to name the party of the second part. Those obliging Kansas City Athletics have come through again this time in a seven-player transaction.

The Navy's Military Sea Transportation Service, the world-wide shipping agency for the armed forces, announced in Washington yesterday that it would retire six Governmentowned T-2 tankers and replace them with five American flag T-2 tankers chartered from private owners.

LONDON, Dec. 11 -- Shares on the stock exchange here finished a good week on a satisfactory note with prices in industrial sections hitting a new high for the third consecutive day. The names of the largest recent purchasers of gold from the United States' slowly declining stockpile were revealed yesterday by the Government. Great Britain bought $150,000,000 in the third quarter, more than any other.

Secretary Herter leaves today for Paris to attend a ministerial conference of the North Atlantic alliance which will prepare the ground for the Western summit meeting. On at least one vital issue this preliminary conference is likely to prove decisive.

Joe Foss, the commissioner of the new American Football League, said yesterday he expected bids "up to $2,500,000" for television rights to his league's games next season.

COLOR in the fireplace is just a matter of the right chemicals, an easy formula and simple preparation, according to Phil Mikoda of the Ansco Camera Club. Chemically treated material is thrown into the fire where it burns in flames of bright red, green and blue, providing enough colored light for exposures of 1/10th at f/3.5 of 1/25 at f/2 on Super Anscochrome.

CHRISTMAS is the Christian 'churches' Feast of the Nativity, but the exact day -- and even year -- of Jesus Christ's birth is unknown. Originally, the Nativity and Epiphany (the adoration of the Magi, or Twelfth Night) were celebrated together. It was not until the fourth century that the church fathers in Rome began to celebrate Christmas (the mass of Christ) on Dec. 25.
ASPEN, Colo., Dec. 12 -- Wallace (Bud) Werner of Steamboat Springs, Colo., America's best hope for skiing honors in the 1960 Winter Olympics, suffered a broken left leg today at the Aspen Ski Area.

Lee D. Witkin's complaint in The Times of Nov. 8 that the television performances of Teresa Wright and Patty McCormack in "The Miracle Worker" have been relatively ignored in the face of the Anne Bancroft-Patty Duke Broadway triumphs is, unfortunately, quite true.
Fordham's last-minute rally failed last night and the Rams were defeated by Rhode Island, 79 -- 77, before 2,000 fans at the loser's court in the Bronx.
THE Piccolo Teatvo di Milano no longer is in the same class with the weather. Someone has done something about Piccolo.

Aptitude tests have been found valuable in showing a person's ability to prepare for an occupation, but they cannot predict his success or satisfaction on the job.
LONDON, Dec. 10 -- The four British rocket bases are now in a state of "readiness" and will be formally declared operational in the near future.
Pan American World Airways confirmed last week that it was combining two of its three geographic operating divisions to meet the requirements of jet operations.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 12 -- The General Assembly adopted unanimously tonight a resolution under which the United Nations will make a fresh start in its efforts to encourage and regulate the peaceful uses of outer space.

In the view of seven qualified Wall Street analysts, the first quarter of 1960 will be a period of no great danger for investors. The bullish influences will remain strong. But most of them add a qualifying "however . . ."

TODAY'S theatregoer may choose a show because of its star, author, director, choreographer or composer, but it is rare that his choice will be made because of the man who once was a major audience draw -- the producer.

Dr. Allan DuMont of Cedar Grove, N. J., was the center of attention at last week's dinner and meeting of the Eastern Cruiser Association in the Shelburne Hotel. The television expert, who is expert in predicted log racing, too, received three major prizes for successes in his avocation.

A woman clerk in a subway change booth was robbed in a Brooklyn station early yesterday morning by a husky hold-up man. He then forced her to walk to an alley six blocks away where he raped and kicked her.

The old principle that politics and education don't mix is on its way into the scrapbook of memories. Politics and education are getting intricately mixed up with each other, and politicians as well as political columnists seem agreed that educational policies will, and should, play an important part in future national campaigns.

People don't like bills, as a rule, but the crisp new bills that banks make available for Christmas gifts are welcomed by everybody. This year, the banks may supply a record number to their customers for this purpose.
ALBERT LEA, Minn., Dec. 12 (AP) -- Action in the protracted labor dispute at the strike-bound Wilson Co. packing plant will shift to the courtroom Monday.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, Sunday, Dec. 13 -- Indonesia angrily struck back at Communist China today by rejecting both Peiping's protest and "false accusations" stemming from the bitter controversy over Chinese aliens in Indonesia.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 12 (UPI) -- The House Veterans Affairs Committee said today the big question facing it next year was whether the Government should provide scholarships to veterans of the 'cold war."
TOKYO, Dec. 5 -- Leading Japanese makers of electric machinery, who have grown with sales of transistor radios, are competing strenuously in making other new electrical products.
MOSCOW, Dec. 12 (AP) -- Premier Khrushchev has called for electrification of the entire Soviet Union within twenty years as part of the country's long-range plan for economic development.
The Yale Ball, a fixture of the Christmas social season for students and graduates in Central New Jersey for more than twenty years, will take place Friday in the Canoe Brook Country Club in Summit.
WEST POINT, N. Y., Dec. 12 -- Five of Army's winter sports teams scored a clean sweep on the home front today.

Some residents in Douglaston, Queens, are planning a last-ditch campaign to turn the marshlands of Alley Park extension into a waterfront recreational area.
SOUTH BEND, Ind. Dec. 12 -- Governor Rockefeller called today for compulsory arbitration of labor disputes that endangered the health, welfare and safety of the nation.

BRUSSELS, Belgium, Dec. 12 -- Delegates to the congress of the International Confederation of Free Trade Unions headed home from their tenth anniversary meeting today uncertain about the future leadership and policy of the world alliance of non-Communist labor organizations.
IVY BLUFF, N. C., Dec. 12 (AP) -- Only three convicts remained at large today, five days after they and seventeen other felons escaped from North Carolina's Ivy Bluff Prison.

LABOR negotiations that may be among the most critical in motion-picture history are scheduled to begin here tomorrow. The Screen Actors Guild is to meet with representatives of the with major movie studios to discuss the renewal of contracts that expire at the end of next month.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sunday, Dec. 13 -- The General Assembly endorsed an East-West compromise this morning by electing Poland to a two-year term on the Security Council.
A service station in Deer Park, L. I., last week called a tire dealer a few miles away and ordered six snow tires and two 13-inch tires for passenger cars.

TO listen to the television critics, the only thing that "C. B. S. Reports" failed to do in its first two ventures was to get the space vehicle into orbit in "Biography of a Missile," which launched the series last Oct. 27.
CHICAGO, Dec. 12 -- An effort to block a proposed integrated housing development in suburban Deerfield by buying up the property was resisted this week.
HOLLY groves in the Pacific Northwest are busy places these days. Growers are cutting and packing the bright-berried branches for shipment south and eastward.

Recording the weekly news review from the Sunday edition of The New York Times, beginning Jan. 3, will be the largest project undertaken by Recording for the Blind, Inc., since its organization in 1951.

PITTSBURGH, Dec. 12 (AP) -- The president of the United Steelworkers of America said today that the union's agreement with the Kaiser Steel Corporation was "proof reasonable men can find solutions to problems through free bargaining."

Khrushchev's sensational confession made at the Ganz factory in Budapest, reported in your issue of Dec. 3, is a striking conformation of the findings of the U. N. FOR the romantic-minded -- which includes the young of all ages -- there is always a place for another "people's knight-errant" who leads his outlawed followers in the name of liberty, not plunder. Such a one is Stenka (Little Stephen) Razin, the huge Cossack hero of Harold Lamb's exciting book.
The Obernkirchen Children's Choir, under the direction of Edith Moeller, exerted its usual spell on a capacity audience at Town Hall yesterday afternoon.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 12 -- The time-honored ploy of statesmen and diplomats, "I once was a newspaper man myself," rang more frequently than usual in the United Nations' halls during the last few days Members of the working press show a conditioned reflex of wincing whenever they hear the all-too-familiar phrase, because more often than not it is used to withhold information or to "plant" the wrong kind.
A committee on public finance of the state Democratic organization recommended this week-end that state aid to education be increased $190,000,000 for the 1960-61 fiscal year.

MOSCOW, Dec., 12 -- The official newspaper of the Union of Writers in the Soviet published in full today a letter from Charles Neider, American author, protesting its criticism of his editing of the "Autobiography of Mark Twain."

NEW DELHI, India, Dec. 12 -- If it achieves nothing else President Eisenhower's journey to the far side of the planet has already proved that the American Presidency is not only the most mobile office on earth but also the focus of the non-Communist world's aspirations.

NEW DELHI, India, Sunday, Dec. 13 -- A huge cross-section of Indian society swelled and shoved over carefully trimmed lawns yesterday for a glimpse of President Eisenhower on his "pilgrimage in quest of peace."

JACKSONVILLE, Fla., Dec. 12 -- Miss Waldo Latham, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Rhydon Call Latham, was married this afternoon to Richard Christopher Craven. He is the son of Mrs. Richard Harrity of 535 East Seventy-second Street. New York. and Thomas Craven of Martha's Vineyard, Mass.

After spending the past five years in India, Dr. Marie Finger Bale of the Methodist Board of Missions recently remarked that there might be fewer divorces in the United States if we borrowed a little from Indian customs. Divorce is almost unknown in India, she said, because parents select their children's mates and continue to control their sons' and daughters' lives after marriage.

GOOD little gardeners can look forward to a rewarding crop of Christmas gifts this year. There are many entertaining toys, games, gadgets and kits that will foster youthful interest in plants and flowers and how they grow.

WARS no longer seem glamorous to the participants -- if indeed they ever did. The war has to be suitably remote in time before a gifted novelist can see (or make us see) glory in disciplined butchery and splendid pageantry in a cavalry charge.

The annual military ceremony dedicating and lighting Park Avenue's thirty memorial Christmas trees will be held today at 6 P. M. at the portico of the Brick Presbyterian Church, Park Avenue and Ninety-first Street.

BOSTON, Dec. 12 -- The Ranger goalie, Marcel Paille, shook off a twelve-stitch facial cut tonight and returnsd to help pace New York to a 4-3 victory over the Boston Bruins. The Blues' center, Red Sullivan, supplied the winning goal with less than two minutes remaining.

BEIDA, Libya, Dec. 1 -- The United Kingdom of Libya, which already has two capitals, s building a third here.

Frank J. Kaps plainly contradicts himself and convicts himself in his letter on the Bronx River Parkway printed in The Times of Nov. 29. He says, "I am not a lawbreaker," after admitting he was doing fifty-three miles per hour in a forty-mile zone.

President Eisenhower set out upon his epochal journey with two main objectives. The other was a practical diplomatic objective -- to achieve a reaffirmation of Western unity on allied relations and on the approach to the Russians at the summit.

Retailers are watching their toy departments to see what the 1959 volume will be. But manufacturers have practically wiped this year off the calendar. Toy sales over the counter now will have no effect on this year's production, although they may change the outlook for 1960.

PARIS, Dec. 12 -- The British-led Outer Seven trade bloc has decided to establish its headquarters here in the heart of its rival six-nation European Economic Community.

Rheumatic disease is the nation's No. 1 crippler. Approximately 11,000,000 men and women over the age of 14 are suffering from arthritis and rheumatic diseases. The major form of rheumatic disease is rheumatoid arthritis, a systemic progressive disease that is the worst of the rheumatic cripplers. Its cause is unknown and the onset is insidious. There is no specific cure, though it is often possible to control the disease.

In winter Europe fades into the murk. The clouds are low and weepy, or fog shrouds everything, and daylight really lasts only from 9 to 3, as it does these December days in New York. The visitor has to grope for the latchstring, but when the door is flung open there inside is the real Europe, warm and bright.

Business conditions in Pennsylvania during October were mixed, according to the Bureau of Business Research at the Pennsylvania State University. Fire Commissioner Edward F. Cavanagh Jr. disclosed yesterday that he was investigating reports that firemen were accepting gifts from building superintendents on Manhattan's West Side.

The American Veterans Committee has noted your approval of the action taken by the American Legion nationally in ousting the "fun-loving" 40 et 8. We wish to concur in the sentiments expressed by The New York Times. But even at the risk of seeming to appear ungracious we must point out that this action was long overdue.
CINDERFORD, England, Dec. 12 -- What does a British miner think when he finds himself handling a machine in a factory after thirty years in the black tunnels of a colliery?

The story of how a Protestant church in the heart of the city can successfully adjust itself to a rapidly changing urban environment is being told every Sunday at Good Shepherd - Faith Presbyterian Church, 152 Wrest Sixty-sixth Street.
BUENOS AIRES, Dec. 13 (AP) -- Don Jordan, the world welterweight champion, tonight blamed a persistent virus condition for the first knockout loss of his career.

PITTSBURGH, Dec. 13 -- The flow of finished steel to users last week showed a satisfactory and on-schedule pick-up. But demand for steel has jumped so sharply in recent weeks that a tight situation is expected to continue for at least the next six months -- or longer.
NEW DELHI, Dec. 13 (AP) -- Mrs. John S. D. Eisenhower had two scares on a trip to the Indian countryside today. One was amusing, but the other was not.

BOSTON, Dec. 13 -- Soviet competition will be severe for decades to come, "but the Communists are not predestined to win," Justice William O. Douglas of the United States Supreme Court said tonight.

ALBERT LEA, Minn., Dec. 13 (AP -- Gov. Orville L. Freeman announced today that agreement had been reached between Wilson and Company and the striking United Packinghouse Workers Union to resume negotiations "very soon."
CHICAGO, Dec. 13 -- The pressure on Secretary Benson to resign was viewed by some farm leaders today as wholly political and not the result of his policies.

Mayor Wagner declared yesterday that any pay rises the Transit Authority might grant to employes on the city-owned subway and bus lines must be "adjusted" to the 15-cent fare. "I and my administration are committed to the 15-cent fare," he said.
POSADAS, Argentina, Dec. 13 (AP) -- Gunfire across the Parana River indicated today that Paraguayan rebels were holding out in the frontier city of Encarnacion in eastern Paraguay.
NORFOLK, Va., Dec. 13 (AP) -- "Our major problem is not Russia, it is ourselves," the Navy's senior chaplain said today as the service's first permanent Jewish chapel was dedicated here.

PARIS, Dec. 13 -- Informed diplomats said tonight that the United States unwillingness to declare itself had made it virtually certain that a split would develop when the Berlin problem was discussed at the Western summit meeting.

MOTHERS who go Christmas shopping or parents who go partying during the Christmas or New Year's holidays should select their children's sitter with care and in advance. During the holiday season, when the demand for competent help is heavy, the National Board of Fire Underwriters offers some sound suggestions to parents when selecting a baby sitter:
A dollar bill found on a sidewalk in New York was sent to the Neediest Cases yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 13 (UPI) -- D. N. Chatterjee, Indian charge d'affaires, said today that India would accept "hygienic and medical" information on birth control from the United States if it did not embarrass Americans.
NIIGATA, Japan, Dec. 13 -- Repatriates sailing for Communist North Korea tomorrow will carry with them a fair sample of what the free enterprise system produces in Japan for ordinary citizens.
AGRA, India, Dec. 13 -- President Eisenhower momentarily turned from the grim problems of the twentieth century to contemplate an old Emperor's memorial to his beloved Empress.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 13 (AP) -- The chairman of the Republican National Committee said today that Vice President Richard M. Nixon appeared to be well ahead in the race for the party's Presidential nomination.
This is the time of year when some of the East's leading boarding school hockey teams invade the metropolitan area for games at Madison Square Garden and the Hobey Baker Rink at Princeton, N. J.
Samuel Rudin, builder and owner of the new twenty-two-story office building at 355 Lexington Avenue, corner of Fortieth Street, has signed three new tenants to complete renting of the structure.

The Church of St. Mary the Virgin (Anglo-Catholic), celebrated a high mass yesterday in honor of its patron saint. The Rev. Father Joseph, superior of the Anglican Order of St. Francis, preached the guest sermon at the church at 139 West Forty-sixth Street.
More pupils were left back last June in the elementary and junior high schools than ever before as a result of the Board of Education's "get tough" policy.

It was no accident that General Eisenhower chose as a title for his war memoirs "Crusade in Europe." The word "crusade" has particular meaning for him. He has often regretted that the free world seems unable to produce a "crusader" to lead the quest for security and peace.
ST. LOUIS, Dec. 13 -- In the heart of heavily Democratic Missouri, Governor Rockefeller received today one of the warmest welcomes of his accelerating political tour.

TAIPEI, Taiwan, Dec. 13 (AP) -- The first regular shipping service between Taiwan and the United States was inaugurated yesterday with the departure from Keelung, seaport of Taipei, of the 11,000-ton Sam Hai Min.
BRENTWOOD, L. I., Dec. 13 -- The Long Island Lighting Company's huge Brentwood operations center -- a physical indication of the growth of Suffolk County -- will begin full service tomorrow morning.
LARAMDA, India, Dec. 13 -- President Eisenhower saw part of rural India today. He told cheering villagers that he would return some day.
Eight films are slated to arrive in local theatres this week. The programs follow:
TEHERAN, Iran, Monday, Dec. 14 -- Shah Mohammed Riza Pahlevi welcomed President Eisenhower to Iran today as a flight of United States-supplied Iranian Air Force jets spelled out "Ike" overhead.
BAINBRIDGE, Ga., Dec. 13 (AP) -- Six persons were drowned today when a small boat swamped in the Flint River.
NICOOSIA, Cyprus, Monday, Dec. 14 -- Minor clashes between Left and Right-wing factions were reported today as Greek Cypriotes voted to elect a President of the republic that will be formed Feb. 19.

DAKAR, Senegal Republic, Dec. 13 -- President Charles de Gaulle of France entered Dakar, the capital of the soon-to-be independent Federation of Mali, in triumph today. He chose this moment to deliver a shrewd measure of fatherly advice to African nationalists.
ATLANTA, Dec. 13 -- The support of the South, which Senator John F. Kennedy once counted as his own, has been stolen by a band of Texas rustlers.

PARIS, Dec. 13 -- The United States is pushing for early negotiations between Western Europe's two great trading blocs to prevent economic and political rivalry dangerous to the interests of the United States and the non-Communist world.

Alf Pike, the New York Rangers' coach, said the other day the Blues had to beat the Boston Bruins consistently to make the Stanley Cup play-offs. Last night at Madison Square Garden Pike's determined Blues made their shots count as they downed the Bruins for the second straight night by the same score, 4 -- 3.

Students participating in yesterday's New York Times Youth Forum agreed that the non-Communist world had a large stake in India's future and that President Eisehower's visit to that country would have beneficial results.

The Alcoa Steamship Company announced yesterday that its vice president and general manager, Fred A. Billhardt, would succeed William C. White as president. The latter retires at the end of this year.
At the very least, the contractual plan of selling mutual fund shares is controversial.
HOLLYWOOD, Dec. 13 -Spectacle will be enhanced by story in films planned by an agreement that would enable Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer to make movies in Cinerama.
MILFORD, Mich., Dec. 13 -- A group of educators said in a public statement today that Federal tax resources must be made available to help support the nation's educational system.

CHICAGO, Dec. 13 -- Arthur S. Flemming, Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare, was accused today of using cranberries and poultry to further his political ambitions, including possibly the Vice-Presidency.

ROME, Dec. 13 -- Pope John XXIII will create eight new Cardinals in a series of colorful ceremonies this week. The new Cardinals include two Americans and will raise the membership of the Sacred College to a record total of seventy-nine.

STOCKHOLM, Dec. 13 -- A new sort of creature had been born into the world with the European Free Trade Association or Outer Seven, and business men in the member countries are only now beginning to realize some of its unexpected implications.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 13 -- Little aside from the pride that goes with a championship was at stake, but the Giants had enough of that today to prove their right to the title they clinched a week ago. As a result, the Eastern Conference champions of the National Football League rallied in the second half for a 24-10 victory over the Washington Redskins at Griffith Stadium.

KANSAS CITY, Mo., Dec. 13 -- (UPI) -- A leader of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People challenged major political parties and 1960 candidates today to assure the nation's Negroes that discrimination against them would end.
ST. LOUIS, Dec. 13 -- Govenor Rockefeller defended Ezra Taft Benson today in the face of proposals that he resign as Secretary of Agriculture.

MELISSA HAYDEN stepped into the two stellar roles of yesterday afternoon's program by the New York City Ballet at the City Center, in which she was not scheduleld to appear at all, and transformed the occasion into one of genuine splendor.
The United Jewish Appeal has raised $69,300,00 this year in behalf of its constituent agencies carrying out programs of relief among 596,000 Jews over the world, particularly in Israel.
Decorations for Christmas must not include real Christmas trees in buildings used extensively by the public, Fire Commissioner Edward F. Cavanagh Jr. warned yesterday.

The figures on employment and unemployment for November -- which were still strongly influenced by the nation-wide steel strike -- continued to move in the wrong directions, in terms of progress of the 1958-59 economic recovery.

Foreign Policy," points up the growing demands for greatly increased communication with Communist China. WASHINGTON, Dec. 13 (AP) -- France's unwillingness to share fully in NATO defenses may touch off Congressional demands for return of some United States troops from abroad, Senator Mike Mansfield declared today.
