Vandals ripped and trod on Torah Scrolls and overturned furniture in three classrooms early yesterday in the Yeshiva School and Synagogue at 1899 Prospect Place, Brooklyn.
SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 13 (UPI) -- The Green Bay Packers spotted San Francisco 14 points in the first eleven minutes today, then came roaring back for a 36-14 triumph.
HACKENSACK, N. J., Dec. 13 -- Bergen County Prosecutor Guy W. Calissi announced today that he would open a major investigation tomorrow into unusually high workmen's compensation claims.
Four young men who were slashing at each other with umbrellas and a knife in a crowded Pelham Bay subway car early yesterday blacked both eyes of an off-duty policeman who intervened.

GALVESTON, Tex., Dec. 13 (AP) -- The Quantico (Va.) Marines ran up the biggest score ever recorded in Public School Stadium today in smashing McClellan Air Force Base, 90 -- 0, in the seventh annual Shrimp Bowl football game.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 13 -Greek Government leaders fervently, hope that President Eisenhower comes "bearing gifts" when he flies into Athens late tomorrow afternoon for a twenty -two-hour visit.
WORCESTER, Mass., Dec. 13 -- Ch. Tregoad's Vicky's Victor, an imported Kerry blue terrier, was picked as best in show to night at the annual Worcester County Kennel Club dog show and obedience trial.

Governor Rockefeller has made an important contribution to the mounting discussion of how the nation can be protected from the damage done by nation-wide industrial disputes, like that in steel, which baffle settlement by free collective bargaining. Broadly speaking, Mr. Rockefeller's program for dealing with them differs from the present Taft-Hartley procedure in three important ways -- one of which could carry Federal Government intervention into untried and hazardous ground.

Robert Casadesus, the distinguished French pianist, gave a recital Saturday evening at Hunter College. Sales and earnings of the Canada Dry Corporation set records in the fiscal year ended Sept. 30, the company has reported.

PITTSBURGH, Dec. 13 (AP) -- Bobby Layne pitched four touchdown passes and scored one touchdown today in leading the Pittsburgh Steelers to a 35-20 triumph over the Chicago Cardinals in a closing National Football League game.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 13 -President Eisenhower has made it clear more than once that he dislikes criticism of his defense policy. Now there are signs of a tendency to consign such critics to oblivion.

NEW DELHI, India, Dee. 13 (Reuters) -- A brilliant century by Neil Harvey and a fourth-wicket stand with Ken Mackay of 132 runs in ninety-seven minutes gave Australia a firm grip on the first cricket test match against India today.

The Fourteenth United Nations Assembly has finished its work and gone home without settling a single one of the questions that deeply and menacingly divide the world, but also without making the division deeper or wider.

Bernard Gordon, realty operator, has sold three buildings at 1963 to 1983 Bryant Avenue, the Bronx, to the Scott-Via Realty Corporation for cash over mortgages amounting to $557,000.

BEDFORD HILLS, N. Y., Dec. 13 -- The twelfth annual Greens Day party, sponsored by the Bedford Garden Club and the Bedford Hills Community House, will be held on Thursday at the Community House, from 9:30 A. M. to 5 P. M. A 200foot garland of fresh greens will be made by volunteers to decorate the main entrance of Northern Westchester Hospital in Mount Kisco.

NEW DELHI, India, Monday, Dec. 14 -- President Eisenhower strongly implied in a speech yesterday that the United States felt it a duty to help defend India against any Communist aggression.
TEL AVIV, Israel, Dec. 13 -Premier David Ben-Gurion formed today a new Government coalition that is more to the Right than his outgoing Cabinet.

IN "The Indestructible Mr. Gore," the drama on Channel 4's "Sunday Showcase" last night, Playwright Gore Vidal was telling the story of his grandfather. The gentleman of the title was a remarkable American who overcame the handicap of blindness to become a United States Senator from Oklahoma.
OMAHA, Neb., Dec. 13 -- Senator Hubert H. Humphrey of Minnesota came to Omaha yesterday on a personal political mission. He left today convinced that he had accomplished it, and more.

PITTSBURGH, Dec. 13 (UPI) -- Striking trolley and bus operators of the Pittsburgh Railways Company voted tonight to accept a contract offer. It provides wage increases totaling 26 cents an hour over the next three years.
Leonie Rysanek will make her first appearance of the Metropolitan Opera season Christmas night in the title role of Verdi's "Aida."
The Port of New York Authority will hold a series of meetings this week to familiarize the public and New Jersey officials with its proposal for a major airport on swampland in Morris County.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 13 (UPI) -- Senator Morton said today that he did not believe pressure within the Republican party would force Mr. Benson to resign before the 1960 election.

SEOUL, Korea, Dec. 13 -- An alert order was issued to all South Korean armed forces late this afternoon as tension mounted between South Korea and Japan over the first projected repatriation of Koreans in Japan to Communist North Korea tomorrow.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 13 (UPI). -- Secretary Flemming said today that he would ask Congress to tighten the law governing the use of chemicals in food processing.
PARIS, Dec. 13 -- Secretary of State Christian A. Herter declared today that the Soviet Union's willingness to negotiate seriously with the West on major issues was in doubt.

WESTBURY, L. I., Dec. 13 -- A boy who does not have a driver's license is accused of driving a car that killed a woman and injured three persons yesterday in a two-car collision on the Northern State Parkway. The youth also was hurt.

LUIGI DALLAPICCOLA has not written an overwhelming amount of music but what he has produced is concentrated in form and feeling. Although he was represented by only three short works at the concert of the New School for Social Research yesterday afternoon, the intensity of his emotion and the power of his communication were unmistakable.

IN September of 1941, when the German armies were threatening to capture Moscow, a 19-year-old Russian youth was taken to the dread headquarters of the NKVD and enrolled as an intelligence agent. Nikolai Khokhlov aspired to be an actor and already was a vaudeville whistler. His new employers appealed to his idealism and patriotism and trained him for underground resistance activity in Moscow after its occupation by the Germans.

Africa is the subject of a new book by Alan Moorehead, "No Room in the Ark," which Harper will publish Jan. 20. It will be the February selection of the Book-of-the-Month Club. Mr. Moorehead says that non-protected wild life has almost vanished in Africa because of encroaching civilization and widespread poaching.
HAVANA, Dec. 13 (AP) -Major Raul Castro told a military court today that he was not a Communist, but he declared he would not lend himself "to the dirty business of anti-communism.

New York State is taking action to preserve the man-to-man relationship of a professional man and his patient or client. Immediately at issue is the case of two corporations that allegedly have been practicing optometry.
RIVERHEAD, L. I., Dec. 13 -- A Brooklyn pathologist has been chosen Suffolk County's first medical examiner, an office superseding that of coroner in the new county charter.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 13 -- The Securities and Exchange Commission is pondering ways -- and whether -- to nip the budding boom in the stocks of companies that advise and manage mutual funds.
DENVER, Dec. 13 (AP) -George F. Rock, banker and Democratic National Committeeman for Colorado, was found robbed and beaten to death early today in a trash-littered park in East Denver.
MONTEBELLO, Calif., 13 (UPI) -- Tommy Jacobs, who learned his golf here, shot a 5- under-par 67 today to win the $5,500 Montebello golf open.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 13 (UPI) -- John C. Doerfer, chairman of the Federal Communications Commission, gave "qualified endorsement" today to action by Congress to license television networks.

Gus Hall was named the new leader of the American Communist party early this morning at the first meeting of the party's newly elected sixtymember national committee. This occurred shortly after the Midnight adjournment fo the seventeenth national convention of the party.

FRANK SINATRA'S second show of the season on Channel 7 last night was in the baritone's own characteristic style: a meticulous choice of standard tunes sung with the distinctive phrasing so much his own. For an hour of popular music Mr. Sinatra is indeed hard to beat.

ATHENS, Dec. 11 -- Walking down Sophocles Street, in the heart of this city, one finds, at No. 10, the Chrimatisterion, or Stock Exchange. It is a three-story building, typically Grecian in appearance, with four Doric columns decorating the facade.
Plans for the merger of three leading publishing houses were announced yesterday.

ACCRA, Ghana, Dec. 13 -Under the projected Constitution that would establish the Dominion of Ghana as a republic the President will have the power to suspend Parliament. The Accra Evening News, organ of Prime Minister Kwame Nkrumah's ruling Convention People's party, said last night.
PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 13 (AP) -- Jimmy Brown brought Cleveland from behind today with two second-half touchdowns that defeated Philadelphia, 28 -- 21.
TRENTON, Dec. 13 -- More than 1,700 low-income families in Newark and Paterson will begin renting new apartments within the next few weeks. They will move into them early next spring.
A Congressional subcommittee investigating reports of low morale among cadets at the United States Merchant Marine Academy at Kings Point, L. I., will convene here today after a nine-day recess.

There is at least a partial solution to the problem of the young teacher who, according to your issue of Dec. 8, voiced over the program "The Superintendent of Schools Reports" the almost universal distress of New York City teachers that paperwork and interruptions leave them too little time to teach.

ATHENS, Dec. 13 -- Tomorrow evening Greek Air Force planes will wing out to escort in the jet transport with the President aboard and guide him to a welcoming throng.

Borough President James J. Lyons of the Bronx and Albert V. Maniscalco of Richmond are to testify today before the State Commission on Governmental Operations of the City of New York.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 13 -- The General Assembly closed its fourteenth session at 4:12 A. M. today after having elected Poland as a non-permanent member of the Security Council.

The city's Commission on Intergroup Relations said yesterday that it was going to keep the membership pattern at the West Side Tennis Club under study and that it expected the club to be non-discriminatory in its membership in the future.

AT the request of the publicity chairman for the golf tournament in Alliance, Ohio, Louise Suggs made the broadcast in near-by Cleveland. It was a notable propaganda contribution because she has long been one of the star performers of the Ladies' Professional Golf Association and she was pleased in her shy, diffident way that it had gone over so well.

PARIS, Dec. 13 -- The Western Foreign Ministers will get together here this week to discuss problems of a military alliance that in its first ten years has had to cope with drastic changes in military concept, in the balance of power and in political pressures.

ONE of the most-quoted aphorisms of Brillat-Savarin says the discovery of a new dish does more for civilization than the discovery of a new star. For theatregoers in the Times Square area, finding a new, worth-while and moderately priced restaurant is eminently more auspicious.

LONDON, Dec. 13 -- According to the 1959-60 edition of "Jane's Fighting Ships," published today, the Soviet Union believes that its huge submarine fleet, guided missiles and long-range bombers would be enough, in the event of war, to deny Britain and the United States control of the seas.
LONDON, Dec. 13 -- A Government pamphlet to be published tomorrow states emphatically that the Druids did not build Stonehenge, the group of huge weathered stones standing on Salisbury Plain.

ANYONE in a stew over what to buy the man in her life may find inspiration at Charles Hamilton Autographs, Inc., 25 East Fifty-third Street. Name droppers and celebrity seekers of yesteryear should find Mr. Hamilton's colorful new quarters a veritable treasure trove.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 13 -- Most of Barbara Jean Eisenhower's life has been just one military post after another. Her father is a military man, Col. Percy Thompson. Her husband is a military man, Maj. John S. D. Eisenhower.
Cotton future prices moved moderately higher on the New York market last week, closing Friday with gains ranging from 15 cents to $1 a bale.

After many years of experience in various departments of the theatre, television and films, Worthington Cogswell Miner has switched to playwriting. He has written two plays. "Spring in September" and "This Is My House."

Making the most of their scoring opportunities and putting up a tight defense, the American Soccer League All Stars upset the Austria Soccer Club from Vienna, 4 -- 1, yesterday at Gaelic Park, the Bronx, before a crowd of 3,000.

MINNEAPOLIS, Dec. 14 -- Governor Rockefeller proposed today a major revision in the Government's attempts to keep agriculture growing.

DOWN below Herald Square, the pavements of the wholesale flower district are turning green with Christmas tree needles. Every day some portion of the annual tree harvest is trucked away to flower stores in every neighborhood of the city.
ALBANY, Dec. 14 (AP) -State Controller Arthur Levitt proposed two bills today to strengthen the Controller's audit of local affairs and to tighten the competitive bidding law.
The Waterfront Commission announced yesterday that new, stricter rules to cut theft losses at piers here would go into effect Jan. 1.
Nonprofessional real estate investors were urged yesterday to use caution by thoroughly analyzing a property before buying brownstone and tenement buildings for rental income after modernization.
PARIS, Dec. 14 -- President Charles de Gaulle returned today from a triumphal visit to Senegal. He arrived amid grumbling from the Right at his liberal decisions in Africa.

Maurice E. Olen, former president of H. L. Green Company, Inc., a woman bookkeeper and three accountants pleaded not guilty yesterday in Federal Court to charges of conspiring to violate securities laws.
TEHERAN, Iran, Dec. 14 -President Eisenhower, in a five - and - three - quarter - hour stop - over here today, reminded Iranians that "military strength alone" could not insure their security.
Tribute was paid yesterday to the late Miss Dorothy Shaver, president of Lord Taylor, by the board of trustees of the Fashion Institute of Technology, 227 West Twenty-seventh Street.
A single word -- "Gratitude" -- written on the back of a bank leaflet, was sent to New York's Neediest Cases fund yesterday along with $25.

Following are the texts of remarks by President Eisenhower yesterday in Athens and Teheran, Iran, as transmitted by The Associated Press. They comprise the President's talk on landing in Athens, his speech on his arrival in Teheran, his toast to the Shah of Iran, his address to the Iranian Parliament and his farewell talk on leaving Teheran.

One sometimes finds himself wondering if the Republican party deserves a Secretary of Agriculture of the caliber of Ezra T. Benson. Once more, with the 1960 Presidential elections approaching, we hear reports of the same suggestions being put forward by unnamed Republican leaders that Mr. Benson should resign or be asked to resign.

THE new novel by Pierre Boulle, who wrote "The Bridge Over the River Kwai," is called "S. O. P. H. I. A."* The initials stand for the Society for the Overseas Promotion of Horticulture, Industry and Agriculture. It is a French company operating in the waning British part of Malaya.
WHITE PLAINS, Dec. 14 -- An analysis of retail activity in Westchester County's 448 square miles was filed by the County Planning Department today with the Board of Supervisors.
Cotton futures moved up 10 to 23 points (50 cents to $1.15 a bale) yesterday on the New York Cotton Exchange. The distant months showed the most strength.

Faculty members at the United States Merchant Marine Academy, Kings Point, L. I., were described yesterday as almost unanimously opposed to a proposed switch of their status from the Maritime Service to Civil Service.
HELSINKI, Finland, Dec. 14 -- The Soviet Union has demanded many of the privileges of membership in the Outer Seven European trade bloc.
PARIS, Dec. 14 -- The staff of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization worked hectically today to put the organization's gleaming new headquarters in order for tomorrow's meeting of the NATO Council.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Dec. 14 -- Labor negotiations between the two most important groups in Hollywood -- the major studios and the actors -- began here today in an atmosphere of ominous rumors.
An investment group headed by Daniel Van Dyk and including David B. Charnay has acquired control of Hazel Bishop, Inc., cosmetics manufacturer.
RIVERHEAD, L. I., Dec. 14 -- The Suffolk County Board of Supervisors appointed five trustees today for the county's recently approved two-year community college.
HONG KONG, Dec. 13 -- Communist China has experimentally produced nearly 10,000 varieties of new textiles and new designs this year.

Record shipments of aluminum produced in the U. S. and a "corrective strengthening of world aluminum prices were predicted yesterday for 1960 by the president of the nation's largest producer of the metal.

AMSTERDAM, the Netherlands, Tuesday, Dec. 15 -- The all-Negro musical "Free and Easy," by Harold Arlen and Johnny Mercer, opened formally at the Theatre Carre here last night without the guidance of its artistic director, Robert Breen.
CORAL GABLES, Fla. Dec. 14 (AP) -- Inherent Self broke through the gate just before the start and was recalled but had plenty left to run off with the featured seventh race at Tropical Park today.
BLUE POINT, L. I., Dec. 14 -- Suffolk County Judge Lloyd P. Dodge, indicted Oct. 8 on charges of accepting unlawful fees, conspiracy and subornation of perjury, refused to resign today.
DES MOINES, Iowa, Dec. 14 Senator Hubert H. Humphrey completed today a hustling, bushing tour of the Midwest that could materially raise his status as a Presidential aspirant.

NEWARK, Dec. 14 -- The battle over a fourth metropolitan airport was formally joined today. The Port of New York Authority made public its "preliminary" plan for a sprawling, jet-age airport in Morris County's Great Swamp, twenty-five miles west of Manhattan.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 14 (UPI) -- The National Association of Broadcasters today announced a 12 per cent increase in the last month in the number of television stations subscribing to the industry's self-imposed Code of Good Practices.
A group of British college students will arrive here next June to help combat juvenile delinquency, poverty and narcotics addiction on the Lower East Side.
NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 14 (AP) -- Joe Brown, the world lightweight champion, kept his right hand under wraps tonight and scored a dull, easy decision over willing Joey Parks of Omaha, Neb.
PARIS, Dec. 14 -- Foreign Minister Couve de Murville protested in strong terms today to Secretary Herter over two United States moves widely considered here as hostile to France.

Borough President James J. Lyons of the Bronx defended "party government" yesterday, and said he had eight Democratic district leaders on his staff. But he said only thirteen of his 914 employes were outside the Civil Service system.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 14 -- The chairman of a special Senate investigating committee implied today that the Administration had withheld information that only 44 per cent of the 3,670,000 persons unemployed in November had been receiving jobless insurance.
Price changes were mixed yesterday in the market for fixed interest securities.

GENEVA, Dec. 14 -- The Soviet Union offered the United States and Britain a "compromise package solution" today for three of the principal stumbling blocks in the negotiations for a treaty-banning nuclear weapons tests.
LONDON, Dec. 14 (UPI) -- An American jukebox with rock 'n' roll spirituals was installed next to the pipe organ in the Pembroke Mission Church here last night.

The problems of New York, a city whose streets since its earliest days have heard many tongues and whose many racial strains occasionally erupt in conflict, are recalled by a 100th anniversary marked today.
DR. WILLARD UPHAUS looks like a divinity school teacher, which he has been; like a good Methodist layman, which he is.
JAKARTA, Indonesia, Dec 14 -- Communist China was denounced by Indonesian officials today as "just another imperialist power with expansionist inclinations."

It is an unhappy reflection on the conscience of the non-Communist world that virtually no voices have been raised here in defense of the victims of the current anti-Chinese measures in Indonesia. Indeed, it is only since these measures have led to diplomatic friction between Indonesia and Communist China that they have received significant attention in the West.

Workmen planted trees on Forty-second Street and on Fifth Avenue yesterday as memorials to two vice presidents of the city's Salute to Seasons Committee. Fifty-one Lon don plane trees are being placed on Forty-second Street from Second Avenue to Times Square in memory of Seymour Berkson, late publisher of The New York Journal-American.
LONDON, Dec. 14 -- The Earl of Harewood has been appointed artistic director of the Edinburgh Festival. He will succeed Robert Ponsonby, whose resignation takes effect next March.

In the busiest day of his whole world tour thus far President Eisenhower, head of the world's strongest democracy, left India, the world's largest democracy, and after a visit to Iran arrived in Athens, Greece, the cradle of democracy, to receive the same rousing welcome that has greeted him everywhere.
LONG BEACH, L. I., Dec. 14 Pat Cici was elected president of the Long Island Professional Golfers Association at the annual meeting at the Lido Golf Club today.
NASHVILLE, Tenn., Dec. 14 -- Vice President Richard M. Nixon was virtually assured today of Tennessee's twenty-eight Republican national convention votes for the Presidential nomination next July.

DURING the holiday season, many cakes made with butter or shortening are baked in home kitchens. There are times when results are somewhat disappointing, even using an excellent recipe, accurate measurements and a good oven.
ASUNCION, Paraguay, Dec. 14 -- President Alfredo Stroessner visited today the Encarnacion area, where armed exiles made an unsuccessful invasion attempt from Argentina.
The Associated Hospital Service of New York, Inc., has broadened the eligibility of individual subscribers. In a statement yesterday, Blue Cross said:

WASHINGTON, Dec. 14 -- The Supreme Court directed the Federal Power Commission today to take another look at the rates involved before approving a huge new sale of natural gas for New York and other Eastern urban areas.

CHICAGO, Dec. 14 -- The Food and Drug Administration warned farmers today that they faced more "blitzkrieg publicity" if they failed to police themselves in the use of chemicals to prevent a repetition of the cranberry and poultry episodes.

McGraw-Edison Company The McGraw-Edison Company will acquire next month the evaporative cooler and central air conditioning business of the International Metal Products Company of Phoenix Ariz. This was announced yesterday by Max McGraw, president of the electrical apparatus end small appliance organization, and A. D. Goettl, International Metal Products president.
Legislation stripping the Market Commissioner of much of his power in the punishment of weights and measures violations will be introduced into the City Council today at Mayor Wagner's request.
Six patrolmen, including two members of the "commando squad," were promoted to the rank of detective, third grade, in a ceremo y at Police Headquarters yesterday.
LAGOS, Nigeria, Dec. 14 -- A coalition Cabinet led by Abubakar Tafawa Balewa will be formed this week to guide Nigeria into independence.
A friendly dog of uncertain ancestry was honored yesterday at the New York Academy of Sciences for its unwitting contribution to the science of heart surgery.
DETROIT, Dec. 14 (AP) -- American Motors, building cars at an record pace for an independent company, has moved into third place in the industry's production totals for 1959.
CHICAGO, Dec. 14 -- Senator Lyndon B. Johnson has left behind in the Midwest the distict impression that he is after working control of the Democratic party machinery.
LONDON, Dec. 14 (Reuters) -- Following is the text of the Soviet statement delivered to the West German Foreign Ministry today and issued in English by the Soviet press service Tass:
LONDON, Tuesday, Dec. 14 -Sir Stanley Spencer., artist whose works are in public gal:cries in many parts of the world, died tonight in a hospital in Buckinghamshire. He was '68 years old.

The Jewish Chronic Disease Hospital, an 810-bed voluntary, nonsectarian institution in Brooklyn, will benefit from two luncheons today, a theatre party tonight, and two theatre parties and a mah-jongg and card party tomorrow. Six of the women's groups affiliated with the hospital are sponsoring the events.

Pre - Christmas celebrations were in full swing throughout the city yesterday. Philanthropic, commercial and social organizations shared the sponsorship as wreaths were hung, trees lighted and children entertained.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 14 -The Government's short-term borrowing costs declined this week after two successive weeks of breaking records.

If anyone on this Bill of Rights day thinks that just because Joseph R. McCarthy is dead and the Supreme Court is very much alive, all's well with the state of civil liberties in America, he should glance through the hundred pages of the latest annual report of the American Civil Liberties Union.
LONDON, Dec. 14 -- The Chancellor of the Exchequer, Derick Heathcoat Amory, said today that the European Free Trade Association was ready to negotiate with the European Common Market at any time.
CONCORD, N. H., Dec. 14 -- Dr. Willard Uphaus, a self-styled "Christian pacifist," was committed to the Merrimack County Jail today for contempt of court.
BOSTON, Dec. 14 -- Sugar Ray Robinson made a highly successful return to ring competition tonight.
The United States Court of Appeals ruled yesterday that three New York bar associations were charitable organizations within the meaning of the Federal estate tax laws.

The Columbia Broadcasting System's television audience will have to adjust to a set of unusual announcements, effective today. At the end of a show, if viewers are told "audience reaction technically produced'' or "certain portions of this recorded program were pre-recorded," let it be known there is an explanation.

MOSCOW, Dec. 14 -- An American who attended the Moscow Youth Festival in 1957 and then went to Communist China has returned to the Soviet Union with his wife and is working as a locksmith in the Ukrainian port city of Odessa.
ATHENS, Dec. 14 -- President Eisenhower arrived in Athens tonight and received a tumultuous welcome from a half million people.

Here is a rather ironic forecast for investors: gains in sales and profits in 1960 but few increased dividends. This picture of mixed blessings was painted in a survey of credit and financial leaders in twenty-five basic industries.

Thomas Mitchell, busy these last six years with television and film assignments, will return to Broadway this season as the star of "Cut of the Axe." This is a first play by Sheppard Kerman that is being co-sponsored by Rita Allen and Milton Cassel.
ALBANY, Dec. 14 (AP) -- A total of 4,815,867 New Yorkers balloted in last month's off-year election but nearly half failed to vote on all nine proposed amendments to the State Constitution.

The Appellate Division in Brooklyn yesterday dismissed indictments against Howard B. Wakeman, a senior vice president of the Long Island Lighting Company, and Robert J. McNulty, Town Clerk of Huntington. They had been accused of having stolen $14,700 to make a political pay-off.

LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Dec. 14 -- Two years ago it would have been next to impossible to drive two blocks in this Arkansas capital without passing a car with a bumper sticker saying, "Occupied Little Rock."

A state Democratic advisory committee urged the scrapping yesterday of Governor Rockefeller's pay-as-you-go program for financing capital construction. As a substitute it urged a "pay as you use" policy.
The nation's steel mills will show a slight dip in production this week after setting an output record last week, the American Iron and Steel Institute forecast yesterday.

ALBANY, Dec 14 (AP) -Governor Rockefeller, in his first grant of traditional christmas time clemency, paved the road today for freedom for four men who had spent a combined total of eighty-two years in prison.

Directors of the Steel Company of Canada, Ltd., declared yesterday a quarterly dividend of 60 cents and a year-end extra of 30 cents on the common stock, payable on Feb. 1. In previous quarters 40 cents a share was paid.
"The Human Condition," a Japanese-made drama, will arrive today at the Little Carnegie, Fifty-seventh Street east of Seventh Avenue.
CHICAGO, Dec. 14 (AP) -- The top price paid for butcher hogs today was the lowest in more than three and a half years.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 14 -- Even if the Republican National Chairman, Senator Morton of Kentucky, had not publicly conceded that Ezra T. Benson is a party liability in the Corn Belt, the old Republican controversy centering on the U. S. Secretary of Agriculture would have flamed up again with the results of tomorrow's Congressional by-election in Iowa's Fourth District.
LONDON, Dec. 14 -- The Soviet Union has accused West Germany of seeking to "step up the arms race" and to wipe out all limitations on its rearmament.
The owner of four West Side tenements was fined $1,250 yesterday for multiple violations of the housing law.
A shoe store's battle against eviction is expected to delay construction of the $2,000,000 Gallery of Modern Art on Columbus Circle for about twelve months.
The volatile career of F. Kenneth Beirn has taken a new turn.
American higher education will require almost $10,000,000,000 annually by 1969, compared with the current expenditure of $3,600,000,000.
A scientist at the Rockefeller Institute reported conclusive evidence yesterday that particles were transported through capillary walls, from the blood to body tissue, in countless tiny spheres.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 14 UPI -- Steel and auto sales and profits fell sharply in the third quarter but other manufacturing lines showed little change from earlier records, the Government reported today.
Herbert A. Koehler of Jackson Heights was elected Queens Democratic leader yesterday without a dissenting vote.
Edward W. Carter, president of Broadway-Hale Stores, Inc., Los Angeles, has been chosen as the 1959 winner of the Tobe Award, one of the highest honors in retailing.
Many persons have planned to entertain in connection with the annual Christmas Ball at the Sheraton-East on Friday.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 14 (AP) -- The General Foods Corporation and P. Lorillard Company today were denied a Supreme Court review of a decision that they violated the Clayton Antitrust Act by certain contracts with broadcasting companies.
Four vice presidents were elected in two major banks yesterday.

The Standard Oil Company (New Jersey) and twenty of its affiliates, faced with a $400,000,000 bill annually for transporting oil and oil products by water, have started a huge technical drive to cut marine transport costs.
At the Bachelors Ball in the Grand Ballroom of the Astor last night, masks were de rigueur for the women, who outdid themselves in the originality of the designs.

Former Governor Charles Poletti suggested yesterday that the Consolidated Edison Company was trying to make its 2,788,000 consumers of electricity in this city and Westchester County underwrite its generosity to the First National City Bank.

INDEPENDENCE, Mo., Dec. 14 (UPI) -- Oscar L. Chapman turned over his personal Cabinet papers today to former President Harry S. Truman. The more than 27,500 manuscript pages will be reviewed by the staff at the Truman Library here, then opened to students for research.
Vincent J. Squillante, his brother, Nunzio, and a third man won a reversal of their conviction for extortion yesterday.
The High School Teachers Association urged higher pay rates again yesterday for secondary school instructors.

ROME, Dec. 14 -- Pope John XXIII condemned today what he called the "erroneous doctrines and the pernicious and death-dealing methods" of birth control as a means of dealing with the problem of hunger in the world.

The nation's major chain and mail order companies in November bettered their sales from the like 1958 month by 6.3 per cent, according to a survey yesterday by The New York Times. Volume for the first eleven months of the year ran 9.3 per cent ahead of the comparable 1958 period.

JOHN BROWNING, prize-winning California pianist who made his debut here with the New York Philharmonic in 1956 and played a debut recital two years later, returned to Carnegie Hall last night for a performance that made clear that he is one of the most gifted young performers before the public today.

BALTIMORE, Dec. 14 (AP) -- Frankie Northcutt set a Pimlico record today when he rode three winners and increased his score for the meeting to forty victories. The previous record of thirty-seven winners was set by David Gorman at the 1956 fall meeting.
NICOSIA, Cyprus, Dec. 14 -- Archbishop Makarios has been elected President of Cyprus by a two-to-one margin.

Now that the U. N. Assembly has gone home at the end of its fourteenth regular session, there will not be quite so much news from the tall building on the East River or the architectural poached eggs that flank it. It would be a mistake, however, to assume that nothing is going on at U. N. headquarters.
The Theo. Hamm Brewing Company of St. Paul announced yesterday it had purchased Gunther Brewing Company of Baltimore.
Heads of city departments were warned by Mayor Wagner yesterday to keep their 1960-61 budget requests to a minimum.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 14 -A meeting of government ministers to consider world economic problems was urged today by United Nations representatives. The meeting would be held in Geneva next July during the session of the Economic and Social Council.

The resounding victory which Archbishop Makarios has registered in the Cyprus elections will be good news to all those hoping to see a peaceful evolution for that troubled island. It means that most Cypriotes are willing to accept the London and Zurich agreements of last February which will bring independence to Cyprus this coming Feb. 19.

Motors, tires, nonferrous metals and most electronics issues pushed ahead in yesterday's session of the New York Stock Exchange. Gains and losses were almost evenly divided but the market averages rose owing to strength among the standard stocks used to compile the market indicators.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 14 Ezra Taft Benson said today from a hospital bed that he would not bow to demands from some farm-state Republicans that he resign for the good of the party.
The city school system is not going to join a rush to emphasize foreign languages in elementary school.

Many persons have taken tables for the New Year's Eve party in the ballroom of the Sheraton - East. Mrs. William vanden Heuvel, Mrs. Angier Biddle Duke and Mrs. Thomas M. Bancroft Jr. are co-chairmen for the Dec. 31 event, which will benefit the International Rescue Committee.

John L. Collyer, one of Cornell University's most famous oarsmen, was honored last night at the third annual dinner tendered by the Cornell Club of New York and the Cornell Alumni Association of New York.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 14 (AP) -- The Supreme Court dealt Caryl Chessman a possibly decisive defeat today in his eleven and a half-year battle to escape execution.
Any direct discussion of the 15-cent fare in transit mediation efforts was ruled out yesterday by Mrs. Anna M. Rosenberg, the head of the Mayor's citizens' mediation committee.
ALBANY, Dec. 14 (AP) -- Skiing conditions as reported today to the State Commerce Department:
NEW DELHI, India, Dec. 14 -- The orange-and-black-nosed jetliner disappeared in the dawn and it was all over. President Eisenhower was gone.
WASHINGTON, Dec 14 -- The Administration has decided to ask Congress for about $800,000,000 for the space program in the coming fiscal year.

ROCK SOUND, Island of Eleuthera, Bahamas, Dec. 14 -- The Island of Eleuthera, one of the largest in the vast Bahamas group, is shaped something like a stuffed Christmas stocking. It is about ninety miles long and for years has been a center of dairying, farming and beef cattle fattening.

I should like to comment on the statements being made that, first, a $41 billion defense budget is inadequate to protect the United States; and, secondly, that the deterrent theory is not the answer to our defense needs.
Two large investment firms announced yesterday new partnerships effective with the new year.

THE life masters' pair championship in the Greater New York Bridge Association's last tournament of 1959, played at the Sheraton-Atlantic Hotel over the last weekend, was won late Sunday night by Victor Mitchell of New York and Morris Shiller of Roslyn Heights, L. I. George Rapee of New York and Dr. George Rosenkranz of Mexico City were second.

THE urgency of Christmas shopping and the late hours of holiday parties will reduce many women to a frazzle. While no one looks her best when she is tired, there are certain beauty tricks that can disguise a look of fatigue.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 14 -One member of the Supreme Court accused another in the courtroom today of writing a "smart-alecky" opinion. The accuser was Justice William O. Douglas, the accused, Justice Charles Evans Whittaker.
WESTBURY, L. I., Dec. 14 -What may be the tiniest postgraduate educational institution in the United States has been established on the premises of a small electronics concern here.

ST. LOUIS, Dec. 14 (AP) -- Two Truman Administration officials received a setback today in their effort to escape going to prison. The United States Eighth Circuit Court of Appeals denied their motion for a re-hearing of its decision barring a new trial to them.
Following is President Eisenhower's official program for his world tour. All times are regional (Athens is seven hours ahead of Eastern standard time).
Ten truckloads of live caponettes were delivered yesterday morning to the New York City Live Poultry Terminal at Fifty-third Avenue and Eleventh Street in Queens.
ZERMATT, Switzerland, Dec. 14 -- A tour of several famous ski resorts points up a curious European phenomenon the deathly stillness that hangs over a town that snow built, when there is no snow.

ITHACA, N. Y., Dec. 14 -Deane W. Malott, president of Cornell University, announced today that, in spite of his continuing opposition to the disclaimer oath provision of the National Defense Education Act of 1958, Cornell would continue to participate in the program to give students access to about $250,000 in loan funds a year.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 14 (UPI) -- Federal provisions guaranteeing secret ballots and other democratic election practices in more than 50,000 national and local unions became effective today under the new labor reform law.
BROOKVILLE, L. I., Dec. 14 -- Officials of C. W. Post College will meet with the faculty here tomorrow to review the college's appointment of a former Nazi-party member.

ONCE again the New York viewer is indebted to Channel 13 and "The Play of the Week." In "The World of Sholom Aleichem," which last night opened an engagement that will extend through Sunday afternoon, there is theatre of gentle beauty, compassion and social protest.

New fissures appear to have opened in the American Communist party in the wake of the major change in leadership voted at its seventeenth national convention, which ended here early yesterday morning.

The Dallas Power and Light Company sold yesterday $20,000,000 of thirty-year first mortgage bonds at an interest cost of 5.149 per cent. The bonds were sold at comp etitive bidding to a syndicate headed by Halsey Stuart Co., Inc., on a bid of 101.5299 for obligations bearing 5 1/4 per cent interest coupons.

The Houston Texas Independent School District sold $16,934,000 of bonds yesterday to the First National City Bank of New York and associates on a bid of 100.0064 for coupons of 5, 4 and 1/4 per cent. The net interest cost to the district was 3.9168 per cent.
ATHENS, Dec. 14 (AP) -President Eisenhower will run little risk of either sunburn or seasickness when he boards the cruiser Des Moines tomorrow for a sail to Tunisia and France.
TRENTON, Dec. 14 -- This city's largest department store offered today to transform into an ultra-modern shopping center at its own expense a nine acre tract in the heart of downtown Trenton.

Squinting under the lights at the 102d Engineers Armory and bent over by the weight of their stopwatches, the schoolboy track buffs, who measure their enthusiasm in decimal points, were out in force last Saturday at the sixth annual Bishop Loughlin track and field games.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 14 -- The Supreme Court, in a new constitutional interpretation, held today that a bookseller might not be convicted for selling an obscene book unless the prosecution produced some proof that the seller knew the book was obscene.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 14 -- The Arkansas laws under which Gov. Orval E. Faubus closed the Little Rock high schools for a year were held unconstitutional by the Supreme Court today.

NIIGATA, Japan, Dec. 14 -With songs and cadenced cheering, and some uncontrollable tears, 975 Korean men, women and children said "Sayonara" (Farewell) to Japan today in a mass migration to Communist rule.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 14 -The irony of the Presidential election so far is that the men who seem to be doing the best are those who are campaigning the least.
PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 14 -Dr. Millard E. Gladfelter, who started teaching in a oneroom schoolhouse, became the fourth president of Temple University today.
Evalyn Steinbock gave a cello program last night in Carnegie Recital Hall that was notable for its musical insights and the presentation of a first-rate new work by a young composer Don Banks.

LYNNFIELD, Mass., Dec. 14 (UPI) -- A business group headed by Leo B. (Buddy) Dowd Jr., a Nashua (N. H.) insurance executive, today revealed plans to obtain a professional football team for Boston under the National Football League's expansion proposal.

ZVI ZEITLIN, Israeli violinist, gave a concert at Town Hall Monday night for the American-Israel Cultural turned to Carnegie Hall Monday night for a performance that made clear that he is one of the most gifted young performers before the public today.

The Houston Texas Independent School District sold $16,934,000 of bonds yesterday to the First National City Bank of New York and associates on a bid of 100.0064 for coupons of 5, 4 and 1/4 per cent. The net interest cost to the district was 3.9168 per cent.
ATHENS, Dec. 14 (AP) -President Eisenhower will run little risk of either sunburn or seasickness when he boards the cruiser Des Moines tomorrow for a sail to Tunisia and France.
TRENTON, Dec. 14 -- This city's largest department store offered today to transform into an ultra-modern shopping center at its own expense a nine acre tract in the heart of downtown Trenton.
The broken right leg suffered by Wallace (Bud) Werner last Saturday appears to have ended America's hopes for a medal-winner in the men's Alpine skiing at the winter Olympic Games next February.

PEIPING, Dec. 14 (Reuters) -- The commander of the Chinese Communist troops in Tibet has said a "handful of reactionaries" there are opposing "democratic reforms" by murder, bribery and intimidation, according to a Tibetan newspaper received here today.

The election of James Cooke as president of the ACF-Wrigley Stores, Inc., was announced yesterday. Until recently, he had been vice president. general manager and a director of the Penn Fruit Company of Philadelphia. In his new post at ACF-Wrigley he succeeds Norman Hirschfield who becomes chairman and continues as chief executive officer.
The American Electric Power Company reported yesterday new highs in net income for November and for the eleven and twelve months ended on Nov. 30.

Another gloomy chapter in the history of the American-Hawaiian Steamship Company, the nation's oldest intercoastal operator, will be written Friday when the company's stock is removed from the listings of the New York Stock Exchange.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 14 -- Charges of widespread deceptive practices in the radio and television industry were reported by Congressional investigators today. The alleged payoffs and kickbacks approached extortion in some instances.
TEHERAN, Iran, Dec. 14 (Reuters) -- Following is the text of a joint communique issued here today following talks between President Eisenhower and Shah Mohammed Riza Pahlevi of Iran:
Legislation was urged yesterday to curb communities that design traffic rules for revenue rather than for road safety.

The three six-story apartment buildings at 1187-97 Anderson Avenue, the Bronx, have been acquired by the Realty Equities Corporation, of which Bernard I. Sandford is executive vice president. They were sold by clients of Dreyer Traub, lawyers in a deal negotiated by Bross Rubin Associates, brokers.

After a five-hour conference among club executives the New York Knickerbockers yesterday asked waivers on Cal Ramsey, the 6-foot 4-inch former New York University star who joined the team Dec. 1. Ramsey, who had scored 80 points in seven games, was put on the waiver list to make room for Mike Farmer, a 6-foot 7-inch forward who had been on the disabled list.

AS holiday shopping gains momentum and the children begin to ask, "How many days till Christmas?" excitement fills the air. Hot chestnuts are sold on street corners, Salvation Army carols fill the air and even the most cynical observer responds to the something special that is Christmas in the city.

MOST baseball men have been viewing Roger Maris with covetous eyes for the past few seasons. From a theoretical point of view he represents the ideal young ballplayer because this 190-pound six-footer gets plus ratings in the three primary requisites. He can run, throw and hit with power.
ATLANTA, Dec. 14 -- A Federal district judge told Georgians today that they, not the court, must make the choice between some racial desegregation and closed schools.

PARIS, Dec. 14 -- Paul-Henri Spaak, Secretary General of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization, welcomed tonight United States criticisms of French deviations from NATO policy as an aid in resolving the grave differences that divide the Western allies.

NEW DELHI, India, Dec. 14 (Reuters) -- President Eisenhower has sent messages to President Rajendra Prasad and Prime Minister Jahawarlal Nehru expressing gratitude for his "memorable and heartwarming reception" in India.
ATHENS, Dec. 14 -- Hundreds of thousands of Iranians and Greeks cheered President Eisenhower as a champion of peace on two continents today.
Two defense lawyers accused the Government yesterday of anti-Italian bias in prosecuting the men who attended the 1957 Apalachin gathering.

SALT LAKE CITY, Dec. 14 (AP) -- A Federal Court jury awarded total damages of $4,500,000 today in three of four antitrust suits against the Union Carbide Corporation, Vanadium Corporation of America and three subsidiaries.
MONTREAL, Dec. 14 (Canadian Press) -- The former heavyweight champion, Floyd Paterson, said tonight he intended to stick with his manager, Cus D'Amato, "come what may."

ATHENS, Dec. 15 -- President Eisenhower reaffirmed his call for peace and friendship today in a brief address to the Greek Chamber of Deputies and received a thunderous ovation. About five hours after his speech, the President boarded the cruiser Des Moines and left Greece for a cruise in the Mediterranean to Tunis, the next stop on his goodwill visit to eleven countries on three continents.

ALBANY, Dec. 15 (UPI) -- The State Department of Commerce today received reports of the following skiing conditions: Whiteface Mountain -- Granular surface, 5-to-18-inch snow base; fair to good skiing.

Some $3,736,238,441 in savings were held by the 229 saving and loan associations in New York State at the end of November, the Savings Association League of New York State announced yesterday. During the month the associations received $108,334,493 and withdrawals were $90,841,514.

The Westinghouse Electric Corporation expects to set a sales record next year, Mark W. Cresap Jr., president said yesterday. The chief executive officer of the country's second-largest electrical manufacturing organization, in a year-end statement, predicted that 1960 billings would be at least 10 per cent greater than those for this year.

MADISON, Wis., Dec. 15 -- Governor Rockefeller declared today that his new farm program could ultimately save billions of dollars in Federal subsidy expense and still produce lower consumer prices in many instances.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 15 -- A move to expand the membership of a proposed highlevel economic conference this summer was turned back late today in the Economics and Social Council.
FARMINGDALE, L. I., Dec. 15 -- An F-105 Thunderchief supersonic jet plane crashed into the Atlantic Ocean eight miles off Montauk Point today. The test pilot is missing.
MAJESTY is the mark of John Llewellyn Lewis.
BUENOS AIRES, Dec. 15 -- Incursions by Paraguayan exile commandos against President Alfredo Stroessner's regime have plunged Paraguay into a new period of severe repression.

The New York Knickerbockers tried their best to beat the St. Louis Hawks last night, rallying a number of times to make the game close. However, the Hawks, with Bob Pettit hitting the target frequently, scored a 119-110 victory before 12,572 fans at Madison Square Garden.
A law that would make it easier for policemen to cross state borders in investigating criminal activities was proposed yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 -- John L. Lewis, who fought his way to the presidency of the United Mine Workers and led the drive to unionize mass-production industries, announced today his intention to resign next month as the miners' leader.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 (AP) -- Vice President Richard M. Nixon said today that the United States must not fail "to tap the resources of all of its people" in the economic contest with the Soviet Union.

" The Big Party" will be discontinued early next year by its sponsor, Revlon, Inc. The cosmetics company plans to introduce a new series of variety programs over the same television network, the Columbia Broadcasting System.
An unpleasant odor spread over the metropolitan area last night, causing a flood of complaints and inquiries to the police and to utility companies. Search teams failed to trace the odor.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 -- The United States has filed a strong protest with Czechoslovakia against an exhibit in Prague that describes the United States as "the last and worst of the colonialists."
WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 (AP) -- The Federal Reserve Board today extended its list of lenders required to make regular reports on stock market credit.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 (UPI) -- Vice President Richard M. Nixon, taking aim at Democratic critics of President Eisenhower's eleven-nation trip, said today that that goodwill the President had inspired abroad was "a very important diplomatic dividend."
IT is hard to understand what could have prompted the revival of "Kataki" at the St. Marks Playhouse last night.
