BALTIMORE, Dec. 15 (AP) -- Pimlico closed out Maryland's 1959 racing season today with C. Mahlon Kline's Mystic II gaining his third consecutive triumph of the twenty-eight-day meeting.
Cus D'Amato's hearing on motion seeking return of his managerial license by the State Athletic Commission was postponed by State Supreme Court Justice Arthur Markewich yesterday until Jan. 11.
Two tenements with which Banton L. Wyckoff and his former rent collector, Solomon Chodorov, were formerly associated figured in Housing Court yesterday.

The age of the airplane has engulfed us so rapidly that no one can seriously argue with the Port of New York Authority's assumption that specific planning must begin at once for a new airport in the metropolitan area. A new airport of 10,000 acres, more than twice the size of the huge Idlewild we used to think of as La Guardia's folly, is proposed for Morris County in New Jersey.

Bert Smith, a former inspector in the Bureau of Weights and Measures who had been accused in two indictments of extortion involving butchers, pleaded guilty yesterday to lesser charges in one of the indictments.

TEL AVIV, Israel, Dec. 15 -Premier David Ben-Gurion postponed the introduction of his new Government today in the expectation that he would be able to present a broader coalition to Parliament tomorrow.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 (AP) -- The Marine Corps announced today plans to test, for possible purchase, a new German-developed antitank missile, the Cobra.

Stocks surged upward as if headed for new records yesterday, changed their minds in mid-session and were headed down at the close. The New York Times combined average of fifty stocks retained a small gain at the final gong.
A Canadian was elected Suffragan Bishop of the Protestant Episcopal Diocese of New York yesterday in balloting that lasted most of the day.
The New York State Harness Racing Commission yesterday disclosed a 206-day racing program for three upstate trotting organizations in 1960.

Please permit me to express my gratitude as an Indian citizen at the enormous goodwill of Americans toward my country. A famine was averted in India in the early days of our Republic with the timely American aid of food grains.
CHICAGO, Dec. 15 -- The five major aluminum producers and the United Steelworkers of America met jointly today in an effort to negotiate new contracts covering about 50,000 workers.
LONDON, Dec. 15 (Reuters) -- Prime Minister Harold Macmillan announced today that the Prime Ministers of the British Commonwealth would open a conference here May 3.
NEW HAVEN, Dec. 15 (AP) -- A price war affecting large and small dairies throughout the state is forcing down the price of milk at the store and at the doorstep.
MILWAUKEE, Dec. 15 -- The Rockefeller Presidential exploration party ran into tough sledding in snowless Wisconsin today.

The appointment of a committee to study ways of protecting prospective buyers of new homes against the loss of their investments through default by builders was announced yesterday by state Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz.
LAGOS, Nigeria, Dec. 15 -- Abubakar Tafawa Balewa was reappointed Prime Minister of the Federation of Nigeria today.
DURING a musical number about the vexations of life in the Army, Harry Belafonte missed a downbeat at the Palace last evening.
LONDON, Dec. 15 -- Communist China is producing twenty to twenty-five MIG-17 jet fighters a month, according to the 1959-60 edition of Jane's All the World's Aircraft, which was published here today.

Kimberly-Clark Corporation, a leading paper producer, announced yesterday that it had completed negotiations for the acquisition of the Paris concern Societe Sopaline, for the production and distribution of its products in France.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 -- Over-all industrial production recovered slightly last month from the low point of the steel strike, the Federal Reserve Board estimated today.
Federal Paper Board Company announced yesterday that it had arranged to acquire the Manchester Board and Paper Company, Inc., Richmond, Va.

BONN, West Germany, Dec. 15 (Reuters) -- West Germany had a trade surplus in the irst eleven months of this year o 5,400,000,000marks (about $1350,000,000). This was 100,000,000 marks (about $25,000,000) higher than in the same period last year. Government statistical today showed I99 imports and2 exports would set new records
Repeal of the 10-cent-a-ride taxicab tax was urged yesterday by the city's largest fleet owner in a letter to Mayor Wagner.

Books Go Down The cost-of-living figures continue to rise, the cost of commuting shows a constant increase, the stock market inches up, but there is one note of good cheer in the statistics of the year -- the cost of being well-read has fallen.

BONN, Germany, Dec. 15 -- The United States has assured West Germany that it will maintain powerful military forces in Europe for at least another five years, Defense Minister Franz Josef Strauss said in an interview published here today.
Both of the Christmas season's Gotham Junior Dances will be held next Monday. They will benefit the New York Foundling Hospital.

The Princeton freshmen and the St. Paul's School hockey teams will meet for the thirty-eighth time at Madison Square Garden this afternoon. Playing for the Hobey Baker Memorial Stick, the teams will be marking the fifieth anniversary of the first contest between the institutions.
The fundamentals of American foreign policy which our Government also urges as a basis of an all-Western policy were outlined anew yesterday in two European capitals.
PARIS, Dec. 15 -- The 1960 United States election is beginning to cast a shadow over the European scene.

JAMES STEWART and George Gobel appeared last night in a Western version of "Cinderella" on "Startime" over Channel 4. The modernization of the fairy tale was done with engaging and amusing charm; the hour was a most pleasant one.
PARIS, Dec. 15 -- The French Cabinet yielded tonight to Roman Catholic demands for state aid to church schools.
The Coast Guard concluded yesterday its investigation of the collision between the liner Israel and the freighter American Press.
VIENNA, Dec. 15 -- The Polish Government has prohibited independent peasants from selling meat in public markets unless they have completed compulsory deliveries to the state.

HAVANA, Dec. 15 -- Maj. Hubert Matos, a hero of the Cuban revolution and former military chief of Camaguey Province, was sentenced tonight to twenty years imprisonment. A military court had convicted him of counter-revolutionary activities against the Castro regime.

In Damon Stetson's news item of Dec. 10 I find that Senator Pat McNamara of Michigan believes that the aged should have substantial increases in Social Security benefits. Senator McNamara backs up these beliefs with a list of amendments he is recommending to the Social Security Law.

MICHAEL SEMANITZKY, violinist, played a debut performance at Carnegie Recital Hall last night. The son of a Russian Orthodox priest who taught him the violin as a boy, Mr. Semanitzky received his Bachelor and Master of Music degrees from Yale University and last year received his doctorate from Columbia University.

The furious reaction of the French Government to the fact that the United States abstained from voting on the Algerian resolution in the United Nations, instead of voting against it, only points up the extreme sensitivity of President de Gaulle on this touchiest of issues.
LONDON, Dec. 15 -- The British are disappointed at the failure of President Eisenhower's special commission to move more quickly in its review of the disarmament question.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 (AP) -- The Federal Housing Administration announced today a sharp drop in November in applications for F. H. A. insurance to finance new dwellings.

Stockholders received no word yesterday as to the future of Windsor Industries, Inc., a holding company, despite their inquiries. The company, whose chief asset is a 57 per cent interest in Bates Manufacturing Company, textile producer, is controlled by the Estate of Lester Martin, which owns about 55 per cent of Windsor's stock.
The faculty of C. W. Post College in Brookville, L. I., endorsed yesterday the college's hiring of Dr. Edward V. Sittler, a former Nazi party member.

The Soviet Union will concentrate its major efforts abroad in the Nineteen Sixties amid the thickly populated countries of Asia -- from India to the tip of Indonesia -- as well as in the Middle East, Africa and the Caribbean, Allen W. Dulles predicted here yesterday.
CHICAGO, Dec. 15 (AP) -- Wheat futures were in good demand today and soored gains running to more than a cent a bushel, an increasingly rare performance for the grain lately.
The American Technion Society will establish a technological center in Israel to accelerate the industrial development of that country.
TOKYO, Wednesday, Dec. 16 -- Japan's Supreme court ruled today that stationing of United States forces here and the maintenance of Japanese defense units were legal under the postwar Constitution.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 -- A Government order prohibiting the giving of payola to television and radio disk jockeys was accepted today by the Radio Corporation of America. Payola is the practice of paying disk jockeys for plugging records.

The general reaction to a proposal to build a jet-age airport in New Jersey to service the metropolitan area produced from all sides yesterday two points of solid agreement: the plan needs lots of study and lots of time before any concrete action can be taken.

Lawyers for twenty men who attended the 1957 Apalachin gathering charged yesterday at their trial here that the Government's prosecution smacked of police-state tactics and was a threat to the integrity of the court system.
TEL AVIV, Israel, Dec. 15 -- The first Latin Patriarchal Vicar for Israel with the rank of Bishop arrived fore Rome today.
TOPEKA, Kan., Dec. 15 -- Officials at Forbes Air Force Base have announced a new policy calling for an around-the-clock check on enlisted personnel, including off-duty activities and associates.
Governor Rockefeller's recently announced highway safety program was called belated and inadequate yesterday by Democrats.
BUFFALO, Dec. 15 (UPI) - A Federal court jury convicted today Sidney Turoff, former Communist, on two counts of contempt of Congress.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 -- The New York Port Authority joined forces with the State of Georgia today in an effort to bring about stability in coastwise shipping.

ALTHOUGH most American designers present their spring fashion collections in November, the two most important trend setters. Norman Norell of Traina-Norell and James Galanos, wait until a later date, keeping the fashion press and buyers in suspense. Following is a report on the Traina-Norell collection, which has just been shown.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 -- Joint scientific meetings on cancer, heart disease and poliomyelitis will be held by the United States and the Soviet Union in 1960 and 1961.

SPANISH is becoming New York City's second language, judging from the signs in that language in many neighborhood groceries and even in some public buildings. Such messages are directed to the more than 600,000 Puerto Ricans here.

Directors of the Lehman Corporation voted yesterday the largest year-end distribution to its shareholders in its history. The declaration of $1.34 a share from capital gains aggregated $14,250,000. It will be paid on Jan. 27, along with an ordinary dividend of 16 1/2 cents a share to holders of record of Dec. 28.

CONCORD, N. H., Dec. 15 (AP) -- Gov. Wesley Powell was asked today to take command of Vice President Richard M. Nixon's political organization in New Hampshire. The nation's first Presidential primary of 1960 will be held in the state next March 8.

The Collins Radio Company attained the highest sales and earnings for any quarter in its history in the three months ended on Oct. 31, according to results announced yesterday by Arthur A. Collins, president.

THE neighborhood fight clubs of a generation ago were the vocational grammar schools of the boxing trade. The students learned their lessons in sound and solid fashion. Not until a scholar had shown marked proficiency in all subjects was he promoted to such fonts of higher education as Madison Square Garden.
PARIS, Dec. 15 -- The United States asked today for an Atlantic alliance loyal to the concept of military integration.
Both Penn State and Alabama expect to be at full strength for their meeting Saturday in the Liberty Bowl at Philadelphia Stadium, the first bowl game to be played in the East.
UNIVERSITY PARK, Pa., Dec. 15 (AP) -- Penn State has a healthy respect for Alabama, its opponent in the Liberty Bowl game.

All property owners here would be required to furnish lights on the fronts of their buildings under a bill introduced into the City Council yesterday. The measure was referred to the council's Committee on Buildings.
Senator Stephen M. Young, the "unhyphenated Democrat" from Ohio, defended last night the right of an American, to hold whatever political opinions he chose and to express them.
PATERSON, N. J., Dec. 15 -- Representative Gordon Canfield, dean of the New Jersey Congressional delegation, announced his intention today to retire on Jan. 2, 1961, when his eleventh term expired.

RUTHERFORD, N. J., Dec. 15 -- Honorary degress of Doctor of Laws were conferred on three persons by Fairleigh Dickinson University this morning in a special convocation at Grace Protestant Episcopal Church, adjacent to the campus here.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 15 -- Horace W. Brower, president of the Transamerica Corporation, announced today that the Securities and Exchange Commission had cleared the way for stockholders of the American Surety Company of New York to act on a merger with Transamerica.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 (AP) -- Farmers approved the continuation of Federal marketing quotas on upland and extra-long staple cotton, peanuts and rice in today's referenda.
WHAT happens when a food concern producing local specialties is forced to leave its native land because of war or other circumstance?

THE Philadelphia Orchestra took the season into account last night and gave its Carnegie Hall subscribers a musical sermon on the birth of Jesus. It consisted of the first three cantatas of the six that make up Bach's "Christmas Oratorio."

MOST travelers travel for fun. Some travel for a combination of fun with professional literary purposes. The two tribes bear small resemblance to each other and barely speak the same language, in spite of the fact that members of the first often read books written by members of the second.
Lewis L. Strauss called on Americans last night to make "good use" of a reservoir of goodwill he said he had found on a recent tour of the Far East.

NEW DELHI, India, Dec. 15 -- The Government made public today an account of the "harsh and inhuman" treatment that, it said, ten members of an Indian police party had suffered in Chinese Communist hands in Ladakh.
The Kudner Agency, Inc., has revamped its executive heirarchy, with some shifting of titles but little immediate change in responsibilities.
Mr. Speaker, Mr. Prime Minister, Your Beatitude [Archbishop Theoclitus, Greek Orthodox primate of Greece], excellencies, ladies and gentlemen, honorable representatives of the Hellenes:

LEOPOLDVILLE, Belgian Congo, Dec. 15 -- Joseph Kasavubu, Congolese nationalist leader returned today from an unsuccessful mission to Brussels and received an enthusiastic welcome from the Bakongo tribe.
The recent classification by the National Legion of Decency of "Suddenly Last Summer" as unsuitable for general movie audience patronage has left no visible marks of worry on the brow of Sam Spiegel.
LONDON, Dec. 15 -- Industrial issues continued to rise on the stock market here today.

New Jersey sold $66,800,000 of bonds to finance higher education yesterday to a syndicate headed by the Chase Manhattan Bank and Bankers Trust Company on a bid of 100.004 for 4, 3.40, 3 3/8 and 3 1/4 per cent coupons for a net interest cost of 3.41 per cent.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 (UPI) -- Mayors of eleven cities urged today the establishment of a Cabinet post for urban dwellers similar to the post of the Secretary of Agriculture, who represents farming people.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Dec. 15 -- The Yugoslavs news agency Tanyug quoted Anton Yugov, Premier of Bulgaria, as saying today that non-Communist countries were welcome to join the Soviet-sponsored East European Council for Mutual Economic Assistance if they desired.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 -- G. Frederick Reinhardt, State Department counselor, has been selected as Ambassador to the United Arab Republic.

ROME, Dec. 15 -- The cause for the beatification of Elizabeth Anne Seton, the New York woman better known as Mother Seton, entered its final stage today. It is foreseen that she will be proclaimed "venerable" on Friday and that her beatification in St. Peter's will follow in 1960.

RICHMOND, Va., Dec. 15 -- A nonprofit organization to provide private schools for Negro children in Prince Edward County, where all public schools have been closed to avoid integration, was chartered by the State Corporation Commission here today.

Never before in the history of automobile racing have so many of the outstanding figures of the sport been together as at Sebring, Fla., last week for the first Sebring Championship Grand Prix. The reasons were many.
A gift in memory of a young pilot who was lost in action in World War II was received yesterday by the fund for New York's Neediest Cases.

Henry Cabot Lodge said yesterday that the refusal of the United States to include Hungary on the United Nations Outer Space Committee would have produced a "breaking point" in his negotiations with the Soviet Union.
HOUSTON, Tex., Dec. 15 -- Anheuser - Busch, Inc., of St. Louis has taken a 120-day option on a fifty-acre tract of land here as the site of a multimillion-dollar brewery.
With the exception of some small details the city completed setting the stage yesterday for Christmas.
PARIS, Dec. 15 -- Secretary of State Christian A. Herter stilled many doubts about United States intentions toward Europe with his speech to the Atlantic Council today.
LOS ANGELES, Dec. 15 (AP) -- The Air Force claimed a world altitude record today, as Capt. Joe B. Jordan flew a F-104C Star-fighter to 103,395.5 feet.
The City Council was urged yesterday to appoint a committee to spur the school construction program.
LONDON, Dec. 15 (Reuters) -- British scientists have discovered a drug they say can kill bacteria "immune" to penicillin.

Atlas Corporation's performance this year was about the same "marketwise and asset-value-wise" as that of the large closed-end and mutual funds, Floyd B. Oldum, chairman, told some 300 stockholders at a special meeting yesterday in the Roosevelt Hotel.
ALBANY, Dec. 15 (AP) -"Don't shoot those guns! Don't hurt the children!" a teacher screamed as two armed men chased another man into a kindergarten classroom today.

An all-Tchaikovsky program by the Moscow State Symphony on the evening of Jan. 17 will benefit Recording for the Blind, Inc. Konstantin Ivanov will conduct the Carnegie Hall concert, and Valeri Klimov, winner of the 1958 Tchaikovsky competition, will appear as violin soloist.
MOSCOW, Dec. 15 -- The Second International Tchaikovsky Music Competition will be held in Moscow in 1962 from April 2 to May 7.

AUSTIN, Tex., Dec. 15 -- A Texan's red white and blue membership card in the Senator Lyndon B. Johnson for President Club carries a pledge to go "all the way with L. B. J." There is a growing feeling here that the members may be asked to do just that.

CINCINNATI, Dec. 15 (AP) -- The Cincinnati Reds traded their ace second baseman, Johnny Temple, to the Cleveland Indians tonight for Cal McLish, a pitcher; Billy Martin, a second baseman, and Gordon Coleman, a first baseman.
PARIS, Dec. 14 -- President Charles de Gaulle said today that a formula should be sought for the Atlantic alliance that fell between integration of forces and a simple coalition.
JACKSONVILLE, Fla., Dec. 15 (AP) -- A Federal grand jury indicted a former captain of the guard, his lieutenant and twelve guards at Raiford State Prison today on charges of abusing prisoners.
ROCKLAND SOUND, Island of Eleuthera, Bahamas -- Juan Fernandez, captain of Eleuthera's Rock Sound fishing fleet, and his wife Carol usually can be relied on for some fishing talk.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 (AP) -- The Food and Drug Administration announced improved methods that are expected to cut in half the time and cost of testing cranberries for the weed-killer aminotriazole before the Christmas holidays. But the agency refused to clear berries not yet tested.

The National Art Museum of Sports, a new educational institution chartered by the Board of Regents of the University of the State of New York, was formed yesterday. Its basic purpose is to increase appreciation of art by familiarizing the sports-minded public with work of art in the sports field and to provide inspiration for new work.
The student body of the United States Merchant Marine Academy does not think very highly of its superintendent or the school's administration, Congressional investigators were told here yesterday.
A narcotics suspect was over-powered shortly after noon yesterday in Eighty-sixth Street after he had fired three revolver shots at two Federal narcotics agents at close range.

CHICAGO, Dec. 15 -- Sybil Shearer and her dance company gave a special performance in near-by Winnetka this afternoon, at the request of the Institute of International Education. The particular guests were three visitors from Brazil, India and Indonesia who are in this country on grants from the State Department as participants in the program of the Committee on Leaders and Specialists of the American Council of Education.

CHICAGO, Dec. 15 -- Plans of Eastern railroads to reduce drastically freight rates on grain shipped from down-state Illinois points without corresponding rate adjustments in Chicago and to Western shippers was assailed today by the Chicago Board of Trade as "unlawful discrimination."

Switching of cocoa holdings from March to May and to September and from July to new December accounter for more than hailf of the active trading yesterday on the New York Cocoa Exchange. Trade selling and speculator liquidation lowered prices.
The Transit Authority promised yesterday to hold subway and bus fares at 15 cents "if at all possible."
WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 -(AP) -- A Senate subcommittee was told today that Government agencies might be buying pocket-size devices that could secretly record conversations.
LIKE the best things in life, many of this season's biggest shows are free. They are the lavish Yuletide spectacles in the windows of department stores here.
CHICAGO, Dec. 15 -- Farm leaders appeared somewhat puzzled today by Governor Rockefeller's proposal for "farm stabilization" supports.

MacRae Cook gave a Town Hall piano recital last night that had at least one unusual aspect. Not one work on the program could be considered familiar. Bach's "Four Duets," which enjoyed a brief vogue about ten years ago, have not been heard often since then; nor is the Rachmaninoff Second Sonata much of a visitor.

DURING its thirty-year life the Museum of Modern Art has periodically put on group exhibitions of work by contemporary American artists that can generally be looked at in the light of "New Talent" shows.

Thousands of home-bound workers and Christmas shoppers were delayed near the end of the evening rush hour yesterday when a derailment on the BMT subway halted all service on that line from Manhattan to Queens.
WASHINGTON Dec. 15 (UPI) -- Following is the text of John L. Lewis' letter to members of the United Mine Workers, announcing his intention to resign as president of the union:
A resolution introduced in the City Council yesterday called for a Council inquiry into reports that radio car policemen are required to issue a monthly minimum quota of traffic summonses.

Frank Moraes, author of "Jawaharlal Nehru" and "Report on Mao's China," has two new books on Macmillan's list. Scheduled for Jan. 25 is "The Revolt in Tibet," a history that opens with an account of the Dalai Lama's flight from Lhasa.
ST. LOUIS, Dec. 15 (AP) -- The San Francisco Giants acquired a second baseman, Don Blasingame, from the St. Louis Cardinals for an infielder, Daryl Spencer, and an outfielder, Leon Wagner, today.
CHICAGO, Dec. 15 (AP) -- The report of today's livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:

The City Council's budgetmaking role was tartly labeled a "farce" yesterday by Joseph T. Sharkey, Council vice chairman and majority leader. Mr. Sharkey urged that the Council be given staff and power to become a "whip" over city administrations.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 (UPI) -- A $500,000 offer for Harmon Killebrew by the Cincinnati Reds was spurned by the Washington Senators.
One of the most curious aspects of the opposition to birth control is that it comes from Marxists as well as from Roman Catholics.
WHEN the dummy seems likely to use its small trumps to ruff the defenders' strong suit, the best defense usually is to lead trumps and try to prevent dummy from rufffing.

" The end of the post-war era of easy, almost automatic dollar supremacy" is over, the latest issue of the Morgan Guaranty Trust Company's monthly survey reports. In an article entiled "The Dollar -- at Home and Abroad" the bank discusses the reasons for the decline in the United States' gold reserves.

Bobby Fischer, the 16-year-old chess champion of the United States, will be just another kibitzer for this year's national tournament. It became official yesterday that he would not compete in the event which starts here Friday.
CONCORD, N. H., Dec. 15 (AP) -- The New Hampshire Supreme Court today took under advisement a plea to free Dr. Willard Uphaus from jail pending the outcome of his appeal from a contempt conviction.

A BOARD U. S. S. ESSEX in the Mediterranean, Dec. 15 -- President Eisenhower concluded the most strenuous phase of his nineteen-day goodwill tour today and put into th Mediterranean for two days of rest at sea.

St. John's, playing with secondstring sophomores during the entire seocnd half, defeated Brooklyn College, 88 -- 49, at the Martin Van Buren High School gymnasium in Queens Village last night. The victory was the fourth in six starts of the Redmen. The Kingsmen have a 1-4 record.
DAR ES SALAAM, Tanganyika, Dec. 15 -- Tanganyika will receive internal self government next year.
Gov. Robert T. Stafford of Vermont said yesterday his state would support either a Nixon-Rockefeller or a RockefellerNixon ticket in next year's presidential election.

NORFOLK, Va., Dec. 15 (AP) -- Coast Guard planes searched from Cape Henry, Va., to Bermuda today, looking for two young men who left here for Bermuda in a seventeen-foot boat Nov. 18 and have not been heard from since.

CHICAGO, Dec. 15 -- Dr. Herrell F. DeGraff of Cornell University and the late Herbert W. Vorhees of Hopewell. N. J., were cited by the American Farm Bureau Federation today for "distinguished and meritorious service to agriculture."
MEXICO CITY, Dec. 15 -- The Administration of President Adolfo Lopez Mateos presented to Congress today a 1960 budget for 10,251,341,000 pesos (approximately $820,107,000).

LOS ANGELES, Dec. 13 (UPI) -- Don Clark resigned today as head football coach at the University of Southern California after one of the most successful seasons in modern Trojan history. His assistant, John McKay, was named as his successor.

Two floors containing 20,000 square feet of space in 80 Broad Street have been leased by R. C. A. Communications, Inc., for its accounting and I. B. M. departments. W. E. Dean Co. were the brokers. The floors will be used by the lessee during construction of a new building at Broad and Beaver Streets in which it will have its headquarters.
Thoroughbred racing broke all attendance, parimutuel turnover and revenue to the states in 1959, the annual Associated Press survey showed yesterday.
CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla., Dec. 15 (AP) -- The commander of the missile test center removed a one-day restriction today on news coverage.
Shareholders of the United Industrial Corporation at their meeting in Detroit and those of Topp Industries, Inc., at their meeting in Phoenix, yesterday approved plans to merge the companies.

ATHENS, Dec. 15 (UPI) -- Mrs. John S. D. Eisenhower, the President's daughter-in-law, went today to the hospital bedside of a little boy critically injured during the welcome for the President yesterday to stroke the boy's cheek and give sympathy to his mother.

A gang of Bronx youths came back to their own neighborhood from a night of drinking and went down a line of parked automobiles smashing the windows and denting the hoods by jumping on them. Asked why they did it by the arresting officers, they said only, "We were out looking for trouble."

DES MOINES, Iowa, Dec. 15 -- John Kyl, Republican, running on the issue of "peace" against his Democratic opponent's "anti-Benson campaign," won election tonight as Representative from Iowa's Fourth District.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 (AP) -- Harmon Killebrew's early season home-run barrage was a big factor in raising attendance at Griffith Stadium almost 30 per cent. The Senators had 615,372 paid customers last season, again low in the majors.

LONDON, Dec. 15 -- The British Overseas Airways Corporation is to cut fares between 10 and 20 per cent below existing tourist fares on routes between Britain and her colonies and territories in the West Indies, Africa and the Far East.

Two investment banking groups entered identical bids for $30,000,000 in debentures yesterday and saved the offerer -- the Bell Telephone Company of Pennsylvania -$42,030 in a rebidding. Syndicates headed by Halsey, Stuart Co., and the First Boston Corporation both bid 101.7199, stipulating a 5 3/8 per cent coupon, for the thirty-five year issue.
Helen Hayes, Laurance S. Rockefeller, and Dr. Jonas E. Salk received the 1959 Gold Medal Awards of the National Institute of the Social Sciences last night at an annual dinner.
An ambitious program has been formulated by Richard Barr and H. B. Lutz to mark their entry as a producing team. They will cater to the off-Broadway trade in a venture named Theatre 1960.

MIAMI BEACH, Dec. 15 -- The International Brotherhood of Teamsters is demanding "continuous sessions" with the board of monitors in the hope of getting a speedy union election and dissolving the court-appointed board.
A Queens mother and daughter were attacked by a robber in their Sunnyside apartment early yesterday morning, with the mother, Mrs. Anna Senft, 75 years old, receiving critical injuries.
The City Planning Commission moved yesterday to speed school construction in East Harlem.
The Federal Government joined Columbia University and the lower East Side yesterday in a joint attack on juvenile delinquency and crime.
A dozen court officers attached to Special Sessions vowed yesterday to work on their own time until a prisoner who escaped on Monday evening was captured.

OUT of Sholem Aleichem's heartwarming tales of the shtetl of Eastern Europe -- the Jewish hamlets and ghettos of a distant yesteryear's renascence -- David Licht has extracted "Thousand and One Nights."
LONDON, Dec. 15 -- King Hussein of Jordan indicated today that the problem of the Palestine refugees might be dealt with as part of a settlement of the whole Palestine question.

SQUAW VALLEY, Calif., Dec. 15 (UPI) -- Housing is plentiful at Squaw Valley and in the immediate neighborhood, despite some propaganda that everything is "filled up" for the Olympic winter games Feb. 18-28.

The brief visit which President Eisenhower will pay to Tunisia today is an act of courtesy that has full justification. Wesley Powell of New Hampshire has descended from his political Mount Washington to head the state group which supports the Presidential candidacy of Richard M. Nixon completes the commitment of that state's most influential Republicans to the Vice President.
Bobby Fischer, the national chess champion, who was dropped from this year's tournament after a dispute on the pairings, was supported in his stand yesterday by his replacement.
The issue of United States policy toward the limitation of births in other countries has brought forth a number of inconsistent and irrelevant statements from persons high in Government circles.
MINNEAPOLIS, Dec. 16 (UPI) -- Gov. Orville L. Freeman told a Federal court today he had closed a strike-torn meat plant in Albert Lea for fear "somebody was going to be killed" on the picket lines.

This likely will be denied, but there was a report around town that when the cleaning squad in the Squibb Building entered the Yankee suite on the twenty-ninth floor early yesterday morning, George Weiss was found sound asleep at his desk, a telephone still at his el bow.

The present and future role of France in world politics is examined in a forthcoming book by Edgar S. Furniss Jr., associate Professor of Politics at Princeton University. To be called "France, Troubled Ally," it will be published Jan. 6 by Harper for the Council on Foreign Relations.
A number of high-level executive appointments at the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company were announced yesterday by Frederic W. Ecker, chairman, to take effect on Jan. 1.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 (AP) -- The State Department said today it was not committed to encouraging exchanges of labor leaders between the United States and the Soviet Union.
HONOLULU, Dec. 16 (AP) -- Forty-one seamen, most of them Dutch, rode three drifting vessels today in stormy Pacific seas. Navy and civilian ships went to the rescue.

Entertainment Productions, Inc., which owned and produced "The $64,000 Question," will go out of business soon. A move already has been started to liquidate the assets of the company, which at one time was a major independent packager and producer of radio and television programs.
GREEN BAY, Wis., Dec. 16 -- Governor Rockefeller promised today to divest himself of any securities that might cause a conflict if he were to become President.

Ten buildings containing 600 apartments in St. Louis are under contract of sale to Benjamin Schaffer, New York lawyer and realty investor, and Sidney Schwartz, realty operator. They are buying the properties from the Mary R. Wolff Management Company.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 (AP) -- Interhandel, a Swiss holding company that has been trying since 1949 to regain control of General Aniline Film Corporation, today won a legal side issue.
The Board of Estimate has been caught in the middle of a fight between citizen groups and the Consolidated Edison Company over the future of the Willard Parker Hospital site.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 (UPI) -- General Nielsen's canceling of the surveillance system failed today to quiet Senate demands for an explanation.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 -- Tunisia is the smallest and the youngest of the eleven countries on President Eisenhower's goodwill tour. Its area is only 48,300 square miles (about the size of Louisiana); its population is about 3,800,000; its annual gross national product is only $620,000,000, and its independence dates from March 20, 1956.
LONDON, Dec. 16 -- The Hawker Siddeley Group and de Havilland Holdings, two of Britain's major aircraft manufacturers, announced tonight that they had agreed to merge.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 17 -- A colleague's contention that United States alignment with dictators in the Middle East and Asia was hurting its efforts for "peace in freedom" was challenged today by Senator Gale W. McGee, Democrat of Wyoming.

B. H. WRAGGE, who personifies the American look in sportswear, has taken a leaf from the notebook of a French vintner. Starting with the cruise and resort collection that is now available at Bonwit Teller, Wragge clothes will be dated by year just like a Burgundy or Beaujolais.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 17 (AP) -- Harold Gross, Teamster official accused of mishandling union funds and taking pay-offs from employers, resigned two weeks ago as head of Local 320 in Miami, Fla., union headquarters said today.
HAVANA, Dec. 17 -- The Rev. Dr. Arthur L. Miller, moderator of the General Assembly of the United Presbyterian Church in the U. S. A., said today that American sentiment in a nineday tour of Cuba.

The grand jury that is trying to determine whether Hulan E. Jack committed an illegal act in permitting Sidney J. Ungar to pay for redecorating his apartment will consider at least two sections of the City Charter and three of the Penal Law.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 17 -- Nine African nations asked Secretary General Dag Hammarskjold today to take "appropriate action" in the "shooting and killing of many innocent and unarmed" inhabitants of South-West Africa.

BERNARR MacFADDEN, who was the chief apostle of physical culture for more than fifty years, once started an annual contest to select the world's most perfectly proportioned man. He abandoned the contest after five years because Charles Atlas always won it.

The Rheem Manufacturing Company is expanding its activities into Mexico with the purchase of a 40 per cent interest in Rassini S. A., of Mexico City for $500,000 in cash. A Lightfoot Walker, president of Rheem, said yesterday that Rassini was the largest automobile spring manufacturer in Mexico.

PARIS, Dec. 17 -- West Germany's case for maintaining the present status of West Berlin in negotiations with the Soviet Union was put briefly to the final session of the Atlantic Alliance's Ministerial Council today.

PRINCETON, N. J., Dec. 17 -- Upsets highlighted openinground action of the twelfth annual Lawrenceville School invitation hockey tournament today. Only two of the four topseeded teams, Ridley College and the University of Toronto School, triumphed.
Holiday travel gathered momentum yesterday.
TOKYO, Dec. 17 (UPI) -The year 1960 should see a distinct rise in the export of Japanese transistor equipment to the United States, particularly with the introduction of portable transistor TV sets.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 17 (UPI) -- The Atomic Energy Commission said today it was trying to recover more than 600 Swiss wrist watches because several had been found to contain too much radioactive strontium 90.
VAUGHN, N. M., Dec. 17 (UPI) -- At least 800 stranded travelers drove to freedom today. Snow had trapped some for forty-eight hours.

FULTON, Miss., Dec. 17 (UPI) -- The world's biggest balloon, lost in the stratosphere over the mid-continental United States for nearly two days, was found punctured and deflated in a North Mississippi pine woods today.
Borough President Hulan E. Jack was accused yesterday of "frustrating and obstructing" the Board of Education in its efforts to obtain its preferred site for a new Harlem school.

For ten years Sol Hurok, the impresario, has dreamed of importing an entire British military pageant of the type known as a tournament or tattoo and usually associated with Edinburgh and Aldershot. Yesterday he announced that he would do so next June in connection with the planned British Trade Exhibition.
PARIS, Dec. 17 -- Western diplomats are beginning to worry that the display of aches and squabbles of the North Atlantic alliance might make the Russians overconfident.
The Board of Missions in North and South America of the Lutheran Church-Missouri Synod has applied for membership in the Division of Home Missions of the National Council of Churches.

Sir Winston Churchill's sixvolume memoirs covering world history from 1919 to 1957 will provide the basis for a weekly half-hour film series to be televised next fall by the American Broadcasting Company.
TUNIS, Dec. 17 -- President Eisenhower brought a message of peace to Tunisia today and highest official circles expressed their belief in his sympathy for Tunisian needs and ideas.
CHICAGO Dec. 17 -- Vandalism was reported today for the first time in the interracial housing dispute in suburban Deerfield.

Hulan E. Jack lives in a grimy six-story tenement building at 45 West 110th Street. His closest neighbor is Mrs. Fannie Hamilton, a 68-year-old widow who used to inspect gas masks for the Army and who is now on pension.
LONDON, Dec. 17 -- Prime Minister Macmillan told the House of Commons today that Britain had never supported what was called disengagement.

Sales of mutual funds in November were the lowest for any month this year, according to statistics released yesterday by the National Association of Investment Companies. Sales at $165,250,000, compared with $183,083,000 in October but remained well above the $159,829,000 reported in November, 1958.

Tikhon Khrennikov and Dmitri Shostakovich, two of the Russian composers who toured the United States in the fall, have praised some American music and musicians but attacked the practice and teaching of twelve-tone music in this country.
PLEASANTON, Calif., Dec. 17 (UPI) -- A group of ninetysix volunteers emerged from an underground fall-out shelter after two weeks today, eager for baths, shaves and good solid food.

The New York, New Haven and Hartford Railroad, which is having financial difficulties, today is going to be asked by holders of 131,385 shares of its $5 preferred stock to pay them $75 a share for the stock, although it closed yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange at $10.62 1/2 a share.
In testimony before the state's Nelson Commission, I. D. Robbins of the City Club of New York contrasted value of real estate in condemnation with assessed value for municipal taxation.

SUMMIT, N. J., Dec. 17 -This city and near-by New Providence announced today the adoption of resolutions opposing the Port Authority's proposal to locate a jet airport in the Great Swamp area of Morris County.

MIAMI, Dec 17 -- The International Brotherhood of Teamsters said today it would seek a reconsideration and clarification of several interpretations of the new labor law given by James P. Mitchell, Labor Secretary.

Promotion of officers of four New York City banks was announced yesterday. Louis Miller has been elected senior vice president of The Williamsburgh Savings Bank, Brooklyn. Formerly a vice president, Mr. Miller has been with the bank more than thirty years.

Every opera house needs expert singing actors who can bring character and distinction to parts just below the starring roles. William Wildermann, American bass, has proved one of the Metropolitan Opera most valuable acquisitions in this category.
STANLEYVILLE, Belgian Congo, Dec. 17 (Reuters) -- King Baudouin of Belgium arrived in this troubled territory today to a stormy reception from African demonstrators shouting for "independence."

A Columbia University professor and a United Nations translator joined about 200 Esperantists here last night to mark the 100th anniversary of the birth of Dr. L. L. Zamenhof, the originator of Esperanto.
PARIS, Dec. 17 -- The Atlantic alliance today adopted strategy to reach its political, military and economic goals in the period of negotiations with the Soviet Union.
Increases in the prices of aluminum were announced by two more producers yesterday. day.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Dec. 17 -- Yugoslav sources assess recent changes in the Soviet bloc as outward indications of efforts by Moscow to tighten ranks before East-West negotiations.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Dec. 17 -- There have been many movies about men convicted because of mistaken identity. But today there came to light here a true story that strongly indicates a man was condemned without knowing he had been tried.
Adlai E. Stevenson says the time may be approaching "when the arms race with Russia can be arrested."

BUD WILKINSON, the coach at Oklahoma, is a man with charm, intelligence and the knack of turning out successful football teams. So vivid is his personality that it appears to make carbon-copy imprints on all proteges he sends into the coaching ranks. They all seem to have the same charm, intelligence and pattern for success.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 17 (AP) -- The Department of Agriculture set 1960 sugar requirements for the nation at 9,400,000 short tons, raw value, and apportioned this amount among eligible supplying areas today.
Maybe Slingin' Sammy Baugh will be back trying to win football games at the Polo Grounds next year.

Servel, Inc., for the fiscal year ended Oct. 31 had a net income of about $3,088,000, according to a preliminary report issued yesterday by Duncan C. Menzies, president. The profit, which included $670,000 of non-recurring income, was equal after preferred dividend requirements to $1.64 a share on 1,766,345 shares of common stock outstanding.
Any slight chance that New Yorkers might receive transit peace as a Christmas gift disappeared yesterday.

Robert Moses said yesterday that it would cost $250,000,000 to clear and redevelop nearly 00 acres of remaining Rockaway slums. But he asserted that potential builders were being deterred by irresponsible criticisms.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 17 (AP) -- Representative Gordon H. Scherer, Republican of Ohio, replied today to an attack on him by Senator Stephen M. Young, Democrat of Ohio. Mr. Scherer said Communists often selected "other people to do their dirty work."

Sidney S. Korzenik, executive director and counsel of the Knitted Outerwear Association, criticized the Japanese Government in a talk last evening for disregarding its self-imposed quota on exports of sweaters to the United States.
MONTREAL, Dec. 17 (UPI) -- The Montreal Canadiens swamped the Toronto Maple Leafs, 8 -- 2, tonight in a game enlivened by a second-period brawl in which ten players were banished.

SEVERAL local grocers report reluctantly that sales of fresh and processed cranberries are, as one of them put it, "not up to snuff." This is so even though the berries are certified as free of aminatriazole, the chemical that has caused cancer in laboratory mice.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 17 (AP) -- The net working capital of United States corporations reached a record of $126,900,000,000 on Oct. 1, the Securities and Exchange Commission reported today.

I should like to second the complaint of your correspondent who, in a letter of Dec. 10, finds loudspeakers on subway trains irritating and useless. On the Lexington Avenue locals I can understand what is meant by Brooklyn Britch, but what does anyone, especially a stranger, make of Astpless, for Astor Place, and Wart for Worth?

LESLIE PARNAS is an American 'cellist with a future. His gifts as a musician, which have brought him several important international prizes, are an earnest of an impressive career. In addition, he has the understanding support of his home town.
HWALIEN, Taiwan, Dec. 17 -- The eastern side of Taiwan, where narrow strips of coastal plain are pinched against the sea by forest-cloaked mountains, is the new frontier of Nationalist China.

Engineers have frozen a column of mud, quicksand and earth near Avenue D and Thirteenth Street in order to sink a sewer-pipe shaft without endangering surrounding buildings through possible earth slides. The frozen area is 43 feet in diameter and 123 feet deep.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange fell yesterday 1 to 12 points. A point is equal to 5 cents a bale.

George R. Hinman of Sands Point, L. I., and the other flag officers were re-elected at the annual meeting of the New York Yacht Club last night in the West Forty-fourth Street clubhouse. Hinman, whose flagship is the forty-one-foot auxiliary cruising sloop Sagola, became commodore for a second term. Those also re-] elected were H.j Irving Pratt, viceI corn modore ;I Chauncey Stillman, rear commodore; W. Mahlon Dickerson, secretary, I and DeCoursey Fales, treasurer.

Borough President Hulan E. Jack acknowledged publicly yesterday that Sidney J. Ungar had paid the bill for the remodeling of his apartment.
CONROY, Iowa, Dec. 17 (AP) -- "You did a pretty good job," said a high school fan, "pretty good, that is, for a girl."
LONDON, Dec. 17 -- Demand was again selective on the stock market here today and small losses predominated in the industrial lists.
POINT PLEASANT, W. Va., Dec. 17 (AP) -- Capt. Thomas Jefferson Reynolds, who for forty-five years piloted showboats on the Ohio River and its tributaries, was killed last night.

A proposal to add ninety-one acres to the 540-acre Alley Park on the Queens north shore was killed yesterday by the Board of Estimate. The vote was 20 to 2.
The softening of basic training methods for the military services reflects in large measure the social mores and customs of the nation.
The Board of Education reinstated two teachers yesterday who had been suspended without pay four years ago as the result of an investigation into alleged Communist influence in the school system.

Events today: New York Philharmonic, Leonard Bernstein, conductor-pianist, David Keiser, Carlos Mosely, pianists, Schola Cantorum, Carnegie Hall, 2:15 P. M.; Twentieth Century Chamber Music, chamber orchestra conducted by Gustav Meier, Carnegie Recital Hall, 5:30; "Tristan und Isolde," Metropolitan Opera, 7:30; Down Town Glee Club, Carnegie Hall, 8:30; Mount Holyoke College Glee Club, Town Hall, 8:30; Jules Eskin, cellist, with John Covelli, pianist, Carnegie Recital Hall, 8:30.

Jack Brause, realty investor, has contracted to buy the four-story loft building at 801 Avenue of the Americas (Sixth Avenue), near Twenty-seventh Street. He is negotiating a long-term lease of the store, now vacant, for occupancy as a sandwich shop.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 17 -The Inter-American Conference scheduled to open in Quito, Ecuador, Feb. 1, will probably be postponed for many months, officials here said today.
The New England Confectionery Company, with billings estimated at $1,000,000 a year, has awarded its advertising account to Kenyon Eckhardt, Inc.

Dr. Edward V. Sittler, who renounced his citizenship to broadcast Nazi propaganda during the war, tried unsuccessfully yesterday to regain it. He was turned down on a point of procedure, but was told he could reapply.
CHICAGO, Dec. 17 (AP) -Bill Veeck the owner of the White Sox, has come up with another new gimmick to lure fans -- a picnic area under the left field stands.

The Missouri -Kansas -Texas Railroad has obtained more than the minimum number of customers it will need for its planned $60,000,000 liquefied petroleum products gas pipeline and is endeavoring to arrange financing for the project.

The case of twenty men charged with conspiring to obstruct justice by lying to the Government about the purpose of the 1957 Apalachin gathering went to a Federal Court jury here yesterday. After deliberating for more than seven hours, the jury was locked up for the night.

Leaders of 35,000 unionized hotel workers here called on Mayor Wagner yesterday to demonstrate the sincerity of his desire for higher wage standards by recommending a city law for a pay floor of $1.25 an hour.

PARIS, Dec. 17 -- Admiral Jerauld Wright, retiring commander of the Atlantic sector of the North Atlantic alliance, indicated today an increasing level of Soviet submarine activity around Allied waters.
LONG BEACH, Calif., Dec. 17 (UPI) -- A Liberian freighter sank in heavy seas early today, but the United States Coast Guard reported that all fifteen persons aboard had been rescued.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 17 -Forty-one Alabama football players, wearing topcoats that reeked of camphor on this unwonted post-season invasion of the North, checked in today for their Liberty Bowl game against Penn State on Saturday.

Heavy buying of hides by shoe manufacturers for spring needs as well as for next fall and winter was noted yesterday at the fifty-sixth semi-annual Leather Show sponsored by the Tanners Council of America, Inc.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 17 -- The chairman of the court-appointed teamster monitors, today accused James R. Hoffa, the union president of adding to his union's bills in an effort to save his job. Mr. Hoffa has been quoted as blaming the monitors, for increases in costs that he estimates at $500,000 a year.
Hearings ended yesterday on a suit by Roosevelt Raceway seeking reimbursement from the state for $3,300,000 in Federal income taxes. State Supreme Court Justice Arthur Markewich reserved decision.

Ever since gunpowder turned sword fighting into a sport, devotees of the art of fencing have kept alive its old world traditions of fierce individual competition, perfect physical control and suave French and Italian phrases.

PROVIDENCE. Dec. 17 (AP) -- Tommy Heinsohn and Bob Cousy ushered Boston to a 137-126 National Basketball Association victory over New York tonight as the Celtics won their tenth straight victory.

Directors of the Amoskeag company yesterday voted a dividend of $2 a share, payable to common stockholders on Dec. 18. This raises distributions this year to $3 from $2.50 paid in 1958.

Dr. Alvin S. Johnson, the educator, who is 85 today, is so confident about the future that he'd like to "hang around" for ten more years. He thinks he would be "rather amused" looking back at the worries of the Nineteen Fifties.

Many of the debutantes of the season, their escorts and their parents will celebrate New Year's Eve at the twentieth Mayfair Assembly, which will be held in the Roof Garden of the Pierre. The party is being arranged by Miss Clementine Miller.
A Brooklyn youth was captured yesterday after a two-mile chase in which the police fired twelve shots. The pursuit ended when the youth's automobile, reported stolen Wednesday, rammed a patrol car.

The Strategic Air Command is not planning to spy on the private lives of its enlisted personnel. The project, announced at Topeka on Tuesday by Brig. Gen. Ariel W. Nielsen, was disavowed on Wednesday.

QUANTICO, Va., Dec. 17 (AP) -- The Quantico Marines, led by Joedy Gardner and Jack Sullivan, downed Jacksonville University, 99 -- 85, tonight and won their own Christmas invitation basketball tournament for the fifth time in six years.
With Christmas just a week away, gifts and messages to the Fund for New York's Neediest Cases mounted yesterday. A total of $17,265.02 from 628 donors was received during the day.

Your editorial of Dec. 8, "Reprieve for Mideast Aid" which states: "a million Arab refugees could not be 'repatriated' in what is now the State of Israel," is the Israeli official position, as a result of which the United Nations is at an impasse on a solution to the problem.

The Theatre Guild and Joel Schenker are the latest owners of "All Women Are One." Faith in the comedy, the first play written by Ben Kerner, author of documentary and training films, had been manifested by various managements.
A Manhattan-bound BMT express train broke down in the middle of the Williamsburg Bridge in last night's rush hour, causing a forty-minute disruption of train service across the span.

BALTIMORE, Dec. 17 (AP) An eagle-eyed football fan claims he saw Johnny Unitas, the Baltimore Colts' quarterback, tipping off plays 3,000 miles away.

National Bellas Hess, Inc., apparel and shoe mail-order and retail chain, is offering today to its stockholders $5,318,800 of 25-year subordinated convertible debentures at par. The New York Telephone Company disclosed yesterday that it had begun sending letters to its 375,000 subscribers having unlisted telephone numbers to explain plans for a 50-cents-a-month charge.

The New York Times Weekly Index of Business Activity climbed to an historic high of 229 in the week ended last Saturday. That figure compared with the previous record of 227.8, set in the week ended on June 13.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 17 -Railroad and truck loadings of freight dipped slightly last week. Indications are that a leveling off period has been reached, and will continue the rest of the year.

EUGENE BERMAN has meant different things to different people. To music lovers he is known as the designer or brilliant, somewhat rococo opera sets. To bibliophiles, he is known as an outstanding book illustrator.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 17--The by-election in the Fourth Congressional District of Iowa this week was by no means a sure sign that the Republicans will recapture their ancient voting majority in the Farm Belt. Nor was their victory, in getting back from the Democrats a Congressional seat a Republican had always filled until 1958, an event on which to base a claim of nationwide party "resurgence."
Oscar Robertson of Cincinnati, in quest of a third national scoring championship, has gotten off to the fastest start in collegiate basketball history with an average of 43 points a game.

Sylvia Zaremba, playing last night at the Metropolitan Museum, gave most of her piano recital under difficulties. She injured the index finger of her right hand during the Ravel "Gaspard de la Nuit" and played the rest of the recital in severe pain.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 17 (AP) -- The Department of Commerce said today that export statistics did not support what it called a widespread impression that American manufacturers were losing their foreign markets.
Vincent Rao, a reputed underworld leader in East Harlem, was one of the landlords summoned to Housing Court yesterday by the city's Health Department.

Consumption of newsprint in this country set records in November and for the first eleven months of 1959.

Charley Conerly, quarterback; Alex Webster, halfback; Mel Triplett, fullback, 27.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 17 (AP) -- Prospects for a settlement of the longshoremen's dispute in Gulf ports looked bleak today, but officials were hopeful of developments over the week-end.

Muzz Patrick, the general manager of the New York Rangers, said yesterday that the National Hockey League club had renewed its working agreement with the Springfield Indians, the pace-setting team in the American Hockey League.

PRINCETON, N. J., Dec. 17 -- Larry Brennan turned in the finest performances of his career tonight as he tallied 25 points to lead Princeton to a 79-63 victory over Rutgers in basketball at Dillon Gymnasium.

CHICAGO, Dec. 17 (AP) -- The Government's final 1959 crop report sent soybean futures into their steepest and fastest decline of the year today. All contracts hit new low prices for the season on losses running to 6 cents a bushel.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 17 (UPI) -- House investigators looking into television practices announced today that they had subpoenaed the records of the nation's largest TV monitoring service to check how certain programs actually went out over the air.
MONROEVILLE, Ala., Dec. 17 (UPI) -- Monroeville's Christmas parade was called off today because the Ku Klux Klan had threatened violence if a Negro high school band were included.

Roger Touhy spent nearly twenty-six years in jail and twenty-three days out of jail before the gunmen caught up with him. The shooting, by men who reportedly identified themselves as policemen, reminds old-timers of famous gangland slayings in the Twenties and Thirties.

Ty Cobb, who will be 73 today, made a plea yesterday on behalf of his contemporaries, gave his views on such current matters as the proposed third major league and the 1960 pennant races, and hailed what he called "the comeback of the stolen base" in baseball.
A new wage agreement covering 50,000 workers of the major aluminum companies was reported near last night.
PARIS, Dec. 17 (AP) -- President Eisenhower will forsake jet plane, helicopter and ship tomorrow as he travels 550 miles across France by train for eight and a half hours.

Potato futures registered one of the sharpest drops of the year on the New York Produce Exchange yesterday. Volume was the heaviest of the year. Prices tumbled 11 to 18 points (hundredths of a cent a pound) on 2.808 car lots (50,000 pounds to a car).
BEIRUT, Lebanon, Dec. 17 -- The possibility of uniting the Orthodox churches has been investigated on a month-long tour of the Middle East by Patriarch Athenagoras.

Simon B. Blumenthal was surprised with a gift of a gold cigarette case on the floor of the New York Stock Exchange yesterday. Exchange Chairman Edward C. Werle made the presentation during the morning's trading.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 17 (AP) -- G. I. home loan activity continued to dwindle during November, the Veterans Administration reported today.

NEWARK, Dec. 17 -- The orderly development of the Port of New York requires Federal assistance in improving ship channels in Newark Bay and the Passaic and Hackensack Rivers, a public hearing was told today.
ROME, Dec. 17 -- Pope John XXIII completed today the installation of seven Cardinals with colorful ceremonies.

Tickets still remain for the Jan. 14 performance of "The Fighting Cock" at the ANTA Theatre, which will benefit the United Neighborhood Houses, a federated body of settlements and neighborhood centers here. They may be obtained from the agency's headquarters, 114 East Thirty-second Street.

What was the top business and financial event of 1959? The steel strike and its many ramifications, according to Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner Smith, Inc., the nation's largest brokerage concern. It had polled the managers of its 129 United States and foreign offices for opinions.

MOSCOW, Dec. 11 -- The Soviet Government has decreed a new formula for bonuses. In effect, the largest rewards will henceforth go to enterprises and workers who drive down production costs. This in most cases will supplant the system of rewarding quantitative output, often without regard to quality or cost.

IN 1642, when Charles I raised his standard at Nottingham and thus officially recognized a state of civil war within his kingdom, two Yorkshire barons, old Sir Ferdinando Fairfax and his son, young Sir Thomas Fairfax, did not hesitate to take up arms against the King.
LONDON, Dec. 18 (Reuters) -- The value of Britain's imports and exports both increased by 1 1/2 per cent during November, according to Board of Trade figures published here today.
Roberto Rossellini, the individualistic motion-picture producer, was in town long enough yesterday to give an appraisal of his career.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 (AP) -- Senator Mike Mansfield asked President Eisenhower today for new information on operations of the foreign aid program in South Vietnam.
ALBANY, Dec. 18 (UPI) -- The State Public Works Department today opened bids on fourteen highway projects, including an expressway job in Nassau County.
CHICAGO, Dec. 19 (UPI) -- Roger Touhy, the gangster who was shot to death twenty-three days after his parole from prison, was buried today.

AGGRESSIVENESS, fantasy and insecurity, those three qualities that are used to explain so much about man, may be found in full measure when we examine the conquest of the American West -- or any other frontier.

Despite tight money and high interest rates, the bankers' banks have been doing very well. According to the American Banker, a trade publication, 497 banks in the nation each had deposits from other banks of $500,000 or more at the end of October, two more banks than a year ago.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 (AP) -- Surgeon General Leroy E. Burney said today that a number of problems must be solved before live virus polio myelitis vaccines would be licensed for general use in this country.

CHICAGO, Dec. 18 -- David J. McDonald, president of the United Steelworkers of America, increased the union's contract demands today. He also threatened to take action in court and before the National Labor Relations Board to speed bargaining on union terms.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 (UPI) -- The board of monitors of the Teamsters Union asked permission of the United States Court of Appeals today to hire outside legal help to press charges of corruption against James R. Hoffa, the union president.
MADRID, Dec. 17 -- As Generalissimo Francisco Franco awaits President Eisenhower's visit here, the Generalissimo's prestige appears higher than it has been in many years.

CLEVELAND, Dec. 18 (AP) -- Despite the steel strike, which virtually halted iron ore shipping on the Great Lakes for about four months, total freight tonnage handled by lake shipping concerns to Dec. 1 was down only 6 per cent from the comparable period of 1958.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 -- Representative Wilbur D. Mills put a sudden damper today on hopes for general tax relief next year.

KEITH ROBINSON, Nicolas Roussakis and Henry Weinberg are three young American composers who use twelve - tone techniques in their music. According to some notions, their work should sound alike. But the compositions heard late yesterday afternoon in a program of twentieth century chamber music at Carnegie Recital Hall revealed three styles and three personalities.
NEW DELHI, India, Dec. 18 -- India observed "Family Planning Day" today to dramatize the need for birth control to ensure a higher standard of living.
LEOPOLDVILLE, Belgian Congo, Dec. 18 -- King Baudouin's visit to the Belgian Congo has taken both Belgians and Congolese by surprise.

Gift From Massachusetts The big Christmas tree at Rockefeller Center this year has interest beyond the fact that it is a splendid specimen of red spruce, full seventy feet tall, eighty years old, and a gift from the Commonwealth of Massachusetts.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange moved 3 points (15 cents a bale) off to 11 points (55 cents) up yesterday.
Passenger and freighter operators have offered the National Maritime Union a 1.5 per cent wage increase, the union disclosed yesterday.
Fifteen parcels of vacant land containing 390 lots in Eltingville, S. I., were sold at auction on Thursday at the Roosevelt Hotel for prices totaling $348,700.
The research schooner Vema has found new evidence of what are believed to be catactlysmic landslides that occur periodically beneath the ocean and race across the bottom at express-train speeds.

The American policy of giving aid to dictatorships as long as they are anti-Communist has come under the thoughtful scrutiny of two of the Senate's younger, more valuable members, just returned from a trip to Asia. They appear to disagree -- but they both are right.

WITH Christmas only six days away, many homemakers are busy decking their halls this week-end. Wreaths interspersed with pine cones, mistletoe, bright-berried holly and boughs of greens are converting houses into holiday bowers. Those interested in an extra touch of glamour might head for the nearest florist.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 -- Attorney General William P. Rogers assured the broadcasting industry today that its units could collaborate to abolish abuses of TV and radio programing without fear of Federal prosecution under antitrust laws.
Jules Eskin's 'cello recital last night at Carnegie Recital Hall was so close to being a real top-notch program that it is interesting to see where it went wrong.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 (AP) -- President Eisenhower told the armed services in a Christmas message today that his talks with foreign leaders had convinced him that they all hoped for "a world of friendship, understanding and mutual progress."
HWALIEN, Taiwan, Dec. 17 -- In this eastern Taiwan region of narrow valleys and precipitous mountains, a serviceable small church of wood and plaited bamboo can be built for $200.

MILLBURN, N. J., Dec. 18 -- Mrs. Mary C. Zelinsky of 759 Ridgewood Road was fined $200 today on a charge that she had refused to break off a phone call to permit a physician to summon an ambulance for a heart patient. Court costs of $10 also were assessed.

What is under-developed in Morocco is not the country but the nation. Launched into sudden independence in 1956, free Morocco has inherited from French rule a remarkable network of roads, spacious ports, a sizable industrial apparatus, and public utilities ready and able to respond to the requirements of expansion.
HOUSTON, Dec. 18 (AP) -- The Bluebonnet Bowl will make its debut among post-season football games tomorrow, with Texas Christian an 8-point choice over Clemson's Atlantic Coast Conference champions.

Slingin' Sammy Baugh, the tall Texan who was one of professional football's finest performers, yesterday was signed as head coach of the New York Titans of the new American Football League.
Fifteen lawyers began a legal fight yesterday in an empty courtroom over a trust fund that may mean $9,000,000 to the Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts.

A large parcel of industrial land at Bruckner Boulevard and Third Avenue in the Bronx, has been sold by the Providence Produce Warehouse Corporation, a subsidiary of the New York, New Haven and Hartford Railroad.

A floor-waxing company used "bait" advertising to lure upstate residents into applying for part-time jobs as floor waxers and then "tricked" them into purchasing expensive waxing equipment, the state Attorney General's office charged yesterday.

TOMORROW one of the quietest and most successful showmen on earth will celebrate a fortieth anniversary. Gene Cavallero, the mild-mannered proprietor of the Colony Restaurant, will mark Your decades of association with the internationally famed dining spot.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 (UPI) -- Federal Judge Richmond B. Keech today postponed a ruling on whether Dr. Milton Eisenhower must testify in a court case involving acquisition by the Alleghany Corporation of the New York Central Railroad.

PARIS, Dec. 18 -- Looking hardy and animated, President Eisenhower ended the recuperative phase of his eleven-nation tour today by taking the salute of combined French and American naval forces off the southern coast of France.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 -- Ecuador, which was to have been host to the eleventh Inter-American Conference at Quito Feb. 1, asked today that the conference be indefinitely postponed.
DETROIT, Dec. 18 (AP) -- Ward's Automotive Reports said today that 40 per cent of the nation's car-assembly plants would work six days this week. Output is expected to rise above the 150,000 mark.
Holiday travel reached the first peak of the Christmas-New Year's season yesterday, a full week before Christmas Day.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 -- After interference actions lasting nearly twenty years, the Chrysler Corporation received this week fifteen patents on inventions involving auto matic power transmissions.

RABAT, Morocco, Dec. 18 -- Urged by his friends and opponents to resign because of the arrest of his main supporters, Premier Abdallah Ibrahim appeared tonight to be determined to avoid a Government crisis at least until after the visit of President Eisenhower next Tuesday.
MINNEAPOLIS, Dec. 18 (AP) -- L. J. Clark and associates have completed arrangements to buy the Nash Coffee Company, a branch of the Nash-Finch Company here. No purchase price was announced.

LONDON, Dec. 18 -- Some more good company statements helped industrial shares here today to maintain their recent improvement. The undertone of all markets kept firm even though prices again closed with irregular net changes.

MAYFIELD, Ky., Dec. 18 (AP) -- Circuit Judge Elvis J. Stahr ruled today that the will of Ed Gardner, multimillionaire, that left about $6,000,000 to a charitable foundation was invalid.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 18 -- With anxious eyes on the weather, the football teams of Penn State and Alabama marked time today for their meeting at Philadelphia Stadium tomorrow in the Liberty Bowl game.

A group of business men, represented by Roy M. Cohn, is seeking to gain control of Rosensohn Enterprises and promote the return heavyweight championship fight between Ingemar Johansson and Floyd Patterson.
LANSING, Mich., Dec 18 -- The Michigan Legislature adopted a tax program today that ended, at least temporarily, the state's long fiscal agony.
Federal Judge Mortimer W. Byers has dismissed nine of twenty-six counts in an indictment against Alexander L. Guterma.

John R. Clark Jr. yesterday was elected the second president of Technicolor, Inc. He will take over the helm of the forty-five-year-old color film processing company on Jan. 1. The board also elected the forty-four-year-old executive as general manager of the company and its subsidiaries.
Assemblyman Joseph Kottler, Democrat of Brooklyn, announced yesterday the prefiling of a series of bills to tighten the state's gambling laws.

The State Board of Regents announced yesterday that it would recommend to Governor Rockefeller and the Legislature that the state increase its aid to public libraries.

The New York Stock Exchange reported yesterday that there was a drop in the short interest to 3,079,881 shares in the month ended last Tuesday. This was 187,144 shares below the revised figure of 3,267,025 for Nov. 13. The Christmas spirit overflowed at hundreds of parties all over town yesterday -- parties for poor children, for orphans, for the sick and aged in hospitals, for disabled servicemen and even for dogs and cats.

A union-owned hat plant has just signed its first union contract -- and the worker-owners do not know whether to be more pleased in their role as employes or as employers.
PARIS, Dec. 19 -- Four leaders of the Atlantic alliance agreed today on the date, place and agenda they will propose to the Soviet Union for a summit conference next spring.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 19 (UPI) -- Col. Chester Lacayo, leader of a Nicaraguan revolutionary movement, asked the Inter- American Peace Committee today to recommend an embargo on arms shipments to Nicaragua.

HACKENSACK, N. J., Dec. 19 -- The Bergen County Board of Freeholders will have a woman director for the first time next year. She is Mrs. Carl S. Marggraff, who was chosen this week and will be formally elected at the board's reorganization meeting on Jan. 2.

INGMAR Bergman has won international renown by asking searching questions about God and woman. He has phrased his questions as unusually, provocative motion pictures and, in so doing, has generated tremendous excitement in the movie world, here and especially abroad.

HELSINKI, Finland, Dec. 7 -- Opposition politicians and many other Finns call President Urho Kekkonen the worst calamity to befall the republic.
NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 19 (AP) -- Fighting King, a colt owned by Joseph Gavegnano, sped out of trouble in the back stretch today and won the $10,000 Yuletide Handicap at the Fair Grounds.

PRACTICALLY every question that may have occurred to the otherwise idle mind of the normal cartoon fan has been painstakingly and exhaustively answered in a loving, generous. nearly non-critical and often brilliant study of the evolution of American comic art by a man of incite patience, Stephen Becker.

AUGUSTA, Me. -- In politics, there used to be some truth in the old phrase that "As Maine goes, so goes the nation." AT nearly every major studio during the closing months of the year, ranking executives gather to decide what grist to feed the cinematic mills for the 1960-61 season. Choice offices that have been unoccupied most of the year suddenly become beehives as the top brass flies in from New York to confer with local production bosses on problems that will determine if the studio will have a cheerful Christmas two years from now.
