ST. LOUIS, Dec. 20 (AP) -The St. Louis Hawks gained their fifth straight victory and lifted their Western Division lead in the National Basketball Association to five and a half games by trimming the secondplace Detroit Pistons, 102 -- 86, today.

An agreement intended to prevent discrimination against Negro applicants for longshore jobs at the Brooklyn Army Terminal was announced yesterday by Elmer A. Carter, chairman of the State Commission Against Discrimination.
HAVANA, Dec. 19 -- The Cuban revolution has produced a new figure to replace the undesirable foreigner Santa Claus in Cuba's Christmas. He is Don Feliciano, or Mr. Happiness.
The writer of the following letter is the author of numerous articles on Soviet population and manpower problems. He is Assistant Professor of Economics at Princeton University.
A proposed zoning resolution, with more than 300 changes from a draft submitted ten months ago by city consultants, was made public today by the City Planning Commission.

Heretofore, William Gibson (dramatist) and Arthur Penn (director) have been associated in their respective capacities with two big hits -- "Two for the Seesaw" and "The Miracle Worker." Yesterday it became known that the team aims to branch out as a producing unit.

MINNEAPOLIS, Dec. 20 (AP) The battle between rival professional football leagues over the Minneapolis-St. Paul territory raged again today with the disclosure that a new group had moved to rand a National Football League franchise.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 20 (UPI) -- The chief economist of the National Planning Association predicted today that the United States' rate of economic growth in the next decade would rise to 4.2 per cent a year.

More than 123,000,000 Americans paid 1,200 insurance organizations $5,900,000,000 for protection against the cost of possible illness and injury last year, according to a report by the Health Insurance Institute.

The Board of Education's purchasing and supply operations are at "a relatively high level of efficiency," but there is considerable room for improvement, City Administrator Charles F. Preusse reported yesterday.

The Rev. John Ellis Large, rector of the Protestant Episcopal Church of the Heavenly Rest, Fifth Avenue and Ninetieth Street, marked his twenty-fifth year in the ministry yesterday with a sermon on the character of power.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 20 -Have standards of literary decency shifted enough in the last decade to change the Supreme Court's mind about "Memoirs of Hecate County"?

"Aida" was presented at the Metropolitan Opera on Saturday evening, with Cornell MacNeil in his first appearance with the company as Amonasro. Mary Curtis-Verna and Regina Resnik made first appearances of the season as Aida and Amneris.

The Commerce and Industry Association of New York has asked Mayor Wagner not to press for a national and state minimum wage of $1.25 an hour. The Mayor's intention to take such action was disclosed last week.
PARIS, Dec. 20 (AP) -Maj. and Mrs. John S. D. Eisenhower went with a party of twelve friends last night to see a night club show.

Two friends decided to give to New York's Neediest Cases this year rather than exchange Christmas gifts. Two weeks ago one of them sent $5 and the Cheery message that came with it -- "Merry Christmas, Tilly" -was published in The New York Times.
Within a few months, the Air Force expects to make the first flight tests of satellites designed to give the nation almost immediate warning of a missile attack.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 20 (UPI) -- The White House has assured Congress that import quotas on lead and zinc would not be withdrawn until the domestic industry showed substantial improvement, a congressman said today.
LONDON, Dec. 20 (AP) -Lady Churchill introduced a new Christmas carol today appealing to families to send gifts to refugees.

HONG KONG, Dec. 20 -- Two United States sailors who entered Communist China from Honk Kong Wednesday were handed over to the British border police by the Communists today. The British turned them over to United States consular authorities.

MIAMI, Dec. 21 (AP) -- With only six days to learn the names of their players and their abilities and to develop a passable and a passing offense, coaches of the North and South all-star football teams wasted no time today when the squads assembled for the first time.

The Federal Communications Commission has failed to ride herd effectively on radio and television programing, two former commissioners agreed in a series of discussions that were made public yesterday.

TOKYO, Dec. 20 -- Yesterday's sharp drop in the hitherto booming Tokyo stock market is expected to dampen the traditional New Year celebrations for numerous small investors. The disillusionment was thought to be particularly heavy among those who rushed to brokerage houses in recent days to put fat year-end bonuses into shares that are now worth considerably less than they paid for them.
The writer of the following letter was Deputy Commissioner of the Department of Air Pollution Control from February, 1956, until his resignation in September, 1959.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif, Dec. 20 -- A prominent movie director has just left for Europe to sign an elephant with personality.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 20 -- The large deficit in the United States' balance of international payments appears to be waning, although it is not cured. The major factors in the improvement have been a sharp decrease in exports and a leveling in the upward trend of imports.

The last year in broadcasting, religion, economics, art, the Law, the press and education was reviewed in an hour's time yesterday afternoon over the Columbia Broadcasting System. Somewhat breathless history, all in all.
LEOPOLDVILLE, Belgian Congo, Dec. 20 -- Congolese pops in battle dress toured filling stations and observation lanes droned overhead today

The importance Moscow attaches to the East-West dialogue was re-emphasized last Saturday when the Soviet Government released the text of Premier Khrushchev's Oct. 15 letter to Chancellor Adenauer. While Premier Khrushchev waits for an answer he would do well to ponder over the thoughtful article by George Kennan in the latest issue of Foreign Affairs.
MOSCOW, Dec. 20 -- Jail terms of up to two years await Muscovites who chop down fir trees in the forests around the city during the holiday season.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 20 -- Eleven major steel companies said today they had "serious misgivings" over union demands that negotiations be started on a company-bycompany basis. Nevertheless, they said they would defer final action on the matter until after a meeting scheduled tomorrow with the Federal mediation service.

There is harmony now in labor relations on the waterfront of the Port of New York -- in sharp contrast to the situation in the South Atlantic and Gulf coast ports. The longshoremen in the latter area, whose strike was stayed last October by a Taft-Hartley injunction, can, and may, walk out again when the injunction runs out next Sunday.

MOSCOW, Dec. 20 (AP) -Izvestia said today the North Atlantic Treaty Organization was split and "there is evidence of a desire to get rid of American dictatorship in the framework of this organization." The paper printed a Paris dispatch on the NATO and Western summit meetings.

GUJRANWALA, Pakistan, Dec. 20 -- President Mohammad Ayub Khan indicated today a hardened policy toward India, reflecting growing disillusionment over the results of President Eisenhower's mission of peace.
During the Christmas season when charity demands are high, it is notable that the Government is the biggest single contributor to charity.
The festival of Christmas continued merrily over the week-end under skies that were bright, cold and windy. Winter arrives at 9:35 A. M. tomorrow.
HAVANA, Dec. 20 -- Premier Fidel Castro told a mass-meeting of workers tonight that they must spy on all Cubans who opposed the revolution and report them to the police.
The Allied Chemical Corporation is extending its activities in South Africa with the planned acquisition of 51 per cent of the shares of the Montrose Exploration Company, Ltd.

Manhattan College's basketball team lounged in the University of Portland's Holy Cross Hall yesterday. The Jaspers watched motion pictures of their 64-61 victory over Portland Saturday night and wondered how they had won the first City of Roses tournament.

A SENSITIVE Christmas shopper who shrinks from crowds and clamor can head for Madison Avenue. Among the many serene shops that offer a good range of Christmas presents is Giulietta di Roma, 789 Madison Avenue, at Sixty-seventh Street. The shop is one flight up. The owner is Mme. Giulietta d'Alessandro who runs the shop alone and helps all customers.
NEW CANAAN, Conn., Dec. 20 -- The ministers of five Protestant churches have issued a warning to parents against a religious youth movement that is attempting to recruit high school students here.

An educator yesterday proposed a world conference in Asia to learn what the world's religious and philosophic traditions "can usefully teach us about the ethics of mutual involvement in each other's affairs."
A group of residents and property owners in Harlem heatedly denied yesterday a charge that opposition by Borough President Hulan E. Jack to a new school site had been politically motivated.

CHICAGO, Dec. 20 (AP) -A bearish Government report last week set off a record volume of dealings in soybean futures for one day on the Board of Trade and ended all hope for a tight supply of that commodity this year.
Philip J. Noel-Baker, who just won the 1959 Nobel Pe Prize, said yesterday he sure the Soviet Union ready to accept full disbarment with adequate inspection.

YONKERS, Dec. 20 -- The largest public library in Westchester County will be built beside busy Central Park Avenue here. Public officials will turn the first shovels of earth tomorrow, when work begins on the $1,780,000 project.

HAVANA, Dec. 20 (AP) -- With the take-over of the fiber plantations, the Cuban regime moved closer to nationalization of the country's agriculture. Agrarian reform officials confirmed that the next major step would be the take-over of sugar lands.
The Rev. Dr. John Sutherland Bonnell said yesterday that Christians and Jews "may be poles apart theologically, but spiritually we are akin."
Thomas E. Murray, former Atomic Energy Commissioner, advanced detailed arguments yesterday in support of his plan for dismantling Soviet and American hydrogen bombs.
The city's campaign against chiseling by meat markets, food stores and gasoline stations has become increasingly effective since it was started three weeks ago, Mayor Wagner was told yesterday.
PARIS, Dec. 20 -- Hundreds of ducks and a solitary heron rose in startled flights this morning from the tranquil waters of a great basin behind the prehistoric chateau of Rambouillet.

LAGOS, Nigeria, Dec. 20 -The new Government that will guide Nigeria to independence by next October was announced today by the Federal Prime Minister, Alhaji Abubakar Tafewa Balewa, deputy leader of the victorious Northern Peoples Congress.

CRACOW, Poland, Dec. 20 -"Bethlehem Crib," read the sales notice, and the price was marked at 30 zlotys, $1.25 at the official rate. A score of Christmas cribs made of cardboard and colored paper stand at the edge of the pavement, and a peasant woman in a shawl offers them to the throng of shoppers on the Rynek, the central market place of this university town.

LONDON, Dec. 20 -- After a pause from the steep climb of the week before, the Stock Exchange edged modestly upward to another record last week on a foundation of apparently indestructible confidence and encouraging company reports.
LAGOS, Dec. 20 (Reuters) -Following is the list of members of the new Nigerian Cabinet: Prime Minister -- Alhaji Abubakar Tafewa Balewa.
Austin J. Tobin, executive director of the Port of New York Authority, declared yesterday that there was no alternative site for the jet airport proposed in Morris County, N. J.
The Martin-Senour Company, paint manufacturer, has leased space for an Eastern regional office in 730 Fifth Avenue at Fifty-seventh Street, through Gallant-Roth Co., brokers.

TUCSON, Ariz., Dec. 20 -Nine persons were killed and thirty-two injured today when a double-decker Greyhound bus and a loaded cattle truck collided. The head-on crash occurred before dawn on a desert highway east of here.

MAMARONECK, N. Y., Dec. 20 -- The Methodist Church of Mamaroneck celebrated the centennial of its white-frame, Gothic-style building this morning with a re-enactment of the dedicatory procession held on Christmas Sunday in 1859.

Diplomacy risks becoming ineffective when it seeks to endorse two foreign policies concurrently. This truism is at the root of present difficulties between France and the United States. For, in terms of both countries, dearly and intimately related, there is a tendency to seek dual objectives at contradictory moments even if their ultimate goals may ultimately rejoin.
ALBANY, Dec. 20 (AP) -Governor Rockefeller has asked a new three-man task force to determine how the state can assure a college education for every qualified youth.

KNOXVILLE, Tenn., Dec. 20 -- The Tennessee Valley Authority expects to wait at least until next July 1 before issuing its first batch of bonds under the agency's new self-financing authority, according to A. R. Jones, T. V. A. director.

"Conservatives in Power: A Study in Frustration," by Edwin L. Dale Jr., will be issued by Doubleday Jan. 7. It is an analysis of the national economy and of the attempts to cope with big budgets and large deficits.
WESTBURY, L. I., Dec. 20 -Superintendent of Schools Cecil I. Rice has advised teachers here to guard against pupils who try to curry favor with "Christmas payola."

THE question of tipping in restaurants has stirred the public imagination more than usual within recent weeks. It is the result of the creation of an organization called Tippers Anonymous, the brain child of a Boston advertising man, Robert S. Farrington. He has been described as "a firm opponent of perfunctory tipping for what he often considers mediocre service."

Birgit Nilsson, Swedish soprano who was acclaimed at her debut as Isolde in "Tristan und Isolde" last Friday, is scheduled to sing three other roles at the Metropolitan Opera this season.

BERKELEY, Calif., Dec. 20 (UPI) -- Pete Elliott, the California football coach, said today there was "a strong possibility" he would take over head coaching duties at the University of Illinois.

After a firm beginning, cotton futures prices turned mixed last week, ending with price changes ranging from 20 cents a bale lower to $1.30 a bale higher. Most of the strength was in the new crop months.

"Playhouse 90" may be converted into a series of special dramas with a considerable increase in budget under a proposal now being considered by the Columbia Broadcasting System.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 20 -Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru believes that increased United States aid to India is accepted as necessary by both nations.

AT 77 Igor Stravinsky has become a monument. He is worshiped at seances that give off the faint odors of incense. Fortunately, he is still around, and the nimbleness of his mind and the force of his spirit are a healthy antidote to the preciosity that has been enveloping him.

Flemming, Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare, that weed killer used on bogs had caused cancer in test rats.

Alf Pike, the New York rangers' coach, has made many good moves in an effort to get his team clicking. An honest-to-goodness little house of real cinder blocks is taking shape on the lower level of Grand Central Terminal. The free flow of traffic to and from the tracks is nicely blocked.

Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru was overruled in India's Parliament yesterday when he tried to ward off a debate on the border dispute with Communist China. Frederick Jarvis, baritone, who gave a recital last night at Carnegie Recital Hall, showed a voice with two distinct qualities.

Henry Feinstein will retire today from his $8,500-a-year post as Superintendent of Transportation in the Manhattan Bor ough President's Office to devote his full time to duties as president of a teamsters' union of city employes.

Two television networks found themselves in the position of cross-plugging each other's program yesterday. It happened because of a pending exchange of visits by Bing Crosby of the American Broadcasting Company and Perry Como of the National Broadcasting Company.

Business in this city gained considerably in 1959, and nearly all concerns in the five boroughs expect it to be as good of better in the first half of 1960. A survey of the business outlook just completed by the Commerce and Industry Association of New York, Inc., indicated that about 90 per cent of the executives of 409 representative concerns were optimistic.

If seventh heaven is rosehued, that is where 103 debutantes were last evening. Clouds of pink tulle and twinkling starlike lights provided a delicate background for the young women who were presented to society at the Debutante Cotillion and Christmas Ball in the Grand Ballroom of the Waldorf -Astoria.

A new volume of Civil War history by Bruce Catton will be published Feb. 4 by Little, Brown, called "Grant Moves South." It begins with Grant's first real Civil War assignment, command of the Twenty-first Illinois Volunteers. It tells how, in the years 1861-63, he progressed from a "reluctant but dedicated soldier" to a forceful general, formed the Army of the Tennessee and successfully campaigned down the Mississippi River, severing the Confederacy.

The election of William I. Spencer and Edwin Thorne as senior vice presidents of the First National City Bank of New York was announced yesterday. Both were formerly vice presidents. PARIS, Thursday, Dec. 24 -- The French National Assembly, by a 427-71 vote, approved early today a bill giving state financial aid to Roman Catholic schools.

The consumer price index of the Bureau of Labor Statistics advanced in November for the seventh month of the eight months beginning with last April. The November rise, 0.1 percentage point, brings the "market basket" of representative commodities in the budget of city-dwelling middle-income families from an average level of 123.7 in March to 125.6 last month, a rise of 1.9 percentage points.
PASADENA, Calif., Dec. 23 (AP) -- The Rose Bowl teams, Wisconsin and Washington, held morning drills today.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 23 (AP) -- President Eisenhower has turned over to Congressional investigators an edited version of a secret Administration report on whether United States foreign aid has been squandered in South Vietnam.
A total of 1,427 victims of uninsured, hit-run or financially irresponsible motorists have made damage claims in New York State this year.
NAIROBI, Kenya, Dec. 23 -- Proposals for greater African participation in the government of Uganda have been made by a special committee appointed by the British Governor, Sir Frederick Crawford.
ALFRIED KRUPP, who agreed yesterday that his company should pay for the sufferings of Jews forced to work in its plants during World War II, was born and raised to be the armorer of Germany.
Tributes to the memory of servicemen who lost their lives in action were among the gifts received yesterday to help New York's Neediest Cases.

The Pennsylvania Railroad, the nation's biggest carrier, operated at a profit last month, although a lesser one than year before. However, the second largest system, the New York Central Railroad, had a loss in November, in contrast to a profit last year.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 23 (AP) -- The Office of Civil and Defense Mobilization today authorized Federal tax benefits for fifty-three defense, space and research projects in advance of the Dec. 31 deadline of the tax amortization program.

Allan P. Kirby's plans to proceed with a unilateral settlement of years of costly litigation that have plagued him and the Alleghany Corporation, which he heads, were attacked in Federal District Court yesterday by the Murchison Brothers.

Dr. H. Apel's letter published Dec. 19 challenges the Dec. 6 statement of the Democratic Advisory Council to the effect that during the seven-year period 1953-59 (inclusive) the nation suffered some 11 million man-years of excess unemployment, and that total national production was about $175-200 billion less than it should have been.
A new electronic process for recording, storing and reproducing photographic images and technical data has been devised by a scientist at the General Electric Research Laboratory, Schenectady, N. Y.

LONDON, Dec. 23 -- A nail file with a diamond abrasive surface on sale for 140 ($392) in a West End jeweler's was not a typical British gift, but it was an indication of the kind of Christmas being enjoyed by Britons.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Dec. 16 -- The tightening of controls in Poland affords the Yugoslavs one slight satisfaction -- they will not have so many visitors telling them they are less free than the Poles.
BOSTON, Dec. 23 (AP) -- The belief that defense carried the Chicago White Sox to the 1959 American League pennant was borne out today by the season's final fielding figures.
An extra-sturdy stork has been having a busy time around the city's zoos lately. He has delivered three baby hippos.

ALBANY, Dec. 23 -- Rate decreases approved today by the Public Service Commission will mean a savings of $1,227,500 to home owners and apartment dwellers who use electricity provided by the Long Island Lighting Company.

Consolidated net profit of the Fram Corporation for the first eleven months of this year was $2,026,324 compared with $1,354,092 in the 1958 period. Sales rose to $32,870,713 from $26,891,644. The results were disclosed by Theodore H. Belling, president, at the annual meeting yesterday in Providence, R. I.
THE Bible says, "There were giants in the earth in those days," and there were giants in the earth in some of the days of bridge.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 23 -- Representative Hale Boggs of Louisiana emerged today as the favorite for permanent chairman of the Democratic National Convention next July.

Parking on several hundred designated streets will be forbidden today as the Department of Sanitation proceeds with snow removal. On all other roads the alternate side parking regulations will again be suspended for the day.
BERLIN, Dec. 22 -- Markos Vafiades, who commanded the Communist guerrillas in the Greek civil war more than a decade ago, is reported to be living among a Greek exile community in Polish Silesia.

The New York Giants, in a liberal holiday mood, yesterday voted to divide their share of the play-off money from Sunday's National Football League championship game against Baltimore into forty-five shares.
Santa Claus arrived two days early at the State University of New York Maritime College at Fort Schuyler yesterday.
TEHERAN, Iran, Dec. 23 (AP) -- All Iranian armed forces were alerted today after Premier Kassim of Iraq was reported concentrating five armored brigades close to Iran's southwestern border.
A sizable step-up in the production of the Republic F-105, a supersonic tactical fighter plane, is reported to be contained in the proposed Federal budget for the 1961 fiscal year.
The Montreal Metropolitan Corporation of Quebec Province, Canada, is planning to borrow $30,000,000 in the United States market on an issue of sinking fund debentures due in 1985.

Prices rose for United States Government securities of all kinds yesterday, making it possible for the bond market to give its best showing of the week. Only in the secondary market for local government obligations did prices continue to flinch before offerings dumped for tax purposes before the year ends.
Santa Claus brightened parties yesterday for thousands of underprivileged children in metropolitan New York.
BONN, Germany, Dec. 17 -- The Federal Refugee Ministry has drawn up a fourteen-year balance sheet on one of the largest relief programs undertaken by one country.
Governor Rockefeller proposed a comprehensive program yesterday to combat youth crime.
A Bronx cab driver was identified last night by Laura Haines as the man who had beaten and attempted to rape her Monday night at LaGuardia Airport, the police reported.

News that the World Bank has decided to lend Egypt $56,000,000 to widen and deepen the Suez Canal will be received with mixed feelings. To improve the canal is obviously beneficial to world shipping and trade as well as to the economy of Egypt. That much is to the good.

BATON ROUGE, La., Dec. 23 (AP) -- Louisiana State's starting halfback, Johnny Robinson, suffered a slight fracture in his left hand during practice Tuesday but has not been counted out of the Sugar Bowl game with Mississippi on New Year's Day.
The second and last of the season's Junior Assemblies, a supper dance series for debutantes, was held last night in the Grand Ballroom of the Pizza.

HAVANA, Dec. 23 -- James C. Buchanan, staff writer for The Miami Herald, was put aboard a plane for that Florida city at 1:15 P. M. today by the Cuban authorities. Earlier in the day a military court sentenced him to fourteen years' imprisonment with suspension of the sentence provided he left Cuba within twenty-four hours.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange were unchanged to 14 points (70 cents a bale) up yesterday. The far months were strongest.

Leaders of 40,000 clothing workers in the metropolitan district called on Mayor Wagner and Governor Rockefeller yesterday to enlist the direct support of New York's Congressional delegation in pressing for a Federal minimum wage of $1.25 an hour.

A prosecution witness said yesterday that a defendant in the fraud-conspiracy trial of Alexander L. Guterma and others had asked him to take the Fifth Amendment and refuse to answer questions when he testified.

BALTIMORE, Dec. 23 -- From Las Vegas, Minneapolis or wherever it is that such items are determined, the word is that the Baltimore Colts still are 3 1/2-point favorites to beat the New York Giants in Sunday's National Football League title game here.
SOME families make Christmas breakfast a memorable tradition. A New Yorker who grew up in the South recalls the veritable banquet served in his home at a shockingly early hour.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 23 -- A Government poll of steel workers on management's "last offer" was set today for Jan. 11 to 13.
A city Board of Ethics was appointed yesterday by Mayor Wagner. When requested, this board will advise municipal officials and employes about any problems that may arise under the new Code of Ethics.
HONG KONG, Dec. 16 -- Communist China has acknowledged that if peasants were left to themselves they would "head for capitalism."

It was strongly indicated yesterday that Mayor Wagner would not reappoint Magistrate Robert F. Mahoney, whose present term expires at midnight next Thursday.
ALBANY, N. Y., Dec. 23 (AP) -- The State Commerce Department received the following reports today from ski centers:
NEW DELHI, Dec. 23 -- Communist China was reported today to be bringing pressure on Nepal to sign a defense agreement merit with Peiping.

Adjustments seemed to be in order in yesterday's session of the New York Stock Exchange. Stocks that have had recent gains were lower as a rule, although there were a good many exceptions in the electronics group. Here and there, neglected issues stirred with life.
Three civic organizations yesterday joined those that have endorsed and supported the recommendations on relocation made in a recent report to Mayor Wagner by J. Anthony Panuch.

PRINCETON, N. J., Dec. 23 -- Varsity, junior varsity and freshman soccer awards have been received by eight New York area students at Princeton University, it was announced today by R. Kenneth Fairman, director of athletics.
ROME, Dec. 23 (Reuters) -- Following, in official translation, is the text of the Christmas message broadcast in Italian today by Pope John XXIII:
The St. Regis Roof provided an appropriately seasonal setting last night for the Mistletoe Debutante Ball, at which nine-teen young women made their bows to society.
Professional football's newly formed American League may take a couple of points -- 2-pointers, to be exact -- from college football next season.
The first directive of Thomas S. Gates Jr., when he relieved Neil H. McElroy as Secretary of Defense, stressed the importance of staff duty to professional advancement.
ASUNCION, Paraguay, Dec. 23 -- Paraguayan Army units were closing in today on a band of rebels in eastern Paraguay, Army sources reported.

Fabulous and fantastic are the words most often used to describe the organization now in readiness to advance Governor Rockefeller as a candidate for the Republican nomination for President by those who encounter it.
CHICAGO, Dec. 23 (AP) -- The grain and soybean futures market burst out of a narrow trading range early this afternoon and scored substantial advances on nearly all contracts.
MOSCOW, Dec. 23 (AP) -- An example of private enterprise came to light today in the reported sale of ikons to tourists by youthful Communists.

A seasonal increase in the nation's gasoline stocks was reported yesterday for the week ended last Friday. Supplies rose by 1,588,000 barrels to 182,838,000, according to the American Petroleum Institute. They were 178,599,000 barrels a year ago.
Following is the text of a letter sent to Governor Rockefeller Tuesday by Eli Whitney Debevoise chairman of the Interdepartmental Task Force on Youth and Juvenile Delinquency:

WASHINGTON, Dec. 23 (UPI) -- Attorney General William P. Rogers suggested today that Congress take a look at existing laws governing the interstate regulation of oil pipelines with a view to the possible enactment of new anti-trust legislation.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 23 -- The State Department disclosed today that it was using its influence in Baghdad and Teheran to persuade both sides to negotiate an amicable settlement of their border dispute in the Shatt al Arab.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 23 -- Senator Harrison A. Williams of New Jersey proposed today that four questions be answered in the review of the program for a new jet airport.

Johnny Unitas, 26-year-old passing sensation of the Baltimore Colts, was named quarterback on both The Associated Press and United Press International National Football League all-star teams yesterday.

A plot of land with a frontage of 400 feet on Central Park Avenue, opposite the Korvette store in the Town of Greenburgh, in Westchester County, has been sold by Nicholas and Frank Palladio to the Plaza Investors Corporation. The buyers are studying a plan for improving the site with a shopping center. William J. Sherry Jr. was the broker for the sellers and Morton Haves of Woodmere, Queens, for the buyer.

Bobby Fischer, the 16-year-old United States chess champion, set the pace last night in the fifth round of the national championship tournament for the Lessing J. Rosenwald trophy at the Manhattan Chess Club.
With the winter holiday season now upon us, safety experts will issue statements about the high fatality rates on the highway.
All honor to a bold man, Benjamin T. Richards of Chappaqua, venturing a word for the nonsmoker in your issue of Dec. 17.

MOSCOW, Dec. 23 -- An official Soviet commentator described as "disastrous and unrealistic'' today the Western leaders' intention to maintain the status quo in Berlin in their coming meeting with Premier Khrushchev.

To the people described in the cases below, as well as to those in every one of 1959's Hundred Neediest Cases, taken from the files of the city's eight major family welfare organizations, a Merry Christmas is more a remote wish than a happy expectation.
TITUSVILLE, Pa., Dec. 23 (AP) -- An airborne magnetometer, one of the newest tools of geology, is being used in a widespread search for petroleum over the world's oldest oil region.
David Merrick, Broadway's most active producer, was a man of many problems yesterday.
GREENWICH, Conn., Dec. 23 -- Teen-agers are safer drivers than many people think, the Greenwich Police Department concluded today.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 23 -- The wife of a Polish diplomat who reported last month she had been beaten in her apartment by three unknown assailants has returned to Warsaw.
LONDON, Dec. 23 -- The small car was being fitfully and inexpertly backed into a parking space twice its size.

Concern about the labor and economic situation in Brazil and the possibility of a change in the exchange rate of the cruzeiro weakened coffee futures yesterday on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange.

Seven East Harlem boys of Italian parentage left for a visit to Puerto Rico yesterday. The trip was part of a program to create better understanding between Puerto Ricans and Italians in the East Harlem area.

THE top brass of the big leagues is split as to both the propriety and wisdom of the new unrestricted interleague trading period. For the first time in the history of the game this waiver-free method of exchanging players was tried recently on an experimental three-week basis. Although it produced only two deals of any consequence, the majority of owners still fancy the idea while the powerful minority is still opposed.
MADRID, Dec. 23 -- Robert Edwards, a British Labor member of Parliament, was arrested and held for ten hours today by the Spanish police.

NEWPORT, R. I., Dec. 23 -- "A Visit From St. Nicholas," the Christmas poem written by Dr. Clement C. Moore more than 100 years ago, was read this afternoon at the house here where Dr. Moore once lived.

The recent upward surge in the price of British industrial stocks is being linked in London to reports that legislation is being prepared to give trustees of British fiduciary institutions more leeway in investing trust funds in common stocks.
Five possible dates in June for a return heavyweight title fight between Ingemar Johansson and Floyd Patterson were obtained yesterday from Yankee Stadium by Roy M. Cohn's new promoting group.

A LAST minute gift that could benefit the entire family all year is a membership to one of the museums in New York City. In addition to the viewing of works of art, admission free, many of the museums offer members such privileges as lectures, movies and concerts as well as discounts in their shops.

The Superintendent of Schools and an advisory group to the Mayor publicly disagreed yesterday on the need for a new special commission to evaluate the progress of racial integration in the city's public schools.

The Federal Reserve System's tight rein on the ability of member banks to make new loans and investments relaxed a bit in the six days ended yesterday. Once again, however, this was thought to reflect the sharp moves common in the year-end money market rather than a shift in monetary policy.

TOKYO, Dec. 23 -- Japan completed today her pledging of reparations payments to countries she occupied during World War II. The Diet (Parliament) gave final approval to a $55,600,000 commitment to South Vietnam.
"Who is better able to diagnose soundness and unsoundness in a dog than a veterinarian? It is an extremely rare judge who has made the study of anatomy that a veterinarian has made."
CORAL GABLES, Fla., Dec. 23 (UPI) -- Walter Blum scored a triple and Spit Ball rallied in the last quarter-mile to win today's feature at Tropical Park.
HOUSTON, Tex., Dec. 23 (AP) -- Apparently confident of its attack, Syracuse tested its defenses again today against Texas runs and passes to drills for the Cotton Bowl on New Year's Day.
Operators of 383 East Coast and Gulf passenger and dry cargo ships will give unlicensed seamen a 4.5 per cent wage rise, beginning Jan. 1.

Tens of thousands of homeward-bound Brooklyn residents were inconvenienced yesterday when express train service on the IRT West Side line was knocked out below the Chambers Street station in Manhattan.

WHEN Etienne Decroux presents examples of his art at colleges and universities, he calls them lecture-demonstrations. A lecture-demonstration is, essentially, what he brought to the stage of the cozy Cricket Theatre last evening.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 23 (AP) -- The establishment of a 100-man inter-American police force and a gradual relaxation of exclusive United States control over the Panama Canal were recommended tonight in a study drafted for the Senate.
The Singer Manufacturing Company will fight a civil antitrust suit filed against it on Tuesday by the Department of Justice, Donald P. Kircher, the president, said yesterday.

THE eleventh hour for Christmas shopping is this minute. On behalf of those shoppers who have not yet made up their minds, have lost track of time or are bereft of any fresh ideas, this column is devoted to last-minute presents that may never have occurred to anybody.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 23 (UPI) -- The Federal Power Commission today approved the merger of El Paso Natural Gas Company and Pacific Northwest Pipeline Corporation to create a new company which will stretch from the Mexican to the Canadian border.

An "informal" conference of twelve Western nations including the United States is to meet in Paris in mid-January in what amounts to an Atlantic Economic Council. Its purpose will be to try to coordinate the economic policies of the industrialized free nations and to mobilize their enhanced resources in expanding world economy and raising living standards for their own welfare and as the best way of meeting the Soviet economic challenge.
LOS ANGELES, Dec. 23 (UPI) -- Six sacks of large, coat-length pelts -- including Persian lamb and Russian sable -- dropped from the sky yesterday onto Alhambra, San Marino and San Gabriel.

Rudy Pilous, the coach of the Chicago Black Hawks, must have a secret formula that he prepares whenever his team meets the New York Rangers. Whatever it is, it worked beautifully last night as the Hawks harassed, heckied and befuddled the Blues to gain a 3-0 victory in a National Hockey League game at Madison Square Garden.
MANCHESTER, Vt., Dec. 23 -- SKI SKETCH: When Hans Palmer was a 6-year-old, he skied on barrel staves in back of his home at Graz, Austria. That was in 1919.

Share earnings of Orange and Rockland Utilities, Inc., this year will be "in the $1.50 area, against $1.29 in 1958 and $1.47 in 1957," Charles L. Hulswit, president told yesterday's luncheon meeting of the New York Society of Security Analysts. He indicated there should be "a further increase" next year as well.
TORONTO, Dec. 23 (Canadian Press) -- Excellent skiing conditions were reported today at two northern Ontario resort centers -- Larder Lake and Sundridge.
The Alfried Krupp industrial empire agreed yesterday to pay up to 10,000,000 Deutsche marks ($2,380,000) to former Jewish slave laborers.
The City Planning Commission decided yesterday that the Polo Grounds should become a housing site, rather than acquire a $45,000,000 "sports palace."
PARIS, Dec. 24 -- The French Senate is expected to complete action Tuesday on a bill providing state aid to Roman Catholic schools.
A ride across the rough North Atlantic in a ship's hold loaded with sports cars was too much for nine Sicilian men intent on being smuggled into the United States.

PORT SAID, United Arab Republic, Dec. 24 -- Thirty-three crewmen and officers of the Danish vessel Inge Toft are no closer to home than they have been for the last seven months and three days. But today they looked eagerly to a celebration of a true Danish Christmas Eve.
A Bronx cab driver who was seized Tuesday as the suspected attacker of an author's daughter near La Guardia Airport admitted yesterday similar attacks on five other women, the police said.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 24 (AP) -- The Bureau of Land Management of the Department of the Interior has announced that some 1,608,000 acres of submerged land off the coasts of Louisiana and Texas will be offered for competitive oil and gas leasing next Feb. 24.
Despite the holiday atmosphere, volume held up fairly well on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday. Prices did the same, creeping a little higher.

CHICAGO, Dec. 24 -- Ross W. Madden, regional director of the National Labor Relations Board, received orders today from Washington to begin preparations for a poll among over 80,000 steel workers in this area on the industry's offer.

ST. PAUL, Minn., Dec. 24 (AP) -- An appeal by Gov. Orville Freeman for the rehiring of strikers replaced by non-union workers at the Wilson Co. plant in Albert Lea, Minn., failed to win any new company pledges today.
The French liner Liberte arrived here last night almost twelve hours late after a stormy trans-Atlantic crossing.

The activities of the twelve players engaged in the United States chess championship tournament for the Lessing J. Rosenwald trophy came to a halt at the Manhattan Chess Club early yesterday morning and the long holiday rest was welcomed by all.
Hanukkah, the Festival of Lights, will be ushered in tonight by the Jewish people here and the world over, and will be celebrated for eight days.
HOUSTON, Dec. 24 (AP) -- Coach Ben Schwartzwalder of Syracuse put in some new tricks for Texas today.
SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 24 -- Rae F. Watts of Portland, Ore., was engaged today to direct the modernization of waterfront facilities and increase the volume of cargo moving across San Francisco docks.

BRANDIED or spiced fruits add a touch of festivity to holiday meats, snacks or salad plates. The following recipes, based upon the use of canned apricots and pineapple, are quick to prepare and reasonable in cost. Both have a better flavor if refrigerated for a day or two before serving.

Charges of "college faculty payola" leveled by a Long Island banker against two New York University professors amount to an attack on academic freedom, the managing director of the Savings Banks Association of he State of New York said yesterday.
Randolph Phillips' five-year suit against the management of the Alleghany Corporation was settled yesterday, to all intents and purposes, in Federal District Court here.

ROME, Dec. 24 -- Heavy rainstorms drenched last-minute Christmas shoppers almost everywhere in Italy. Moistureladen warm winds from the south sent the temperature up to 60 degrees and opened the floodgates of the skies.

Martyn Green, the British actor, who lost a leg in an elevator accident seven weeks ago, left Knickerbocker Hospital yesterday and moved on crutches into a surprise party. They were all downstairs waiting for him -- friends, actors, photographers and his pet cocker, Gimlet.
LONDON, Dec. 24 (AP). -- Sir Winston Churchill has fought off a new bout of illness, a source close to the family said tonight.

A snow-shovel brigade of New York Giants pushed the Yankee Stadium portion of White Christmas to the sidelines yesterday so that the full squad could put in a much needed session of blocking, passing and punting.
NAHA, Okinawa, Dec. 24 (UPI) -- A New York fireman - turned - missionary is bringing the Christmas spirit to poverty-stricken villagers on tiny Miyako Island in the southern Ryukyus, south of Japan.
FORT WORTH, Tex., Dec. 24 (AP) -- A private plane, groping for landing in a fog, crashed in a woods near here today. Three Dallas construction men aboard were killed.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 24 -- A special appellate division of the Interstate Commerce Commission rejected opposition from a stockholder of the Alleghany Corporation today and permitted the holding company to refund $15,000,000 in notes.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 24 (AP) -- The Surety Association of America has approved a new form of bond designed to meet the requirements of the new labor law.

The Federal Home Loan Bank Board reports that individuals own an "impressive" $291,000,000,000 in savings accounts, life insurance and Government savings bonds, at latest count which covers the quarter ended on Sept. 30.

Parking will be forbidden again today on sections of 120 streets designated by the Department of Sanitation. On all other roads the alternate-side parking regulations will again be suspended for the day.

TRENTON, Dec. 24 -- Legislative leaders joined New Jersey's Congressional delegation and other state and county officials today in a campaign to establish a new jet-age airport in the pine barrens of Burlington County.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 24 (AP) -- The Interstate Commerce Commission today granted an application of the New York, Susquehanna and Western Railroad Company for a Government repayment guarantee on a privately negotiated bank loan of $300,000.

PARIS, Dec. 24 -- Although calm was reported today to have been restored to Martinique, a spokesman for the French Government said that police reinforcements had been flown to the West Indies island from Guadeloupe.

The Harnischfeger Corporation and its consolidated subsidiaries had a sharp rise in sales and earnings in the fiscal year ended on Oct. 31. LONDON, Dec. 24 -- Iain Macleod, Colonial Secretary, returned tonight from a fortnight's tour of Africa. He said th enext two months would be of great importance to Britain's East African territories.
HOLLYWOOD, Dec. 24 (AP) -- Edmund Goulding, film director, died of a heart ailment in Cedars of Lebanon Hospital today. He was 68 years old.

PARIS, Dec. 24 -- Pierre de Gaulle, brother of President Charles de Gaulle, was named a grand officer of the Legion of Honor today as he lay ill in the American Hospital in the Paris suburb of Neuilly.

The 1959-60 appeal for New York's Neediest Cases continues this Christmas Day. The 100 cases of the city's most destitute, lonely and poverty-stricken families were chosen from the files of eight charitable organizations cooperating in The New York Times' appeal.

Check transactions in the twenty-six major cities of the country reached a record $28,986,134,000, in the week ended on Wednesday, Dun Bradstreet, Inc., reported yesterday. WASHINGTON, Dec. 24 -- Rail and truck loadings of freight dipped again last week. Declining loadings are normal for this time of year. ELISABETHVILLE, Belgian Congo, Dec. 24 (Reuters) -- King Baudouin, continuing his two-week study and information tour in the Congo, received delegations of political parties here today.

One of the pleasant duties of Christmas morning, year after year, is to report on our stewardship of The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund, to thank those who have given so generously, according to their means, in large measure or small.
The Coast Guard, patrolling the waters from Maine to the Aleutians and from Puerto Rico to Guam, has added a new search and rescue plane to its fleet.

It is probable that not one American in ten thousand has ever heard of the lush little tropic city where Dag Hammarskjold, Secretary General of the United Nations, is spending Christmas today. It is Conakry, capital of the year-old Republic of Guinea on the West African coast; and a spot less likely to have the Christmas trimmings of ice and snow and fir trees of Mr. Hammarskjold's native Sweden could hardly be imagined.
The network of direct wires connecting the nation's bond houses were loaded yesterday with Christmas greetings instead of bid and asked quotations.
The first single-channel telephone system linking the bridges of two vessels was tested Wednesday in the Delaware River off Marcus Hook, Pa. It is designed to help prevent collisions.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 24 -- The United States and the Soviet Union will resume negotiations here Jan. 11 for a settlement of Moscow's World War II lend-lease debt, the State Department announced today.
Mayor Wagner said yesterday that he did not intend "at this point" to reappoint Magistrate Robert F. Mahoney, whose present term expires next Thursday.
Prices of potato futures moved up yesterday on the New York Mercantile Exchange. Volume was strong.
Differences between the Pentagon and the State Department about United States policy on Panama will soon be laid on the President's desk for settlement.

In a news item in your Dec. 9 issue reference is made to the resignation of James H. Case Jr. as president of Bard College. In this dispatch the statement was made that President Case resigned over a matter of faculty salaries.
BONN, Germany, Dec. 24 -- A German who has been living in the United States for four months has concluded from his experiences that Germans could learn much from Americans.
Two store managers for the Times Square Stores Corporation were robbed of receipts totaling $10,200 in cash and checks last night by armed men in Staten Island and Queens.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 24 -- Maj. Gen. William Everett Potter, Governor of the Panama Canal Zone and ex-officio president of the Panama Canal Company since April, 1956, is on the side of those who have argued the canal's importance to the United States.
CLEVELAND, Dec. 24 (AP) -- A Cleveland group began a Kennedy for President drive today with the blessing of the Cuyahoga County Democratic organization.

While on the question of segregating veterans in relation to the autonomy of American Legion posts as it pertains to the 40 and 8 Negro issue, might we not also give thought to correcting the practice of segregating veteran organizations according to ethnic or religious groups?
WASHINGTON, Dec. 24 (AP) -- President Eisenhower today appointed John J. Muccio, now Ambassador to Iceland, to be Ambassador to Guatemala.

A food exhibition with a carnival-like atmosphere will open to the public at 1 P. M. tomorrow on the ground floor of the New York Coliseum. It will include a tea pavilion, a simulated German beer garden and assorted demonstrations of strudel-making, flaming desserts and electronic cookery.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 24 (UPI) Harmon Killebrew, the slugging half of the Washington Senators' "million-dollar duo," came to terms today on a 1960 contract. The contract calls for between $22,000 and $25,000 -- well over double his last year's salary.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 24 (AP) -- The Securities and Exchange Commission said today it would hold a hearing here Dec. 30 to determine whether a stock registration statement filed by Skiatron Electronics and Television Corporation was false and misleading.

To celebrate Christmas at home is the most natural thing in the world -- except when you have neither home nor homeland in which to celebrate. And when that is the case, it can be about the most tragic thing one experiences in the world.
The American Rug and Carpet Company of New York has leased space for new quarters in the Textile Building, 295 Fifth Avenue, at Thirtieth Street.
Mayor Wagner gave his approval yesterday to Governor Rockefeller's program to fight juvenile crime.

Science has reached the point where, instead of fighting a rear-guard action by filling and pulling teeth, it can make a frontal assault on the cause of tooth decay. This is the view of Dr. Reidar F. Sognnaes, acting dean of the Harvard School of Dental Medicine.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 24 (AP) -- The National Science Foundation reported today that substantial increases had been made during the last six years in the nation's financial outlays for research and development. The Federal Government provided most of the funds.
Three new films will open here today.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 24 (UPI) -- Two members of Congress called today for an evaluation of the International Cooperation Administration's evaluation program.
LONDON, Dec. 24 (AP) -- Dr. Barbara Moore, a soberly plodding apparition amongst cheering Christmas Eve revelers, completed her walk from Edinburgh tonight and landed in a hospital.
BAGHDAD, Iraq, Dec. 24 (Reuters) -- Premier Abdul Karim Kassim was reported today to have accused Iranian "imperialism" of inciting aggression against Iraq.

BONN, Germany, Dec. 24 -- The facades of some tall apartment buildings in West Berlin and West German cities were dappled with yellow light from candles tonight.
MOUNT KISCO, N. Y., Dec. 24 -- Funds contributed by the public for the victims of an automobile crash here on Nov. 20 reached $26,280 today.
Ceramic mosaic tile, a wonder-child of the building industry, is expected to account for the lion's share of all expenditures for ceramic tile in 1960.

The Times has rendered a service to its readers in publishing Abe Rosenthal's five articles on Poland. The very fullness of his coverage, however, overshadows certain basic facts.

Norman Rothschild, 41-year-old Syracuse boxing promoter, was summoned yesterday to appear before the State Athletic Commission on Jan. 12 to show cause why his licenses as a matchmaker and promoter should not be revoked.
Reflecting the 54 per cent increase in sales of Foote Bros. Gear and Machine Corporation in the fiscal year ended on Oct. 31, earnings rose sharply over those of a year before.
MANSFIELD, England, Dec. 24 (AP) -- One of Britain's oldest soccer boot manufacturers is so disgruntled with fashion changes that he has decided to close.

KANPUR, India, Dec. 24 (Reuters) -- Jasu Patel and Polly Umrigar spun out Australia today as India gained its first victory over the Australians since the countries began test cricket meetings in 1947.
Unexpected scientific findings have eliminated cosmic rays from the hazards to be faced by the seven United States astronauts who will take their first tentative step into space next year.

JERUSALEM (Israeli Sector), Friday, Dec. 25 -- Church bells rang out in near-by Bethlehem last night to celebrate the arrival of another Christmas. Stars shone brightly from a clear sky as Christians from many lands thronged into Manger Square before the ancient basilica built over the grotto revered as the birthplace of Jesus.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 24 (AP) -- The United States District Court of Appeals ruled today that Lucien Coudie, a 27-year-old French chef, could prepare his esteemed souffles in the Cordon Bleu restaurant here.

THE ancient art of storytelling is being revived today with renewed vigor and interest. The value of a good story well told is now recognized as more far-reaching than the mere fun which results from a whimsical bit of "yarn spinning."

With gratitude for dangers past and with new confidence in the future, free Europe has put aside its many unsolved problems for the moment to count its blessings and to enjoy the merriest Christmas it has had since the end of the war. In every city, town and hamlet this side of the Iron Curtain, the lights are brighter, the gifts under the Christmas trees more plentiful, the festive boards more abundant.
LOS ANGELES, Dec. 24 -- Sunshine - conscious California rejoiced today over the most welcome of "Christmas presents" -- a rain storm that drenched virtually all the thousand-mile length of the state.
VIENNA, Dec. 24 (AP) -- Italy informed Austria today that she had barred three Tyrolean politicians from entering Italy.
Last night's performance of "Faust" at the Metropolitan Opera had three changes of cast -- Nicolai Gedda in the title role, George London as Mephistopheles and Rosalind Elias as Siebel.

JERSEY CITY, Dec. 24 -- Police Chief Michael Cusack announced his intention today to retire in a week. Several months ago Mrl. Cusack successfully resisted efforts by the city's Public Saftey Director to force his retirement.
Five thousand train riders, many of them bound for Christmas reunions, were delayed as much as eighty minutes yesterday when New York Central train operations on the Harlem Division were halted.
Americans throughout the country and the world are in the midst of observing the traditional Christmas holiday today.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 24 (AP) -- Delegations were named by President Eisenhower today to represent him and the United States at ceremonies in two African countries.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 24 (AP) -- The National Labor Relations Board reported today that Gulf Coast longshoremen had turned down a "last offer" from employers. But the vote apparently will be meaningless because a tentative settlement has been negotiated since the balloting.

The Biscayne Apartments at 102-25 Sixty-seventh Road, Forest Hills, Queens, and the Gramercy Apartments at 99-60 Sixty-fourth Avenue, in the same community, have been purchased by Hanover Associates, Inc., in association with Arthur G. Cohen and Edward Gettinger, investors.
Thousands of New York churchgoers heralded the Nativity last night in solemn midnight masses, at candlelight services and by reverent moments of devout prayer and music.

SHORT HILLS, N. J., Dec. 24 -- With the coming of winter and the prospects of snow, Mrs. John D. Bell 3d of 66 Canoe Brook Road gives more than casual interest to weather reports.

SAN JOSE, Costa Rica, Dec. 24 (AP) -- Striking banana workers were reported today to be in complete control of the port of Golfito on the Pacific coast. The reports said strikers were stopping pedestrians to ask for identification and to search for arms.

LONDON, Dec. 24 -- Industrial shares continued their record-making advance in the stock market here today despite the usually depressing influences of end-of-the-week trading and of the bookkeeping account.
Chicago, Dec. 24 (AP) -- Grain futures dealers did little more than even up commitments for the Christmas weekend in today's transactions on the Board of Trade. Prices ranged from firm to weak.

A four-alarm fire roared through a five-story furniture company building on the lower East Side early today. About seventy-five persons were evacuated from a near-by tenement because of the heavy smoke pouring out of the burning building.

BALTIMORE, Dec. 24 -- If the Giants have any clear advantage over the Colts for Sunday's pro football play-off at Memorial Stadium, it is in kicking. Everybody in the Baltimore stable -- Hosses, Steeds or whatever nickname one prefers for the defending champions -- concede that.

A petition bearing the signatures of 1,500 residents who favor the Riverside-Amsterdam slum clearance project was presented yesterday to Dr. Samuel Belkin, president of the Yeshiva University Graduate Center. The university plans to build a campus in the upper West Side area.

Andy Robustelli, star end of the New York Giants, may be doing his defensive master-minding from the sidelines next season.

HAVANA, Dec. 24 -- Cuba enthusiastically celebrated the holiday season today. People gathered for the traditional "noche buena" fiesta after midnight mass and to cheer the revolution, which on Jan. 1 will mark the first anniversary of its rule.

Loans to business by fifteen large New York City banks declined $6,000,000 in the week ended on Wednesday, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday. A decline in business borrowing is usual after the quarterly Federal tax payment dates.

William Saroyan generally extols lofty ideals in his plays. But in "Settled Out of Court," he has switched to a more realistic attitude. He has turned out a melodrama, based on the book of the same name by Henry Cecil (nom de plume for a British jurist). The book is to be issued Jan. 6 by Harper.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 24 -- Imports rose 7 per cent in November, about half as much as they fell in October. The basic trend of imports remains as it has been since late summer, leveling off at record high levels after a year-long rise.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 24 (AP) -- James V. Bennett, director of the Federal Prison Bureau, used his year-end report today to describe what Federal prisoners have been doing in the last few weeks to help others.
The expert who was hired by the City Housing Authority eight months ago to establish an over-all social work program has quit in disgust.

PARIS, Dec. 24 (Reuters) -- The Government announced today an end to quota restrictions on a wide range of imports from North America and the nations of the Organization for European Economic Cooperation (O. E. E. C.).

They sent it to the fund for New York's Neediest Cases, asking that the money be used to help Case 55, a mother doomed by cancer and her 7-year-old daughter.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 24 (AP) -- A record world wool production of 5,545,000,000 pounds is estimated for 1959, the United States Department of Agriculture said today.

Advanced training in physical medicine and rehabilitation will be received by five foreign physicians in the United States in 1960 under fellowships of the World Rehabilitation Fund, it was announced yesterday by the fund president, Dr. Howard A. Rusk.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 24 (AP) -- The Russians were pictured in a technical report today as seeing possibilities of improved radio, television and telephone communications as a result of advances in the knowledge of atmospherics.

PLATTSBURGH, N. Y., Dec. 24 -- A State Supreme Court justice here dismissed yesterday a renewed move for the release of Joseph (Socks) Lanza, labor extortionist, from Clinton State Prison at Dannemora.

ROME, Friday, Dec. 25 (AP) -- Pope John XXIII led Roman Catholics today in the religious observance of Christmas. Recalling the example set by his own parents, he said a strong family life based on love was needed to bring world peace.

Nearly 10,000,000 Methodists in the United States will commemorate beginning tomorrow the 175th anniversary of the founding of their church. Thirty-nine thousand local congregations over the country will hold special celebrations either tomorrow or on Jan. 3.

The thirty-seven-year leasehold on the building t 435 Fifth Avenue, between Thirty-eighth and Thirty-ninth Streets, has been sold by the Beekman Operating Company, Milton Sass, vice president, to an investing client of Gettinger Gettinger, lawyers.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Dec. 25 -- A reappraisal of Yugoslavia's position in the light of a possible relaxation of tension between East and West is now under way in Belgrade. One result could be closer relations with the Western European nations.

After a day of rest, the twelve competitors in the United States chess championship will resume play at the Manhattan Chess Club today. Five of the six games in the sixth round will start at 2 P. M. Samuel Reshevsky's sixth-round match with Robert Byrne is scheduled to begin at 7 P. M.
DETROIT, Dec. 25 (UPI) -Brian Cullen scored two goals just sixteen seconds apart in the final period tonight to lead the New York Rangers to a 5-2 victory over the Detroit Red Wings.

THE open-land hunting seasons in this part of the world are about over now and the preserve seasons are really beginning. So a defense of shooting preserves may not be out of place, especially since everything said about them here has not always been complimentary.

A non-stop Paris to New York record was claimed yesterday by Pan American Flight 115, Capt. Edward F. Sommers commanding. The plane landed here at 7:37 P. M. after covering the 3,700 statute miles in seven hours, ten minutes.

PAINESVILLE, Ohio, Dec. 25 (AP) -- Mrs. Charles R. Clark, whose husband was killed last night by a sniper's bullet, told the police today that she had had a love affair with a truck driver. The man was held in connection with the shooting.

TEMPE, Ariz., Dec. 28 (UPI) -- The National all-stars, who have so much talent that Bill Burrell and Richie Lucas, two all-America selections, are defensive specialists, are 12-point favorites to whip the Southwest all-stars in tomorrow's second annual Copper Bowl football game.

How far will Communist China press its border claims against India? This question troubles all who are aware of the explosive potentialities in the current dispute between the planet's most populous nations. It becomes particularly insistent in the light of the latest reports about the massing of Chinese Communist troops near the Indian border and the building of airports and other military installations on the Chinese side of the line.

To have been Viceroy of India, Secretary of State for Foreign Affairs and Ambassador to the United States in wartime was an extraordinary record. This was without counting other high government posts stretching over fifty years.

For science, 1959 was largely a year of preparation for the launching of new ventures to probe deeper into the great unknowns of nature. Lower prices at the cost of quality have never tempted Charles W. Lubin, president of Kitchens of Sara Lee, Inc., Chicago-based food company.

I agree with W. A. Darlington in The Times of Dec. 13 that Brendan Behan's "The Hostage" has no real story line. What it has by way of plot is mainly a framework for irreverent and amusing iconoclasms. However, Shelagh Delaney's "A Taste of Honey" does not belong in this plotless category.
IN connection with Margaret Leech's "In the Days of McKinley" may I note two points in the treatment of matters relating to American Catholic churchmen which are in need of some correction?

THE review of Vol. I of "The Papers of Benjamin Franklin," edited by Leonard W. Labaree and Whitfield J. Bell, recalls the suggestion I made four years ago at the time of the celebration of Franklin's 250th anniversary, that we should teach that there was a "Franklin Era," to be ranked with an "Elizabethan" or "Periclean," or any other great period.

Hulan E. Jack, the Democratic Borough President of Manhattan, has been known as a jovial, outgoing man, with a twinkling eye, a quick wit and a ready answer of phrase or speech length for any occasion. But last week he was tight-lipped and subdued, his usual volubility gone, and he was letting his lawyer do his talking for him.

The cost of pensions will rise substantially in 1960, with an increase of 20 per cent in Social Security taxes a prime factor. Employers and employes will share this increase, but higher costs for increased benefits under private pension programs will be borne mostly by management.
A Senate investigation on railroad rate procedures on long-haul traffic where shipping competition exists may be started when Congress reconvenes.

Edmund L. Grimes, chairman of the Commercial Credit Company, has been elected chairman of the Textile Banking Company, a factoring subsidiary. William R. White, vice president of the Morgan Guaranty Trust Company, was elected a director of Textile Banking.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 26 (UPI) -- Senator Harry F. Byrd and Secretary of Commerce Frederick H. Mueller pledged mutual aid today to put the Federal interstate highway building program back on a "pay-as-you-go" basis.

Steel output in the Cleveland-Lorain district soared to an historic high of 99 per cent of rated capacity in the week ended Dec. 19, indicating a physical volume of more than 150,000 tons. Production exceeded the previous peak, reached last spring, by 1 per cent.

WITH very little fanfare, something wonderful has appeared at the Metropolitan Museum. This is a loan exhibition of ancient art, comprising some 300 objects owned by New York private collectors, a show that no one who lives by the eye or thrills to the sense of history will wish to miss.
PARTICULAR attention is being paid these days by a group of executives of the news and public-affairs department of the National Broadcasting Company to developments in Cuba.

MEDARDO ROSSO (1858-1928), prophetic Italian sculptor whose work is having its initial showing in America at the Peridot Gallery, is considered the first artist to have translated the principles of Impressionism into sculpture.

THE Fifities were a time of optimism and expansion. Energies consumed by the war and its immediate aftermath in the Forties could be channeled into artistic matters. Thoughtful Americans realized that it was not enough to provide people with cars, electrical appliances, pretested, preshrunk and predigested goods and the other miracles of a booming, technically advanced, assembly - line economy, and they moved to enrich opportunities for nourishment of the mind and spirit.

THE figure of George Armstrong Custer is certainly one of the most flamboyant as well as controversial in American history. Even before he died at the hands of the charging Sioux in 1876 at the Little Big Horn, he was celebrated; and this as much because he was an ebullient show-off and self-publicizer as because of his military exploits, spectacular as they were.
Joseph P. Routh, chairman and president of the Pittston Company, is a man who makes friends easily, in addition to being a man who knows one lump of coal from another, as so many people do not.
Dacron filaments now can be crimped uniformly for so-called textured yarns, it was announced recently by the Deering Milliken Research Corporation.
HARTFORD, Dec. 26 -- The Connecticut Democratic Central Committee will meet here Tuesday night to confirm June 17 and 18 as the dates for the state party convention.
The leadership of the Transport Workers Union voted yesterday to recommend a New Year's Day strike on New York's private and public transit lines to support demands for a wage rise.
Norway's merchant marine has proved relatively depression-proof.
BALTIMORE, Dec. 26 -- Charlie Conerly did it once, but he doesn't recommend it as standard operating procedure. He completed a touchdown pass while flat on his back.

PERHAPS it is perilous to say this, but it is beginning to look as though the quality of motion pictures is definitely on the rise. The courage to venture this statement comes from a close perusal of our reports on all the 1959 pictures in search of the traditional ten best of the year.

LONDON, Dec. 26 -- Sea captains can now go to school so that they can recognize in advance the conditions that created the situation that led to the disastrous collision between the Stockholm and the Andrea Doria in 1956. Both those liners were being navigated on radar, and the inquiry after the collison disclosed that both ships could see each other on the radar sets.

The aptitudes and abilities of America's high school students will be tabulated during the 1960 population census to be taken this spring. A scientifically selected sample of half a million pupils throughout the nation will be given a two-day series of examinations by "Project TALENT" in March.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 26 -- Leading Democrats were publicly canny but privately pleased tonight by Governor Rockefeller's decision not to seek the Republican Presidential nomination.

From a recent report in your esteemed pages, I gather that our Secretary of the Treasury has successfully opposed appointment of Jean Monnet to a mission of outstanding international bankers going to India and Pakistan to study their basic economic problems.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 26 -- Secretary of Labor James P. Mitchell and Representative Charles A. Halleck emerged tonight as the two most talked of possibilities for the Republican Vice - Presidential nomination.

THE millions of motorists who use the New York Thruway will receive a belated Christmas present. Effective next Friday, gasoline sold on the 553-mile route will drop 10 per cent in price and procedures for handling disabled vehicles will be drastically revised.

Holiday influences affected the stock market last week. Trading was restricted to four days by the Christmas closing on Friday. Most of the activity was in the nature of year-end adjustments of accounts, with no marked trend manifested.
