A BURST of enthusiastic sight-seeing probably marks the beginning of an overseas sojourn for wives of our servicemen stationed abroad. But, after the first flush of enthusiasm is over, how do they occupy their spare time? The wiser ones no doubt take the unique opportunity to go more deeply into the culture of other lands.
WHEN the fashions of the Fifties are chronicled at Brooklyn Museum, they will go down in terms of a rangy girl named Lauren Becall.
NEW DELHI, India, Dec. 27 -- Prince Norodom Sihanouk, Premier of Cambodia, expressed today his Government's "sympathy" to India in her border troubles with Communist China.

PURCHASE, N. Y., Dec. 27 -- Governor Rockefeller, after a five-hour stop-over at his home in near-by Pocantico Hills, left here in his private plane this afternoon to return to Albany and "continue my job as Governor.''
ALBANY, Dec. 27 -- Governor Rockefeller returned to the capital tonight, his Presidential ambitions laid aside, to tackle some of the state's weighty problems.

PITTSBURGH, Dec. 27 (AP) -- Representative James G. Fulton, Republican of Pennsylvania, said today that although Governor Rockefeller had withdrawn from the Republican Presidential race he had left the way clear for a draft-Rockefeller movement.
Negro college fraternities were pictured yesterday by Herbert E. Tucker Jr., assistant attorney general of Massachusetts, as having reached a crossroads in their own integration policies.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 27 (AP) -- It's becoming socially correct for the wives of upperincome husbands to take jobs, a Labor Department economist reported today.

Back in 1948 Nikita Khrushchev complained bitterly about a "little worm" which he had detected in the "soul" of Soviet peasants. That "little worm," be explained, was "the tendency toward private property * * * in the conscience of the collective farm peasantry." The results of the latest meeting of the Soviet Communist party's Central Committee which ended last week-end suggest that the "little worm" is still giving Premier Khrushchev trouble.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 27 (UPI) -- Senator Thruston B. Morton, chairman of the Republican National Committee, announced today the speaking assignments for nine Cabinet officers at G. O. P. fund-raising meetings to be held across the nation on Jan. 27.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 27 -- The Justice Department's report on television will probably be delivered to President Eisenhower this week, providing a late and probably undesired Christmas gift for the industry and its regulator, the Federal Communications Commission.

The oldest show ever presented in New York once more started a short run on Saturday night. It was the New York Pro Musica's presentation of "The Play of Daniel," the twelfth-century music-drama, and it was given at the Chapel of the Intercession of Trinity Parish.
The 19-year-old son of a West German Army officer was arrested in Brooklyn early yesterday and charged with attempting to rape the wife of a policeman.
MINNEAPOLIS, Dec. 27 (AP) -- The Minneapolis Lakers made it two straight victories over Detroit today, beating the Pistons, 119 -- 109, in a televised National Basketball Association game.
PLATTSBURG, N. Y., Dec. 27 (AP) -- Signor Goretsch of the Roosevelt Field Skating Club of New York City captured the championship of the Plattsburgh-Lake Champlain outdoor speed skating meet today.
CHICAGO, Dec. 27 -- Trappist monks who live largely on milk and eggs have fewer heart attacks and other manifestations of coronary disease than Benedictine monks whose diet is "normal."
TEHERAN, Iran, Dec. 27 -- Officials appeared today to be soft-pedaling the martial aspects of Iran's border dispute with Iraq.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 27 -President Eisenhower attended church this morning before flying to Augusta, Ga.

TANGIER, Morocco, Dec. 27 (AP) -- The body of a girl found sewn in a gunny sack and hidden in the underbrush of a forest near Tangier has been identified as that of Helen Mueller, a 19-year-old tourist from New York, the Tangier police said today.

DID anyone give you a book for Christmas you had already read or one you were grimly determined not to read? If so, when you go to your favorite bookshop this week in hope of making an exchange you might consider "Living Japan: The Land, the People and Their Changing World," by Donald Keene.

BALTIMORE, Dec. 27 -- With a conceded Republican championship tucked in his pocket, a smiling, relaxed Vice President Richard M. Nixon watched the Baltimore Colts pulverize the New York Giants for the professional football championship.
PARIS, Dec. 27 (Reuters) -- Twelve hundred children will try out France's new "heavy" franc tomorrow -- four days before it goes into circulation -- to show adults how easy it is to use it.
CALCUTTA, India, Dec. 20 -- A lot of life remains in the Indian Communist party here.
Details of what the Board of Education calls its "austerity" school building program for 1960 were announced yesterday.

European maritime nations are renewing protests to Brazil on her alleged shipping discrimination policies, according to a report by the Maritime Transport Committee of the Organization for European Economic Cooperation.
BALTIMORE, Dec. 27 (UPI) -- Tom Landry, a defensive coach for the New York Giants for the past six seasons, has worked his last game for the National Football League club, it was learned today.
Bobby Fischer and Samuel Reshevsky, the favorites in the United States championship, won seventh-round games last night at the Marshall Chess Club.
l.eeord smle fo the eighth .c,L_ve year and a $3,677,increase in earnings were features of the annual report f the United States Borax and Chemical Corporation, released today.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, Monday, Dec. 28 -- Indonesia formally accused an American flier today of aiding "enemies of the state" in the spring of 1958 and of carrying out a bombing raid that killed seventeen members of the Indonesian armed forces and wounded six others.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 27 (UPI) -- The American Automobile Association said today that the Administration planned to ask Congress next month for an additional rise in Federal gasoline taxes of a half-cent a gallon. An increase of a penny a gallon was voted last session.
IN Shakespeare, those who cannot walk must be cautious about running. If they cannot speak poetry they should leave "The Tempest" alone.
Music in Our Time opened its season Saturday night at the Lexington Avenue Young Men's and Young Women's Hebrew Association and batted .500 on its first program.
May I add yet another word of protest against the IRT public-address system?
Disappointment over the level of 1959 Soviet farm production is indicated in the decisions of the Communist party Central Committee meeting made public in Moscow last week-end.

OTTAWA, Dec. 27 -- Canada's economy is sound and should continue to expand substantially in 1960, Gordon Churchill, Minister of Trade and Commerce, reported today in his annual report to the nation. The value of all goods and services, or the gross national product, he said, had risen by 7 per cent from $32,500,000,000 in 1958.
A fight involving seven youths in the Bronx early yesterday morning led to the stabbing of one of them. A policeman who arrested three of the youths was hurt.
Contracts awarded for new construction work of all types throughout the country last month amounted to $2,372,826,000, a decline of about $220,000,000 from November, 1958.

AUGUSTA, Ga., Dec. 27 -President Eisenhower flew here from Washington today to begin a scheduled nine-day holiday of golf and relaxation preparatory to the Congressional session and the pressing problems of foreign affairs.
The writer of the following letter is the author of "Le Mouvement Poujade" and of numerous articles on France. He is Associate Professor of Government at Harvard.
BONN, Germany, Dec. 27 -- The Cologne police announced new arrests tonight in the Christmas Eve defacing of a synagogue.
MOSCOW, Dec. 27 -- The Soviet press hinted today that Premier Khrushchev would insist on talking about his total disarmament plan at the East-West summit meeting.

A request by the recently organized Society of Stage Directors and Choreographers for contract negotiations with the League of New York Theatres has been rejected. The League represents Broadway producers and theatre owners.

Cotton prices held within a narrow trading range last week in rather limited dealings. At the end of trading on Thursday active futures contracts on the New York Cotton Exchange were up 7 to down 6 points from the previous week's close.

The Rev. Dr. Roswell P. Barnes, American secretary for the World Council of Churches, reported yesterday that Protestantism, Roman Catholicism and Eastern Orthodoxy "now recognize the urgency of better mutual understanding."
Obviously, a cheaper way to buy is to avoid the usual salesmen's commissions.
A blizzard in the Plains States and freezing rain in upstate New York created traffic hazards yesterday as the nation's holiday count of traffic fatalities rose close to 500.

Governor Rockefeller's decision to withdraw from the 1960 Presidential race represented the dominance of the view among some of his advisers that the odds against winning the Republican nomination were too great.
LONDON, Dec. 27 -- Ernest Marples, Britain's energetic Minister of Transport, will visit the United States this week in search of new ideas for relieving Britain's ever-increasing traffic congestion.
Tough teen-age boys who used to scorn dancing classes as square have been flocking to schools lately to learn the latest rock 'n' roll gyrations.

This country's business cycle is still on the way up, with a turning point a year to a year and a half in the future, according to a panel of fifteen nationally known economists taking part in the National Industrial Conference Board's annual economic forum.

Count Geza Esterhazy, 70-year-old exiled member of the Austro-Hungarian nobility, whose body was found Saturday in the East River, apparently died of submersion, an autopsy at Jacobi Hospital showed yesterday.
PEIPING, Nov. 30 -- More than 40,000,000 Chinese are at work on their country's most ambitious project -- harnessing and distributing the waters of the nation's 1,600 main rivers.
RIO DE JANEIRO, Dec. 26 -- President Eisenhower's world tour has aroused demands in Latin America that the southern part of this hemisphere be added to the President's 1960 travels.

Fannie Hurst, the author, told a New York Times Youth Forum yesterday that 'it is bitterly true that we just do not know how to read as a nation." She said it was "depressing" to a writer to learn from the young panelists that they devoted more time to television than to books.

THE New York Philharmonic is having a week's Christmas vacation, but yesterday afternoon Carnegie Hall was as jammed as if the orchestra had been playing there. The artist who took the Philharmonic's accustomed place was David Oistrakh, the Soviet violinist, who, after a four-year interval, is making his second United States tour.
ALBANY, Dec. 27 -- Governor Rockefeller today appointed former Assemblyman Lewis W. Olliffe of Brooklyn to the State Supreme Court bench in the Second Judicial District.

The United Aircraft Corporation is expanding its European interests. Through its Hamilton Standard division, it has completed negotiations leading to the purchase of a 50 per cent interest in Microtechnica, Inc., of Italy. Details of the transaction were not disclosed in the week-end announcement.
LONDON, Dec. 27 -- The Stock Exchange soared upward last week on the news that the Government intended to give trustees a vastly wider power of investment.

IN newspaper reports of bridge hands there are often cases in which an expert player could have made his contract, but did not. The reader, seeing all four hands, may easily discern the winning play and may attribute the expert's failure to ignorance.

Now that the new Nigerian Cabinet has been formed following the recent election, it looks very much like the last one. The Prime Minister, Abubukar Tafawa Balewa, is again heading a coalition government in which his own party -- the Moslem, conservative, British-inclined, Northern Peoples Congress -- again represents by far the strongest element in Parliament. At least half a dozen of the Prime Minister's former Cabinet colleagues are also continuing in office.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 27 -- Thousands of economists and statisticians gathered here today for their annual Christmas week skull practice. They practiced first on new studies of unemployment and stock market trends.

ALBERT LEA, Minn., Dec. 27 (AP) -- Striking employes of Wilson Co. heard a plea from their union chief today to avoid any violence. The meat packing concern will resume operations here tomorrow with nonunion workers, after a sixteen-day shutdown.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 27 -- The opposing philosophies of competition and regulation have rarely been more graphically illustrated than in a developing struggle between the Justice Department and the Federal Power Commission.
Media are preparing to close their books for the year with generally strong increases, compared with 1958 levels.

OAK RIDGE, Tenn., Dec. 27 -- Liquid-fuel reactors can be successful, according to Dr. Alvin M. Weinnberg, director of the Oak Ridge National Laboratory. He says that has been proved in the homogeneous reactor experiment for producing power at the laboratory.

Audrey Hepburn, who appeared in the title role of "The Nun's Story," and James Stewart, who headed the cast of "Anatomy of a Murder," were judged the outstanding motion picture stars of 1959 in the annual poll of professional film writers conducted by The Film Daily, trade journal.
The Rockefeller Foundation is spending beyond its income and dipping into its capital to finance its expanded programs in Latin America, Africa, the Middle East and Asia.

CHICAGO, Dec. 26 (AP) -- One brief burst of buying provided the margins by which the grain futures market finished the week in a steady to firm range.

MUTOTO STATION, Belgian Congo, Dec. 25 -- Twenty lepers of the Baluba tribe were among the patients attending a Christmas service in the Mutoto Leprosarium today. They were the only Baluba left in an area once strongly populated by this tribe.

STOWE, Vt., Dec. 27 -- Judging from the situation at the Mount Mansfield-Spruce Peak ski area here today, the Christmas vacation picture certainly has changed for Eastern prep school students in recent years.

This he defines as "the surging demand for the means to meet more adequately the essential requirements of daily life." These demands are especially evident in the less well developed nations, regardless of political and economic systems -- capitalist, Socialist or Communist.
In the wake of the season's first snowfall, large pieces of plastic that mark crosswalks in midtown Manhattan are being torn up.
The first ship flying the flag of Ghana sailed into the harbor yesterday.
This is basketball's festive week throughout the country. Seventeen collegiate tournaments begin today and six others, which opened last Saturday, move into their final rounds.

LEOPOLDVILLE, Belgian Congo, Dec. 27 (AP) -- Five African nationalist parties in the Belgian Congo have agreed to meet Belgian Government representatives Jan. 5 to discuss the Congo's future.

DETROIT, Dec. 27 (UPI) -The Montreal Canadiens scored two goals within a minute and eleven seconds and another on an open net tonight to hand the Red Wings a 3-1 loss and remain undefeated on Detroit ice for the thirteenth straight game.
The Metropolitan Community Methodist Church in Harlem played host yesterday to university students from Africa who are studying in New York and to student members of its congregation.

The New York Rangers set a club standard by getting three goals within forty-four seconds in the second period last night. But they ran out of gas and dropped a 6-3 decision to the Toronto Maple Leafs in a National Hockey League game at Madison Square Garden.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Dec. 27 -- On this long week-end movie making here was replaced by movie talk, with many of the haranguers convinced they are charting new courses in the industry.

Strauss' "Der Rosenkavalier," with Nicolai Gedda appearing as the Italian singer for the first time this season, will open the eleventh week of Metropolitan Opera next Monday.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 27 -- Judging from railroad merger negotiations under way and the apparent shift in the attitude at the Interstate Commerce Commission, 1960 should see a bumper crop of railroad mergers. Despite unrest on the labor front and regardless of the conclusions of numerous transportation studies, the present climate appears to be more suited to the merging and consolidating of railroads than at any time in the last thirty years.
Bil and Cora Baird's marionette theatre set up shop over the week-end in the renovated Hudson Theatre and, in a manner of speaking, the holiday show season for the youngsters is official.

Jussi Bjoerling sang a recital that drew a capacity audience, including stage seats, to Hunter College last night. The event was billed as a "concert extraordinary," which proved to be no exaggeration.

PITTSBURGH, Dec. 27 -- Some steel shipments were lost last week because of the Christmas holiday. While most open hearths and blast furnaces were in production during the holiday, most finishing mills were shut down.
JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, Dec. 27 -- Christmas season road accidents and crimes of violence in South Africa have exceeded all records. So far, 107 persons have been killed and 2,700 injured.

The Suez Canal has been in the news lately for two reasons. First, the United Arab Republic continued its policy of refusing passage to Israeli ships and cargoes, including cargoes carried in neutral bottoms and no longer owned by Israelis. Second, the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development announced in Washington a loan of $56,600,000 to U. A. R.'s Suez Canal Authority for the purpose of widening and deepening the waterway.

Stocks yesterday ran partly true to Wall Street's predictions of last week. The high-flying issues of 1959, the glamour stocks, were generally down as investors took profits that would fail in the 1960 tax year.

An executive in a Baltimore department store sent his second donation in a month to the fund for New York's Neediest Cases yesterday. He said his first contribution "just wasn't enough."

NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., Dec. 28 -- The Rutgers Research and Educational Foundation, established by Dr. Selman A. Waksman. Nobel Prize-winning scientist, has received more than $9,000,000 in income in its fourteen years of operation.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 28 -- The President's Board of Inquiry in the steel dispute found the knot tied tighter today than it had left it ten weeks ago and said that mediation looked futile now. Five apartment buildings in the Bronx have been purchased by Burton I. Goldberg, operator. The structures, each five stories high, are at 544 to 556 St. Paul's Place and at 1415 Fulton Avenue. They contain 128 apartments and four stores.

Arrangements are being made for the fifty-first annual dinner dance for the benefit of the Blue Ridge School of Virginia. Mrs. Charles Fullerton Hamrick, chairman, is being assisted by Mrs. John P. West.

BALTIMORE, Dec. 28 (AP) -- Reductions in round - trip coach fares between major Eastern cities and the Midwest will go into effect on Jan. 5, the Baltimore and Ohio Railroad announced today.

SOME of the finest theatre of the current season has been found on television, not Broadway. It has been presented on the Channel 13 project known as "The Play of the Week," which for set owners in New York has been an island of civilized viewing fare.

I was interested to read Oscar Vago's letter published Dec. 22 looking to a time when the nonsmoker would be free of the smell of tobacco smoke of one sort or another. It is unfortunate that the pressure to smoke is apparently so strong in the smoker that he cannot long live without it.
BERLIN, Dec. 28 -- Heinz Galinski, head of the Jewish community of West Berlin, criticized the West German Government today for tolerating the re-emergence of Nazis and neo-Nazi groups.

FOR a number of years Thomas Scherman and the Little Orchestra Society have celebrated each Christmas season with a performance of Berlioz' "L'Enfance du Christ." Last night at Carnegie Hall they turned to Handel's "Judas Maccabaeus," which recalls the triumph in Israel that is now observed by Jews as Hanukkah, and it is a good guess that another annual tradition has begun.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Dec. 28 -- A methodical middle-aged English couple, who are spending their Christmas holidays here making murder pay very nicely, today brushed off Sir Arthur Conan Doyle as a virtual amateur.
PARIS, Dec. 28 -- France is ready to consider a common air defense system in Western Europe, Foreign Minister Maurice Couve de Murville asserted today in a debate
DALLAS, Tex., Dec. 28 (UPI) -- The curtain was raised last night on the only public theatre designed by Frank Lloyd Wright.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 28 -- Representative Frank Thompson charged the State Department today with the "virtual exclusion of young people" in its cultural exchange program involving the theatre.
POSADAS, Argentina, Dec. 28 (UPI) -- Argentine border forces were reported to have clashed today with a Paraguayan Army patrol searching for rebel guerrillas along the Parana River.

"WILDLIFE IN AMERICA,"* by Peter Mathiessen, is a superb history of the other inhabitants with which we share this continent and the seas around it. The fact that Mr. Mathiessen is also an accomplished novelist gives his writing about scientific and historical matters the advantage of a sharp, luminous and uncluttered style.
Bobby Fischer, defending his title, scored his fifth victory of the United States championship tournament at the Marshall Chess Club last night.
DALLAS, Tex., Dec. 28 (AP) -- Phillip E. Fox, at times a sensational figure in the public affairs of both Texas and Georgia, died here of a heart attack yesterday. He was 72 year old.
The Welfare Department said yesterday that a decline in the number of relief cases had made it unnecessary to hire the 181 additional employes authorized in the 1959-60 executive budget.

The Dec. 24 paper brought the news of the death of two personalities whose passing will provoke much comment and rich recollections of their characters and careers. I refer to the death of Earl Halifax and the tragic accident which has deprived us of Charles Curtis of Boston.
CHICAGO, Dec. 28 (UPI) -- A gale-driven snowstorm swirling out of the West marooned hundreds of holiday travelers in Salina, Kan., and other Midwest cities today.

LEOPOLDVILLE, Belgian Congo, Dec. 28 -- King Baudouin arrived here today in the capital of the Belgian Congo. He was met by cheering crowds, but shouts of "Long live the King!" were drowned by a mass of Africans roaring: "Independence! Immediate independence!"
STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Dec. 28 (AP) -- Ingemar Johansson agreed today to defend his world heavyweight boxing title against Floyd Patterson, the former champion, in a June rematch in New York.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 28 (UPI) -- A substantial majority of the 200 economists attending a top-level conference here agreed today that the business boom would continue in 1960.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 28 (AP) -- United States cotton textile manufacturers appeared cool today to a compromise offer by Hong Kong garment manufacturers to set an expanded ceiling on cotton exports to the United States over the next three years.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 28 -- Governor Rockefeller's decision not to seek the Republican nomination for President, though it has made the choice of Vice President Nixon as certain as anything mundane can be, sowed a whole crop of new uncertainties.
WNTA-TV (Channel 13) and its "Play of the Week" may take credit this morning for another artistic accomplishment.
LIKE a non-objective mural, or Tabasco sauce, Mrs. Anna M. Rosenberg evokes neutral feelings in practically nobody.

CHRISTMAS is over, but that does not necessary bring gift-buying to a close. In fact, naturalized New Yorkers spending New Year's Day with friends may already be struggling with hostess gifts. This column is devoted to those guests with a depleted bank account who want to concentrate on gifts for the children of the house.
THE first pine needles have hardly dropped from the Christmas tree when the stream of New Yorkers begins to head South for warmer climes.
BOSTON, Dec. 28 (AP) -- The Boston Celtics extended their winning streak by defeating Minneapolis, 107 -- 104, with a fourth-period rally tonight at the Boston Garden.
ALBANY, Dec. 28 -- The state's farm leaders urged Governor Rockefeller today to consider financing local school budgets with sales or income taxes rather than through higher property taxes.
ALBANY, Dec. 28 -- Governor Rockefeller reaffirmed tonight his "final and irrevocable" opposition to accepting the Republican Vice-Presidential nomination.
The Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts, expected to be completed in 1963, will join the ranks of advertisers this week.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 28 -- The 6 per cent differential enjoyed by West Coast shipyards in bidding for contracts partly financed by the Government was challenged here today by Clarence G. Morse, chairman of the Federal Maritime Board.

Misinformation on the subject of fluoridation is being widely distributed by a self-appointed committee of misguided persons, none of whom are expert in the field of public health or preventive medicine.
BOSTON, Dec. 28 (UPI) -- Dick Kazmaier, a halfback on Princeton's undefeated 1951 team, was named today as the Ivy. League's player of the decade by a panel of twenty-one football writers.
General Sessions Judge John A. Mullen yesterday denied a motion to set aside the conviction of James J. Moran, a former Deputy Fire Commissioner.
RALEIGH, N. C., Dec. 28 -- A Protestant interracial group began to lay the groundwork today for the Episcopal Church's first Society for Racial Unity.
MADISON, Wis., Dec. 28 (AP) -- The 28-year-old son of a millionaire New York industrialist was given an unannounced Christmas Eve pardon by Gov. Gaylord Nelson, the executive office confirmed today.
PASADENA, Calif., Dec. 28 -- Twenty-four billion years was tentatively advanced today as the possible age of the Milky Way, the galaxy of which the sun is a member star.

That dark blue feeling with which Jim Lee Howell returned from Baltimore late Sunday had, with a night's sleep, changed to light blue when the head coach of the vanquished Giants awoke yesterday morning.
ONE of the most interesting commentaries on year-end drinks, at least the one known as wassail, was made by Julian Street in the recently published "Table Topics." (Alfred A. Knopf, 1959).

BORDEAUX, France, Dec. 28 (Reuters) -- Floodwaters from rivers in southwestern France, swollen by four days of torrential rains, have submerged thousands of acres of farmland and caused substantial damage to property.

"Complete confidence" that the majority of the nineteen new school projects slated for 1960 would be under contract during the new budget year was expressed yesterday by Charles J. Bensley. Mr. Bensley is chairman of the Board of Education's Committee on Building and Sites.
The One William Street Fund confirmed yesterday that it had been approached by "representatives of Managed Funds, Inc." who sought to sell their portfolio to the Lehman Brothers-managed mutual fund.

MOST women walk away from their jobs at five o'clock. Thirty-year-old Barbara Nagorski cannot detach herself so easily. Too many people are desperately dependent on what she can achieve in a working day.

Thomas R. Waring, editor of The News and Courier of Charleston, S. C., has denied that the newspaper "is editorially forsaking total segregation," as alleged in the annual report of the American Civil Liberties Union. The report was made public Dec. 14.
The Eastern College Athletic Conference's eighth annual Holiday Basketball Festival will have an all-Midwestern final.
Cotton futures moved 5 points (25 cents a bale) off to 7 points (35 cents) up yesterday on the New York Cotton Exchange. Trading was slow with the gains in the near and distant month.
LONDON, Dec. 28 (Reuters) -- Leeds beat Tottenham Hotspur, the leader of the English Soccer League's First Division, 4 -- 1, today in the top upset of a day of surprises.
Extensive alterations are planned for the twenty-one-story office building at 501 Fifth Avenue, southeast corner of Forty-second Street.
